text: This is a difficult book, in a lot of ways. The writing is positively Edwardian--some of the writing conventions used are not modern, at all; the book is really dystopian and deals in "big ideas." It's like this was written by Jules Verne, filtered through Kurt Vonnegut.It's about Mars, but it's also about class distinctions, and gender issues, and possibly about the end of the human race. All of the characters are adults with long, odd histories. The storylines are disjointed and very train-of-thought.Also, the writing itself is just strange: the characters talk in non-sequiturs; there is an odd amount of exposition; it takes half the book to get used to the author's writing style, which is like vignettes strung together, somewhat randomly.I'd recommend this, though--it will take a long-time to read, but it is good enough at creating the alternate-world-building that is the reason so many of us read science fiction, that I wanted to finish the book.  This is literature, worthy of being taken seriously.  It's the kind of thing I'd read on vacation--I kept picturing it as the sort of thing one would want to break up the monotony of the sort of endless beaches one finds in some parts of the tropics, when there is really time to think. Recommended.

These are great for organizing. They are also great if you're living in a house built before 1960--the closets seem to be much smaller in older houses.  I bought the six-pack of these for clothes--six of them will hold thirty pairs of underwear, forty pairs of socks, five pairs of bike shorts, ten bras, and five pairs of shorts. Basically, if you have space in a closet, with these, you can avoid having a chest of drawers. These are also better at the organization of small clothing pieces;I could never find this much, as fast, in a regular set of drawers.

These look great. They fit my Frigidaire Range. If you're looking for covers to fit a nineties or early aughties Frigidaire range, these will fit your stove. I bought these as part of final touches on a house redo, and they really make the stove look better.
These slide really well. Unfortunately they scrape the rod when you put them in. These are reasonably well made, and pretty. Recommended.

This is my second Tuft and Needle mattress--the first one I had slept on is on the third floor of an old house in Baltimore, actually on an old wood floor.  This is a fantastic night's sleep!If you have tendinitis, this doesn't hurt pressure points. It's very, very comfortable if you are a back sleeper.One warning: once you open the second cover, the mattress will inflate like a balloon in a matter of seconds. Don't open that last cover until you've put the bed where you want it. Recommended.Edit:  After a few days, I feel better than I have in years. (I was sleeping on a fifteen-year-old Sealy futon.)  Seriously, this will make back pain and tendinitis from sleeping on an old mattress better in days.  This is a cure for soft tissue pain caused by an old or too hard bed. It's amazing.

My corgi/chihuaha mix seems to love the taste. She is a smaller dog, and she has no trouble with the larger kibble; it doesn't aggravate her food allergies.This also seems to improve her digestion. Recommended.

These are really good construction:  they are made of a black enamel shelving that seems to be easily obtainable. I have a shelf made by the same manufacturer--just coincidentally--that is fifteen years old.  The shelf hasn't rusted or changed appearance in all that time, through two moves and some rough handling--just don't lose the plastic pieces that attach the shelves to the rods.  I was so overjoyed to realize that the manufacture is identical to something I've already owned for fifteen years--that still looks great. Recommended.

This is a fairly mildly scented, non-irritating shampoo. The scent is a mildly acidic botanical that doesn't really remind one of anything, except, it's vaguely vinegary.  This makes hair look good.  I can see using this for years--you don't notice it, either on hair or on skin. (I kept forgetting to review it, because you're not reminded that you're using it, either by scent, irritation, or oiliness.) Recommended.

This is a way to get a garlic taste into food if you're allicin intolerant. (Onions and garlic make you ill.) Something about mixing garlic with salt neutralizes the allicin, so it's safe to eat.  Recommended

This is an incredible book. The most important thing it has to say, is that the romantic bond is much like the attachment a parent has to a child--and if you criticize, you break that bond.  It talks about how to re-establish the bond, and create a better relationship. (For Example: don't reality check your mate. It's actually destructive.)

This is a phenomenal science fiction movie.  It takes place in a near-future planet earth in which NASA is in hiding, and the only hope for humanity is to go to the stars.  So much of the science--what a wormhole looks like, relativity, Newton's Third Law, is real, with a little bit of an homage to 2001--and the acting is really good, and you'll cry through half of it.Loved it. Absolutely fantastic.  NASA should make movies like this part of their budget.

These are very cooling gel and mouth line patches that adhere directly to clean skin. They feel good, and they are not irritating. They appear to smooth out lines, a little, in only ten minutes. (I'm 45, and they smoothed out the lines between my eyebrows, much better than I would have expected.)  While nothing that is not injectable can do that permanently and immediately (even prescription Retin-A takes weeks or months) I would use these if I were going to an important appearance of some kind, like a date, reunion, or camera appearance. They do work.These are safe for celiacs or people who are gluten-intolerant.  The website says these are gluten-free. In fact, according to their website, many of the skyn Iceland products are gluten-free.

This is probably not a guy's sunscreen. It has an amazing smell--somewhere between honeysuckle and mountain laurel.  Being female and fond of scent, I love it, but I can't see the macho cyclists and climbers I know slathering this on before hitting the trail. I also wouldn't use it on my face, because of the scent.That said, this is an aesthetically and technologically impressive sunscreen.  When it first goes on, there is a little bit of irritation, but then it sinks in.  After five minutes, it sinks in and it's not greasy at all.  It doesn't leave white marks on upholstery or clothing.And then, it does something a little odd: if you cover your arm in it, and then run water over it, the water acts like you have put a layer of Gore-Tex on your arm.  On the front of the bottle, it says, "sweat evaporates away."  I don't know about evaporation, but this will make you slightly waterproof.This also contains Helioplex, which is a European sunscreen finally being sold in the U.S. It's a very effective sunscreen that actually protects against UVA and UVB. I would buy this again, because it doesn't leave white marks, and because of the wonderful scent.One caveat: my boyfriend is chemically sensitive, and this made him wheeze, so if you have trouble with a lot of chemicals or scent, this is not for you.

This is a compelling and fun collection of ghost stories that even adults will enjoy.  Our protagonist is a young boy drawn to a gathering of slightly ghostly people, sitting around a table, each telling a story in turn. Each one is voiced a little differently, which makes the book interesting enough to come back to repeatedly.It's a little advanced--there is some gore. I might not give it to kids under thirteen, particularly if they're the type to get nightmares.  None of these is particularly scary, and at least one is kind of sweet.I liked this book and wanted to finish it. It's a little flat in places, but then you find yourself with that, "Ooh, what happened next," feeling you might remember from summer camp stories around a camp fire.  All you're missing is the s'mores. Recommended.

In water by itself this is a thick coconut shake. It's not gritty, and it's very, very filling.  It tastes good, and it staves off hunger. It's truly gluten free. (I have celiac and it didn't make me sick.)What it contains:whey, which is a muscle building ingredientmicellular proteins (They digest slowly, so supposedly you'll feel fuller longer)apple pectin (This is a filler; my mother used to drink it for weight loss in the seventies; pectin makes you feel fuller, longer.)casein, which is great if you just need the protein--it takes a while to digest.Lo Han Guo.  This is a sweetener used in traditional Chinese medicine, as a longevity aid. It tastes good!Having said that, this is a little bit of an odd product.  I'm not clear why they bothered to make it gluten-free. Many celiacs are lactose intolerant, so this product is not for them. Also, many people with gluten intolerance are lactose intolerant, so this product is not for them either. And, celiacs can have an immune system reaction to casein (think colitis), so this  product is not for lactose-tolerant celiacs who react to casein.Having said that, I'd say this is recommended if you're gluten-intolerant, but not reactive to casein or lactose intolerant.

This is the supplement recommended by doctors to make skin look more youthful. I took it and saw no difference. It did make me have some abdominal pain, though:  the culprit?  The capsules are made from methylcellulose, which is known to cause a strong colitis reaction in people with any tendency towards having colitis.  (Google:  Nature: colitis and methylcellulose.)Jarrow ought to know better, and they ought to change the formulation of their capsules. It made me mad enough that I did more research: a lot of Jarrow supplements use methylcellulose for their vitamin capsules. Your vitamins shouldn't make you sick. Not recommended.

I have a dust mite allergy. If you have to get an unzippered cover, this works better than some unzippered covers for dust mite allergy. This is the second mattress cover I've tried that does not cover the entire mattress, and I don't notice much of a difference between this and an unsealed mattress, but this does work better than others I have tried. (If you're trying to treat dustmite allergy, you need zippered mattress covers. My doctor also said that I needed zippered covers, but I was hoping to save the cost by trying something less expensive.)  Dustmites are everywhere, and unless you seal up your mattress, your allergies won't be helped as much.Also, this  is slippery against an older mattress. If you have an older mattress or futon that is even a little bit concave, you'll spend your night slipping into the center of the bed.  I've slept on sealed mattresses in hotels treated for bed bugs, where the cover was not as slippery.This isn't completely a loss. It has a soft terry cover, so it might work for a newer mattress, if you're just trying to use it as a waterproof bed cover. Also, it's well constructed--it just won't help much with dust mites, like the manufacturer claims. Recommended, but only if you're just using it as a waterproof bed cover on a newer mattress, or your dust mite allergy is mild.

Set in 2010 London, this story follows several days in the life of an early twenties-Londoner with a sleep-wake disorder, a coding job, a clubbing habit, and a real fondness for trying new street drugs.  There, any similarity to the real world goes slightly, and wonderfully off-course:  the book is full of amazingly constructed sentences, infrequently-but-creatively used words like "farrago", and addictively inventive writing. The plotting is incredibly creative: it starts out, literally, a little like Neil Gaimain's, "Neverwhere," complete with mascot animal, and then it heads into William Gibsonish cyberpunk, with elements of the slightly mononoke (Japanese spirit animal) themes that animate Hiruke Murakami's work.  It's also really, really funny, and has a lot of action, which suggests Neal Stephenson's near-future-unlikely-hero intrigues. It's also full of realistic, grimy details from Burma and everyday London, that remind me of Pat Cadigan's gritty cyberpunk noir.Plot-wise, I don't want to reveal too much, because it would spoil the book. If you like any of the modern-near-future writers, or you are or were a fan of cyberpunk, this is for you. It's remarkably creative. This is a short read, at something nearing 250 pages, but you should read it when you don't have other important things to do, because the story will compel you to keep reading. Highly, highly recommended.

I have a corgi/chihuahua rescue that has some allergies. Normally I keep her on Diamond K Chicken and Rice, and she does pretty well with licking and scratching. However, I wanted to try her on another kind of food, just to keep things interesting. She loves this.  It doesn't seem to make her allergies any worse, and she eats it all up.I can't unequivocally recommend this for one reason, though: it's very high fiber and high volume for a dog food. The original Purina formula was developed with dogs kept in a lab in the basement of an office building.  The researchers were looking for a food combination that would produce low volume, compact waste, so that a dog living in an apartment would really only need to go two or three times a day.  This formula is nothing like that; it produces really high volume dog waste, even after a slow addition to regular dog food.If you can walk your dog often, your dog has a yard, or even if your dog has a dog door and a patio, this is fine.  However, if that is not the case, your dog will be waking you in the middle of the night to be let out, even in an older, well-house trained dog.  I'm sure the fiber and real food are great for dogs--I know mine loves it-- but I can only recommend this for dogs that have good access to the outdoors on a very regular basis. With that caveat, recommended.

This is a nice backpack.  It has very well done exterior stitching, and lots of interior pockets. It also has a (reasonably, except for the zipper) waterproof interior pocket big enough for a laptop.  I'm a 5'3", medium-framed woman, and this is comfortable.  It's comparable to the quality of REI backpacks. It does not have a key clip, though. Made in China.

This is one of those books that you'll read in a day. Forget whatever else you are supposed to be doing--you'll just keep reading. Michel Faber is one of those authors that people who like good writing will want to read, just for the writing alone.The main character is an English recovering addict/alcoholic who has become a minister.  A mysterious "corporation" sends him to a faraway planet to minister to the natives. His wife, a nurse, is left behind on Earth.  What follows is the story of his redemption, as his home planet falls apart.The plot description sounds like it might fall prey to a million different sci-fi cliches, right? Not so.This is inventive, poetic, and incredibly sad. Highly recommended.

These taste like gritty chocolate bars. They're quite palatable, and very yummy. However, they're really sweet, so much so that they sometimes cause acid indigestion. These are also truly gluten-free. (I'm a celiac with an old diagnosis; 10 ppm makes me sick. These do not.)I ate the entire box.  If you're working on something intellectually stressful or physically demanding, these will get you through it.  The acid indigestion goes away after a couple of days. I lived on these during a moving-with-only-some-help-from-movers/renovation-done-by-family friends/IKEA buying whirlwind that involved long days and a lot of heavy lifting. I didn't feel sore or sick afterwards. Considering I am celiac and I have multiple food intolerances, that is nothing short of a miracle. I will definitely buy these again. These really won't make you sick, if you have celiac. Very good.

This is truly gluten free.  The Vega One website says that they ELISA test to make sure their product is less than 20ppm gluten. I'm celiac, and I didn't react, so I think it's truly gluten-free.However, this has many other issues.  This has inulin, which can be difficult to digest for people who have IBS or trouble digesting some sugars. It's also really high fiber, so it's not completely tummy friendly.This is also gritty. It has a bitter aftertaste, which is pretty normal for shakes of this type. The bitter aftertaste is really, really strong, though. In fact, it's so strong, that I've come back repeatedly to edit this review to emphasize how bitter it is.  The four stars are for the nutrition and the gluten-free-ness, not the taste. This is like oat-free soylent.  I bet you could live on it, too.It does feel and taste like real food, though;  I would recommend this for people who have celiac or gluten intolerance who can tolerate inulin, and who are finding it difficult to get gluten-free food because of traveling or living in food deserts without good grocery stores. It will stave off hunger for several hours. Mixed in with a cup of almond milk and a cup of water, it's palatable, except for the aftertaste.  Basically, it's better than not eating!

This is the story of a trip to another star.  It is written, in large part, by the ship's computer--and the language in the book is odd, probably for that reason. It's also more detailed than I would have liked, which makes it a little difficult to read.More about big ideas than about moments and little details, an intricately plotted story follows a group of people in a multiple wheel ship to Tau Ceti, following the political and biological problems they have along the way. A lot of the science is really good--when you are missing certain elements, your ecosystems start to have issues. Overall, though, this is a little different and charmingly light.It's not space opera, so much as space serial; it has some odd plot holes; a large portion of the settlers are sequestered, in a sense, and then never mentioned again. More Niven than Reynolds, less Degrasse-Tyson than Chomsky, the book spends a lot of time parsing language, and not as much showing how neat such a voyage might be. Worth reading,  but not necessarily recommended.

I ordered six pairs of blue, black, white and blue print underwear. What I got was ten pairs of grey, black, and rose, in what looks like a vegetable dye. I actually prefer what I received, but it was a strange surprise.  If you're not expecting much, other than new underwear, they might be worth the gamble. I actually like these enough, I came back for a second try:  six pairs of tan, maroon, white, dark brown, and rose appeared on the second try.  Made in Bangladesh.

This story collection isn't heavy on the complicated sci fi worldbuilding or the huge ideas--which is a nice change.  Each one is more about the characters emotions.  Light, fanciful, and even pretty, in some cases, this is a good collection of stories: Recommended

This is rough.  It's also a fun ride.  Set in an alternate future in which Texas, as well as Arizona and New Mexico are natural deserts, the book is an intricate, interlocking puzzle of sandstorms, refugees, water rights, and huge interior water reclamation plants, complete with apartments, greywater recycling and glittering technologies.  (Even the trash disposals recycle methane.)The story follows a Phoenix journalist, a morally ambiguous, but not-entirely-morally-bankrupt "water knife" who is basically a fixer towards anyone who gets in the way of water rights, and a girl from Texas.  There is a lot of bloodshed, gore, torture, prostitution, and exploitation.  The bad guys don't always win, however, so this is something to keep reading through the difficult parts. It's a satisfying story.This is also very cleverly written: it plays with a lot of ideas based in current events.  Refugees from Texas are called, "Merry Perry's".  Canadians and Chinese are the economic victors; there are references to "desert cough", which is a real, current, medical problem caused by airborne fungus in areas struck by drought.One caveat:  if you have ever spent any time in Texas, there are some things about this book that don't sit right. Texas has been farmed since the 1600's, by Spanish settlers that built the Missions in the central and border areas of the state that have aquifers restored by native rain, not the Colorado River, which the book is about. The author seems to think that most of the state is naturally desert, instead of prairie (technically Texas is part of the Great Plains); Austin has more in common with the cattle-ranching-oil-industry city of Calgary in Canada, than it does with Phoenix, the city to which Austin is compared. However, in the author's defense, making Texas into a natural desert may have been a conceit to get the rest of the book to hang together.Also, like some of this other author's works, I can't recommend it to people who have issues with sexual exploitation.Overall, though, this is an entertaining, wild ride. The writing is well worth the price of admission.  With some reservations, recommended.

This has clean lines and feels solid; the design is pretty cool--the attached cable snaps into a holder on the side of the plug.This works well for charging phones and tablets simultaneously. The total U.S.B.out is 2.4 amps, so if you're trying to charge all your devices in one place, this is fairly impressive, unless your particular items need a lot more power. (Like multiple Apple devices.)I tested it with an Motorola Atrix and an I-Pad Mini at the same time.  They both charged at the same time without a problem.  It should take about four hours to charge both an Android phone and an Apple I-Pad Mini at the same time.  Recommended.

This is truly gluten-free--I'm a canary-in-the-coalmine-celiac, and I don't react to it. It's very moisturizing. For that I'd give it five stars--and then I'd have to start taking some stars off: I have six of the colors in this line, and this is my least favorite. It goes on as a clear gloss, almost, and it has an odd chemical scent, unlike the others, which smell like bubblegum.  The Almay Liquid Lip Balms are moisturizing and pretty, but, because of the chemical aftertaste, I would give this a pass.

I bought this out of nostalgia for the 'eighties--we used to wear colors like this in high school.  However, this doesn't show up as a dark color. It's a very pretty light maroon, and the color stays on.I'm a celiac with an old diagnosis and I react to gluten in very small amounts.  Where makeup is concerned, I start feeling sorry for myself, because there isn't much on the grocery store shelves that is safe.  When the Almay Liquid Lip Balms came out in my neighborhood, I bought six of them, as soon as I realized that this doesn't cause any reaction. This is truly gluten-free.This is one of the best colors in the line--it doesn't wear off, and it actually has a fair amount of color. Recommended!

There is a lot to like in this book.  Some of the stories will remind you of many traditional military science fiction stories, in which our heroes in uniform stumble upon something really not quite o.k.  However, the vast majority of the writing is very original and engaging.  There are plot lines here you definitely haven't seen before.  At least one is a fantasy story set in a science-fiction universe--and surprisingly, it has the most emotional impact.Neal Asher's particular contribution has the kind of amazing world building that makes you hope he writes a novel around the story included here. This is a wonderful collection! Recommended.

These are life saving if you are a celiac with fructose intolerance. It says these are certified gluten-free--believe it. This is good food, and these can correct vitamin imbalances that go with celiac. If you eat these for a week, you'll feel better, I promise. These also don't have FODMAPs (other things that are dificult to digest.) They won't make you sick, and they don't cause any digestive issues at all. This is real, safe food.Having celiac isn't easy--you get busy, and you get poor from buying expensive gluten-free food, and suddenly you're getting sick again. These can be the stopgap food that keeps that from ever happening, because they are tasty and cheap.Also, there is enough protein and fat in these that two will make a meal replacement. They work for easy weight loss if used for at least one meal a day.  You can eat them and not get blood sugar crashes or extreme hunger.Very good. Highly recommended!

I love this. It grips the floor really well. There are little plastic extruded dots on the underside that make this feel really stable on tile. It also doesn't hurt sensitive feet.(I studied Iyengar for years, and I've become afraid to do the longer timings because I haven't practiced in years.  Practice on a regular mat is difficult; my feet get painfully tight because I'm afraid to fall over. This solves that problem, because it feels really stable.)

I'm a fortysomething Scots Auburn with rosacea, broken caps, mild acne, and a predilection for using Retin-A in large quantities. I also have celiac, and the only two foundations I'm comfortable wearing are this and ZuZuLuxe's certified gluten-free foundations.This is my favorite foundation. I wear the lightest shade, 02. This doesn't oxidize or wear off, the Environmental Working Group doesn't absolutely hate it,and I can say from personal experience that performs well in every weather, from glaciers to the coast of Aruba.  I carry it in a big purse, and it's never broken. I even carried it in luggage, being careful to bury it in clothes, and it didn't break.If you're celiac--I have a diagnosis that predates this century, and I've learned from long experience that I react negatively to both oats and 10ppm or higher gluten in anything.  In February of 2015, Body Shop emailed me back almost immediately, and confirmed that this is gluten-free. I've worn it for months, and it doesn't make me sick.One compact of this foundation will last about three months. When Body Shop has big sales, the price is comparable to higher end drug store makeup. Recommended, and then some!

These are really yummy.  The chocolate is good quality and dense.  The label on the back says gluten-free, and having tested these, I can definitely say they are gluten free*!!In a regular store, these cost about $1.50 each.  They are about as big as the palm of your hand. Recommended!(*I have an old celiac diagnosis and 10ppm gluten is enough to make me sick.)

Seriously, I spent my Friday night complaining at and to my very patient computer programmer (PhD, thank you), trying to get this darn thing to work.  When we reset my MediaLink router--which is the first step in the instructions for the TP-Link Wireless Range Extender--the "range extender" broke some of the internal programming in my original router and we had to to a hard reboot of the Medialink router (with a paperclip).Don't expect to use this unless you're willing to spend several hours with a very patient IT professional fixing your original router, and you can be without your original router for that long.  By the time we got the router running again, the  TP-Link range extender didn't connect anyway, and we couldn't get the range extender to connect so that it would work.  The only thing the "range extender" did was cross wires with my original Medialink router, making it so that I had several hours with no internet connection at all.Once we re-established the internet connection, even with a functioning, reset Medialink router, the TP-Link would not connect.  It might work with another kind of router, but it won't work with a Medialink.So ultimately, we threw this in the trash.(Nope, I've just been advised not to throw it in the trash, because it might have stolen data. We're going to take it apart for scavengeable electronic parts. It may be repurposed as a synthesizer, or something that doesn't require a wireless broadcast. It might make for an interesting noise instrument. Since it doesn't broadcast at all, I have no doubt that I can get some of its circuits to do feedback.)

I'm a mid-forties natural redhead with very oily skin and rosacea.  I thought this was neat--it made my pores instantly smaller. However, I woke up the next day with a face full of hives.What it is:  tiny particles of charcoal in a flower-scented gel, meant to be used as a face wash two or three times a week.What it does:  this minimizes pores, instantly, just like the claims on the package.  It's also very drying, although it's not irritating, even if you have rosacea. It causes hives, though. It has a very strong scent--that may be the allergen.Who this would be good for:  anyone with blackheads and oily skin, who is not actually allergic to much.Note: this has no gluten-containing ingredients, but it doesn't say, "gluten-free," on the package. The Biore website doesn't have a search engine, so it's not clear if this is actually gluten-free. I actually emailed the company to ask if this is, in fact, gluten-free, and they never responded.

I'm a Gen-X-er who survived whooping cough at two-and-a-half months as the not-old-enough-to-be-vaccinated-infant of a medical resident on pediatric contagion rounds at New Orleans' infamous Charity Hospital.  Decades later, I'm a) lucky to be alive, and b) the happy recipient of what I'm told by several voice teachers is scar tissue in my chest, although, having passed the Texas Bar and been a National Merit Scholar a few decades back, I apparently escaped the brain damage you can get from many childhood diseases like measles.One in a hundred children died from whooping cough before vaccines.  Measles is worse, because it causes seizures, encephalitis, and brain damage, before the child dies from pneumonia as a complication.Speaking from personal experience, there is a reason we vaccinate. This is not chicken pox, folks.  If children do survive, they may have lifelong damage.

I have a corgi/chihuahua rescue who is the miracle dog--she survived three days in the snow with a prior owner; she was heartworm positive, and is now heartworm negative, two years later. She has survived a lot, but I'm a little afraid of putting medicine on her that I'm not familiar with--she has sensitive skin, too. She has to have special shampoo (Crazy Dog for Puppies) and specific protein food (Diamond Chicken and Rice), because of allergies.Usually, I use Frontline, but I live in a very heavily populated area of the South that has tons of small dogs and feral cats, so the fleas here are somewhat Frontline tolerant.  I put this on the chigi's neck earlier today.  She stopped scratching, which usually means the fleas are going away.I was impressed by the formulation--my chigi has the corgi double coat, that is oily, and sometimes Frontline starts to roll right over the outer oily layer of fur.  This is more like a gel, so it's easier to rub it into the skin with the applicator.This seems to work well for dogs with allergies, sensitive skin, and double coats.  Recommended.

This novel was originally published in 1987.  I got this as part of Kindle Unlimited, thinking the Kindle republishing date (in the 2000's) was the original publishing date.  About halfway through reading this, I was so impressed with the writing and worldbuilding, that I started researching, "Greg Bear," and discovered that this is a much older novel.  From then on, it was kind of a, "Where's Waldo," of seeing if a casual reader could spot the absence of cell phones and the internet. (You can't.)Despite the age of the book, this isn't dated at all.  It's a the-aliens-land-and-aren't necessarily-friendly-first contact novel. It's hard going in the beginning, because there is a lot of exposition to get the story started--and then it all pays off with moments of magic.  This is worth the time, and the effort.(And then you'll want to read the sequel, and at Greg Bear's 2012 novel, "Hull Zero Three," which is about waking up in an ark ship gone wrong, and either precede that or follow it with, "Moving Mars," ,"Queen of Angels," "Slant," and, "Eon,")If you like hard sf, I've just given you your reading list for the next few months.  Enjoy!

The stench pouring off of these when i unboxed them was phenomenal. I'd been warned by the reviews, so i opened them outside, and i'm glad i did. For the next week i left them out in the fresh air, and we even got about an inch of rain during that week, and they STILL smell so awful i can't go near them. It's worse than normal stinky plastic smell, in both strength and character.

I don't drink a lot of soda, but when i do, i buy the foofie ones made with real sugar an warm spices and stuff. Basically, what this one claims to be. And sure, maybe it has 'em, but it's mostly just the old water/sugar/citric acid/'flavors' mix. There's no complexity to it.Basically, there's nothing wrong with it, but there's also nothing right with it.

We had a skunk-based incident that left our previous coop unusable AND meant we needed a new coop before nightfall. The local farm supply store had this coop, and only this coop, in stock, so it was what we got.1) Assembly: pretty easy. Doable with one person, but you'll be a lot happier with two.2) Basic functionality: the doors latch, which is good, but if you're going with this product be sure to buy some hardware cloth to go underneath. Rats and other vermin can tunnel in easily otherwise.3) Capacity: We currently have six hens in here at night, and they range during the day. I'd be hesitant to put even two hens in here full-time. The footprint is small, there's no room for them to stretch their legs.4) Facilities: There is no roosting bar, you hens will have to sleep on the floor. This isn't a crisis, but chickens are happier roosting. The pull-out tray for changing litter is basically useless unless you have so little litter in there that the litter will be useless. Probably works better for rabbits than chickens, which is what i think this was designed for. Sticking a food and water dish inside is nearly impossible, so if you animals aren't ranging during the day, you'll have to be creative.5) Long-term functionality: Less than two months in, and both door latches are rusting badly. The product is not well-made from quality materials. Before shelling out cash for this, realize what you're getting: a cheap but functional product. It's low-end Ikea for your chickens. Also, if you do get this, try to let it air a few days before putting the chickens in it, as there is a lot of off-gassing.

This thing prints fine. Scans, copies, yeah. The ink cartridges are tiny and ridiculously overpriced, but that's pretty much par for the course.But the wireless, oh, the wireless. I bet it could have driven Mother Theresa and the Dalai Lama to fisticuffs. After going through the process four times, using three different methods, my computer could still not find the printer on the network. I might have been able to connect it via USB and just walk away, but as i was setting that up (the USB cord is, of course, not included), the PRINTER notified me of a firmware update on the internet, downloaded it, and installed it. So yes, my printer is sufficiently connected to my router that it can update Canon's spyware database, it can download updates, but not so connected to the router that it can talk to the computer also connected to that router.

I'm lucky enough to have tap water that tastes fine to me, so i don't need a filtration pitcher just to make my water palatable.I do, however, need one to keep trace salts and minerals from building up in my potted plants and my humidifier. Using a brita filter dramatically reduces the amount of mineral build-up in my humidifier, which of course makes cleaning faster and easier.(As for the 'volumetric' filter alert on this: yes, it's better than the old style timer one, that reminded you to replace your filter every x months whether you refill it twice a day or once a week. This new model basically counts pitcher-fills, based on how often you open the lid and the demand that you always and only fill the reservoir to the fill line. So... better, yes, but still pretty slapdash.)

I admit, i've only read a few of her books so far, but i've pretty universally loved them.Not this one.I get that books written for a certain age group, and especially the male stereotypes of that age group, often contain 'gross-out' humor like eating worms and such. I can cope with that. But Ruffleclaw is universally rude, and downright mean. He lies, steals, destroys things for fun, and subjects Tommy to an unceasing barrage of verbal abuse. And for this, he's rewarded by being welcomed into the home!There are flimsy morals about looking past the surface and accepting people (or monsters) who are different than you, but in all, it's a story about how breaking the rules and destroying other people's belongings is funny.

With all phone cases, there's a tradeoff between size and protection. This is, by far, the slimmest case i've tried, it only adds marginal size and weight to my phone, but it seems to provide about the same protection as the bigger cases. It's easier to hold, easier to fit in pockets, and less clunky-looking.My only complaint is that the image on my screen looks like a reasonably bright purple, while the actual product is a cooler, slightly darker shade. (I lose my phone constantly, and prefer brightly colored cases to make it easier to find.)

Normal cotton shirts usually work fine for my kid, even when he's running and playing quite vigorously. However, i signed him up for tumbling classes, and he really works up a sweat there. This shirt doesn't stick, bunch, cling, or chafe. It also doesn't glue him to the mat when he ends up flat on his back. He and i both prefer that he wear plain cotton shirts for most activities, but for tumbling (and probably the summer soccer season), this shirt is the go-to shirt.

The main characters are basically execrable. I can cheer for heroes and anti-heroes, but scum? Nope.The story, uh... well, it's in there somewhere, between geography lessons and grocery lists. I think.And the writing. So, there's a lot of sex and violence, but it just didn't work. It reminded me of nothing more than my preschooler shouting 'poop!' because it's the worst word he can think of.

While a bit smaller than i expected, this is a big hit with my car-obsessed preschooler. Gates, two levels, ramps, and a tunnel mean there's a lot of places to drive on, through, and around. It comes packaged with two cars, just in case you don't already have a few hundred in every nook and cranny of your house.
These feel a shade flimsier than the standard red solo cups, but i suppose that just means less mass in the landfills.

I tried these myself and noticed no real effects, but then, i'm not teething. They dissolve slowly, and have a very mild sweetness as they do.I was, however, unable to test them on the teething toddler due to the fact that the teething toddler had no sense of humor about having small white thingies shoved in his face.

The 'thing' that makes this game 'different' is the negotiation aspect: after killing a dragon, the people who teamed up to slay it get to haggle about who gets what from the dragon's hoard. The different kinds of treasure mean it's not just about getting the majority, so that's nice. However, if you end up playing with a jerk, it can ruin the whole game. Sure, playing with a jerk can ruin any game, but it usually can't affect the actual game mechanics. Here, it can. (Likewise, playing with younger people who don't understand the difference between 'negotiating' and 'unilaterally stating demands' often results in drama.)It's easy enough to learn, but it won't be in my Game Night Pile for fear of causing social disharmony.

One of my cats prefers to drink moving water, but this fountain doesn't move it very much. Certainly not enough for the cat, who just stares at it balefully.Also, it requires weekly cleanings. And no just wipe-it-down-so-it-doesn't-get-manky, but full on disassembly of the entire thing, even the pump casing.If you've got a cat with health issues and you're willing to spend your saturday morning trying to pry the little fan thingie out of the housing (the instructions blithely say you can do it by wedging a fingernail under it, but their must have different kinds of fingernails than i do), well, it is a lovely shade of purple. As for me, i'll probably use it until i forget to clean the pump some weekend and the whole thing grinds to a stop. Then my picky kitty will be back to staring balefully at normal water dishes.

This color is a shade too orange for me to think of it as 'scarlet', but as with anything, color is in the eye of the beholder. Just don't expect a pure red.The case itself is reasonably solid, easy to put on, and so forth. It looks pretty good fresh out of the box, but the rubber edge around the screen can scuff up, and when it does, it goes from looking 'pretty good' to 'pretty cheap' pretty quickly.

The basic premise of this just seems so much more like a summer teen horror movie than even a beach read. A random social network appears, and people start dying. Yep. It's just too thin a premise, and too rediculous, to work as a novel. 90 minutes of running and screaming and tight close-ups of terrified beautiful people? Absolutely. A few hundred pages of reading? Nope. That gives you too much time to gag on the stereotyping, the plot holes, and so on.

Anyone who's ever sprained an ankle or wrist knows the joy of losing those little metal butterfly clip things for elastic bandages (and, if they're extra-lucky, the joy of finding it again with a bare foot). While this new-fangled velcro/plastic clip isn't perfect, it has the double bonus of both not being poky AND not falling off entirely even if it comes loose from one side of the bandage.The instructions are a little lacking, but a few seconds of messing around should be enough to figure out what the blurry black-and-white pictures are getting at.

Sometimes simple is best. If what you need is a basic 8.5x11"-ish planner, with one month on each open page and a few pages after that for notes, future planning, and whatnot, then this'll do you fine. The cover is a generic beige, but the cover edges and the coil are a nice burnt orange that works surprisingly well as an accent.The only change i'd make to this is using a slightly thicker paper. Since the back of one month is the front of another, any heavy-ink writing shows through a little. It's not a deal breaker, it doesn't show through so much that readability becomes an issue, but with so few pages it wouldn't have made the planner too thick to use slightly thicker paper.

This is a basic morality story about why you shouldn't dump your friends/belongings when someone/something new shows up. New isn't always better, even if it seems so at first.The front and back cover also contain simple instructions on how to draw all the various characters in the story, which artistically inclined kids will enjoy.

If you're a collector, you don't need to be told to get this doll. If your child (or you!) is just a fan of the series and want to play with the dolls, it's also great. However, the doll is a little flimsy, with teeny-tiny limbs and joints that i'm not sure will take a lot of action. Jane is not built for adventure. I would not recommend this doll for general purpose play.

I didn't much like this book, but i was sufficiently engaged in the core mystery to finish it. That's why it gets more than one star.For starters, the basic premise is flawed. The main character is The Last Robot In The World, which should make him the WORST private investigator/assassin ever, not the best.Second, the writing is an awkward halfway between old fashioned hardboiled noir and standard mystery/thriller. At times it's horribly over-written for the latter, and at times it's horribly streamlined for the former.Third, the book feels compelled, every few pages, to remind us rather bluntly that the PI we're following around is a robot, with robot characteristics and abilities, and also a robot, in case we forgot.And last... well, it just doesn't make sense. At the end you'll get a nice wrap-up, a who/what/where/when/why, but it just doesn't work. We know why the robot PI was hired in the first place but...well, i repeat myself: it doesn't make sense.Granted, this is apparently the first in the 'LA Trilogy', so maybe the heavy foreshadowing laid in this book is for future books and not this one, and perhaps the totally nonsensical explanation for the events in this volume is part of that meta-narrative, but... well... it didn't make sense. And, alas, i'll never know, as i've no plan to read books 2 and 3.

This book is a personal drama, it is a dystopian landscape, it is a political commentary, it is a technological warning. It is all these things while being only one thing.I'm not an overly emotional person, and overly emotional books just annoy me. This i hope provides the context to signify the magnitude of the following: i read most of the middle third of this book with tears in my eyes.The book is written with such brilliant understatement that i had no choice to feel what the characters were feeling, because the author perfectly showed it without ever saying it.Upon finishing this book, i first had to sit a while and just digest what i'd read. Then, i got up and ordered the other books written by this author so far, because they simply must be at least partly as good as this one, and partly as good as this one still edges on brilliant.
If you have a kid who likes pink, even if they have no idea who 'Abby Cadabby' is, they'll probably love this. She's soft and cuddly, and oh so pink.

There's something delightful about a preschooler having a stuffed animal almost the size they are. Mine loves his friend 'Blue Monster' so much we've had to pull an extra chair up to the table for it at dinner time.

The first few chapters of this book blew me away. The author used language masterfully to drive home how desolate, how heartbroken that world is. It was almost hard to read.Then it did get hard to read, because for the middle section nothing is happening but a bunch of bickering between people who should know better. I'm not a big fan of character drama and i had little patience for the family grudges when, somewhere off camera, the world was literally ending.Thankfully, the camera's gaze turns back toward the apocalypse for the third act, and it picks up again.While i have some curiosity about What Happens Next, i really hope this book isn't the start of a series. It ended cleanly.

The fit is fine, and the material is ok (not soft, but not itchy), but the thick seams (especially around the legs) literally rub me the wrong way. It's not that the leg holes are too small or too tight, it's that the seams are thick and press uncomfortably when sitting.

The fit is fine, and the material is ok (not soft, but not itchy), but the thick seams (especially around the legs) literally rub me the wrong way. It's not that the leg holes are too small or too tight, it's that the seams are thick and press uncomfortably when sitting.

The author does a great job of fleshing out the personal, professional, and political enmity these two men held for each other, while also making it clear that it was none of those in and of themselves that resulted in the duel directly. It is as much a biography of the two men as it is an analysis of the social requirements of the time, defending one's honor being foremost among them.

The readings seem ok, but i can't get the device to communicate with my iPhone most of the time. The whole reason to go with this model was having numbers automatically update the record on my phone. If i have to enter them manually, this device is no different from any other on the market.
This is a fun, silly toy, even if your kids aren't in to the whole Miles thing, but it's cheap, verging on junk. The color chips off easily, and the wings fall off it you look at it wrong.

This hard plastic doll is not terribly kid-friendly. The button to activate the flop/phrase-from-movie is hard to push, even for adults. It doesn't stand up on its own, and there's no way to get the book to stay on the hand. I'd recommend it for adult fans of the film, but not as a kids' toy.

The majority of the stories in this collection are on the sightseeing and of the sightseeing-adventure spectrum of travel. It's not that there's anything wrong with that, i just prefer the more exciting adventure stories to the cozy ooh-look-at-that stories. While the overall quality is fine, a few of the entries were gratingly bad, and i wondered why they were included at all.

This collection manages to contain a story about the Seahawks/Broncos Superbowl in January, 2014, but nary a peep of the Men's World Cup in the summer of 2014. I give them a pass on skipping the Women's World Cup in 2015, as these collections nearly always run a year or so behind, but nothing about then men's competition? Nothing about FIFA, and their troubles that were beginning to show through even 18 months ago? I guess when they say 'american sports writing', they mean canonically american sports. Apparently shooting elephants is more american than soccer.If the 2016 volume is still FIFA-free, i'm going to give up on this increasingly uneven and melodramatic series that spends a great deal more time talking about people-in-sports than sports themselves.
This is a charming, snarky, and blunt book about friends, relationships, forgiveness, things left unsaid, loss, holding a grudge, and letting go.

This book takes a few subgenres of YA/fantasy, piles them together, and makes them good again. The zombie/post-apoc thing meets naive-girl-in-a-theocratic-america thing was good. The main character had a good mix of strength and weakness, of willfulness and fear. I liked her.Then Finn showed up.I'm beginning to think it's illegal for a YA book to be published without 'stomach' and 'flip-flop[ed]' in the same sentence somewhere. Despite the fact that Nina is terrified, traumatized, and has just discovered that nearly everything she knows is a lie, Finn initiates a romance without telling her the really, really stupid but really, really important 'secret' about himself.Ugh.So then the whole, y'know, actual plot about demons and the church and whatever is periodically sidelined by Nina and Finn gazing into each other's eyes and/or feeling mad and betrayed and whatever about some stupid misunderstanding. Because when the whole world is hunting you, you'd best put everything on hold for yet another timid hand-holding and eye-gazing session.

The cover of this notebook is very floppy, so if you don't like writing along the curve of your legs, it'll only be good for meetings at conference tables, desks, or other convenient and accessible flat surfaces. The cover is also made of some sort of synthetic material that stinks like crazy at first - i couldn't bring it indoors until it'd had a good 24 hours outside to offgas.The paper is good quality, and each sheet has space at the top for a header and at the bottom for Action Items. I just wish it had a rigid cardboard cover.

I guess if you're getting this bag so you can hang a single bulb of garlic somewhere instead of leaving on the counter, it'll work. But it'll pretty much only hold one bulb (maybe two if you take out the cotton lining), so unless you're hanging it, putting your garlic in this bag will mean it takes up even more space than before.

This is my first-grader's preferred nighttime reading assignment. Some of the words are definite challenges (camouflage, ingenious, etc), but he loves the content so much that he's patient with facing a lot of new and unfamiliar words. And we know he's actually learning from it, since he'll pepper us with trivia about the previous night's reading during breakfast.

This is a pretty solid, readable, and accessible explanation of why there is no science whatsoever backing up the racist, classist, and sexist themes that crop up every few years in the mainstream media. It's also full of dry humor as the author explains why, exactly, one would have to be utterly ignorant or utterly incompetent to actually believe the pseudoscience used to back it up.

So, by 137 pages in (37%, for you who prefer percentages), we've learned the following:1) There's 'something' the main character needs to do in the real world, he's not just averse to captivity2) The rig is really secure3) 'Something' is going on with the peer antagonist and his posse4) 'Something' is going on with the rig as a whole5) Actually, specifically, what his roomie did to get him put on the RigFor a more than a third of the way through the book, that's an awful lot of not much yet.

I get that Winnie's mom died a few months before, and i get that this makes her morose and prone to finding fault in everything, but that doesn't mean i want to read a protracted letter to her bestie about exactly how and why everyone and everything around her sucks.

They're brightly-colored, they nest, they scoop up water and leak it out. If your kid makes a mess with normal buckets in the bath, they'll make a mess with these, too, but the holes in the bottom make for a lot more giggling.

This case will protect your iphone from the usual accidental drops and bonks. It's completely clear, no tinting. It does significantly increase the size of the phone, of course, so if it was a tight fit in your pocket before, it probably won't fit at all with this case, but that's the trade you make for not having the screen pop out next time you drop it.
The name and description don't make it clear that this product contains fish oil, but the smell sure does. Uck.

This case provides reasonable protection from drop and bonks, but it looks a bit cheap. The grey rubber edge around the phone screen is particularly jarring, juxtaposed with the fancy retina display. The 'insert' is just a piece of paper, which i guess means you could also print up your own to personalize it.In all, it does the job, but if you care about what you'll be seeing every time you look at your phone, you might want to go with another case.

If a book about an albino amnesiac with encyclopedic knowledge of everything except himself showing up in a small desert town full of corruption and betrayal right after a mexican drug cartel plane goes down nearby sounds like your thing, then this book is probably your thing.The only thing i really disliked about it was the POV issue - it jumps back and forth from Creed's first-person-present-tense narration to a third-person-omniscient-past-tense for everyone else. I could deal with the book being written as one or the other, but the switches between the two were jarring for me.

Despite some interesting elements, especially mutant-powers-from-an-alien-visitation, this is basically just a generic YA book.-Girl who doesn't understand her own powers-Dead mother, missing father-Friend/romantic partner angst-Post-apoc-ish world with a totalitarian government-Said government comes after Main Character, destroying her 'safe' home and sending her on the run-...where she learns her father had secrets, the government has secrets, the rebellion-ish-thing has secrets, etc.Despite being a derivative YA fantasy novel, it had potential to at least be a _good_ derivative novel. Unfortunately, Penn's powers serve as a deux ex machina to solve whatever problem she gets into, as if the author wrote without planning ahead and just had to keep pulling out the 'Oh, but now Penn can ________, so it's ok!' card.

This is a great item in theory, but making the tee light enough to be 'fold away' means it's not heavy enough to be a tee. Even with the whiffle-like-bat, the tee is way too easy to knock over. Unless the lesson you're trying to teach your child is 'be perfect or the world will fall apart around you', this isn't a great product.

Amazing pictures of butterflies, with descriptive and explanatory text. A must for butterfly enthusiasts, anyone who likes beautiful images of butterflies, and possible even children and young adults who are into science and bugs.

The mesh material is great if you're sweating - it breathes, and the material doesn't stick like wet cotton would. However, the fit is odd. The waistline rides much higher in the front than the back. I'll wear the ones i have, but i wouldn't buy more.

There are times when blurbs do a disservice to a book by comparing them to the greats. Given that, of the blurbs on the advance copies, at least two compared this book to Pratchett, and one to The Princess Bride, i had some expectations going in. And while there was enough clever wit going on that i annoyed friends and family alike by reading sections aloud at random intervals, there's one key factor that makes this book fall well short of anything Pratchett ever wrote: character likability. The heroes, the villains, even the random extras in any Pratchett book (or Princess Bride) were delightful characters. Certainly not always people you'd like to sit next to on a cross-country flight, or even know they live in the same town as you, but always, in their way, delightful.This book? Well, i kinda wanted the main character to fall into a bog or something, and he's the one i liked best.So... good story, i love the dry British wit, but ugh, the characters ruin it.

Functionally, i have no quibbles with this. I plug things into it and it into the wall and it works.However, i do giggle every time i see it. If it were intentionally retro, that would be one thing, but the blocky grey plastic is just so ugly i can't help but wonder why on earth it's being manufactured in this day and age.

With psoriasis and eczema in the family, the softer the better for washcloths. These are very soft and fuzzy, even the preschooler likes them whether or not he's having a psoriasis flare-up. I'd give them the full five stars if they were just a bit thicker.
This is probably a must-have for kids in love with Inside Out, but as an adult, i just can't stop being squicked by the fact that the speaking/hand-waving is triggered by squeezing her legs together.

My nephew is a vigorous toddler, and tests the limits of nearly anything he can get his hands on (family included). I suspect, for normal toddlers, this toy will be sufficiently sturdy, and the fold-up-and-put-away feature is great in a world of kid toys that take up too much space.However, if you, like i, have an excessively rambunctious littling, you might want to go with a shape sorter that isn't designed to collapse.

I took the batteries out of this before giving it to my kid. The recorded phrases were uh... loud. Since this is a plush doll, not a hard plastic doll, it does get plenty of snuggles, it's dangerous to have a snuggle-up-at-bedtime doll that might shout at your child in the middle of the night if you forget to turn it off (and getting to the on/off switch is a fair challenge).

Since reading this book, i haven't been able to get into any other YA SF/F/specfic. Ness just eviscerates the whole Chosen One anchor of the genre so completely that i can't really focus on Penn or Scam or Katniss or Harry. I'm wondering about their neighbors, their cousins in another state/district, the ones who are trying to just live their lives when superheroes are destroying things, wizards are at war, or some other kid is picked for the Hunger Games. The Special Snowflakes of YA books just seem even more ridiculous than they did before.In a way, i'm hoping Ness writes a 'sequel' to this one, where he actually writes the YA ordinary-girl-saves-the-world-and-falls-in-love-in-the-span-of-a-week-or-so that happens in the background (well, technically, the chapter openings) of this, just because it seemed like it would also be a send-up of the genre.

About a quarter of the way through this book, our inexplicably action-star hero (he keeps dropping comments about how people must wonder where he learned to handle a gun etc whatnot, it gets repetitive) stumbles upon a woman half his age who of course gets swept up in his guns-and-explosions lifestyle. In fact, even while being actively shot at, he takes time to admire her backside and the fit of her pants. He also says delightful things like 'i've known enough women to know there was no point in arguing.' Because all women are the same, of course.So.... a solid B+ on the plot and action, but it's hard to really engage when you're hoping the hero will fall in a hole and die or something.

I have several books by this author on my shelves, and i'm always delighted to get a new one. Armstrong writes religious histories perfectly, providing detailed accounts of the topic without getting bogged down in minutia or glossing over too much. I knew basically nothing about St Paul before reading this book, and she managed to give me enough background to contextualize the new interpretations of his message while still staying on topic - basically, a lot of the writings attributed to Paul were not actually written by him, and if you stick to the ones that are, you get a very different message.

This is a story about a severely messed-up family, girls uprooted from their lives, and magic. While i could see the parts that were supposed to make it heartwarming and comforting, i was stuck on all the things that made it terrifying. I can't imagine, as a young girl, reading a story about a mom who treats her family that way and not freaking out. I'm also a little disenchanted with the 'run away from your problems and hide in a magical closet' approach to difficult times. However, it's also a story about sisters coming together in tough times, which is sweet in its way.
A little on the small side, especially if you include a drink, but better than a sack and an icepack.
My kid didn't need help assembling the driller, he needed help making sense of the instructions. A great construction toy.
This story read like a functionally-plotted encounter-oriented middle grade book, sussed up and fluffed out to YA level.
The first 100 pages need to be trimmed down to 10. Loved the story, hated waiting for it to happen.
Good food, beautiful pictures, but don't mistake the high page count for a good estimate of the number of recipes.
If you can't use a humidifier to help your stuffed up little one breathe, this is a good back-up option.
This book explores not just realities of life in ultra-poverty, but the systems, policies, and economies that cause it.
Tuck annoyed me so violently that i couldn't even finish reading the book, which is a shame. It had promise.
A thought-provoking novel about troubled teens, but i just never bought into the story. The ending undermined the beginning.
Half the time the fist falls when you touch the snail, half the time it doesn't fall even after spinning.

As a physician it is pretty much mandatory not to wear latex gloves anymore due to the fairly high number of people with latex allergies.  Unlike other nitrile gloves I have used that have powder in them, these Ammex gloves are nice because they are easy to put on and take off without a powder residue.  They feel a little thin, but seem durable enough to provide adequate protection for performing non-sterile medical duties.  These are ideal for wearing while handling body fluids, drawing blood, performing rectal or pelvic exams, etc.  They would also be suitable for many non-medical purposes, too, as long as tough durability is not needed.  For example, these are useful to wear at home while working on the innards of my computer or protecting my hands while using solvents to clean my firearms.  I wear an Extra Large glove size, and these X-Large gloves fit perfectly.

I use nitrile gloves to protect my hands from solvents while cleaning firearms.  These Ammex gloves are comparable to other (blue) nitrile gloves I have used in the past.  Unlike the others I have used, though, these gloves seem to slip onto my hands a lot easier despite the lack of powder.  I also like the fact that there is not powder all over my hands after wearing them.  They seem to be very durable, stretch well without tearing easily, and work well for my stated purpose.  These would be good gloves for most non-medical situations where one might want protection from solvents or other contaminants or to keep oils and moisture of the hands from contaminating work surfaces.  I usually wear an Extra Large glove, and these X-Large gloves fit perfectly.

This is the second Philips Sonicare Flexcare Platinum toothbrush I have owned.  The first one lasted a little over 2 years, which was an enormous disappointment.  Compared with other Sonicare toothbrushes, the Flexcare Platinum can be highly customized for intensity and also for duration of cleaning.  It does a very good job of cleaning my teeth, and I especially like that it will remember the last setting so I don't have to keep readjusting it for a deeper clean.  The brush is designed to tell you if you are brushing too hard, which helps to protect your teeth.  The brush will keep a charge for 2 weeks, meaning you don't need to take the charger if you are travelling for a shorter period of time.  The travel case is firm plastic and keeps both the handle and brush head well-protected.There are some things to dislike about this product.  The button to change brushing intensity is long and centered in the handle.  It is way too easy to accidentally change the intensity of brushing while holding the handle during brushing.  The handle is quite slender and, in my large hands anyway, is a little awkward to hold compared with other Sonicare models that have a rounder handle.  Unlike other Sonicare models, there are no indicator lights to show you the brush is charging while on the charger.  This was quite disturbing at first, and I wondered if I received a defective product, but the handle charged up with no problems.  The charging base has a post to store a second brush head, but at this price point the base should have a UV brush head sterilizer built in.Sonicare makes some excellent rechargeable toothbrushes.  The Flexcare platinum is at the higher end of their product line, but quite honestly you can buy another Flexcare model that will work equally well for less money.  If you look at the other Flexcare models on Amazon you will find you can buy a set of two Flexcare handles with brushes, a charger with UV sterilizer, a travel charger, and two travel cases for about the same amount or less than you will spend on this Flexcare Platinum model (see Philips Sonicare Flexcare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush Premium Edition 2 pack bundle (2 Flexcare Handles, 2 Diamond Clean Standard Brush Heads, 1 Compact Travel Charger, 2 Hygienic Travel Caps, 2 Hard Travel Cases, 1 UV Sanitizer)).

I had the opportunity to use and review Axe White Label Body Wash, Night 16 oz  recently and so loved the body wash and the scent that I quickly bought more.  So I was very excited to try Axe White Label Shampoo & Conditioner, Night scent, which I thought would be a great match for the body wash.  Boy, was I wrong.  This product smells nothing like the body wash with the same name.  In fact, I had to check the product label to make sure they sent me the correct one.  The label was correct.  The product sent to me was lime green in color (unlike the dark purple color of the body wash) and smells just like Vick's Vapo Rub while applying it to my hair.  It even has a similar menthol feel while washing with it.  Thankfully, the scent goes away readily while rinsing my hair.  Does it shampoo well?  Yes.  The conditioner is mild and leaves my hair feeling soft.  But the smell.  Epic fail.  Axe:  if you are reading this review, please change the scent to match the body wash.  This one is a loser.

I have purchased several Anne Klein watches for my wife over the years, and she has always loved them.  They have always kept good time.  So I knew she would be excited to own this one, too.  Like all Anne Klein watches, this set comes packaged in a very attractive gift box with good padding inside.  The watch was already set to the correct time when I received it, so there was nothing for her to do other than unclasp it and put it on to wear.  It has a Japanese quartz movement in it, which in my experience has typically been very good at keeping accurate time.  The photos of this product really do not do it justice.  The detail, colors, and Swarovski crystals make the watch look absolutely beautiful when seen in person.  The bracelets are equally attractive and match well with the watch.  The clasps on the watch and bracelets all fasten securely, and my wife had no difficulty opening and closing them.  She happily wore the watch and bracelets to work today, but they would also look very attractive for formal wear.  You cannot beat Anne Klein's lifetime warranty, either.  I have used their warranty service in the past when my wife accidentally broke a ceramic watch bracelet, and they sent the needed parts with no questions asked other than what model her watch was.  Their customer service is excellent.This is a very pretty watch & bracelet set with a lifetime warranty that would be perfect for a woman to wear for both casual and formal occasions and would also make an excellent gift.  Considering the quality of the watch and jewelry you are getting, Amazon's current selling price of $150 is very reasonable and a good value.

I purchased this garage door opener remote after discovering that the Linkmaster remote given to me by a relative would not work with a Genie garage door opener.  I ride a motorcycle and wanted a remote that would be small enough to fit in my pocket.  This remote is no larger than a small matchbox and is perfect for my intended usage.  It took longer to remove the two screws in my garage door opener housing to access the learning button than it did to program this remote which literally took only a few seconds.  There is one large button and two smaller buttons that can each be configured to work with the same or different openers.  Unfortunately, only the large button on the remote would pair with my garage door opener. The two smaller buttons did not work. It appears other reviewers have reported this same problem, so there may be an issue with quality control in manufacture.  That is the only reason I docked this item 2 stars in my review. There is an included keychain with a plastic quick disconnect feature to it.  Those wanting a remote to attach to a car visor will not be happy with this product as it is not designed for that purpose and does not have a visor clip.If you have a Genie garage door opener with Intellicode (ours is over 15 years old) and want a small remote control for it that you can attach to a keychain and/or carry in your pocket this model should be ideal if you can get one that works properly.Update 8/21/15I received a very prompt replacement remote from the seller.The product information sheet that comes with the remote tells you how to change the battery in the remote but not how to program it.  For the Genie Intellicode garage door openers you must open the front housing of the garage door opener (where the lights are -- you may need to unscrew screws to do this).  On the front of the garage door opener panel (which will likely be on the same side where the wire antenna is located) you will see a small button next to an LED light.  You press the button to activate the opener's learning function, and the LED will turn on.  You then point the remote at the opener from at least 2 feet away and press the button on the remote that you want to program for that opener.  This must be done within about 30 seconds or you will have to start all over again.  Do not press and hold the button on the remote or it may not work.  For Genie openers with Intellicode you held down the desired button for only a couple of seconds, release the button, and then press for another couple of seconds, release, and press at third time after which the garage door should open.  The other thing I discovered is you can only program one button for any given garage door opener.  So if you only have two doors, you will only be able to get two buttons to work.  I think this may be by design and not a defect in the opener.  You should also know that Genie openers with Intellicode can only learn and retain a limited number of remote codes.  So if you exceed that limit one of your other remotes may no longer work after programming a new one.  So, in summary, I have been able to pair both of my garage door openers with this remote.  I cannot use the third button but don't need it to open both of my garage doors with the other buttons.

I own many Invicta watches and have always been curious about Swiss Legend watches as they appear to have similar styling.  So I was happy to get the opportunity to review this watch.Like most watches, this watch arrives in an attractive presentation box that is well-padded for protection.  A small instruction booklet is included that provides instructions not only for this particular watch but also other Swiss Legend watches with different features.  Other manufacturers do this, too, and I find it somewhat difficult to sort out which instructions pertain to the watch I have.  That aside, they do contain the information needed to properly use this watch.The first thing to notice about this watch is it is absolutely beautiful.  It looks much more handsome than the photo implies.  The blue hue in photo is much more subtle on the actual watch itself, making the watch appear much more elegant than the photo suggests.  There is a lot of plastic wrap to remove from the metal band, watch face, and back of the watch.  The watch is large but not overly so and is comparable to the size of many Invicta watches for those familiar with the brand.  Counter to another reviewer's opinion, I do not think this watch is too large for the wrist of most men.  It is hefty, which in my experience is usually found in watches of higher quality construction.When I first looked at the watch I thought it wasn't running because the long second hand was not moving.  What I discovered, though, is the long second hand is used for the stop watch function, and the continuous second hand is actually located on the upper right small dial.  The other thing to know about this watch is it has a screw down crown.  This means you need to unscrew the crown by rotating it counterclockwise until it pops outward before you can adjust the time, day, and date settings.  After doing so you need to be sure to screw the crown back down for the watch to remain water resistant.  Having both day and date features is something you do not often see in watches in this price range, and it is handy being able to keep track of the day of the week. The stop watch function is operated by the two buttons at the 2:00 and 4:00 locations on the watch case.  I had a little trouble figuring out the purpose of the knurled knob on the upper left edge of the watch case but quickly discovered it adjusts the inner ring that lists the names of other countries so you can set it for the time of the country you are in and see what time it is in other countries at a glance.  The print is far too tiny to be of any use to me, but for world travelers with sharper vision than mine it may be a useful feature.  The date window is quite small, and a small magnifier would have been nice to read it more easily. So far, given the short time period I have owned the watch, it appears to keep accurate time.The stainless steel band appears to be well-constructed for a watch in this price range, and it is large enough to fit a pretty large wrist.  Like other watches, the band has removable links that allow you to adjust the band for proper fit.  I have an average sized wrist for most men and had to remove two links for it to fit my wrist well, which I had no difficulty doing with a standard watch link removal tool (available from Amazon and a very handy and inexpensive tool to have for anyone who collects watches).  The clasp on the band is a "hidden" clasp that folds inward from both ends and secures in the center making the band look like a continuous bracelet.  The clasp seems secure and is easily opened by pressing inward on the small wings that stick out on the edges of the clasp.Overall, I am very impressive with this Swiss Legend watch.  It is very stylish and attractive in appearance, and it seems to be of good construction.  It is large enough to get noticed on a man's wrist but not so large to look out of place.  The "list price" of $995.00 is absurd, but Amazon's much lower current selling price of about $156 is a very reasonable price for a watch of this quality.  It compares very favorably with Invicta watches selling in this same price range.  This watch is well worth consideration for any man wanting a stylish watch with these features in this price range.

Being someone who absolutely hates to use floss, and seeing that the Philips Sonicare Airfloss Pro is intended specifically for people like me, I was particularly anxious to try this product.The product sent to me for review arrived in a rather plain-looking cardboard box.  There was almost no product identification printed on the box.  The product itself arrives nestled inside with good protection from damage.  Included is a charging base, a single floss nozzle, and a small 2 oz. bottle of Philips BreathRx mouthwash.  Additional nozzles and mouthwash can be purchased separately (a pair of nozzles list for $8.99; 16 oz. of Philips BreathRx mouthwash is $14.99).  The included product manual states the AirFloss unit can be used with either water or mouthwash and, after initial charging for 24 hours, will operate for up to 2 weeks without needing to be recharged.  The charging base appears to be the same one Philips uses for their current line of FlexCare electric toothbrushes.After charging the AirFloss unit for a full 24 hours I filled it with my usual Scope mouthwash.  The hatch for filling opens and closes easily, and I had no trouble pouring mouthwash into the reservoir, although it fills rather quickly, and I spilled a small amount of mouthwash in the process.  Using a smaller mouthwash bottle would probably make this process easier.  The nozzle clicks into place on the top of the handle.  The opening of the nozzle should be positioned facing away from the button on the top of the handle.  There is a small button on the bottom of the handle that turns the unit on.  Several small lights with turn on to indicate the unit is on.  Once you do this the AirFloss is ready to operate.I flossed my teeth earlier the same day so I could give the AirFloss Pro a fair chance of working optimally.  After brushing my teeth I gave it a try. Starting at the center of my mouth I positioned he tip of the nozzle between my teeth at the base of my gum and pressed the top button on the unit.  As advertised, a burst of 3 quick shots of liquid was fired from the nozzle (this can be configured with the power button to use 1, 2, or 3 bursts -- the default is 3).  The liquid comes out forcefully enough that I could feel it go between my teeth and exit behind them.  I then simply moved the nozzle tip slightly to fit between the next two teeth and pressed the button again.  It did not take longer than about a minute to use it between all of my teeth, and the amount of liquid that accumulated in my mouth was maybe half the amount I would normally use to rinse and gargle with.
