She's now Camille, drowning in beige, drinking and taking drugs just to cope with what her life has become.This was the part I struggled with at first I wasn't sure how I'd get along with someone who had willingly turned into a Stepford Wife and allowed herself to be told what to eat, listen to, wear etc and I can admit early on I kept reading mainly for Gauge who is smoking hot, but I'm getting ahead of myself.When her father Tank comes to visit Gauge comes along for the ride and the second he sees Cami he's lost, she's the woman he wants. As for Cami, in Gauge she sees a real man, no pretence, falseness or excuses and she can admit to herself that she wants him, badly.It turns out all Camille needed was something or in this case someone to make her realise how much she's gradually given up.I mentioned earlier that I struggled initially with Camille, at first glance she appears weak but it doesn't take long to discover her inner fire and once again she becomes Cami.There's so many MC books available at the moment and I try to read as many as I can, this comes out on the softer side and if you'd have asked me a while ago I would have said I preferred a darker, grittier read but now I'm not so sure since I really enjoyed this, I loved all the characters and the club and I can't wait for the next one 'Shift'Is this a 5 star read? Honestly I think it's a 4 but I enjoyed it so much I'm bumping it up.

This is the first book I've read by this author, I liked the blurb and while it was the second book in this series I didn't really like the sound of the first one so I just went with this.I have a friend who once she starts a book she has to finish it, no matter how bad it is I'm not like that I start and reject so many books but this one I kept reading and I'm not exactly sure why.I didn't really like any of the characters, or the set up or the story.The two main characters Ace and Janelle met...in Ace's words :"Don't you remember how we met? I used a f***ing taser on you and took you hostage. You watched me kill your ex."Not exactly a romantic start and not the easiest foundation on which to build a new relationship.I'm not really sure what else to say, maybe I missed a lot because I skipped the first book but so many things didn't make sense to me at all. The main one being after what he did how is Jester still alive? Really I'd like to know because it completely baffled me.The multiple POV allows us to understand why Ace in particular says what he does and acts like he does but ultimately this just didn't really work for me.

This is a cute little shifter read which ticks all the boxes, hot domineering alpha, curvy female, humour, hot sexy scenes and of course a nasty female who wants him for herself.Ginger is down from New York putting 'as much physical distance as I can financially afford, between myself and that cheating, lying, useless pig of an ex-boyfriend of mine. Not that I'm bitter.'And while the Sheriff is the hottest thing she's ever seen, he's got muscles on top of muscles and has women dripping all over him after her breakup Ginger is lacking in confidence and all these women are so slim and beautiful that when he commands her to dance with him she refuses.Expecting it to have blown over by morning Ginger is amazed to discover that everyone knows about it, Winifred has a theory 'Social experiments have determined that in smaller communities, this type of salacious news travels in a manner similar to a contagious virus, only faster.'Well that and it was in the morning paper.To make amends and to keep the peace between the packs Ginger is made to apologise and is given the job of Sheriffs assistant for the next two weeks.This is an entertaining funny shifter read, well worth a try if you want to escape for a while.

While this is the second book in this series it can easily be read as a standalone but for those who read the first book 'Two Truths and a Lie' this takes place while Elena is in New York for 4 weeks.Piper has suffered through ten days of her property being vandalised and she's finally had enough so Vance, Wes and Jason from PRG Investigations are fitting a security system.Piper and Vance have always been attracted to each other but neither has acted upon it until now.I have to admit to being disappointed in this book especially after the previous one which I enjoyed.What went wrong?Firstly I felt it was a mistake to make it so obvious who the stalker was so very early on but then continue on as if we didn't know.Piper is an intelligent, independent woman but even knowing someone is after her she makes a stupid mistake and I really hate it when women are portrayed as idiots with no sense of self preservation.While I liked Piper and Vance most of the time we're not given any real background and I didn't feel any development or depth.While I liked Wes and did intend to read his story I think I've changed my mind after this.

Elena is desperate, she been on the run for a year and she's reaching breaking point. The thing is she's running from her 'fianc' who's a cop and it's proving difficult, she's been given the name of a private investigator, Jason Pierce and told he's expecting her and where to meet, the problem is when she arrives he's no idea who she and so she runs, leaving her last chance behind her.Jason may be difficult, intimidating and well, an a**hole but once he's calmed down he'll realise it was desperation in her eyes and he'll step-up.The title comes from a piece of advice Jason gives her:"Two truths and a lie, babe, he says. Makes the lie harder to pick up on."I really enjoyed this book, I liked all the characters and the way everything played out. It was actually the second book 'Play it Again' that I noticed but when I realised it was book 2 I checked out the first one and here we are.

Justin Masters is a shifter and he's in no hurry to find his mate, at twenty-eight years old he's happy with his life as it is, along with his best friend Trevor they share women, they live together and run a dairy farm together so Justin finding his mate could have devastating consequences but she's here and there's nothing he can do about it now.Kara is a gymnast and she does nothing but work so her best friends drag her out for a night and she's unbelievably attracted to a man she meets there, Justin.Justin is relieved to discover that Kara is also Trevor's mate but she's human and smells of innocence so they have there work cut out for them.This is a hot read as you'd expect from a shifter mnage and the characters are likeable enough but while there's loads of sex there's not really much else, a stalker is thrown in to try and add more to the story but for me this didn't work, there's no depth or growth and it's a story I've read so many times before.*** I checked out the next book 'Lindsey's Wolves' before reading this and was surprised to discover Lindsey is mated to Ryan and Alejandro yet Ryan was with Justin the night he met Kara, Lindsey was also there. Why didn't Ryan sense her like Justin did, did he have a bad cold or has he no sense of smell, which would be bad for a wolf, I don't understand but I'll admit I'm not curious enough to read it.

Amelia loved her husband Stephen when they married but the very next day she heard him admit that he'd only married her for her money. After just one night together she flees to her sisters now six months later she's back and preparing the house for Christmas with both families.Stephen wants his wife back, he knows he's to blame for hurting her but he's going to try and woo her back into his life.This is a lovely sweet read and I do have a weakness for a Christmas romance but at only 44 pages it's incredibly short and therefore lacks any real depth, character development or background, not that it needs it it works as it is but that's the reason for my 3 stars.

I love MC books and this one had some really great reviews but I struggled with it, I'm too picky, I know I am but once I notice something or something annoys me I just can't let it go, I wish I could it would make it so much easier.Anyone familiar with my reviews knows I don't put spoilers in very often but I can't review this book without them.#### SPOILERS ####- I did pause very early on when the map blows away and Eve then has no charge on her phone, I just think first time in a strange country by yourself when it's getting dark you'd be a bit more careful. Maybe that's just me.- It made no sense that Satan didn't just pull the trigger, it would have only taken seconds and not held him up.- And seriously why wouldn't Eve lock her door if she going to get naked on her bed in a clubhouse full of bikers- Satan provides them with footage of him and his boys torturing and then killing Lola they then dump her dead body outside the clubhouse....isn't that enough to have him put away? I can't understand why they would go to all the time and trouble of setting him up on drugs charges when they've got proof he committed murder. Is it just me because it doesn't make any sense at all.- 'I feel bad about giving Angel that sedative now. I hoped tonight he'd have told me how he felt about me' again is it me....seriously Eve wants Angel to tell her he cares Angel is desperate to tell her he cares so she sedates him. Then next morning she's unhappy because 'He didn't say anything last night' that's cos you sedated him before he had a chance.- This is just the main points the list is actually quite long.I knew before starting that this was part 1 of 2 and as it reached the end it was obvious how it would finish and again##### BIG SPOILER #####When Angel wakes from his sedation and gets to the airport -  "I'm sorry sir, that flight has just departed" She gives me an odd look. "Funny that, I could have sworn I'd already checked you in"Now I know Angel has had a rough time lately and he's still recovering but doesn't it ring any warning bells at all.I wont be continuing on to the next book because while I liked Angel and the rest of the MC there were just too many inconsistencies for me.

If I'm being honest I don't think I actually intended to read this book, after being disappointed with 'Hatred' I waited for the reviews to come out on 'Temptation' and they were very mixed so I'd more or less decided to give up on this series but lately I've been re-reading a lot of my old favourites which included 'Honor' and 'Duty' and I'd forgotten just how good these books are so having decided to continue on I skimmed 'Hatred' to get me up to date.Firstly I have to say I liked all the characters in this book, even Gianna who annoyed me in 'Hatred' her personality works surprisingly well as a secondary character, I love Luca, Aria and of course Matteo.If I liked all the players then what went wrong, frankly I'm not really sure but it was missing something it felt a bit drawn out and dare I say boring in places, there wasn't enough story and the relationship unfortunately didn't carry it for me.This said I'm glad I read it as I enjoyed keeping up with the other characters and while parts of this book were slow it picked up towards the end and finished really well.So yes I will be reading 'Vengeance' when it's out.

The blurb hooked me straight away, I quickly scanned a few of the reviews and they were good so I couldn't wait to start.Now I'll skip my usual summary since there's already a lot of reviews summarising it better than I could, I'll just give my opinion, which is mixed, very mixed.As I've said I loved the blurb and the idea behind this book and even though I read this in one sitting I always felt something was missing.Nico, I liked Nico as a man but he wasn't the character I pictured as the boss of a crime family.Angelica, she annoyed me endlessly and I got so frustrated with her inability to even consider the fact that her father obviously wasn't the man she thought he was.The story was light and I think this was part of what was missing for me.I didn't feel any real connection or chemistry between Angel and Nico.As for the ending, yes I should have checked I know it says book one but I didn't realise it was a cliffhanger and I can't honestly see me continuing on I just can't face more Angelica.

Nikolai has been my favourite character from the start so when I discovered he had a second book I couldn't wait in fact I nearly just dived straight in but since it's been a couple of years since I read the first four books I decided to re-read them and 'Sergei' first.There's so many reviews plus I'd be worried about inadvertently giving something away so I'll skip my usual summary and just give my opinion......It's fantastic and I loved it.....That's my opinion.There's so many scenes I love I couldn't pick my favourite, the story keeps you fascinated, the characters are great, the relationships, the romance everything but one scene in particular took my breath away, Nikolai has done what needed to be done and he's in bed with Viv.I just love that man.

I read and loved the first four books in this series but as often happens to me in the wait for the next book, in this case 'Sergei' I got distracted. I always intended to read this whole series but decided to wait until they're all available but the series is growing and I'm falling so far behind that I've decided to play catch-up.It's been about two years since I read the previous ones so I've just re-read them all and I have to say I loved them just as much the second time.Since there's already so many reviews I'll skip my usual summary and just give my opinion.I loved both Bianca and Sergei, they work so well together. As with the other females in this group she's intelligent, kind and beautiful, Sergei is the gentle giant, at about seven feet tall he's intimidating and it's worked well for him but it's not the life he wants,  he wants Bianca and a normal safe life but is it even a possibility for him?

This is a sweet romance between two widowed fifty year olds.Grace is 56 years old she has two children, two step-children and grandchildren but three years ago she became a widow and she doesn't know how to move on. She's never known the kind of love you read about, she was never the girl men lost their hearts over and so she married Harold Edwin Luff III, a rich older man who needed a stepmother for his two sons. She married a man who had become a friend, one who could give her security but not passion and romance.Harold is the only man she's ever kissed and he's left her incredibly rich so how can she possibly tell who wants her for herself or for her money, she's lonely and has no idea how to change it.Finally her daughter steps in and books Grace on a singles weekend away. Grace is not impressed until she meets Tray Bradshaw and she wonders if she still has a chance at love.It made a nice change to read a romance about two older people and I wish it had been longer.

This series was a bit of a surprise to me, far better than I expected and while I'm not personally a fan of short serial books, if I see what I think is going to be good I wait until all parts are available and read them as one, it also helps if like this one they're on KU.This book is where all the planning and hard work come together as Mark and Sophie try to clean up the city. There's a lot to do and most of it is dangerous but Mark is atoning for his past sins by trying to balance the scales a bit.As with the other books this has some hot scenes, the love between Mark and Sophie is obvious and the core of the book.This is a good conclusion to this series and I'm so glad that Tabby is getting her own book.

Mark and Sophie continue on with their plans. As Marcus Smiley and Sophia Warbird they are busy keeping up their public persona and building their portfolio while behind the scenes they're planning away.It's hard to see how they're going to get to live the lives they want, free and in the open but Mark is not a man to be underestimated and he's found his perfect partner in Sophie.Tabby is helping in anyway she can and I hope she finds her HEA.I'm a fairly quick reader and the mistakes in a book have to be bad for it to really spoil it for me which is why I've not mentioned them in my previous reviews but this series really needs editing, I don't know if this book was worse than the others or if I just noticed it more but even the first paragraph of this book has:'It was quite a change from being plain old Sophie Snow'She was Sophie White not Snow, he was Mark Snow. It may seem a bit picky but surely this should have been picked up.Anyway mistakes aside it's straight onto the fifth and final book for me.

Mark and Sophie have made decisions on their future, Mark has done a lot of bad stuff and they've decided to balance it out a bit. Sophie is fully on board and learning fast as Mark trains her in weapons, knives, dirty fighting, surveillance and tracking etc.After lots of hard work, surgery and planning they return to the U.S. Earlier than they'd originally planned but ready.I have to say this series has surprised me at every turn, the first book was so much better than I expected, the second didn't just build on Mark and Sophie's relationship like I'd expected and this book is again so much more, we have the romance and the sex but we also get the planning and action.I have to say in the interests of leaving a totally honest review there was one part that I just couldn't make sense of, Sophie suggests something and considering the situation they find themselves in it seemed ridiculous or maybe it's just me.It's straight onto book 4 for me.

The first book completely surprised me and I loved it, this one also managed to surprise me.Sophie is the hardworking medical student who's working two jobs to get by, in the previous book she meets Mark and is instantly drawn to him.The attraction between these two is off the charts and they just can't stay away from each other. We discovered what Mark does for a living but as far as Sophie is concerned he's a freelance troubleshooter. By the end of this book Sophie will know a whole lot more about Mark as she gets dragged into his world.This book didn't go at all how I expected, I thought Sophie and Mark would spend this book having loads of sex and just getting to know each other, ok so they do have loads of sex and they do get to know each other, very well in fact but there's so much more to this book.I know after discovering who Mark was I should have expected more and I think I did but just not this soon, so it's straight onto book 3 for me.

New York 1901 is a worker placement game set in the world of construction and skyscrapers at the turn of the century.  On their turns, players can draw a colored card that matches lots on the board, players can then build buildings with Tetris-like shapes.  As the game progresses, players can demolish their existing buildings and build the next generation of buildings.  Each time a building is built, points are scored.  Eventually, players can build an epic skyscraper for an epic amount of points.  Whoever has the most points at the end of the game wins.  The game that New York 1901 reminds me of most of all is Ticket to Ride.  It's a fairly light, accessible game that nevertheless offers a healthy dose of strategy and fun.  This is the kind of game you pull out for your friends who aren't really into niche gaming in order to introduce them into the hobby, and its a game that you and your niche-gamer friends will want to pull out every once in a while for a great gaming experience.

So, I screwed up.  I thought I saw that this was for an iPhone 6 Plus, but it is not.  It looks sturdy enough, and feels good to the touch.  Good colors and fit, I just wish I'd paid closer attention to the label.

I purchased this product to cut plastic pieces out of their sprues for board games.  After unsuccessful attempts with scissors and the always disastrous twist-and-pull method I needed something more reliable so that I wouldn't ruin them.  I couldn't believe how easy I was able to cut them out with this product.  If you enjoy board games, or are into modeling, this product will serve you well.

I'm not a big fan of wrestling.  It's just not my thing, though I have many friends who enjoy it.  I am, however, a huge fan of Gale Force Nine, which created such amazing board games as Firefly: The Game, Sons of Anarchy: Men of Mayhem, and Homeland: The Game.  With such an outstanding track record, I though I'd give WWE Superstar Showdown a chance.First of all, three stars does not mean I think it's a bad game.  There is a lot I like about this game.  Like Gale Force Nine's other games, this one is super-thematic, and really captures (as much as a board game can) the feel of professional wrestling.  There are different scenarios that players can choose from to mix things up, and in a two player game each player selects one of the wrestlers- both his figure and his unique deck of cards.  Players place three tactic cards before them, and they reveal each once simultaneously, then compare the results.  There is a rock, paper, scissors mechanic to the combat, (grapple beats strike, strike beats maneuver, maneuver beats grapple, slam beats everything), and the winner of each card contest can take the actions on the card like movement, power, or setup.  The loser must surrender cards equal to the winner's power card (plus any setup from the previous card), unless he played a block card.  Once a player can no longer play cards because his deck has been depleted, he is out.  There are also many other thematic elements to the game, like pinning an opponent, throwing an opponent out of a ring, and more.Despite some generally fun play, the game never really captured my imagination.  Part of that is because of the theme (again, I'm not one much for professional wrestling), but also because the "rock, paper, scissors" mechanic got old fast, and meant that any pre-planned strategy went right out the window as soon as combat began, (see "Fury of Dracula: Third Edition" for a rock, paper, scissors combat mechanic that works really well).  There are fun choices in the game, but in the end it felt too random.  Fans of professional wrestling, I suspect, will really enjoy this offering from Gale Force Nine, but it just left me a little flat.  If a friend suggested playing this I would, and I'd probably have fun, but it's not a game I think I'll ever be suggesting.

This Swiss Legend Men's watch is beautiful.  It really is quite stunning.  The Problem with it, as other reviewers have noted, is it's size.  It is really, really quite big and heavy.  I'm not a very large fellow, and the watch feels kind of clumsy on my wrist.  I think a larger man could make this work, but as for myself, I don't know that I'll be wearing this all that often.  From the photograph you rally can't get a sense of just how massive this timepiece is.  Again- it's beautiful, but it's just not as practical as I hoped it would be given its size and weight.

Fury of Dracula, 2nd Edition, was one of my favorite games of all time.  As a serious gamer and Youtuber, I recently completed my top 100 games of all time, and Fury of Dracula came in 3rd place.  It's a tense chase across Europe as four vampire hunters attempt to corner and defeat the evil Count Dracula before he can create an army of the undead.  I bought my copy from Amazon a few months before it went out of print in 2012- and I was so glad I did.  For the past few years there has been a renewed interest in the game, particularly by those who had never had a chance to play it before.  Many called upon Fantasy Flight Games to reprint the game, but the company remained silent on the issue.  That is until a few months ago when Fantasy Flight Games announced a brand new third edition that promised streamlined play and easier to learn rules.I was a little reluctant when I heard that Fantasy Flight Games was planning on streamlining this game.  I loved so much about it, that how could they possibly make it better.  The more I thought about it, however, the more I realized that the game did have some clunky rules, and perhaps a new edition could indeed simplify a few game concepts.For those of you new to the game, Fury of Dracula is a contest for 2-5 players.  One player takes on the role of the evil Count Dracula, and the others take on the roles of the vampire hunters form Bram Stoker's historic novel- Abraham van Helsing, Mina Harker, Dr. Seward, & Lord Godalming.  The hunters begin in various cities around Europe, each connected to other cities by road and rail lines, then Dracula can choose his secret starting location.  As opposed to the second edition, in this edition the hunters a daytime action and a nighttime action.  Hunters can only move between cities during the day.  They can move once per road, or by reserving a train ticket (another action) they can potentially move up to three spaces by rail by drawing a random ticket token.  (This is different from the second edition, where players had to roll a dice to determine rail movement, and could be quite frustrated when they were "detained over papers"- losing a turn).  If players enter a location where Dracula has been, Dracula must reveal the card from his trail.  Players can attempt to resupply while in a big city by drawing an item card, then drawing an event card.  If they resupply during the day, they can draw the event card from the top of the deck- if it's a Dracula event card they can discard it- but at night they must draw from the bottom of the deck, and if it is a Dracula event card they must give it to Dracula.After both the hunter day and night action, Dracula can move.  He secretly selects a location card from his deck and places it on the board.  Previous location cards slide to the right.  Unlike the second edition, where Dracula used cardboard encounter tokens from a pool, here Dracula has an encounter deck, from which he draws cards to lay down upon his location cards in order to set traps for the hunters, and in order to mature his vampires.  Combat is also streamlined in this version.  Where in the second edition players would roll dice and then play cards to resolve the winner's and loser's effects, here players both just play cards simultaneously.  These cards represent tactics available to Dracula and the hunters.  Typically, there are six rounds of combat unless someone escapes first.  There is a real "rock, scissors, paper" feel to combat, but it can be incredibly intense, and surprisingly I liked it a lot better than combat in the second edition.Finally, Dracula's victory conditions have changed somewhat.  In the second edition, Dracula had a vampire track that went up to six.  If Dracula matured vampires the track advanced, or if he knocked out a hunter it advanced.  The game could take a surprisingly long time to get to six, and this game could potentially go on for 8 hours or more (though that was uncommon).  Now, Dracula has an "Influence Track" that runs to 13- his victory condition, and he can gain influence by maturing vampires and knocking out hunters, but in another important way as well.  In the middle of the time tracker is a sun face.  After each game "week" a evil third to this face is added.  After three game "weeks" the evil face is completed, and despair among the hunters takes hold.  Each turn thereafter leads to Dracula's marker advancing by three along the influence track.  This adds an important timer to the game which can keep it from going too long.  It is still at least a 2-3 hour game, and can go longer depending upon the players' analysis paralysis problems, but the game just seems to move quicker than its predecessor.All told, this is a brilliant new edition of a wonderful board game.  Fury of Dracula is one of those games that serious gamers can really sink their teeth into (pun intended), and offers some really great board game experiences.  Many games will come down to the wire, (a game I played on Halloween came down to Dracula with just one health point left, and he was able to escape just as his influence track hit 13), and you and your friends will be laughing throughout.  I'm a little disappointed with the aesthetic here.  I do prefer the artwork on the cards, the board, the box, and the overall visual presentation of the second edition, but as far as game play goes, Fury of Dracula third edition is the winner hands down.  I'm really excited that with this new edition more and more gamers will have the opportunity to enjoy this great game!  I cannot recommend it enough.Review copy provided.

This food dehydrator is a pretty smart looking package.  Digital displays, metal trays, and relatively light weight.  The instruction manual, however, is not as clear as I would have liked, and frankly, I'm still confused about how exactly it is supposed to operate.  I recently tried to make some banana chips and made a hash of it.  The manual talks about the two different settings, yet offers little explanation of just what they do and why they are different.  That was nothing, however, compared to actually trying to set the thing.  The manual stated that you needed to put it in raw mode, so I pressed the button to set it, but it kept moving back and forth between that mode and the other, and would not let me just set it for raw.  Am I missing something?  I'm sure this item is very useful if you no how to use it, but unfortunately, I'm having a hard time figuring it out.

Osprey Games' They Come Unseen is a game a hidden movement set in the Cold War.  While it plays up to five players, it works best with two or four.  One player (or team) takes on the role of two NATO submarines in the Barents Sea, while the other player commands two Soviet destroyers, and three logistic ships.  The subs and the destroyers each have player boards, which feature dials to track battery and depth for the subs, and fuel and salvos for the Soviets.  The NATO player has access not only to the main board, but also to a smaller board hidden behind a large player screen.  Whenever the NATO player submerges one of his subs, he puts it on the hidden board so that he can keep track of it while the Soviet player searches for him.At the beginning of the game the NATO player selects four random cards that feature Soviet bases- these are his targets.  Since there are six total bases, most of them will be targets, but the Soviet player has no idea which ones to defend and which ones are red herrings.  The NATO player then moves his subs- every point of movement wears down his battery power- and he may surface to recharge his batteries, surface in a Soviet base to destroy it, or lay mines on the hidden board, (the NATO players only form of attack).  The Soviet player then moves his destroyers, which costs fuel points, then they can drop a sonar net to try to locate the subs.  Two clear tiles are laid down with colored webs.  If a sub is beneath one of the colors, he must call out "Contact Yellow" or whatever the color is.  The Destroyer can then launch his salvos, trying to guess the exact spot and depth of the sub.  He must pick the correct spot, but if he's close on depth he can still wound the sub.  If he is exactly correct, the sub takes a hit.  If the sub is hit three times, it is knocked out of the game.  The Soviet player can also move his logistical ships which carry ammo and fuel from one base to another, and one of the ships can resupply the destroyers at sea.  If a sub destroys a base all the fuel and ammo in it are destroyed.  Since ammo and fuel are limited, you will want to use the logistical ships to distribute these resources.Weather also plays a factor as storms move over the board and affect the players' ability to move and take actions.  If the NATO player successfully destroys all of his objectives, he wins the game.  If the Soviet player sinks both subs, he wins the game.They Come Unseen has some problems.  Its components- specifically the ship counters- are a little weak.  The game would have benefited from plastic minis.  The problem is, virtually all of the Soviet ships look alike.  Second, the rulebook is not easy to follow, and can be downright confusing in some areas.  The rules refer to "surface" and "periscope depth" interchangeably, without any explanation that they are the same thing.  If you don't know that they are the same, you might get confused.  Also, it would be nice if the player boards could more easily track information, since Soviets can move, take an action, then move again.  There are a few other little fiddly things that it would be nice if there was a way track, but its not here.Criticism aside, They Come Unseen is a very fun game.  It's a game of hidden movement not unlike Fury of Dracula or Letters From Whitechapel (though those two games are superior, in my opinion).  What is cool here is the cold war theme that really comes through in gameplay.  Each move, players are desperate to stay hidden or locate their prey.  Games typically last about 90-120 minutes, and they usually come down to the wire.  I've had some really intense games where it came down to the last few moves to decide the winner.  If you like tight contests and tense, hidden movement mechanics, you may want to check out They Come Unseen.  I'm only rating this game with three stars, because of the above criticism, but that does not mean that this is a bad game by any means, merely that I think the presentation could have been better.  I have no doubt that for the right kind of gamer They Come Unseen will scratch an itch!Review Copy Provided

This watch is absolutely beautiful.  More than simply a timepiece, it feels like jewelry.  Once a few of the links were removed it fit great and rests easy on the wrist.  It comes with easy to follow instructions for setting and maintaining it.  This is the kind of watch that people comment on when you where it, impressed with such a beautiful and functional timepiece.

I use this Amazon Basics tripod for shooting my board game reviews for your youtube channel.  I have two Canon Rebel cameras, and each came with their own lightweight tripod.  I've used one of them for over a year and a half, but it finally fell apart on me.  I went ahead and purchased this tripod as I've been pleased with Amazon Basics products before.  I wasn't disappointed.  In fact, this tripod is far superior to the two tripods that came with my cameras.  It is a bit heavier, but it is also a bit sturdier- I like that.  Easy to use and manipulate, this Amazon Basics tripod is everything I hoped for.

The Hernfar Guardians army pack expansion for Battlelore, 2nd Edition, from Fantasy Flight Games, expands the Daqan faction and brings some fun new extras this great game.  First, there are new units such as the Battlemages, the Ironclad, and the large Siege Golem.  Each has their own new and unique abilities.  This pack also comes with the Crystal Spire terrain tile.  When units start their activation on this tile they gain one additional dice during combat.  There is also rules for shielding, which allow some units to essentially absorb a hit before suffering damage.  A new lore deck is included as well, which can be used instead of the deck from the base game.  New scenarios are also provided.Lovers of Battlelore, 2nd Edition will have a field day with this fun new army pack, which provides many new options for the game.  It seemed as though Fantasy Flight Games was not going to support Battlelore, considering that the base game came out in late 2013.  It's really good to see that this game is still on their radar.  It should be on yours.Review copy provided.

Fauna is a game in which players attempt to bet on where animals are found around the world, as well as animals' other characteristics.  An animal card is shown and players then place markers on a geographic location somewhere on the world map.  Players score points for correctly guessing where the animal is located, or if they placed a marker adjacent to the region.  Players can also bet on things like the animals' weight, length, and tail length.  Several rounds are played and once one player reaches a certain score based on the number of players, he or she wins.Fauna is a generally fun educational game, that children should really take to.  Adults will be less impressed.  It almost seems that it would be easier if players simply guessed aloud the info, then revealed the cards. It really is a rather simple game.  Still, people are likely to learn a thing or two about nature and geography with this game.  Another complaint- as a member of the Amazon Vine program I received a review copy of this game.  Usually vine review copies are new.  This game, however, was pretty beaten up.  The box was weathered and had a "demo" sticker pasted on it, and the board itself looked as though it has seen some mileage.  This is curious because all of the animal cards were still wrapped in plastic.

Forbidden Stars is Fantasy Flight Games' latest title set in the grim Warhammer 40K universe.  In this grand strategic wargame, which plays in about 2-3 hours, two to four players take on different factions like the Ultramarines- enhanced humans who fight for their corpse emperor; Orks, brutal space pillagers; the Eldar, a species with advanced technology and psychic abilities; and the Chaos Space Marines, evil humans corrupted by the warp.  Each faction has its own faction cards, combat deck, event deck, and upgrade deck, as well as mountains of plastic spaceships and land forces.  The board itself is made up of tiles "systems", depending upon the number of players.  Each system contains worlds and voids- spaces for land forces and spaceships.  Scattered throughout the systems are each factions objective tokens, forcing conflict as players attempt to gain their tokens.The game plays out in a series of up to eight rounds, each round containing three phases.  The first phase is planning.  Players each place four command tokens on systems where they have units or adjacent systems.  During the next phase, player take turns resolving the tokens they have placed.  Since tokens are stacked in each system, players must plan carefully.  Only the topmost token in a system can be activated, and if a player has no tokens on top of a system he must wait until one is next before he can resolve it.  The command tokens allow players to deploy, essentially allowing them to build units and structures (factories, cities, and citadels); the dominate token allows players to exploit the resources of their worlds and gain special tokens that can help in building and combat; the strategy token allows players to upgrade their combat decks or gain upgrade cards, giving them special advantages; and the advance token can be used to move units from one system to another, or move units within systems.  In order to move players must have a chain of land units and spaceships from point of departure to point of arrival.When one or more units enter a world or void where an opponents units exist, combat ensues.  Both players total up the amount of dice they roll based on their units.  The dice can roll a gun symbol, your attack power; a shield symbol, your defense value; and wings, your morale.  After drawing five cards from your combat deck, each player then selects one card to play- first the attacker plays and resolves, then the defender.  Assuming one side isn't wiped out, combat goes three rounds.  At the end of three rounds, if neither side is completely eliminated, morale is used to decide the battle.  Other factors can be included in combat as well, such as reinforcement tokens.The game lasts until one player has captured objective tokens equal to the number of players, at which point he or she wins the game.  Alternatively, if no one has fulfilled this condition, the game ends after eight rounds and whoever has the most objective tokens wins.  The are a few more rules here like warp storm movement and event cards, but that is the gist of it.Forbidden Stars is a game that Warhammer 40K has been calling for.  It is an Axis & Allies-type strategic adventure game that is deeply thematic and offers more than just dice-chucking battle after dice-chucking battle.  Each faction plays very differently, with their units and abilities, and makes for some fun asymmetrical encounters.  What is really great about this game is that it doesn't allow players to turtle.  If you want to win, you have to attack.  Players who just sit there building up units will definitely lose.  In that sense the game is deeply thematic as well as fun and engaging.  The Warhammer universe is all about war, and the game really reflects that.  Combat is fun and engaging, as players must constantly make choices about their cards and how best to mitigate their dice rolls.  Also really fun is the way in which players can customize their decks, building them up for later advantage.  It's a fun deck building aspect that really adds a lot to the game and a mechanic that one would not expect from this big box light wargame.The game, of course, is a beautiful production for start to finish.  The artwork, the cards, the tokens, the minis, the board- it's all first rate.  Once again Fantasy Flight Games has demonstrated why they are a leader in board game design and execution.  This game follows in the footsteps of other great Fantasy Flight Games productions like Twilight Imperium, Battlestar Galactica, Star Wars: Armada, and Star Wars: Imperial Assault.  Top notch components all the way.My only significant complaint with the game has to do with combat.  Combat, while fun for players engaged in it, can take a while.  In 3-4 player games this means a lot of sitting around.  A lot of games have downtime, but this is a game that keeps all players fairly engaged throughout- except when other players are in combat.  This is too bad, and perhaps this is something that the inevitable expansions will address down the line.  Still, this is a relatively minor complaint compared with everything that this game gets right.All told, Fantasy Flight Games'  Forbidden Stars is another fantastic board game that will keep you and your friends riveted throughout.  It's just a lot of fun!Review copy provided.

"The Salt of the Earth" is a wonderful documentary about an extraordinary photographer and amazing human being.  Wim Wenders co-directs this film about Sebastiao Salgado, a man who studied economics, but ended up traveling the world in search of the human condition through his art.  The film chronicles Salgado's projects to photograph the peoples of Central and South America, the genocides in Africa, the firefighters putting out Kuwaiti oil fires in the wake of the 1991 Gulf War, the world's workers, the natural world, and more.  The film also documents the successful efforts of Salgado and his wife to replant the rainforests of their home in Brazil.Wenders portrays Salgado as a real-life Indiana Jones adventurer.  The treasure Salgado finds, however, is the rich experience of humanity and the planet Earth.  The film never strays too strongly into politics, though it's easy to see what Salgado's views are on a myriad of topics.  Regardless of your own political standpoint, you can't help but be moved by the man's adventure, and, more importantly, his photographs.  "The Salt of the Earth" is simply a remarkable film that features Salgado's beautiful, haunting images throughout.

Heir to the Jedi is an adequate Star Wars novel, hitting most of the right notes yet still falling flat a lot of the time.  The story takes place after the events of A New Hope, but before The Empire Strikes Back.  Fresh from his victory at Yavin, young Luke Skywalker is sent by Admiral Ackbar on a mission to open up new supply channels to the Rebel Alliance.  He soon finds himself hooking up with the beautiful daughter of a galactic industrialist with her own grudge against the Empire.  Eventually, the two are assigned to help an alien cryptographer defect from the Empire to the Alliance, and soon have Imperial agents hot on their trail.The book has some clever moments and tense scenes as Luke and his allies face off against the empire, pirates, and deadly alien creatures.  It's fun to see Luke's naive optimism, believing that his father was a great man, struck down by the evil Darth Vader.  The book also offers some decently drawn characters that add to the narrative.  The problem with Heir to the Jedi is that it never really feels that engaging.  Part of that is due to the fact that you know where it is heading ultimately, not only in terms of Luke's overall story arc within the saga, but also within the book itself.  There are not a lot of surprises, and it's easy to spot who will live and who won't make it.Heir to the Jedi is a good Star Wars novel, it's just not a great one.

X-Men: Mutant Revolution, from WizKids, is a re-theming of Gale Fore Nine's game Spartacus.  In X-Men, 3-4 players take on the role of a mutant school, each with its own unique vision for mutants, and is headed by either Storm, Cyclops, Wolverine, or Magneto.  A game round takes place over a series of phases where players bid "hope coins," the game's currency, to buy new heroes and students for each school.  There is also a plot phase where player can team up to play cards against other players or work together for mutual benefit.  The final phase is the mission phase, where players set their character tokens out on the board and battle each other, or attempt to overcome some unique objective.  When players' characters are placed on the board, three dice are placed on the board as well, and turned to the character's stats- attack, defense, and movement.  The numbers indicated how many dice are rolled for attack and defense, and when players engage in combat they compare their rolls, from highest to lowest, creating a "dice string."  When characters take hits they must lower their dice stats.  The player that wins the mission gets a reward.  The goal of the game is to be the first to gain six revolution points.X-Men: Mutant Revolution is a pretty good game, though there are a few criticisms.  First of all the game is too long.  It would be better if it was a 1- 1.5 hour game, instead of a 2+ hour game.  The "teams" players build rarely feel like a team, as players only field one hero or student during missions.  Additionally, the game can come across as a little fiddly with all the steps each round.  Having said all of that, this game is fun.  Players use bidding dials to bid for characters and to become the mission leader, that resemble the dials from Star Trek: Attack Wing.  The Bidding can get quite intense.  The "take that" element during the plot phase is a lot of fun, too, as a players' best laid plans can go up in smoke if players band together against him.  There is a real negotiation mechanic going on here that is a always welcome in games- and it may be the most engaging part of X-Men: Mutant Revolution.  Also, while some of the missions are so-so, some of them are really cool.  The combat between players, when it takes place, is a whole lot of fun.In summation, while the game does have some drawbacks, it is generally a fun and engaging game that players will really enjoy.  Fans of X-Men comics and books will have a field day as their favorite characters come to live on the board and with the cards.  If you like X-Men, you'll definitely wand to check this one out.Review copy provided.

In "Star Wars: Lords of the Sith", author Paul S. Kemp has written a engaging and generally enjoyable adventure story.  The books centers around events on the world of Ryloth, home of the Twi'leks, several years after the events in "Star Wars Episode III: Revenge of the Sith."  Dreaming of a Ryloth free from the empire's yoke, several Twi'lek freedom fighters learn that Emperor Palpatine and his minion Darth Vader will soon visit their world.  They then prepare for a daring plan to assassinate the two agents of evil.  Soon, Vader and Palpatine find themselves alone in the forests of Ryloth.  Battling horrendous monsters, Imperial officers with their own agendas, and the freedom fighters themselves, The Emperor and Vader must use all of their cunning to survive.  But just as importantly, can one Sith ever truly trust another?While "Star Wars: Lords of the Sith" is a good Star Wars title featuring the Emperor and Vader, it never quite lives up to thrilling adventure and intrigue of books like "Star Wars: Tarkin" or "Star Wars: Darth Plagueis."  Those two books were brilliant explorations of the dark side's greatest champions that meshed brilliantly with the wider Space Opera of the franchise.  "Lords of the Sith" offers some of this, but the story just feels much smaller.  Rather than a sweeping galactic adventure with grand political overtones, Kemp's book is more intimate, focusing perhaps too much on the Twi'leks and the politics of Ryloth than on the Emperor and Vader.  Still, the book is fun and fans should really enjoy it.

This media software largely works as advertized, effectively organizing and presenting DVDs, CDs, and more.  Interface is easy to use- both on PC and through tablet devices.  Really, there are no complaints about the software itself- but- modern Windows and Mac software do about the same thing.  I don't know that this product is really a step up from other basic factory software on your computer.  It does a good job for what it does, a very good job in fact, but so do these other systems.  All told, it's a good product, but I'm just not sure if it's worth it.

This necklace, which features a silver heart with a silver "Mom" and a five-petaled flower within, is absolutely beautiful.  The flower features purple amethyst stones as petals, and contrasts wonderfully with the silver.  The ornament rests from a sturdy silver chain, and the whole presentation is remarkably stunning.  Perfect for a wife or mom in your life, this piece of jewelry will no doubt see a lot of use.

My girlfriend absolutely loved this gold piece.  The pendent, which is a circular "hope" design, is beautiful and really catches the eye.  The pendent isn't very large, roughly the size of a penny, but it really stands out at its place below the neck.  The chain is small, and virtually invisible, making the pendent even more striking.  This is really a nice a piece of jewelry that women will love to wear and men will love to see their women wear.

The first time I opened the package for this Juicy Fruit Starburst Gum, the scent of juicy fruit permeated the air, hitting me like a 2x4- a sweet, delicious 2x4 of goodness.  What can I say, this gum just fills up your mouth with strawberry flavor and one has a hard time believing that it is sugar free.  With 15 sticks to each package, and 10 packages to the pack, this is a pretty good deal.  I really enjoyed this Starburst gum quite a bit.

Braven's wireless speaker is easy to use and looks great as well.  The speaker boasts as easy interface with large buttons on either end, for power, volume, pairing/activate call/pause music, etc...  It also boats audio in and audio out jacks, a USB charging port, and a removable cap.  It's small but looks great, and delivers a terrific sound quality.  If you're in the market for a wireless Bluetooth speaker, you might want to give this Braven speaker a try.  I think you'll like it.

This Travelpro expandable suitcase is a great compact travel storage item.  Lots of space and compartments highlight this sleek, black design.  The handle easily pulls out from the suitcase and retracts easily as well.  The thing that really strikes me is the durability.  Traveling a lot in a car, this thing can take the punishment of shifting around without looking too much the worse for wear.  I really like this travel suitcase and would recommend it.

Having never played XCOM the video game, I didn't know what to expect from XCOM The Board Game.  Knowing that Fantasy Flight Games was behind it, however, made picking up this game a no brainer.  In XCOM The Board Game one to four players take on specific roles in order to fight an alien invasion of Earth.  One player plays the Commander, who must keep track of the budget, deploy interceptor aircraft to fight UFOs, and choose which Crisis card the team will have to deal with.  The Chief Scientist must choose which tech to research and how many resources will be devoted to each research.  The Squad Leader will be responsible for selecting missions, deploying four different types of soldiers to accomplish the missions, and deploying soldiers to defend XCOM's headquarters.  The Central Officer is in charge in satellites, which are used to combat UFOs in orbit.  All players have starter cards and can gain techs which allow them to use special abilities to help to the team.  Everything the team deploys, from interceptors, to soldiers, to scientists, to satellites, must be paid for out of the budget, and so players must constantly negotiate with the rest of the team for everything they want to do.The Central Officer has another major responsibility in this game- managing an app on a tablet, cell phone, or laptop (which is downloadable for free from FFG).  The game plays out in two phases- a timed phase and a resolution phase.  During the timed phase, the app tells the Central Officer what action can be taken by which player, and gives them a strict time limit to accomplish their task.  The tasks may be: research tech in a specific slot, an alien invades the HQ, interceptors must be deployed, UFOs appear over continents or in orbit, a new mission must selected, and more.  The Central Officer must relay all of this information as quickly as possible to the other players, and make sure they are not taking too long.  During the resolution phase, players then resolve all of the tasks that they set in motion in the timed phase.  Players roll dice in order to get success for tech, knocking down UFOs, killing aliens in the base, and more.  Players roll XCOM D6 dice, which features two success symbols on, as well as a numbered D8, which functions for the alien enemy.  When you fail a dice roll, you can roll again, but it becomes increasingly likely that you will be defeated because with each non-success you move the threat marker up one space (from 1 to 5).  If the D8 is equal to or lower than the threat marker, it is a fail and you lose the scientists, interceptors, soldiers, satellites, etc...  If, at the end of the resolution phase, there are UFOs left over continents, that continent is moved forward on the panic track (if two nations make it to the orange section of the panic track- the players lose the game).  If there are any aliens left over in the base, the base damage marker moves forward (if ever this marker reaches the end- the players lose the game- and there are also other negative consequences for it hitting red points).  Players are working toward being able to complete the "Final Mission" and the app will tell you when you are able to do this (based on completing other missions and other criteria).  Once the Final Mission is completed successfully, the players win the game.XCOM the Board Game is a thrilling adventure that offers a fun yet stressful timed component.  Not all of the decisions in the game are in the timed phase, so players won't be stressed out too much (like in, say, Space Alert or Damage Report).  Rather, decisions of significance are equally divided between the timed phase and the resolution phase.  The app is really fun and adds a lot to the game, without it being gimicky.  It draws players into the high tech feel of the game, while at the same time giving players just enough time to negotiate with other players about how much money can be spent on each task, and then making those decisions.  Essentially, what you do during the timed phase is really about setting you up for the resolution phase, getting yourselves into the best position to deal with the multiple crises the game presents.  The dice rolling during the resolution phase adds a push-your-luck mechanic that may cost the team, but the potential rewards are just too much to ignore.All told, XCOM The Board Game succeeds brilliantly in creating a tense, engaging, and incredibly fun experience.  Each player will get sucked into their role, and the unique game challenge that that presents.  At the same time, all players know they have to work together or suffer catastrophic defeat.  Fun, inventive game play, really well designed cooperative mechanics, and a great theme make XCOM The Board Game a winner!

Murano, from Mayfair Games, is a fun mid-level eurogame that takes place in Venice.  Two to four players work to gain the most victory points by manipulating gondolas around the board, building buildings by placing tiles on islands, and various other actions.  On a player's turn he or she may move a gondola along the track around the board, but must stop before entering a space with another gondola.  Whatever space the gondola lands allows players to take a specific action- from collecting building tiles, building buildings and roads, producing glass in factories, selling goods to customers, and more.  Also, an important action is drawing character cards and placing gondoliers on the islands.  At the end of the game, if certain conditions on an island have been met for held character cards, and the player has a gondolier on that island, he or she may spend that gondolier to capitalize on the character card.  Whoever has the most victory points at the end of the game wins.The above, of course, is just the bare bones of the rules for Murano, and there really is a lot more to it than that.  The game is very interesting as it really forces players to decide which gondolas to move in order to do the actions that are required for victory.  Players' strategies must evolve over the course of the game as new character cards are drawn and considered, and players will end up fighting over resources and islands.  Though the game initially looks rather intimidating, it is actually a very fun and relatively quick light to medium level eurogame.  This is a perfect game for families and those who prefer indirect conflict in their board games.  Very fun.

Dead of Winter, from Plaid Hat Games, is a semi-cooperative board game with a hidden traitor element.  The game takes place in the middle of a zombie apocalypse, as survivors have made a haven for themselves at a place called simply The Colony.  There, plagued by shortages and fighting the bitter winter cold, they hope to make their stand.  In addition to The Colony board, several location cards are set out, featuring places like the Gas Station, the Hospital, the School, and more.  Players choose, either together or randomly, a scenario and place it in the appropriate spot on The Colony board.  Each scenario features a group victory condition that all players must complete in order to win.  The Colony board also features a round track and a morale track, with each scenario noting the starting space on each track.  If ever either track gets down to zero, the players lose.  Also, each player is given his or her own objective cards.  Essentially, each player must complete his or her specific objectives as well as the scenario's objective if they are to win the game.  Players must help each other to complete the main objective, but must also work secretly to complete their own private objective.  As though this was devious enough, one of the players may receive a Betrayal card, making them a secret traitor who works against The Colony's interests in order to win.At the beginning of the first player's turn he or she must resolve a Crisis card, some unique problem that players must all contribute cards to in order to beat it by the end of the round.  If they do not beat the Crisis, something bad will happen to The Colony, most likely a loss of morale.  Then, players take their individual turns.  All players having rolled dice at the beginning of the round players can spend their dice rolls to take certain actions like killing zombies, searching for equipment at locations, or taking out the trash (seriously- an important part of the game).  Players can also take actions without spending dice like moving to locations, trading cards with other players, playing cards, and more.  Whenever a player moves to a location or kills a zombie, however, they most roll the exposure dice, which will either wound them, frostbite them (which makes them progressively sicker), or zombie bite them, which will kill them and spread the infection.Also, at the beginning of each players' turn, the player to the right will draw a Crossroads card and read the top part secretly.  If conditions on the board match conditions on the card, the rest of the card is read, providing a new narrative element and leading to a decision.  The active player can choose between two options- something good with a cost- or all the players may be required to vote on the question.  The game ends if either track hits zero, or if the scenario objective is met.  Each player checks to see if he or she has met their own secret conditions to determine winners.Dead of Winter is a fantastic game that is incredibly innovative on a lot of levels.  First of all the whole dynamic between completing the individual objectives and the scenario objectives is a lot of fun.  Players do not know if other players are acting in their own interests or in the good of the whole.  Additionally, with the possibility of one player being a traitor, the game really succeeds in creating an air of paranoia, perhaps better than any board game since Battlestar Galactica.  Where the game really shines, however, is in the Crossroads system.  The idea that on any player's turn a dynamic new narrative element appears requiring a tough choice is just fantastic, and really takes Dead of Winter from being a good game to being a great game.A game that revels in tough choices, fun narrative play, an eerie theme, and paranoia so thick you can choke on it, Dead of Winter is easily one of 2014's best games and a wonderful tabletop experience.  You will want to check this one out for sure!

Argent: The Consortium, from Level 99 Games, is a worker placement game in which players vie to become the new chancellor of a magical university.  Essentially, players must learn who is voting for the new chancellor, and then adopt strategies to get their vote.  The voters have cards that say that they will vote for the player with the most X tokens, or the most Y tokens, or the most gold, or the most spells, or the most etc..  These voter cards are placed face down.  On a player's turn, he or she may take actions to gain those items and tokens, or look under the voter cards to determine who is voting for what.  A worker placement game, players place their figures on spaces in rooms throughout the university, and each space allows players to take special actions.  The order in which figures are placed in the rooms can have an impact as well, allowing for more or less abilities.  Players each have factions that offer individual strengths and abilities, and each player has different colored figures that can perform different actions even as they perform the action of the room they are on.  When the game ends players reveal the voter cards and see who the voters elect the new chancellor.  There is A LOT more to it than that, but this is just a basic overview of the rules for Argent: The Consortium.First of all, Argent: The Consortium is a huge game.  Make sure you have a ton of space to play on, because you'll have university tiles, player boards, bell tower cards, spell cards, item cards, and more all over the board.  Seriously, this may be the largest game in terms of sheer playing space that I have ever played- and I've played Arkham Horror with expansions and Firefly: The Game!  Game play itself is a lot of fun, as players are bombarded with options and potential strategies.  There is really a ton of things that you can do in this game, and a ton of things that can happen to you.  In this sense, Argent: The Consortium's strength is also its biggest weakness.  Players who suffer from analysis paralysis will really suffer in this game (as will those who play with them- waiting for their turn), and even seasoned players will agonize over the best path to victory.  Still, this does mean that the game has significant replayability.With great components, stunning artwork, fun competition, and a great thematic experience overall, Argent: The Consortium's strengths outweigh it's weaknesses.  If you like challenging and engaging worker placement games with lots going on, you will want to pick up this game!

Armada Invincible, from Zvezda, is a game of naval warfare and strategy set in the 16th century.  One player takes on the role of the English and the other the Spanish in the time of the Spanish Armada.  Each player receives a ship card and a command card, along with a dry erase marker to write on them.  Each player also receives a ship model which must be assembled before play.  Players then pick a scenario from the scenario book.  Simultaneously, players write down their orders on their command card- low mast, half mast, full mast- which give them movement tokens, and in which direction they are moving or turning.  Wind is set before the scenario, and depending on the ship's relationship to the wind, movement will cost more or less tokens for each space it moves.  If the enemy ship is in range and line of sight, players may begin combat.  Combat is also simultaneous, and players roll a number of D20s depending on how many cannons they have that are still active and charged.  Consulting a chart on the ship card, players are told what their dice rolls hit on.  Ships that sustain hits must cross of durability points in the hull along the port, starboard, or stern.  If every all the durability points on either side of a cannon are knocked out, the cannon itself is destroyed.  Also, once a cannon is fired it must recharge before it can fire a again.  One cannon on each side of the ship may recharge per turn.  Also, in combat, players can select which type of ammunition to use- chain, ball, or grapeshot.  There are also rules for crew, pikemen, and musketmen on deck, boarding parties, and more.  Each scenario has objectives and victory conditions, but if at any time all the durability points on one side of the ship are destroyed, the ship goes down and that player loses.Armada Invincible is a fun and engaging naval warfare game that really packs a punch.  The dry erase cards are a great way to keep track of information and the variation in options and scenarios mean that this game has a lot of replay value.  It is a game of constant tough decisions as you need to line up for an attack, but may not have the movement points because you'll turn into the wind.  Do you expose yourself this turn in the hopes of advantage on the following turn?  Or do turn away to regroup.  Do you close in tight and try to board, or do you keep your distance?  Should you try to dismast the enemy ship, or merely bombard and peck away at his cannons and durability points?The game's ship models are beautiful and highly detailed, but they must be assembled.  For those of us without a model building aptitude, that can be quite intimidating, (my friend assembled them for me).  Also, without glue or adhesives, the models tend to lose pieces during play and must be re-attached.  It is a little annoying but nothing that stops the game from being generally enjoyable and engaging.  If you like board games with strong historical themes and naval adventure, you just might want to check out Armada Invincible.

Sellswords, from Level 99 Games, is a fun and engaging light card flipping game.  At the beginning of the game twelve cards are dealt out in a pile in the middle of the table.  Back and forth, each player takes one of the cards, which boasts a red side and a blue side, depending on who plays it.  Each card has four attack numbers on its sides, as well as special text that allows for special abilities during the game.  Placing a terrain card in the middle of the table, which may contain special modifiers to the game, players take turns placing their cards next to already placed cards or the terrain.  When a card's attack value on the side that is adjacent to an enemy card is greater than the enemy card's, the active player may flip the enemy card over to his color.  Each card's special abilities, however, can be game changers.  For instance, a card may allow you to attack a card two spaces away instead of just being adjacent.  One card will allow you to successfully any card around it, but then that card itself must be flipped.  Some cards effect scoring.  And there are many, many more.  Once all cards have been placed, scoring takes place by determining the number of your cards in rows and columns.  After two rounds, the player with the most points wins.Sellswords is a fun little card game.  The heart of the game is each card's special abilities, which allow for variation with each play.  Also, this game is very quick, each round playing in perhaps 10-15 minutes once players know what they are doing.  It is very light, and the mercenary theme, while present, is not particularly strong.  If the abstract nature of the game doesn't turn you off, you might really enjoy Sellswords as a two player opener for game night.

Erich von Manstein was quite probably the most capable operational general from any nation in World War II.  The architect of the plan that ensured Germany's victory over France in 1940; the commander who took the Soviet fortress of Sevastopol; and the brilliant strategist who reformed the German line after the disaster at Stalingrad.  Von Manstein was undeniably a brilliant general.His memoir, "Lost Victories," represents his version of events as they played out during World War II.  The book itself makes for some very dry reading.  There is a lot of operational talk (i.e. this numbered unit moved to this town, will on another sector of the line another numbered unit counter-attacked...).  If one is interested in the minutia of the war in Russia, then this book will be very informative and engaging.  Where this book shines, however, is in von Monstein's dealings with Hitler, who as the war dragged on increasingly micromanaged the war, often ignoring the advice of von Manstein and other generals, and blaming them when things deteriorated.  Von Manstein's portrait of Hitler is fascinating, and gives us a greater look at his unwillingness to cede any power when it came to the direction of the war.  The book also succeeds when von Manstein details the people with whom he worked and fought, a driver, a pilot, his son.  Von Manstein's human experience of the war among the most engaging parts of the book.The sections detailing von Manstein's attempts to relieve the 6th Army from Stalingrad are interesting, but again are far too dry to make for truly enjoyable reading.  The same could be said for the chapter about saving the front in the wake of Stalingrad.  The one section I was really looking forward to, von Manstein's role in Operation Citadel, the Battle of Kursk, clocks in at just four pages.  The translators, however, note that this chapter is not directly from von Manstein's notes, but rather a brief report he wrote later.  That was very disappointing.Also disappointing is von Manstein's commitment to only addressing the military matters at hand, and not addressing the dark reality of Hitler's regime.  This perpetuates the myth of the "Clean Wehrmacht," where the German army had nothing to do with eastern front atrocities, which was supposedly the unique work of the SS and Gestapo.  In fact, the German army had a lot of civilian blood on its hands in the Soviet Union.  At Nuremberg, von Manstein stated that he constantly argued and fought against the SS during the Russian campaign.  In fact, his arguments never proved a moral objection to SS atrocities, but rather arguments over allotment of manpower, which was often used to commit atrocities regardless of who commanded- the SS or the army.  Von Manstein's unwillingness to address his role in eastern front atrocities, as well as his cowardly hiding behind a solely "military" memoir, echoes the tactics used by other figures from the Third Reich like Gen. Heinz Guderian and SS intelligence chief Walter Schellenberg.All told, "Lost Victories" is an important historical document for a number of reasons, but it is, ultimately, self-serving and incomplete.  Additionally, because of its dryness, this is not a book for the casual student of history.

This digital audio recorder is a great little package that is great for taking notes or other short term audio recordings you might need.  In addition to the recorder itself, the package includes a USB connection, microphone with lapel clip, headphones, and more.  Digital files are easily convertible into MP3 format, and the interface is incredibly easy to use- both for recording and for playback.  I say that this is a good device for taking notes and short term audio recordings because the recordings do contain a little static in the playback- not enough to detract from playing back notes or other similar functions.  I had thought I might be able to use this for audio recordings for video productions, but the quality is just not up to that challenge.  Still, for the price you get a solid digital recorder that is easy to use and produces good, if not great, quality recordings.Review copy of this product was provided free of charge.

The Blue Sun expansion for Firefly: The Game adds a map board extension, two new reaver vessels, new captains, new missions, new contacts, new worlds to trade with, and a ton of new tokens and cards.  Essentially, this game offers little in the way of new rules, but tons of "stuff" to you Firefly adventures.  Some minor new rules changes involve the placement of reaver ships, and the fact that when they move out of a sector they leave behind tokens that can trigger the appearance of a reaver ship when players' ships pass through them.  The expansion also replaces some existing cards with updated cards.If you love Firefly: The Game, you really need this expansion.  Where the reavers were a minor annoyance in the base game, they are a serious threat in this one.  Also, the expansion provides so many new options, adventures, and places to explore that I will never play Firefly again without it.  Blue Sun just makes a great game even better.

In Citadels, 2-8 players attempt to score the most victory points by assuming roles and building city districts.  Each player starts the game with two gold and a hand of district cards.  Then players pass around character cards- each with different powers.  There is the assassin, who can name another character (but he doesn't know who took that character card), to take them out of the game for a turn.  There is the thief who can steal gold from a named character.  There is the magician who can swap district hands with another player or with the deck.  There is the king, who gets to choose characters next time, and many more.  After you reveal you character and take its unique action, you can take two gold from the bank- also, some characters earn more gold depending on the types of buildings them build.  Or you can take two cards from the district deck and keep one.  Then, you may build a building from your hand by paying its cost.  Many different buildings also allow the player certain powers.  It's gold cost is also its victory point value.  As soon as someone is the first to build eight buildings the game hits the end phase and at the end of the round the game is over.  Players total up their victory points from buildings and a few other factors and whoever has the most is the winner.Citadels is a fun and engaging game of bluffing and hidden roles.  In many ways it is reminiscent of other popular card games like Love Letter and Coup.  When playing characters like the assassin and the thief, you must wisely pick your target, and that often depends on looking at each players' buildings.  A player that has many green buildings may have picked the merchant, because he gets extra gold for the buildings- the king is the same with yellow buildings, the warlord the same with red, etc...  It is a very engaging game that keeps all players invested throughout, because you never know who is who and you must constantly weight the advantages of selecting defensive characters against the necessity of selecting more aggressive or profitable ones.The game does have a few minor drawbacks.  For instance, when passing character cards around players with analysis paralysis can take a long time to select their role, which leads to a lot of downtime for everyone else.  Also, games with a lot of players can go on for a bit longer than you would hope, and sometimes the last few rounds tend to be less fun and engaging because of it.  Still, these are minor complaints in what is really a fun game that both serious and casual gamers should really take to.

Villainous Vikings, from Victory Point Games, is a wonderful strategic game that plays in about 60-90 minutes and is set among the rampaging, long-bearded fellows from up north.  Three to five players take on the roles of a viking ship's captain and crew.  First you must select a captain card which boasts special abilities- one static ability and a few abilities contingent on dice rolls.  You ship is made up of three cards which represent different colored dice- gray, white, and red.  A journey deck is prepared using cards from Age I, Age II, and Age III.  The cards are laid out and each turn players can take too actions, traveling to locations in the journey deck, attacking those locations, hiring mercenaries, trading, repairing ships, and other actions.  If a ship moves to a location with another ship, battle ensues.Battle is very interesting in this game.  Essentially, you are rolling to get the most swords.  Some captains have static sword abilities, and some warriors you can recruit will to.  Players roll the dice depending on what condition their ship is in.  Swords add to combat power, but rolling hammers trigger your captain's special abilities, which may result in more swords or other surprises to help you win.  Rolling shields help to block sword damage, which will destroy part of your ship if it is not blocked.  Players may also buy swords for gold, or may sacrifice a warrior card or location card in order to gain more.  There are a lot of choices to make when attempting victory.  Finally, sometime at the end of Age III, the Ragnarok card will come out, leading to one final roll off between the players.  The winner gets the Ragnarok card with it's bonus victory points.  Players then tally up the victory points from their various cards, gold, and bonuses, and whoever has the most is the winner.Villainous Vikings is a great strategy game that offers players some really touch choices and depth.  How and when to sacrifice cards in combat is crucial, as is knowing what to do with your actions each round.  The game is really one of risk management, as you must decide to attack locations or other players and just what you are willing to sacrifice in terms of victory points and persistent bonuses to win the battle.  A beautiful game design and a whole lot of fun, Villainous Vikings was a big hit with my game group, and I think a lot of people will really enjoy it.

Star Wars: Imperial Assault, from Fantasy Flight Games, is Star Wars in a box- minus the space battles.
