The game can be played in two ways- as a two player skirmish game, and as a 2-5 player campaign game.  First of all, in the two player skirmish game, one player plays the rebels and the other plays the Imperials.  Players select a scenario to play, and set up the tie map accordingly.  They each have so many points with which to build an army, and select various characters and their corresponding cards.  Then players work to meet the victory conditions of the scenario.In the campaign game, one player takes on the role of the Imperials while the others pick heroes to play throughout the campaign, using different cards than they do during the skirmish game.  While the Rebel heroes are largely generic characters created for this game, it is possible to meet up with allies like Han Solo and Luke Skywalker.  Also, the Imperial player can activate Darth Vader and other characters to help him crush the Rebel scum.  Players have two actions each during the game, moving, attacking, interacting with objects, etc...  and play alternates between one Rebel hero and one Imperial unit.  Depending on whether the heroes meet their objectives or not, the story will advance in a certain way.  Between games, the Rebel and Imperial players will all have the opportunity to upgrade, and the Imperial may also prepare a number of nasty surprises for the Rebels.Combat in this game is really cool.  Each unit/upgrade card tells the player which colored dice to roll when attacking and defending.  Players can roll damage points, which damage the target, or surge icons, which can be spent on the unit's unique abilities for different outcomes.  The defender can roll a black or white dice which can block damage points or cancel surge icons.  The "X" on the white dice can cancel at attack all together.  The attacking dice also have an accuracy rating which is used for determining success in ranged attacks.  It's a great dice rolling mechanic that contains a lot of luck, but still gives players a measure of choice over how to use their surge icons.  The campaign evolves over the course of the missions.  In addition to upgrades, players will get the opportunity to go on new missions, set agendas, and see an original Star Wars story come alive on the tabletop.All told, Star Wars: Imperial Assault is a fantastic dungeon crawl adventure set in the rich Star Wars universe.  If you love Star Wars- and who doesn't- and great tabletop games, you'll want to pick this one up.

When I was in high school I read Timothy Zahn's Heir to the Empire trilogy and loved it.  I read several other Star Wars novels after that that ranged from mildly interesting to outright atrocious.  It kind of put me off of Star Wars books for a long time.  Then I picked up James Luceno's "Star Wars: Tarkin" on a whim.  I loved it, and when I saw that he had written about the master of Darth Sidious, I thought I'd give it a try as well.  I loved it, too."Star Wars: Darth Plagueis" tells the stories of Hego Damask, aka Darth Plagueis, and his apprentice Palapatine, aka Darth Sidious.  A Muun, Plagueis was at the heart of the Intergalactic Banking Clan, and commanded great wealth and influence in the galaxy.  Secretly a Sith, he sought to bring down the Republic and restore Sith rule to the galaxy.  Finding the young, troubled Palpatine on Naboo, a world with commercial interests that fit into Plagues' plans, the Sith master took the young noble under his wing.  What follows next is the story of the two men's plans to overthrow the established order and usher in the reign of the Dark Side of the Force.This novel is highly political, and the action is much more potential than kinetic.  It is a story of plans within plans, misdirection, and subtlety.  Don't expect many grand space battles, though there are a few dramatic confrontations, split second escapes, and other adventures.  If, like me, you find Palpatine a fascinating character, you will devour this novel as his dramatic rise and terrible machinations come to light.  Beginning several decades before the Battle of Yavin, (Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope), the action occurs all the way up through the events in Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace, and Palpatine's election as Supreme Chancellor.  It's very fun too peel back the curtains and take a look at this iconic character, probably my favorite in all of Star Wars.  The book is a great, quick read and abounds in Dark Side fun!  Though probably not for everybody, if you love the politics of the Star Wars universe, you'll no doubt get a big kick out "Star Wars: Darth Plagueis".

Munchkin Panic incorporates the silly Munchkin theme from Steve Jackson Games and the Castle Panic mechanics from Fireside Games.  Up to six players must defend their castle, even as they seek to become the sole winner by scoring the most victory points.  In the center of the board is a castle, with a number of walls and towers.  Extending outward from the center are a series of rings, which are separated into ranges- forest, archers, knights, swordsmen.  The rings are divided laterally into three colors- blue, red, and green.  Players receive a number of castle cards for their turn which indicate a color and range, meaning that you can score a hit against a monster in that space.  The monsters are activated at the end of every players' turn, then new monsters are added to the board.  Players also have the option of negotiating for cards, but some players may not want to give other players their cards because, though they all want to protect the castle, other players may not want you to get the points for the kill.  The monsters win if they can knock down all of the towers at the center of the board.  The players win if the castle can survive the onslaught of the monsters' attack.  Then, players add up their individual points and whoever has the most is the winner.I am not a huge fan of silly games, and Munchkin never really captured my imagination.  I have never played Castle Panic, though I did play Dead Panic.  While I enjoyed Dead Panic, I thought that there were other zombie games out there that did what that game did but did it better (i.e. Zombicide).  Munchkin Panic straddles a very thin line here- it's a cooperative game but there can be only one winner.  It's a bit of a contradiction and this kind of semi-cooperative game can be really tricky.  Marvel: Legendary manages to do it quite well, and there are others.  Here, the individual victory must take a backseat to the really cooperative elements of the game, largely because the monsters just keep coming.  You're working too hard to kill them to think too much about stabbing each other in the back.  When some cards allow you to screw over an opponent, you really think twice about playing it because the odds are it will screw over you as well in the long run.There are some fun thematic ideas here (insurance salesmen and lawyers being monsters, for one), and the game is generally enjoyable.  It is not, however, a great game.  Mechanically, it just doesn't quite work the way the designers had intended and, personally at least, the theme didn't thrill me.  There are a lot of Munchkin lovers at there, and I believe a lot of people will really enjoy Munchkin Panic, but it really is just not my cup of tea.

For what this GPS brings to the table I am generally impressed.  It provides great directions to locations, as well as info on gas, food, and other things going on around me.  I'm a bit of a Luddite, and while I did have a few minor frustrating moments getting the app to work properly, overall it has behaved well and been very helpful in some instances.  After those initial problems, the app/device have worked great together, and I really like the integration with the phone.  I remember back to the days before GPS, when you had to hunt for an address or street, or turn off.  Now, it is so easy to find the locations we need to find, and this Magellan SmartGPS is a great help and a cool looking/operating piece of tech for your car.

Knightmare Chess is back, and it's better than ever!  Combining both Knightmare Chess (1994) and Knightmare Chess II (1998), this new third edition contains 158 cards that really bring some fun adventures and wild chaos to the traditional game of chess.  Both players select up to 150 points worth of cards, (each card has a point value depending on how powerful it is), and have their own decks during the game.  On a players turn he may play a card after his move, though some cards allow players to play a card during an opponent's move.  The cards themselves are a lot of fun.  One card makes enemy knights drunk, essentially allowing a player to move an opponent's knight one space after it has moved.  One card allows the creation of a new unit, the princess, provided the king and queen are next to each other.  One card allows you to move a unit next to enemy pieces, then explode, killing your own unit but capturing all adjacent units (except a king).  One card turns your king into a warlord, allowing him to move up to two spaces per turn.  Some cards allow you to copy enemy cards, or steal them, or negate them.  My favorite card, however, is the Doomsayer card.  When it is played the next player to say the name of a piece loses that piece himself.  It keeps players on their toes and forces them to watch their words as they play.Unlike a traditional game of chess, which forces players to think two or three moves ahead, Knightmare Chess makes planning a long-term strategy impossible.  Because the cards can radically alter the game from one turn to the next, players must learn to improvise and constantly reassess their situation. You and your opponent will be laughing at the unexpected twists every time some unusual card or ability is played.  Knightmare Chess is great fun and really brings something new to the chessboard.  If you're a fan of chess, you will get a kick out of the new options and possibilities that this game offers.  If you don't like chess, you will love this unique variant which plays very differently than the chess you remember.  Check this game out!

WizKids' Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing is another game that makes use of the Flight Path system, used to such great effect in Fantasy Flight Games' "Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures" and WizKids' "Star Trek: Attack Wing".  Each player can build an army of dragons and other fantasy miniatures (assuming you have bought more expansions than just the core set), outfit them with upgrades, and then prepare to battle.  On a players' turn, he or she secretly selects what movement their dragon is going to make with a dial, then, based from lowest to highest on the dragon's level (initiative), the dragons activate.  Players use templates to guide their dragons along a path, moving them to another location in the play area.  Unlike Warhammer or other minis games, Flight Path games require no tape measurers, or awkward movement mechanics.  After movement, players can choose from several action options to help them in battle.  Once all the dragons have activated, the dragon with the highest level attacks first.  All dragons have either front (bite) or rear (tail) melee attacks, or they can attack with their upgrade cards.  All dragons attack within an arc before or behind them.  Red dice is rolled for attacks, while green dice is rolled for defense.  Players can choose to play scenario driven games or basic elimination games.D&D: Attack Wing is a generally fun game, though this is a game that was meant to be played with expansions.  One aspect that is different from previous Flight Path games is ground troops and combat.  Each dragon has two maneuver dials, ground and flight.  Playing with expansions could open up some really fun adventures for this game, but the base game really plays too similar to Star Wars and Star Trek to really feel like anything new and exciting.  The lesson is: if you want to pick this starter set up, be prepared to invest some money in expansions if you want the full experience.  I will not be collecting D&D: Attack Wing, as I am already heavily invested in Star Wars (and for a time collected Star Trek as well).  If you prefer the D&D universe, you may want to get started collecting this game with this starter set.  Just be prepared for the long haul if you really want to enjoy it.

Golem Arcana, from Harebrained Schemes, is a fantastically fun adventure that takes board gaming to the next level.  The base game comes with six beautifully painted miniatures, as well as a stylus.  Players must download a free app to a smartphone or tablet.  Programming in which minis they are using, players build an army.  Then, tapping the minis, the appropriate cards, the game board, and the app, players can wage an epic fantasy skirmish.  The app is easy to use and really brings a video game feel to the tabletop- in fact, this game brilliantly meshes board gaming and video gaming.  I was initially skeptical about a board game that required an app, but playing made a believer out of me.  Golem Arcana is a very fun game that brings something new, unique, and exciting to the tabletop.  Check it out.

The first time I heard someone talking about Gravwell I thought it sounded very complicated and not much fun.  When I read the rules it seemed less complicated and I thought it could be okay.  I played it- and immediately fell in love with it.  Gravwell is very easy to learn and play.  Up to four players take on the roles of spaceship crews as they try to escape the gravity of a black hole- but they have to use each other's gravitational forces to break free.  Sounds like something only Stephen Hawking would get, right?  Wrong!The game plays out over the course of six rounds.  A spiral arm filled with spaces extends outward from the center singularity, where the players begin, toward a warp gate- the players' objective.  A number of cards are laid out based on the number of players x3.  A three player game would see nine cards laid out- face down, then nine more face up on top of them.  Beginning with the youngest player on the first turn, (then with the player closest to the singularity on subsequent turns), players choose cards they want to use.  Each player then has a hand of six cards that they keep hidden from the other players.  Cards have two pieces of information upon them- a number of spaces to move, and an element corresponding to one letter of the alphabet.  Players play their cards simultaneously, and cards are resolved in descending from A to Z.  Here's the thing- players move toward the closet ship, whether it is in front of or behind them.  Because you don't know turn order until you all play the cards, nobody knows if they will be moving forward or backward during the turn.  In addition to the regular movement cards, there are also repulsor cards, which act in the opposite fashion of regular cards, and move you away from the nearest ship; and tractor beam cards, which pull all ships closer to the active player.  Also, each player has his/her own emergency stop card that can be played once per round, essentially allowing you to cancel your movement for one turn.  In addition to the player spaceships, two derelict ships are spaced out on the spiral arm, and can provide positive or negative gravity to your ship along the way.  The winner is the first player to make it to the warp gate, or, after six rounds, the closest player to the warp gate.Gravwell is a whole lot of fun and surprisingly simple in its mechanics.  This is game that you and your friends/family will laugh with as each of your cards play out- many with unexpected consequences.  It's a game of personalities and outguessing your opponents as much as it is a simple movement game.  I'm constantly amazed at how often times the simplest mechanics and ideas can create such wonderful gaming experiences, and Gravwell is definitely one of those games.  If you love to laugh while sitting around your tabletop, and have a fun space-themed adventure to boot, you will definitely want to check out Gravwell.

Timeline -Americana, is another get Timeline game, this one covering American history.  The Timeline games have to be about the easiest games to learn and to play out there.  Essentially, each player begins the game with a hand of cards containing some event or other historical item.  On the back is the year that that event occurred, and players may not look at the back.  One card is drawn from the deck and placed face up, revealing the year.  Going clockwise around the board, players place of their cards either to the right (before), the left (after), or in between cards that have already been placed, then reveal the card.  If you placed the card in the right location, you do not need to draw another card.  If, on the other hand, you guessed wrong, the card is placed in the correct position and you must draw a new card.  The object of the game is to be the first to get rid of all of your cards.A very simple game, Timeline -Americana is a wonderful challenge that will engage young and old alike.  Children will learn a lot about history, and so will adults who didn't pay attention in class.  This is great, highly educational game that I recommend.

The First World War, from Mayfair Games, is a fun and engaging light wargame set in the 1914-1918 conflict.  Up to four players take on the roles of belligerents: The Western Allies, Russia and minor states, Germany, Austria and minor states.  The game does not play out like a conventional wargame.  In fact, the game almost feels more like a eurogame with wargame theme.  The board is divided into three theaters: The Western Front, the Eastern Front, and the Italian Front.  Each front is then divided into several sections across which players' armies advance.  These lines of advance contain cities- squares represent victory point cities while circles represent supply cities.  At either end of each line is a base.  Players have a number of army chits of varying power, as well as many dummy armies with no power.  At the beginning of each round players place their armies and dummy armies face down in the various sections of the front.  Then, players take turns launching attacks or moving units around the board.  In combat, players reveal their armies in a section, discard dummies, then roll a dice and add it to their lead unit's strength.  The loser's lead unit is eliminated, while the winner gets to place an advance token on the next city in the line.  If the winner captures a square, he gets a victory point.  If he captures a circle, he can deny reinforcements to the enemy.  If he advances toward a base, the loser must move their surrender token up a point on the surrender track.  At the end of the round if a player has any points on the surrender track he must roll a dice.  If the number is equal to or less that the number of the track, they immediately lose the game.  Otherwise, players play out six rounds and at the end whoever has the most victory points wins the games.The First World War is a fun and unique wargame with eurogame feel to it.  Much of the game is bluffing, placing the dummy armies in sections of the board that are threatened, in order to prevent other players from attacking.  Every player is stretched to the limit in terms of military resources, and the game does a good job of simulating just how powerful, yet relatively evenly matched, both sides in WWI actually were.  Players can also gain tokens which can add factors to attacks and defense.  Some tokens give no advantage- but your opponent doesn't know that- adding to the great bluffing mechanics of the game.There is one drawback for this game.  The rulebook is not good.  It is overly complex and struggles to communicate relatively simple ideas and concepts.  Fortunately, with resources like boardgamegeek and others, you can find examples of play and amended rulebooks online that will make learning the game easier.All told The First World War is a fun wargame/eurogame hybrid that offers a lot of strategic challenge while still being very much about the personalities of the people playing.  I highly recommend this game.

Let me add my voice to the chorus calling this game fantastic!  Commands & Colors: Napoleonics is the best of Richard Borg's C&C system so far.  With 15 scenarios spanning the Napoleonic Wars in Spain and during the Waterloo campaign, the game has a highly historical theme.  Game play is always the thing, of course, and C&C Napoleonics is a whole lot of fun.  The board is divided into three sections- right flank, middle, and left flank, and players play cards to activate units in the specific sections.  Units are made up of a number of blocks representing infantry, artillery, cavalry, and generals.  Each unit has several sub units like line infantry, light infantry, guards, grenadiers, etc...  Each unit has unique characteristics that really add some fun variation to the battlefield.  Also, there are a number of really cool cards that also add some fun surprises to the game.  First Strike allows the target of a melee attack to attack first, possible forcing the attacking unit to retreat.  Rally allows players to return blocks to multiple units and then attack with them.For these reasons and more C&C Napoleonics is now my favorite C&C game.  Memoir '44 may be better for players newer to this system, but experienced players should really get a kick out of the variety that C&C Napoleonics brings to the table.  Highly recommended.

Walter Borneman's biography, "Polk: The Man Who Transformed the Presidency and America", is a solid look at our 11th president.  Written with a good pace that never skimps on facts, "Polk" examines the life of this extraordinary, though often neglected, historical figure.  Borneman correctly points out that had Clay, Van Buren, or another candidate won the 1844 presidential election, the very borders of the United States might look very different today.  The author also states that few U.S. presidents enjoyed as much success as Polk.  From the start of his administration Polk set out to do four things: create an independent treasury, reorganize America's tariff laws, settle the Oregon question with Britain, and acquire what is now the American southwest from Mexico- by either diplomacy or force.  All four goals were achieved and Polk lived up to his promise to serve only one term.  This work is no hagiography, however, and Borneman frequently shows Polk's less admirable qualities.  Due is given to the ambiguity under which Polk requested a declaration of war against Mexico, and his often petty prejudices and dislikes against other American notables.One of the main reasons I picked up this book was to learn more about the U.S.-Mexican War.  While the book does contain a great amount of detail on the subject, too often it is at the expense of the biography, and the book reads more like a straight history narrative in these chapters.  As history it is a wonderful exploration of the war, but as biography, it falls a bit flat.  There are several relatively large sections of these chapters that do not deal directly with Polk at all, but rather figure like Zachary Taylor, Winfield Scott, John C. Fremont, and others.  In fairness, Borenman notes this in the introduction.  Still, a closet tie to the subject during the narrative is always appreciated in a biography.All told, however, this is a fine look at an amazing period of U.S. history, seen through the perspective of one of its principle players.

This Taylor Digital scale is beautiful and functional.  I'm really impressed with how thin it is, and the sleek design is a great addition to my bathroom decor.  The digital display gives an (unfortunately) accurate reading, (sometimes you need a scale to lie to you!).  For what it is, this Taylor scale does the job and looks great doing it.  It is a tad heavier than I would have liked, but that's not a major complaint.

Star Wars: Empire vs. Rebellion, from Fantasy Flight Games, is a two player card game in which one side takes on the evil empire and the other side takes on, you guessed it, the rebellion.  The game takes place over a series of rounds.  First of all, an event card is drawn from the event deck.  The event card has an objective number, the number both players are trying to hit without going over, as well as telling players how many cards they can play that round.  Players each then secretly choose a strategy card which will be revealed at the end of the round, and can alter the game in certain ways, or give certain advantages to one side or the other under certain conditions.On a players turn he or she can do one of several things: First, players can play cards- essentially drawing a resource card from their deck and putting it on the table.  Next, a player can use a played card's power by rotating it 90 degrees.  Then, a player has the option of spending influence tokens to return a rotated card back to its starting position.  Finally, a player can pass.  Once both players have passed, the round is over.  Players then both reveal their strategy cards, and depending on the conditions of the cards, players check to see who came the closest to the event card's objective number without going over.  Whoever did so wins the round and claims the event card.  Each event card also carries a VP value, as well as possibly an influence number- the winner gets that many influence tokens.  The first player to score 7 points wins the game.That is essentially the game, though there is quite a bit more to it than that.  For instance, resource cards all have a numeric value, in addition to their text abilities, and character resource cards numeric value change drastically when they are exhausted- making manipulation of these cards key to winning the game.  Occasionally, players will paint themselves into a corner, haviong no legal moves left and must concede the round.  It's a balancing act that offers some touch choices and real competition.  The Star Wars theme is there with the photos and text, though it's not terribly strong.  I believe this engine originally started with another game and Fantasy Fight Games slapped the Star Wars IP onto it.  The theme is there, for sure, it's just not as strong as it is in, say, Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures.Star Wars: Empire vs. Rebellion plays in about an hour.  It is a generally fun, relatively fast-paced card game that fans of Star Wars should get a kick out of.  Fans of fairly light-to-medium card games should enjoy it as well.  The game does get a bit repetitive after a while, though I suspect this is not a game that players will play constantly.  Rather, this is a great once-in-a-while light-to-medium card game.

The DC Comics Deck Building Game: Forever Evil is a brand new base set for the popular (or is that infamous?) Cryptozoic Entertainment deck building engine.  Here, 2-5 players take on the roles of various super-villains from the DC Comics universe like Lex Luthor and Black Adam as they attempt to take down various superheroes like Wonder Woman and the Flash.  Mechanically, the game works almost exactly like the DC Comics Deck Building Game and its sequel, Heroes Unite- so much so that cards from Forever Evil can be mixed together with cards from the other sets.  There are a few, slight mechanical differences here.  First of all, the cards in this set emphasize attack far more than the previous sets do, leading to slightly more player interaction in this game, (one of the chief complaints of the first two games, other than the thematic issues, was that each player essentially played their own solitaire game).  Also, players will be able to, and indeed are often rewarded for, destroying cards.  This means, as decks evolve in the game, they don't necessarily become very thick.  Indeed, the game boasts some pretty thin decks by game's end.  Another departure from the other games, Forever Evil features VP tokens.  In addition to the victory points that are on most cards, players may be rewarded with VP tokens throughout the game, and may have opportunities to steal VP tokens from other players with attacks.  Mr. Freeze cards allow players to freeze certain cards in the line-up, essentially taking them out of play for a turn and possibly destroying them, (Why this needs a token, as opposed to just turning the card over, I don't know).As stated above, this is the third set in the DC Comics Deck Building Game line.  Each one of these games, and Cryptozoic's Lord of the Rings Deck Building Games, are essentially the same.  Each game has its minor adjustments, unique cards, and other quirks, but generally speaking, if you've played one you've played them all.  Understanding this, how does one rank Forever Evil?  Mechanically, with its emphasis on attack and card destruction, it may be the best of the bunch.  As stated above, those things really add a new dimension to the game, within the general parameters of Cryptozoic's deck building system.  Also, the VP tokens bring some fun new angles to the game.  The card combinations, however, may be the weakest of the three DC games.  It's nothing I can put my finger on, but generally I enjoyed the flow of the game and the powers of the cards much better in the other games, (Heroes Unite is probably my favorite of the three in that department).  It's something of a trade- best mechanics, weakest cards.  Still, if you like the engine, despite its thematic flaws (which I'm not going to rehash here), you should really take to Forever Evil.One final thing.  Cryptozoic needs to stop releasing these base sets of this game and instead just call them what they should be- expansions.  In addition to main deck cards, each set comes with weakness card, kick cards, punch cards, and vulnerability card.  WE DON'T NEED ANYMORE OF THESE CARDS, CRYPTOZOIC.  Seriously, Cryptozoic is simply upping the price by making each of these titles stand alone games.  It's a bit tacky and fairly off-putting to those of us who have stood by this game system, despite the haters and the thematic flaws.  Please, please, please- no more base sets, just give us expansions like the other good game companies do.  FOR REALSIES!

This Pure Protein Nutrition Bar tastes like a candy bar- great taste.  Only 200 calories, and gluton free.  While I do like the taste and the explosion of protein, it is a bit pricey- no, it's really pricey.  Still, not a bad little bar that will give a mega-protein fix and them some!

I know this book is supposed to be a classic and that it has a huge following of devoted fans. Personally, I just couldn't get into it. I trudged and stuck with it as far as I could (3/4 of the book) but, frankly, couldn't identify with the characters or immerse myself in the plot. I found it rather somber and unexciting. It is probably realistic for the time and place (obviously, since it was written by a contemporary author), I found the  constant struggle, never-ending challenges, and an outlook which I perceived as lacking hope and optimism to be rather wearing on me as a reader. The heroine is certainly heroic and praise-worthy, but she lacks the spark and charm which other heroines (such as Elizabeth Bennet) have to get themselves (and the reader) through the difficult times. She is somewhat reminiscent of Mary Bennet, except that she is truly virtuous instead of merely tedious.Is it possible that, in the last quarter, the cloud of doom is lifted, the characters bloom, and the plot becomes uplifting? Maybe. I just wasn't going to bet on it and decided to cut my losses.

This bedrail is designed to take with you when you travel. While I think it's feasible to take with you when you travel by car, I'm not too sure that it's especially feasible to take a bedrail with you--any bedrail--when you travel by plane.Having said that, for me it's absolutely perfect as a home bedrail. I like that it's not  almost bed length, as most are. (I think most bedrails are meant to keep the person from rolling off the bed and falling, not to provide support and stability). It only occupies a little bit of space so as not to limit your access of leg movements when climbing in or getting off a bed. This is good design because many products that are designed to solve one problem end up causing another, but not in this case.My use of the bedrail is primarily for stability. Since my heart operation, I am a bit unsteady going from a lying down position to standing. This helps me, not only by giving me something to hold on to while my world steadies, but also the bonus of something to hold on to getting in and out of bed. The design allows for a place to put my kindle and glasses and does not interfere with the cpap machine tubing.My installation is permanent. I have a king sized posturepedic mattress (which weighs a ton). Getting the safety strap under and across the mattress was quite a project and we had to wait until my son came by to accomplish it. I don't plan on ever undoing it. It did secure firmly to the bedframe on the other side of the bed and it feels solid as a rock and I'm confident and secure when holding on to it and don't let go until I've slipped on my slippers and I'm sure I can walk steadily. It has been a blessing for me and given me and my husband peace of mind as I'd come close to falling a couple of times before I had it.

Lonely Planet's "Wine Trails" is an interesting hybrid between between a travel book you can use for planning & a coffee table book you can lay out for eye candy and casualk reading for your family and guests. One could spin that negatively--it neither has the glossy pages and printing of a true coffee-table book nor the detailed planning tools of a normal Lonely Planet guidebook--but to me it's a lovely book that will inspire you to travel and give you at least the first tools to start planning your trip.I should disclose that I'm a big foodie and an even bigger traveler who finds that the world's wine regions are usually spectacullarly beautiful places to visit, but I'm not a wine connoisseur so it will be difficult for me to assess the quality of their vineyard recommendations. I'll leave that to other reviewers and focus here on the layout and detail of the book and its usefulness for travel inspiration and casual reading enjoyment.The book is extremely well orgtanized and easy to search through. Most of the world's famous wine regions are covered, each with it own chapter., as the book focuses on 52 wine regions (one for each week in the year) in twenty countries. Besides the ones I would have expected, there are some under-my-radar choices like Hungary and The Republic of Georgia. Within each chapter/wine region the book gives you nearly a dozen winery recommendations with photos, blurbs, and information. They also give you a handful of food recipes in each place and maps to help begin to plan your itinerary.The photos are beautiful though, again, my one criticism is that their beauty is somewhat undercut by being printed on matte instead of glossy paper. On graphic design, I'd give the book and A+. The wine bottle graphics are gorgeous and clever and the layout of the book is just a joy to flip through..

I was attracted to the idea of recycled battery power but, as it turns out, so little of what makes up the battery is actually recycled that the difference is negligible. As far as performance is concerned, once you're used to lithium batteries, going back to alkaline is a step back. Compared to other alkaline batteries, I haven't noticed any difference in performance or durability. (I've only tried them on low-demand items such as wall clocks and remote controls.The part I do like is that the unused batteries should last 12 years in storage. Given that I live in a hurricane-prone area, it is good to have something that you can put away and not have to think too much about replacing and rotating.

At times, the balance between fantasy and reality is strongly tilted on the side of reality. For example, if youre making up an imaginary country anyway, why does the actual location of the country matter? Why cant you not set it up between Spain and Portugaleven if that is not strictly possible in the real world? Why have to recruit citizens for a country that exists only in your imagination, or get an internet presence for it, or apply to the UN for membership?This is supposed to be an exercise in imagination and setting perimeters that are too academic might inhibit a child from wanting to complete the project on his own. (Although, as a teaching/learning experience for a classroom project it would be great.)But what the book does very well is make the child aware of all the different and taken-for-granted aspects that characterize a nation and make it functional and unique. Although it sometimes goes into too much detail (flag-raising rules), other factors such as postage stamps, currency, natural resources, border security, education, transportation, health care, and so on are serious and thought-provoking without being boring.The book does succeed in creating awareness of what it takes to govern, the importance of a strong economy, the relationship between governments and the governed and between other nations. When watching the news or learning of current events, he will be more aware of how each event fits into the larger picture.

My grandson has been diagnosed with ADHD and was given a prescription for a medication to help him concentrate in school. My daughter (his mother) was understandably hesitant to medicate him. I found this product on Amazon and figured it was worth a try. It worked so gradually that we really didn't notice the transition or that it was, in effect, making a difference. Then he had a stomach virus and didn't take it for four days. That is when we noticed how much more active and less attentive he became. After taking it again for a few days, we went back to what we call the "new normal."Don't get me wrong: this isn't a cure. What it does is tune down the hyperactivity somewhat so he can concentrate a little more, listen longer, get a little less frustrated, and be a little more still when doing ordinary things (like watching Ninja Turtles without jumping on the furniture.) He is still an active child, he still struggles, but he blends pretty well in with the other first graders. His teacher is satisfied with his progress and seldom has a complaint. He is still the same happy, smart, loving, and fun child he has always been and we are delighted that we didn't put him on a strong medication that might have changed his personality. We love him just the way he is.

I have to admit that the story is original. It had twists that I'd never read before and, therefore, it was an entertaining read. I somehow missed the moment that made Elizabeth fall in love with Darcy. One page she wasn't and the next she was. That is a fairly common occurrence in these variations--actually, even in the original the transition is sort of forced. But I love the books that build it up gradually. But the main reason for only giving it three stars is that the editing errors were so noticeable that even using a spell-checker would have been an notable improvement. Of course, the spell checker wouldn't catch errors such as calling Lady Catherine "your lordship."

I probably ordered the wrong adapter for my particular PC (read the other posts regarding DVI vs something else. The pins did fit in without forcing but maybe that's normal). So that part of the malfunction may have been my fault. In any case, it didn't work.HOWEVER, the design part of the malfunction was not a consumer error. The way the unit is designed you cannot screw in the little screws with your hands because they are small and hard to grasp and turn and, due to the protrusion at the other end it is impossible to hold a screwdriver at the right angle to get access to the screw. You sort of have to use the screwdriver sideways.(Note the illustration: those little silver things at the narrower end are what you have to find a way to fasten securely to the CPU. As you can see, the wide ends impedes using a tool and they are small and close to the body so turning them manually is next to impossible).

I expected something a little bit more substantial from the description, but was very disappointed. There was so little depth and development in both plot and characterization that it felt like a first draft that wasn't working too well. I would advise the author to slow down, write fewer books, but make them worth reading.

I never believed it was possible to make a laptop that weighs less than the I-pad. Yet, here it is. It's so beautiful. it's almost art. It comes loaded with all kinds of apps; the system is fast in every respect; the keyboard has a soft but responsive feel; the screen resolution is gorgeous; the sound is exceptional. It's not only great to have at home and take with you to work, but it's also the ideal size (and weight!) to travel with--especially now that airlines are getting so nasty about what everything weighs.Is it perfect? We'll, it falls just a little bit short. I am not enamored of Windows 10 (despite the high hopes I had for it as a substitute for Windows 8). As of today, Microsoft is acknowledging that there are networking problems with the operating system that they are working hard to fix. Unfortunately, I am experiencing them and it doesn't make for a happy camper. The internet disconnects spontaneously--assuming I can log in at all, which I usually can. But, since Windows 10 is not the computer's fault and a fix is on the way, let's skip ahead.As you might imagine, it has no cd drive (it couldn't possibly fit in!). In this age of streaming movies and downloading software, that is less relevant than it would have been before, but I'm old-fashioned enough to miss it. The only real problems are keyboard related: 1) in order to keep the design sleek and modern, the letters are thin and don't contrast much against the metallic keys. Some keys (like the period and comma) are so small, you hardly see them. 2) The other design flaw I find is that the lit keyboard, while gorgeous, is not terribly helpful. The part that is lit is the area around each key. You see where the keys are, but not what the keys are. (Other lit keyboards have the letters lit from below so you actually see the letters, but with painted-on letters you can't do that).Anyway, the pluses so far outweigh the minuses that this is an incredible machine to have and the fact that it's drop-dead gorgeous is an added advantage. Even my son, who has never had anything but a Mac is impressed.

This light saber is pretty impressive. It has a hefty feel (much better than the Luke and Darth Vader light sabers which are much more lightweight and plastic looking) and great sound and light effects. When I received it (around Halloween and before the  December release of The Force Awakens) it has less impact than I'm assuming it will have once my grand son finds out exactly who Kylo Ren actually is. He will also know what a light dagger is (one is included here) and how it's used. Actually, I'm sort of glad because his imagination has to kick in a bit more during play.Right now, he is tremendously impressed with the light saber and will take it out on Halloween dressed as Darth Vader. He is the envy of the block and I'm glad for the light (which is pretty bright and attention-catching) which will make him more visible as he trick or treats.As with other light sabers, it is a toy to play with mostly outdoors if you don't want them to knock over a lamp or something. Unlike others it has the advantage/disadvantage that it is part of a system of light sabers that can interconnect (read: additional purchases) which, I imagine, will be promoted after the film.

This is my second "portable power pack." The first one I owned was a nameless brand I picked up from a display at Target for $5.99 (they have since stopped carrying it.) I liked the concept since I'm the type of person who always forgets to charge her cell phone (assuming I remember to take it). That power packed lasted for exactly 5 charges and then it just died.I figured that something made by HP would be somewhat better and I have not been disappointed. I have used it more than 20 times and it still charges my phone (it takes it from no charge at all to 58%, and I can use it with the cord attached beginning at about 15% charged). So, performance-wise it, so far, earns 5 stars.What is absolutely awful is the "instruction" factor. It comes with a leaflet that says the same useless thing about 5 volts in about 50 languages and a gray scale drawing of the unit. Most of it is self-explanatory except the bit about the lights. It has four blue lights (that look no different in either of the gray scale drawings) and it doesn't tell you what the lights mean. I know that they blink when charging but they don't seem to indicate anything (fully charged? 50%? ).

This polarizer is the first I have ever owned and I'm still in a state of awe and wonder. As a new user, it has made me realize a few things:1. If you spent good money on a good lens, it makes no sense to put a cheap bit of glass in front of it. This glass is not cheap in either cost nor quality. It is more of an investment than an expense.2. Outdoor photos, particularly landscapes look so much sharper and richer. Even photographing a simple bush, you notice the difference. The bush without the polarizing filter reflects glare on each leaf and that glare ends up making the image look softer. With the filter, you kill most of the glare and each leaf can come into sharp focus.3. You "recover" highlight data better than using the highlights slider in Lightroom or Camera Raw.4. Blues and greens are boosted without crossing the line into fake-looking.5. My camera auto-focus (Nikon D80) has no problem locking in on any subject with the filter on. Quite the contrary, it seems to me that the outdoor photos are sharper.6. I've experimented taking indoor photos and, although I don't see a dramatic change in the colors or quality or focus, I'm glad to know that I don't HAVE to remove the polarizing filter to do so. (I did try photographing the flat screen TV and the photo did come out better than previous efforts, but "people pictures" are not affected one way or the other.7. If there are people, structures, etc. in your outdoor photos, they are not affected unless there is some kind of reflection or glare (or sweat) on them. But skin color does not change.7. Photos taken through glass, even in a moving vehicle, are noticeably better than without a polarizing filter. I'm assuming that the ability to shoot at higher speeds accounts, at least partly, for this.8. Photos of fountains, fish ponds, and beaches are breath-taking.I realize my newby observations will not be of interest to photographers who are veterans of the many benefits of using a polarizer but, in case there is someone who (like me) had failed to take advantage of this amazing tool, hesitate no more.I have owned other screw-on filters before and do notice that this particular brand seems better made. It's like comparing a wine glass that is made of lead crystal to an ordinary wine glass. There is something in the clarity, the weight, the feel that tells you that this is a superior product. I am DELIGHTED to have it and will never miss an opportunity to use it.

You now, from the beginning that these are short stories. You hope, because you've read other Rose Fairbanks books before, that they will be good short stories. They aren't horrible, but they aren't particularly great,either. "Boring" would probably best describe them. There just isn't enough time to create chemistry between the characters or  to  engage the reader.

My husband's physical therapist walks behind him using exactly this belt to hold on to him. Now that he's moving more, I got one of these belts, too. I walk behind him with my hand on the belt and, if I feel any unsteadiness I pull lightly. In the case of the therapist, who is a hefty individual who could probably carry my husband from the belt using one hand, I think that this belt which, although it isn't worn tight locks firmly, serves many more purposes than when I use it. I think that the support that I provide is 50% psychological and 50% practical. I may not be able to completely break a fall, but I can support him and help him lean against a wall, re-position his walker and so on because of the grip that the belt provides. It also prevents further hurting a patient by pulling on an arm etc. It's handy, sturdy, and does what it's supposed to do very well.

This is a pretty sturdy and very useful ramp to maneuver someone on a wheelchair into the house and, if you have indoor steps (such as in sunken living rooms) this will also do the trick. It can easily bear the weight of a six-foot, 230 lb man plus his wheelchair. It has little ridges that help traction, especially when going down. This ramp is perfect for one-step obstacles, but if you have two steps the angle is too steep.When ordering a ramp, keep in mind that you need to have space, not only for the length of the ramp, but also to be able to maneuver the wheelchair so you can place it in front of the ramp. (This is about an additional 3 feet, at least.)  Indoors this means moving furniture to clear the approach. If, after studying your particular situation you find that you would have room for the 4-foot ramp, I would seriously consider going for that extra foot. Although this ramp has served me well, I think the 4-footer would have been ever easier.Besides the sturdy construction, I also like the convenience of fold, carry, and store. It's pretty light-weight and takes up no room at ll when folded. You can tuck in in the back of a closet.

I can't begin to tell you how handy this has been for me recently. My husband broke his quad tendon and had a cast that went from his groin to his ankle for 8 weeks. I don't think I need to go into detail of how a man who suddenly finds himself with a leg he can't bend and weighs a ton feels. For the first 3 weeks, he could put no weight on that leg at all.  He's usually pretty independent and finding himself needing help for everything was a worse punishment than being unable to move. I found myself having to hove around where he was resting because, if I wasn't around when he called, he tried to get up to do it himself. (He fell during one of these ill-advised expeditions). We tried calling each other on the cell phone but either one of us didn't have it with us or a battery was low.This little device is a life saver. He wears it around his neck and I carry the little box to my home office or wherever I am. It's reach is phenomenal. There isn't a place in the house it doesn't reach. The bell is perfectly audible but doesn't make you jump out of your skin.  I finally convinced him that, for MY peace of mind, he should call me and he is going with the program.This is a wonderful device. I wish I'd had it when my mother-in-law was sick. All she had was a little bell and, if no one was nearby, the poor thing had to wait. It would also be great for a sick child, someone recovering from surgery, or anyone else for that matter. I just ordered one to give a friend whose wife had a knee replacement.

The word "dictionary" is a bit misleading. The only resemblance is that the words appear in alphabetical order and broken down by syllables. Although it doesn't have pronunciation keys, it makes some exceptions with easy-to-confuse words.  It is a list of words you might want to know how to spell (but already know the definition of). The selection of words is quite ample and would probably serve a student up to the 6th grade. It's a bit of an over-kill for my first grader, but we have been using it to get familiar with the concept of alphabetical order and for other extracurricular learning activities. I expect we will get many years of use out of this book.

This is a great, really great, substitution for those rubber tips that come on the back legs of standard walkers. They stick to the floor instead of sliding  and each step requires a bit of extra effort. I didn't fancy the idea of poking holes in tennis balls, which many friends recommended. These have the benefit of not sticking but that's about the only benefit they have.These "glides" are the perfect solution. They slide smoothly but you are still in control of each step. There is no danger that they will slide so much that you will fall forward. They work well in conjunction with the front wheels to provide a smooth and less awkward glide. They work well on all surfaces, indoors or out. They are easy to install and fit snugly inside the cylinders.

First and foremost, it's important to note that the criteria for selecting 100 buildings among the millions and millions of available choices is a highly personal one. Had it been up to me , I would not have made the same choices. However, Dan Cruickshank is to be congratulated for having embarked on (and completed!) this difficult and bound to be controversial endeavor.For the most part, I think he did a marvelous job. Not only are all his selections photographed, but there is accompanying text as to why he selected them and what makes them important in the history and evolution of the art (and science) of architecture. From a personal perspective (and that is what a review is supposed to be) every building that I love or consider important is included, so I can't think of a complaint of something he has left out. However, there are some that he put in and that, in his opinion, are outstanding or pivotal structures that I see very little virtue in and consider that the space could well have been filled by something a bit more awe-inspiring. But, since he's the one who wrote the book, his opinion rightly prevails.The book itself is not a coffee table sized book. It fits on a standard book shelf which, I suppose, has its merits. However, the size does impact on the size (and probably number) of photographs. The photographs themselves are adequate, but not outstanding and usually only one photograph appears per entry. The text is smaller than I am comfortable with and the layout, while artistic, is impractical. The outer margin is 2 1/4" from the edge of the page, but the center margin is about 3/4" and rounds itself towards the center. The combination of font size and text layout makes reading very uncomfortable. (I should note that this is a general description of the layout. There are some random pages that do allow for a different arrangement of the margins, although the size of the text is consistent throughout.) This last paragraph explains why I deducted one star from the book which, otherwise, is a fascinating and stimulating contribution to the study of architecture.

I had this book on my wish list for a long time and hesitated to order it because the idea of D & E being siblings in love with each other rather turned me off. Finally, I decided to take the plunge and I'm very glad I did. It proved to be a very well-written story with just the right amount of angst. Our characters (and the author) handled the sexual tension with decorum and dignity. The secondary plot was well-handled as well, emotionally involving the reader in all aspects of the story.The only thing I could not wrap my head around was Lizzy's anger towards Mr. Bennet. It  was unfair and made no sense at all given how close they had been and how loving he had always been towards her. It didn't mesh well with Lizzy's personality which, otherwise, is pretty close to canon.Luckily, after a convoluted but necessary process, all is resolved more than satisfactorily. And, better yet, you don't have to wait to 90% of the story for the HEA. The beginning of the happy ending starts at around 75%, so you can cruise through the rest of the book enjoying all the ends being happily tied, all the characters happy, and a glimpse into a well-deserved happy future.

Im very impressed with the Epson Expression ET-2500. It has a ton of good qualities in its favor:--it is a compact unit, does not occupy too much desk space but is still capable of carrying out a full work load.--all the functions are up to Epsons high standards from print quality to scanning capabilities (8.5x11 scan surface).--it has an absolutely STELLAR quality: the ink supply. Not only does it come with a huge supply of ink, but the ink holders are refillable by color. This is a huge savings on two fronts: you have ink to last for thousands of copies and, if you run out of only one of the colors (usually cyan) you dont have to replace a three-color cartridge.--the ease of installation is virtually fool proof. You insert the disk in the computer(s), run the wizard, and it practically does everything for you. NOTE: for installation purposes you do need a USB cable for the first computer in order to set up the wireless network. Subsequent computers dont need the USB cable and, at this point, you can just put it away and operate wirelessly (unless you prefer to use USB). An unexpected bonus: at the end of the process you are issued an e-mail address to which you can e-mail stuff to print from your phone or i-pad from wherever you are.--did I mention wireless? Yes, indeed, it picks up signals from all computers in which you installed the disk (even several rooms away) and also from smart phones, I-pads, etc.--Scanner: wireless is not especially practical for scanning since you have to get up to place the material on the glass, but you can preview and adjust the scan (using the usual Epson interface which is easy to use, even on professional mode) and save from your desk. Then you get up again, to scan the next sheet..--Copier: the same surface on which you scan can be used as a copying machine for 8  x 11 paper.There are a couple of minor details Im not enamored of:--the cover of the scanning/copying surface is made of pretty light plastic. Im not saying its flimsy and it should survive use by adults, but a bit more heft would be reassuring.--the paper supply is exposed to air (sits exposed in the back of the unit), not in a tray. Since I live in Florida and turn off the air conditioning at night and some weekends, the paper is not as well-protected from humidity as it would be in a tray. This is particularly noticeable when you use recycled or 20-lb paper. I am now using only 24-lb paper.--like all Epson scanners it uses a proprietary color profile (EpsonRGB). This is just fine if youre printing to an Epson printer but, if you want to have scanned photos printed at a retailer (say Costco, drugstore, mail order, etc.) you have to remember to convert the color profile to sRGB which is the standard color printing profile for photos and artwork. If you forget, sometimes the color differences are minor and sometimes pretty noticeable. However, when printing to this printer, with these inks, on any paper (but particularly when using Epson photo papers, the photos come out really, really lovely. I particularly like the Epson heavy-weight matte paper.But despite the very minor drawbacks you should really take this unit into consideration. It is a great performer and a very good value. I reiterate the ink consideration: recently it seems printer manufacturers sell you an attractive printer for a lower cost and then, forever, nail you on the ink. I am very happy to see that Epson has taken the initiative of selling a well-priced quality machine with a durable supply of ink (good quality ink, at that) and made the replacement process less frequent and expensive.

I wasn't really sure what to expect, but I have to confess that the book was a pleasure to read. It was realistic, in that neither E nor D were perfect and made mistakes, but they admitted them, and they grew and learned from them as normal people do. Other than Lady Catherine and Annabelle, who were a bit over the top, the rest of the characters were balanced and contributed to the story.It was lovely to see E&D's  progress towards their happy ending in a way that was natural, unrushed, and believable--even with bumps in the road.. I was sorry to have the book end and happy to have found a book with sufficient length and depth to keep me entertained for several days.

My old Panasonic 1200 W died after years of intense use and I knew I wanted a similar one. Actually, I like this one better: the controls are more flexible in that I don't have to dial in time in 5 or 10 second intervals. I can press buttons to get whatever time I want (i.e.18 seconds) at whatever power setting I want. Much more flexible.I was surprised that there really isn't a notable difference between 1200W (which is pretty powerful)  and 1250W. I still use the time settings I was accustomed to using for each item. The inside dimensions are pretty large (18.5" wide), the rotating glass tray is also larger than any I have seen before (16.5"), while the outside dimensions don't really reflect the inside capacity.I've had it for only a month and I really like it, even though it's maybe a bit larger than I need.

This is one of the few short stories that I was glad was short. Making it longer would not have made the plot less predictable or the characters less shallow. Three people descend on Pemberley, two of which the Colonel had a slight previous acquaintance with, which is the only tie-in. None of them is particularly likeable and two-hundred more pages couldn't have helped. They caused all kinds of inconveniences and, thankfully, left.

Around the year 2000, I discovered Triple-Flex and have mostly used it ever since. We stayed at a hotel that was near the Spanish Steps in Rome and, after three days of going up and down, I thought the pain in my knees would kill me. The next year we went back to see our son who was spending Junior Year in Italy, stayed in the same hotel, went up and down the same steps, and didnt have a problem. I wasnt more fit, I hadnt lost, weight, I was a year olderthe only difference was my supplementation. I have never again had problems with my knees or other joints, which I find rather amazing for a 67-year old.Sometimes to save money or take advantage of sales, I would try products with only two of the three ingredients and I find that products that include MSM work better than just Glucosamine/Chondroitin alone. This is anecdotal data based on my observations over 15 years. Some studies I read contradict this, but I have proved to myself what works and what doesnt.Part of the reason why Ive looked for an alternative to Triple Flex is that they are large, dry, hard-to-swallow pills. As you get older and your mouth gets dryer, they become even harder to swallow. That is why Im so happy to have discovered this Viva three-ingredient product.Comparing it directly to Triple-Flex (the product Im most familiar with) the most notable difference is that you take 4 capsules of Viva and 2 Triple Flex pills. The daily totals if you follow the recommended dosages also varies a little:2 Triple Flex:  Glucosamine: 1500 mg; Chondroitin: 800 mg; MSM: 750. Sodium: 70 mg.4 capsules of Viva: Glucosamine 1500; Chondroitin: 1200; MSM: 1000. No sodium.I dont think the slight change in formulation is particularly important. What I do consider decisive is that these are capsules, they are reasonably-sized, similarly-priced per serving, but easy to swallow. I think Im sticking with these from now on!

This is a pretty impressive building set. It's a bit of a stretch to call it "engineer kit" since the principles of flight are not an issue, it is pure entertainment value and, at that, it excels. It is rather unique in that it comes with a story book in which the models you can build play a role. As you read along, you build the plane. It is not a one-day & put-it-away type of toy, it creates involvement and identification with the planes and the characters.Regarding the age that is appropriate for the toy, I think that 4 to 6 is ideal because the child can follow along with the story and take an active part in the building of the planes. These are projects which need parental involvement for both the reading (my 6-year old grandson can read a bit, but not enough to read the book himself) and for the building. If left to himself, he would rush in a quest for immediate gratification and not assemble it properly. It isn't difficult and the color coding makes it almost foolproof, but it is a question of 6-year old maturity. The I-pad games have spoiled him a bit, and it's great to have something that motivates him enough to want to put some time and effort into it, but he does need a hint here and there.Another plus is that the finished product looks exactly like in the book and is larger than I would have expected from the illustrations. It's very rewarding to see that all the "work" was worth it and a lesson in patience and commitment  The benefits (eye-hand coordination; reading comprehension, following instructions, work in a certain sequence, patience) are all well-disguised as "playing." . Everything stores in a neat little chest, which is another plus and, in addition to the illustrated planes a child can build his own creations from the provided parts.I do think it's a shame, though, that this toy was not geared towards an 8-year old age group. That age group could handle the whole process, from reading to assembling alone. But the business of having planes with googly eyes and personalities would probably offend them. At that age they would want something more realistic, less cartoony--more engineering.

This product has made a noticeable difference to the internet connection to a computer that I have in an addition at the end of the house. I was able to get internet there, but pages were slow to load, downloads were slow to complete, and videos went black (with the little spinning dots) so often I simply didn't watch videos there.I was concerned that the two components were going to be so far away that they wouldn't be able to pair, but pair they did. This is the procedure:1. You get two of the units shown in the photo and two Ethernet cables about 6 feet long.2. You take 1 unit and connect one end to the ethernet cable to the unit and the other to your router then connect it directly to a wall socket (not to a power strip).3. Take the 2nd unit, connect the Ethernet cable to your computer and the other end to the unit. (NOTE: while you're not supposed to connect it to a power strip, I have the computer connected to a battery back up/surge protector and I connected it to that instead of to the wall--it worked).4. Press the "Pair" button on both units. There are three little lights on the side and, once all of them have stopped blinking (which happens pretty fast) and stay on solid green, you know they are paired and working.5. It is possible to piggy-back additional units onto this system. You would use the same connection to the router, so each additional set of two units would pair two additional devices to this line. Not a bad deal if you have far-flung devices in the same house, which would include TV's and whatever else you connect to the internet (as long as said device has an Ethernet port).I have found an improvement in the performance of my internet connection. I can watch a whole video on you-tube without having to wait for the connection to catch up (or whatever it was that happened before). I haven't downloaded anything yet, but pages load fast and I have none of those delays in moving up or down the page, I can have a lot of tabs open, and I can switch between them instantly. Also, the computer is now recognizing that other computers exist on my network and that there is a wireless printer several rooms down. Up to now, it was oblivious to them.So, I would say that this is pretty outstanding.

While designed for a younger baby, I have had great success in using this for my 2-year old granddaughter. It arrived on a day that she was feverish and cranky and refusing to cooperate on everything just for the principle of the thing. She needed to nap and I made a big production of opening the box, placing the batteries in, and turning it on (without ever even glancing at the instructions.) She agreed to be in her crib during this procedure and was immediately fascinated by the light show as soon as I turned off the room lights. I turned on the white noise because she thinks that any music is an excuse to dance and that wouldn't serve my purpose at all. While the fish aquarium is really well done and beautiful, she isn't too impressed since they have a real fish aquarium at her house.This was a godsend because she was not feeling well and in one of those moods where everything is a reason to cry. The light show attraction was just the right thing to distract her from her misery. It is attractive (and well done) enough to capture her attention initially and monotonous enough to lull her to relax and start winding down. The white noise is really necessary in my house, not only because of its calming properties but also because it effectively muffles other noises (including the pool pump which is right outside the window and kicks in at the worst times). The music is sweet and has a music box quality to it that is very lulling. I plan to use it sometimes but, for me, the white noise is a must. It is a watery-sound type of white noise, a little bit more subtle than I would prefer but, probably, just right for a newborn.You can pick the combination of features you want to use (such a lights only, lights + music, white noise + lights, etc.) The only thing I wish was different is that everything you pick works in tandem. It starts out strong and starts winding down until it shuts off completely. I don't mind the lights turning off, but I would like to keep the white noise on at the full level but can't control it independently. If I want to, I can start just that again, but it will just wind down again.  I do have a clock in the room that makes white noise and I have to run it at the same time so the room won't go silent. That wakes her up, she needs some background noise to sleep.I don't know if it is because I was exhausted from taking care of a sick child, or if the lulling effect of the watery light show got to me as well, but I lay down while she quieted intending to leave the room as soon as she fell asleep and I was out like a light. We were both refreshed after our nap.  I just might take this to my room on one of those nights when I wake up at 3:00 am and can't get back to sleep.

I like the product and assume that it does a good job of cleaning open wounds. I love the idea of spray-on versus dab on because it not only is much more convenient and it doesn't push debris or dead skin down into the wound (as dabbing does) it sort of washes it away. I recently took a bad fall and the wound card nurse used a spray-on product which I was unable to find so I ordered this one to have at home. I like her product better because it sprays on like this one does but doesn't sting at all. This one stings a little bit, not painful, but a little sting on open wounds.

This is a product I would much rather not need but, since I do, I'm happy to have found it. These little wipes help dissolve the adhesive of tapes, bandages, and band-aids so that they are easier to remove and pull less on delicate skin. My skin gets red marks (blood under the skin) when I pull on bandages and, without this, I'd be even more colorful than I am now!

Fate is the third character here. How else can you explain that Fitzwilliam and Lizzie met end up married in a mutually convenient arrangement? Unbelievable though the concept may be, the two do match very well and find happiness. The Fitzwilliam family with the addition of a delightful grandmother (and the exception of a particularly vicious Lady Catherine) are immediately delighted by Elizabeth and accept her wholeheartedly.It's a primarily happy story, very little negative happens after the two meet, but what happened before was so horrible that I wish that the author could, somehow, have lessened the tragedy.

If its possible to feel favorably emotional about a computer, this would be the one to qualify. (I know it is possible to feel unfavorably emotionalto put it kindlyabout a computer!). This one has so many things to get excited about that I am listing them in no particular order:--The graphics card, NVidea GEFore GTX 745 is great. Its approved by Adobe to run Photoshop CC2015 for 3D image rendering and operations requiring Open GL and Open CL. Its also a great card for gamers, according to NVidea.--The Intel 7-core processor is incredible. I had a 5-core in my previous computer and didnt expect to see much differencedo I ever!--It has a 1TB hard drive 7200 RPM and 2 open ports to install to install 2 additional internal drives which I plan to do.--It has USB 3, which Id never tried before and is wonderfuland it has 6 of them, in addition to some USB 2s.--With 16 GB of RAM you can easily process photos from any camera, even those huge 24 and 36 megapixel cameras. You can even have several open at the same time as well as multi-task with other applications. I downloaded creative cloud and Photoshop CC2015, Bridge, & Lightroom. Im in heaven, no matter what I do (and Ive thrown in 3-D and all the heavy filters) I dont have to wait for anything, everything happens instantly. No spinning wheel. I cant believe it.--The computer itself is 17 inches tall, 6.5 wide, and 16 deep. On all counts, a smaller chassis than my previous Dell.--It comes with one optical drives that reads and burns and a program called Cyber Link Media Suite that does much more than I need it to do. If you should want to add an additional optical drive, the space is there.--It also has 4 media slots that, between them can read 19 types of media cards. (I didnt know there were that many!)--It also comes with Microsoft Office Trial which you are bound to have to purchase later, but at least you get a breather while youre buying monitor(s), speakers, etc.--It does come with a basic wired Dell Keyboard and Mouse both of which are basic and perfectly acceptable (though Ive lately grown addicted to lighted keyboards).--It also comes with a one-year Dell support contract (renewable yearly for several years) which is a blessing. Ive had Dells since 1998 and, besides the fact that they are great machines; the tech support is so good I wont get anything else. Between laptops and desktops and between my husband, son, daughter, and sister-in-law, this is the 16th Dell in our householdand never have had a bad apple.--The only thing about the computer about which I am totally unenthusiastic is Windows 8.1 which Ive found horrible and annoying. Microsoft makes decisions that control the way the computer is configured and operates that are different from what Id prefer and Im not given the choice to change them. Its sort of a battle between two control freaks and Microsoft wins. I understand Windows 10 (what happened to 9?) will get the start button back and that should be an improvement. I plan to download it when it becomes available because it just cant be any worseBut, others than Windows 8, this is as close to perfect as Ive ever dreamt of being. The xps 8700 does everything well, fast, and beautifully.

Im very happy with the UP3. My previous experience was with a Garmin product that had all kinds of software bugs to the point that I couldnt trust any of the readings. This is so much more intelligent and the software is so dependable and user-friendly (without being bossy or controlling) that its a pleasure to use. In no particular order, these are my observations (all positive except the last):--The results are portrayed in text and graphics and the tone of the assessments, no matter how deficient youve been that day, are positive instead of scolding.--The app is very user friendly and keeps a sort of history or time-line in a dashboard like format, and you can compare your activities in order to compare today with better days, etc.--On the upper right it shows a battery and how much its charged. This is important information because, with a device you use round-the-clock, you need to think ahead as to when it would be more convenient for you to recharge. Fortunately the charge lasts more than a week so its easy to plan.--It works very well in conjunction with your smart phone. You dont have to have the phone with you at all times, it syncs when they meet.--Attaching the wrist band is not the easiest process, but it works. You need to be aware of where the sensors are and adjust accordingly so they make good contact. It cant be too tight, but it has to be snug. Its never come off during the day, but Im such a restless sleeper that Ive dislodged it twice at night.--The wrist band is made of a rubbery material and the part with the technology in it is only slightly raised. It tapers up to about  high at the center, which is not bad. Its relatively waterproof for everyday activities, but I take it off to shower. To clean, just use alcohol.--It has some little lights that are only visible when youre charging or changing modes. For example, the blue light clicks on momentarily if youve successfully changed it to track your sleep.--Heart rate tracking only at rest so if youre running or exercising rapidly it doesnt measure that heart rate. When you exercise, you have to tell it what you think you did and it will tell you how many calories it thinks you burned. Since all I do is walk, this is fine with me.--If you swipe from the dashboard, you get a lot of software options. Havent use the stopwatch option, the idle or activity alerts or the alarm clock features, but they are part of the software and a good idea.  Overall, its a very good assortment of options. On this screen it shows your battery time in approximate time left, say about 2 days.--One of the options, the one you click on to switch the mode so it will track your sleep, It gives a pretty thorough report but I cant help but wonder how it knows so much about when Im in REM sleep, etc. When Ive had a sleep study for apnea, they had to put sensors all over my body, including my head. Dont know how exact this measurement is, but its a good guideline and, surprisingly, seems to gibe exactly with my evaluation of how the previous night went.--There are a lot of other apps that are compatible with the UP3, you can set goals, track your calories and weight, upload a photo, etc. The diet tracking can be very techy, you can photograph labels to get real specific about caloric content. Trends is about the only one Ive used because it lets me see (via bar charts) how Ive been doing in terms of steps or hours of sleep over a long period.--I only use it for resting heart rate, steps taken, and sleep monitoring. If it did nothing else, Id be happy but there really are a LOT of options, apps, and modes to choose from. Right now, Im on Weight Watchers and I track my food intake their way.--Ive been using it for several days and I think Ive noticed a flaw in the way it counts steps. If your arm is free it doesnt miss a beat. However, when youre walking in a place where you have to push a cart (Costco, Marshalls, the supermarket, etc.)  and your hand is resting on the cart handle, then the steps dont seem to register. Once you take the cart out to the parking lot and its a bumpier ride then steps do register, but not in the soft glide of the store. You can miss out on hundreds (or thousands) of steps that way.
