Its pretty impossible to maneuver a cart with only one hand, so the only work-around I can see is to pull the cart with your other hand, but thats pretty uncomfortable. (I had the same problem with the Garmin product I used before).

This is a small camera, easy to carry around in pocket or purse and instinctive to use. All the controls are easy to decipher and use. It comes with one battery and the charger and the battery charges fairly fast.The image quality is OK as far as sharpness is concerned but the color rendition is not true to subject, it's a little bit under saturated, particularly the blues (what should have been a royal blue had too much cyan). It also doesn't perform as well in very bright situations and tends to overexpose. Granted, you can fix all  that in Photoshop, but you shouldn't have to.
This is something you can easily do without if you have the little spatula. I thought it would be good for scraping big cuttings off the mat, but it's really pretty mediocre.

Not a bad cookbook on Cuban food, especially for a beginner or someone who has only tried it in restaurants. I have tried some recipes and, while not as good as those handed down by family with a more homey touch or personal touches, it is fairly representative of what you eat in restaurants in general and Versailles in particular.For something less commercial, something more like what you would eat at the home of a Cuban family (especially if the hostess is a good cook) I highly recommend "The Cuban Table."

My granddaughter, for some reason, finds Curious George very endearing. This DVD has a series of short cartoons, some better than others, and some short films that a 2 or 3 year old finds very distracting (some kids assembling furniture others doing Kung Fu, etc) that have nothing whatsoever to do with Curious George. I have to fast forward through those parts.On a DVD about parties, I was expecting more music and there is very little. This DVD doesn't entertain her as much as others like the Curious George Christmas DVD, for example. But it's OK overall.

These cutters cut pretty well! I use them mostly on card stock and they go through it with no problem making detaching the design for the mat no problem at all (as long as you have the little spatula). They last pretty long but, alas, they do have to be replaced after a big project. Most of my cutting is on setting 4 and the only real way to know if it's time to replace is when the designs become hard to remove or there are skips in the cutting.I'm not employed by Amazon, but I have to say that theirs is the best price I can find. Michael's and JoAnn's carry them but, if you read the small type on the coupon, those 40% discounts do not include Silhouette products. Since I don't know if I'm going to need to change blades in the middle of a project, I always order an extra one so I can continue without interruption and not have to pay full price if I'm in a rush.

Years ago, I had gotten another Swiffer mop kit and was disappointed. The pole in that kit consisted of two metal bars that (I believe) screwed together. This left the pole rather vulnerable in the middle and you couldn't press down very hard because it would arc or bend. From then on, I only used the dry wipes for furniture, etc.This kit is entirely different. The pole is made up of several rigid pieces that secure to each other firmly. There is no bending in the middle, it really feels solid, so I give the design of the pole an enthusiastic 5 stars with no reservations.The dry wipes, which I love for cleaning furniture, tv, shelves, books, just about everything except computers--are a welcome addition to do touch up floor cleaning--especially now that my grandchildren are spending the summer in Camp Babba (that's me). There is always something that needs touch up, especially after meals. With this new non-bending pole they are great, really great for dust bunnies. 5 stars here, too.The wet wipes, which I had never used before, I am a little less enthusiastic about. I have Italian tile floors all over the house, including the kitchen. While they do clean well initially, it seems to me that the floor gets dirty faster after using them. I don't know if it leaves some sort of film or what. I gave them to my daughter (who has wood floors in most of her house) as she has used them in the past and she has no problem on the wood.

I hate to be a dissenting voice as so many others just loved the book. I can agree with them that it is well-written, imaginative, and well-edited. It is also of sufficient length to justify the price. I have given it a 3-star rating because, to me, the "enjoyment" factor is a vital component in rating a book and I wasn't able to enjoy the book as much as I'd hoped.The reason is that, for the first 93%-94% of the book Darcy is dejected (and rejected). The poor man suffers unrequited love and Elizabeth unknowingly adds to the pain. Then, in the last few screens, everything is resolved (although the thrill factor is somewhat muted). There, frankly, was no reason why it couldn't have been resolved much earlier but, when you consider that the actual book ends at 97% (the rest is coming attractions) we get to enjoy his happiness a very short while.  I guess the author ran out of salt to add to the wound.I realize that any P&P variation has to put Mr. Darcy through the wringer for a while, but this was a bit too much. And, to add insult to injury, there are so few upbeat pages. If she had, at least, elaborated a bit more on the happy times but, no such luck.

I had ordinary plastic shower curtain rings and, while I didn't mind, I have to admit they did require a hefty yank to get the curtain closed. This sometimes resulted in tearing the first (or last) couple of holes in the curtain. This is a completely different scenario. The rings look great, the ball bearings roll and slide beautifully and you don't have to yank as hard (although old habits are hard to break!).I usually try to balance my reviews with a less-than-stellar quality or something I think could be improved but, truthfully, they look and work great and even after staring at them, then coming back here to stare at the screen, I just can't think of anything I would change.Considering how shower curtain rings are, pretty much, a one-time investment, it makes sense to get the best from the start.

The book is well-written but  I couldn't get past the fact that it is very unlikely that Anne should, suddenly, be perceived as beautiful, tempting, intelligent, and charming by someone who has known her for years and believed the opposite. The fact that this person is her first cousin added another bit of discomfort to me, even though I know that this wasn't considered odd in the 19th century.The transformation or, at least, the modification, of Lady Catherine to a woman who would put her daughter's happiness ahead of her own was welcome, but I thought it odd that Lady Catherine was the sister of the Earl's wife instead of the sister of the Earl. I have no idea why that was since it makes no difference to the story.

This is, really, the only tool I use. It is extremely useful in removing small and not so small pieces from the cutting mat. The only problem I have with it is that it keeps getting lost and, since I can't work without it, I've bought two.

If this was any other author, it would rate 5 stars but, for Abigail Reynolds, who has demonstrated in her many previous books that she can do so much better, it is just slightly less than I had been expecting.The premise is interesting and could have worked so much better but the obstacles, misunderstandings, unexplainable interferences, and annoying delays before reaching a satisfactory resolution made reading the book a bit more frustrating than it should have been. It almost seemed as if she had to extend the book by adding additional complications because she needed to reach a certain page count before our characters could find happiness.

Not only is this water bottle gorgeous, it is extremely functional, too. There are many things that I love about it:--the color is a deep cobalt blue (one of my favorites)--the capacity is excellent (18 ounces)--the opening is wide enough that I can fill it from the refrigerator water dispenser--the water stays cool a long, long time.--the exterior doesn't sweat, even if the water is ice cold.--the drinking hole is big enough that you don't have to make an effort to drink and small enough that you're not likely to spill (about the size of a nickel)--the lid is easy to screw on and secure.--I have no trouble remembering to take it since I put my car keys inside the lid every night so I can't leave w/o it.--the snap closure is also secure and easy to open and close and unlikely to open by itself.--it fits into my car drink holder and doesn't tip over (surprisingly, since it's so tall).--I'm saving a lot of $$ not buying water bottles every time I'm out shopping in the Florida heat.Is there anything I don't like about it? Not really--unless you count that, although the bottle itself is lightweight, adding 18 oz of liquid to it adds a load to my already heavy purse!(The manufacturer says NOT to carry it around in your purse since something might press on the button that clicks the top open resulting in an spill. I'm being careful how I position it, but I know that, if I don't put it in my purse, I'm going to leave it someplace.)

This "cooling sensation" is actually a pretty good idea. I think that my 25 month old granddaughter has finally gotten the idea that she's wetting her diaper. Unfortunately, although she promptly notifies us that her diaper is wet, she still wets it unless, by some miracle, we manage to time the potty stop just right. We are working towards having her identify the feeling that comes BEFORE the coolness.The fact that when she's in childcare 5 days a week there isn't any follow-through on toilet training isn't helping. I believe that during summer vacation when I have her more often and can be more consistent, these trainers will be a big help in making a cause-and-effect connection. At least, between the princess design and the cooling sensation, she's somewhat engaged in the process.

This may not be a luxury bathroom set, but it will do just fine for a second bathroom, a dorm or starter apartment.The good qualities are:--its bright and colorful and the range of colors is wide enough that it will go well in most neutral colored bathrooms and with any shade of blue.--the quality is pretty good for the price. The shower curtain is made of polyester, which gives it a bit of a shiny appearance, and the print is just as sharp as you see in the photos.--the matching sink accessories have a matching design which is also sharp and bright.--the lotion dispenser can be used for liquid soap of the non-foaming variety and the pump works just fine.The less stellar qualities are:--the soap holder has drainage holes which, while preventing the soap getting mushy, passes the mush right through to the sink. A two-piece soap holder with a removable bottom would have been better.--the shower curtain has reinforced button holes instead of grommets. Im not sure what that means for durability, but I dont find it promising considering how people seem to yank at shower curtains.--the plastic hooks fit fine in the button holes (as any hooks would). They are of a different design than the usual plastic shower hooks, but dont work any less well or feel more fragile.Neutral notes:--since a toothbrush holder wasnt provided, I use the cup to hold toothbrushes and those tiny paper cups for rinsing. Its much more sanitary anyway.--a clear plastic liner should be purchased before first use to avoid getting the shower curtain wet or soapy. (This is standard procedure, regardless of the quality of the shower curtain, but the liner is not provided in the kit.)--the set has a definite masculine feel to it. This is fine for my guest bathroom since its my son and grandson who primarily use it.

This toy is as much fun as it looks in the TV commercials. My grandson had been attracted to it when he saw it and I was delighted to have it offered on Vine.Knowing how commercials tend to exaggerate, I was a little skeptical that it could live up to the hype. Surprisingly, it does provide plenty of excitement and the toy functions just as we saw in Nickelodeon. The ring does shoot off the shield with great force.Some of the virtues of the toy, such as the efficient and rapid way it dispatches the star rings can also be faults. It shoots hard and far and high. This is very good from one point of view but it has its downside as well.  Its hard to find the right place to use it without losing a ring or hurting a bystander. Its perfectly safe for the child using it, but it can hurt someone in the way of the projectile or (as happened to us) it can get stuck in a tree or a roof. I was able to get one off the roof using a step ladder and the pool brush but Im waiting for the gardener to come again to get the one that is stuck on our live oak in the front yard.The path of the ring is also a little bit hard to control. The slightest breeze or variation in the angle in which its being held and it swerves off what you expect would be a straight trajectory. The only safe place to stand is behind the child shooting it.This is not a toy to use indoors. The best place Ive found is my brothers back porch which runs the whole width of the house and has nothing breakable and nothing on which the rings can get caught.Another con is that it only comes with two rings. Given their propensity to travel fast and high, it is not unlikely that in the near future one will get permanently lost.But all of the above are adult concerns. My grandson loves it. His friends love it. The construction, functionality, design, and colors are just right. It has been used intensely and often by different children (ages 6 and 7) and a couple of so-called adults and there is no noticeable wear or deterioration. If we manage to hold on to the rings, the toy (and the excitement) should last for a long time.

It's not that I don't like it or find it flimsy or badly made. It's perfectly sturdy. The problem is that I haven't been able to find it useful in any of the projects that I've taken on. I recently cut out a tree with many small leaves and would have thought that this was the project in which it would prove its worth. No such luck, I can't imagine what it would be used for.  The tip is not sharp but I guess it's sharp enough to classify as a hook. The only tool I've found to be essential is the spatula. I have to use that on every single project.

Tracks of Her TearsRoughly seven months have past and Seth and Carly along with their daughter have settled back into being a family. Seth has left the Drug Task Force is now working as a county investigator on the Major Crimes team. When he's called to the scene of a murder he is shocked to find the victim is his wife's younger brother's girlfriend which leads to realizing that Bruce is also missing.It was nice being back with the Taylor family. Each one of them is unique in their own way and I love their momma Patsy who is a force to be reckoned with when her family is threatened. As with the other books in this series the mystery/murder/suspense that starts in Melinda's book isnt fully solved/concluded until Kendra's (or vice versa).I've enjoyed all the books from these two author's separately for years and was excited when they teamed up to write the Rogue River series and even more excited to see they were going to team up again to give us more of Carly Taylor and Seth (Melinda) and Stevie Taylor and Zane (Kendra) along with a new murder/mystery to be solved.(ps.. its so hard to write separate reviews for these two books as they are closely connected. Bottom line I really liked both books and hope we get more stories from these two about the Taylor family)Dead in Her TracksIts been 7 months and Stevie has still not 100% committed relationship wise to Zane. The two are called out to a murder at a hotel of a young girl and realize that the killer they had arrested for another murder (from Melinda's book) either had committed more murders than they thought or there was another killer out there. Through out the investigation and interviewing of witness and suspects they come to realize there are a lot of shady and bad things going on in there sleepy little town.As with the other books in this series the mystery/murder/suspense that starts in Melinda's book isnt fully solved/concluded until Kendra's (or vice versa).I've enjoyed all the books from these two author's separately for years and was excited when they teamed up to write the Rogue River series and even more excited to see they were going to team up again to give us more of Carly Taylor and Seth (Melinda) and Stevie Taylor and Zane (Kendra) along with a new murder/mystery to be solved.

Roughly seven months have past and Seth and Carly along with their daughter have settled back into being a family. Seth has left the Drug Task Force is now working as a county investigator on the Major Crimes team. When he's called to the scene of a murder he is shocked to find the victim is his wife's younger brother's girlfriend which leads to realizing that Bruce is also missing.It was nice being back with the Taylor family. Each one of them is unique in their own way and I love their momma Patsy who is a force to be reckoned with when her family is threatened. As with the other books in this series the mystery/murder/suspense that starts in Melinda's book isnt fully solved/concluded until Kendra's (or vice versa).I've enjoyed all the books from these two author's separately for years and was excited when they teamed up to write the Rogue River series and even more excited to see they were going to team up again to give us more of Carly Taylor and Seth (Melinda) and Stevie Taylor and Zane (Kendra) along with a new murder/mystery to be solved.(ps.. its so hard to write separate reviews for these two books as they are closely connected. Bottom line I really liked both books and hope we get more stories from these two about the Taylor family)

Dana Martin gives us a dark and vengeful hero in this latest in the Civilian Personnel Recovery Unit series.I didnt quite know what to make of Light Walker when we first meet him. He is one angry dude out to avenge the death of his younger brother. He left the SEALs and is now a mercenary for hire who doesnt think twice about killing.Clara Roberts typically found and retrieved US citizens and got them back home whether alive or dead. She's about to take a leave from her job to go and help her father through his chemo when instead he sends her on a mission into Mexico to find a missing young woman. Her father asks Walker to be her guide and muscle to help. The two embark on a harrowing trek through the Mexican jungle running from banditos and the deadly wildlife of the jungle.Walker goes through quite the transformation through out the book. He's lived for so long looking for the man that killed his brother and killing any bad guys in the way he figured he didnt have a heart left. Clara surprisingly makes his dead heart start beating again and he has to decide what's more important  his need for revenge and not caring about anything or to come back to being a human being that cares about someone.

I didnt know what to expect from new series from Anne Marie Becker. When I first read what the series was going to be about I was skeptical as it seem like such a huge departure from her previous series. Now that I've finished the book and I can it definitely say  its nothing like her Mindhunter series but I'm hooked and loved it. The characters are not your normal everyday law abiding people. Doesnt mean they dont have good hearts but they defiantly walk a fine line.I love strong heroines that can take care of themselves and Skye Hamilton is definitely that kind of woman. She was raised by men who are anti-government and constantly train for any type of disaster.  She trust no one and is an expert with both guns and knives and hand to hand combat.  She's currently helping a friend look for his missing daughter which bring her face to face with a man who at first seem to be working for the enemy.Jared Bennigan didnt have the greatest upbringing and left for the Army as soon he graduated. This is left his much younger two half-sisters in the care of his reckless mother who ended up dead due to her life style choices. He's now back in Las Vegas working for Global Security Solutions. When one of his sister goes missing he goes in as a bodyguard to one of Hollywood's elite after a clue points to him having knowledge of what happened to her.  Robert Stone is also the man Skye is tracking for the same reason.As the reader we know what's going on and who has the girls and for what purposes. Even knowing this the suspense was still pretty high and there were plenty of secrets that were still left to be revealed as the story went along.Jared was a guy that kept his cool pretty much the whole book and had lots of patients on getting the very non trusting Skye to eventually trust him so they could team up to find the girls together. The final showdown with the bad guys was violent and gory but ohh so satisfying.So to end my review I shouldnt have worried about this new series because it was just as captivating as her previous one. Looking forward to future books in the series.

From page one you are pulled into a captivating story that takes hold of your mind and catapults you through such an emotional journey to finding the truth about a murder that happened over twenty years ago.Loreth Anne White  has such an intelligent way of telling a story. I've always thought her voice was unique and In the Waning Light proves that still to be true.I'm not going to speak much about the actual story  the blurb gives a good description  as it would give away too many secrets that are a big part of this book. The reader needs to experience them as Meg Brogan (the heroine) a true crime writer as she writes and experiences them during the book. The author doesnt write what I call conventional romantic suspense. What she puts a reader through is torture until that last page. When I say that I am not meaning it as a bad thing just you have no idea of which way something is going to go until the end.

I soo didnt want this book to end. I'm not a huge reader of paranormal and it really has to be good and engaging and the world building done in a way you understand what's going on and this book accomplished all of those.I dont even now how to explain everything that went on in this book but if your a lover of spooky paranormals with great characters and a story line you can see going on for many books then I recommend you try this series.

This is about two families. There were two children from those families that fell in love which didnt excite either family. Right after a spur of the moment decision to marry the girl is devastated by something her husband does and runs away for 6 years.After six years she comes back for a divorce and winds up finding out the truths about both families and boy are they shocking revelations.The name of the series is The Syndicate so that should give you a clue that this is about the Mafia so that shouldn't be a spoiler. Everyone from both sides had done a great job of making sure that Calla Greer had no idea what kind of family she was born into nor what kind of family her husband Cain was from.Callie has been living clueless in Canada for 6 years not knowing that there has been a contract out on her. When she comes back to Detroit for a divorce she had no idea what she was walking into.As with any Mafia series its not just about the 2 main characters. The mob is all about the family and there are plenty of additional characters that make up this story. I enjoyed this first book that introduced us to the two families and look forward to getting more of their stories in future books.(NOTE: This is not a cliffhanger book per se as Calla and Cain resolve their issues during the book but there are threads that are not concluded that I am sure will be in the future books)

There is always going to be a first and what that first is for me is not liking the first 35% of this book.  It took 10 chapters to finally (which is what the chapter is called coincidentally) get the reason Millie Cross left Logan High Judd 20 years ago. And once we got that reason it was ONE not was I was thinking and TWO kinda anticlimactic.I get the sacrifice that Millie made for Logan  it was noble but geez  it was dragged out to long. BUT once the secret is out from that point on I loved the book. It became the type of love story I've come to love from Kristen Ashley. The only parts I liked with the flashbacks was getting to see how the club was 23 years ago when Crank was the president of Chaos. It was cute getting to meet Tabby when she was just a little girl and getting to see a little of the brothers that were now dead but have been talked about through out the other books. Long time enemy of the Club, Benito Valenzuela is back still trying to stir up trouble for Chaos.So the last 65% of the book gave a great story with plenty of laughs from the women, plenty of hot lovin between Millie and Logan, little bit of suspense and some interesting developments on some possibly future stories..  So all in all I enjoyed most of the book and very curious to see whose story is next.

What a great love story. I would never have thought a story could be written about two broken people and it not be over the top in angst or drama but Aly Martinez has written that story in The Fall Up.This books deals in some serious subject matters, suicide, mental illness and depression. You would think that would mean a sad story but it wasnt. It was uplifting that two people ended up being the shining  light the other was lacking in their lives and gave each other the confidence to face past and current demons and to do what takes to become healthy so they can start their journey to happiness together.This books was a perfect blend of romance, healing, and laughter with a perfect ending.

Revenge, retribution and eternal love all wrap up the Luminous series. We were left in the middle of huge cliffhanger at the end of Translucent. Transparent picks right up where we were left hanging and we get the answers to who kidnapped Blake.I was surprised at who had kidnapped Blake and why but pleasantly so. I'm not going to go into detail about things but I will say I was very satisfied with everyone's fate by the end of the book.

Secrets, lies, betrayal and shocking revelations are just a part of what goes on in this latest from Pamela Clare.I've come to expect a great story from Ms Clare but knowing what she went through during the writing of this book makes it that much more amazing.To keep from accidentally divulging any spoilers all I am going to say is everything you thought you knew about Holly Bradshaw from all the previous I-Team books is wrong. The hero is this one is someone we had not met before, Nick Andris who works for the CIA and in reading this book my feelings havent changed about the CIA  shadiest group of people that always has a traitor or two in its mist.I've enjoyed all the I-Team books and this was no exception. Looking forward to the Christmas I-Team novella coming soon.

Slower paced and more time spent with character development than in peril but still a solid 2nd book in the series.The Biological Response Team is still searching for the terrorist that wrecked havoc in the first book. This time up its Sophia Perry who is a virologist and hematologist. Sophia had leukemia as a child and even though she went into remission now her bone marrow has stopped producing. She figures she is on borrowed time and wants to do one last big thing before she dies. She gets that chance when the terrorist unleashes a new bio weapon.Connor Button is the latest Special Forces soldier to be assigned to the BRT. He was the sole survivor of an IED blast that killed all of his team. He too is looking for one last big mission to put himself in harms way in hopes of it also taking his life. What he didnt count of was the young genius he was assigned to.  During their time getting to know each other and after being deployed to the latest site of the biological strike two people who didnt figure they would live long lives come to find a reason to want to live.There is one more book in the series which will hopefully wrap up catching the terrorist and will give us the head of the  Biological Response Team story.

This fast paced, intense suspense keeps you on the edge of your seat till the very end. I think this book has the highest body count I've ever read. Its like watching the Walking Dead, no one is safe.Having read my fair share of Military romantic suspense I was pleasantly surprised to find this series  goes a step further and incorporates bioterrorism and the Biological Response Team who does their best to make the world safe from the terrorists that use it.The book takes place in Afghanistan where Grace Daniels is both a trauma surgeon and on a Biological Response Team.  She has seen the ugly side of war from all sides and its definitely left its mark on her soul. She has become best friends with one of the men assigned to keep her safe and when a village is completely wiped out from an anthrax these two have to depend on each other to not only keep themselves alive but to also stop a terrorist bent on revenge.Once I started this book I couldnt put it down until I'd finished it. The action is non-stop and every situation was intense. Looks like I've found a new author and series to read and cant wait to start the next book in the series.

What a journey this series has been. The search for a killer finally comes to a conclusion and in the fashion of how this author has written this series it is not done in an orthodox way.There is nothing more sweeter as a reader to not know the journey I am about to take when starting a book. This series took you places you never expected to go, blew your mind a time or two and if you have the tendency to side more on the twisted side of thinking this ended will satisfy all your cravings.

Every once in a while you see something come across your news feed that catches your attention. This was that book for me. The title  the blurb and even the reviews drew me in. The two main characters are 17 and still in high school but have known each other since grade school. Delilah Blue has been away for 7 years after punching two bullies that were picking on a boy she was crushing on. Her family then sent her off to a all girls boarding school. Now she is back home and attending public school where she runs into her childhood crush Gavin Timothy again. Delilah has some weird fascinations, one being  medevil torture devices and other morbid things and she doesnt really care what anyone thinks of her. Her crush on Gavin who was always known as the weird boy who lived in a even weirder house hasnt lessoned any during her time away. Now that she's older she decides she is going to rekindle their friendship in hopes that it turns into more.On the surface this was a funny budding romance between two quirky people who just fit together. Once the story got going we saw that Gavin had a strange childhood. He wasnt raised by a person  he was raised by a House. For a short while you think ok that's creepy but what a cool concept. Well House doesnt like to share and we come to find out that if you make House mad bad things can happen.**SPOILERISH**The big showdown between Delilah and the House was cool when she pulled out her inner Buffy and kicked ass. There is a shocking revelation towards the end but we never really find out why the House was the way it was.  END SPOILERThis was an entertaining read and if your looking for something spooky to read around Halloween I'd recommend this book.

This had all the elements you expect from Jill Shalvis and the Animal Magnetism series. Plenty of humor, great sexy banter between the H/h and plenty of cute animals. Along with the things you've come to expect it also surprisingly had a good deal of time spent on a suspense plot which gave this more of a romantic suspense feel than just a contemporary romance which was a bonus for me.

This author never ceases to take me on an emotional roller coaster ride with every book she writes. This series has never had any conventional romances. She always takes two people who couldnt be more different from everything from looks to moral values to where and how they were raised but yet as the story progresses you see along with the characters they are perfect for each other.Shane Rydell never felt like he fit in with his family even though he loved his brother dearly. They were raised on a cattle and horse ranch and horses were never his thing. His father was a little rough on him due to this which in turn made Shane once he was old enough leave for months at a time on his Harley. Shane answered to no one and he did what he wanted no apologies. He was happiest when he was fixing old tractors or cars or motorcycles. Give him something electronic and he'd tinker with it. He also didnt believe in relationships. He unapologetically slept with who he wanted whether they were married or not and his conscience was clear because he wasn't the one cheating. His view on life and how he lived it came to a screeching halt once he has to attend his nephews parent/teacher conference when his brother is away on his honeymoon.I look at this book as two parts. The first part was the restoration of Shane's conscience by Allison Gray who is an elementary teacher with aspirations of helping others with reading disabilities. She has a strong moral compass and doesn't hesitate in telling Shane his selfish actions have the potential to harm innocent people. As Shane starts to finally feel in his heart again and look at his actions your heart breaks for him when even his own family has a problem believing the drastic change. The second half of this book is Allison Gray's story. Shane knew right away he loved Allison but he had no idea of the deep rooted emotional pain she was hiding. I'm not going to get into what that was but it rips your heart out a time or two or three.Unknowingly Allison made Shane into a better man which she in turn would need to help her move past some traumatic issues.There was one other thing that was very special to see during this book. In the first book in the series the heroine was illiterate and had suffered because of her never being able to learn to read. Allison knew she suffered from dyslexia that had gone undiagnosed for more than 26 years and through Shane's urging convinced Allison to get educated and certified to teach Erin how to conquer her disability and finally learn to read. Nothing is ever easy for any characters in any of Leanne's books but love and determination eventually get these characters the happiness they finally deserve.

Note: Reading Until July should be done before reading this one as it literally picks up after a rescue done at the end which involves the heroine of this book.The Until Her/Him series consist of the children of the Mayson men from Until series (which I also recommend reading). When Jax Mayson rescues Ellie Anthony  along with his cousin July from human traffickers he experiences the BOOM.  Fans of the series know what the boom is  for those that dont all the men know immediately when they've met the one. Ellie was that one for Jax.Ellie didnt have a good home life and could only depend on her brother but when he and the mother of his daughter are killed in a car accident Ellie becomes the guardian to their infant daughter Hope. Hope is now 3 and she about steals all the scenes in the book.Along with the love story there is also the wrapping up of the human traffickers and also a surprise ending to some thing from Jax's parents book Until Lilly. Plenty of teasers too about the other Mayson kids stories which I cant wait for.

HIDDENHang on to your hats - there is a new suspense sheriff in town. I can not express how much I loved this book. I am a huge fan of Karen Rose and when I saw her recommend this author I didn't even think twice just bought it and started reading.From the opening scene until the last, the words just flowed. The author flawlessly takes us on a journey that spans the course of 11 years.There are many cast of characters. The sole surviving victim of the Co-ed Slayer who had murdered nine female students 11 years before. Lacey Campbell barely escaped but her best friend was taken and never heard from again even after he was caught and sentenced to death based on her testimony. She is now a forensic odontologist examining teeth and bones for the state Medical Examiner and is shocked when called to a scene to help identify bones that were found under an apartment that they are the bones of her friend that was taken all those years ago.Jack Harper is a ex-police officer who happens to own the property that the remains are found on. Before Lacey figures out that the bones are of her friend there are some sparks that fly between him and Lacey. Jack who used to date one of the murdered college women and was questioned as a suspect back then and comes under the scrutiny of the press again after the body was found on his property.Michael an investigative reporter who is also Lacey ex-boyfriend and best friend doesn't like Jack and when he sees there's an attraction between Lacey and Jack he runs Jack through the ringer in the paper. But his first and only goal is keeping Lacey safe and that common tread eventually make Jack and Michael allies.Mason Callahan and Ray Lusco are with the Oregon State Police Major crimes and play a big part through out the story.Then we have our sick and twisted killer. Who could this killer be that is going after all the people that put the Co-ed Slayer away. It cant be him as he died in prison.I live to read books like this. I love the suspense and getting into the mind of the killer and watching the quest to hunt the killer down from every person from the Hero to the police.CHILLEDAs with the first book the author flawlessly takes us on a journey where the words just flow.There are a lot of characters that we bounce back and forth with. A search and rescue team is assembled to go into the Cascade Mountains to search for survivors of a plane crash. On board the plane were two pilots, a US Marshal and a serial killer.Sheriff Patrick Collins rounds up his SAR crew who are Jim Wolf and Thomas Todoroff, deputies with the Sheriff's ofc, Ryan Sheridan a cop from another county and Brynn Nealey (our heroine) who is a forensic nurse who goes along in case someone is hurt. At the last minute they get a call that a US Marshal is going to be joining them in there search. Alex Kinton (the hero) has lied his way onto the search team to search for his brother's killer to make sure he is either dead or reprehended.The other characters are the serial killer Darrin Besand and Alex's old boss Paul Whittenhall.We are lead from here on a chilling trek through the forest through freezing temps and snow. We learn about each of the rescue crew along the way. Alex after losing his brother and putting away the man who killed him and then eventually losing his job had done nothing for the past year but drink and take pills. He thought he was emotionally dead inside and struggles for most of the trip to find the plane about his attraction to Brynn and eventually to caring about everyone on the team.BURIEDKendra Elliot has written her best book to date and shows why this series is called bone secrets.Twenty years ago a school bus with nine children and the driver just vanished. Two years later one survivor walked out of the Cascade Mountains with no memory and near death.Now it is eighteen years later and a grisly discovery has been made. They have found the mass grave of the children and others that were not on the bus but one child is still unaccounted for, that is our hero Michael Brodys brother.Fans of the series will remember Michael from the first book as the intense reporter ex-boyfriend of forensic odontologist Lacey Campbell. He is just as intense in this book in his quest to find out what happened to his brother and why his bones are not with the others. This quest leads him to the sister of the lone survivor who he now desperately wants to talk to. But Chris Jacobs has been in hiding and no one knows where he is. Jamie Jacobs is a principal and needs to have order in her life since her brothers abduction and return. She cant just up and leave at the spur of the moment even if it is to help find her brother. That is, until she is attacked by why looks to be the man that tortured her brother all those years ago.Mason Callahan and Ray Lusco with the Oregon State Police Major crimes are also back in this book and these two are such a hoot together.This was a heartbreaking tale especially since it dealt with children. The author did a fantastic job of taking us through the discovery, the ME reports and the investigation on who had done this and a few other big twist that lead up to a shocking ending.VEILEDJack and Lacey are back. We met these two in Kendras first book Hidden. They are at a resort scoping it out as a possible wedding venue when they find themselves in the middle of a murder investigation when a woman in a wedding dress is found floating in the resorts hot tub.Even though this was a novella sized book we still got a good murder mystery to follow from all aspects  the interrogations to the autopsies. One thing Jack and Lacey cant do is walk away from a murder and when they find out Jacks old partner is the Chief of Police in the small town they decide to hang around and help solve the murder. Jack and Lacey work well together and are even closer after everything they went through in Hidden. It was great to get to revisit them again and follow them along on the investigation that has a few surprises along the way.ALONEMy final thoughts as I finished this book were this was a great example of overcoming adversity. The heroine, Victoria Peres overcame many during her life and as the book goes on you realize this woman really beat the odds.Weve met Victoria in previous books. She is a forensic anthropologist that has been nicknamed the ice queen and bone lady. She is perceived as being anti-social and unfeeling. But that is not the case and her walls begin to crumble at the site of a mass murder of young girls when one of the reasons she sealed off her emotions, Seth Rulledge, shows up at the scene as one of the candidates for the medical examiner job that would make him her boss. Seth and Victoria were college sweethearts whose romance ended in heartbreak but Seth has vowed to make up for that now and hopes to win Victoria back.The investigation of the murder of the young girls and its eerie similarity to one from the 60s is treaded throughout the book with plenty of fascinating information on how a forensic anthropologist finds out who a person is just from bones and the inner workings of an autopsy but it was also a character story of how people overcome a bad childhood, relationship heartbreak and traumatic events to still succeed in life by being persistent and resilient and not letting circumstances or events knock them down for long and that in the end love, inspiration, faith and patience can finally pay off.Mason Callahan and Ray Lusco with the Oregon State Police Major crimes are also back in this book and as always are a joy to read as they try to solve the case.It may not seem like it from what Ive written so far but this book did have plenty of suspense. From the moment the girls are found lying in a field all in white dresses and arranged in a perfect circle to the atrocious revealing of why, you are turning the pages and gasping as each clue is revealed.I am never disappointed by Kendras stories and that was no different with Alone. I look forward to the next book from her.

VanishedThe combined elements of a murder mystery and kidnapping of a young child make up this psychological thriller that deals with danger more on a mental level rather than a physical one.Mason Callahan is a character weve met in previous books in the series. He and his partner Ray Lusco are with the Oregon State Police Major crimes division and have been instrumental in solving cases in the previous books. Mason has always been a fascinating character and I was thrilled to learn this book was going to be about him. Weve only got to see the work side of Mason  even though thats all Masons life really is about  so it was nice to finally get to know the man behind the cowboy hat.While I was reading this it came to mind more than once what on earth Mason had done to the author to warrant her putting this poor man through the mental anguish she did in this book. But that makes for good reading and she didnt just stop with him, the heroine FBI Special Agent Ava McLane, who was part of the team working to find the girl, certainly had her fair share of mental anguish too. I really liked Ava, she was good at her job and had great insights and was able to separate personal issues from the job which was something Mason wasnt able to do in this book.There was a large cast of characters in this one along with many facets of the FBI including the Child Abduction Rapid Deployment (CARD) Team which was fascinating to learn about. They deploy teams of experienced personnel to provide on-the-ground investigative, technical, and resource assistance to state and local law enforcement when a child is abducted. There was obviously a lot of homework done in the writing of this book and it really showed. I was captivated from page one and of course was rooting for my man Mason to get his HEA and some peace of mind.BridgedAs a lover of romantic suspense I always find its a sign of good writing when I find myself feeling sympathy for the killer. Now that doesnt always happen as some are just too sick and twisted to relate to but the killer in Bridged is one I found myself understanding his reasonings behind what he was doing.This second book in the series picks up a few months after the firsts one. Mason and Ava are now practically living together and making their relationship work even with the stresses of their two jobs. His as a detective with the Oregon State Police and she is a FBI agent. The work collides with the death of a man found hanging naked on a bridge.I liked how the author writes about the equal balance of home and work between these two. Mason and Ava have always been dedicated to their jobs but balancing a relationship between that is new to both of them and I thought they did a great job of it. No egos got in the way between them as it was clear they respected the other and the work each does.This was a good mystery as to why the killer was doing what he was doing and the reveal slow as to what the main motive was. As the book went along your thoughts on the victims certainly changed.I always enjoy the stories Kendra has to tell and this was no exception. Im looking forward to whats next in this series from Mason and Ava..SpiraledHold on to your seats for this one. Literally starts off with a bang and youre on a adrenaline filled ride to the end. Ava McLane has gotten herself in the middle of chaos again.Its been 8 months since Ava and Mason met and their relationship has sure been filled with intense situations that would test any new relationship but Mason has proven hes in it for the long haul. Ava is supposed to be on vacation from her job with the FBI but instead finds herself in the middle of mass shooting at the local mall. This isnt the first mass shooting recently and before long there is another. Mason and Ray get assigned to the task force to figure out whats going on and of course Ava cant just sit on the sidelines.There are many twist and turns throughout the investigation with some shocking revelations. Ava is brought to her breaking point not only with the shooting but also by her sister Jayne. Avas twin is such a pain as a reader I want to just strangler her for what she puts Ava through. Another great story in the Mason and Ava series and I hope the love these two have for each other continues to hold strong through all their trials and tribulations.

The impression you have of what the book is about in the first chapter is not at all what you get by the end. There are so many twists to the story that were slowly revealed until a surprise ending. I highly recommend this one. It also has quite of few characters that are from her older suspense books that make appearances.

Part 1Wow.. This is one of THOSE books. The kind that leaves you speechless at the end and still thinking about it hours and even days later.Its so hard to write a review about a book like this because its an experience book. You as a reader need to experience every single thing yourself as your reading it. To talk in depth about this book would give away to many spoilers. But its soo worth the read.My best advice is to read the blurb.. Id like to give you a few warnings but I wont. Well maybe one  plenty of explicit sex.. And a mind blowing ending.I also want to say the cover for this book is 100% spot on. So many covers dont accurately depict the characters but once you read the book and then look back at the cover, its telling you a story all in itself.Part 2This is the conclusion to Contrite which was such a phenomenal dark and twisted book. There were things I was happy with in this book and things I was disappointed in. Contrite was such a rush  like an extreme high and Reprisal was so mellow in comparison.I still recommend reading this series as Contrite was one of the best books Ive read this year.

After reading this I have come to realize that I have issues with this type of story line. So take my 3 rating and review with a grain of salt. When the lead is a reporter for most of the book they are lying or conniving to get that story. Shelley Jackson finds the body of a friend who she briefly dated in an ally where he had asked her to meet him about evidence of corruption at a large company. For someone she should have care about all she was really interested in was finding on his dead body that evidence and then left him in that ally. Yes she called 911 but it was still a cold thing to do.Jason Mallory is the dead man's step brother and feels guilt over his brother death as he was getting the information for him. Jason is a rich businessman who knows Shelly is keeping secrets about what happened to his brother. As these two eventually team up to find out who killed him a few more bodies pile up and they also start a sexual relationship.Even though I had issues with Shelley's moral character she was a tough woman and I loved how she kept one upping a sleazy fellow reporter. The writing was good and the middle part of the book kept your interest but then we get to the ending. Shelly did a 180 and become a Scarlett O'Hara  begging Jason to not leave her and vowed she would get him back. The switch from strong tenacious reporter to sniveling love struck woman was hard to swallow.

I applaud authors who want to step out of their normal writing box and write something that's shocking, dark and very taboo. But there is also a risk of either the subject matter or story being a little out of the comfort zone of the reader.The author wastes no time in introducing the shocking and taboo parts of the book in the first chapter. If you can stomach the first chapter the rest until the end isn't so bad. One thing I am not a fan of putting a character through hell giving them a tiny glimpse of normal and then yanking it from them again at the end for reasons that really dont make sense.Something I had not seen before was the author gave us two epilogues so you can decide how you wanted it to end. I got how the heroine could go either way but after reading the book I was left very unsatisfied with all the outcomes. For me where it went wrong was the last chapter before the epilogues.

Paige Tyler kicks off a new series (non paranormal) with Rekindled which is about Firefighters in Dallas, Texas. Jax Malloy and his team are called to a hotel fire. One of the women he rescues happens to be his best friends sister who he hasnt seen in 10 years. Skye Chandler and her brother Dane lost their parents years ago to a fire in their home. Skye shortly after left for college and never returned. Now after breaking up with her boyfriend and quitting her job she's returned home to start a new career.Jax offers for her to stay at his place after the fire and two get reacquainted and find themselves attracted to each other. This causes a bit of a rif between Jax and Dane but when there is another big fire and Jax is hurt everyone comes together and realizes their may be more going on than just the typical fire bug.This was a good start to the series and I am looking forward to Dane's story.

Its always sad when a series comes to an end but the author always gives us such great epilogues that in the end you feel happy for all the great couples we've met over the course of this series.The last couple up in the 'Berg series are two people that have been in the background since the first book. Cher (Cheryl in previous books) was the Bohemian brash bartender who unfortunately had dated and been deceived by a serial killer. Afterwards her and son changed their last names to stay out of the limelight. Cher is not a conventional mother but she loved her son deeply and did whatever she needed to do that make sure he had a good life growing up. Through out the years she's watched her friend Garrett Merrick mourn over his marriage while having a crush on him. One night when Merry was drowning his sorrows in a bottle of boos Cher decides to lay it out for him about his ex wife and the two end up getting drunk and having a wild night of sex.Garrett is a Lieutenant with the local police department. He and his sister both didn't deal well with the tragic murder of their mother years ago. Her death left them both with inner demons that sabotaged any personal relationships. Rocky finally got her issues worked out with Tanner but Merry was still stewing in his until Cher opened his eyes to maybe its wasnt all on him on why his marriage didnt work out and that maybe his friend Cher was the woman who would give him back his soul.All the previous cast of characters are back in Hold On and along with the romance there are a few suspense plots running through the story. One of the things I've really enjoyed about this series are the characters are in their late 30's to early 40's and some already have kids they are coming into the relationship with along with pasts that need to be worked through. Even though the characters are sometimes over the top and of course fictional they are written to where you feel like these are people you could know in real life and can relate to.

A much deserved second chance at love for a man who weve seen in so much pain throughout this series since his wife was tragically gun down in front of BKI headquarters 2 years ago.Dan Currington drowned his grief in a bottle. He had lost his will to live. But with the help of his friends and AA he has come back to the land of the living. Two months ago on a fateful mission in Kuala Lumpur he met Secret Service Agent Penni DePaul. They had an immediately chemistry which surprised Dan but when a bomb takes out the rest of Pennis team they part ways.Dan and Dagan Zoelner have been in Peru for the last 3 months along with CIA agent Chelsea Duvall trying to catch the CIA traitor that was in part responsible for the bombing in the last book. Dan hasnt been able to get Penni off his mind and is shocked when she shows up saying she needs to talk to him. The action takes off from here and the 4 of them find themselves dodging bullets before managing to get out of Peru.As with all of the books in this series there are overlapping story arcs throughout the books along with the setting up of the next couple. It was great to finally get to see Dan get some happiness back in his life and I liked how the author handled still honoring Dans deceased wife along with allowing him to find love again.

The Hatfields and McCoys got nothing on the Parkers and Bainbridges. Knox Parker and Felicity Bainbridge are from two families that hate each other. Regardless of this they fall in love as teens. But the Bainbridges wont have their daughter soil their name by being with a Parker and Knox pays a horrible price for loving Felicity.First off I have to say I loved that we got alternating views through out this whole book. Knox's were in the present and Felicity's were the past to start off with. Some of the books in the series have only been one POV and the alternating in this one blending past and present leading up to a horrible climax made the story work very well.Knox wasnt a character we had met before this book. How the author introduced him to the gang of the previous book was heartwarming and I have to say Pick has certainly become quite the matchmaker. Felicity was friends with many of the girls from the previous books and worked at Pick's bar. Knox didnt think he had any connection to any of group that he worked with at the bar but as the author unfolded his story that was not the case.As with all the Forbidden Men books at the core there is a great love story but this group of friends have all gone through hell before either meeting their soul mate or met them young and circumstances tore them apart until fate brought them back together again.Knox and Felicity story went through so many emotional stages. The young lovers thought despite their families hatred that their love for each other would be enough. And in a way it was even with all the hell that Knox went through and losing so much that it changed him to a angry man he still never stopped loving Felicity even though he didnt think himself worthy of her anymore. Felicity walked away from her family's and their fortune at 18 and never looked back even with her struggling financially. She never though she'd ever get a second chance with Knox and when he came back into her life unexpectedly she wasnt going to let him push her away even with all the demons he was fighting within himself.Asher's story is finally up next and boy does the author leave us with a bit of a cliffhanger about his story.

You just have no idea what this author is going to come up with in her books and its guaranteed to either shock you or give you the heebee jeebees where your going Oh My God she didnt just go there.Now with that being said I cannot tell you what gave me that moment in this book as it would be a spoiler of course <grin> but its still making me go ICK ICK ICK. I didnt think she could top the ickyness of the necrophiliac in the last book but she totally did.A lot of suspense authors (in my opinion) have gotten into a cookie cutter format and you feel that you've read that before or you can totally guess what's going to happen  no originality. I am here to tell you that after reading 10 books from this author she still has the power to surprise me with what her mind comes up with.If you haven't read this author and love romantic suspense with some of the sick and twisted killers I highly recommend you read her CORE series  all of them!

This series has been full of emotions. The Stockton brothers had such crappy childhoods that it left big scars on their souls and none thought they were worthy of love. Its taken women who are just as broken as they are to heal their hearts and the journey is all the sweeter as each couple has helped the other heal on their way to finding that lasting love.Who doesnt like a bad boy on a Harley. From the moment we met Zane Stockton in the first book he had me intrigued and looking forward to his story. He and Taylor were just perfect for each other. Two people so in need of love and affection but yet scared to death of it at the same time.Though we only got 3 of the Stockton brothers stories in this trilogy there are many more of them out there and I hope the author plans to continue the series.

Quick suspense of stalker who was underestimated by our hero many times. Dan McCray was asked by a friend to help a woman who has been continually victimized by a stalker. No one knew that he was so much more than just a common stalker.This was an enjoyable read and could have certainly been great full length suspense.

I liked this story about a active Navy Seal trying to find his sister that had went missing. Kevin Rimshot Stanton just couldn't get over her disappearance that had yealded no clues as to what happened to her. His father didn't really seem to care and he was at loose ends on who to contact to help. One night out with his team mates its mentioned he should hire Jaime Hensen a local PI who is known to find even the impossible. Rimshot's never forgotten the one time he met Jamie which was at his friends wedding which they both walked away from without acting on their attraction.Over twenty years ago Jamie's older sister went missing. Jamie has made it her life's goal to find her or at least what happened to her and went on to college to become the best tracker she could. When Kevin comes to her wanting her help to find his sister she was both happy to take the case and to finally get to act on the feelings they had at the wedding.Right up until the end I enjoyed the story and was curious as to what happened to Kevin's sister. I never dreamt we'd also get to find out what happened to Jamie's sister too. The last chapter is where I realized the author tied in a story that was started in another series of hers. It kind of took me out of the story a little as that series is a paranormal series and without having read it was a little confused. Other than that I really enjoyed Rimshot's Hard Target.

Two strangers meet in an airport closed by the weather turn out to have a lot more in common than they could have ever imagined.Kimberly Slocomb is desperate to get to her son in Virgina who was kidnapped by her deceased  husbands family. With no rental cars available she cautiously accepts a ride from a stranger who has offered to help her.Brier Larsen is on his way home after being away for months working for the Guardian Angels Protection Services when he see's a woman having a melt down over not being able to get to her son. He decides to help her out and offer to drive her their.What neither of them knew until the long drive through a snow storm was their lives were connected by Kimberly's dead husband who was a bad man and whose father was even worse.This was more suspense than romance as the majority of the story is Brier and Kimberly revealing their story  the common thing that connected them  on the drive and the suspense would they ever be safe from her son's grandfather. They did have an attraction through out the story but it wasnt until the epilogue that we saw the romance had truly formed.

First off that cover is hot isnt it? And the man inside the book was just as sexy. Mason Steele is feeling a little sorry for himself when he's forced out of the SEALs by a heart issue he'd developed. Having to do guard duty for a spoiled rich businesswoman who carries a dog everywhere is not where he saw his life ever going. Pansy Hightower has no idea who this huge hunk of a man is that has been following her but she is grateful he was when she is kidnapped and taken to the desert to be killed and buried.I liked both of the characters even with the super fast tracked romance that had to happen. My only little pet peeve was his calling himself a bedroom Dominate but yet at the start of the book we see him feeling sorry for himself and then when the first bedroom scene happens he is hemming and hawing when trying to explain to Pansy his dominant preference. That does not scream Dom to me. Other than that for the shortness of the book it was sexy and had just enough suspense to keep your attention.

Wow. J.M.'s military stories are always very emotional but the subject matter she tackled in this one and how she had her main characters deal with it was  I just cant think of the right word  but it makes you FEEL!!Trying to describe this book in a normal review would give away a lot spoilers. I'm just going to say this was a heartbreaking reunion story with shocking revelations.Its short, and I always feel the endings to these are a bit abrupt but it still packed a huge emotional punch. Another great addition to the Lost and Found series..

Right from the start you see that this heroine can take care of herself. First chapter of this book has Dana Markham kicking ass and not bothering with names.Dana and her 10 yr old son have been on the run for years from her ex husband who is dirty in many ways. She's learned that she can depend on no one but herself to stay alive as the FBI has fumbled more than once. In the latest attempt by her ex husbands hire killers to kill her and take their son she manages to kill all but one and that one turns out to be an undercover FBI agent who ends up taking responsibility for Dana and her son by going on the run with them.I didnt realize until about half way into this that I had read this years ago under another name. I take it since the cover and name of the book have changed its a complete reboot. I only say this to those who may have read the first book Dark and Dangerous (which is no longer available). If you haven't read that book then I recommend Dead Run. This was a fairly fast paced read with like I said a very exciting opening and two people who fall in love while on the run with lots of great scenes with her son and their very protective dog.

These Stockton boys sure tug on the heartstrings. I figured from the first book that Steen's story would be the most heartbreaking and it was. All of the brothers lived through hell in their childhood years but from that pain forged a tight bond between them. That past also made them leery of women and they each vowed to never marry or let a women ever get close enough to hurt them. Steen was the exception to this as he never felt he forged the tight bond with his half brothers and doesnt think he is the one worthy of love from a good woman.In the last book we knew Steen was in prison and had stepped in front of a knife to save a fellow inmate. It wasnt looking like he was going to make it until his brothers fiance whispered to fight to live because there is a woman out there who needs him and was waiting just for him. When this book starts Steen is getting out of prison still mending from his wounds and even though he was in a coma the words she spoke are still on his mind. When he meets a woman from his childhood he realizes she is as broken as he is and thinks his reason for not dying is to make sure she gains the confidence she needs in herself to move past the damage her parents and ex husband have caused her. He never once thinks he is deserving of anything. But as their time together progresses he see's that maybe he got it wrong she would be the one to save him  to make him see that he did deserve love just as much as she did.This story was just these two spending time together and slowly revealing their painful past to each other. No big suspense plots or action scenes, just two lonely people connecting and learning to forgive themselves for their past mistakes. The author does a great job of just pulling you into their grief and making you feel for them and want to see them finally get that piece of happiness they deserve.

Dangerous Waters (Vancouver Island - Carver Brothers #1)Great small town murder mystery with lots of twist and a romance.Opens with a shocking murder that happened 30 years ago and then goes to present day where another murder has happened. The story takes place in a small remote town in Canada. After two divers find a body underwater Sergeant Holly Rudd of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and her team arrive to investigate. Holly's father is a commanding officer with the RCMP and she always felt she had to prove herself. This was her first time being in charge of a homicide by herself and she wants to make her father proud. She is still smarting over getting involved with a staff sergeant who forgot to inform her he was married.Finn Carver, one of the divers who discovered the body has an ugly history with the little town. After serving many years in the special forces he comes back to town when the man who raised him is beat to within an inch of his life.He and Holly have an instant attraction but neither want to be, but they are constantly thrown together during the investigation. As the investigation goes along we see that the town is pretty good at keeping and hiding secrets. And there is a doozy of a one being kept hidden.I really like all the twist and turns during the investigation. The author kept you on your toes as to who was bad and who was doing what with whom.I was excited to here that Finn's brother will be getting his own book next. After you read this book you will see why he deserves his own book.Dark Waters (Vancouver Island - Carver Brothers #2)The author takes us on deeply sentimental journey of gritty realities with two resolute and courageously scarred characters.Right from the prologue you are thrown into a conspiracy of intrigue. When a father whos ex-wife and daughter doubted his innocence when he was convicted of crime many years ago and served 5 years hard time for it finds himself in trouble again he manages to send a message to his daughter to go to the only man he trust, Brent Carver his cell mate from prison, for protection.I fell in love with Brent in Dangerous Waters. He spent the better part of his life in prison and just did not adapt well to the harsh realities of the real world and all the people that lived in it. He has isolated himself in his home and just wants to be left alone to do the one thing he loves, painting. His peaceful isolation is thrown into a tailspin when Anna Silver, the daughter of the only real friend he ever had shows up on his doorstep needing his help.Annas childhood was not only torn apart by her fathers conviction but also by a mother who became distant and didnt pay attention to her and also missed the signs that another tragic thing had happened to her. Due to this Anna has chosen to live her life with white picket fences and teaching children. She is in no way prepared for the mess that her father unfortunately put her in the middle of.As these two skittish people try and figure out who is trying to kill Anna and avoid them they find that they bring out the strong qualities of courage and tough uncompromising resolve in each other. The journey we take with these two not only on the harrowing investigation but also on two broken hearts healing is compelling.I knew from the moment I met Brent that his story would be a powerful one and the bonus is his heroine was just as strong and courageous as he was even though neither of them saw themselves that way. There were some great twist and surprises in this book that kept you turning the pages until the very end.

She Can RunGreat suspense novel that has dual story lines that end up interconnecting. Beth and her two children have been on the run from her abusive husband, a Congressman who has a secret he wants to kill Beth for knowing, for ten months. Beth's Uncle, unknowingly to her, sets her up with a job with an old Nam buddy of his. But before Beth gets there he dies. His nephew (a cop who is on medical leave) has inherited the place and decides to keep Beth on for the job his Uncle had hired her for as he can tell there is something bad Beth and the kids are running from that has traumatized them.The other story line is Riverside Killer who abducts, rapes and murders women who all bear similar appearances. And the Killer now how his sites set on Beth.This was the first book I had read by this author and being a lover of romantic suspense I was very pleased at how well written this book was.Another great suspenseful novel full of multiple story lines that all converge together with a great supporting cast in a small northeastern Pennsylvania town.Rachel Parker has returned home 7 years after running away. She has come back to try and turn her grandfathers farm into a horse training and breading business after her career ended after being thrown from a horse. Not long after arriving bad things start happening on the ranch. An attempted break in and threatening messages painted on her barn. She just assumes they are from her brother in law who has turned into a mean abusive drunk. She is also suffering from guilt for just leaving town after her mothers funeral which in her eyes forced her sister to marry young to get away from their father. After getting a call from her sister to come and get her and her kids and rescue them from him she ends up having to fight for her life after finding her sister beaten and unconscious. She is rescued by the Police Chief Mike OConnell. They are both blindsided by their attraction but carry a lot of baggage that prevents either from acting on it at first.Mike still carries guilt for not catching a serial killer that had lived right under is nose. This guilt has has turned into an insane need to protect his town, and there are many weird things going on in town. When his growing feelings for Rachel turns into a conflict of interest and bring him under the radar of some corrupt city council members , one of which who wants to get him fired, he has to decide whats more important.There are multiple mysteries going on at the same time that all converge by the end of the book. The author does a great job of keeping your interest in all of these and wondering what is really going on. There was also a greater sense of camaraderie with the town in this one. Lots of great secondary characters and we get to see how Jack and Elizabeth from the first book are doing. I am looking forward to many more books from this author.She Can ScreamCharacter driven suspense with highly engaging characters and a killer to keep the tension high.The main characters Brooke Davenport and Luke Holloway are two souls haunted by past tragedies. Sixteen years ago Brookes roommate was murdered and it still haunts her today. Along with raising her two kids and teaching she feels she must make young women aware of the dangers that lurk around the corner and teaches a self-defense class. Lukes tragedy was more recent. Three months ago in the Philippines a terrorist bomb went off in the building he was in along with his assistant. Luke cannot get past seeing her die in front of him.The two are thrown together when Brookes brother who is Lukes best friend ask him to watch over her while he is deployed. When Brooke stops a killer from taking a young woman Lukes job changes from watching to protecting as Brooke cant let go of finding the perp and the killer decides he is going to mess with Brookes mind by leaving clues on bodies.Throughout the investigation we get to see some previous characters from the other books. Police Chief Mike OConnell and retired detective Jack OMalley are a big part of the team trying to catch the killer.Even though the killer/mystery is at the forefront there is also plenty of family time between Brooke and her kids and Luke and his grandmother and both of them having to finally come to terms with the significant things that has affected their lives and the decisions they have made based on those things.She Can HideA slow building mystery that has many characters that all end up coming together from different directions for the shocking conclusion.My thoughts on this one are that the author has written it so that the readers must deduce for themselves what the characters are like through their thoughts, actions, and interaction with other characters. When you got to the end of the book some of those conclusions you made throughout the book were not the right ones. Sometimes its refreshing to be wrong when reading a suspense or mystery trying to guess the who and what.This book was the perfect example that not all books have to be filled with tons of action to keep you turning the pages. Every character was interesting and you wanted to know more about each even though at first you didnt understand why all these characters were being introduced. But eventually the author reveals those reasons when the story lines intersect for what was a tense yet very satisfying conclusion.He Can FallWhat an adrenaline rush all packed into a short suspenseful story. All the characters were fascinating even the bad guys. It was also very noticeable that the author incorporated her real life training in Kenpo techniques into this book which for one made me never want to take her on in real life and and loving the creative way the hero took out the bad guys.Even though this was a fairly quick read it was jammed packed with action and suspense from the beginning and had a very satisfying ending. I bow to Ms Leigh and concede I loved it..

Running On Empty (LCR Elite #1)Fabulous start to the series.. I still remember how I felt when I read Rescue Me  the first in the Last Chance series  and this was just as powerful. One of the biggest things I love is that Noah is running the new group. Cannot get enough of that man : )There were plenty of new and old characters in Running On Empty. We meet Sabrina Fox and Declan Steele after they are married. Declan works for another covert group that Sabrina used to work for and Sabrina now works for LCR Elite. They had tons of history and what looked like a very strong bond/love for one another that nothing could tear apart. Well fate had something else in store for the two when Declan is presumed dead after an explosion.I love the women that Ms Reece writes  they may not always come from a good background/childhood but they grow into strong kick-ass women. Sabrina stayed strong through it all even after her husband came back with wanting nothing but revenge against her for thinking she was a traitor and had him tortured for months. Poor Declan (I love his name BTW) mind was messed with so much during his torture/interrogations that even though he didnt break his mind did end up believing the lies they told him. It was painful to watch Sabrina and Delcan together when he first returned because you knew of the love they had before it was ripped from them.Even though these books are fiction, the emotions, partnerships and situations always feel so real. Its like an adventure reading one of Ms Reeces books. I am so happy she started this new series and look forward to many books to come in the series.Chance Encounter (LCR Elite #2)I loved that Ms Reece brought back a character from a previous book to give her story closure. Now of course she put her and her LCR protector through hell before that but that makes a great suspense.For those that dont know, Kendra Carson/Kacie Dane story began in No Chance (Last Chance Rescue #4). She was Skylars model friend who was kidnapped and drugged and raped repeatedly by Skylars sick and perverted uncle.Now five years later she has changed her name and appearance and is working her way up in the modeling industry again. She still suffers from nightmares but refuses to let what happened to her in the past define her.
