That is until she starts getting creepy messages from a man she knows to be dead.Brennan Sinclair is new to the LCR Elite team and his first assignment is to be Kacies bodyguard. Brennan past was a horribly sad and tragic and has left some pretty deep scars. Kacie and Brennan are like two sides of a coin  they both had traumatic past but Kacie still choose to see the good in people and life where as Brennan was very cynical and trusted very few. Neither had even thought about getting involved with anyone since their tragedies but their sorrow seems to bind them during their time together.As the book went along with the LCR team trying to find out who was harassing Kacie by sending her sick reminders of her time in captivity your page turning wondering who is going to be the person behind it and why. Ms Reece as always has a twisted mind and the revelations are shocking.Im so glad she is continuing this series and even bringing back past characters weve met. Its always a joy to get to see the past LCR characters and I look forward to many more books in this series.

Liam Beckett lives up to the proverb of like father like son. Which means the son will have traits similar to his father upon reaching adulthood and boy does he ever.The woman that Liam determines is his has emotionally shut down to prevent her heart from ever breaking again. There were times early in her grief of losing her husband that even her daughter couldnt bring her out into the light.Through the friendship of Cohen Cage who served with her husband and his wife Dani she has allowed herself to open up just enough to allow friends in but yet still keeping her deepest secrets to herself. She finds herself attracted to Liam but is so afraid of opening herself up again that she's been pushing him away for years.Liam finally decides he's had enough and smothers her and her daughter with kindness and love in hopes that she will eventually let her barriers she has erected over her heart down enough to trust him and allow herself to feel and be loved.There were many times I found myself misty eyed through out this book but I also felt it mirrored just a little to closely to Dee and Beckett's story so it lacked a little originality.Overall I enjoy all of these characters and getting to now read the next generation of a great group of men and women who I came to love in the Corp Security series.

Its always disappointing when you've loved a previous series of an author and when they come out with a new one you just cannot connect to it. That is the case for me with Deep Six. The base of the series being about retired Navy Seals switching to underwater treasure hunters just didnt thrill me. And sadly neither did any of the characters.

Blood and Bone is a psychological thriller. Its a bizarre mixture of science fiction, mind games and serial killers. I guess I should state that those words I just used to describe the book could also be a form of a spoiler. If youve ever seen the movie The Cell then you will get the concept of this book.

First off, I am so happy the authors early suspense books are getting cover makeovers and being re-released. Her suspenses arent always about a HEA, your lucky if you get a HFN (happy for now  case in point her Fear the Dark book) and this book also has a nontraditional ending.The plot of this book is LeAnne McVeigh whos a homicide detective arresting the husband of woman who was found strangled to death in their home. Up to the point of arresting him she was so sure he was guilty. But once she interviews Marcus 'Snake' Gallego little tiny seeds of doubts start especially after his request to see her once hes in prison telling her to please dont stop looking for the killer because it wasnt him.LeAnne gets lot of opposition on her thinking especially from her soon to be husband who happens to be the prosecutor and is looking to go for the death penalty.  Not long after Marcus is in prison two things happen. One a witness step forward giving him an alibi for the night his wife died, two another murder happens.Once Marcus is released he and LeAnne try to find out who the murder is but as they are investigation more murders keep happening. The reveal of who the murderer was wasnt a huge surprise but there is a big twist at the end thats shocking.  As I said in the beginning this book does not end in the traditional way. Its not concluded until Eyes Of Betrayal which is also being re-released soon.
This is the perfect movie trope for Keanu Reeves. He excels at playing the brooding silent action hero. I liked the story and the soundtrack was also good.

Im sure my fascination to watch this came from all the viral hype of this movie. I love horror/scary movies and this premise of this sounded intriguing. I think maybe this would have been a better book so we could at least get the inner dialog of what the characters were thinking. On screen it was just too much of the characters sitting or lying around not speaking waiting for something to happen. There really wasnt a lot of dialog throughout this movie. If youre going to have it be more showing than telling you need to at least show something. Unfortunately I have to agree with other reviews  for what I paid to watch this it was nowhere near worth it.

College themed series about a group of guys who all live together and play for the schools hockey team. They each are very serious about playing the game. When its time to practice or get ready for a big game they dont mess around. But all other times its about the women and parties.  Garretts father was a big time professional hockey player. He is loved by many and raised his son to follow in his footsteps. Problem is he was very abusive and now that his time has passed he wants to live through his son and puts unrealistic pressure on him. Garrett manages to get good grades in all but one class. He just doesnt understand why he cant get a passing grade on any of the test. When his eligibility to play because of his grade in that class comes into question he knows he needs to get a tutor to help him pass. Problem is the smartest girl in the class wants nothing to do with tutoring him.Hannah has a crush on a football player. Its all that occupies her mind. Shes a good girl, gets good grades and this crush thing is throwing her for a loop. Enter one pain in the butt hockey jock that is determined that he needs her to tutor him. She tries to blow him off numerous times to no avail. He finally convinces her by telling her that if she tutors him and goes to a few parties with him that would catch the eye of her crush and he would finally notice her.Neither of these two want a relationship with the other but as the tutoring sessions go along they form a platonic friendship and start caring about the other but each refuse to give up their main goals  he his future hockey career and she her football crush. Cupid on the other hand has other ideas.There is some angst throughout the book (its a NA after all) but there is also plenty of humor and great comradery between the roommates.  Even though these two dont see if for a while you know right off the bat these two belong together and are rooting for them almost right from the start.
Short but funny heartwarming addition to the story of Chloe and Sawyer as they bring their first child into the world. Their story is first told in Head Over Heels.

I love all things Zombie so I was intrigued by the synapses of this movie. Its more about the love a father has for his daughter and waiting until she reaches a point where he knows he will have to end her life and the struggles he goes through as they get to that point.

Sad and tragic are two words that defiantly describe most of this book. A girl who is taken in by her grandmother at an early age due to traumatic childhood finally learns to accept love and strives to do the one thing her Nan wants her to do  graduate from high school. On that day of graduation though life knocks her down again when the only person to have ever loved her dies and she is left not only alone but also without a place to live or any financial means.Jake Dunn left town years ago to get away from an abusive father. He swore hed never return but when he finds out his fathers alcoholism has put the garage his family owns in jeopardy he returns to just get it back on its feet. Its during this time that he finds a young girl asleep in a truck that had been towed in behind his garage.Jake had no plans to stay in town but offers Abby a place to live and they embark on a journey to friendship. They both have such deep scars from their past that a relationship just doesnt seem possible between them. Right when its looks like maybe their ready to try Jake has to leave town and something horrific happens to Abby.This is such a dark book with its subject matter and at times you want to scream that Jake and Abby had had enough. Neither thought they were strong people apart but together they manage to be strong and carve out their own piece of happiness.

Imagine being 15 and having a debilitating, undiagnosable fatal lung disease which severely limits your activities. Then suddenly, you find yourself whole and strong, and the heroine of the sky-world Magonia, with its sky-ships, bird people, squall-whales and canwrs  your own personal bird which lodges in your chest and enables you sing unimaginably beautiful music. The powerful music you sing with your canwr can even help you save Magonia from its enemies, and enable you and your world to survive.This is the situation of Aza Ray (named after the full spectrum of the alphabet, A to Z) once she is called to leave behind her dear friend Jason and claim her birthright.Aza is a witty, snarky teenager. Lovable quirky nerd Jason is devoted to her although both are unable to verbalize their feelings for each other. Aza learned from Jason: "If you need a certain word to communicate, but that word happens to have years of baggage, and you want to get rid of the baggage it comes with, you cross it out, but use it anyway. Some people do it like this: " (The text here reveals the word love with a strike-out line through it, which the Amazon site is unable to show).Aza and Jason have had an unusually close friendship since before Aza was five. According to the author, when Aza thinks of Jason, she knows "I can read the gaps in your sentences. I can read the space between your letters....I know your language. It's my language too."But when Aza's symptoms worsen, she develops pneumonia, and a feather is found in her lungs, Aza ascends to Magonia, a world that expert researcher Jason knows derives from medieval Celtic legends about people falling to earth from a sky-ship. He cannot bear to be parted from her. He must find a way, however dangerous, to find her and be with her again.During the first third of this original and well-written young adult novel, we are on earth. The characterizations of Aza and Jason, and their banter, are superbly presented. But Aza becomes a flatter character once in Magonia, and although highly imaginative, the characters there and their relationships are one-dimensional. Although original, the bulk of the book which occurs in Magonia is too unbelievable  artificial, hollow, and lacking characters you really get to know and care for.In Magonia, there are pirates, vultures, and a threatening enemy determined to destroy Aza and her companions. Earth's environmental catastrophes are also depleting Magonia's food supply, which is procured by invisible ladders to earth's crops. Most fascinating are the birds-in-the-chest, although the relationship between the birds and their hosts is not sufficiently explored  or any relationships on Magonia, for that matter. The author seems to have become enamored with world-building and left behind her talent for characterization and relationship building which made the first third of the book so emotionally engaging.At least we have brilliant, devoted Jason, who isn't willing to lose Aza Ray, and is even willing and able (unbelievably so) to cause an international incident in order to reunite with her.I rate the first third of the book a strong 5 stars. However, the majority of it, taking place in Magonia, barely rates a 3. However, I give it an overall 4 because of the superb beginning, its originality and the endearing relationship between Jason and Aza Ray.

Why does a 12 year old, who doesn't even remember her name, wake up in what appears to be a coffin in a room filled with coffins? Are they indeed coffins, cradles or beds? Why is she now in an almost-adult body? Why are the other young persons she frees in a similar situation, but with different markings on their foreheads?Who are they all? Where are they? Who put them there? Why? Why are there so many corpses, bones and body parts in the many adjoining rooms? How can they stay alive in the adverse circumstances they encounter? How can they escape from their seemingly endless passage through macabre rooms?How can Em, as elected leader, deal with the power conflicts among members of her "tribe" and the "tribe" that they soon encounter? Finally, how can she bear the responsibility of decision-making, and the struggle between her own conscience and her newly discovered aggressive instincts?Reading ALIVE is opening yourself to the same questions that Em and the major characters ask about their circumstances. The novel arouses curiosity from the start and answers many but not all the questions it raises  although not, in my opinion, very convincingly.I found Em and Baker to be three-dimensional characters, although both possessing in-charge macho qualities and violent tendencies. The other characters are one or two-dimensional, and too many are introduced by the middle of the book.At first, although I am an adult and not a young adult, I enjoyed the novel and wanted to keep reading. But by the middle of the book, I was fed up with all the violence, death and gore. I was only interested in finishing the book out of curiosity and an interest in the psychological development of Em. However, her decisionmaking process was well beyond that of a 12 year old, even in a grown body.ALIVE did remind me of THE HUNGER GAMES and even moreso, LORD OF THE FLIES  the latter, because of the dark side expressed by some of the characters in their terrifying situation, and Em's encounter with the beast within. Aggression in life-and-death circumstances is certainly celebrated in the book, but fortunately is balanced to some extent with attention to resourcefulness, leadership skills and interpersonal negotiation.Overall, I became disappointed with the novel because the mysteries it raised were not convincingly answered, and because it was too filled with horror, violence and gore. For young adults, I'd rate it a high 3 or low 4. For me, it's a 3.

I received a set of red and white NOW tea towels to use and review, although I hoped for and expected blue and white towels, which would better match my blue and brown kitchen. For the past few weeks, I have been using them daily to dry several different kinds of glasses, as well as plates and the deep inside of a blender. Except for the color, I am quite pleased with them.POSITIVES: THE BEST1) The are thin and flexible enough to penetrate into and dry the deeper crevices of tall thin glasses and a blender2) They really don't streak glasses.3) They don't bleed at all when washed, even in hot water4) They are fairly absorbent (although inevitably fail to dry effectively when they get too wet)OTHER POSITIVES1) They are quick drying cotton2) They are decent size 28 x183) They have hooks so they can easily be hung on a wallNEGATIVES1) I don't care for the boring red and white stripes.2) They are two expensive  an exorbitant cost for two dishtowels.Although I'm inclined to rate them four stars because of the above negatives, I am rating them five stars because they more than adequately serve the purpose of streak-free drying of glasses.

How do you  review a book that is brimming with theories and generalizations about people that do not pertain to you? When the authors repeatedly makes assumptions which may accord with many people's experience but not your own, so that you are unable to agree with the primary thesis?This is my dilemma reviewing this THE WORM IN THE CORE, which addresses the fear the death.  In my nearly seven decades, I have had many confrontations with death  my own, family and friends. I have always felt connected to the spiritual world, and sometimes felt quite eager (without denying the joys of physical reality) to return the state between lifetimes.So the authors' thesis that people are so terrified of death that they erect innumerable barriers against dealing with it seems questionable to me, although I acknowledge that it is probably true for many people.  But it is not true for everyone.To be completely fair, the authors do (although only in a few sentences) say that religious people of deep faith (what about non-religious but deeply spiritual people?), self-confident people, those who have had close brushes with death, and the elderly may have come to terms with their mortality and be less afraid of death. But after briefly acknowledging these exceptions (which may be a substantial part of the population), the authors return to their central thesis. They are quick to draw conclusions from their research projects and experiments that associations and behaviors people have after being exposed to death-related imagery means that they have a deep-seated fear of death.The authors are terror-management specialists and clearly have considerable experience dealing with people suffering from terror-related disorders. But as a PTSD sufferer myself and a licensed psychotherapist, I am very aware of other terrors that may be at least, if not more, intense than the fear of death for some people. Consider:---the fear of psychological disintegration and insanity;---the fear of repeating an early unbearable trauma;---the fear of complete isolation or alienation;---the fear of being completely overpowered (psychologically or physically)---the fear of having one's life prolonged against one's wishes, one's living will ignored (which happened to my mother, who had previously had after-death experiences during surgery, and was eager to enter the afterlife), being forced to continue in a  helpless semi-vegetable state.Some of these fears are indeed fear of a kind of psychological death, a death of one's self, and end to personality integrity and cohesion.In all fairness, the authors of THE WORM INTHE CORE address the connection between fear of death and fear of losing self-esteem. They also discuss the urge for immortality, which can mean seeking to continue one's existence after death through one's children or creative work left behind (symbolic immortality). They clearly understand how the conscious or unconscious desire to escape from terror can be a central motivating force. Influenced by Ernest Becker's DENIAL OF DEATH, they expand upon his work, attempting to back up theory with scientifically valid research.I just question their interpretation of the results of many of their experiments, which seem to me to be reductionist - as if they had their premise from the start and were stretching their interpretations of the data in order to fit it.I also had the impression that they were dismissive of people to whom spiritual reality is at least as real as physical reality. "So our ancestors...created a supernatural world, one in which death was not inevitable or irrevocable," they write, referring to early conceptions of heaven or the afterlife. Their vague references to people who believe in life beyond death (whether spiritual or physical) give the impression that they think "believers" are living in a world of make believe as an escape from our terror.I also question their generalities about the fear of death being related to a terror of one's personal and cultural world view being challenged. Not everyone's sense of self exists in their belief system  though living in the world of academia can lead one to be overly identified with one's thoughts.It also seems to me that a primary motivational force may be approach-oriented at least as much as avoidance-oriented --  movement TOWARD fulfillment in life, not running FROM death. Of course, confrontations with one's mortality (especially if one is over 60) can lead people to become more strongly invested in making the days they have left more meaningful. But many different factors (some pro-active and life-affirming rather than fear-oriented) can motivate the desire for meaning and significance.In short, I did not find THE WORM IN THE CORE to be worthwhile reading, in contrast to half a dozen books (including DIE WISE, which I recently read and reviewed) that I did find personally meaningful. But I acknowledge that THE WORM IN THE CORE may speak to many readers, especially readers in their 20s and those who are completely identified with their physical body and doubt spiritual reality. I therefore rate it three stars.

I was given the opportunity to review the Thule Urban Guide Sports stroller, and used it several times with my neighbor's grandchildren, whom she is unable to take out on her own. One is 1  years, and the other 4 years old. My impression is that this exceptional quality stroller is great for children ages 6 months to nearly 6 years, although children four years and older are likely to become adept at unstrapping themselves. Megan certainly was.When I last took it out on a trek to Trader Joes, I only had one child with me, and used the other seat for two hefty bags of groceries, which worked fine and counter-balanced the child's weight. The terrain between my apartment complex and TJ's is rough and varied  concrete, grass, muddy trail, a steep hill and a few stairs, and the stroller performed exceptionally well on all terrains,  though the stairs were of course bumpy. Because the front wheel swivels to any angle, I could easily turn the stroller, even in the tight 90 degree angled doors entering TJ's.With two children, there is still a storage area in the stroller for a purse, jacket, bag of groceries etc.Because of my own physical limitations in regard to lifting, I hesitated to open and close the stroller to take it in and out of a car, but when I did so recently I found that it was easy to fold up and lift in and out of the car seat then I had anticipated  easier than lifting a squirming four year old who doesn't want to cooperate.I also like that the reclining seats are helpful in encouraging a child to nap, that there is an adequate sun shade (though the summer sun isn't yet a problem here in New England), that the wheels can locked (you would lock the front wheel when jogging anyway), and that you can control the height of the handlebar. I did try jogging with it, and found it easy to do so  the stroller just seems to glide along and the handle even provides some support. The zippered storage area is also particularly useful.I can only compare this stroller to the one I had and used many years ago  which was bare bones, and weak in every way that the Thule Urban Glide stroller excels. I can't imagine that any stroller could be better than this one unless it is equipped with some kind of self-soothing spray oriented to keeping kids on their best behavior.My only gripe in regard to using it  - the strap for locking it closed is not very durable and almost fell off during my third stroller trek.Although I was initially inclined to downgrade my rating for this stroller because of the high cost, I am rating it 5 stars because of its exceptional quality.

I have thick straight hair halfway to my waist, which has never held wave or curl for more than a few hours. Although the InStyler excels in straightening hair and increasing  volume, I was more interested in creating waves and loose curls (as well as flip-under and flip-up effects) which would hold for several days.Amazingly enough, the InStyler was quite successful in doing so, although the learning curve was greater than I wished, and I still hesitate to use it even after several weeks, for fear of burning my fingers. Of the four settings, the hottest temperature setting  - best for long thick hair  is 425 degrees.When I first received the Instyler, I was intimidated by its size, the various pieces included in the kit, and the instructions, and did not use it immediately. However after viewing half a dozen of the videos about using it at myinstyler.com I gained enough confidence to try. There are about 20 2-3 minutes videos there on such topics as Fine or Short Hair, Flip In, Making Soft Curls, Installing the Thermal Guard etc. At Youtube, there are even more videos demonstrating various  curling, straightening and volume enhancing techniques geared specifically to short, long, fine or thick hair. I highly suggest watching those relevant to you before using InStyler, so that you do not burn yourself or are unhappy with the results.The optional thermal guard attachment which helps you avoid burning your fingers can also catch and tangle your hair, so you may choose not to use it. I snapped it on initially but removed it after several weeks.Because the videos and included instruction manual clearly explain and/or demonstrate a variety of InStyler techniques, and many Amazon reviews also provide how-to tips for different hairstyles, I will not do so here. Instead I will indicate what I like (a lot) and don't like about InStyler, and provide a few hints I've learned about using it.FEATURES: POSITIVE--takes only 30-40 seconds to heat up, and provides 3 heat settings--consists of an automatic rotating barrel and several brushes which keep the hair soft and smooth as they straighten, increase volume or curl--includes an excellent large comb, heat-resistant pad, and readable instruction manual--the 1  inch barrel is just the right size for loose curls--has a thermal attachment to help you avoid burning your fingers--has an automatic shut-offADVANTAGES--keeps hair soft and smooth--does not tangle your hair (except occasionally when you use the thermal protection)--has superb results creating waves with long thick hair--most people can completely style their hair in about 15 minutes--your styling result holds for several days--can be used to straighten or curl hair, and to increase volumeCRITICISMS-- No storage bag is provided.--The drill sound the Instyler makes when in use is too loud - unlikely to please a sleeping partner or nearby roommate.--Anyone who had a rotator cuff or upper arm injury might find (as I did) that raising their arm to hold the large InStyler up for 10 seconds at a time on a dozen or more sections of hair at the back of the head can be difficult and painful. Since I have had rotator cuff injuries and cramps in both upper arms, I find that styling long back hair is difficult and painful, especially near the back of the head.SUGGESTIONS FOR USE-- First, watch the videos that are relevant to you-- Start with dry or only slightly damp clean untangled hair that you have just brushed-- Pin up clumps of your hair so you can work on your hair in sections-- Give yourself at least half an hour the first few times you use it-- Although the highest setting for long thick hair is the hottest, use the medium setting and take additional time if you are uncomfortable with the intensity of heat-- Be very careful not to burn your fingers-- Go very slow, spending at least 7-10 seconds on each section, and hesitating for a second more at the end of your hair-- Gently your hold each hair section up for a second or two after styling it to allow it to set-- If creating beachy waves or loose curls, alternate the direction to which you rotate the brush or twist your hair so that your curls fall both out and under, both left and right-- Don't brush or comb hard when done, but rather use your fingers to fluff up your hair and separate any clumps-- Enjoy the new you!

I loved THE EUREKA FACTOR! Of course, being 100% intuitive on the Myers-Briggs test and a writer and once-upon-a-time photographer and psychotherapist, I was bound to relate to the authors' descriptions of personalities and circumstances conducive to insight, intuition and creativity. Indeed, THE EUREKA FACTOR is likely to be especially meaningful, confirming and illuminating to readers who possess the kinds of minds that psychology professors Kounios and Beeman describe.But it is also likely to be informative and enlightening to anyone who wishes to understand the factors  innate and engineered  which contribute to creativity and insight, especially the AHA experience in which insight unexpectedly bursts into consciousness.The authors are skilled at backing up their assertions with considerable research, which wisely they place in lengthy notes at the end of the book rather than clutter the pages with scholarly footnotes. Unlike most academics, they also write in a clear, highly readable, almost conversational manner, without dumbing down their explanations or inflating their message with unnecessary repetitions and lengthy anecdotes. The examples and anecdotes they do provide are succinct and relevant.Yes, many readers are likely to already know some of the of the points they make. For example, immersion in a problem with substantial preparation followed by a relaxing diversion or sleep contributes to creative insight. But Kounios and Beeman do not just inform us of the findings of neuroscience. They are also practical, and oriented toward helping readers enhance their own insight and creativity. In the latter part of the book, the authors provide more than a dozen suggestions for increasing the frequency and significance of one's "AHA" experiences.Examples of some of the discoveries about "the eureka factor" which they discuss include:1) People experience an increase in alpha waves before an insight emerges into consciousness, and then a huge burst of gamma rays in the right temporal lobe (the anterior superior temporal gyrus) when it unexpectedly emerges.2) The right hemisphere of the brain far more than the left enables us to make remote associations, drawing from a wide network of neural connections, which remain active beneath the surface of consciousness before the "eureka" moment.3) A narrow analytical focus can crush an emerging insight and prevent it from becoming conscious.4) Analytical personalities tend to "errors of commission" whereas insightful personalities tend to "errors of commission".Suggestions for maximizing our capacity to have breakthrough insights include:1) Attention to the far-off, long-range and general rather than the near, short range, and specific.2) Exposing oneself to new, unusual perspectives and environments.3) Engaging in activities which contribute to a positive and especially a playful mood.4) Choosing to be in an environment which is spacious and open, such as a large uncluttered room with a high ceiling or nature (the colors blue and green are particularly advantageous).Many years ago, when applying to graduate school, I took the Miller Analogies Test and scored quite well. But being particularly fond of making remote associations, I wanted to retake the test and improve my score. I bought a study guide for the MAT, at the same time  started reading a new science fiction series which completely entranced me. Inevitably, instead of  studying the MAT book, I read 15 science fiction novels in the one month before retaking the test. The result? My score improved so dramatically , that it was now at the very top of the scale.  That experience made a lasting impression upon me, and is now confirmed by Kounios and Beeman's emphasis upon opening the mind new contexts and alternate realities.My only criticisms of THE EUREKA FACTOR are very minor ones. Although they briefly address the issue of pseudo-insight or false intuition by suggesting that we ask why we are having a particular insight, the authors don't elucidate the emotional factors that can contribute to such self-deception. They refer to "prevention" and "promotion", but do not discuss how the role of fear and desire can interfere with the validity and significance of one's insight.  They also do not elucidate the different qualities of consciousness that can accompany different kinds of insight  states of mind of which those of us who meditate or pay considerable attention to the subtleties of our inner process may be aware. But I have yet to encounter any writers who adequately address either of the above topics, so I cannot fault the authors for failing to do so.In short, I highly recommend THE EUREKA FACTOR to everyone who wishes to understand the physiological and psychological factors contributing to creative insight and/or wishes to increase their own ability to have "AHA" experiences.

"My father tried to teach me I have a place. Trying to be out of that place is like the stars fighting to move outside their path. I am on that path, now, and I must stay there.....I gave an oath to my father. I cannot dishonor his memory."These are the words of Adira, daughter of the caravan. In order to accompany and help her merchant father, Adira has been dressed and raised as a boy. When her father is killed, she is unwilling to be daughter to her uncle and aunt, Abram and Sarai, or to live the restricted life of desert females.Adira heads off alone into the desert, in pursuit of her father's killers and Raph, a mysterious Northman with whom she has fallen in love. She believes Raph and his brother Mika (perhaps variants of Raphael and Michael) to be angels who are seeking out Abram, on some secret mission of their own. Mika even appears to have magical powers.Many years ago, I read Anita Diamant's THE RED GATE,  Biblical fiction with a pagan slant, which soon afterwards became a popular historical read. I was pleasantly surprised that I enjoyed ANGELS AT THE GATE even more than Diamant's excellent novel. ANGELS AT THE GATE is well-researched but not heavy with historical details, and has only a touch of early Hebrew religion as well as paganism. Best of all, it features a courageous yet vulnerable young heroine whom readers cannot help but like.Devoted to her loyal dog Nami and the memory of her father, Adira is determined to be true to herself.  Except for when she chose to take off on her own into the desert without adequate water, I found her to be completely believable. Author T.K. Thorne succeeds in portraying Adira from the inside out, so that we experience her feelings and thoughts, and yet also stand outside of her, caring for her and feeling protective of her as she struggled to survive in a threatening environment.In ANGELS AT THE GATE, the Biblical story of Abram and Sarai remains peripheral. Yes, Adira eventually is compelled to marry Lot, and is confined to life in hostile, degenerate Sodom. Yes, Sodom, is on the verge of destruction. But Thorne skirts around the brief Biblical narrative without altering it, providing her own unique perspective on characters that the book of Genesis does not reveal in any detail.The story that Thorne tells is so engaging that the words are almost invisible, painting scenes that leap off the page and lead us to want to know more.  One lesson that Adira learned from her father was the importance of asking the right questions. As we read about her, we are likely to ask a number of questions ourselves: What is the dreaming stone that Mika and Raph protect? Who really is Mika? Will Lot's unappreciated preaching of the god El bring danger to his family?  What happens to Nami?Most of our questions are likely to be answered . Others remain a mystery, but not knowing the answers does not detract from the fulfilling conclusion to the novel. ANGELS AT THE GATE is a book to be savored. I rate it five stars.

Although I have an abiding interest in ancient Greek myth and literature (which I teach) and have travelled extensively in Greece, I have been ignorant about Greece's contemporary issues, and was eager to read this book. For the most part, it did not disappoint, although the reality it portrays is sobering.THE FULL CATASTROPHE clearly explains the dilemmas of Greece's financial irresponsibility and indebtedness, economic and social welfare troubles, and ongoing multiculturalism vs. anti-foreigner conflict, particularly in reference to the activities of the xenophobic, far right Golden Dawn political party.  This illuminating book reveals how these situations developed since World War II, and especially during the past decade.I did however feel that author/journalist James Angelos spent too much time interviewing a handful of people regarding the immigration conflict, and focusing on the troubles in Agios Panteleimonas Square in Athens. What about the situation in the rest of Athens, and above all, most of Greece? After quite successfully describing the dilemmas Greece faces today and the causes, the book focuses for far too long on one piece of the puzzle and becomes partial and imbalanced in its perspective.Some insights gained reading this book:1) Joining the EU boosted Greece's economy but the large amounts of money borrowed from other European countries was not spent on strengthening Greece's economy, but rather disappeared as a result of increased handouts and corruption. Meanwhile, Greek politicians were slow in abiding by their agreement in regard to "cleaning up" the system and cutting back on social welfare.2) The Greek government apparently "cooked the books" in order to get Greece into the EU.3) Greek society seems to depend to a frightening extent upon graft, bribery, political patronage, and various forms of trading favors.4) Many Greeks receive benefits they do not deserve (e.g. seeing-persons receiving benefits for the blind) , with the help of officials who take kickbacks for overlooking offenses.5) Unemployment is between 25-30%, therefore contributing to dependence upon social welfare and understandable protests against austerity measures.6) The Greek system which forbids firing of public employees for incompetence and guarantees jobs for life has contributed to the laziness and inefficiency of many government workers.7) Many Greeks seem to be taking refuge in the "glory of the past" rather than committing themselves responsibly and wholeheartedly to coping effectively with present circumstances.8) German/Greek tensions are high due to Germany lending considerable money to Greece, and Greeks, still haunted by memories of the German occupation in World War II, feeling they are entitled to war reparations they never received.9) Greece, as a gateway to Europe Proper is an unintended waystation for hundreds of thousands of poor, suffering immigrants from Africa and the Mideast who are unable to reach their intended destinations, and severely overburden an already strained economy and social welfare system.10) A far-right strident and sometimes violent anti-immigration political party called The Golden Dawn has inflamed many Greeks against foreigners, distorting reality in the process. Police support of the Golden Dawn often has led to failure to protect foreigners, who are victims of harassment and violence.Greece truly is the young, not-very-welcome child of the European Union, who unlike Joseph who was thrown into a pit by his brothers, appears to have dug its own pit and want rescue without being willing or able (often for good reason) to climb out of the pit itself.As Angelos points out, the attitude of some Greeks is "We gave light to the world and held onto the darkness." And yet Angelos tells us that "Greeks also often see themselves on account of their ancient legacy, as a kind of chosen people, superior to others....Greeks consequently often feel that Europeans should be grateful for being shown the way out of the cave and into the light."What is the solution? Angelos doesn't dare to speculate. The problems are deep-seated and extensive, with Greece on the verge of losing its membership in the EU and undergoing an even great socio-economic meltdown. Hopefully, Greece's new liberal government will find a way  slowly and arduously  out of the pit, but it is dark and deep. Meanwhile, author James Angelos sheds some light for us in this engaging and illuminating presentation of the problems of Greece today.

In these times of self-glorification, celebrity-worship, competitive pressure to succeed, and rampant consumerism, what has happened to personal morality and commitment to such enduring values as integrity, self-discipline, honest self-examination, humility and service? Whether or not you are religious, whether you are Democrat or Republican, you can still choose to increase your worth at least as much as your wealth by dedicating yourself to building your character.New York Times columnist David Brooks admits in THE ROAD TO CHARACTER that he has been a "narcissistic blowhard" ambitiously pursuing external values, and that only recently has he undergone the self-searching that led him to research and write this book . "I wrote it to save my soul," he says.Clearly, he is addressing the soul of our society as well, as he points out that the words character, conscience, gratitude and kindness are used far less frequently than they were in the mid-20th century, and that human research reveals a huge drop in empathy since the year 2000.Borrowing from Rabbi Joseph Soloveitchik, Brooks distinguishes between two kinds of personalities  Adam I (aggressive pursuer of worldly success) and Adam II (persons committed to the inner life, and values such as kindness, integrity and dedication to a larger purpose). He also differentiates "resume virtues" of external achievement from "eulogy virtues" of inspiring character. This book is about notable Adam IIs and their "eulogy virtues."Basically, THE ROAD TO CHARACTER consists of profiles of 11 admirable persons whom Brooks admires for their virtues, in spite of their personal flaws. Although similarities exist in regard to most of these individuals  an emphasis upon self-examination, integrity, self-effacement, kindness, commitment to facing and learning from adversity, service  they also differ in some significant ways.These are the major chapters in the book and personalities discussed:The Summoned Self- Frances PerkinsSelf-Conquest  Dwight EisenhowerStruggle  Dorothy DaySelf-Mastery  George MarshallDignity  A. Philip Randolph and Bayard RustinLove  George EliotOrdered Life  St. AugustineSelf-Examination  Samuel Johnson and Michel MontaigneThe Big Me  Johnny Unitas (in contrast to Joe Namath)Having a lifelong interest in ethics and the inner life, and possessing a philosophy of life deeply influenced by Viktor Frankl, I have felt out of place in contemporary society and hungry for the kind of ethical nourishment and personal examples that Brooks' provides. Two of the persons he profiled have previously been meaningful to me  Montaigne and Eliot  and indeed Brooks' chapter on Eliot was my favorite, apart from his inspiring conclusion.George Eliot not only wrote exceptional novels, she also translated Feuerbach's ESSENCE OF CHRISTIANITY. But as Brooks pointed out, Eliot believed that religious faith is not necessary for one to dedicate oneself to character development and kindness, and that living an ethical, compassionate life can be helped by having a deep personal relationship based on both spiritual and physical love. Defying convention, Eliot experienced such a love with George Lewes, a married writer separated from his wife. Brooks eloquently describes her personal transformation and resulting beliefs, such as "All love is narrowing. It is the renunciation of the other possibilities for the sake of the one choice."In addition to Eliot, I was also moved by several others of Brooks' profiles, notably Johnson, Eisenhower and Day. Johnson, for example, felt that we all have a duty to train our will, and to help make the world a better place. He also believed that good literature could aid us in our moral improvement.  Eisenhower was suspicious of hubris and the misuse of power, sought to subordinate himself for the good of the whole, and cultivated a persona which demonstrated as much as possible the traits he wished to manifest.Despite the inspirational examples of many of these profiles and an exceptional concluding chapter, THE ROAD TO CHARACTER is, at least in my opinion, somewhat flawed. Bayard Rustin, who led a wild, promiscuous life certainly did not belong in the book. And too many of the persons Brooks discussed lived stoic, self-denying lives.  I found myself questioning whether living ethically and cultivating such virtues as kindness necessarily have to mean considerable repression of instinct, desire and emotion.My impression that Brooks mostly chose examples who possessed qualities that were the opposite of those he sought to overcome. There's nothing wrong with that  but a virtuous life may not require extreme self-denial if one doesn't have too large a self initially. These persons may not all be ideal role models for those of us who are seeking inner balance and adaptability to today's world.Consider  the many women in particular who still place undue emphasis upon others or may subordinate themselves not due to their ideals but rather due to lack of self-esteem. Perhaps a viable character ideal for them, and for many people today, does not involve self-judgment and self-repression but rather developing a healthy sense of self and healthy balance between meeting the needs of self and responsiveness to others.We all have multiple selves within us, manifesting at different times and in different ways. We can live virtuous lives, and deeply care for others, while being self-confronting, dedicated to self-improvement, self-accepting, self-effacing and self-confident. We can also pursue success in the world while maintaining an internal sense of gravity, being true to one's own conscience and values. We can construct for ourselves the life of an Adam III --- or an EVE III.In Brooks' eloquent final chapter, he presents his humility code which includes fifteen admirable qualities of character. Live not for happiness, but for holiness, he tells us. Cultivate a long-term rather than short-term perspective. Learn to quiet yourself and your ego. Maintain humility and respect for the wisdom of the past. Seek to find and commit yourself to your true vocation, and strive for excellence in your work. Seek maturity above success."People do get better at living, at least if they are willing to humble themselves and learn," Brooks tells us. "Over time they stumbles less, and eventually achieve moments of catharsis when outer ambition comes into balance with inner aspiration, when there is a unity of effort between Adam I and Adam II, when there is that ultimate tranquility and that feeling of flow  when moral nature and external skills are united in one defining effort."Despite its flaws  its unevenness, omissions, and occasionally simplistic and one-sided generalization, THE ROAD TO CHARACTER is an important and substantial book. The values that Brooks discusses are indeed being neglected in our society, to our detriment and the detriment of future generations. Indeed, many of these values have the potential to unite Republicans and Democrats who polarize over specific causes rather than seek agreement and cooperation in regard to the values and ideals they hold in common. For these reasons, and the fact that Brooks write in clear, accessible language, I rate the book five stars.

The Hamilton Beach Food Processor is my first food processor so I can only share my experience and opinions without comparing it to other food processors. Basically, I am pleased, and am amazed at what this relatively inexpensive appliance can do.Not quite sure how it worked and anxious about trying new (potentially dangerous) appliances, I was glad that it came with a detailed instruction manual (14pp. in English) with safety tips, diagrams, instructions for use (of chopping blade, slicing disc and shredding disc), processing charts indicating the kinds of foods suitable for each of these three fixtures and the maximum amount of ingredients to use with each one. Also included in the instruction manual  hints for care and cleaning, a troubleshooting guide, and several recipes.I also appreciate a number of hints included for maximum effectiveness such as freezing soft cheese for 30 minutes before food processing and adding ingredients in similar size chunks, if possible. Users are advised NOT to use the food processor for slicing frozen meats or crushing ice.Important safety precautions include: Unplug the appliance when not in use, and never feed food into the chute by hand (use the food pushers).Fortunately, it is  easy to assemble this food processor  just situate the bowl on it and snap in place,  insert the blade or disc you are going to use and the black plastic pusher piece necessary for it to operate, add ingredients into the food pusher, snap on the secure lid, and press the right button for the job  slide/shred, puree/mix or pulse.Although the food processor supposedly holds 12 cups of ingredients, I was not comfortable adding more than 10 cups  nor did I need to do so. In many  cases, you are supposed to leave  of the space open at the top (beneath the lid, of course) anyway.In my first month of having it, I have used it mostly for cutting many fruits and vegetables, preparing soup, shredding carrots and pureeing tomatoes. It definitely is not good with very soft sticky foods (bananas, muenster cheese) but otherwise has not presented any difficulty. The motor is powerful and the blade is very sharp (frighteningly so!).Other features I like about it:a) it doesn't work unless the black plastic piece is inserted and the parts are snapped together properlyb) you don't need to do much precuttingc) it has a spout for pouringd) the blade and lid securely stay in placee) it's easy to clean.My only issue with it is related to my having a kitchenette in a small apartment, with limited counter space. The height of the food processor is  inch too high for the space under my kitchen cabinet, so it takes up the only open counter space I have when in use. Also, as a single person household, it is larger than I need - I would have preferred it to be a bit smaller. But this isn't likely to be an issue for most users, who will probably be pleased at the efficiency and capabilities of this economical food processor.

I ordered EXPLORE THE COSMOS to read and review because I am fascinated by astronomy,  love the book FAR OUT with its amazing full color images of outer space, and was drawn to the publicity about EXPLORE THE COSMOS's "striking images from the Hubble Telescope."Therefore, upon receiving it, I was deeply disappointed to note that it not only has no color pictures whatsoever, but that the few dozen black and white pictures it contains are notably poor quality  underexposed, and with very little detail and minimal gradation of light to dark (I teach Photoshop, and even tell students who Hubble telescope images are translated into color and b&w pixels, so I'm not at all ignorant on this subject).If review copies of this book  lack color photographs that the final editions contain, then at least the publisher could have indicated to reviewers that their editions would lack "striking images". But since there was no indication, I can only assume that this book contains only low quality underexposed images.EXPLORE THE COSMOS is listed as intended for ages 8-12. I am considerably older than that, but have taught 12-years olds, and chose to read a children's book because I thought it would help me clarify and organize the smatterings of astronomical knowledge that I have into a coherent whole. In fact, it did. In this way, the book is a relatively thorough basic introduction to astronomy.Of the 162 pages in this book, 27pp. are about the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson  the first two chapters and a later chapter. These introduce him not only as an astrophysicist but also as a well-rounded human being who has pursued other interests as well  even wrestling and ballroom dancing. Only 1/6 of the book is about Tyson; the rest is an introduction to astronomy.The astronomy chapters cover:1) the history of astronomy and the nature of life;2) the origin of the universe and galaxies, nebulae, dark matter etc.;3) the Milky Way and our solar system (general);4) the inner planets;5) the icy giants beginning with Jupiter and the outer reaches of the solar system;6) future prospects in astronomical investigation.Apart from an absence of quality color photos, my primary issue with EXPLORE THE COSMOS concerns the unevenness of the text and language, given its 8-12 audience. For example, on the one hand, the book defines light years and the Big Bang, but doesn't clearly explain why we can view light events that occurred relatively soon after the universe was born.This is one of several cases in which the book assumes middle school plus reading ability and understanding. Yet at the same time, it is full of short simple sentences, which seem to be addressing second  grade readers  e.g. "Scientists expect that our Sun will burn for another five billion years. That is a very long time."I also found myself wondering why author Saucier would briefly refer to dark matter and yet make no references whatsoever to CERN and recent developments pertaining to the discovery of the Higgs-Boston, and ongoing experiments in that regard, as televised on NOVA and many science shows. Wouldn't a young reader want to relate his new knowledge  of astronomy to the current events in astronomy he or she might be watching on tv?But I did find that EXPLORE THE COSMOS  successfully summarized key astronomical developments and clearly defined its  terminology (with a glossary containing about a hundred entries  e.g. dwarf planet, red shift, Oort Clouds, planetary nebula). It also provided interesting tidbits of information that I had not previously known.Some examples: Before the mid20th century, Hubble Telescope scientists believed that the Milky Way was the only galaxy. The process of a black hole squeezing an object as it sucked  it into its singularity is called "spaghettification." There have been no humans walking on the Moon since 1972. Uranus's moons are named for Shakespearean characters. In the next few years, we will be receiving new astronomical data from missions probing Mars, Jupiter and Saturn.One anecdote shared by Saucier was particularly interesting to me, and likely to be meaningful to other female readers in particular. In 1961, a 14 year old girl wrote NASA asking how she might become an astronaut. NASA told her that girls can't be astronauts. (Why? They didn't say.) In 1967, NASA accepted its first black astronaut, and in 1978, its first female astronaut. Who was the girl who wrote the 1961 letter to NASA?  Hillary Rodham Clinton.

I am a big fan of Bosch wiper blades, and this one is no exception. I only got one  a 20 incher for my old toyota, since I replaced the other blade with Bosch about six months ago and it's still working fine. Although the two aren't identical, visually they look similar and both do the job well. This particular "Insight" blade definitely suggests quality.What counts most for me is that this blade quickly clears the windshield, which with the freezing rain we often get here in New England is an absolute necessity. And it doesn't leave messy streaks either which impair vision. Also, it doesn't squeak when the windshield is barely wet but still needs some clearing - some cheaper wiper blades squeak, which is particularly annoying.Because we've had very little snow so far this winter, and I haven't driven yet while it's snowing, I haven't had the opportunity to try them out in conditions of heavy snow, but the blade quickly clears the window of accumulated snow. The close friction with the windshield appears to generate heat too which helps with the melting of ice.Not being handy, I had my helpful auto serviceperson install the blade, as I always do. It takes him less than two minutes. . If you've never installed a wiper blade before, ask your service station worker or mechanic  most would do this for free and quickly too  if you're also giving them paid business.

THE EVIL HOURS is both a personal exploration of author, war correspondent and PTSD sufferer David Morris' own PTSD experience incurred in Saydia, Iraq, AND an informed discussion of the history of the history of PTSD and various successful and unsuccessful treatment methods. The chapters are titled Saydia, In Terror's Shadow, Toward a Genealogy of Trauma, Therapy, Drugs, Alternatives, and Growth. Also included are an epilogue, extensive, well-research notes, and a select bibliography.PTSD is now the most common psychiatric disorder diagnosed in the U.S.  "Trauma destroys the fabric of time," Morris  tells us, describing  how the brain keeps reliving unintegrated traumas which appear to have seared themselves in our brain cells.  "The more helpless the patient felt, the more likely he was to be traumatized... PTSD survivors are not alive, not dead, but somehow both and neither."PTSD survivors often live a state of emotional numbing and hypervigilance, interrupted by flashbacks and eruptions of repressed feelings. They may also increasingly isolate themselves in order to protect themselves from exposure to words or events that will potentially trigger the original trauma, "living inside a PTSD bubble, a severely limited range of activities that doesn't trigger their symptoms".Morris explains that PTSD was not a recognized psychiatric diagnosis until 1980, a result largely of the battle by Vietnam Veterans Against the War to get the disorder officially recognized.In tracing the known history of PTSD, Morris tells us that an ancient Sumerian text, THE LAMENTATION OF UR (ironically, Ur = Uruk = Iraq) referred to traumatic reactions to war, and that the ILIAD and ODYSSEY have been significant texts in regard to the literary portrayal of PTSD. Having been moved and influenced by Jonathan Shays' ACHILLES IN VIETNAM, I highly recommend Shay's book and related writings, especially since Achilles so thoroughly demonstrates the sudden eruptions of PTSD rage - and the road back to integration within the community.Morris discusses the traumas experienced by Civil War Veterans, many considered to be cowards, and how they were sometimes regarded as having a mental disease, their symptoms being referred to as nostalgia or heart-ache (in the Greek, nostos=home and algia =pain). A more extensive but still incomplete recognition of the adult-onset disorder occurred during World War I, when thousands of soldiers and veterans were diagnosed with what then was called "shellshock".Although Morris refers to other kinds of PTSD (such as rape trauma) besides combat trauma, his focus is on the PTSD experienced by veterans, particularly veterans of Vietnam, Afghanistan and Iraq. As a PTSD survivor myself, whose own PTSD was a result of hundreds of small but deeply impactful traumatic incidents in childhood, I wish that Morris had explored in some depth the experience and treatment of non-combat and long-term chronic PTSD.Nevertheless, much of what he wrote was meaningful to me - especially the sharing of personal experiences of PTSD survivors and the effects of various kinds of treatment.What might enable the PTSD victim to cope more effectively with his PTSD symptoms? In quoting a VA researcher, Morris tells us that "the major PT factor is whether the traumatized person received social support." "Accept that there are things in this world that can break us," Morris advises readers suffering from PTSD. "Only then can we begin to make meaning out of everything that came after."The resilience of PTSD survivors is helped by "having a solid moral compass, spiritual faith, having a role model, social support, confronting one's fears, and seeing oneself as having a mission in life. The key predictor of who would bounce back....was a sense of optimism."One focus of Morris' book is the process by which Vietnam Veterans against the War with such leaders as Robert Jay Lifton actively fought to recognition of PTSD in opposition to the Nixon White House and often the VA itself, which wished to minimize the negative consequences of war.In his very informative chapters on treatment options, Morris warns us that the focus on pharmaceutical means of treatment and mass-produced treatment programs neglect the important interpersonal dimension of the healing process involved, short-circuiting and ignoring completely the therapist-client relationship. It can also can lead to avoidance in regard to confronting moral issues such as torture that contribute to the onset of PTSD."The problem, really, is that while humanity continues to experience huge leaps in technology, we experience no equivalent leaps in our ethical capacity. On the never-ending arms race between technology and ethics, technology always wins."Morris discusses pharmaceutical treatments (e.g. propranolol, zoloft), psychodynamic therapy (especially  helpful for long-term chronic PTSD), flooding and prolonged exposure (PE). The latter he points out is not effective for some PTSD sufferers because it may retraumatize them.I found myself particularly intrigued by the two last chapters in which Morris explores alternative treatment methods and the possibility of resulting personal growth. Rather than address the trauma, yoga, meditation and other mind-body techniques are particularly helpful to the reintegration process.Some veterans have also indicated that their PTSD experience has actually had positive as well as negative consequences - that they were able to allow the crisis of PTSD to enable them to change their lives for the better, and in many cases, awaken their compassion and spirituality. This focus, ignored by most treatment plans and by the VA, is certainly one that can enhance the coping ability of PTSD survivors.

Tracy K. Smith won the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry in 2012, at the age of 40, for her book of poems, LIFE ON MARS. I had not read her poetry when I chose to read and review her new memoir, ORDINARY LIGHT. But enamored with her illuminating prose, which reveals her skills as both poet and storyteller, I am now reading LIFE ON MARS  but  much prefer her marvelous, touching, tenderly self-revealing, distinctively unordinary ORDINARY LIGHT.Tracy grew up in a predominantly white northern California suburb, in a large loving black family which prized education, achievement and Christian values. She was considerably younger than her four older siblings. Her mother was a warm, nurturing evangelical Christian from Alabama, her father a caring but frequently absent Air Force engineer who eventually left the Air Force and worked on the Hubble telescope, at a distance from his familyIn the first half of her book, after sharing her experience of her mother's death, Tracy presents significant episodes from her childhood, many from when she was 8-9, and later, a few from high school and college. We view her on Halloween, dressed as a ghost in a costume that looked more like a Ku Klux Klan outfit than Casper or Spooky, and resulted in uncomfortably odd looks from candy-distributing benefactors. We travel with her to Alabama to visit her grandmother and to become aware of a milieu in which blacks have a distinctively inferior position.We see her navigate her way into a special MGM class Mentally Gifted Minors, tauntingly called Mentally Gifted Monkeys by excluded classmates. We experience with her the initial embrace of her Southern Baptist church-goings, but also her terror reading the book of Revelation and discovering that God could be cruel. Confusing too was her entry into a Christian youth study group which was oddly called "Hot and Fast," but was too traditional for Tracy's questing mind. "God is not that small," she wrote to herself on one occasion as she began to define her own religious beliefs ("I think of God as a current that runs through all that is") as well as her identity as female, black, and talented.I was most moved by Tracy's self-aware and open sharing of her platonic "love affair" with one of her married high school teachers, a man who dared to confess his growing love for her and with whom she exchanged daily letters for many months. Inevitably, that relationship ended, as did her first few sexual relationships. Beginning to emerge from the warm, secure embrace of her family, Tracy was compelled to come to terms with the pain of loss and betrayal."Pain. Somewhere it was never too far around the bend. When I was a child, I'd viewed its promise as part and parcel of the reverie of deep feeling. One day, I will house a tremendous heartache. One day, I will reel with a singular ecstasy."At least  after each self-protective closing, there was always the promise of the next ecstasy."Another function of sex.......to open up new depths within the self that can be filled just as easily with elation as with a merciless leaden sorrow."During her college years at Harvard, Tracy discovered Afro-American studies and explored her racial identity.  She began to write poetry seriously, and continued to redefine her religious beliefs, separating from the Christianity of her upbringing and also her mother. But unfortunately, as Tracy entered and attended college, her mother struggled with cancer. As Tracy needed to separate and forge her own identity, she also had very compelling reasons to remain close to family.Coming full circle, she returns at the end of the book to her relationship with her mother, and the impact of her mother's death when she was still in her early twenties: "The only thing to do, I suspected, would be to move over and learn to live beside the gulf left in my mother's wake, peering down into it at times out of need, but making every effort not to topple over and fall in."During  her life, Tracy also learned the importance of telling one's story: "Silence feeds pain, allows it to fester and thrive. What starves pain, what forces it to release its grip, is speech, the voice upon which rides the story......Telling the story bolstered my sense of hurt and anger..... Yet it also tamed the pain, giving it a shape, a beginning, middle, and eventually, an end."In ORDINARY LIGHT, Tracy opens her heart as she guides her readers through her most poignant experiences and eventual fulfillment in love, motherhood and passion for writing.  Her  touching memoir is written with gentle self-awareness, the words lyrically crafted into prose and imparted with the sensitive skill of a poet and the flowing intimacy of an engaging storyteller.

I was not familiar with either Badiou or Fienkielkraut when I chose to read and review CONFRONTATION. My aim was to stretch beyond my U.S.-centric political awareness and become more knowledgeable about the political issues of concern in Europe today.Reading CONFRONTATION indeed was very helpful in this regard, despite my lack of familiarity with some of the names and historical references, and the frequent use in the book of academic terminology. Understanding the perspective presented is challenge but a satisfying one for the newcomer to these well-known French thinkers, as well as to their fans and followers.Alain Badiou is a philosophy professor emeritus in France, known for his far left Marxist orientation, and his support of universalism as well as a revitalized communism. He is also a defender of the Palestinians and the rights of  immigrants. He is very concerned about the consequences of "the world everywhere under the control of an extremely close-knit network of financial and media oligarchies that impose a rigid model of development do so at the price of crises and never-ending wars."Alain Finkielkraut is a conservative French professor of the History of Ideas, a left wing Zionist who believes in a two-state solution for Israel and Palestine, who deplores multiculturalism and mourns the weakening of traditional French (and human) values. "All the degradation of the modern world, i.e. all lowering of standards, all debasement of values," he says, "comes from the modern world regarding as negotiable the values that the ancient Christen worlds regarded as non-negotiable. And this universal negotiation is the cause of its universal degradation."Four hours in length, this transcribed and edited debate is divided into four segments: National Identity and Nations; Judaism, Israel and Universalism; May '68; and Communism (Past and Future).One focus of discussion is the importance of national identity (French) which Finkielkraut fully supports vs. a greater identification with multicultural and global concerns.  In another discussion, Badiou defends and explains the original ideals of communism in contrast to totalitarian communism of 20th century Russia and China.  In another debate, Finkielkraut claims that Badiou blames Israel for the Mideast conflict and increasing anti-Semitism in Europe, whereas Badiou claims that Finkielkraut is too quick to blame radical Islam.In my opinion, these two esteemed thinkers are not as polarized as they appear initially to be. In much of their debate, they label each other or characterize the other as holding a more extreme view than he does. The accused then defends himself, and in turn often labels the accuser. But there are a few circumstances in which they appear to fully hear each other, and to acknowledge their agreement with the other person's assertions.Personally, I found myself shifting my support of arguments presented by each of these the thinkers, favoring initially the more liberal views of Badiou but also finding him too pie-in-the-sky impractical. On the other hand, I believed Finkielkraut to be more realistic and grounded, but unable to come to terms with some of the changes that have occurred in today's world. However, he staunchly defends important values which indeed are being quickly eroded.All in all, this is a stimulating debate, likely to be thought-provoking both to readers who are familiar with the issues raised by these thinkers as well as those who are newcomers to their points of view.

"He had joined the air force because James wanted the height and distance of the plane in relation to the ground. 'So I don't have to see the people I'm killing,' he had said to his sister, Enid."James had been an elementary level teacher, and although lacking the temperament for war, became an RAF officer for Britain during WWII. When his plane was shot down and he became a prisoner of war in Germany, he spent his time in the POW camp observing and recording the behavior of birds  the redstarts just outside the barbed wire fence enclosing the camp. Aware that many letters prisoners sent to their loved ones were heavily censored, and perhaps also not wanting to dwell on the realities of being a prisoner, James filled his letters to your new, young bride Rose with observations of redstarts.Rose, age 22, who barely knew her 32 year old husband when the war began, is bored by his letters and allows herself to fall in love with and have an affair with a married man. But to complicate matters, James' older sister Enid arrives at Rose's country cottage, having lost her flat, her belongings, her job and her lover in a recent London bombing. Enid has nowhere else to go.The separate and intertwining experiences of James, Rose and Enid  as well as some of James interactions at the POW camp (most notably with the German Kommandant who is supportive of James' bird observations) provide the substances of this straightforward, easy-to-read, and gently touching novel.  Since the 290 pages of the book have been formatted with relatively large type and considerable space between lines (with 240 words per page rather than the standard 400+ words per page) it is really quite a brief novel, almost a novella.Although weak in action and slow in plot, THE EVENING CHORUS is a quick read. It is sad but not depressing, reflective but not profound. Only one statement about a character struck me as particularly insightful, lending some dimension to Enid, who was not drawn in much depth considering the traumatic experiences that had recently shaped her:"Enid thinks that this is precisely what words are for  to change what was awful into something you can live with. She had a made a new story of her affair with Oliver Matheson....Enid has even told the story out loud several times, and she is surprised to find that something that played such a large part in her younger life takes only the length of one gin and tonic to disclose."The first 2/3 of the novel occur in 1940. These chapters may be realistic, but I found the circumstances of James ' imprisonment in a POW to be a bit unbelievable due the kindness of the Kommandant and the life of leisure that the prisoners led. But perhaps in those camps which did respect the Geneva convention and were manned by German officers who were not aggressive by nature, such relatively benign imprisonments did occur.Although most of the book takes place in 1940, the last third skips ahead ten years to 1950. Unfortunately, because we miss out on the characters' lives during the intervening years, the changes in their circumstances ring a bit hollow and are less engaging than the first two thirds of the book.Given how much of the book focused on James' study of birds (with additional study of plant life by Enid), I also think that the book might have benefited by having facsimile illustrations and entries from James' journals, including his own drawings of redstarts and a few color pictures of them. If illustrations had been included, the reader might more fully appreciate James' focus upon his bird observations which preoccupied him instead of plans for escape. But even without illustrations, the segments pertaining to James' bird study reveal his gentle, but purposeful nature and set the stage for the growing schism between himself and his wife.

This Kate Spade watch, which I received rather than purchased, has too large a watch face and watchband for my tiny wrists, but having a jeweler remove several of the band segments is easy. Women who prefer large watch faces are likely to love this watch  it has a simple and casual elegance which makes it wearable for many occasions.The watch face itself has a clear silver-white background, with straight silver line markers rather than numbers indicating each hour. Another silver marker keeps track of seconds. At the 3:00 position, a small inset indicates the day of the month, which (like the time) is easy to set. However, since there is no indicator for setting the month, and months vary in length, you will need to change the day setting every month or so.The watch face is encircled with tiny gleaming crystals.  The watchband is shiny, metallic and mirror-like. Its width is 18mm and its length 7.85 inches. The watch has stopwatch capability, which I personally do not need but those who need a stopwatch will find its operation explained in the stylishly designed user guide that has text in half a dozen languages. The battery lasts about two years.My primary concern about this watch  apart from it being larger than I prefer  is that it is water-resistant not waterproof.  It can withstand light rain and light splashes but not submersion in a shower or bathtub or prolonged exposure to steam. This, of course, means that you have to remember to take it off every time you shower  which may not always be easy to remember. Also, if you wear the watch snug against your wrist, it is not easy to unclasp, since the unclasping is along the underside of the watchband, against your wrist. This means that having to take it off for a daily shower can be a bit of a chore.It is, however, a very attractive, stylish watch, suitable for wearing on many different occasions. I most appreciate its casual elegance.

Rabbit is born in 1975, during the last year of the American occupation of Vietnam. She has in fact been buried with her mother but is still alive when Huyan Honey and her daughter Qui dig her up out of the grave. It may well be that Rabbit's own burial in her first year of life give her an uncanny ability - to deeply enter her own silence and hear the voices of the dead. This ability of hers is one of the themes of the book, but is not presented in a way that enables the reader what Rabbit is experiencing.During the first part of the book, we are treated to a few flashbacks about her ancestry, particularly in regard to her grandmother Ba's attempts to survive the French occupation of Indochina after spending all her money agreement, which as it turned out, only allowed to her to do backbreaking work in service to the French.Much of the story occurs around 1975-76, soon after the Americans have left Vietnam. Rabbit, her father Tu, Huyan Honey and Qi along with a number of others including Cambodians appear to be fleeing South Vietnam for North Vietnam. Throughout this journey, we also are told stories of others who suffered during the war and were captured by enemy forces.We move forward to time to when Rabbit is a young adult and some events which occur then, such as her love affair with a Russian and an attack by pirates. We also learn about the experience of An, a friend of Rabbit's father, who was punished for his role in the war and experienced firsthand the cruelty of the North Vietnamese guards.I struggled continually to read and understand this novel, but ultimately gave up 2/3 of the way through it. Wanting to enjoy it, I kept rereading passages, hoping to better understand the plot and make deeper connections to the stories and characters. But I found too many gap in the plot interfering with my ability to understand what was happening, and the characters were cardboard characters who never came alive on the page. As a result, I cannot recommend this novel.

Amazon offered me this sturdy Oxo collapsible dish drainer to review only minutes after the plastic utensil holder broke off my previous dish drainer, so I immediately started using the Oxo as soon as it arrived. I live in a small apartment in a very old building, with only two feet of open counter space for a dish drainer and cutting board, and no dishwasher, so I handwash and drain my dishes three or four times a day.Unfortunately, however, this dish drainer at 20x16 is slightly larger than my previous one, but doesn't hold as many dishes.  What is most frustrating is that it has holder space for only four cups and glasses (with two sets of five prongs too close together so that two are needed for each glass and the ones on the end are useless) . If you have some very narrow but not tall glasses (tall glasses fall over on the short holder plugs), you may be able to make space for six, but not with standard glass sizes.In contrast, the six silverware holders (great for sorting forks, knives and spoons) hold over 60 pieces of silverware. I was pleased to discover that they can be removed. But removing one of the two sets of three utensil containers in order to free up more glass plugs accomplished little. The new visible glass plugs are right up against the plate holder area so that you would have to collapse the plate holders and not drain any plates in order to use them.Since I drink 12+ cups or glasses a day, and often drink smoothies instead of eating meals, I find this setup very limiting.
