Fortunately though, I  can use the open space next to the plate holder area for cups, though I prefer not to stack up glasses there.Also in regard to glasses, not only is the horizontal space a problem, but height is as well since the prongs are so short. My wine glasses keel over and lie almost flat on their sides when I try to place them on a glass prong. And in fact, most tall glasses keel over too, so there is no other option than to place them open side down in the larger drainage area.The plate area which holds six plates is suitable only for plates not bowls, unless one has very shallow bowls. I don't. So bowls as well as cups and tall glasses need to be drained in the open area, which (when the plate and glass holders are in use) is only 10" x 10". So basically,  there's only space for the dishes of one person for two small meals or two people for one small meal  and perhaps afternoon coffee or other drinks.What I do like about this dish drainer is that:a) it is made of very sturdy plastic which is likely to last for several years;b) it has metal handles which make it easy to lift and carry;c) the utensil holders don't fall over when full, and (praise be!) are not closed at the bottom so silverware can easily drain and the container remain clean;d) it is on a slant and has a plug that can be opened for easy draining into the sink if water accumulates;e) the plate rack folds down to make space in the open area , so that if you don't have plates but need space instead for glasses, bowls, lids etc., you can easily create space.Its collapsibility is another advantage although I'm not likely to take the time to fold it up and reassemble it unless I have no dishes to wash for a day or so and am desperate for more counter space.This drainer could have been better designed  with three rather than six utensil holders, and more glass holders (with taller plugs) spaced further apart so that the drainer could easily drain 8-10 cups or glasses rather than 4-6. For what you get, it's also considerably over-priced.

These ultra-light packing cubes aren't really cubes  they're zippered bags  but they are ultra-light. The mesh on more than half of one side of the bags allow clothes to breathe, but wouldn't contain spills if you use the bag for toiletries. The double zipper allows you to partially open them, and the handles are helpful for carrying them, although I wouldn't trust them to hold up if they contain several heavy items.Although I find them useful, they are smaller than I expected, and pricey considering what you get. A set of three or four (including  two of the larger bags) would make more sense to me at this price.The small bag, which is actually considered "medium", is slightly smaller than a size of notebook paper, and is really only suitable for undies, bras, socks etc. or maybe a few t-shirts rolled or folded up small and ready for laundering. Although it's about the size of the toiletry bags I use for travel,  it's not viable  for liquids or creams that might spill or ooze. It could also be used for electric chargers, plugs etc. or other small pieces of equipment including small hair dryers, and is useful for keeping that sometimes hard-to-find equipment together. Apart from travel, it could be used for organizing and storage.The medium size bag which is considered to be "large"  is 14 x 10.5 inches.  It can hold half a dozen folded blouses, or several pair of pants  and like the smaller bag, expands  to a larger size than you would initially believe because of its relatively shapeless form. It is actually quite useful for clothes, although I wouldn't put a dress or suit in it and expect it to maintain its shape or remain iron-free. Actually, it doesn't really have much advantage over plastic bags or ziploc bags.Although initially these bags look ideal for holding bathing suit, towel and other swim club paraphernalia, they aren't water-tight because of the mesh and therefore would not prevent a wet bathing suit or towel from leaking moisture over everything contained in a larger bag.

In THE ART OF YOUTH, author Nicholas Delbanco examines the lives of three talented artists -  writer Stephen Crane, painter Dora Carrington, and musician George Gershwin - all who died by the age of 38. He also includes an autobiographical chapter about himself, apparently considering himself to have been a child prodigy as well, but this chapter does not seem to belong to the book, since he is not as noteworthy as these three artists, and he clearly did not die young.I was not very familiar with Stephen Crane, but previously knew about Carrington from watching the film Carrington starring Emma Thompson. I had long appreciated Gershwin's music - and been intrigued by him also because we share the same birthday and a similar ancestry. Having personally experienced the peak of my own creative success when I was a teenager, I was hoping that the author Delbanco would have insights to share about early but truncated creativity. However, he only pointed out half a dozen of the obvious characteristics that these three artists had in common such as creative energy, ambition, early support, and a self-absorption combined with an outward focus.Stephen Crane started writing poetry at the age of four, and published his second and most famous novel, Red Badge of Courage, when he was only 23. He wrote ceaselessly but did not take care of himself physically, suffered from a GI disease and died of a brain tumor when he was only 28.Dora Carrington was a portrait and landscape painter. While DelBanco focuses on the creative outpouring of Crane and Gershwin, he appears to assume that since Carrington was female, that her relationships should be the focus rather than her creative work. Indeed, her love affairs and friendships are intriguing and unusual - especially her lifelong platonic love affair with her live-in companion, homosexual Lytton Strachey. But DelBanco could have shown Carrington the same respect he showed the two men by fully acquainting the reader with her work. Although I've watched the film about her and read this brief biography, I still know little about approach to painting or her specific works of art.George Gershwin was born to a poor Russian Jewish family, originally named Gershowitz. His father's unstable work history led the family to be constantly moving, but his parent encouraged the musical talents of their children. From an early age, Gershwin was obsessed with music - hearing, playing, performing, composing. At the age of 23, he composed Rhapsody in Blue, followed by American in Paris and Porgy and Bess. Gershwin enjoyed immense popularity. When he died of a brain tumor at the age of 38, there was a national outpouring of grief and many memorial concerts.Although I was pleased to learn about these three artists, I found the author's approach to them dry and tedious. Delbanco takes a distancing, external perspective on these three artists, presenting facts about their lives, but not providing any sense of their inner selves or revealing enough about their personalities to bring them to life on the page. The book is short but because it is not at all emotionally engaging or intellectually stimulating, it did not hold my interest. I rate it three stars.

Boyd Varty grew up on the Londolozi Game Reserve in South Africa, in a family dedicated to respecting and protecting wild animals, while also leading safaris.  Londolozi, which in Zulu means protector of all things, was founded by Varty's great grandfather and has been run by four generations of family members. It is one of the most well-known game reserves in the world, and was even visited by Nelson Mandela soon after he was released from prison.In the first half of Cathedral in the Wild, Varty shares many of his early and recent experiences with the animals of Africa  leopard, lions, elephants, impalas and many more. Most of his anecdotes  are fascinating, and relate to experiences of deep bonding with wild animals or surviving dangerous encounters, particularly with cobras and crocodiles. Some of the experiences he shares are laugh-aloud funny. For example:"Jamu had a passion for toilet paper rolls. She would steal ours out of the latrine and in usual leopard fashion, hoist it into the branches of the sausage tree....After a few hours, Jamu had the tree looking like a frat house after a hideous keg party."Throughout the book, Varty also, in conversational and often witty prose, tells us some of what he has learned about African animals. For example, elephants have a low frequency communication that human ears can't hear. Zebras have stripes to confuse predators, who can't tell where one zebra ends and another begins. One family member taught him: "In the bush you never panic. When you panic, your brain turns to sponge.....Always have an escape route."In the second half of the book, Varty focuses more on the difficulties he and his family faced  a lawsuit in regard to a tiger-related project that was prolonged for many years (although he doesn't give enough details for the reader to understand the nature of the charges), and a traumatic experience which resulted in PTSD symptoms, not only for him but also other family members. He also took time off to travel, and attempted to heal himself through visiting a Master in India, participating in a sweat lodge ceremony in Arizona, and living in the African jungles learning to track from a native tracker.The last few chapters are particularly moving, as Varty shares some inspiration and insights he gained both away from Londolozi and at Londolozi experiencing profound closeness to nature and animals. "I'd found safety again in nature and in my own heart in the cathedral of the wild," Varty tells us.During his long process of healing from trauma, he began to perceive the connections between working with wild animals and healing both oneself and the planet : "If we want to restore the planet, we must first restore ourselves. I believe that you find your way to your right life, your mission, the same way you find an animal. First, quiet your heart and be still. Then find the fresh track and be willing to follow it. You don't need to see the whole picture; you only need to see where to take the next step. Life isn't about staying on track; it's about constantly rediscovering the track."The Cathedral of the Wild is an engaging and amazing narrative about an African habitat , which may feel like another world to many readers, as it did to me. But it also fascinating, amusing and mind-expanding. Varty openly shares his own adventures and introduces us to some of his family members, including his colorful, obsessed filmmaker Uncle John who is known for many of his nature documentaries.We also are given at glimpse of some of the native Shangaan and Masai tribal members who are expert trackers or working with animals in the reserve   and treated almost like family by the Vartys. Both during apartheid years and the turbulent first decade after apartheid was abolished, Londolozi was a rare sanctuary of cooperation between tribal blacks and South African whites.Through Varty's eyes we experience an African thunderstorm, the calming presence of elephants, lions pouncing upon their prey and ripping it apart, the madcap life of a wildlife filmmaker, the raising of orphaned lions or leopards, and so much more. The Cathedral of the Wild  captures wild Africa in all its glory, danger, oddities, and magnificence.

This brief but informative biography is ideal for readers interested in Van Gogh who won't want to read a more extensive life history. Bell's prose is readable  not dry, but not lyrical or memorable. My primary issue with the book is the lack of reproductions of many of the paintings discussed  I had to rely on the Internet to locate those which on available online. The superb CGFAartonline site and Van Gogh site are at least helpful in this regard.Although I had read  Irving Stone's biography LUST OF LIFE  probably three decades ago  I did not remember many details about Van Gogh's life and was intrigued to learn that he only painted for ten years before committing suicide, and that initially, his painting interests were primarily peasants and coalminers.Along with painting, Van Gogh had a passion for prostitutes, and contracted syphilis and gonorrhea, which most likely contributed to his mental illness. He completed some of his well-known paintings when he was institutionalized, even painting the cypress trees that were visible through the bars of his room.Bell also clearly allows us to perceive Van Gogh's unstable bipolar temperament, marked by bouts of rage and depression. His difficult selling his painting and dependence upon his brother Theo (excerpts of some of his letters to Theo are included) for financial support were major sources of conflict for him. Van Gogh was never able to hold down a job or support himself for more than a few weeks at a time.Author Julian Bell is a painter himself, and most excels in conveying Van Gogh's attitudes toward painting  particularly his fascination with bold, intense color, and shifts back and forth between painting from imagination and directly painting from reality. I also appreciated Bell's brief discussions of a few dozen of Van Gogh's paintings (especially Starry Night), and the context Bell provided regarding the Parisian art scene of the late 19th century. Toulouse-Lautrec and Gauguin were two of the other painters in France who significantly influenced Van Gogh.VAN GOGH: A POWER SEETHING is a good but not great biography. Readers wishing to know more about Van Gogh's life and art are likely to enjoy it and find it informative, although most will undoubtedly  prefer a biography which includes  has reproductions of many of Van Gogh's most famous paintings.

I have visited NYC half a dozen times in the past few decades,  mostly in order to see museums, bookstores and shows. Since I travel light but rely a lot on guidebooks, I am grateful for the compact yet comprehensive Pocket NYC from Lonely Planet, which will undoubtedly accompany me during my next trip.The book is superbly designed and easy to navigate. Most of it is divided into chapters by neighborhoods:  Lower Manhattan and the Financial District;  Soho and Chinatown;  East Village and the Lower East Side; Greenwich Village, Chelsea and the Meatpacking District; Union Square, Flatiron and Gramercy; Midtown Manhattan; Upper East Side; Upper West Side and Central Park. The largest chapters are the ones on Greenwich Village and Midtown.Brief highlights are also provided for Harlem, South Brooklyn and Williamsburg, but the book primarily covers Manhattan. As a result, I was disappointed that it neglected a few notable cultural sites outside Manhattan which interest me, such as the Brooklyn Museum.Each neighborhood chapter, however, is packed with useful color-coded information, and includes a two-age map. Following "Best of NYC" section on the most recommended sites in each neighborhood, the guidebook then provides details on more sites related to eating, drinking, museums, entertainment, and shopping, with price codes, addresses, urls, phone, hours, and subway information. Some special features  such as brief article on the architectural design of the New Museum in East Village  appear throughout the book.I am particularly pleased that in addition to well-known sites, Pocket New York City introduces lesser-known sites, many which I've added to my to-do list for my next trip. Some of those are: The Morgan Library, Mahayana Temple, Phillip Williams Posters, Ellis Island Immigration Museum, the NY Theater Workshop, The Fashion Institute's Costume Museum (first priority  I had no idea that existed!), the Conservatory Garden, Village Vanguard Jazz, and the shopping experience at the Hasidic-owned B&H Photo.In addition to the neighborhood chapters, this Lonely Planet guidebook includes a quick start section, and a survival guide with tips about transportation, money-saving, basic do's and don'ts, and more.  Over 30 pages are also devoted to NYC's Best by category  walks, nightlife, "with kids", LGBT, sports, parks, tours, "for free" etc. The full-size large folded detachable map of Manhattan is particularly useful.Since visitors to NYC have various interests, a pocket guidebook (even one that is 256 pages) which attempts to appeal to a wide range of visitors cannot cover any one category in depth. This book is particularly lacking in hotel information, but a visitor carrying around a pocket guidebook is likely (hopefully) to have arranged accommodations in advance. But this guidebook attempts to provide the highlights with details and recommendations in just about all possible categories (and for all budgets), and succeeds in doing so. If it included every site which might appeal to tourists, it would be the size of the Manhattan phone directory, and not a pocket guide!For its size, POCKET NEW YORK CITY packs a considerable amount of useful information into a small space without sacrificing readability. I rate it five stars.

In ON TWO FEET AND WINGS, Iranian Abbas Kazerooni tells the true story of his surviving alone when only nine years old in Istanbul.During the Iran/Iraq war, boys were drafted by the age of nine  which usually meant an early death.  Because the parents of Abbas had supported the Shah, they lost almost everything when the Shah was deposed, and faced restrictions on their freedom as well. To keep Abbas from being drafted, they intended to accompany him to Turkey and help him get a visa to England, so that he might live there with an Iranian cousin. But their plans went awry, and Abbas found himself alone in Istanbul.Without knowing either Turkish or English, Abbas  had to find accommodations and support himself during the long and complicated bureaucratic process of applying for a visa. His father had sold everything (even the beds!) in their house in order to buy plane tickets and raise the money Abbas would need living in a cheap hotel in Turkey for many weeks or months of waiting. On a tight budget (one meal a day), the terrified but amazingly clever and resourceful Abbas befriended the hotel clerk Marat and devised schemes  playing backgammon for money, shining shoes  in order to pay for food and lodgings.ON TWO FEET AND WINGS is not only likely to appeal to children nine years and older. Abbas' heartfelt narration is also likely to move adults. I personally was deeply touched, and wished I could have met and comforted him during this time. Although Kazerooni wrote and published his book decades after his experience (the first edition, called Little Man, was actually published in 2005), he was still able to capture the feelings of a child alone in a foreign country  the fear, loneliness, and longing for parents and home. Clearly, Abbas's father prepared him well, for Abbas' knowledge of what to expect and what he needed to do combined with his almost unbelievable courage, intelligence and resourcefulness, is impressive.But more than knowledge and cleverness was required. Abbas had to continually decide who to trust, how much to share of his circumstances, and how to protect the money he carried in his pockets. He had to budget, eating only one meal a day, resisting temptation. He had to cope with the feelings aroused by a few dangerous encounters. Fortunately, his own remarkable circumstances and precociousness helped him to attract the goodwill of Iranians in Istanbul, as well as Turks who spoke Farsi and legitimately wanted to help him.Abbas Kazerooni's childhood experience was remarkable, and his narration of it, written simply but coherently from a child's perspective, is emotionally engaging. This is the perfect book for a family to read together and discuss. It is also likely to inspire children coping with new and difficult circumstances to look within and discover their own courage and capabilities.

The Bose Soundtouch 3.0 wifi music system is a sleek compact system with superb rich, full sound in treble, midrange and bass. Once I survived the setup process of connecting to my pc and home wifi (more later in this review), I found it easy to access any of the 20,000 different worldwide Internet radio stations available and was impressed with the sound.  Immediately, I looked up Portugal stations, and started checking out a few dozen in search of fado music (my current passion). You could probably spend the rest of your life checking out all the radio stations available to you here. Being able to search by music keyword, however, would be helpful.What I particularly like, apart from the quality of the sound, is that users can preset up to six stations and access any of them via buttons atop the system without having to connect to one's computer or device. I rely on the Bose software with my PC, but users can also connect via Airplay and access the system via Android, smartphone, Iphone, Ipad or Android (although streaming is not available via Android devices). Presets may be accessed not only for radio but also for playlist (Internet-based or personal music collection but not cds), although the playlist choices are limited.First, the playlists for online services using the Bose software are only for Iheartradio (limited to certain localities, and not my state of Massachusetts), Pandora, Spotify and Deezer, but accessing playlists for the latter three seem to require paid-for premium accounts which I was not willing to purchase. The Hearts of Space service, to which I do subscribe, is not supported by Bose. YouTube also is not available.Second, you can connect to your personal playlist on your computer but only if you created playlists with ITunes or Windows media player and are connected to the computer that contains the music files and playlist (not a smartphone, tablet, Iphone or Ipad).  The files can also only be access if in the official folder for My Music or ITunes Music.If you're using a personal computer and not relying on WiFi, you can use the cable which is provided to connect from the auxiliary outlet on the Bose system to audio on your computer. Bose provides a power cord, USB cable (for computer use only) and remote control for your use.I did not have playlists created in either ITunes or Window media player, and had to spend several hours creating them and transferring them and all my music files to my Windows 7 laptop since my music files were on my Windows XP desktop computer. I was not able to connect the Bose system to my XP desktop, although it supposedly is compatible with Windows XP.Users who are very tech savvy or who have considerable experience setting up music systems most likely will find setup much easier than I did. From the start, I was frustrated that virtually no instructions were provided apart from a card with a few brief steps in large type for connecting via a smartphone or tablet, neither of which I have. On the back of the card, however, in very small type, are brief, incomplete instructions for setup via Airplay,  computer or another mobile device.Considering the cost of this music system, Bose could at least have provided instructions of more than 150 words that specify the initial steps for getting started. The brief instructions provided tell you to "connect the device and SoundTouch system to the same Wi-Fi network" and "Select correct network name and enter password" without even telling you that after you turn on the system and connect your device or computer, that if you are using a computer you have to download the software. Of course, Bose doesn't even tell you what software or where you get it.I finally figured out that I needed to go to bose.com, look up my system, click on customer service, and find the link at the bottom of the screen to the user's guide so that I could download it. The user guide which tells you these steps but you have to figure them out on your own in order to access it  as well as continue with setup. And in fact, in the user guide, instructions for setting up the system via a computer are on the LAST page of the guide in the appendix.At least a USB cable is provided so you can connect to your computer and access the Bose site from there, and Youtube has a few excellent tutorials on setting up this system, which I relied on (at a friend's suggestion) before I was able to locate any of the Bose help online.Apart from relying on the User Guide, you can follow the instructions IN the user guide to go to Soundtouch.com/app in order to download the software, launch it and complete the setup instructions, as well as manage  your sound system.In retrospect, I realize that I probably could have saved time by contacting Bose tech support initially, I had chosen to set up and start to use the system on a major holiday.In short, I am happy with the quality of sound, thousands of radio stations, and presets. Initially, I was not happy with setup, lack of included software or user guide. And I am still not happy with the limited options in regard to accessing playlists, either in regard to streaming OR accessing one's own musical collection. But for what it does, this is a fine system, so I rate it four stars.

During the first half of his previously unpublished novel SKYLIGHT, Nobel Prize writer Jose Saramago introduces us to the working class apartment dwellers in an apartment building in 1950s Lisbon.We meet an elderly couple who take in the boarder Abel, the kept woman Lidia and her lover Paulino, and the Spanish Carmen who despises her husband Emilio and battles for the affection of their son Henri. We are introduced to the middle-aged sisters Adriana and Isaura and their interfering aunts, the sadistic Caetano and his contemptuous wife Justina, and finally, Rosalia, who hopes that Lidia's wealthy lover will employ her 19 year old daughter.Reading SKYLIGHT at four separate sittings during one week, I found that each time I picked up the novel I had to reacquaint myself with the characters. There are too many introduced early in the novel  as many as four per apartment. Making a diagram of the apartment building, listing and identifying each resident, was helpful. The chapters alternate, each dealing with one set of residents, providing initially unrelated vignettes of six families, without any central plot. Midway through the book, I would have rated the novel three stars.But then, suddenly, the stories deepen. Each one presents a dramatic conflict and lets us perceive more fully the inner dynamics of the characters. Some subplots are tawdry, even ugly  in particular, the hostility, revenge-seeking and even sexual exploitation occurring for two of the couples. It may have been reality in 1950s Portugal that a wife had no right of refusal in regard to her husband's advances, but I found this reality particularly disturbing.Justina, who scorned her husband and welcomed his affairs is shocked and confused by her reaction to his unexpected desire for her:  "She had never been thrown, as then, into the maelstrom of pleasure, with all ties broken, all frontiers crossed. What for other women was an ascent into the heavens for her was a fall....Justina moved between those two poles  newly awakened desire and the desire to be in control. One excluded the other."Sex is also central to the concerns of Lidia's lover Paulo, and to one of the sisters, whose repressed sexuality suddenly surfaces.The story that most captured my attention, which I believe is the most brilliantly crafted and meaningful, is that of the elderly cobbler Sylvestre  intelligent and self-educated  and his deepening friendship with his young boarder, Abel. Searching for meaning in life, Abel is challenged by the one-time political activist, Sylvestre."We won't become what we are meant to be in life by listening to other people's words or advice. We have to feel in our own flesh the wound that will make us into proper men," Sylvestre tells Abel. Sylvestre, who is happily married, believes in "loving each other with a lucid, active love, a love that can overcome hatred." His philosophy is that "we should be fully engaged with life, each individual should reach out beyond himself. Being merely present isn't enough. Being a mere witness is tantamount to being dead."But Abel feels lost in regard to his own path. "How to reach out? And where to?....THERE'S a problem that throws up a thousand other problems.... there's a thousand answers to the 'how' and the 'where'."Whereas I rate the first half of SKYLIGHT three stars, I rate the second half 4  stars. My only criticisms of  the second half pertain to the ugly soap opera of the two hostile couples, and a second anonymous letter sent to one characters  I felt as if readers were meant to understand the source of this letter and the motive for sending it, but this plot element escaped my understanding. I also wish the novel has a more conclusive ending.But Saramago excels at both characterization and dialogue. The translator, Margaret Jull Costa, conveys his precisely crafted yet natural language.  You do not need to be familiar with Saramago's later work  - I wasn't  to appreciate his skill as a writer in SKYLIGHT.

Of the hundreds of books I've read and reviewed for Amazon, many have been excellent and emotionally engaging. But only a few are, in my opinion, truly great. THE NIGHTINGALE is one of those rare great novels you are not likely to forget. When I finished reading it, I experience a sense of awe, the kind of silent reverence one might feel in a cathedral, or viewing Michelangelo's David.In THE NIGHTINGALE, author Kristin Hannah convincingly portrays life in occupied France during WWII from the points of view of two very different sisters - "Viann, the rule follower and Isabelle the rebel....Everything she did, she did full speed ahead, no brakes."When Paris is occupied and Isabelle flees to the village where Viann lives with her husband and daughter, we suspect that Isabelle is not going to submit willingly to the Nazi occupation. Indeed, she does not. She becomes the Nightingale, the daring Resistance leader, sought by the Nazis, known for transporting hundreds of downed British air pilots (and other persons wanted by the Nazis) by foot across the Pyrenees. She also falls in love with a Resistance fighter whose life is also at risk.Participating in the Resistance was dangerous not only to oneself, but also to one's family. The Nazis killed those who were suspected of giving aid, and their relatives. Not only Isabelle but also Viann was continually faced with difficult choices. How much risk should each take in rescuing allied servicemen, protecting Jews, or saving the lives of orphaned children? At what point should they choose safety over principles? At what point will they be unwilling to compromise their principles? When is the wisest course of action cooperation or even collaboration?When Viann's husband is imprisoned by the Nazis and German officer is billeted in her home, Viann is faced with dilemmas she never anticipated. Avoiding good vs. evil stereotypes, Hannah portrays officer Beck as basically a good, kindhearted man who is compelled to obey orders which he does not support. The challenge that both he and Viann face as she resists their developing friendship is particularly moving, and likely to lead the reader to question how he or she might react in Viann's situation.Viann's circumstances are also complicated by Isabel's dangerous comings and goings, and Viann's close friendship with a Jewish family - Rachel and her children. At this time, more and more Jews are being deported to "work camps" to fulfill Nazi quotas. Beck warns Viann, "They are not deporting French Jews....Yet." But circumstances keep changing, and as much as Beck wishes to protect Viann, he is a German officer afraid of the Gestapo.Conflicted, Viann consults her Mother Superior, who tells her, "Think about who you are and what sacrifices you can live and what will break you...The path of righteousness is often dangerous."THE NIGHTINGALE actually does not begin with Viann and Isabelle's story but rather begins more than fifty years later with an elderly woman locating the identification card of Juliette Gervais. Juliette was the fake identity of the notorious Nightingale, Isabelle. Had this woman herself once been Isabel and buried her past? Hannah wisely avoids revealing her identity until the end of the novel.Meanwhile, we are drawn into the lives of other characters as well - the sisters' inhospitable father who owns a Paris bookstore and eventually works at the German high command, Viann's daughter Sophie, Rachel's son "Daniel", Isabel's lover Gaeta, and the cruel and sadistic Nazi, Von Richter.Kristin Hannah has a remarkable talent for creating characters who seem to live and breathe so that you forget you are reading words as you envision their lives. Most novels, even the best ones, have noticeable flaws - weak characters, holes in the plot, awkward dialogue, but THE NIGHTINGALE is that rare novel that is crafted to perfection and yet has a natural flow that captures attention from start to finish. It is likely to be one of the most highly acclaimed novels of 2015.

THE TOP TEN THINGS THAT DEAD PEOPLE NEED TO TELL YOU is mistitled. It is not about the messages from another plane channeled by psychics, or from people who have briefly died and had actual after-death experiences. In fact, the book might have been more accurately titled NEW AGE THINKING FOR DUMMIES, for indeed that's what it is.I don't mean to imply that there is not some (probably) valid information about the next plane in this book - although of course, no one can know for sure. But the manner in which author Mike Dooley imparts these teachings -a compilation of new age thinking he has gleaned from dozens of sources, without crediting the sources - is seriously flawed.Personally, I also found his conversational writing style grating - a combination of condescending, artificially hip, and "mickey mouse". I read every word in the book, but his invention of many fake cheery "letters from the dead" as well as some of his sentences made me cringe, and yearn for meat and potatoes rather than more whipped cream and marshmallow:"As you stir in thoughts, winds begin to howl.""As you smile, waves of love lap upon eternal beaches.""Dearest darling, those who have passed see better than ever that dreams really can come true."Gag. And I am a romantic, with a deeply spiritual approach to life and belief in reincarnation - but not a fondness for saccharine cliches. I also don't believe that evil does not exist, and that everything that happens to us is a result of our thoughts or part of some benign cosmic plan. What about natural laws? Chaos theory? The uncertainty principle? What about genocide, concentration camps, torture, rape? According to Dooley, people really choose to be victims of such atrocities. I don't know what planet Mike Dooley lives on, but it is not the earth I know.What do the dead want to tell us according to Mike Dooley (And how does he know, anyway?)?  "Love is all... ....Everyone is doing their best and is of good intent" ......It's all good and all God....There is no evil other than what I choose to see."Even near the end of the book, where Dooley presents false assumptions, the underlying reality they avoid, and alternatives we should substitute, Dooley implies that if we think materialism can be corrupting, then we are covering up "I don't like being human/alive" -  the actual truth is that "money is pure spirit". Tell that to my landlord and the IRS.  We may experience an abundance of spiritual wealth during this incarnation but it is not a viable means of barter on the earth plane.In all fairness:  A lot of what Dooley writes is congruent with concepts espoused by well-known psychics in the last century, as well as personal growth practitioners who have focused considerably on intention and visualization (he could at least credit them). Some of Dooley's aphorisms, which have floated around the new age world since the 1970s may indeed be valid:  "To create anything in the physical world, it must first exist in the unseen." "Free will reins, but logically individuals must operate within the collective's massive range of probabilities."It may well be that we each have a greater Self beyond our conscious self in this lifetime, one that chooses the nature of each lifetime and lessons to be learned. It may well be that our experience of the afterlife is influenced by our expectations in regard to it, and that suicides cannot escape their pain and will have to face it again in another lifetime. It may well be that defining what we want, envisioning it and being open to receive it can increase the odds that we will attract - the universe, Dooley says, does the rest. (But there is no guarantee that the everyone else's "principle of attraction" may be in harmony with others and that our intention will prevail and our visions will manifest.)One of the difficulties of this book is that the concepts that might be most meaningful to readers are like candles burning on a cake, candles that sink so deep into the frosting that their flame is extinguished by three inches of orange and pink sugar fluff.If you are seeking a sugar high, THE TOP TEN THINGS DEAD PEOPLE WANT TO TELL YOU may be just the icing on the cake that you want to ingest. But will it provide the substance, the nutrition that you need in order to better grapple with the very real obstacles and limitations of life on earth? And are you able to cope with the sugar crash that is likely to follow?

I intended to use the Griot's Microfiber pad for polishing my old, beat-up toyota after giving it a rare cleaning. But soon after my order arrived, I landed in the hospital and was eventually discharged in weakened condition, in no shape to polish my car.I also discovered that being 5'3" with small hands that my hands with fingers spread are exactly the size of this 6.5" diameter pad. It is impossible to stretch my hand around it to grip it, and I'm not about to  purchase a handstrap. I advise anyone (particularly women) with small hands to be aware of this issue and only purchase this pad to use on their car if they have a handstrap.So I decided to use this finishing pad in other ways  ways that it turned out were actually more important to me due to my being bothered for years by streaks, smudges and fingerprints that  never could successfully remove from half of a dozen items in my home.Success! It works perfectly removing smudges, streaks and fingerprints from my tv screen, computer screens, phone screen, two mirrors, and the mirror-like surface of my cd player. It also does a fair but not super-job of ridding of streaks on stand-alone glass. However, it was too big to reach into the crevices of a lattice-work style glass cabinet with 16 small glass panes.The finishing pad is high quality, and can undoubtedly survive many cleanings. It has a felt top area over a spongy middle area above the actual soft flexible surface used for cleaning. Apparently this is microfiber, but it looks like fluffy, soft black yarn about  inch high.You may not want to spend this much money to purchase this microfiber pad just for screens, mirrors and glass, but you might be pleased to know that it is very useful for other purposes besides polishing a car.

What if your soul/consciousness could be preserved when you're dying and returned to your body once your body was healed? What if it could be transferred to another body? Would the previous occupant's body influence your consciousness and behavior?What if a technology could enable this process, and be used for both noble and nefarious purposes?  Would only the rich have access to it? Would there be widespread religious objections?How much of our identity is consciousness and how much is the body, anyway? Would those who saw the light and returned to life want to die over and over again in order to re-experience that light?  Could a dead murder victim return in another body to testify against his killer?Would body theft become a new form of criminal behavior? Might recreational body-sharing become a new form of pleasure, with people able to experience bodies healthier or more physically capable than their own, or to get high on drugs on another person's body?To what extent might the government take control of the body-sharing industry and constructively use or misuse its power? What might happen when other countries  or terrorists  begin to adapt Soulminder for their own purposes?These are only some of the questions raised by SOULMINDER, a philosophical science fiction novel which thoroughly and brilliantly explores many ramifications of the technological development of this Soulminder process, although the book is mediocre as a work of fiction.The story begins as we learn that  Adrian Sommer (with business partner Jessica Sands) has developed Soulminder after the traumatic death of his five year old. His aim is completely well-intentioned. He wishes to circumvent death by keeping the soul (consciousness) alive and accessible while the body is kept functioning on machines as it is surgically repaired and healed. Then, the soul can be returned to it and the patient continue to live.Sands, however, has a different vision in mind  immortality. Why not be able to restore the soul to a younger, healthier body, and perhaps keep living in healthy bodies ad infinitum? But that is not the only possibility for Soulminder, and once objections to its existence are overcome, its possible uses began to expand and significantly influence individuals and society.Consider the beginnings of computers. Or the Internet. Who could have foreseen all the ways they are used now? The free open access to so much information, the speeding up of communication, the transcending of time and space  and yet cyber-theft and Internet addiction. This book may be about Soulminder but it also raises both practical and ethical issues in regard to the development of new influential technologies in general, and their potential for both good and evil.Fortunately, the philosophical speculation that SOULMINDER stimulates is so meaningful and fascinating that it succeeded in enabling me to forgive the second-rate craft. Except for Sommer, the characters are flat and one-dimensional  and even our perception of him is limited because we don't experience him apart from his relation to Soulminder. Author Zahn does not fully develop the religious opposition that is likely to occur, or explore what it's like to return to life or live  in another's body.He does, however, to a limited extent, describe the experience of being a disembodied soul  floating, sensing the presence of other bodiless entities, being drawn toward or away from a powerful light. One of his character says , "Soulminder....It's just like purgatory. You're dead, but you can't get to heaven."Because SOULMINDER was originally written as a series of  novellas, there is some disjunction between the chapters, which suddenly skip time periods and explore different dimensions of the expansion and uses of Soulminder. First, Soulminder succeeds in its initial testing and is further developed. Then it goes public and encounters the opposition of evangelists. Then, different uses and misuses of this consciousness-transfer technology begin to emerge and spread. The U.S. government seeks increasingly to take control, and  other countries begin to use the technology for their own purposes. Finally, Zahn returns to Sommer, who is now attempting to maintain control over Soulminder and prevent its continuing misuse.In the second half of the book, the main thread focusing on Sommer is lost for a considerable time, first due to a murder and detective story (which digresses far too much, and  should have been omitted), and second, to chapters exploring different Soulminder experiences of other persons not integral to the story. The personal vignettes are interesting because of the different perspectives they provide, although they are more like short-lived tributaries that do not influence the overall flow of the story.Although the third part of the book ricochets off from the more meaningful focus on Sommer's attempts to control the expansion of Soulminder, it does fully portray the unexpected and often frightening consequences of a technology that runs rampant in ways unforeseen by its developers (e.g. the atom bomb) and without ethical restraints.In the novel, Sommer says to a colleague, "Soulminder is an archangel. I'm very afraid that it'll be beyond your ability to keep it from being a demon." General Diaz, the novel's dictator of Chile states, "It is now the hand that rocks the CASKET that rules the world."I highly recommend SOULMINDER to those who like philosophical science fiction which explores the moral and ethical issues, and in particular the consequences of technology. The book stimulates considerable reflection, and would be a superb book for a book club oriented toward serious discussion. Yes, the writing craft is mediocre. But like Aldous Huxley's THE ISLAND, a novel which I read decades ago and remember as being visionary and meaningful although poorly written, SOULMINDER is substantial and significant.

I only took these raspberry ketone capsules for a week due to severe gallbladder pain that may not be related to the capsules, but was exacerbated by them. The gallbladder digests fats, and these capsules are high performance fat-burning. I ordered them because I recently became hypothyroid, and had gained 20 pounds in recent years, which I was not able to lose.Due to an unfortunate coincidence, I started experiencing occasional digestive pain a few days after ordering these capsules - a problem I've had in the past and for which I take omeprazole on a regular basis. When the capsules arrived in the mail a week later, I was hesitant to take them for fear that they would worsen the digestive pain.Indeed, within a week of taking them, that is what happened.  And in fact,  I now have all the symptoms of a gallbladder infection, with severe debilitating pain and fever incapacitating me at least six hours a day. I have just had medical testing, and am now in the process of being treated for a serious infection.Anyone who experiences occasional or frequent digestive pain that may be gallbladder-related (and can be mistaken for stomach pain) should  consult with a doctor before deciding whether to ingest these capsules. Also, read carefully the safety information and legal disclaimer that appears on this site. DO NOT DO AS I DID AND TAKE A CHANCE WITH THESE CAPSULES IF YOU EXPERIENCE DIGESTIVE PAIN.I am rating these capsules one star due to my own experience, but recognize that healthy individuals with no history of digestive pain may find them helpful.

GREAT MAPS is an extraordinary one-of-a-kind book published by the Smithsonian incomparable for the quality of its text and visuals, especially considering the low cost. Each of the 55 full-color historical maps (and Google Earth) are presented in a large 2-page spread with accompanying text. The initial map is followed by detailed close-up pictures of various sections of the map, also with explanations.The book divides the maps into five chronological categories. Below is a listing of these categories, each followed by three or four examples of maps in that category:CLASSICAL MAPS  1500BC-1300CEThe Babylonian World Map (the earliest known map) -- Dunhuang Star Chart (Li Chunfeng) -- The Book of Curiosities (Arabic/Islamic)DISCOVERY  AND TRADE 1300-1570Fra Mauro's World Map - -Map of Utopia (Holbein) - First Map of America (Waldseemullar)  --Mercator's Earth MapNEW DIRECTIONS AND BELIEFS 1570-1750Map of the Holy Land (Bar-Jacob) --  New Map of the World (Blaeu) -- Map of New England (Foster) --Brittania Atlas Road Map (Ogilby)THEMATIC MAPS  1750-1900Dr. Livingston's Map of Africa -- Map of All Under Heaven -- Indian Territory Map (Tanner)MODERN MAPPING 1900-PresentInternational Map of the World (Penck) -- London Underground Map (1933, Beck) -- Lunar Landings (NASA)- -  Equal Areas World Map (Peters)GREAT MAPS has a preface and introduction explaining the history of cartography worldwide. Brief text accompanies each map, describing its origin and providing guidance in regard to interpreting it  not an easy task. The "Visual Tour" close-ups of each map zero in on different sections  e.g. Peter street, The Isle of Devils, Paradise, The Great Wall, The Mountains of the Moon, Andalusia, the Heliocentric Solar System.In many of the earliest maps, small mythical pictures and scenes are portrayed across the map, indicating the overlap between the mapmakers' subjective and objective perceptions  how religious beliefs were intertwined with geographical awareness.  I also found myself captivated by the distortions and false impressions of the world throughout various time periods  e.g. the continent of North America without its West Coast. I wonder:  To what extent  in the future will we perceive the inaccuracies of our maps today of undersea or distant space?GREAT MAPS is gorgeous, with quality full-color printing and a dust jacket image a map, glittered in gold.  The book is a magnificent work of art as well as history. Also impressive is the immense amount of scholarship involved in decoding the maps  which contain text in a variety of languages (some archaic) and thousands of esoteric symbols.In conclusion, I will provide another glimpse of the material contained within this book by including my comments on some  of the maps that particularly intrigued me:THE CATALAN ATLAS OF 1375 includes both real and mythical lands, and doesn't distinguish one from the other.The CHINESE DUNHUANG STAR CHART not only portrays over 1300 stars, but links them to Chinese astrological symbols, and includes 26 cloud formations with their meanings.THE ARABIC BOOK OF CURIOSITIES significantly exaggerates the sizes of Spain, North Africa and Arabia.The 17th century SAWLEY WORLD MAP posits the Island of Delos as the center of the World, and also focuses upon  the Garden of Eden.The gorgeous Venetian WORLD MAP of Fra Mauro reveals the medieval Christian view of the world, from the perspective of Biblical geography.Juan de la Cosa's WORLD CHART of 1500 shows Columbus' landfall.The 1569 MERCATOR MAP is the first map to reveal a familiar looking North America.The 1648 Blaeu NEW MAP OF THE WORLD is remarkably precise in regard to Europe and Africa but omits the northwest U.S. and western Canada.Living near Boston, I was particularly intrigued by John Foster's highly distorted 1677 map of Massachusetts  the first map printed in the U.S.  Most towns around Boston are located in the completely wrong place  e.g. Concord east of Watertown, Springfield north of Marlborough.The KOREAN MAP OF ALL UNDER HEAVEN (1800) include some oddly named lands such as lands of the "tangled strings" and "people without bowels".The DIGITAL WORLD MAPPER CARTOGRAM created by Danny Dorling inflates or shrinks the size of countries in accordance with the variable being measured  e.g. population, poverty, transportation.In conclusion, GREAT MAPS is likely to be appreciated and treasured by anyone age 10 or older who is interested in maps, history , changing perceptions of the world, and magnificent visuals. It is a spectacular and substantial coffeetable book, and would be a excellent  birthday or Christmas gift for anyone with a love of learning.

I was given the opportunity to use and review this gloss shampoo, although I'm not the ideal candidate. My car is 16 years old, quite beat-up, and has survived many New England winters in an open parking lot, unprotected from the elements. I have no access to a hose for manual washing, and rely on several gallon-size water bottles, and sponges. Finally, due to a rotator cuff injury  affecting both arms, I have little arm power for vigorous cleaning. So this review pertains to the use of this gloss shampoo in the worst of circumstances.As some reviewers have noted, Einszett gloss shampoo is not very effective at cleaning a car of deep-seated grime. I did rinse my car first  filling and refilling gallon water bottles  before using  one capful of this concentrated, sudsy shampoo per gallon of water, and my toyota definitely does look better and even has a little shine. But the deep-seated grim remains. And there was some streaking, perhaps in part because I was unable to give the car a good hose-down.Because of the warnings about getting the shampoo in one's eyes or on one's skin (avoiding the latter is difficult  I used rubber gloves but still spattered a little), I was anxious the whole time I was cleaning about spattering the shampoo on my arms and legs, and afterwards gave my body a perhaps better cleaning than my car.I'd advise anyone with an old, weather-beaten, grime-saturated car who really want to improve their car's appearance to get it professionally cleaned first. Then this concentrated gloss shampoo may have greater effect. And if the car has lot of dings and scrapes, you may  to want gloss to call attention to them anyway. There are cheaper, more effective solutions for people in a similar situation as mine.

Although I am not a young adult, but rather, a senior citizen, I was drawn to read this young adult novel, which is actually a novel for adults as well. I teach photo-related courses,  and have color/verbal synaesthesia  in contrast to Giulia, this book's heroine, who has color/music synaesthesia.Actually though, I don't believe the author Victoria Strauss is very knowledgeable in regard to synaesthesia - which has to do with overlapping sensory areas in the brain, and does not suddenly occur during one's life. Plus, Strauss doesn't present with Giulia's synaesthesia with any depth or detail  it really isn't even essential to the novel, apart from its title.When Giulia gives up a sorcerer's charm at the beginning of the book, she begins to hear colors sing, especially the rare and costly "passion blue" color which has the purity and clarity of bells. But there is little discussion or development related to Giulia's synaesthesia. There is much more focus on the visual, especially the color of "passion blue"  "bluer than sapphires, bluer than oceans...with swirling azure currents and glinting sapphire radiance."Synaesthesia issue aside, this is a highly absorbing, well-written historical novel about Giulia, an 18 year old girl with a passion for art who is forced into life in a convent against her will, in 15th century Padua, Italy. Fortunately, however, the convent is the only one of its kind that has an art studio for women. There, Giulia develops her talents in drawing and painting, and forms a close relationship with the maestra, who is also the inventor of a recipe for a rare and expensive form of blue paint  passion blue. When her beloved Maestra dies and bequeaths the secret recipe to Giulia at the beginning of the novel, the jealous new Maestra Domenica  restricts Giulia's ability to paint because she won't hand over the valuable recipe.In this world of limited options and little safety for females, Giulia escapes the convent, dresses as a boy, travels to Venice, and attempts to become the apprentice of a master painter, Maestro Ferraldi.  Here, Giulia struggles with trying to maintain her disguise, knowing that she will be kicked out and perhaps forced to return to the convent if she is discovered  or if she is found by her enemies who seek the rare passion blue recipe. But she has friends as well, particularly the courtesan Sophia and her 19 year old son, Bernardo, who does not know that she is a girl.Author Strauss is adept at enabling us to experience Giulia's fears and passion for art, as well as her life in Venice. Clearly, Strauss has researched the Venice of the early Renaissance, as well as the plight of women and the details of artists' workshops, including the making of paint. She skillfully integrates historical details into the novel, which moves at just the right pace, with just enough twists and turns to hold interest. Although I could foresee one development that would occur by the end, another was a complete surprise.I had not read Passion Blue, the precursor of this novel, and wished I had, but since author explains the key happenings in the first novel that are relevant to Giulia's current situation, it wasn't necessary to have read the preceding book. However, if readers have the choice, they might enjoy Color Song even more if they begin with Passion Blue.Color Song is likely to appeal to young adults and adults who love historical novels, coming of age stories, Renaissance Italy, and the world of art.

The place is Germany, not the Germany we know today, but rather the Holy Roman Empire. The time period is the mid 1400s, the transitional time between the Middle Ages and Renaissance - a time of plague, dictatorial Church power, hints of future rebellion against Rome (particularly in Northern Europe), the fall of Constantinople, and the aborted beginning of the Crusades.GUTENBERG'S APPRENTICE focuses upon the scribe Peter Schoeffer, and the years during which he worked day and night, contributing to the printing of the first Bible at least as much as Johann Gutenberg did. The novel presents in detail the obstacles faced by Schoeffer - particularly the difficult of devising the first means of printing and the process of printing a 1200 page Bible.It also reveals the struggle to keep the entire venture secret, including paying off many guilds of craftsmen who were contributing necessary supplies. If the Church found out about the printing press, the men involved might be convicted as heretics. But even more likely, the Church would take over the press, and use it for corrupt purposes - the mass printing of indulgences, the Church's practice of selling its blessings in order to acquire greater wealth."When you get to my age, Peter," Gutenberg told Schoeffer in regard to his invention, "you do begin to wonder if it really is a gift from God - and not a curse sent up from hell."Peter Schoeffer himself, as portrayed by Christie, was a scribe who was initially appalled by the idea of a mechanical means of printing God's word. But soon, he became convinced of the sacredness of the task and the significance of making the Bible available to thousands of people, not just the clergy and the wealthiest of the wealthy.Until the invention of the printing press, every Bible was hand-copied by scribes, and was sold for more than a years' wages of the average worker. The educated were a minority, but few of them had access to a  Bible. They had to rely on readings by priests, who used their near-monopoly over religious texts as a means of cementing control. The development of printing was a turning point in history, and contributed greatly to the flowering of the Renaissance.I loved this book, and found the historical detail fascinating. I highly recommend it. But I also recognize that readers who aren't spiritually inclined or not in continual awe of the power of the written word, might not find the novel as absorbing as I did. It is not fast-paced, and although Alix Christie is skilled in narrating the early days of the printing press, she does not excel in character development.But the main character, Peter, is real enough, as is the half-mad, temperamental and unpredictable Gutenberg. After all, GUTENBERG'S APPRENTICE is not meant to be a character-driven novel, but rather an in-depth research-based although fictionalized narrative.What for me is most lacking is resource material - illustrations of the different components of the early printing press, and an encyclopedic text-based summary of the stages of the printing process with descriptions of each component. At the very least, the author could have pointed readers to relevant online resources, particularly visual resources.But even without such supplementary material, GUTENBERG'S APPRENTICE thoroughly and effectively allows us to experience the earliest days of printing, and the key characters who made possible the mass proliferation of books.

E-CUBED  is a "new age" book, reflecting the same "You create your own reality" view as the book, THE SECRET.  Author  Pam Grout presents principles from what she calls the outdated worldview #1, and the alternative, more life-affirming principles of worldview #2. She also presents nine behavioral experiments to test the validity of those principles.I take issue with many of them, but also strongly believe in the validity of others. In this review, I will first express my skepticism in regard to some of her assumptions (explaining my reasons), before noting the facets of her book which I believe have value and for some readers, are worth reading.Some of the principles she presents are: "There is nothing to fear," " Everybody gets a happy ending,"  "There is no reason to struggle," "Life emanates from me,"  "The only thing I have to do is follow my joy," and "Money isn't real".When I was in my 20s and 30s, beginning in the late 1960s, I would have agreed with most of Pam Grout's assumptions. At that time I was beginning to lead "new age" workshops, and to write books which professed a "new age" philosophy. I also attempted to live by that philosophy, attracting some wonderful, synchronistic experiences and also near-catastrophes. Now I am aware of how naive and ungrounded I was - not preparing  for the worst or taking necessary precautions to ensure my future wellbeing.The corollary of "You create your own reality" is the belief that you choose the reality you experience and if what you intend and envision does not manifest, then you are failing to believe deeply enough or to apply the principles effectively.Bull. I do not believe that my professional pianist aunt chose to have seven fingers cut off in a car accident caused by a drunken driver the week before her first international concert tour, which she wanted more than anything. I do not believe that my mother who had had after-death experiences, had deep faith in the next world and carried her living will around in her wallet, chose to be kept alive on half a machine for six months by doctors who ignored her living will - the hospital collected her $6 million worth of supplemental insurance and let her die when her insurance ran out. I do not believe that despite years of affirmations and healing practices, that I chose to suffer from a chronic illness for forty years.Men don't usually choose to be killed in war; women don't choose to be raped. Bad things happen to good people, often through new fault of their own.  And spending hours a day praying and envisioning your life dream is no guarantee that it will manifest. (But it certainly is likely to increase the odds of your being able to manifest it, provided you do more than just envision it.)Pam Grout's "worldview 2" is based upon unlimited abundance, wish fulfillment, blind optimism and goodness in contrast to a bleak "worldview 1" which assumes a hostile dog-eat-dog universe of constant struggle, where work is a necessary evil. Personally, I don't buy either view.  There is a middle way between blind optimism and unrelenting pessimism. It's called realism.Within the worldview of realism, we have some ability to manifest or attract what we seek, and our beliefs and thoughts do influence reality. But limitation is real, obstacles (internal and external) are real, and (on the earth plane), money is real as well --- and  if you act as if it isn't, you'll create a lot of difficulties for yourself. I've known several "new age" people who operated on the principle of an abundant universe that they could trust to fund their life purpose. Both went bankrupt and lost their homes. The first also lost his marriage. The second committed suicide. There is no substitute for grounding in physical reality.So far I've presented some principles discussed by Pam Grout and my reasons for being skeptical - and encouraging you to be skeptical - in regard to some of them. As a deeply spiritual person, I on the other hand affirm other principles that she presents.. Some of them are: ""There is an invisible energy force field of infinite possibilities," "You impact that field," "Whatever you focus on expands," "Your thoughts and consciousness impact matter" (Note:  "impact"  not "create"), "You are connected to everyone and everything in the universe,"  "My worthiness is not at stake," and "God is  state of being, a loving energy that flows through me."There are a few life-expanding personal experiments in this book. There are also many gems of wisdom. For example: "If we want to create more energy and therefore more 'bandwidth' for a joyful life, we must being to pay attention to things that matter. And let go of all the things that don't."In short, E-CUBED is a mixed bag. If you read it, I suggest maintaining a healthy skepticism but also a healthy openness. You don't have to agree with it all or debunk it all, although you may be tempted to take one stand or the other. Life is neither  black and white, nor either/or. There is a middle way.

I was in the middle of a non-stop sneezing allergy attack when I heard a thump at my front door, and opened it to discover that my giant package of Puffs softpack tissue had arrived. Of course, I was quick to open and use them.One reason why I like these packs that few people note is that the opening at top is not a cutout area that leaves the top tissue partly exposed to the dust particles in the air. The top tissue can be pushed back into the softpack so that the pack is almost sealed closed. This is a great advantage for anyone allergic to dust. Tissues are of little use when the top one only exacerbates nose-blowing because of invisible dust particles it has attracted. Also, the allergy prone might be happy to know that the tissues have no noticeable scent.The most lauded characteristic of the softpacks appears to be the softpacks themselves  that they are lighter, smaller and above all more collapsible than regular kleenex boxes. Sure, this is a plus, but I don't find it to be as big a deal as the advertising suggests. The space-saving is really quite minimal. Nevertheless, it certainly can be an advantage in many circumstances.Some people dislike the different color combinations of the soft plastic packaging  mostly a pale turquoise/silver streamer design, gold/white polka dots, or yellow/silver swirls. I don't mind, but if you keep your softpacks out in the open and want them to match the color of your decor, you have little choice here. However, if color matters to you, you are probably best off  purchasing color-coordinated boxes in which to place your tissue packages.The tissues themselves are slightly larger than regular box size tissues, and certainly stronger. I did a strength test on both dry and wet tissues, and indeed Puffs were more difficult to rip in both circumstances than either the regular box tissues or the small purse packets that I had on hand. But are they 50% stronger? Of that, I'm not sure.If some of the benefits of Puffs that I mentioned appeal to you, then by all means, purchase them. I find them superior to kleenex tissues that I used in the past, and recommend them.

FLIP-IT! comes with six 38mm purple base caps with attached stands (so the bottle can stand upside down), several sheets of different sized punch-out  gaskets for inserting in the cap or adapter, and two each of three sizes of adapters for 33mm (red), 28mm (orange) and 24 mm bottle necks or large tubes.I am not very handy and was afraid that I wouldn't be able to figure out how to use FLIP-IT, but the instructions are clear. What confused me initially is that the adapters and gaskets all looked the same size. But the included list of items noting the color/size combinations helps differentiate them, and when I tried them I did see the difference. It did seem, however ,to be a hassle to have to try different combinations in order to find the right ones to use  - and so many parts means more dishwashing to do.I only regularly use three kinds of bottles or tubes containing thick fluids. The large cap did work in minutes for my giant Heinz ketchup bottles. Since what has most concerned me is all the expensive John Frieda conditioner and shampoo I lose from  their large thick tubes, I was pleased to discover that the FLIP-IT! caps (with middle size adapter and gasket) work on these. I had hoped FLIP-IT! would work on toothpaste tubes, but not so.One problem for me is that the flipped bottles and tubes upside down on the cap + base must be stored on a solid surface. This is not convenient for me. I live in a tiny apartment with almost no counter space and a small refrigerator. The large extended size of the upside down caps means that large ketchup bottles can only tightly fit in the refrigerator door, and take up extra space. In the bathroom, the upside down shampoos and conditioners can't be stored on open metal racks nor will they fit in the medicine cabinet, so the only alternative is the limited floor space, which means they can be easily kicked over in a tiny bathroom.Finally, given that I finish about one bottle a week, my estimate is that using FLIP-IT! will save me about 25 cents per week or about $1 a month. It will therefore take 20 months to pay off the $20 cost. For me, it is not worth it. But for a single person who uses twice the number of thick fluids as I do, or for a larger household, it may be worth the cost and the time.

Wow. Just woe. I have loved the myth of Hades and Persephone for as long as I remember, and this book does not disappoint the very least! The author remains faithful to her source material, while at the same time adding several fantastically creative twists to the myths. I found her version of the Sisyphus myth to be especially brilliant.Normally, I'm not a fan of the version of the Persephone myth which has her being promised to Hades by Zeus (or Poseidon, in the couple of versions where Poseidon is her father instead of Zeus) at birth. It's never felt right for me for babies to be promised in marriage, however, Ms. Alexander pulls this off with surprising tact, and there is a very good story behind this promise, which makes the story work so well.And what about the Hades/Persephone dynamics? Very well-executed here, as well. The entire book has been thought out well, and she put in some fascinating details/aspects about the Underworld that made it feel much more real. Her research, and twists, are spot-on.And the erotic scenes between our dynamic duo... mmm. Definitely swoon-worthy. I've read too many erotica scenes with cheesy descriptions and metaphors, but Ms. Alexander writes such scenes in such a steamy yet tasteful way that leaves the reader wishing that they were Persephone (or Hades) Nom nom nom.I await with bated breath for the sequel.

Well. What a huge letdown. Not that I should expect much else from Andrew Neiderman trying to masquerade as V.C. Andrews, but the premise of this novel did actually sound promising, and anything, just about ANYTHING had to be better than the Christoper's Diary books!However, I found the character of Mayfair Cummings to be unlikable. Like, seriously. She has a brilliant IQ, and naturally people with higher IQs may feel frustrated with people not as smart as them, but Mayfair is so condescending sometimes that any pity you might feel for her (like having a stepmother like Julie) is wiped away once she deliberately baits someone or tries to make them feel stupid. Even her stepsister, who she gets along better with, is still condescended down to.For a premise that sounded so promising, Neiderman ruined it with his lackluster, rushed writing... as he always does. This book does not measure up to VCA standards, but it doesn't measure up to ANY good standard, period. I'm serious - I've read LOTS of self-published books that are of far better caliber than this.

This is a pretty easy book to read and was a fairly quick one for me. I was a bit confused with the timeline, there is this family tree at the beginning of the book. Sam's birthdate is given as 1958, while Callie is 1960. However, reading the book and doing the math (Callie was pregnant at 27) would put her birthdate as 1969. There's also the fact that it has been mentioned there is a decent age difference between them.One other thing I didn't get was Callie's father's treatment towards his daughter. He cut ties with her because she slept with her brother... only the man in question was not related to her in any actual way, he was just her stepbrother (who was 10 years her senior, and never actually lived with her) so I found Dad's attitude a rather contrived plot point especially given he did a 180 at the end of the book. I think the story could have been mapped out better.

I enjoyed this book and learned about the marvelous Dixie Dingo breed. The story itself was also pretty good, albeit keep in mind this is a children's book, not a full-length novel. I found the subject matter and narration appropriate for children, though I do wish that the author had toned back a bit on how Honey spoke.I know Honey is a dog and all that, but there was so much of Southern/country drawl/slang in the narration (not the dialogue) that I found it a tad off-putting at times. That was my only real complaint though, and I would definitely be eager to read the next Honey book.

This was actually a rather enjoyable read, and one where you could tell the author was trying to avoid some of the overused tropes that one sees often in romance. I absolutely loved how the two main characters decided to simply have one another in secret instead of trying to be all 'proper'. My only complaint is the book ended too quickly, I wanted to see more of Simone and her sassiness.

I found this book to be all right. The historical research seemed to be well-done, but then I read this back in high school so I don't remember all the details. I do remember wishing there had been more sci fi in here, more looking into the time travel and all that. It was an all right read.

I will admit when I first started this book, I was disliking the guy a bit. He is very well-off and has the money to pay for a very high-quality dating service, instead of using OkCupid. However, as the novel went on, I found myself liking the guy more and more. I felt bad for him when he spent all that money on these Russian women, it seems like they were using him and purposely keeping him at arms length just to get more from him.I was happy for him when he found relationships with other women that worked out, at least for a while. What I would have liked to know a bit more about is the circumstances of his divorce, as a setup to this tale. Overall I really enjoyed this book, and wish the author the best in his romantic endeavors.

Wow! This book was a game-changer! An race in the last book, the Alarians, make their re-appearance here as the story moves along with the evil Alarian commander, and Mallory, continuing to try to manipulate the element for themselves.There was a surprising revelation including Jacob here, and the only complaint I have is that chronologically, it befuddled me (don't want to go too much into derail as that would be a spoiler) but it did explain quite a bit.In the last three books, and of course, this one, Owen journeys to a pillar and learns the importance of this or that trait (i.e. patience, prudence) but this book also represents a pivotal turn in the series as certain events ensure that the lives of many will never be the same again, and will doubtlessly affect the rest of the books in this series, which I am of course eager to read!

After having read the first two books, I was eager to read this next one. We are introduced to a new race, the Alarians, and we learn more about the element and its creation/purpose.I feel that the author did a bit more telling than showing in some parts, as some parts felt a bit rushed through and it was hard for me to visualize what was going on, but I still very much enjoyed this book, and read the fourth book right after this. If you read and enjoyed books 1 and 2, then continue the series and pick up this book.

Having enjoyed some of Mr. Koontz's work very much in the past, I was eager for this book, after hearing about how popular it was. What a letdown...The story started off really well. it was interesting reading about a character with such a genetic issue like Chris, and how it has affected his life in such a way. I would have liked to read more about that. As the bigger picture was revealed, it became more incoherent. The monkeys, for example, and the story about them... I found the story just too implausible. Mr. Koontz has a good writing style, but this story was a major letdown, and extremely cliched and cheesy in some ways, especially the scene where Chris goes to visit his friend on the boat and there's the whole conversation the friend had with/about the dog and cat and all that.Definitely not one of Mr. Koontz' best work, I recommend Darkfall or Lightning instead.

I have mixed feelings about this volume. I know the story had to end eventually, and this volume has a lot of satisfying endings (Ambrose and Lake, Jack of Fables) but the ending of some others stunned and saddened me (Cinderella and Frau Totenkinder)There are still quite a few questions left unanswered, like how Snow managed to have children, and even sons, without killing off Rose Red. It's been shown that fates can be changed (such as Lake changing Bigby Wolf's destiny) and it may have been this that changed Snow's own fate.There are some things i really enjoyed about this book and others I didn't. Nonetheless, it was still overall a pretty good book, nd if you've read the rest of the Fables books, then by all means, read this one. I just wish there had been more for poor Darien...

I have mixed feelings about this book. Aside the whole fact that this book was released after the end of the Fables series despite the events in this volume happening before the end, there are two major issues with this book. Now, mind you, I enjoyed the story of glamour and the animals wanting glamour, but wasn't this series meant to focus on the women of Fables and explore their backgrounds?The first book revolved around Sleeping Beauty and to a lesser extent the Snow Queen, and was the best in the series. Volume 2 was about Rapunzel and left more questions than answers and now with the end, it looks like we will never find out about Rapunzel's babies. Vol 3 was about Prince Charming! Vol 4 was about Cinderella but we don't learn anything about her past other than a couple of details which just left us wanting more (like about her stepsister. That was never explained!)And so here we are with volume 5, which had a nice story about the animals, and a issue about Goldlilocks, but this issue doesn't ever explore her past and how she came to her beliefs.The second major issue is the story revolving around Renard the Fox. I felt that his romance was slapdash and sloppy, and just a way to tie up something (that didn't even need to be tied in the first place)So I am giving three stars for the good things, including the sidestory about Owl and Pussycat, but deducting two stars for the issues I mentioned above. I'm disappointed with how the series went after the first volume, and wish that the writers had stayed on topic.

I have mixed feelings about this book. It made me feel sad that the Fables series was coming to an end, but with over 20 graphic novels, the time had to come, sooner or later.
