In Mein Kampf, Hitler would later criticize the movement for its inability to address the lower classes, for its halfhearted attempt to bring about historical change through the parliamentary system, and for its directing national attention away from the group  that he too believed to be the true enemy of the German people. But even before the outbreak of World War I, these criticisms had become commonplace among Pan-Germans in both empires.  p. 231.//So much of this is both familiar and foreign.  From reading about the Nazi movement, and other sources, I've heard the names mentioned in this section, but I never had the context.  I had always thought of Houston Stewart Chamberlain as a relatively inconsequential racists precursor to the Nazis, but I had no idea that his writings were informed Protestant anti-ultamontanism.  Further, the opposition to "Political Catholicism" was a mainstay of the Nazi political program, but it would seems that the tradition of assailing "Political Catholicism" was simply a continuation of traditional "antiultramontanism" of the Reich.In fact, this book makes Mein Kampf comprehensible.  The opening chapters of Mein Kampf involves Hitler's description of the Catholic church's oppression - in his view of Austrian Germans at the behest of Austrian Slavs - and his praise of Schonerer.  I previously didn't have the context for those passages, but I see now how formative to Hitler, the antiultramontane movement was for his stated political views.In a way, then, this book, and the history it covers, is like a skeleton key for understanding the early Nazi movement, which is necessary for understanding the mature Nazi movement and the dynamics of the Nazi-Catholic relationship.Before I began this book, I had the relatively tentative position that the popular linkage of Catholicism with Nazism, i.e., that Catholics or the Catholic church supported the Nazis, was nonsense because Catholicism was intrinsically non-nationalistic and had an allegiance to someone who was not German.  This book solidifies that view, and therefore is quite worth reading for anyone interested in that subject.

I purchased this book under the belief that I would be getting something akin to the Nuremberg trial transcripts, which might offer some insights into the mindset and workings of the Third Reich.What I received was a fantastic story about how Gestapo Chief Heinrich Mueller didn't die in 1945, but instead was recruited by the CIA as part of its anti-Soviet efforts and lived until sometime in the 1980s. The author claims to have the secret files of Mueller which he obtained through means that "are not necessary for the reader's understanding."Real history tells us that Mueller died in Berlin in 1945, or, at least, that was when he was last known to have been alive.If I had known the real history, the 1948 interrogation subtitle would have been a red-flag. As it was, I suspected a rat within a few pages when the author began to insinuate that the Final Solution hadn't happened. With that red-flag, I did a quick search and found an article from the Institute for History Review entitled "Not Quite the Hitler Diaries," that spells out the extent of the fraud. [Upon further research it turns out that the Institute for Historical Review is part of the holocaust-denial collective, so take the article with a grain of salt, albeit why a site with a holocaust-denial agenda would blow the whistle on a holocaust-denial forgery is a bit of a conundrum.]I can't see any reason for purchasing this book, unless you are a Holocaust-denying, conspiracy nut.

If you are a fan of Robert Heinlein, then you will love this movie.  It is based - and stays extremely close to - Heinlein's classic story "All You Zombies." I tumbled to the connection in the first few minutes when some of Heinlein's lines were showing up in the movie, but when one character introduced himself as the "unmarried mother," I knew I had to check IMDB. Heinlein purists will love this movie. There are lines right out of the story, and the background has things from the story, such as a jukebox playing "I'm my own Grandpa." There also all sorts of clever "tells" planted in the movie, which you will spot if you know the story.The movie does extend the story, but not in a way that hurts the message or plot. In fact, the extension is necessary to round out the story from the standpoint of fitting a Hollywood checklist for plot closure (the story being famous for not having closure.)I am not sure that anyone will be surprised by the plot turns, but, then, I read the story a half dozen times before I graduated from high school.The actors sell their roles.  Ethan Hawke comes across as an experienced agent, and Sarah Snook delivered on her roles as well as one might expect for such a pretty and feminine lady.

And boy does this nail polish remind me of the 1970's, in many ways. There is absolutely no reason to buy this nail polish. Here's why:--The color is a orange-y coral, not peach and very different from the picture. I would describe it as "1976 MuuMuu Giant Flower Pattern".--The polish is thin, runny and smudgy.--For the same price, you can buy Pacifica's 7-Free polish (free of the seven most common nail polish toxins, as opposed to essie essie's three), which is superior is texture and application. If you want a pale pink I suggest their "Blushing Bunnies" color.This is my first experience with essie essie as a brand and it will be my last. Many other reviewers report the same color and quality problems I list above, and they are all correct. Best skip this one.GRADE: D

Here at our house we've been going against the grain (wheat grain, anyway) for about ten years. This review will focus on preparing the Bona Dea Marvelous Muffin Mix vegan, as the instructions list eggs in the steps (but the mix itself is vegan). We used Santa Cruz Peach Applesauce and Garden of Life Organic Ground Flax as our egg substitute.Well, not very good. As my sister commented, you will not want to eat the full dozen yourself, that's for sure. Now we have been gluten-free for many years, and so we have pretty loose standards for what tastes good to us, but this is just not cutting it. Also, the luscious blueberries pictured on the front of the package (and on this product page) might lead you to believe the mix contains blueberries; it does not. The flour mix smells almost rancid, but this is probably the smell of the teff, which is a bit unusual. At least I hope that's the teff. Despite being declared whole-grain, the muffins have just one gram of fiber each (but ten grams of sugar and twenty-seven carbs); however all the grains are organic. So that's nice.In the end, not enough. Not nearly nutritious enough to be called healthy, and they don't taste that good. If nutrition is not a concern and you just want delectable muffins, go with the King Arthur GF muffin mix, or if you want a bit cleaner ingredients try out the Cravings Place mix. The Bona Dea mix falls far short of both the tasty and the healthy mark and rates:GRADE: CNOTE: For comparison's sake, we prepared a second batch, this time following the exact instructions on the package, which have you use eggs. The results were better tasting, but still less than stellar (There's this strange aftertaste that persists in both versions. It seems to be the baking powder, not the grains themselves.). I'm going to rate the mix 3.5 stars if you use eggs and 2.5 if you prepare it vegan, for an average of 3 stars.

There are many remedies for a tummy that's feeling poorly, and Mastic Gum is one of the more interesting and time-tested on the long list. This review will focus less on the medicinal effects of the gum in general and more on this specific product, compared to other mastic supplements on the market (although anyone and everyone who suffers from a H. Pylori infection should check out a landmark study done on Mastic Gum in 1998 and published by the New England Journal of Medicine).Generally, I like Jarrow products, although sometimes their additives and fillers leave much to be desired. This Mastic Gum has that almost indefinable grassy/root smell, and is dosed at 500 mg per capsule. They use magnesium stearate and silicon dioxide as fillers; far less desirable than the MCT oil (usually from coconut) some companies are now using instead for other kinds of supplement formulations. However, so far every brand making mastic gum uses magnesium steareate as at least one of the excipients, so you are stuck with it if you choose mastic gum as a treatment.We're starting to see fillers disappear from many higher-end supplement brands (like Renew Life and Enzymedica) as brands catch on that consumers would rather have just the supplement and not powdered plastics, cheap oils, or whitening agents along with it. A product with just mastic gum and the capsule fibers would rate five stars from me, but this one gets:GRADE: B

This vegan protein leaves a lot to be desired. We are big on daily workouts here at my house, and so we always have half a dozen protein powders around for a a quick post-workout snack. How does this one compare to other vegan options? Some points of interest:--First of all, the full retail on this protein is outrageous. The ingredients are not organic, and carrageenan, a notorious gut-irritant used as an emulsifier, is the second ingredient on the list. At full price this is more expensive per serving than the Vega Sport Protein, which is considered quite pricey and is made from a similar blend of plan proteins.--The amino-acid content, very important information, is listed on this Amazon webpage. That's awesome, because it's not on the package. If you were to buy this in a store, you would have no way of evaluating the BCAA content in the moment. A weird oversight.--The package proudly calls out "No Sugar", which is great, but the same cannot be said for sodium. Each scoop contains a whopping 540 mg of sodium. Compare that to Vega's "Protein and Greens" blend, which has much more nutrition, is cheaper per serving, and only contains 180 mg for roughly the same serving size. Obviously athletes do have different sodium needs than non-athletes, but 540 mg seems excessive, even if is from sea salt.--Since carrageenan is the second ingredient, there is probably very little rice and hemp protein in this product. Another indicator is the poor vitamin and mineral content; brown rice protein has a lot of naturally occurring iron, and this protein has 0% of your RDA for that nutrient.In conclusion, a sham. You can get organic, better-quality for proteins for less per serving very easily. You're basically paying for the Everlast name here. My personal fav of all the vegan proteins is Ojio's Sprouted Brown Rice protein: The sprouting process jacks up the amino acid content, the nutrients are higher, it's certified organic, and if you shop around you can get it cheaper per serving than this product.Problematic at best and rating:GRADE: C-/D

So said the great violinist Yehudi Menuhin. Of course, if you want to get all that you will need good earphones. I love these earphones. They fit my ears perfectly, I love the sound, and I love the bells and whistles. They will be a misery for the wrong person, however. Some points of interest:THE FIT: I have a smaller head (I am 5' 7) and the ear hooks fit like a glove. Larger ears? You are going to be in trouble, as several reviewers note.The Apple compatible version of these phones have a lop-sided cord, with one side being much longer than the other. Sennheiser says Apple made them do it that way. It doesn't bother me at all, personally. The cord is supposed to be "tangle-free"; well, mostly. Mine is a bit tangled. To be fair, I am a notorious tangler of cords, with some headphones so tangled I am in danger of choking myself to death as I walk down the street. I wish I was kidding. The only truly tangle-free cord I have ever used was for these ear-buds:Phiaton MS 100 BA Balanced Armature Earphones with Mic. It was kind of amazing, the only really amazing thing about them.THE SOUND: Like all good headphones/speakers, these ear phones need to be broken in for the best sound quality. My brother, who is autistic and absurdly picky about his audio equipment, recommends breaking in ear phones of this range and quality by plugging them into your computer and playing music at full volume for one full day (don't have them on when you do that!). These mellowed out nicely for me in a short time. If you are very choosy about sound, this product is not a good idea, as the highs are a bit tinny. But for my taste, the sound was adequate.THE ANTI-BACTERIAL TREATMENT: This actually freaked me out at first (I didn't notice the feature when I ordered them), because I don't trust companies not to spray their products down with some sort of horrible toxin and poison me. It's the world we live in.  Some research revealed that the anti-bacterial element is a silver ion treatment, similar to silver applications in hospitals. The company who makes it (Steri-Touch) states that the silver is non-nano. So I feel a bit better about that.QUALITY: These look study and well-made, however I am aware that some reviewers had their phones break after a short time. I've been using these nearly everyday for about a month with no quality problems at all, but a month is not a long time. At this price they should last years, and I will report back if I experience quality issues down the road.These earphones are compatible with my old, dinky, non-Apple MP3 player (though the on-cord volume control does not work) and my Toshiba computer. They come with extra ear-buds and a nifty pouch (worlds better that the bag that came with the aforementioned Phiaton buds) that has a Velcro closure.In conclusion, recommended. Yes, you can get higher-quality sound, especially if you're willing to pay a lot more. And yes, you need to have smaller ears or you run the risk of a bad fit. But for me, for the reasons above, a perfect fit and so 4.5 stars, which we'll round up to five for Amazon purposes, and rating:GRADE: A-

If like Katherine you have paired down your beauty regime down to the essentials, consider this lip balm. I decided to post a review for it when I saw there weren't any yet, because it has a weird property worth knowing about: It doubles as a bug-bite balm. The nice folks at Badger mentioned this facet to me when I got one, and a couple of days ago I also got my first mosquito bite of the summer. Surprisingly, applying this balm really took down the itching dramatically. Since Burt's Bees is no longer making their beloved Bite Balm, this is a nice substitute.The Tea Tree and Lemon Balm are there to help heal cold sores or other such issues, and the cocoa butter gives you some added softness and protection against the elements. I don't understand the current price of $10 for the balm, as it is about $5 at any natural foods store. I've giving it five stars as a product, because it works so well as a balm, cold sore healer, and bug bite soother. Just make sure you only pay about $5 for it.

I like these. Yes the concept is silly, but at my house we do not use paper towels to clean up messes (unless the messes are a total bio-hazard or something) and I often need just a small scrap to use as a napkin or to pat down meat before cooking or whatever. And they are kinda cute.The Sparkle Mini Rolls are currently unavailable (bad sign), so I can't give you buyers a price comparison to regular paper towels, but they certainly wouldn't be worth more just because they are petite. I am deducting one star based on other reviewers who said the price differences weren't favorable, but otherwise I am very happy with the quality and I admit, the concept. It worked in our house, and the quote above is in reference to me, because I hate cleaning and do everything I can to keep my sparkle. These little towels are helping, in a little way.GRADE: B

Do the Kimberly-Clark towel-dispensers have to be so ugly? They're ubiquitous across the U.S.; in insurance offices and doctor's offices and now at my house for some reason, and man they are ugly. Surely it would cost no more to mold the plastic in a shape less reminiscent of a Communist Regime. As for the towels themselves, they are perfectly fine, decently made and will get your hands dry. I am rating the product three stars because in order to use these towels as they were intended you have to have a hideous dispenser, and you will break a nail getting it open to load your towels (it is a fact.).We, the hapless insurance buyers and patients of doctors and denizens of my house, should demand better. And by better  I don't mean making it bigger and weird-looking, Purple-People-Eater-style, like this one from San Jamar: San Jamar T990 Oceans Element Roll Towel Dispenser, Fits 8" Wide and 8" Diameter Roll, 12-1/2" Width x 12-3/4" Height x 8-1/2" Depth, Black Pearl. I mean truly better.I sense a golden opportunity for some enterprising start-up.Til then we're stuck with:GRADE: C-

This is a 4.5 star review rounded up to five for Amazon. The Aroma Digital Kettle has some small design flaws, but nothing major and the kettle is a very good deal for the performance. This review will directly compare the Russell Hobbs KE9000S Electric Kettle, Stainless Steel, which right now on sale is exactly the same price. Details as follows:SET-UP: Much easier than many kettles (including the Hobbs) which you to have to treat the pot with vinegar and let it sit for hours before the first use. The Aroma kettle only requires a light water rinse and you're ready to rock. The kettle is sturdy and well-built, but be advised the cord is a bit on the short side. If your desired location is more than two feet away from an outlet you might want to look elsewhere.PERFORMANCE/USE: I love the easily adjustable water temps that allow you to more precisely brew different kinds of tea (higher temps for black tea, lower for white, etc.). I would say this kettle is ideal for the more serious tea-drinker, as it comes with a recommended temperature list for different beverages (printed on a slip of paper; it would have been infinitely better to etch it on the kettle itself). RE: The water line. Why do these kettle companies make the water level marker so hard to read? Both the Hobbs kettle and this one suffer from the same dumb problem. There needs to be a mark line INSIDE the kettle since you can't  pour water and watch the water line at the same time. It's easy to over shoot.This isn't a lightening-fast kettle; full 212 degree water takes 8 minutes when the kettle is at the max line.I like the easily removable filter on the spout that keeps out sediment from your beverage. Nice.SAFETY: I really like how the lid on the unit locks shut, preventing scalding or spills. The temperature display at the top lets you know how hot the water inside is in case you have multiple people using the kettle and not communicating what they've been doing (it happens). If you overfill the kettle you do risk boiling water coming up the spout.PRICE: Is it worth double the price for a digital kettle? To me, yes. We brew about 14 cups of tea a day, and rotate between all types of tea and teasans, so I really appreciate the temp controls. The Aroma has held up to heavy use very well so far. This is superior to the Hobbs kettle, and I do recommend it. You might be able to find it in the forty dollar range if you shop around or wait for a better sale, and I would say grab it at that price.The only real flaw is that hard-to-read while pouring water line, and it's relatively minor, so I've comfortable rounding the star rating to five (we gave the Hobbs kettle four). Happy tea-drinking! (Or oatmeal-making, as the case may be.)GRADE: B+/A-

We have a ViewSonic projector ViewSonic PJD6383S XGA 1024x768 DLP Projector, 3000 ANSI Lumens, 15,000:1 Contrast Ratio, 120Hz/3D-Ready- Black which is no longer being produced by ViewSonic. When the bulb started going out, I called them and asked which lamp to order as a replacement, and they said to get this one (which at the time was selling for $329). They informed me that this model lamp will last for 22,000 hours.Installation I would put at a medium-level difficulty, perhaps out of the range of most people without technical experience in this field. If you have projectors littering your living room floor like confetti and work with this type of equipment every day (like my brother does), then you'll be fine, but if this is your first time changing out a projector lamp here are some tips:--Have two people on the job--Block out at least an hour--The instructions for replacing the lamp are in the digital manual, which you can download at viewsonic.com. Just paste in your projector model #, then go to "downloads" on the navigation bar under the product image, then scroll down to the User Guide.--You have to unscrew the top of projector (very small screws), and because my partner in crime is a former contractor, we happened to have a tiny screwdriver in the house. There is one more screw to undo on the inside. You then lift up the old lamp by the metal handle VERY slowly (or the glass will shatter). The lamp is plugged in at one side and can be hard to disengage gently, but we did our best and the lamp did not break on us. You then insert the new lamp (without touching the optics underneath), screw everything back in as directed, and once the projector is back on you reset the lamp hours from the menu display. The instructions talk about a "film" you replace with the lamp; we have no idea what they are talking about. The foil panel on the top of the lid? If so, a new one did not come with our replacement lamp, but the old one looked perfect so we left it as is.That's it; hopefully this helps some of you out. I wish I'd known more about the whole thing before I started, but if worse comes to worse you can always call ViewSonic and make them walk you through the process. They informed us they will be producing these replacement lamps (which fit a couple of models) for five more years. Then we're on our own.Hard to come up with a star rating, but the picture is bright and perfect, it was only the installation we found unpleasant. So four stars for now, and we will update if the lamp doesn't last the full 20,000+ hours. On projector is on 8 hours a day, so this should last a few years.GRADE: B

I wanted to compare this zester/grater to the best-selling Microplane 40020 Classic zester/grater, which I own and is slightly cheaper. Here's how they stack up:The OXO has a wide zesting/grating surface, which is great if you're zesting over a large bowl for a recipe but messy if you're trying to accent a dish. It also has no side-catch for shavings, like the Mircoplane. They both have stainless steel blades and zest citrus and chocolate with ease, and both can be put in the dishwasher. I do recommend the Microplane over the OXO because of the side walls that catch your shavings and smaller grating surface. But I use zest and shavings mostly as a garnish; if you are zesting large amounts of citrus for recipes you might want this product instead.OXO Zester Features:--PVC-free packaging and handle is BPA-free--Dishwasher safe (top rack)--Large handle easy on achy hands and wrists (a frequent feature of OXO products)GRADE: B

That's true, now more than ever. Since today you can alter and toy with photos in a dizzying amount of ways, maybe it's time to get a printer that can do more for your photography. Is this a good choice? Read on!SET UP/ASSEMBLY: Unlike some reviewers, I did not think set up was simple. It really depends on the kind of printers you have been used to--since I normally review office equipment the CANON PIXMA is the first printer especially designed for photos that I've owned (if you don't count my Epson printer, which is older but great with photo printing.). From the ink installation to the paper trays, a lot is different and it took me about 2 hours to complete the installation and registration (more on that in a minute). The LAN connection set-up had me running between the floors of my house to activate the access point on my modem so the printer and my computer could enjoy harmonious matrimony. No printer installation I've done has been so complicated, but they do walk you through it step by slow step, and if you can't get the LAN wireless connection up you do have the option to use a USB cable. Naturally, they don't provide one.APPEARANCE/USAGE: This is one pretty printer. Sitting next to my oafish HP Officejet Pro the CANON PIXMA is definitely a tearing beauty in comparison. The compartments are sleek and elegant, and the touchscreen gorgeous. Looks-wise, I've never seen a more fetching product. Great design, and well-made. Navigating between functions is easy and intuitive, and as a basic everyday product highly recommended, especially at the reasonable price. The printer comes with a tiny pack of 4"x 6" photo paper so be sure to have more on hand if you want to start on a project right away. The colors on my test projects were vibrant and all you could ask for outside a professional-grade unit.A quick list of considerations/perks/problems:--You will be forced to register the product if you want to use many of the online functions, like the Easy Photo Print+. Have your serial # (it's on the backside of the unit) and date of purchase ready.--After set-up you will be asked if CANON can track your every move for R&D purposes. I have not had a printer in the last four years from any brand that did not try to pull this, but at least HP offered me a bribe (or as they put it, a "prize". A mystery one!). CANON's legal-speak accompanying their request for data contained this gem: "The above information will be sent to Canon through the internet every month for ten years. The internet connection fee shall be borne by you." They're using my connection for their R&D? I think not.--If you use CANON ink, you get access to "Creative Park Premium", where you can print out origami or make cards for your relatives or stationary for Junior or whatever. I highly recommend looking through the available images; some are really strange. My personal favorite is the one with the flight attendant thanking the passenger for being in her life. Or maybe the passenger is thanking her. It's hard to tell.--No thumb drive insert; you have to use a memory card or USB cable if you need to physically load images onto the printer. Bummer.--Though marketed as "All-in-One", this printer does not include a fax. I know faxing is on it's way out the door, but I still sometimes have to send a fax, particularly when signed documents are requested. Some places won't take an emailed scan of a signed document, but will accept a fax. Happens to me a couple times a year.The long set-up and arrogant data request kinda rubbed me the wrong way, so I'm deducting 1/2 star for that. That leaves us at 4.5 stars, which I will be updating as I use more functions. This is a very good buy for a printer that does a LOT of things. Rounded up to five stars and rating:GRADE: B+

A great pair of headphones is like a gift, especially if you love music. This review will focus on the sound depth and quality of the Turtle Beach Stealth 500X Headset, particularly while listening to music or other audio. In my opinion, at this price a headset should be able to pull double duty.NOTE: According to Turtle Beach, this headset's wireless feature is ONLY compatible with the XBox One. I know that is obvious to many of you, but for those Amazon customers who do not frequently use gaming headsets or are looking for a gift for someone else, beware.You may have noted that the Sleath 500X Wireless headsets have polarized reviewers on Amazon. I do agree that they are overpriced by about 50%, but they have their good points. They are comfortable if a touch heavy for all-day use (I have been wearing them for hours at a time the last few days), they're sturdy, and not ugly (though not the coolest brand I've seen). Since other reviewers have focused on the Xbox One gaming experience, I'll talk a little about using the headsets for music or PC gaming, comparing them to a few other brands of headphones/headsets.My brother, who is autistic and a die-hard audiophile, is disdainful of Turtle Beach products; only once has he given one of their headsets a passing review (surprisingly, one of their cheapest models.). Still, he hasn't tried this wireless model and was a touch jealous when I told him I had one. His headphone brand of choice while gaming is Sennheiser, and if we're talking about listening to music tracks side by side with both brands even I can tell Sennheiser has superior sound quality. I tried out "What Are You Going to Do, Save the Whole World?" from the "Man of Steel" Soundtrack and "Flynn Lives" from the "TRON" soundtrack with first my Sennheiser headphones and the then Turtle Beach headset, and there is no comparison. The depth and richness of the former gave me chills, and the Stealth sounded tinny in contrast. Top-of-the line Sennheiser gaming sets run a bit more than the Stealth 500X, but the average customer review is currently higher. You might want to check it out, unless you are really big on the wireless feature. When it comes to straight music, the Turtle Beach 500X was barely better than my Tribeca headphones, and those are only around $50 a pair.A few other considerations/observations:--The mic turns itself off after a while if you don't speak into it; annoying. However, I loved how well you can hear yourself and the mic worked very well when I played an online game that requires me to both hear myself and be clearly recognized by the computer.--The Amazon page touts "Up to 15 hours" of use before a charge is needed, but Turtle Beach's own site states these phones last 10 hours before needing a charge.--I really hate it when the technical support on a product doesn't allow you to call the company. Bad sign. If you need help with these sets and go to the website, you will have to fill out a long form and submit it while waiting a full business day for an answer. It would take you 1/5 the time to just tell someone over the phone all the information they make you type out, but that would save your time, not theirs. I have deducted a half star just for the poor technical support set-up.All in all, not bad. No real big complaints; if the tech support was better designed and the sets were half the price, I would probably rate it five stars. As it is, for this price you might want to weigh other choices.GRADE: B

In the spirit of the founder of FedEx's quote, some information about this packing tape:--I tested this tape out side by side with Scotch brand Packing Tape. The first difference is country of manufacture: The Duck Brand Tape is made in Taiwan, Scotch brand is made in the U.S.A.--I can detect no difference between the quality of the two tapes, save one: The Duck Brand tape has a slight chemical smell up close. That's it. They performed exactly the same and appear to be equal in every way.--At current prices, the Duck brand will cost you about 11.5 cents a yard, and the Scotch tape 6 cents a yard. That's at current prices--the Scotch tape is sold at a hefty discount on Amazon. Normally the Scotch brand would be more expensive.That's it. A perfectly good, sturdy tape. Rated four stars because of the price and slight smell. Happy packing!GRADE: B

You may not need to change your shirt every day, but you definitely need to clean your teeth. This is the third Philips Sonicare Powerup I've owned and the fifth Sonicare product I've tried out. I absolutely love the Powerup; it's affordable, works excellently, and has very few drawbacks.I got my first Powerup a year ago and have yet to change the battery. The handles of these brushes do pick up stains (like makeup) easily, but I don't care much about that. Though the Powerup does rattle your head a bit, I found that by going down one degree in brush firmness (from my regular medium bristle to soft bristle) this effect is diminished somewhat. My Sonicare DiamondClean, which is more than twelve times the price of the Powerup, died on me after two years and has resisted all attempts at resurrection. Not cool. Plus, refills on the Powerup will cost you about $3.50 per brush head (as of right now), as opposed to $10-$12 each for the DiamondClean.The product comes with batteries (yay) in the package and is ready to go. Though you don't get a choice of speeds, a carrying case, a cup, or any other bells and whistles, I don't think you really need them. I recommend this model over much more expensive Sonicare products, and the replacement heads won't cost you a fortune either.GRADE: A

This is an odd movie. It's odd, and it's the kind of odd that seems to be purely unintentional. Ostensibly a bright, sunny update of the Cinderella fable, "Irene" has many famous, talented faces (Billie Burke, Arthur Treacher, Roland Young, and mama pajama Dorothy Dandridge, hanging out of a window sill) but doesn't give them anything to do, good source material and solid dialogue but an underdeveloped narrative, and ultimately a poor choice for the female lead that a great choice for the male one can't overcome.Anna Neagle is the titular Irene; decent, pretty, hard-working, sensible, and Irish as the Gaeilge. While measuring upholstery in a rich family's house she is spotted by Ray Milland, who takes an instant shine to her and helps her land a job at "Madame Lucy's", a hoity toity couture house that he has pull with. His pull turns out be that he IS Madame Lucy. There's a ball, lots of dancing, romantic mix-ups, an accident involving Irish stew, some banal singing, and LOTS of satin and lace before everything is resolved in a perfectly uninspired manner."Irene" was based on a long-running stage hit that featured no less than three huge stars in turn (Irene Dunne, Jeanette McDonald, and in a revival Debbie Reynolds), any one of which could have played the role better than Anna Neagle. Neagle was actually British, and a very big star in post-war Britain. She seems nice, but she can't really sing, she can't really dance, and worst of all she has no chemistry with Milland. He tries his best (and his best is pretty great), but without chemistry between the leads the romance has no steam and the story no traction. We have great actors assembled but the script doesn't give them any good characters to play (Dandridge gets about twenty seconds of screen time), there are no real laughs, and the plot is wafer-thin. All that can be said for the film is that the clothes are fun. And that's it.Harmless, not really boring, but a missed opportunity and not worth Warner Brothers' asking price. Recommended only for the most rabid of Milland fans, and rating:GRADE: B-While watching Neagle's solo "dance" sequence, my Dad kindly suggested that maybe her dancing was good for her "era". The era of Ginger Rogers, Vera Ellen and Ann Miller?No, it wasn't.

If you too want breakfast any time in a short time, you might want this toaster oven. This is the first toaster oven I've ever owned. In a house full of food allergies and diabetics, we just don't eat much processed or packaged food (or toast, for that matter). But having been warmly assured by my Aunt that once I tried a toaster oven I would never use my actual oven again or be happy with anything else, I decided it was time to give this appliance a whirl.SET UP/APPEARANCE: Ready to go right outside of the package. A nice-looking toaster oven, actually as nice-looking as ovens at much higher price points.INSTRUCTIONS: If somehow you have escaped knowing how to use a toaster oven and so have to actually read the instructions (like me), you have the option of perusing the quick start guide or the full manual (about two pages). I enjoyed the many warnings, such as not using the oven as a toy chest, not using it as a shelf, not using it outdoors, not using it to run your own restaurant, basically not using it in any way shape or form that could be considered creative. There are some contradictions in the manual about preheat times (they tell you to preheat the broiler for 10 minutes, then two lines later tell you to do it for 5), but mostly the instructions are straightforward and easy to understand. They do tell you not to cover any part of the oven with foil (which everyone told me to do to make clean-up easier) as this causes the oven to get too hot. Being a very rule-oriented person, I will follow Black and Decker's admonition, in this regard, anyway (see next item).USE: The timer is analog instead of digital, and you can only turn it up to 30 minutes max (though there is a "Leave On" setting for longer jobs--just don't forget it!) We tested a variety of projects, as detailed below:For toasting: While my test toast turned out terrific (ha!) it did take a LONG time in comparison with my regular toaster. This toaster oven could replace your toaster if you have counter space issues, but be advised it isn't fast. I would say you will need a little less than double your normal toasting time. For heating up frozen food: I cooked up a veggie patty, which un-thawed and warmed up in 10 minutes. I did not preheat, because, um, Black and Decker is not the boss of me. Actually it was because I didn't want to wait. My patty did not stick to the oven tray, which was awesome.For baking, in the sense of actual cooking: I whipped up some basic biscuits to see how the unit handles simple baking jobs. The toaster oven gets very hot to the touch (hence the warning about not using it as a shelf) and the 30 minute timer limit is a drawback, but my biscuits came out flaky and tasty, if a trifle late. I would say I needed an additional 20 minutes of baking time, probably due to heat leakage from the unit.Broiling: Best feature. Food was nicely browned and fast. As good as my oven, actually.Conclusion: A serviceable toaster for an extremely reasonable price. I am giving this 4 stars, with the biggest plus being the price point. It is not the best toaster oven out there. It takes longer to toast bread than a toaster and longer to bake biscuits than an oven. It gets very hot on the top and only has a 30 minute timer. But it is very affordable, attractive, and compact. So four stars for a toaster oven under $30, not for the entire toaster oven category. If you throw out the price considerations, I would give it 3.5 stars.So my Aunt was wrong; I won't be replacing my toaster or oven with this baby anytime soon. I'm not going to tell her though. Not a bad product, and useful in its way. For this price I don't think you could do much better, and so rating:GRADE: B+NOTE: Burning yourself is very easy to do with this oven, because the heating tray gets scorching hot. Play safe out there.

Buy this. If you love classic film, buy this DVD. That's the short of it. Here's the long of it: When you love old movies, there comes a time when you've watched and re-watched all the famous ones. After that, you embark on one long treasure hunt to uncover hidden gems. "After Office Hours" is a certified forgotten gem. Ignore the boring, generic title and be prepared for a film with top-notch one liners (screenplay by Herman J. Mankiewicz--how is this not a famous movie?), gorgeous people (Debate: Who is more beautiful, Clark Gable or Constance Bennett?) incredible clothes (RE: Bennett's silk dress in the night club scene. How DID they keep it from wrinkling?), an excellent, suspenseful plot, lots of beloved character actors (William Demarest as a cop, a flash of Margaret Dumont, and the delightful Billie Burke in a perfect, perfect role for her) but mostly, glorious fun from beginning to end.Clark Gable is a newspaper editor (naturally) and Bennett his new and well-connected music critic. He fires her over her high-brow taste, only to learn she is friends with a circle of people Gable has been trying to pin a scandal story on for months. He rethinks his choices, they spar (a lot), there's a murder, some suspense, gowns are worn, faces are slapped, Gable gets beat up, Gable beats up others, Billie Burke is adorable, Gable is sexy, and it all ends exactly as it should. My only complaint is that at 72 minutes "After Office Hours" is far too short, though as you can imagine at that length the pace is lightning.I am so happy I saw this and so happy it is available for burn-on demand (so many terrific films still are not) and so happy I can share it with Amazon readers. Is it worth the very high burn-on demand price? If you love Gable or Bennett, or Hollywood glamour in the 1930's, then yes. Very much worth buying at least used for any film fan and rating:GRADE: A(Favorite line in a movie brimming with good ones: Bennett orders Gable out of her car and tells him to walk home. "What, like a GIRL?" he asks incredulously.Fabulous.)

Berra's right, as usual. I'm going to kick off this review by addressing the issue that was of biggest concern to me when I got this DeLonghi Radiator: The offgassing when the heater is first used. Many other reviewers noted a strong smell from the unit when it is initially fired up; some reviewers complained of the smell never getting better. This is a huge issue to me as I have several people with fragile health in my house and certainly don't want to poison a family member with a defective heater. So did our unit offgass?Yes, for the first half hour or so, VERY strongly. We had to put the heater outside. The smell diminished rapidly after that first 30 minutes, and after the first day or so the scent was and is only detectable if you lean up right next to the radiator when it is going full blast. It's kind of a burnt metal smell. I find this acceptable, and so am recommending the product, with slight reservations. If you are very chemically sensitive, you may want to keep looking.Other than this issue, a very good heater. We are using it to warm up a kitchen/living room area, and I am very pleased with the results. The unit is super easy to use and understand (with one exception, noted below), the controls mostly intuitive and the manual simple. I love the antifreeze setting, which you can use if you have a small living space, are traveling, and are worried about your pipes freezing. The highest setting got our desired space nice and toasty, without me having to heat up both floors of our house.The exception to the radiator's simplicity is the "timer", which is bizarre and unlike anything else I've ever used. It involves setting red knobs in 15-minute increments using what for all the world appears to be military-time. A digital timer would have been too much trouble, apparently. One star total deducted for the weird timer and the initial strong smell as you're breaking your radiator in.Other than that, recommended. For $18 you can buy an extended warranty to protect your unit beyond the manufacturer's two-year limit. Doesn't really seem worth it me, as shipping this thing would cost you a bundle. The Delonghi is a reasonable price and we're happy with it, and so rates:GRADE: B

This ultra comfy, plush, cushy and squishy bath mat is SO much better than I expected for the modest price. I love it. The color on the web page is true; a very vanilla coffee-cream shade. The weave is soft and and it's a little addictive to squish it between your hands.What can you say about a bath mat, when it's a perfect bath mat? If the size works for you, snap it up. I will post as we run it through the washer (probably twice a month) and let you know if we experience quality issues. But for now, a lovely, affordable mat and rating:GRADE: A

I guess it's subjective, since I noticed several reviewers don't like the texture or feel of the popcorn bath mat. But I found it so thick and nice and the texture is so comfortable underfoot -- like a foot massage -- I decided to use it as a bedside rug instead of in the bath. And the one I got looks well made to me. I noticed no fraying or loose edges. And I love that it's 100 percent cotton.

This little guy is amazing.  It's a capable and accurate thermal imager, as well as a decent flashlight.  My primary interest was to see if it would be good with diagnostics.  You can check the wiring in your home to see if there are any hotspots, or find out if your climate control system has any major areas that it's leaking.  One of these units could potentially save you thousands in the long run if you use it properly.But I found the most important reason to have one: It's really fun :DIt's a sleek device - it's light, small and comfortable in the hand.  The buttons are rubberized and easy to activate, and the menu, although clunkier than a touchscreen smartphone, is intuitive and simple to navigate.  The dust cover over the USB port and MicroSD is a nice touch.  If I do have a complaint, it's that the MicroSD card is very difficult to remove without tweezers.  When you depress it a spring pops it out but not far enough to clear the edge of the channel, and the plastic wall is only about 1mm away from the card making it hard to grasp with a fingernail.  Not something that bothers me for my purposes, as I don't intend to take many snapshots with it.Not sure of it's effective range, but I've pointed it out in the back yard at night and seen a whole host of critters (mostly kitty cats) running around out there from at least 30 feet away.  It's sensitive enough to pick up foot prints on our tile floors (barefoot) up to a few minutes after you walk there.  The different modes make it easier to see heat signatures in different conditions.  There's a Black and White setting that almost works like night vision - you can make out the shapes of objects in the dark from quite far away just by the different surface temperatures - pretty cool.I think my most practical use now will be for travel.  I travel a ton and I'll have this in my EDC backpack for when I'm in strange cities alone.  You can scan dark areas before entering into them, also you can use it to identify if there is anything nearby you need to run from if you are camping and you hear something rustling outside your tent.  This is also where the flashlight comes in handy.  If something looks suspicious on cam you can light it up to verify.  Or you can choose to not do that and avoid giving away your position if you want to avoid potential trouble.It's functional, sleek and SUPER cool.  Get one.  5 stars.

Vibrant, cheerful color, large, nice woven texture, and they lay flat. They're 70 percent PVC and 30 percent polyester, so they wipe clean easily.And they can be trimmed with scissors and won't fray or unravel. We rounded the corners on ours and they stayed together just fine.

This toaster has a great retro style and color, and works really well too. I noticed other reviewers have reported that it is slow due to having ceramic heating elements instead of wire, but the one we received toasts just as fast as a conventional toaster.I was a little confused that you can't just lift the side lever to stop toasting. But all you need do is press the "cancel" button in the middle of the light/dark dial on the front. I was also puzzled that there were three buttons on the front -- "defrost," "reheat," and "bagel" -- but no "toast" button. Turns out it toasts by default. Just set the shade you want and push the lever down and away it goes.The instruction book has a series of pictures of shades of toast along the number settings. It's pretty accurate. Our first try resulted in a very close match in shade. The window really comes in handy for getting toast just the way you like it.The red outer shell is plastic, not metal, in case you're wondering. It wipes clean easily. It has a slide-out crumb tray, and the window is removable for washing. So it can be kept sparkling.It's a little large because it's end-to-end instead of side-by-side.

This phone takes a little tweaking, but for the market price this thing is really awesome.  Here are the features I really liked:  Long Battery Life  Dual Sim Cards  awesome for travelers or if you live or work somewhere rural with little service  MicroSD slot  getting rarer these days  Sleek and Snappy response  Camera Flash and Front Facing cam (rare in phones in this price range)  Android 4.4.4  though not the latest, it is still an awesome OSThings I didn't care for:  Any application that starts with Acer  Its not upgradeable to Lollipop (5.0) without custom ROM (not many available)  Screen resolution is limited  though not bad for a budget phone  The Acer launcher is a total piece of junkThe reason I give this little communicator 5 stars is because with a little tweaking, this phone is absolutely stellar.  The first thing I did was replace the launcher with Nova Prime, hid all of the factory Acer apps in a folder in the drawer, and changed all of the default apps to Googles System Apps or ones that I prefer.  Then I disabled the Acer Widgets on the lock screen and got rid of the cheesy animations.  Then I added a bunch of games with unicorns and candy and stuff and I gave it to my Mom, who absolutely loves it (after I taught her how to use it :P).  It runs really well as long as you get rid of everything you dont need.For this price range, I highly recommend this as an entry level phone or for someone who only uses it on occasionally to send me a text of a funny cat video or emails me to come fix her computer or gossip about my Aunts.  Get one today.

I'm using this controller to play Steam games  its wired and came with a 10 ft USB cable so that made it an easy decision.  I dont have a use for most of the functions, even though its incredibly capable and I gave all of them a test drive.The learning curve for using the features is a little steep at first, but I got used to programming it pretty quickly.  First off the customizable prismatic pipe color is really awesome.  It will lock to basically any neon color in the spectrum, so I was able to make it match my shoes, desktop, or whatever gaming interface I was using at the time.  You can also map the multiwheels under the controller to different functions, which I found convenient in more complex RPGs.  You can also customize the rumble feature and the led lights on the inside of the controller.The software works independently of the XBOX ONE, so I was able to manipulate the functions of it as long as it was plugged in.The aesthetics of this thing are really great  as far as the function goes its stellar, as well.  The triggers feel a little springier and cheaper than the standard XBOX ONE controllers, but I got used to them pretty quickly.  Once this thing is plugged in it looks really radical, and I wasn't having any troubles with lag  all the buttons and the analog sticks are super responsive and swift.I like this controller a lot  Ill definitely be hanging on to it for my PC gaming.

Good for the price. They don't enclose your ears, they rest on them. They're certainly not noise canceling. Sound quality is okay, a bit strong in the mid range, perhaps a tiny bit muddy, but clear enough. Don't expect overly impressive bass response and you won't be disappointed.They fold up compactly, a nice plus, and so is the in-line volume control. A nice alternative to ear buds when you want to listen to something without being too particular about audiophile quality full range sound reproduction.

I really like this case.  I've been carrying on my Galaxy S6 since I got it.  The only time I take it off is to put the phone in an extended battery case on days when I'm going to be away from home for awhile.The fit is excellent.  Instead of a 2 piece like the Defender or Commuter OtterBoxes, this is a single piece, slip on case.  It quickly accommodates the phone and grips it snugly.  The buttons are covered by a dense rubber, but still quite functional.  The headphone, power port and speaker are each recessed deeply by the case, but any standard headphone or power plug should fit it fine because the holes are flared quite wide to accommodate your accessories.  I don't have a dock, but I imagine fitting into one could be difficult.  There are no dust or moisture covers for the ports.The form is fantastic.  This case looks super stylish.  I have the blue one with clear backing, and with a deep blue galaxy (space blue or whatever it's called) it looks great.  It's kind of like a Tron theme.  I imagine it would look awesome on the white model, as well.The function is absolutely brilliant.  The case holds the phone very snugly.  I have a range of cases and this is the one that I feel gives the best shock protection.  It also has the most effective screen recession.  I like this case a lot.There is one major drawback and it's specific to the ROYAL CRYSTAL model.  The plastic on the outside is super durable, but on the INSIDE not so much.  I put the phone in by the base and it was about an inch high so I slid it down to the bottom and it SCRATCHED the entire bottom inch of the inside of the case (the flat clear plastic part).  The glass edge on the bottom of my S6 was too much for this thing.  It's now super scuffed, and I couldn't believe how little force it took.  I did the same thing again with the corner of the phone in the already scratched area - I only used the weight of the phone and dragged it along the surface about a quarter of an inch - and it left a DEEP gouge in the plastic.That being said, I think it's an oversight and not enough to kill my review.  I still love the case and I'll be looking to get one that's not crystal.
Nicely made, not too thick or heavy. Just right for cool but not cold weather or rooms. It works well as a middle layer.The men's small size is equivalent to a women's medium.

It's really cute, and big (compared to a Dachshund, on which Slinky Dog is modeled). And it's plush and huggable. Even the "slinky" part -- a plastic spring -- is covered in soft fabric. The return springiness is provided by an elastic cord in the middle of the spring. It doesn't have sound or lights or animation or anything like that in case you were wondering. No batteries needed.I'm deducting a star because the actual Slinky Dog we received doesn't look as happy as the one in the photos. The corners of its mouth don't turn up. It looks happy from the front when it's posed on its haunches and its head is up. But when it's in a standing position its head kind of hangs down, and it looks toward the floor with a rather forlorn-looking expression.Otherwise, hey, it's Slinky Dog from Toy Story and it is cute.

I'm using mine for a workstation and it is performing like a champ for my purposes. I did try out FSX Steam version and got pretty good performance with scenery set on a medium level. It seemed to strain a little and did some blinking at higher settings.But for workstation use it's doing a fine job. It's quiet and hasn't overheated once so far.

Nice way to convert most any lamp into a night light. It produces a warm, soft glow. I was thinking the bulb is so low in wattage that it will last a long time, but several other reviewers are saying theirs burned out quickly. So far mine's holding up well, even surviving a couple of thunderstorms and power surges.

Lightweight material but they do the job. Mounting is pretty easy. Pre-drilling holes (smaller than the screws) is always a good idea. That minimizes splitting the wood trim and makes driving the screws easier. Keep in mind these wouldn't be the best choice for heavy material like blackout curtains, but work fine for sheers and light fabrics.

I made a pedestal for my mount out of 2 X 4 stock ripped to 3 inches wide. See the photo. The height of the pedestal is 20 inches. It's just right for working from a comfortable chair. I assembled it with carpenter glue and drywall screws and gave it a coat of polyurethane varnish. I used some beefy sheet metal screws to attach the mount to the pedestal. It works great.

Great fragrance, goes on smoothly, no orange "fake and bake" look, and I love that you can build up to the tone you want over several days instead of going too far with one application. The color develops slowly, so some patience is required. In other words, no need to reapply if you're not seeing color in minutes. Wait a day then reapply if desired.As other reviewers pointed out, gloves are a good idea so you don't accidentally tan your palms. And do extra rubbing to make sure it's evenly applied, and not too heavy on the knees and elbows.Great natural looking results.

Strong masculine fragrance that smells even better once it's on -- and not quite as strong, which is a good thing. The citrus and cedar and spice aromas are forefront, with leather following. I couldn't detect the advertised tobacco notes.From the description I expected a bit more of a barbershop fragrance, but it's more library in tone. Still very masculine though.As a shower gel, it performs well, doesn't over-lather and leaves a clean feeling. And it leaves your bathroom smelling great.

Some retinol-containing products are just too strong and cause a rash or irritation, but this product is mild enough for me to use.You pour the contents of one of the bottles over a stack of pads in a jar. Then wipe your face with a pad in the evening, and leave the product on overnight. I saw nice results -- smoother skin -- within just a few days. A set of "charged" pads should be used up within 30 days. There's a 90-day supply (three bottles of product and 90 pads) in this kit.I'm not sure all the additional botanical extracts (cucumber, chamomile, green tea, aloe) contribute anything but a little sizzle to the steak. And some people are sensitive to them. Also, retinol products increase sun sensitivity, so sunscreen or other protection from sun is recommended while using them.Note that this is being marketed as a cosmetic to improve skin appearance (minimize pores, smooth imperfections, etc.). As to the price point and whether it's worth it -- over 60 dollars for a 90-day supply -- well that's just going to be something for individuals to decide for themselves. I'm not sure I'll be reordering since the results are nice, but maybe not sixty-dollar nice.

I normally wire my pedal board with George L's. I was skeptical about this D'Addario cable set until I opened the package and saw and felt the quality.First of all, the cable is thicker -- heavier gauge -- than George Ls. The right-angle plugs are robust and secure.A cool feature of this set -- it includes a wire cutter that works very well if you line it up properly. The cutter is part of my tool kit now in case I need to repair or make a cable. A screwdriver is also included -- everything you need to patch your board is in the set.To assemble a cable, you just back the plug's locking screw out, and insert the straight-cut cable with a twisting motion. You'll feel it lock in place. You then tighten the screw down and the connection is made, and it is secure.There are enough plugs in the kit for five patch cables. And a generous amount of cable. Even after wiring my 26" x 12" pedal board, I had 4 feet of cable left over -- plenty left to make more.The sound quality is fantastic -- comparable to George Ls. I twisted them around to listen for shorts or noise, and everything stayed clean. And since they're a little easier to assemble than George Ls, and a bit beefier, I might just stick with these.

I prefer black teas with no milk or sugar, so I like very high quality, since nothing masks the flavor.I could taste the quality on first sip.I'd describe it as full bodied yet mild, soothing floral notes -- barely, if at all bitter, and only subtly astringent. Very nice mouth feel. Aromatic, but not overly so.Good black tea in every sense of the word!

Very well made case. Nice, even stitching around the leatherette pocket, fits the S6 like a second skin. It's a slightly slimmer profile than an Otterbox case I also own for my S6. It's not quite as much protection as the Otterbox, but still feels very secure.The credit card pouch is a little tight with three cards in it, but I'm thinking it will loosen up a bit over time. In theory, according to the manufacturer, the pouch will also hold cash in addition to three cards, but only a tightly folded single bill. In theory. If you do it, you're going to be squeezing a booger out of Alexander Hamilton's nose.It is ingenious design to utilize a card in the case slot as a stand. This helps keep the profile very slim.Despite the slim profile, the bezel around the camera is deep enough to protect the lens. The case bezel around the screen on the front is deep enough to keep the screen recessed for protection. The ports don't have a cover like an Otterbox, but it does make them easier to access.It's great to have a lightweight efficient case so I don't have to carry a wallet full of cards for short trips out.For slimness and convenience, I'm gonna give it five stars.

I'm impressed. My son bought the twin sized one from Amazon and I had the pleasure of assembling it. And it really was a bit of fun putting it together because its well designed and went together easily. I had it assembled in about 15 minutes.Here are a few points that impressed me:-- Everything is included, including the hex key (Allen wrench) to tighten the bolts. No need to dig out any tools.-- The side frames simply unfold and are locked in place by a brace and pre-installed wingnut. Almost as easy as a camping cot.-- There's no "wrong" way to put in the three rectangular cross members. The holes are equally spaced and they are completely reversible and invertible.-- All the metal "slats" just press into place with a little body weight.-- All the metal-to-metal contact points are cushioned with plastic caps -- no squeaking or scraping.-- The head and foot slats are pre-drilled with holes so you can attach a headboard and foot board if you choose. (Maybe one of your own making. Fun!)-- The legs are capped to prevent floor scratches.-- It's surprisingly light. The twin size in the box was only a little over 25 pounds.-- In spite of that light weight, when assembled, it's VERY sturdy and rigid.-- It can be unassembled just as easily, making it a great stowaway bed frame. If completely unassembled, it takes up little space. The box it comes in measures about 15 by 40 inches and only 2 and a half inches thick. Easily stood in a closet (along with many more, if you choose.)It's fun to work with a product that is well thought out and well made. And at a very nice price point too.

I don't have a nail fungus to try this out on. So I tried it on a spot of scalp fungus, and got good results. I applied it only once a day instead of twice, since the scalp is a lot less tough than a nail.(This is an off-label use of the product, so keep that in mind if you decide to try it.)I've gotten good results using unrefined coconut oil in the past, but straight coconut oil is, well, oily, and stays oily. Coconut oil's lauric acid content is rather dilute, and it works slowly. And of course it smells coconutty. Not complaining, but there may be times you don't want oily coconut-smelling hair. This product isn't as oily and has no fragrance. And, although I didn't count the days until I got results, it seems to work faster.I also like that there isn't a single sulfite or sulfate compound in the list of ingredients.If you try this for a similar use, instead of using the bottle's dropper, dabbing it on with a Q-Tip will help put it where you want it and keep it from running and dripping.

I'm a "model 77" worm-drive fan, but I have a feeling I'll be reaching for this sidewinder a LOT.This Skilsaw is a "righty," meaning the blade is on the right of the motor and is positioned toward the right side of the plate foot. So most of the plate's width is to the left of the blade, supporting most of the saw's weight.For a right-handed carpenter, there are advantages to having the foot plate and the weight of the saw to the left of the blade. The saw is supported on the stock material instead of the "drop" material (the piece that will fall as you make the cut).With the lefty saws, only about an inch of the plate is on the stock material. As you near the end of the cut and the drop starts falling away, you're forced to keep the saw square with your wrist -- sometimes a 14-pound saw -- and that can result in inaccuracy in squareness. But your cut is true to the line because you can see the line easily for the whole length. (Credit where credit is due: Experienced, skilled carpenters can hold a very accurate square cut with a lefty worm drive saw.)Because of the stable support on the stock material for the whole length of the cut, you easily get dead square cuts with a righty saw when cutting studs and such.A disadvantage of a "righty" is the cutting line is difficult to see -- you have to look over the motor and through an opening in the foot plate. When cutting panel or sheet goods, the farther out you reach as you cut, the less you can see.This Skilsaw allows for that with a very large opening in the foot to view the blade. However it still goes out of view as you reach forward with a long cut on sheet goods. For those situations, some sort of saw guide is practically a must.Speaking of the plate foot, this saw has the largest foot of all the circular saws I own -- it's roughly 6.5" X 11.5". It's practically an inverted table. LOTS of support for stability in cutting. And it's cast magnesium, like the worm drive 1677M, instead of stamped metal. Which is great -- no warping or bending. I have a feeling a stamped metal foot that large would be bent within a week of use.Because all that surface supports a combination square or speed square very nicely, it's easy to adjust the blade into squareness. Skil does not include a hex key (Allen wrench) for this. I used a 2.5mm size. It only took a quarter turn of the adjustment screw to bring it square.After getting that square, I set the foot angle to the 45-degree stop and checked it, found it about a half degree shy -- close enough for most uses. The stop is a spring tab that can be pushed out of the way to increase the foot angle to over 50 degrees. It's not recommended due to increased chances of blade binding, but that extra angle is there for the rare occasion you might need it.Max cutting depth is 2.5 inches, but at that setting the motor housing will not clear the flange of a speed square. So if you're using a speed square for true cuts, max depth is going to be just a bit over two inches.It's VERY well built. I haven't done a tear down (and don't plan to), but it looks and feels about as well built as my Bosch 1677M. Skil is wholly owned by Bosch (and that's why it's cool that Bosch makes "model 77" worm drive saws -- since they own the company that invented it). And though Skil has become thought of as more of the consumer line to Bosch's pro line (as Black and Decker is the consumer line to the DeWalt pro line), this saw has the quality and feel of a Bosch-branded saw, or a top-shelf Skilsaw from back in the day.I'm not quite sure what they mean by "worm drive technology" in what is obviously a direct-drive sidewinder, there being no gearbox or oil reservoir. It appears that it's a reference to the power and design of the drive motor. The manual warns about startup torque, but it's nothing like the twisting torque of a worm drive. It's just a brief little lift of the back end. It's downright stable.It doesn't seem to be as muscular as the worm drive 1677M, but it's still powerful. Knots and sapwood aren't going to challenge it at all.For its size and power, it's light. That's excellent. Here's a weight and feature comparison of the circular saws I own, mainly to show how this Skilsaw compares in weight:-- Bosch 1677M. Cast magnesium plate foot, narrow. Worm drive lefty. 14 pounds.-- Skilsaw 534 consumer light duty sidewinder righty. Vintage saw, 6.5" blade, reminds me of a retro diner milkshake mixer. Stamped metal plate foot. 9 pounds.-- DeWalt DW939 18V cordless, sidewinder lefty, 6.5" blade. Not much power. Very occasional use. 8.25 pounds with battery.This Skilsaw, with by far the widest plate foot, cast magnesium, sidewinder righty, 10.25 pounds.Despite it being a powerful and solidly built saw, it's closer in weight to the light saws than the heavyweight 1677M worm drive.The on-board blade-changing wrench storage is a nifty feature.And it comes with a couple of nifty Skilsaw brand logo stickers.At this price point this thing is a winner all the way. And if one were to choose to head to a site with only one saw, or to have only one saw in the shed, this could well be the one to choose.

Nice curtains, great price. They're definitely blackout curtains The fabric is nice but just a bit limp -- the ungrommeted version with fabric back loops sags a little bit between the loops instead of standing up like the photo shows. But that's a minor quibble. They still look very nice.I found them a bit of a challenge to alter. I shortened them from 63 inches (they actually measured 62 inches) to 48 inches. I found that the reason they are such effective blackout curtains is there is a layer of black fabric sandwiched within them. Those layers make it difficult to iron a crease for a hem -- it kept springing back. The curtains are labeled 100 percent polyester, but I found I had to set my iron on the wool setting to get the fabric to behave. (If you try this, make sure you stay alert for scorching or melting.) The fabric is very stretchy too, so I found that a few puckers were unavoidable when sewing the new hem. Fortunately they're all on the window side and don't show.All that said, it's a great price for nice looking thermal blackout curtains.

Let me point out that the "Indian Summer check" pattern is an autumn palette of colors, not a summer palette. It seems obvious in retrospect, given that Indian Summer is an autumn event, not a summer one. But for some reason I saw the word "summer" and expected summer colors.That said, the colors of the Indian Summer palette check napkins are beautiful -- rich and vivid autumn hues. The material is a nice weight -- not too thin. And there are other uses for these. I know because a crafting person I know got a look at them and confiscated them to make purses with. She plans to give them a good spray of fabric protectant and craft away.At 20 inches square (or 18 after washing) they're a good bandana size too. And might even look better for that purpose after a few washes.Since they are cotton and so richly dyed, if I were to wash them (I'm not going to have a chance to, since they're going to craft use), I would put a cup of vinegar in the wash to help lock the colors in, and of course touch them up with an iron after drying.

This stuff is really sticky and gooey, but it dries glossy and white. The trick in applying it is to run a very small bead. Then you "tool" it with a finger. If you run too thick a bead, it accumulates as you run your finger along, and you're bulldozing a big lump of it and it spreads too wide, and cleaning that up is a chore. (I use rubbing alcohol to do that.)Speaking of chore, removing old caulk is where the real work is. I use WD-40 and Dawn detergent together and let it soak few hours to soften it up a bit. Sometimes it works, sometimes not so much. Whether it softens a lot or not, I then remove it with an old wood chisel and paint scraper (one that uses single edge razor blades.) I take care to cut and slice the caulk out, not gouge the tile or tub. I follow with a good cleaning with detergent to remove the oil and old soap accumulation before re-caulking.Fresh, bright, glossy, non-mildewing caulk like this will really brighten an older bath. And it is practically odorless, just as described.

First thing I noticed on unboxing this projector is it's SMALL. Very portable. It's about the size of a slice of bread and an inch thick. It fits in a jacket or jeans pocket. Our kitchen scale says it weighs just over 10 ounces.My first concern was that 100 lumens is bright for a flashlight, but not so much for a projector. A home theater projector requires 1200 or more lumens for a nice bright picture. I looked forward to trying it out.It has wifi, and has a built-in Android operating system (v 2.3.1, according to the manufacturer website.) It has a touchpad on top, along with a focus wheel. No optical zoom wheel or adjustment.(Just to clear up any potential confusion, let me point out that this is a full color projector. The listing title says "black/white," but that's just the color of the projector itself.)There's an SD/MMC card slot in back, along with mini-USB and mini-HDMI ports for connecting to a computer, and a headphone/audio out jack. There are laptop-size speakers built into the sides. On one side is an 1/8" A/V in (in case you want to hook a game console, video camera or separate media player to it), the other has a standard USB port for dongles or thumb drives (so you can play videos or other media from them or cards in the SD/MMC slot. In other words, you don't have to carry a tablet or computer to play media, just an SD card or USB drive with your movies on it.In addition to media, it also has viewing support for .pdf, .ppt/pptx, .xls/xlsx, and .doc/docx formats.What's in the box:The projector (of course.)An HDMI-to-mini-HDMI cable. The big end goes to your computer's HDMI port, the little end goes to the projector. If you have an HDMI port, this will give the best resolution.A USB-to-mini-USB cable. Same deal -- big end to computer, little end to the projector. Use this to move files to the projector and upgrade software.Quick start guide and manual (in several language versions). These docs are TINY, with TINY text, difficult to read as a result, and I could find no downloadable PDF versions online. Not even on the XSories web site. (I assume that brand name is pronounced "X-S-ories.")AC adapter/charger (12v, 2A) with three different snap-in, easily interchangeable plugs for US, UK, and EUR use.A soft case. The AC adapter was packed in it, but it's obviously for the projector.What's NOT in the box (but available for purchase separately as accessories):A 5-way splitter component cable for connecting to component systems.A 3-way A/V splitter cable for connecting to game consoles, video cameras or other media players.An antenna for digital TV.An iPhone/iPad connector cable.A sound station for audio boosting.An MHL to HDMI cable.A VGA cable.I plugged it in for a charge. I noticed the LED adapter/charge indicator is not very bright. That's GOOD. Shows some thought went into this device. You don't want a too-bright LED competing with your projected image.After charging the recommended 3 hours, the LED switched from red to green, and I was ready to try it out.If you want something this portable and convenient, chances are you're not going to be lugging a screen around. That's okay, because there are plenty of things that can be used as makeshift screens, such as walls or poster board or sheets or foam core or large sheets of paper or the side of a tent (or the ceiling, which is awesome for watching while kicked back in a recliner or sofa or such). Or for a better image quality you could buy some projector screen material and just roll it up and take it along and tack or tape it up when needed. A dry-erase whiteboard makes an excellent screen for this projector. That's what I used for most of my testing, along with a wall and a ceiling.After booting (which takes about 30 seconds) and focusing the projected image, I navigated to the Android OS and activated wifi. In about a minute I was online.The Android OS is limited. And appears dated. I tried to browse YouTube and got repeated security certificate warnings, so I disabled the warnings in the Android settings panel. Scrolling is done by sliding a finger along the side and bottom of the touchpad. There are no buttons -- you tap the touchpad to click. There are spots on the top for "home," "back," and, I assume, "settings." It's not really easy to navigate.I went back to YouTube and successfully played a video, but navigating around YouTube was frustrating. The browser wasn't smooth, and the scrolling and such was kind of clunky. I'm not sure online viewing with the built in OS is a strong point with this projector.Speaking of which, if there's an easy way to install an Amazon or Netflix app (which don't come pre-installed) on this device, I couldn't find it. I suspect it takes one of those complicated procedures like with a rooted device -- using the USB cable and connecting to a computer and flashing ROMs and and such.I tested playing .mp4 vids and viewing .jpg photos from an SD card, and it readily found and played both. Photos are launched in a slideshow by default, and transitions and view times and such are adjustable in settings. Likewise, it easily found and played .mp4s from a USB stick.Adjusting things like contrast, brightness, color, volume, and such is a bit of an annoying process. Some are done from the native menu. Other adjustments and setup (such as for wifi) are done within the Android settings menu. And it's not really easy to get things done with the touchpad. There are some pop-up adjustment sliders that will appear if you slide a finger along the right edge of the pad while playing media, but they're still a bit difficult to get used to adjusting.It gets really warm while operating, and there is some fan noise, but it's relatively quiet. Battery life seems to be as advertised, about 2 hours on a charge, but leaving Wifi on will probably shorten that. If a movie runs over 90 minutes, you're probably better off using the adapter.The built-in sound is about what you'd expect from a couple of tiny laptop speakers. You'll want to use headphones or run the audio through a system if you want better quality.There's no optical zoom. The picture size can only be adjusted by moving the projector. Brightness diminishes considerably with distance and picture size. I'd say 12 to 14 feet is about its max effective distance, and at that distance the image is a little larger than 6 feet across. In total darkness you may be able to go a little larger with it.There is no keystone adjustment either. If you want to avoid the trapezoid, the projector will have to be positioned square to the screen.The projection lens isn't very wide angle. The distance-to-picture-size (or MTS or meter-to-screen) ratio is kind of small. When the projector is at optimum distance for brightness -- about four or five feet from the screen -- the picture doesn't look much bigger than a regular laptop monitor. Which sort of defeats the purpose of having a projector in the first place. You could just turn your laptop around and show it to the group.And to go much larger, you're going to need a very dark room and some distance. It's not going to be useful for the typical boardroom or conference room.About picture quality: I tried it as a display/monitor with two different laptops using the HDMI cable, and spent some time tweaking settings to get the most I could get out of it, and got similar results. It's not HD. It's a tad globby, whether operating on wifi, HDMI, or watching a movie from an SD card or USB drive. Considering the size of the projector I guess it's a bit much to expect genuine hi-res 1080p.So those are the two negative things -- picture size and picture quality. Kind of important for a projector. But it's a trade off for the super portability.To summarize, this isn't a productivity or business item. It's a fun item.
