It will do for movies and images, but used as a computer display/monitor, screen fonts are not clear and crisp, and it is sure to be tiring if one is using it for number crunching or word processing for any length of time. It may be useful for the occasional location presentation to a very small group in a very dark room. But I'd say this one's for movies and pictures or gaming that isn't HD dependent. Even then, don't expect wall-sized projection and super brightness. I'm guessing it will be about half the size and brightness you might expect.I'm giving it four stars because of the coolness and wow factor -- the smallness and portability -- but with reservations. Since battery life is only two hours, you're going to probably be carrying the adapter with it. And at this price point, I'm not sure what the advantages are except for the exceptionally small size. For less money you can get a 1200-lumen HD projector with many features this projector lacks. So whether this projector appeals to you is going to depend on your intended use and situation. Who knows -- maybe you're looking for a little projector to connect to your computer to watch Amazon Prime or Netflix on the ceiling, or one you can toss in a bag or backpack with some SD cards and take with you on trips. If so, it may be just what you're looking for.

The bulbs in the photo in the listing are a little different from what's in the package. The bulb has a standard base for common light and lamp sockets, but the bulb part is smaller than what appears in the photo -- it's not much bigger than a golf ball. But it still puts out a lot of light. And even though it has a skirt like most LED bulbs, it sits so low in a lamp base that it casts light around about as well as an incandescent or CFL bulb. Meaning no "skirt shadow" on the lamp shade or globe.The light color is just a bit to the warm side of white. Not too yellowish, and not a trace of annoying blue tint. They're pretty close to incandescent light in color.The brightness is a bit surprising. Though they're supposed to be equivalent to a 25-watt incandescent bulb, they look closer to a 40-watt bulb in brightness to me. And all that while drawing less than 5 watts of electricity. And they're rated for over 30,000 hours of use. In spite of the up front cost of over $6.00 USD per bulb (which is a lot lower than LED bulbs used to cost), they will save money in the long run.Do note in the listing that these are not dimmable bulbs. They probably wouldn't play well in a circuit with a wireless remote switch either. I had an LED bulb go out in such a circuit once. These are best used in lamps or circuits with simple straightforward on-off switches.

I ordered three of these -- two of the 18-inch  and one of the 12-inch sizes. All three were slightly twisted. The mounting plates weren't square and aligned evenly and parallel with each other.The problem with the mounting plates not being even and square is the temptation to screw them down hard until they sit flat on the wall. That introduces a lot of spring tension that can result in the screws popping out, or not being able to get them driven in in the first place.This appears to have been a manufacturing flaw, not something that occurred in transit. I say that because the square bars appear to be tempered -- straightening them required a lot of force. I clamped them to a heavy sawhorse and, wearing work gloves, muscled them back to as straight an alignment as I could. I didn't get them completely straight, but I did manage to get them a lot straighter than they arrived.Speaking of screws, the ones included are a little short for a sturdy installation, in my opinion. And wall anchors are not included. The screws heads do show after installing.I'm still giving them three stars -- the "it's okay" rating -- because they look okay, and would work in contemporary or retro decor. And they're quite a bargain compared to buying actual vintage retro chrome towel bars. Just be prepared to have to straighten them before installing.

Serviceable bits for occasional use in softwoods. They're obviously not top grade, but they work. I guess I got a good batch. All were straight and sharp.When drilling, I withdraw the bit frequently to clear chips and prevent overheating. It makes drilling go faster, and, I'm thinking, might extend the life of the bits.If like me you only occasionally need a long bit to drill holes in softwoods, then these might be just for you. Better than spending big money for bits you only occasionally use.

I think the picture is a bit misleading. These are sheer. You can not only easily see through them, you can literally read through them. I easily read the fabric care label on the back of them right through the cloth. Even gathered on a curtain rod they're still quite sheer.On the positive side, they are colorful, cheerful, and let a lot of light through. However, they are strictly for decoration, not privacy, and not for light blocking.

Sharpening tools is an arcane art I never thought I could master. Thanks to instructional videos like those by Paul Sellers (do a search for "sharpen a chisel" and you'll find one) I found I could not only do it myself, I could attain the legendary "scary sharp" edge. I mean actually scary sharp. I've gotten near mirror-finish edges so sharp that just checking an edge for sharpness with a light touch with my thumb resulted in small shallow cuts. And that without a final leather buffing.It's a great skill to have. Sharp tools are a pleasure to work with. And if you accidentally drop a tool or dull a blade somehow or over time with regular use, you can bring it back to sharpness yourself.And plate glass with wet-dry sandpaper is the most cost-efficient and simple way to get it done. No need to spend upwards of a hundred dollars or more on exotic stones or diamond-imbedded plates. Just glue some wet-dry sandpaper to a dead-flat piece of glass and you're in business.I had success my first try. I borrowed a plate glass top from a patio furniture table and used some spray glue to fasten the sandpaper to it. As I recall, I used pieces of 400/800/1500/2000 grit. I used soapy water in a spray bottle to wet the paper (just a few drops of dish soap per bottle of water). Then I used the techniques I learned from the Sellers video. Even without the benefit of a bevel edge guide, within an hour, several cheap chisels from my tool box had hundred-dollar edges and performance.Unfortunately the glass had to be returned to the patio table. And the spray glue wasn't holding reliably and was a bit of a bother. And I felt I could get more repeatable results with a bevel edge guide. So I ordered this kit, along with a set of coarse replacement paper to go with the fine grades of paper that come with the kit.Since the paper is self-adhesive, no spray glue is required. And with the included grippy mat to hold the plate glass in place instead of rubber feet, sandpaper can be applied to both sides of the glass to maximize usefulness.The glass in the kit is tempered and has a nice smooth finished edge. The bevel guide has a smooth rolling wheel (important for not tearing the paper or wearing the wheel) and reference settings molded into the side so you'll always have the reference handy to check how far out to extend the chisel blade to get the degree bevel you want. (Those settings are in millimeters, by the way, so you'll need a small metric rule for accurate setup.) The bevel guide also accepts hand plane blades.This system is, to me, the way to go. This is an inexpensive and effective way to turn budget tools into top-drawer performers. And of course once you get those super sharp edges, handle and store your tools safely and out of the reach of children!

Works great! You'll need to provide your own fan (a 20-inch box fan is recommended) and plug-in timer. A surge protector strip is handy too. That way you can plug the ozone generator and fan into the surge strip and the strip into the timer, and the timer into the wall outlet.I didn't use a 20-inch box fan. I used a 12-inch one set on high and got great results. The situation was a reno of an old 12 X 16-foot room that hadn't had much air circulation for a few years. So there was a distinct musty odor even after cleaning and painting.I picked a day with low relative humidity (recommended for better results), set everything up, set the timer, and closed off the room and stuffed towels in the crack under the door. Even with that, the unit made so much ozone I could still smell whiffs of it in the hall. I ran it for two hours, let the room stay closed for another two, then went in and opened the windows and aired the room out for a couple of hours.What a difference! Now all I can smell is the trace of fresh paint!This thing works!

For some reason our cat eats most any other canned wet food with gravy in two stages. First she laps up all the gravy and leaves as if she's done. Then she'll come back later and eat the rest. With this, she charges right in and eats both at the same rate.I guess that's a vote of approval. And it smells good when you open the can. Some fish-based cat foods aren't too appetizing in fragrance, but this one's fine. It's a good product.

Let's face it: this thing is pricey. Is it worth the money? Until I tried it out, I wouldn't have thought so. But now I do, not only because it's well made, but because it has several advantages:It heats a lot quicker than a large stove top pot. It's more energy efficient than stove top canning. The more home canning you do, the more of an advantage that can be.It doubles as a large blancher. If you dehydrate vegetables too, this comes in very handy. One reason we stopped dehydrating food was it took so long for the large stove top pot we were using to start boiling again after we added vegetables. They wound up cooked instead of blanched. With this, we'll probably be dehydrating our own veggies again.Everything, including the base, stores right in the pot. It's a big pot, but that makes it more compact and easy to store.Because it heats so quickly, I don't think it makes a great general purpose cooker. Even the manual advises food with thick sauces or not enough liquid can scorch. We have a pressure cooker and a slow cooker that we'll continue to use for stews and roasts.You'll need a pair of jar lifters (tongs) and a ladle, and of course jars and lids. Everything else is included.Tips: Always preheat jars when canning. And don't run cold water over the lid when it's hot.

It's lightweight, pretty easy to unfold and fold the stroller part, and pretty easy to click and unclick the car seat and switch it between the stroller and the car base.The springs are too stiff to be effective shock absorbers. And the stroller is meant for hard or paved surfaces only. The wheels just aren't up to grass, sand, or soil.The straps are not one-strap adjustable. The straps have to be fiddled with to get a good snug fit.There's no quick release on the base. Taking the mounting base in and out of a car requires a bit more time than if it had a quick release. The solution is to buy extra bases for other family cars.Baby is about to outgrow it at one year.All that said, the positives outweigh the negatives. We'd rate it on the higher end of budget models. For more features (such as quick release base and simplified strap adjust) look for higher end models.

How nice to have a grain-free wet cat food! We leave dry food out for our cat, and that provides more than enough grain (although grains are not part of a cat's natural diet). Twice a day we've been giving her canned tuna, which avoids adding more grain to her diet and helps her get more hydration (important for cats). We just buy the off-brand tuna on sale, and it's often cheaper than name-brand canned cat food. Incidentally we also have a cat water fountain for her, which we found works wonders in getting cats to drink more water.It's great that a grain-free complete nutrition wet food product is available like this. She likes it fine, although she didn't seem to like it on the first offer. Cats are finicky, and anything new or different is sometimes regarded with indifference, but they tend to come back to it. Which she did, and quickly.

It works. Here in the deep South, insects show up as soon as the rose leaves and buds do. Aphids, Japanese beetles, and several other insect beasties that just love to feast on roses. This knocks them right out.And the roses still smell like roses. No chemical smell lingers after application.This insect killer has a dual action of being both topical and systemic, so it lasts a while. That's a good thing. Insects don't show right back up and motivate you to reapply -- and overapply -- the product.On the negative side, the spray bottle itself isn't the greatest. It leaks a little around the trigger. Definitely wear gloves when you spray. And although the instructions recommend turning the spray bottle nozzle to adjust it to a fine mist, there's no such thing. At least not with the bottle we tried. The best we got out of it was a rather coarse spray.All that aside, we plan to stick to the "no more than five applications a year" guidelines, even if at times it means insects on the roses. I hope one day all pesticides can be 100% safe to beneficial insects. Until then, it's up to us to apply and use them responsibly.

Love this table. One of the secrets to always having a place to tackle a project -- at least for me -- is a folding table. Any "permanent" tables tend to attract clutter. And that means that before you can begin a project, your first project has to be clean off the table. But if you put a folding table away between projects (which is another big tip), it doesn't collect clutter and it's always ready to go when you are.This table has three height positions, which is very convenient. You can adjust it to whatever chair you happen to be working from. Or high enough to work from a standing position if you prefer. And it's big and wide enough to spread the work out on.It takes a little practice to get good at opening and folding it. It can pinch fingers. And it's a little awkward, having to turn it over and to from end to end to unlock the legs. And unsnapping the clip when first opening it takes quite a bit of pull. I went through the process several times to get good and familiar with it so I could set it up and take it down smoothly.It's not rock steady, but stable enough for most things. And it's not really light, which is a good thing. It's heavyweight and durable and unlikely to sag. Overall a really good table.

I like everything but the switch. The tool heats quickly, is easy to handle, and makes short work of shrink tubing and other small heat gun tasks.The switch, though. It's mounted without a guard and stands out. If you leave this thing plugged in and unattended, and it gets knocked off a workbench and lands on that switch or something bumps into it, it could easily switch on. That could result in scorching or melting something, to say the least.So the obvious workaround is to never leave this thing plugged in when you're not using it. Otherwise, good little heat gun.

Runs quieter and smoother and faster than the name-brand rotary tool I own. That might not be a fair comparison, since the name-brand one I own has a few years on it. Still, this is a surprisingly good-running tool. And it fits in the Dremel 220-01 Rotary Tool Work Station just fine. Five stars!

There are times when multi-tool pliers just aren't enough to turn a small bolt or nut. So this is a great little addition to an EDC bag. Quality is very good. The jaws will open wide enough to accommodate a half-inch bolt or nut max.

The one I got didn't get hot enough or apply enough pressure to do a good job with 5mil pouches. It left unsealed stripes and a pretty large unsealed border around cardstock. I found the Fellowes M5-95 (which is just a few dollars more) does a much better job with 5mil.With either machine, the tip other reviewers have about putting a book or something under the outfeed side to hold the pouch level when it comes out of the laminator is a good one. That will keep it from warping or getting wavy while it's still hot.

Everything is great about this product except the scent. Of course that is subjective. I'm sure some people will find it very pleasant. But I didn't. To me it smells like something that can't decide if it is fruity or floral. And it's rather subtle. It almost smelled like an "unscented" product--like a product with a masking fragrance.Now that the negative is out of the way--and again, that is subjective opinion--everything else about the scrub is great. It doesn't feel gritty at all in spite of being exfoliating. That's probably it's best feature--no scratchy feeling, no overly abraded results.It doesn't dry out the skin and it rinses clean.If it smelled a little better I'd give it five stars. And if you like the fragrance it may be a five star product for you. Everything else about it is great.

I ran a side-by-side test with the AmazonBasics laminator, which at this writing is about 10 dollars less.And there is no comparison. The Fellowes M5-95 performed much better.I tested using 5mil pouches and pieces of cardstock. The AmazonBasics laminator just doesn't seem to get hot enough or apply enough pressure with the rollers to get a clear and clean result. It left a 1/8-inch unlaminated gap all around the edge of the cardstock, and there were streaks where it appears there just wasn't enough heat to make a good clear seal. Even making two passes through the machine didn't result in much improvement.The Fellowes laminator made a good clear seal on the first pass through, and the gap around the cardstock was much smaller -- only about a 16th of an inch, and it was even all the way around, indicating even pressure by the rollers. I don't think any budget-priced home laminator can completely eliminate that gap. But these results are very good.A couple of tips when using either laminator: Put a book or something on the outfeed side of the laminator, level with the bottom of the slot, to give level support to the hot pouch as it exits the machine. This will minimize warping.Secondly, don't trust the green light. Give the machine a couple of extra minutes to heat up.And finally, leave a little border when trimming laminated pieces. If you trim right to the edge of the laminated piece, it will eventually delaminate at the edges. If you like that look, make extra copies so that you can replace them from time to time.

This is a serious mat. It's not prettied up at all. This mat is about function.The foam is dense, and that's a good thing, so the mat feels heavy when you carry it. It's grippy on the bottom, so it stays where you put it on most any type of floor. And it's big enough to suit most everyone.I can't speak for people who have the green-colored mat, but the black one doesn't show dirt or stains badly at all. And the surface is absorbent as advertised. The problem will be cleaning it once it has absorbed too much. The manufacturer recommends spot cleaning only (with their brand of mat cleaner or water and a mild detergent). I'd be tempted to throw it in a tub and scrub it with a brush, but I'd be concerned that might loosen the fabric or cause other problems.The manufacturer also recommends keeping the mat out of direct sunlight when storing, or it may get brittle. Apparently it isn't UV resistant.It has a chemical-factory odor when you first open the packaging, but that dissipates in a day or two.So those negatives warrant deducting a star. But otherwise it's a durable and serious workout mat.

I think the picture of the HS-1000-WX in the Amazon listing is a bit misleading. It's not as slim as it looks in the picture. (It measures about 13 inches wide and a little over 16 inches tall, which isn't too far from being square.)Let's get the negative stuff out of the way first:It's not a silent operator. It makes a bit of noise. Other reviewers noted fan noise and a clicking sound when it cycles.It's wall mount only. The bottom is slanted and it will not operate as a free-standing or portable unit. You'll have to decide where it will stay.It's 1000 watts. That's not going to warm a huge room. I think installing it in a room larger than 12-by-12 feet is going to be a waste of energy, unless you want it to warm up just one zone of the room.The cord is three feet long. So you'll need to hang it near an outlet. (As with any heater, extension cords aren't a good idea.)The operating manual has some of the tiniest print I've seen in a manual.On the positive side:It has a sleek contemporary design.If floor space is more valuable to you than wall space, then wall-mount-only is a desirable feature.The remote control is very handy, if a bit limited in range.The cord will store inside the heater in the warmer season. But you have to kind of push it in. It doesn't retract. The sharp metal edges on the cord storage opening may do some damage to the cord over time, so that's something to watch.It comes with mounting screws (and lugs for drywall) and a little level to make sure it's plumb on the wall.Even though it is wall mounted, for safety, if you plan to mount this heater in potentially wet areas (bathroom, kitchen, etc.), make sure you have a GFI (ground fault interrupter) outlet to plug it into.I'm deducting one star for it's lack of versatility (a flat bottom with an option to remove it from the wall and use it as a freestanding heater would have been awesome), but overall it's a good little unit. And if you're looking for a sleek-looking wall-mounted heater for a small room, this may be just the heater for you.

The design of this jacket with its removable layers makes it ideal for southern US winters. In the deep south, one day it's mild, the next three it's very cold, the next rainy and mild again, and so on. You can just pick the layer(s) to wear, or all of them, depending on the day's weather. On mild days you can just wear the outer shell as a windbreaker. The inner liner can be worn as a fairly warm jacket on cooler days. On cold days, you can wear both liner and shell.Even with all layers, it's warm without being bulky, and you can move well in this jacket. The hood is roomy enough to accommodate a cap or even a bike helmet underneath.The jacket is very well made, with big, useful pockets. The fit is just a smidgen to the small side, but not enough to recommend switching to a full size larger than you might normally wear, unless your size is already sort of on the border between two sizes.Like other reviewers, I'm not too fond of the logos, but it's a great jacket nonetheless.

On a scale of good/better/best I would rate these pliers on the very high side of "better." They're not boutique tool grade, but they are high quality.And it's a very useful assortment of pliers, with cutters and a large needle nose pliers included. The push-button adjustment of the channel lock pliers is a lot more convenient than the old "open 'em wide" style of adjustment. The smaller of the channel lock pliers has hex-shaped jaws, making it handy for tightening or loosening bolts.Of all the pliers in the set, I personally find lineman's pliers the most versatile and useful for general tinkering. The squared jaws are perfect for bending light gauge metal, they grab well, and the built-in cutters are very handy. If I carried only one pliers in a tool bag, as long as I had an adjustable wrench in there, lineman's pliers would be the one.The handles are comfortable and solidly bonded to the pliers.The tool wrap is a nice bonus. It's well made too.Great set.

These are much better than standard spade bits.  The self-feeding screw tip makes for a lot less effort in drilling, except for that final bit of drilling when you do have to give a bit of a push. The drilled holes are a lot cleaner with less blowout and splintering on the exit side. Not perfect, but better than regular spade bits. And they drill holes at a fast pace. That pace, incidentally isn't adjustable. The screw is going to pull the bit into the wood at the same pace every time.I agree with other reviewers that these bits are going to deplete cordless drill batteries in a hurry, so unless you have only a few holes to drill, they're best used with a corded drill. I also agree that they seem to work better when chucked to the rounded part of the shank instead of the hex end.Overall very good quality bits and a good addition to the tool box.

The new Sperry Instruments LED Shock II GFCI Outlet Circuit Analyzer Tester can be a lifesaver--literally and figuratively--for anyone attempting to install or replace wiring and outlets. It's one thing to run wiring and install an outlet, but you need the right tool, particularly with GFCI circuits, to help trace and resolve issues. I really like the simplicity of the Sperry model--the LEDs are nice and bright, and unlike some competing models, the labels are easy to read and understand. At less than $20, this is a no-brainer investment in making sure your DIY work is done correctly and safely.

I have always been a fan of Microsoft's "Step By Step" guides because they simplify the learning process without completely dumbing it down. I buy these books for my wife's parents and recommend them to friends and collegues. The "Step By Step" approach seems to be of particular help to less-experience users (and they significantly reduce the volume of tech support calls we get from friends and family members!)

This is a super-fun remote vehicle that absolutely delighted all the kids on my block when I took it our for a test drive. The attention to detail is VERY good, and the ATV (and its determined-looking rider) take off like a scalded dog when you hit the gas and corner like the thing is running on a rail. The only complaint I would have is that the battery pack--like all remove vehicle battery packs--never seems to last long enough. But the quick charger works as advertised, and you can be up and running again in a short while. This is a very cool toy for the money, and it looks a lot more durable than other models you'll find under $50.

McKinsey is one of the world's biggest consultancies, and their approach is (in my experience, anyway) pretty straightforward and aggressive--and typically very effective. "The McKinsey Edge: Success Principles from the World's Most Powerful Consulting Firm" is a compendium of their client companies' executives "tips" on managing projects and running a business. A lot of these collections are just ego stroking vanity books that allow a company like McKinsey to curry favor with the people who sign their checks, but to author Shu Hattori's credit, this is a very good collection of genuinely great management tips and approaches. The breadth of contributors is impressive, as is the breadth of covered topics. "The McKinsey Edge: Success Principles from the World's Most Powerful Consulting Firm" is a quick, engaging read and there's enough good nuggets in this book to produce a tidy return on your investment of time and money.

I wasn't sure what to expect from a set of bulbs that cost less than $7, but I was pleasantly surprised by how bright these are compared to the incandescent bulbs they replaced. Be forewarned, however, that the "documentation" for these bulbs is mostly indecipherable.

The quality of these USB chargers is, at best, so so. One was dead on arrival, another failed after a couple of days, and the overall construction of the products is not great--one gets the feeling they're close to falling apart at any time. I have so little confidence in these chargers that I threw them away rather than risk further issues.

These lights are complete garbage. Two of the three lights would not function no matter how much I fiddled with them. The one light that did work was a garish bright blue color that was painful to look at. There are so many better options out there--avoid this junk and save your time and money.

My girlfriend has been raving about this corset. It's a well-made product and, yes, it is incredibly sexy. The materials and craftsmanship are first rate--you will not be disappointed. I would encourage potential buyers to order one size larger than normal.

Extremely well made product and incredibly sexy. The materials and craftsmanship is first rate--you will not be disappointed. I would encourage potential buyers to order one size larger than normal though.

Extremely well made product and incredibly sexy. The materials and craftsmanship is first rate--you will not be disappointed. I would encourage potential buyers to order one size larger than normal though.

I have used lower bandwidth powerline adapters, so upgrading to the new TRENDnet Power Line 1200 AV2s was a revelation. It would be extremely difficult to run Ethernet cable to my bedroom TV and DVD player, so I've been relying on a 300 Mbps powerline adapter to deliver a stronger signal to enable streaming video. The results seemed to be okay, but I always encountered dropouts and stuttering when streaming. Now that I'm using this 1200 Mbps setup, the problem has disappeared. I'm generally quite happy with this product, but I did struggle a little to get a handshake between the two adapters. The product documentation was poor, so I ended up on an unnecessarily long call to tech support to resolve the issue. Ultimately, we got things working, and I have had no issues since installing these adapters.

I used to wear a Howard Leight hearing protection headset which was, in a word, crap. Only one channel ever worked and the customer service effort was downright hostile (they accused me of abusing the headphones and refused to replace or repair them even though I called them after the first time I tried using them). The contrast between that awful headset and the 3M Worktunes headset is night and day. 3M's product is clearly superior in every way, from the way they're built (rock solid) to the way they sound (amazing, even with significant background noise). They are idiot-simple to connect and use, and they are more comfortable than any other hearing protector I've used over the years. This is a VERY good product, particularly when compared to the mediocre junk from other manufacturers.

The quality of this print was dreadful. The screen printing is dull and I could see a number of places on the canvas where it looked like somebody used a Sharpie to correct problems with the print. Also, the top part of the frame was so warped, I had to take it apart and replace the wood pieces in order to hang it flat against a wall.

This is an excellent grill light that could have been great with a more thoughtful design. It's awkward to mount, and the battery compartment has to be unscrewed in order to change the batteries. Try doing that in the dark! I was also disappointed to find out that it's not waterproof. If it rains unexpectedly, you have to quickly remove this light from your grill so it doesn't get damaged. Those drawbacks are pretty serious in my opinion, and I hope the manufacturer goes back to the drawing board to address these issues. If so, then I'd be happy to buy version 2, because the light output on this particular model is superb.

I really liked the idea behind the OtterBox Agility Portfolio Bundle with keyboard and wall mount. I often use both of those aaccessories with my iPad, but there's always extra work--or major compromise--involved. The new Otterbox case lets you move from tabletop to wall mount without having to remove your case, which is a godsend to those of us who keep our tablets around pretty much 24/7. And when you consider this bundle doesn't cost any more than a name-brand keyboard case, it's like getting a fully compatible wall mount for free. I like that kind of value proposition.

This is a good all around vitamin supplement, but it's not exceptional--particularly when compared to less-expensive brands that offer essentially the same formulation for about half the cost of the Ultra Man daily vitamins.

These Ammex XNPF Xtreme blue nitrile gloves are terrific: strong, good feel, very durable. The only issue I had with them is that the fit is a little on the snug side compared to other brands. But I will trade fit for durability any day, and I couldn't be more pleased with these gloves.

The concept of "Freedom to Change: Four Strategies to Put Your Inner Drive into Overdrive" is simple enough--change is possible if you approach the effort in the right way. Author Michael Fullan establishes a strong case for his "four strategies," but none of them is revolutionary--or are they particularly clear in terms of a "Go and do this" prescriptive type of approach. If you're looking for motivation, this is a great book. If you're in need of a concrete strategy and a set of best practices, then there are probably better options out there, including working with a life coach.

This was a disappointing study guide. I found it hard to use because the organization of the book did not do much to speed up the process of working through the material, and as soon as I thought I had mastered a concept, I would run into information in the following sections that seemed to conflict with what I had previous "learned." It feels like this book was produced quickly and could have benefited from another few rounds of editing before going to print.

I ordered two sets of these lights and they compare very well to a set of "name brand" lights I got at Macy's for about 4x the price I paid for these. The Blue Wind lights are bright and last a surprisingly long time on a set of batteries. My only issue is that the battery compartment is quite large compared to the delicate lights themselves, but I suppose you can always hide the battery box somewhere (we used a cable tie to attach ours to the back of our Christmas wreath). On the whole, these turned out be an excellent value.

First of all, how nice is it to receive a quality gift box when you order what is a relatively inexpensive piece of jewelry? These folks ship this bracelet in a very lovely box that is nicer than most of the gift boxes I've seen used for much more expensive pieces. A+ for packaging! The bracelet itself is also lovely. It's well made with a sturdy chain and clasp, and the stones are actually nicer than they look in the photo. For less than $20, I can't think of too many pieces that would equal or better this bracelet in terms of bang for the buck. The recipient was quite thrilled (although she doesn't know what I paid for it!)

I was extremely pleased with the quality of this bag. In fact, it FAR exceeded my expectations considering that it costs about 1/10th of what a similar bag from LL Bean or Land's End costs. I will definitely order more bags from this company for Christmas presents (but I won't tell anyone how inexpensive they are!).

This is an AMAZING bag for the money. I didn't want to spend a fortune on a canvas bag, and this one came up in my Amazon search. It looked nice in the photo, so I took a chance and ordered one. Needless to say it has far exceeded my expectations. I've owned bags made by LL Bean and Eddie Bauer and this bag is absolutely the equal of those bags--and in some ways, far better--for about 1/10th of the price of the "name brand" bags. The packaging was excellent (the bag arrived in a nice cloth wrap) and everything from the fit and finish to the quality of the zippers they use is top shelf. An A++++ product for a bargain price.

This is a very handsome bag, and it has every feature--and the quality and craftsmanship--that I would expect on a much more expensive "brand name" bag from LL Bean, Eddie Bauer, or any other retailer that costs about 10x what I paid for this one. I could not be more pleased with my purchase, and I am planning to buy some additional bags from this manufacturer as Christmas presents for my college-age kids. (I think they'll be very pleased.)

I do a lot of remodeling work, which involves painting and handling some really nasty materials, glues, and other stuff you probably don't want to get on your hands. It's always hard to find the right glove for the job, and it's almost impossible to find a disposable glove that holds up for more than a few minutes' use or that even fits right in the first place. Ammex' APFN Blue Nitrile Glove are actually medical exam gloves, but they are perfect for most of the projects I use them for. They fit my large hands, well, like a glove, and they keep the bad stuff off my skin about as well as any glove I've used. Plus, the great thing about exam gloves is that they are tough AND they still are thin enough so you can feel what you're working on--which is critical in so many remodeling applications.

I got this cover to replace the piece of junk that came with my fire pit. That "cover" was paper thin and was about as waterproof as a sheet of wrapping tissue. In contrast, the new cover is a rugged, well-made and durable cover that fits my fire pit like a glove. My only quibble is the color. It's darker than what you see in the photo and it's not exactly a cheerful addition to your patio. Still, I bought the cover primarily to protect the pit, and I am completely satisfied that it will do that quite well for years to come.

Sage 50 is my accounting software of choice (mainly because my CPA uses it and is willing to offer helpful guidance on using it. I've been a user since this was "Peachtree Accounting" and I have generally been very pleased with the completeness and the ease of use of this program. But this year, I ran into all sorts of problems installing the updated version and I was very disappointed with the help offerings from Sage when I got stuck in the process (multiple issues). I am also less than enthusiastic about the value of this year's update. In previous years, I felt like I was getting my money's worth in terms of few features, improved user interface, etc. But this year's version left me scratching my head in terms of where the value was. Maybe it was a slow year for innovation at Sage, but I would suggest that you could skip the 2016 effort and wait for the 2017 revision and hope it provides a little more bang for the buck

Like most "Dummies" books, "Getting a Codingg Job for Dummies" will serve as a good--but not exhaustive--primer on the ins and outs of trying to find a decent job in what is, right now at least, a pretty decent market for IT professionals. This book is well organized and the suggestions and resources seem to be spot on for somebody coming into field for the first time, as well as for the "gray beards" who are looking to change organizations or at least explore some new options. It's a cheap investment in your career, and you'll find enough useful info in this book to make it worth your time and money.

I've owned a few "sports" armbands for various devices over the years, and they're an essential accessory if you want to take your MP3 player or phone to the gym, on a hike, or when you walk your dog. It seems the quality of these armbands varies wildly among manufacturers--some seem to last forever, while others fall apart like a cardboard suit after a few uses. I am happy to report that Bluebits' new sports armband is extremely durable and it looks like it could withstand a lot of abuse, sweat, rain, and whatnot. It's easy to use--no complicated latches or hooks, and the plastic covering your phone is thin enough to make using it easy (some of these armbands use plastic so thick and/or inflexible that no amount of pressing seems to cause your phone to respond). The best part of this armband, in my opinion, is the price. $15.99 gets you a product that I think is actually better than the Belkin I paid $30+ for. In terms of negatives, the only thing I can think of is that I would have liked the "belt" to have been a little longer. I have large biceps and it can be a bit of a challenge to attach this armband. An extra inch or two would make a huge difference.

One person's anecdotal reporting about their limited use of a supplement like Jarrow's Vegetarian Jarro-Zymes Capsules--which is a vegetarian- and vegan-friendly alternative to traditional "anti-gas"/digestive health products, but I was very happy with the results I got after about a week's worth of ramp-up time. They seem to work as advertised--to help the digestive system process protein--and they didn't produce any noticeable side effects for me. They are more considerably more expensive per dose than generic anti-gas/digestive health products you can find at Sam's Club or Costco, but of you're vegetarian or vegan, the extra cost is probably worth it.
This appears to be a very good daily multi in terms of the spectrum of vitamins and minerals it contains, but it doesn't have any magic ingredients that justify the relatively high per-pill price.

Even though I am primarily an Adobe Photoshop and Lightroom user, there are many times when I actually prefer the simplicity and automation of Photoshop Elements, which is a graphics editor that has 90% of Photoshop's capabilities for 20% of the price. It's been a few years since I upgraded my copy of Photoshop Elements, and the newest version (#14) seemed to have enough new and interesting features to make me want to make the jump--and I'm really glad I did.Over the years, the full Photoshop program's interface has become almost comically dense, making it hard to find less-frequently used tools and features. Elements, on the other hand, seems to be getting simpler in newer generations. I like the streamlined "desktop" and the way the tools and controls are laid out and organized. Things seem more logical now, and for less experienced image editors, the intimidation factor has probably dropped a few notches as a result.I won't list all the feature changes between my old version of Elements (#11) and the new one, but if you're upgrading from a 3- to 4-year old rev of the program like I am, you'll definitely feel like you're getting your money's worth in terms of added capabilities, a richer set of tools, filters, and templates, and a really slick approach to automating repetitive tasks like batch converting images from one format to another.Adobe has always struggled with the "kitchen sink" approach to software development, and they seem to be doing a lot to streamline and simplify, particularly in the consumer-focused products like Photoshop and Premiere Elements. They're both terrifically capable tools for editing pictures and videos (and packaging the end result for family and friends), and you simply can't argue with the price. Yes, there are a lot of free apps and programs out there that claim to do what Photoshop Elements does, but I haven't seen anything that matches the seamless integration of so many functions and options into a really slick, user friendly package like this. Highly recommended for novices and experts alike.

Vornado fans and heaters move a lot of air, which is a critical success factor if you're trying to cool or heat a larger room. But that's true of a lot of products like this one--most of which sell for a lot less money. What differentiates a Vornado heater from the off-brand (i.e., "el cheapo") products that you can find at Target or WalMart is quality, plain and simple. The thing is built to last--the case feels sturdy, the controls and switches move smoothly and give you positive tactile feedback so you know moving a dial is actually doing something, and even little things that you seldom notice (from the heavy gauge power cord to a well-written and designed owner's manual) are top shelf and a real confidence booster. Trust me, you don't want to be thinking about where the manufacturer decided to cut corners when you flip the power switch on a space heater in your kid's bedroom. So again, this is a product that exemplifies the motto, "you get what you pay for." It's a powerful, quiet heater that works efficiently and operates effortlessly. The only quibble I have with this model is that there are only two power settings--750 watt and 1500 watt--and that can make it a challenge to reach your desired temp and keep it there. Otherwise, this is a fine product and well worth the investment.

These LED off-road floodlights are a massive upgrade from traditional incandescent lights. They're diamond bright and throw out a ton of light. Unlike the other off-road lights I've used--including a set that was MORE expensive--these WARN 93925's produce a really wide and consistent beam of light--there are no dead spots or weird shadows. My buddy said flipping on these lights was like "having the sun mounted your light bar." It's an apt description. I thought installation was surprisingly quick and easy--particularly if you're replacing an older set of lamps. In terms of fit and finish and overall quality, these floodlights feel like military grade and will probably outlast my 4x4. Considering these cost about as much as a single good off-road tire, I can't think of a better bang for the buck when you're outfitting your rig.

I prefer to wear my activity tracker wristband 24/7, but I've gone through two similar products because they apparently had no tolerance for moisture and the bands themselves couldn't handle continuous use. A friend of mine who works at REI (and does a lot of extreme outdoor activities in brutal conditions) recommended the Jawbone UP2 which is designed to withstand a little more abuse than most wristbands. It's also better able to flex thanks to a clever loop design that loosens up if you snag the band on something. In terms of the tracker hardware and software, I greatly prefer the display style and website/app software to the relatively crude user interface of the Fitbit devices. Of course, this is just a matter of personal preference; both systems work pretty much the same and provide the same data. I didn't have any issues with the accuracy of either brand's wristbands. On the whole, I think the Jawbone UP2 will turn out to be a better investment, if for no other reason than that is seems to be holding up better than the wristbands I've used previously.

I've been using Office for many, many years, and to Microsoft's credit, they have always offered a lot of added value with each of their major product updates (unlike companies like Quicken, Adobe, etc. whose annual product updates add on piles of mostly useless "features" that just make their programs increasingly complex and hard to use).I thought Office 2013 was a polished, well-integrated suite of software products and I have been very happy with the significant improvements to the user interfaces and the key functionality of Word, PowerPoint, Excel, etc. The 2013 release made Office easier to use, and it was worth the cost of the upgrade.The Office 2016 suite gives users an equivalent level of improvement overall. The first thing I noticed is that the programs load much faster, and the interfaces have been further streamlined (in particular, the menus and tools can be more easily configured to individualize the user experience). If you're a long-time Office user, this new version will feel familiar and comfortable--and a lot easier on the eyes.One of the most noteworthy new features is something long overdue--real-time collaboration--which allows multiple users to work on a document at the same time. Alterations to a document or slide show are annotated with the date, time, and name of the person making the change. This is a terrific feature for those of us who depend on content and edits from colleagues in order to bring a document to finished form. Google Docs has offered this feature for some time now, but Microsoft has done a better job of logging changes and allowing the document owner to revert to a previous version if necessary.

I am really pleased with the performance of Vornado's new heater, model AVH10. Living in the Upper Midwest, I've probably owned a dozen of space heaters over the years, and most of them were junk. The AVH10 is a cut above the rest. It feels solid, and Vornado didn't cut any corners in terms of the materials used to make this model. The controls are idiot proof and the temperature settings seemed to be pretty accurate. It's also a very quiet heater, which is significant if you plan to use this in a bedroom or office. In terms of power, the AVH10 puts out an amazing amount of heat when you consider how small this thing is. The only drawback I could think of is that the initial "burn off" from the heater coils fills the room with a pretty nasty chemical smell. It took 3-4 hours of use for that smell to completely dissipate, but the issue is common to most space heaters. All in all, this is a well-designed unit that will probably last for years.

"Super bright" is an apt description for these LED replacement bulbs. I can't quantify the exact difference in lumens between these bulbs and the standard ones I replaced, but I can definitely tell the difference when I'm driving at night. Installation only took a few minutes and I haven't had any issues since I put them in. Considering how much extra light is thrown out by these bulbs, this seems to be a very low-cost safety upgrade for your car, truck, or motorcycle.

This is a pretty typical hose nozzle that is made exceptional by a ergonomically superior design. Finally someone has figured out that those of us with large hands would appreciate a longer trigger to spare us from having the blunt end dig into our palm every time we use a product like this. This sprayer is priced a little higher than other models--almost double what I paid for my last nozzle--but I appreciate the value of the design every time I turn on the hose.

QlikView is an extremely powerful and flexible data analytics tool, but it has--and this is putting it mildly--an extremely challenging learning curve, particular for business analysts and other data consumers who don't have a background in scripting or programming languages. The new book, "QlikView Your Business: An expert guide to Business Discovery with QlikView and Qlik Sense" is an exceptionally thorough guide--literally 800 pages of background, instruction, examples, etc--and it is a superb reference for those of us who use QlikView on a regular basis. However, while "QlikView Your Business" is easily the best resource available right now, the book's organization seems a little disjointed and the text could have used another round of editing--there are instruction sets that just don't make sense (or are simply inaccurate), but fortunately those gaffes are the exception rather than the rule.

R is definitely NOT for dummies. It's a challenging language, and the people in our business who use it--mainly business analysts and database programmers residing in the IT department--struggle to tap into the power of R. If you've done any programming at all, the syntax isn't that tough to pick up. But it's the application of those scripts and functions that leave some scratching their heads. Most R e-learning programs leave a lot to be desired, and that's why I appreciate the hands-on, real-world approach Andrie de Vries and Joris Mays use to teach the language AND to help novices (and intermediate programmers and analysts) understand how to use it to process and model data, develop graphical interpretations of the data, and use the included sample code to help them ramp up more quickly. The only issue I have with "R for Dummies" is that the design is as dated and chaotic as anything being published these days. There's so much visual noise on every page that you imagine you're looking at a church newsletter from the 80s designed in Printshop. Ugh.

After seeing what my dealer wanted to charge me to replace these parts ($1350!), I decided to do the job myself and ordered these instead. They arrived in about a week, and were well packaged. Granted, installing these isn't a trivial job, but there are enough videos and instructions online to take most of the guesswork out of the project. All told, it took one relatively leisurely afternoon of work to finish the job, but I saved $1100 and used replacement parts that actually look and ride better than the OEM bags I removed.I couldn't be more pleased with this product (and with the money I saved tackling the job myself).

I have to admit I was a little skeptical about replacing my older Honeywell programmable thermostat with a wi-fi/app based unit, but after seeing how much flexibility these products provide--not to mention the potential for increased heating and cooling efficiency--I decided to give one a try.I've been using the Lux Products GEO-WH wi-fi thermostat for two weeks now, and I am happy to admit my reservations about a wi-fi/app system were misguided. I LOVE this thermostat! It was extremely easy to install (it took about 10 minutes to swap between the Lux thermostat for my old Honeywell), and the setup--which one might assume is kind of complicated--was actually a piece of cake. The controls are logical, the app works great, and there was no issue connecting to my router. All told, I think I spent about 45 minutes from the time I opened the box to having all the settings worked out. (Lux did a good job on the product documentation--something that's all-too-rare when it comes to these devices).

The new Logitech BLOK keyboard case is an extremely lightweight add-on for your iPad Air 2. Unlike some of the older keyboards of this type--which made it seem like you had a concrete block strapped to your iPad, the BLOK is surprisingly slim and has kind of a natural feeling, as if it was part of the iPad rather than just being attached to it. I'm not sure what gives the BLOK that kind of seamless integration, but when you spend a ton of money for your new tablet, you don't want the beautiful design and finish to be ruined by a badly designed, overweight keyboard.In terms of functionality, the BLOK has excellent ergonomics and the keyboard has a pleasantly light touch. Some might find the touch a bit too light, but when you compare it to typing on the iPad Air's screen, it seems perfect.I would much rather tote an iPad Air and a keyboard case than a full-blown laptop most of the time--especially when I'm traveling--and of all the keyboard/case combos I've tried (and mostly hated) over the years, the BLOK is as good as it gets.

This is not the largest or most comprehensive college finance book out there because the folks at CliffNotes did what they do best and distilled a ton of information into a very readable digest that will meet the needs of most parents who are trying to figure out how to pay for their kids' educations. Given the wealth of information available on the web, the value of a book like this ultimately comes down to explaining the best STRATEGIES for finding money to fund school, not on providing 100,000 sources of funding (many of which are outdated by the time one of those monster guides comes out in print.

ASUS has come up with a "flip" design for their Transformer Book product line that feels so much better than the designs used by most competing models. The hinge that allows you to flip the screen display runs across most of the long edge of the device which increases stability and makes everything feel more secure (and in the long run, more durable). The flip hinge might not seem like a big factor when you're deciding which laptop, tablet, or 2-in-1 notebook to buy, but when you use a device like this in one of the various viewing modes (tablet, tent, stand, and laptop), it's reassuring to know that when you set it down on an airplane tray, it's going to stay in place. (I'm speaking from experience after watching somebody's iPad air flop onto the floor and crack when the $200 alligator skin case suddenly collapsed. Ouch!)If you're a power user, the specs of the ASUS Transformer Book Flip TP200SA-DH04T won't excite you. In order to increase portability (and make it possible to use the device in tablet mode), a lot of compromises were made in terms of what you find under the hood. Although the TP200SA-DH04T runs the more efficient Windows 10 operating system, 4gb of RAM will prove a liability for people using memory hogs like photo/video editing software, working with large spreadsheets, or watching high-definition video. But I found that in general use (web surfing, streaming music and video, Microsoft Office applications, etc.), there were no significant speed issues--due in part to the sizable 64gb SSD that serves as a memory cache.Another factor impacting speed is the decision to use the new 802.11AC protocol rather than the slower 802.11N standard for WI-FI. If you have an AC router, you will immediately notice how much faster everything loads when you're online.The other hardware specs are typical for a device in this price range--which is to say you get a lot of capabilities for a machine that sells for under $400.All in all, this is a very capable and flexible computer. It's lightweight, it has the convenience of a dual tablet/notebook configuration, and for the vast majority of users, it will run most programs as well as most of the laptops on the market. The inclusion of Windows 10, Bluetooth 4.0, and 802.11AC means the TP200SA-DH04T will also protect buyers from the scourge of obsolescence.

The concept of the iHealth BG5 Wireless Smart Gluco-Monitoring System is sound, but the execution is so-so. The idea is that you can view, save, and assess your blood glucose levels using an app on your smartphone, and even share the data you collect with others, including caregivers and family members. This is all well and good, but we found the app is, at best, a work in progress. I used the app on a LG G3 phone running Android v5.1 and while it installed successfully, it crashes virtually every time I open it. I tried turning off various background programs, assuming there was some kind of a conflict going on, but it didn't seem to make much difference in terms of the success rate of getting the app to launch and load without crashing. Then I installed the app on an older Moto X phone running Android 4.x and the app seemed to load okay--but then  crashed randomly just about every time I launched it. It's a shame, because without the app, the iHealth BG5 is pretty much useless.

This really a nice, solid product that feels great in your hand and does a superb job of shaving and trimming. At this price point, that shouldn't come as a surprise, but over the years I've been repeatedly disappointed by shavers that have all the bells and whistles, but can't shave my face worth a darn. The newest Panasonic model gives you a surprisingly close shave--without the irritation and "gotchas" of cheaper or inferior models. Maybe that has something to do with the design and ergonomics. This particular shaver feels perfect in my hand, with just the right heft to keep it steady and a head design that conforms to all the curves and angles of your face. It's an impressive product and it looks like it was built to last for many years to come.

The concept behind the elaborately titled "Spending the Holidays with People I Want to Punch in the Throat: Yuletide Yahoos, Ho-Ho-Humblebraggers, and Other Seasonal Scourges" is a good one, although not unique in the annals of holiday literature. Still, who doesn't enjoy a good Christmas-themed yarn about the people in our lives--the well-meaning, the kooks, and the malcontents--who can make or break the season with their overbearing, selfish, clueless, or drunken behavior? I certainly do, and I was eager to dive into Jen Mann's new book. Unfortunately, while Mann has conjured up a lot of good stories, the writing isn't as polished--and the wit isn't as sharp--as I would have hoped. Mann is a decent writer, but these tales lack the sparkle and vividness of similar compilations. It's worth a read, but it's not on par with the best in this genre.

If you want to study abroad, you have to take the standard TOEFL iBT test in order to get your application approved. The test evaluates basic competencies in all the expected areas - reading, writing, listening, and speaking and has an impressive variety of study aids (CD, video, practice tests, etc.) to help you prepare for the test. Considering the price, this is a pretty good package. The quality of the instructional information and the practice tests is excellent, but the online content and multimedia offerings feel incomplete and dated. Frankly, most students are familiar with most of the curriculum presented here, and unfortunately Kaplan's presentation of the material is not particularly compelling, making me wonder if the typical user of this guide will find it interesting enough to derive much value from it.

I've worn a beard for many years, and I have used a number of trimmers over that period--some good, most mediocre. It shouldn't be that difficult to design a cordless trimmer that conforms to one's face, fits the hand well, holds a charge longer than 10 minutes, and stays sharp for more than a few months. In contrast to all the disappointing trimmers I've tried and discarded, the new Panasonic ER-GB60-K trimmer is excellent. It's quiet, has great ergonomics, provides a wide range of trim lengths, and runs for nearly an hour on a charge. It's pricier than most trimmers on the market, but I'd rather spend my money on one really good trimmer than a drawer full of crappy ones.

This is a good starter guide to understanding electronics--how things work, why failures occur, and how to fix stuff that breaks. In an age in which "how-to" videos proliferate on YouTube, it's still nice to have a book on the shelf that provides important context and instead of just showing the steps involved in making repairs (along with stilted narration and poorly shot video in many cases). I was particularly happy to see the inclusion of some excellent material on bench equipment--what it does and how it works. "How to Diagnose and Fix Everything Electronic" is actually more of a one-stop resource for hobbyists and tech fans. It's rewarding reading, and a valuable resource to have available when things stop working.

BIC's Hybrid 3 "Comfort" razor is not marketed as a "revolutionary" product (anybody wanna guess how long it will be before we see 10-blade razors?), but it's a rock solid, everyday shaver whose refill blades don't cost an absurd amount of money. I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the shave and the longevity of these blades. The only negative is the ergonomics of the handle--I like to shave while I'm showering, and this handle is particularly difficult to hold when it's slippery. I haven't had that issue with other "premium" razors, and it's something you might want to consider if you "wet shave" like I do.
This is an amazing looking piece of wall art. I'm not a big fan of "trophy heads", but this piece looks like a bronze sculpture and it's the showpiece of my living room--absolutely gorgeous!
I would have loved to have hung this piece on my wall, but the shipper managed to punch a hole completely through the box (and through the print) making it effectively unusable. Dang.
This is a TERRIFIC selection of snacks! I brought the canister into the office today to share with my colleagues, and nothing has elicited smiles like this assortment of Hershey's snacks.

As a nerd, I had high hopes for "Networking for Nerds: Find, Access and Land Hidden Game-Changing Career Opportunities Everywhere." It's always a challenge to find a position that is well suited for your specific "nerdish" talents, and I figured author Alaina G. Levine had uncovered some rich trove of job postings that would open some completely new pathways to the job of my dreams. Unfortunately, "Networking for Nerds" is mostly a rehash of the resources any intrepid nerd would find using Google or Bing. And while it's nice to have a book like this to vet some of those resources, I found Levine's uniformly positive assessments to be a real obstacle to my effort to parse what may or may not be a legitimate focus area for a job search.

Here's the bottom line in terms of whether or not you'll enjoy playing "Utter Nonsense": If you're intending to play this game with your kids or your elderly parents, you might find the experience to be a little uncomfortable. The game has a certain shock value like "Cards Against Humanity" that makes it more suitable for playing with a group of adult friends. Having said that, how much you enjoy playing this game with your adult friends will depend on what your definition of "funny" is. A lot of the humor is pretty crude, and the basic concept of the game involves having participants use accents to read off scenarios. That can be funny, but at times playing the game reminded me of the scene in "The Office" in which Michael Scott repeatedly asks one of his employees if she "wants a cookie." What made that scene so uncomfortable to watch--it was not intended to be a "funny" scene, by the way--was that Michael Scott was speaking in a ridiculously exaggerated Indian accent and his employee, whose family was from India, is deeply offended and ends up slapping her boss. If you think that kind of thing is a riot, then you'll probably get a kick out of "Utter Nonsense." But if your players fail to see the humor, you might get a slap out of "Utter Nonsense" rather than a kick.

I have the misfortune of being a Mediacom customer. If you've never had the pleasure of dealing with this stone-age cable provider, then you're really missing out on something. All of their proprietary hardware--from cable boxes, to DVRs, to modems--looks and operates like technological relics from Soviet-era Eastern Bloc countries. Although I can't choose my cable provider, I can swap out their hardware for stuff that's light years ahead of their crap. I replaced their DVR (which had a user interface that was one step below an Atari game system) with a Tivo, and their modem was recently shipped back and replaced with a shiny new TP-LINK Archer CR700 AC1750 cable modem router. Naturally, Mediacom did everything they could to make the transition as difficult as possible. First, they refused to provision the TP-LINK because it was not on their approved list of modems. I asked to see the list, but they refuse to post it on their website or send it to customers. WTF? I finally reached a tech who admitted they do this to pressure people into using their $8/month relics, but he said he sympathized with my "situation" and would provision my TP Link model as a "one-time exception." Again, WTF?Once we got past Mediacom's draconian policies and procedures, setting up the TP-LINK CR700 AC1750 cable modem router was a piece of cake. The admin dashboard for the TP-LINK router is excellent. The UI is simple and clean, and everything is logically grouped--which really makes setup go fast. The TP-LINK CR700 offers users a lot of options, including four gigabit ethernet ports for direct connection, and two USB ports for adding printers or external hard drives. I was extremely frustrated to see that the USB ports are 2.0, not the current USB 3.0 standard. That's fine for printers, but if I'm going to attach an external hard drive as a data server, I want the quickest possible throughput. It's inconceivable to me that the manufacturer would elect to cut costs in this manner. However, the ports do work as advertised and that's better than having no ports at all.The wireless performance of the TP-LINK CR700 is exceptionally good--I was able to stream 1080p video without a single hiccup, and internet speeds are virtually as fast using Wi-Fi as they are when I connect directly to the device with an ethernet cable. That's pretty remarkable, and this kind of throughput is what justifies the relatively high cost of these devices.From a user perspective, I found the TP-LINK CR700 to be close to perfect. The only drawback--and it probably won't be an issue for most customers--is the decision to go with USB 2.0 ports in a world in which USB 3.0 is getting to be ubiquitous. I took off one star for this issue. Otherwise, the product is a gem.

This turned out to be a perfect replacement for the water filter in our Samsung fridge, and aside from the label, I didn't see any significant physical difference between this filter and the OEM filter it replaces. Considering that it costs about 1/3 as much as that OEM filter, I can't see any reason to buy the Samsung-branded filter.

I am an avid reader of non-fiction, but had read Life of Pi among the select fiction that makes its way into my stack of books. I thoroughly enjoyed Life of Pi and was eager to read this new book by the same author. This book sets off on three distinct journeys that are connected. The trio of tales makes for a compelling read, albeit at a pace that can lull at times. I felt the narrative was not as tight as Life of Pi, and maybe that was partially due to Life of Pi being a story where lulls actually added to the telling.  Still, Martel's command of beautifully descriptive and captivating writing propels this book to an excellent read. The characters are fullly fleshed out and are the centerpiece to a set of stories that is not quite as original or endearing, to me, as Life of Pi, but still novel and captivating in their own right.

Typically, I have no interest in poetry - zero.  However, after seeing Donald Hall on The Colbert Report some time ago, I was sincerely intrigued. Now that I have read through most of his selected poems, I really have nothing but praise. His lifetime's mastery of prose is evident throughought the collection and makes a stunning departure from my presumed concept of poetry being an overly-wrought melodramatic and pretension format better suited to personal expression in private than a public display - a notion I haven't yet entirely shed. I would highly recommend this book to nearly anyone. It is, to me, the pinnacle of the art form and casts a wide net in its target audience.

Just Dance has been around for many years now, but each refresh brings a new list of songs, many of which are recent hits.  A few more creative mixes add variety, such as the Angry Birds theme song.  The big new feature this year is that you no longer need Kinect. You can use an app for your phone to play instead. It works well, but is not as convenient as a Kinect. Overall the songs are pretty good this year and the game  has become faorly polished through its many iterations. Don't expect it to teach you to dance for real, but if you aren't too serious, you will have plenty of fun.

These smartly designed toys appeal to babies as young as 5 or 6 months and are still fun and engaging for children up to around 12-18 months. The two pods work together to respond to your child so they are not just paying attention to one of the two pods. It is an interesting mechanic that works really well. They are also colorfully decorated and built to last through some abuse.

This is a cute Snowman Snowglobe with a satisfying glittery flurry when shaken. Shamefully, he is not entirely well-appointed as his garb and various details are smitten with a general slop unbefitting his prim demeanor.
I love arts and crafts with my kids, but not the mess that usually accompanies such activities. Unfortunately, this is one of the messiest art projects I have encountered. Dress appropriately.
This is a good, rugged grill cover that will protect your grill under in climate weather. It is sized sensibly to fit most kettle or small grills.

This is a big and goofy looking dinosaur - a bizarro T-Rex? So far so good, but holy moly is this thing loud and annoying. Your kid may not mind, so it all depends on whether or not you do. Makes a good gift for someone else's kid.

These generously sized towels are tea towels and, as such, need to be broken in with several washes before they can absorb any liquid. Vinegar helps. Still, I don't find them as useful as a good cotton dish towel. they just don't resist heat or absorb liquid that much even when broken in. But they are attractive and affordable. If you do like tea towels, you will be happy with these.
Works just as well as the Apple lightning cable, even looks the part. Overall, no complaints.

This internal desktop wifi adapter is easy to hookup and gets great reception thanks to the dual antennae. I have tried several USB wifi adapters and none come close to the reliability and range of this unit. The cable to attach the antennae make it easy to find a sweet spot if your desktop is in a cabinet or something that interferes with a wifi signal.

This is a really nice quality keyboard that is responsive and has decent travel and feedback, but the connection can be haphazard. It is an unfortunate design flaw and is compounded by a poor design in the stand for the tablet. For the price, you should get something with less issues.
This is an effective product that works as promised. It soothes the skin almost immediately.
This is an effective cream that works as promised. It protects from the sun too with an SPF of 30. A little goes a long way.

As the description and images clearly state, this is a set of 20 bilingual cards for your little one to play with. It is an odd choice to have word in english and spanish on a  toy that really is designed more for a 9 month to 2 year old rather than a 4 or 5 year old who might actually be starting to learn to read. Basically, the words printed on the cards are completely superfluous other than to remind a nearby adult or older sibling what the english and spanish words for the object shown are so that they may communicate these facts to the baby/toddler.  So, I am completely bewildered by the complaints some reviewers have left, but not to dwell on it, these cards are a fun and engaging toy and work well for siblings of the right ages to play with together.

These are a big step up from the regular Huggies but they are not quite up to Pampers Sensitive Swaddlers. They offer a lot of similar features, like a softer material, wetness indicator and a snug fit. Yet, they aren't quite as soft and the fit is not quite as snug. Huggies does make a really terrific pull-up diaper though.

While expensive, the Kohler Transitions toilet seat provides a superior potty experience for young children, like mine.Especially in the age range of 2 to 5 years old, it can be difficult for kids to sit on an adult toilet seat on their own.  You can buy a kids toilet seat booster insert for not much money, and we have liked our baby bjorn model, but if you are going to have a lot of shared use between adults and kids, this is a more effortless solution.  The nightlight also comes in very handy since my kids hate having the lights on bright if they wake up at 11pm to go potty.Overall, it is a premium product at a premium price. The value proposition may or may not be there depending on the customer, but it does work well as advertised.

This large playset offers kids tons of play options. It's a house and it's a boat. It has a pool and it comes with a rowboat and an island. They threw in everything and the kitchen sink. We have a similar toy that is a boat and converts to a house-like-thing, but this toy is a bit bigger and has more a few more features. I would have liked a few more characters included with a such a large playset, but we already had a few, so my kids were quite happy with what comes included in the box. Overall, its a sturdy set full of details and is very engaging. My two daughters will get a ton of play time out of it together. Best of all, there are no batteries required.

For any fan of the show, this cookbook is a sure hit. It has a good mix of show-related content and genuinely worthwhile recipes for a wide variety of foods. There is a emphasis on american, latin american, and asian fusion cuisine. As far as I can tell, the recipes are all at least alluded to in the show, if not directly referenced or shown. I can tell so because a side bar on each recipe page gives the relevant dialogue mentioned the food.The production quality on this cookbook is phenomenal. The pictures are gorgeous, there are a ton of little sections about different characters or other things about the show that really make this much more than a cookbook. I don't watch the show that much, so I was more interested in the food. In short, the recipes are great. You could actually separate the recipes and the other content into two books and they would work just fine alone, I think. The recipes are on par with any other cookbook in my collection. The difficulty on them ranges from overly simple to moderately complex and all the ingredients are fairly easy to get ahold of.  There isn't really anything too exotic, but I like that they didn't try to invent their own Modern-Family-Themed foods that really have little to do with the show. This plagues similar cookbooks I have seen for other shows/movies/books. The recipes also manage to balance the demands of being believably part of the show but also consistently worth making. Again, this is often not the case with such cookbooks. Obviously, it is easier to tackle the dishes from Modern Family than those from Harry Potter or Game of Thrones, but it is still an achievement worth praising.Overall, this is one of the most beautifully produced and successfully composed cookbooks related to a show, movie or book that I have ever seen. It stands on its own merit as a cookbook, but would make a terrific gift for any Modern Family fan regardless of how much they like to cook.

This is a very tasty and tender (relatively) all-beef jerky that comes in a handy 1.5 oz package perfect for a quick snack.  I like the taste better than most other brands, though it reminds me somewhat of a hot dog that has been left out for several hours. If you love chewing endlessly on a leathery piece of jerky, you will be disappointed by how tender this jerky is in comparison and, while it is a bit chewy, you'll find the 1.5 oz stick disappears quickly.Complaints about the salt content are a bit odd as it is jerky. They are all salty. It's a preservative. But yes, it does have about a quarter of a day's worth of salt in one serving, but on the bright side it is 12g of protein and only 90 calories, so if you limit sodium otherwise, it can still be a pretty health addition to your diet.  I also sampled their turkey with bron sugar jerky and was not as happy with that flavor.

Some of the Utopian movements detailed in this book are likely familiar names from early American history, as they were quite popular in their time. Yet, they all failed for one reason or another. Perhaps it is easy to say such attempts at a Utopian society are entirely sisyphean, or worse, but it is obvious through the narrative that many, many people believed sincerely in the promise that these movements gave of creating a peaceful, united community free of strife. The author does a terrific job with the flow of the book. Despite these 5 movements being independent of one another, the author is able to successfully connect them to each other and also manages to avoid dwelling too long on any point.  Overall, it is a great read for any pre-civil-war american history buff or those interested in learning about some of these novel movements.

Atheism gets a lot of criticism, especially on the supposed basis that it is a fairly recent construct. That is almost obviously not the case, but this book really provides a clear picture of what Atheism was in ancient times and I found the content even more engrossing than I expected. Not unsurprisingly, Atheists often had a tough time of it in the old world.
