The details of what Atheists faced when in the public eye was interesting, but I did find the author's definition of what an Atheist is to be less purely convinced against the possibility of supernatural forces and somewhat overlapping what I would consider agnosticism. Certainly, even today, the two are often conflated. Yet, to me, agnosticism is quite incompatible with atheism. Regardless, I enjoyed the book and the depth of historical research it provided in discussion of the various atheist figures and movements in ancient times.

I was immediately impressed by the production quality of this large, beautifully illustrated and printed book of puzzles. The whole "History of Mathematics" line doesn't really come across as prominently as I expected in the course of the puzzles. Within each chapter you go from one puzzle to the next without any text in between, but there is a narrative and the author does talk about specific historical figures, mathematical concepts and, of course, puzzles.  The puzzles all are rated by challenge and this makes it easy to use the puzzles in a classroom setting or otherwise. Most of the puzzles are not so hard, but there is a lot of variety and even the easier ones are interesting.  This book would be a perfect resources for a math teacher or as a coffee table book. It is far more interesting than pictures of Nantucket, I think. Overall, its a really terrific colllection of interesting puzzles that does manage to tell a story by taking the reader on a chronological journey through mathematical concepts via brainteasers.

Sage 50 (formerly Peachtree) Accounting software offers a single solution for most small businesses. You can keep track of payroll, inventory, accounts payable/receivable, job costing, financial reports and more. There is an additonal annual fee for  subscription service needed to use all of the payroll features and it will run you extra ($250 currently) after the first year, but this is the norm.Compared to QuickBooks and Quicken, Sage 50 is designed more toward accounts or those with some basic accounting experience and knowledge. It also tries to accomodate legacy users of the older software versions by keeping much of the interface familiar.The cost is not cheap, but it is the cheapest of three versions - Pro/Premium/Quantum.  Most small businesses will probably be fine with Pro, but if you have more than one or two people handling the accounting of your of business, then you should consider Premium and the extra savings potentially afforded by a multi-user license. Also, depending on the nature your of business, you may need the features of Premium over those of Pro.  Quantum is for larger enterprises with much higher volumes of data and is priced accordingly.Overall, Sage 50 is a feature-rich, well-organized, reliable accounting software system that can serve as the backbone for almost any small business given the proper trainng and knowledge.

I work as a consultant for large corporate clients and so I found the content quite relevant and helpful. The 47 strategies detailed in this book for effective project management and consulting really helped me hone in on how to improve my approach to work in general and somewhat realign my perspective working with clients.  While I found the content valuable, I can't say I really enjoyed the book. The conversational style of writing attempted to keep a smooth flow, but its a style that can detract from effectively communicating complex or detailed topics; and, it is best employed when there are more interesting anecdotes or narratives to keep the entertainment going.

This is a very tasteful piece of jewelry at such an unbeatable price point. The sterling silver is a great material choice for an affordable piece that doesn't look or feel cheap. The cubic zirconia add a little sparkle, but are way too small to be identified versus genuine diamonds. Overall, an attractive piece likely to please most mom recipients.

I have always loved board games, but video game adaptations are very hit and miss. This one packs in 4 of the most popular board games, all favorites of mine, out of which only one is a dud.Trivial Pursuit, Risk and Monopoly are all given fairly decent production values, but Scrabble did not receive the attention it deserves. Scrabble is an odd choice to include anyhow as it is the only game that really involves private player information (the cards in risk are not as problematic). Having to switch between players in Scrabble as implemented definitely slows the game down versus playing a physical copy, but it is largely unavoidable. A different game would have made more sense to include and maybe that is why the production values are lacking on this entry.Aside from Scrabble, the games work quite well. Trivial Pursuit also doesn't lend itself as readily to the video game format, but the game was reworked into more of a game show format and this was an excellent design choice that really makes Trivial Pursuit stand out as one of the best titles. Risk has a great interface as well and benefits from automation. Monopoly is also implemented well and it is fun. I used to play an old NES version a lot as a kid and this is certainly a step up, but the physical copy works better for larger numbers of players, especially considering trading.Overall, this is a fund title that gives you 2 terrific multiplayer games in Trivial Pursuit and Risk, 1 decent multiplayer/single player experience in Monopoly and 1 solid single player experience in Scrabble. Since the emphasis is on multiplayer, it would have made sense to replace Scrabble, but I am sure it will get some play time for 1 or 2 player games.

There are not a lot of video games my whole family can enjoy, but this is definitely one of them.  Yes, it is a bit goofy and somewhat embarassing, but that is part of the fun.  Just Dance takes itself a bit less seriously than Dance Central, which I prefer since I hardly learned to dance for real with that game. Of course it is the Disney music that really makes this game worth buying and there is a great assortment of hits and lesser known tracks.

This handheld device gives you a thermal visualization of your target area to help identify where water is building up.  It also offers a moisture reading by contact with the unit or using the cable ending in two pins. It all functions as promised and has a wide variety of applications, from home maintenance or inspection to agriculture.Having the images available to view or save is helpful for demonstrating a problem to someone or for documentating a problem for insurance or other purposes.
These liners look nice but could use a little more grip so they dont slide around.  The size is big enough to fit most cabinets and drawers.  Easy to throw in the washing machine for cleaning.
This girls shirt has a cute cut form and is a bit plain, but works well for uniform dress or more serious affairs. Quality is great for the price.

This dark navy cardigan is versatile enough to wear as a school uniform, for more serious occassions, or just as an additional layer when it gets cold. The material is tough but comfortable and it looks great.
This dark navy shirt is good for casual wear occassions or as a school uniform.  It is not likely to get your kid excited to get dressed, but it doesn't try...at all.

This big, colorful playset offers plenty of interactive features to keep your toddler engaged. There are pieces that connect together and come apart, things that make sound, figues and lots of detail.  A fun toy for any kud ages 1 to 4 years old.

While I generally favor warm / steam humidifiers, especially in the winter, I am impressed by how easy it is to clean this unit, which is always an issue with my steam humidifiers.  It also humidifies fairly well if you stick it in a small to medium size bedroom maybe up to 150 square feet or so.  Make sure to elevate it so the vapor has a chance to dissipate before falling onto the floor. Operation is quiet as expected.

This farm set is pretty fun for toddlers and offers a lot of interactive features to keep them engaged. There is a lot to do with the animal figures (which  you can buy more of on the not-so-cheap). There are pieces to fit together, things for the animals to do and the whole set has plenty of bright colors and sounds to add to the experience. I would recommend this toy for ages 1-4 years.

This cute dollhouse offers a lot of interactive features and tons of little details to keep your kid engaged. There is a lot of variety thanks to the outside walkway that connects together and the slide, as well as all the furniture and figures. True to VTech, the set is colorful and a-buzz with electronic sounds.  It is also a nice size, not huge, but large enough to make it easy to play with for young kids. I'd recommend it for ages 1-4 years old.

This card game is certain to please fans of Game of Thrones and card games in general. Gameplay is fairly original and fits quite well into the theme of the books/show. As is common with these types of games, the rules are fairly complex and take some getting used to, but I rather find that part of the charm of the game.  Art is terrific and the cards themselves are decent quality, but could be thicker. Overall, the game has a lot of replay value if you can get past the initial learning curve. Expansions to come should further enrich the experience.

Shipping fine chocolates is a tenuous affair. If I can't find the chocolate product I want in a store locally, I will usually order from an online retailer specializing in chocolate. However, that tends to cost more than Amazon, so if the weather is agreeable (throughout the US) then I order chocolates from Amazon. I have had success with Leonidas and now these Cailler chocolates have also arrived pristinely.These arrived packed in a custom fit cardboard box so that they fancy presentation box did not get dinged.  They look great and taste just as good.  They are quite up to the standards of similarly priced chocolates and superior to lindt or godiva. I do wish each piece were just a tad bigger, but then I would not be able to eat as many different ones. The variety is terrific and sure to please any chocolate lover.
It is a pleasant and distinct aroma that is masculine but in a modern sense. Some earthy or woody tones underlie a slightly fruity smell, with some spice.  Not too strong, but noticeable.

This 1 1/2 kid stroller is a practical compromise between a single and double stroller and works well depending on the age of your kids. Like most strollers, it doesn't work so great with a car seat, but better than most. The car seat makes it hard for the 2nd kid to find a comfortable position.For the price, it is built pretty well and barring any rough treatment, it should last for years. Handling is mediocre at best; along with the spartan sunshade it is the weakest area for the stroller. Its best feature is how light it is compared to a double stroller.  The storage caiacity is also helpful.

This dolled up version of Remington's best-in-class beard trimmer offers some much-needed accessories for those looking to maintain or cultivate a full-figured moustache or beard.  I have been fairly happy with a similar Philips Norelco featuring a vacuum system to reduce mess, but this is a more effective, flexible and precise tool.The accessories, which set this package apart from the regular trimmer, are wortwhile to have. I especially like the wide range in trimming lengths they afford. All that is missing is some beard oil.

This compact toaster oven is the perfect size for those without a lot of counter space to spare.  The interior is a little over 9x9 inches. It handles basic toasting and baking just fine, but is hampered by its capacity when baking as it fluctuates in temperature more than a larger toaster oven. It is also lacks some of the features of Hamilton Beaches' modestly more expensive units, like convection. But if you like the size of this one, it is a good value.

This wood toy is simple but fun and requires kids to use hand-eye coordination, spatial skills, and their imaginations.  The game is a suitable challenge for kids around 4 to 7 years old, give or take.

This book covers all manner of familiar things (oddly many unique items are included, like the Empire State Building). The book is quite packed with pictures and information, routinely placing three items on a page.  Organization by subject makes it easy to jump around. Most importantly, there is a good mix between detail and an economy of words, with the emphasis on brevity.  Some items inevitably feel shortchanged, but I am eager to fill my thirst formore with the first volume now.

This rug cleaner was very effective and pleasant smelling.  It got a lot of stains out that had been in our carpets for a long time, but the darker stains are still faintly visible. Considering how old the stains are, I did not expect much, but was impressed overall.

The kids (5 and 8) absolutely love this toy and were blown away by what it can do.  They have been playing with it every day. The track, which can be configured many ways and expanded with 2-piece packs sold separately, is quite large. The cars take one lap around to learn the track setup and then they are ready to race.  What really sets this toy apart though is that each car (2 included; more for sale) has a very distinct set of 3 special powers and also different base attributes, like in many racing video games.  The cars can attack each other and it is fun even just to watch.  Each car is controlled by an android or iOS device (not included) and the controls are surprisingly tight and refined. I would recommend it mostly for ages 6+ but some 5 year olds may be able to handle the controls. There really is no upper limit for age; it is just such a fun toy.  I especially like how even though it uses electronics it really is not a digital experience and is more social and constructive than video games. The expansions are not cheap, so consider the additional costs you are likely to incur, but I find this starter kit is priced reasonably for what you get.

This is a cool alternative to Legos that my kids really enjoyed.  It is not a big set, but like Legos, you get a lot of replay value. Quality is pretty good, and pieces fit nearly as perfectly as Lego (which they can be used with), providing a non-frustrating building experience suitable for ages 5+.  Plus my kids love anything that lights up or glows in the dark.

Honestly I have little certainty over how well this stuff really works, but a long time ago I read phosphotidylserine was great for post workout of strenuous exercise.  I have taken this kind of supplement ever since.  The addition of PA should also be beneficial. What I can say for certain is that the price point is reasonable compared to other brands and there are no noticeable side effects.

We usually get Nordic Naturals, but these seem quite comparable in potency and lack of pungency. The importance of fatty acids is well documented and has a statistically significant contribution toward cognitive function.  My wife takes these along with Rainbow Light prenatal vitamins.

I have been in need of a new electric for some time as my current (made in Japan) Panasonic that I love no longer holds a charge. This shaver is similarly oriented, like a Braun, which makes it much easier to maintain facial hair versus the radial design of a Philips Norelco.Overall performance is great.  It  produces a smooth shave, though rougher than my Norelco.  Very little razor burn and I love the beard trimmer attachment, as I was about to replace my Philips beard trimmer as well.  It could use some longer settings though.  While I am not confident it will last nearly a decade like my old Panasonic, it is a great shaver for the price.  Fyi, with my old one I cleaned it a few time a month by hand and replaced the blades annually.

This is one of the milder Poo-Pourri scents. Deja Poo is a bit sweet smelling with vanilla and the usual citrus. It is a fairly good scent, if a bit feminine.  As usual, the product works as advertised.  Size is convenient for home or travel.

My wide and I are not thrilled with all the toys we have that take up a lot of space and use batteries. However, VTech's Flipsies are actually quite decent toys at a reasonable price.  This boathouse offers a lot of interaction, which is key.  My 5 and 3 year old play with it a lot and have not gotten bored with it, as happens all too often after just a couple days.  I would rather have toys that are fun then ones that are just bug or cheap.  This one offers the best of all worlds.  It is just a fun toy that requires some imagination and with the addons available, it will definitely last well through the holiday season.

This is a very attractive piece that offers a classic but updated look.  The natural brown and white diamonds provide a nice contrast, though at such a small size, I don't know if it makes a big difference to use genuine dianomnds versus imitation ones.

This cute piece of jewelry is smartly themed with every girl's favorite movie, Frozen.  But it is a nice piece rregardlss for any girl at this price point. It wont be mistaken for real jewelry, but it does not look cheap either.
These underwear are a bit thin, but quite breathable.  The colors are attractive and the fit is comfortable.  Overall a nice set for a reasonable price.

I pity anybody who lacks the opportunity to try this delicious beverage.  Among bloody mary cocktail mixes, it is both king and queen. I enjoy drinking it straight or otherwise.  These cans are the perfect serving size either way.  Best on ice.  They also make a horseradish flavor and one that is bold and spicy if you prefer.

This thing is much larger tgan I imagined it would be.  It holds a lot of mouthwash and is meant to stay on the counter so you can dispense mouthwash by the dose. It works very well, but it is fairly unnecessary.  I almost prefer refilling a travel size Listerine bottle, but this is more civilized. So you probably dont need it to begin with, but if you do get it you will mot be disappointed.

I didnt really get the concept of the book, or maybe the company making it didnt.  The book is about different mysical instruments, which is nice, but the only music comes from the notesattsached to the book.  It plays a little music box melody.  Why not play sounds relating to the instruments in the book?  Anyway, it is for babies and they have no idea what is going on, so my kid likes the book just fine, but it is poorly executed and feels incomplete.

My aged hulking UPS/power strip is so old that it barely lasts long enough in an outage for me to save files, let alone shutdown my computer. These things don't last forever. I wanted something a little different to replace my current UPS and I am glad I went with APC's BGE50ML.Having access to the internet is really the main concern in a short blackout.  This device will keep you powered for 2 to 8 hours and best of all, if you forgot to charge your phone or are running low on energy for any usb device, you can charge it portably. I will probably get another large UPS power strip eventually, but this is a great product for any power outage.

Rest assured, this is a terrific product. It works well, it has a superior product design, is extremely durable and, while it looks ramrod straight, it is in reality as maneuverable as a team of gymnasts.Plainly put, if you like the way it looks you wont be disappointed. It is what the ad says: a great lamp.Heres what I like about it: First, I love its design. It has a sleek modern look, but I think it will fit into lot of decors. I like its disguised simplicity: while it bears an initial similarity to a large hair straightener, this is deceptive in ways beyond the obvious.  A little over a foot in length (about 14-15), it has an interesting technology behind it that produces a diffuse light beam that doesnt glare like the old desk lamps from when I was young. This is not to say it isnt bright; it is. Quite. But it doesnt hurt your eyes when youre working nearbyand it is easier to understand when you look at the schematic they provide about why that is (Ill leave it to you to read the product info).There are also a lot of forms it can take: it can be bent into a lot of different variations from the norm. Straight up, bent this way, bent that way, tilt the head away, tilt it towardit really has a wide array of ways that this can be used. And it has three brightness levels for whatever use it might be designated for, the time of day, and so on. And if you dont like cords you can even unplug it. The lamp will work for 8 hours without being plugged in. Not that its made for this, but you can even use it as a rather oddly shaped and purposed flashlight. It doesnt even have to go on a deskthere is a small aperture through which a hook/fastener can attach to it and it can be hung from a wall.But beyond its looks, which again, I like a lot, it simply works well. Twist it this way or that, youre going to hear a click. Things simply lock in place, and youll feel like the product is going to stay in the formation you set it in. Its REALLY designed cleverly.About all I can say as points of advice are:Make the base of the lamp either a little larger, or heavier or both. There are a couple of configurations that I would love to set up where the lamp cannot stand, or does so for a while and then tips. While I love the wide array of choices, there are indeed a couple that don't work, and it's almost always because the base cannot support the configuration. Again, I must point out this is very definitely in the minority.Consider other shades/colors: black, silver, grey  even colors. I love the white, but I think other shades would increase its marketability.But other than that I can hardly think of any other suggestions; its darn near perfect as it is.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

The Aoneky Magnifying Glass is near perfect: I like its look and I very much like the clarity it delivers when it comes to reading the fine print on so many products nowadays. (If youll permit me this one sort of off-base rant: why do so many shower hair products make their print unreadable in the ONE PLACE NO ONE CAN WEAR GLASSES!?)Additionally, if you are at all like me I love to look through optical devices. I love kaleidoscopes, I love crystal, I love telescopes,, and I love magnifying glasses. There are all sorts of things one can discover with them: small print, little doo dads, bugs (sorry, women), the miniature nature of mechanical objects  you name it: theres a whole world out there waiting to be discovered.And so, back to the Aoneky Magnifying Glass: I like how crystal clear the product renders small objects, and it is easy to hold and delivers a very readable and legible lucidity to small print when the lens is held at out six inches off the surface of whatever Im reading (a very easy-to-attain distance). Ive also noticed it allows my face to be a good foot away from the surface of the lens  again, a very easy-to-attain distance. I say this because I am a back pain sufferer and have no ability to maintain my posture in some bent-over position for ANY length of time. And this is, I am sure, a problem MANY people face who need the magnifying glass: Okay, yes, OLD people. Like me.A really nice thing is also that the lens is indeed made of glass. Thats a significant thing: plastic warps under light, and it can scratch and get cloudy with time. And yes, glass can scratch too, but it is at least a fault that IS avoidable with a little care. (Things like cloudy plasticnot so much.)I also like that the magnifying glass has some heft to it  while the rosewood handle is attractive, it is act ually quite light, but the glass and its rim are, together a little weighty  about 5 and a half ounces, or a third of a pound. Thats extremely light overall, I think most will agree, but that small amount of weight gives the lens and frame a little substance which I think makes it much easier to handle that way. I find that the lighter something is the easier it is to fumble around  and harder to hold steady. Without heft, the lens would be simply too easy to let slip in and out of focal range. That heft gives it mass without making it burdensome.Now, mind you, the heft SHOULD NOT give anyone a problem. I say this knowing there are extreme cases. For instance, though a certain older woman but-not-exactly-my-mother passed away some time ago and I honestly COULD see her complaining about something like this. In fact, there was practially nothing on this planet that could not have some fault or the other, and in this case I can see her telling me that the Aoneky is too heavy for her to hold it. Perhaps that is why the handle is able to be unscrewed (something I talk about in the next paragraph). It might give those who dont want the weight at the end of a handle  the rule of the fulcrum and all  so it is possible that unscrewing the handle and letting the person hold the brass frame itself may help, but I think thats really being quite picky.As to that handle: I dont prefer it being removable. I say this knowing that Ive just come up with a (very picky) reason why one might want it to be, but it still doesnt thrill me. To even argue against myself further I suppose that it might allow some to work more easily in some cases, like a crowded workspace or some kind of greater maneuverability, but I am still not a big believer in it. But, EVEN IF IT WERE IMPORTANT: why, oh why does it have to ALWAYS COME LOOSE? The handle is forever loose! I find it very distracting and, mind you, I really like the magnifying glass. But even given all those other things, why does the little nub at the otherwise entirely superfluous metal nib come loose? And worse, it is always falling off  is it so that we will store secret messages within the hollow handle?  Come to think of it, maybe Ill do that myself. Right after I glue the little sucker on permanently. To my way of thinking, this is a problem that doesnt have to exist.To close up, while I dont like that those two parts come loose easily, I do very much like the Aoneky Magnifying Glass. I am an inveterate Saver of Things, and I now keep my Aoneky in an old fuzzy felt-like bag with a drawstring at the end, and that keeps the magnifier nearby without letting it get scratched. Its a nice add-on feature I (and you might) like.All in all, a great product that does me a lot of good in my old age.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

I'm really very pleased with the UniBall Jetstream: it's a roller ball pen -- a product that I love -- and it writes beautifully: it produces a nice, even line with no smearing or interruption. For some reason this has been a difficult refill to find, and I'm glad that Amazon has it.I like the .7 mm size because (like Goldilocks) I am frequently displeased by the extreme thinness of the .5 or the heavy fullness of the 1.0. The .7 is a nice alternative, allowing the ink to still show the fine traits of a narrow tip, but still produce a writing line that has clarity and definition. I frequently feel the very fine points are just too wispy and minimal.Anyway, a great refill at a really good price  Nice job, Amazon!

If youve ever hungered for a low-priced speaker ($34 at the time of this review) that delivers bass as well as it does treble, this is the speaker for you.Im really blown away by how well it reproduces sound like a much more expensive speaker  while most of these inexpensive products deliver higher pitch music through tweeters quite effectively, its the woofers that never seem to effect a very powerful sound. Here, though, the solution is provided by a mere three letters (and a hyphen if youre counting): a SUB-woofer is doing the work here, and it does a terrific job.Woofers (which got the name for reproducing a dogs low-pitched bark) work in the lower range of human hearing: somewhere around 20 to somewhere below 20,000 Hz. But a sub-woofer is more specific: it usually specializes in the 20-200 Hz. range, and thats what youre hearing with this speaker. Interestingly enough, sub-woofers only really became an issue when computerization of sound became so sophisticated that we could really faithfully reproduce this  lower range  which often substituted volume for intensity  was accessible to the products the average person could own that reproduced this sound  like CDs, for instance.Now, please note that Im putting this in commonly referred to generalities: I havent seen any exact specs when it comes to this speaker. But put me down as a believer: Ive heard this speaker and I love it, and its now my go-to at home for reproducing sound off my little laptop, and for once Im REALLY impressed by the sound my (nothing special musically) Sony Vaio makes.Theres a picture I-Venstar supplies that makes these speakers look huge  it dominates the picnic blanketl being used by two joyous romantics  but to me this is using the wrong kind of psychology. Its the tiny-ness of these speakers that makes the great sound quality so extraordinary: its about as big as a loaf of Melba toast as long as my outstretched hand. (Maybe if a congregation of ants were to carry it off under their stunned supervision.) Call me crazy, but I think its relatively small size is a terrific selling point: being able to transport great sound in a package smaller than a tube of tennis balls is pretty sensational  at least to me. (See my picture of it compared to a universal DirecTV remote.)Anyway, the speakers are rubberized and seem virtually indestructible to everyday use. It also helps it be "grippy" on smooth surfaces, so even placing it on a slightly slope-y incline is usually no problem. NOTE: I-Venstar says it is water resistant but warns not to submerge it. (Hence: use near the shower, not IN it.) It operates off a Li-ion battery, and has jacks for connection through micro USB or 3.5mm audio cable if you wish.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This is my third or fourth different review for glass screen protectors, and if you've read the others please realize I might repeat myself a bit. I love the clarity and sharpness of glass -- plus the protection factor -- and I absolutely refuse to let my phone go without one anymore.I'll talk about the glass first, and will discuss why I deducted a point for this otherwise fine product in the second-to-last paragraph.FIRST:I'm a big glass screen proponent: they are are remarkably clean and "crisp" when it comes to their appearance. In my experience, glass provides a truer, more authentic image than does plastic. That's true from the first minutes of its use and only gets better as time goes on. Glass cleans up better; I find that with plastic there is a certain degradation due to build up no matter how much you clean it. Glass holds up better than plastic.The thing I really like about glass screen protectors is how hard they are and how sharp the image comes through. I cant tell you how often I look at my screen and say, Wow! to myself because of how remarkable the bright, striking image looks. Im not making this up: take care of your screen, keep it under glass and keep that glass clean (and not simply by rubbing it on your pants or with your shirt-tail) and youll see what I mean.But this is important: take reasonable care of your screen protector  that is, keeping it clean and not wiping it off on your sooty OshKoshes after a day of roadwork, the GLASS protectors look beautiful; even stunningly so  depending of your care of them. I keep little packets of Zeiss Pre-Moistened Lens Cleaning Wipes nearby (they cost only about six cents per wipe) for my phone, tablet, and my glasses and the result is worth it.Now, as to whether the ballistic glass is actually more responsive due to the improved technical process that allows it to be thinner than standard glass screens, time will tell. More on that laterI've seen that some reviews have complained that the instructions weren't complete or that they weren't clear, but I did not encounter that problem. I thought the instructions included were pretty clear and besides, the kit included a URL address for an installation video that spelled everything out even clearer. I think installing glass screen protectors is WAY easier than plastic ones, especially when it comes to bubbles. As I said earlier, I've installed several glass protectors and I find that bubbles are quite easy to clear up in glass, while plastic installation is pretty problematic that way.The only reason I deducted a point off the final score is that I felt Exheed could do better when it came to the double package it provides of screen protectors. Specifically, while Exheed includes two screen protectors, they only supply one of the little alcohol wipes and only one of the little tape removal sheets, two items that are really important when it comes to making a proper cleaning of the surface upon which the glass is placed. Granted, if you're doing two phones at once then you can probably get by with only one of each. But if you're being frugal or cautious and are going to set the other one aside, then you have don't have the proper prep kit anymore.Otherwise, this is a great kit.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

I am maybe the perfect example of a person who gets tremendous value from this little kit. I am a card-carrying House Husband right now. My wife works hard outside of the house.Ive never taken any real sewing lesson other than watching my mom do this kind of work (much better on her worst day than I ever could on my best) and asking questions of herand all this 30 to 40 years ago. I dont buy sewing magazines. I only occasionally see Pinterest pages (which I admit I love) and I have no projects Im working on. I am NOT especially talented. But I know how to do basic work and I know when a kit like this comes out an gives us a great little product.1. + ITS GOT A SECURE LITTLE BOX:It has a nice, easy to open format and a hard but not too thick structure to it. If it falls the kit holds together as long as its zipped shut.2. + ONCE OPENED, EVERYTHINGS IN A LOGICAL ORDER:Even a guy like me knows where stuff is hereits all very visible and makes sense. The two exceptions are the pins and safety pins, whose bags I wish were strapped in a little betterIm always picking them up off the ground (but theyre at least in bags, which helps).3. + THE THREAD COLORS WERE REALLY WELL PICKED:Intuition tells me there will be some disagreement as to this, but I like these colors and shades. I know Im not the most intelligent or fashionable person, but they look like great choices in colorsthey have a great deal of range and (I think) they represent a pretty full range of colors.4. + EVERYTHING ELSE IS OF VALUE:Youve probably seen the list: lots of sewing needles and threads, scissors and a standard but nice little thread cutter. I was a little put off when a needle bent quite early into its use. I think I was probably using it against its ability level (I was trying to mend a tear in my couch, and perhaps the material was a little too tough for it.) Still, it didn't last very long.5.  I WOULD HAVE LIKED A LARGER THIMBLE:There are times I have to get needles through tough fabric: a couple of layers of jeans, for instance, or worse. Even tough guys will use a thimble (though maybe they look over their shoulders before taking it out).6. + THEYVE INCLUDED TWO THREADING HELPERS:Good for them. I always have trouble finding them, and an extra one will do a lot of good. One came apart though, right after I used it for about four or five threadings, and when I tried to fix it the backing just collapsed under my fingers.. Lucky for the extra one.7. + /- THEY HAVE WHAT APPEARS TO BE A GOOD GUARANTEE (BUT ITS NOT WRITTEN OUT)They do however ask you to email their offices about any problem with their product, and promise 100 percent satisfaction.In closing, it bears mentioning that my mother actually gave me a little kit like this when I headed off to college.ALMOST HALF A CENTURY AGO. No lie. Anyway, I still have it and, more importantly, I still use it. I add a button here or there, and I get a little thread here or there, but the kit is basically the same.  And now that kit may retire to the back of the closet while this new kit takes over. I think its probably earned its rest.So, four stars: it's a good kit, and has a lot to offer for it, but some of the earliest uses terminated two of the products. But there were a lot of others to take its place.NOTE: I was supplied with this product free of charge with the sole stipulation that I provide an unbiased review, which this is.

Being retired and not having done any Christmas shopping yet, I havent run into any RFID scanners recently. RFIDs are the Radio Frequency Identification information that are encoded within the magnetic strips on your credit and store cards, and they are in definite need of being protected from outside illegal scanning...how often do we hear of ID theft and the horrors associated with it?So in this particular case (and I assume, most others), my review will have to operate on the assumption that the cards offered by RFID Secure do indeed protect the cards from being scannedwhich I believe is a safe assumption. That being said, what matters is1 HOW EASY THEY ARE TO USEAs one might expect, these cards couldnt be simpler to use and the card fits neatly inside. Theyre just about a perfect sleeve within, too: not sticky, but not too slide-y either.2 HOW WELL THEY FITAbout the only negative I could come up with is really picky. Simply put, while the sleeves easily fit the main pockets allotted them, these sleeves dont fit within some of the slots where wallets typically allow placement of credit cards or other similar cards. In other words, if you want the cards to "wear" the sleeves as protection, yo'll have to be very mindful of finding very particular wallets or other methods of holding them. (Truthfully, given the importance of protecting ones personal information nowadays, I might consider whether the wallet goes before the sleeves. REALLYin fact, it might be wise for companies to consider.)OVERALL:I do not have a passport, so I did not find a use for that particular sleeve. As for the ones I did use, I selected the rather straightforward white sleeves because I liked their simplicity. I suppose down the road there will be all sorts of colors and styles. I think the overall ratings are a great indication of how well this product works: at the time of this review there were 95 % of them at 4s and 5s (with 82 % being 5). Those are HIGH numbers.So, yes, I have been really pleased with the sleeves, and feel the RFID Secure people have done a nice job with designing them so that they are about as snug as one could expect a sleeve could be. You really cant fit another card within, and I could find no portion one could really shorten or reduce otherwise. Theyre effective, theyre easy to use, theyre made just about perfectly, and they look good. Thats just about perfect in my book.NOTE: I was supplied with this product free of charge with the sole stipulation that I provide an unbiased review, which this is.

My first reaction to the Raqpak Reflective Cord came as I took it out of the bag and I saw the striking yellow color and reflective propertiesthis rope really looks cool.My second reaction was one of relative amazement as it came completely out of the bag: it was really compact, measuring lengthwise about the size of my outstretched hand, and its bundled thickness was a close to the size of my  fist.But I became hooked if youll pardon the pun, when I began using it on little projects outside the house: I strung it up on our old clothesline to see how it held weight over a distance of 25 feet. To test this, about two days ago I tied one end of the old clothesline T (that was still up, obviously), pulled it over the opposite end and pulled tight and anchored it. There was almost no feeling of stretching once it reached its maximum length, and I took that as a good sign: you dont want tent lines, say, to stretch.Anyway, it was fine for clothes I took some items out on hangers and it held up well. For a thin cord it had a great tensile strength and showed no signs of breaking. Additionally, the terrific "reflectivity" of the strands makes the cords really show up when I went into the yard at night: Whereas I frequently scalp myself (there are some areas in the yard where the clothesline is at right about high forehead height, which is hilarious to my much shorter wife and children. Well, the jokes on them now, because Ill always see the cord ahead of time  (unless Im wearing my darn ball cap, like last night, and the bill obscures itOUCH! No fault of the rope there.)I also cut a few lengths of it and used them to tie up wood bundles and they held greatthe bundles were about the size of the ones you see at grocery stores and held about six forearm-length wood sections. With these little bundles you have to use two strings on each bundle, as the wood would shift too much with only one string. It held great.The great thing about this cord is how brightly it reflects: you can see this at night REALLY easily as long as there is a light source somewhere nearby so it can reflect. This makes it super intelligent to use as say, tent cords, as any late night trips that usually end with someone tripping over them. The danger in falling is not only the tripping over the string, but also the persons possible landing into one of the pegs pounded into the groundsome of those pegs are metal and can cut the person falling on them. My sister needed stitches one summer because of them.While the cord is really thin  about the width of shoelaces  it is really strong. The company says it has a 360-pound break strength, and I can believe it. As I said before, I think this is probably a terrific cord for small tasks where string is NOT an option and you dont need full ropes. As it is VERY light  the whole 100 foot cord runs in the area of five ounces, counting the bag it comes in  and this makes it extremely wise for camping. It adds almost no weight to your camping gear.This is an excellent cord to have around for all sorts of reasons. Now that I own it I know that if I were ever to go camping again I would HAVE TO take this cord.. i could be either cut ahead of time to make putting up a tent ahead of time, or it could simply be brought along to help with any number of uses on an outing: bundling items, setting traps, clothesline, hanging up food to keep it free from pests, shoelaces, lashing down gear and so on.NOTE: I was supplied with this product free of charge with the sole stipulation that I provide an unbiased review, which this is.

My first reaction when I received this Camping Light was how tiny it was: so compact that it easily fits into my pocket. But if I thought its LENGTH was tiny, I was still in for another shock:I looked at the bulb. About the diameter of the head of a finishing nail  or for those unfamiliar with nail sizes, think of it this way: see this O? It would fit in that circlewith room to spare.But heres a case where size doesnt matter: while I wouldnt use it to read by, it will certainly illuminate your room, take you around outside the house on a moonless night, take away your fears in the dark basement of your house (well, at least some of them), help you find things under the couch, and so on and so on. Its really a fine little illuminating aid.And whats even better is that it has this slidey little end (where the transparent plastic sheathe is), that allows you to adjust it by sliding the bulb closer to the little metal dish at the end of the sheath, or move the dish away from the bulb and allow the light to become diffused through its hazy plastic sides.One of the things I really like about this flashlight is that it not only has the ability to either blip three times fast (and then faster), but it doesnt have to happen EVERY time, thereby freeing you from having to cycle through the unnecessary steps every time you use it. True, if you click it in a regular on, then off, then on, then off, etc. pattern you will travel through the five cycles: 100%, 50%, 25%, fast strobe, slow strobe (or SOS). If you pause at any point, however, you will break the pattern and have to start over. I LOVE THAT. Im so glad that it makes you follow a short specific sequence to bring it about, and does not occur EVERY time you turn your flashlight on and off  which is a major pain.I also like that the sliding mechanism can be used by the person holding it in one hand WITHOUT having to use the other hand. The one-handed operation  helps an great deal when, say, you're near the edge of the woods, or on the side of the road changing a tire, or any other scenario, when you hear a noise. If you're carrying something you do NOT have to put it down to use the little sliding mechanism...which really simplifies things.A few closing facts: the supplied battery is an 18650 battery, which Im finding is getting more common nowadays. One tiny downer: I did not receive an orange filter with my battery, but I have decided to live on without it. And finally, there is a small colorful lanyard that comes with it, which I found supplies an added benefit if you attach it: it prevents your flashlight from rolling off the surface its on. Thats a nice little feature..in addition, it should be mentioned that the one-handed operation of the device I just mentioned -- the sliding feature -- is that much better when you're wearing the lanyard. It really eases operating the device with one hand when you're absolutely sure you won't drop it.NOTE: I was supplied with this product free of charge with the sole stipulation that I provide an unbiased review, which this is.

THE LOST FLEET: FEARLESS is a terrific book in its own right, and also as an important book in the series. While it continues the strong writing of author Jack Campbell (a pseudonym for John G. Hemry), it also quite necessarily advances the central conflicts within the novel AND the series.Of course, there are the Syndics (The Syndicate has been at war with the Alliance ever since the time of Acting Commander John Gearys century-long hibernation), but the beauty of the authors writing comes from his ability to keep several metaphorical plates spinning at the same time. Not only does he have to return his fleet to their allies along with the hypernet key they successfully smuggled away, but he must do so while continually proving his abilities as a leader to this men (a term that in the military applies to women as well). At the same time he must prove to them that he is John Geary the man, not Black Jack Geary the legend  while he doesnt mind using the alias to psych out his enemy, he knows that his legendary status is just too impossible to maintain. He fears (and rightly so) that the greatest challenge he will face is when that image finally falters in their eyes and they are crushed by the realization.Another interesting aspect about keeping the legendary Black Jack identity at bay is that it employs the otherwise secondary character of Madam Co-President Victoria Rione as a restraining force on his continual rise to greater acceptance, and this is important in two ways. First, it serves as a check as to whether or not he is becoming too powerful, and then in an equally important role for the reader Rione often serves as a foil for Geary. She is a character who helps project or define his character traits  as well as a clarifier of his tactics, motivation, or any other aspect the reader is likely to need explained.As a prime example, early in the novel Geary invites Rione to sit beside him to explain rumors she may be privy to, and she offers the following:You know I distrust youAt first it was because I feared the hero worship that could make you as big a threat to the Alliance and this fleet as the Syndics. Now its because of that, and because youve proven yourself a very capable man. The combination is very dangerous. I like Rione, though I admit she can sometimes be a bit repetitive with her negativity. Overall, though, I think Campbell makes good use of her as a valuable check on Gearys power.And that power gets a severe test in this book: when they free a Syndic penal colony one of the men they liberate is a legend himself: captured two decades ago, Captain Fighting Falco is a man as gifted at self-promotion as he is at compelling his men to fight the enemy. When Geary refuses the mans offer to take the fleet on a very dangerous mission, Falco feels Geary to be too timid and he mutinies, taking a sizeable chunk of the fleet with him. Again, it is time again for Geary to be tested and to see if he is worthy of the command he now holds.One other thing: though there is more fighting in this book than there was in DAUNTLESS, the first novel in the series, it is still a credit to the author that his novel can maintain itself as a military sci-fi while still being a book that primarily discusses factors such as discipline, strategy, ethics, leadership, the abuse of power, and other dynamics of war and leadership that I find fascinating. I was a high school teacher, and when Campbell writes about war I find that his book teaches me as well, showing me how to use leadership as a way to motivate those I lead without demeaning them, to lead with positivity and wisdom and openness.  I find these books fascinating in that regard.Its a testament to his skill that he does it so well. Its obvious from Campbells writing he was not only a Navy lieutenant commander, but also a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy: his tactics at constructing a complex fleet-wide battle scenario are well-described and boast a strong sense of logic,-- interesting particularly because he must do this in a naval conflict that adds one full dimension to a battle on water.Two last notes: First, ever since the first book I was enthralled with the authors decision to emphasize the physics of relativity and distance when it comes to space battle: its battles have a slow and almost maddening pace to them, since millions of kilometers are being crossed every minute. Messages take seemingly forever to reach their counterparts, as to the weaponry and maneuvering.  So many books and movies paint space battles as taking no more time than across a field, and its refreshing to see how Campbell denies such tactics as scientifically false.Second, and finally: there is a two distinct things being foreshadowed in this book, and both have something to do with the hypernet gates. I will not discuss them except to say that while one has to do with scientific considerations, the other has to do with boundaries, and the implications of just how these gates came into the hands of the Syndics. Both are potentially powerful when it comes to further installments of the series, and I look forward to their impending developments.

When I was young I was playing with my brother and at a key moment I zigged when he zagged. His face hit the edge of our coffee table and the collision opened a gushing wound above his eye that required several stitches to close itthere was so much blood that I was more traumatized, I think, than my brother was.The odd thing was that the coffee tables edges were extremely blunt. The edge probably took  to  of an inch on the horizontal AND  the vertical to carry out the edge. But the edge was wood, and my brothers skin was between it and his skull and, well, something gave. Horribly.In retrospect, the Edge Mellow Edge & Corner Cushion would have been a great solution. It is a quality product that should make the edges of any table, shelf, desk or safe...in fact, its SO cushioning and safe that you have to be sure, I think, to avoid using it on anything like stairs for fear that it might trip people. AND it might make for a fun thing for children to play with, as it does present itself as a very pleasant-feeling object that they might want to pick at.The process of applying it as almost a no brainer. It comes with double sided tape that goes on the interior of the edging and then the edging material simply is pressed to the corner or edging youre trying to protect. The directions it comes with are easy to follow as well. They warn you about things like making sure to measure it first before laying out the edgingyou dont want to stretch or bunch the materials; as you can assume, that would compromise the longevity of your cushioning. Also, be aware of the wood finishing, and so on)Other than the two things Ive mentioned (that children might pick at it and that its so large that you shouldnt use it where footing is involved), I would only mention that its a bit expensive: $1 per foot. I know that its a lot less than hospital bills, so that should outweigh all other considerations, but consider that a coffee table thats about 5 feet by about 2  feet will cost about $15. Should you have a couple of end tables, a TV stand, shelves, and so on, it could mount up. But again: the trauma it will save you is really worth it: imagine sitting in an emergency room and looking at your childs face: thats worth a bit more than a $1 a foot, Im sure. (And all products that I checked  quickly  cost about the same.)(Plus, remember that you only have to cover EXPOSED corners and edgesif half the end table is against the wall and, say, a chair, you dont have to cover those edges. That helps.)This kit comes with 18 feet of cushioning and four corners.NOTE: I was supplied with this product free of charge with the sole stipulation that I provide an unbiased review, which this is.

I must admit that I seem to have a weakness for anything that G4Free puts out: their line of bags is without fail wisely conceived and well manufactured out of strong, durable materials. This bag is no exception.This Tactical Waist Pack  which is to me a more tech-savvy way of saying fanny pack, (more on that later) shows their typical use of high quality material and smart workmanship, with no skimping anywhere along the process. Just handling it gives you that feel of a great product: a strong, durable high intensity 600D polyester fabric and really great stitching, nicely squared seams, etc.As for the aforementioned D, I did a little checking, and found that the D refers Denier, a term  get readythat designates the fabrics weight (in grams) when it came to the standard 9,000 meters of that fiber. All that essentially means is more or less what youd think: that 600D polyester is stronger than, say, 400D polyester; 600D nylon is stronger than 400D nylon, etc. (And nylon is incidentally stronger than polyester, if you wanted to know.)  Polyester is used in particular for its propensity toward water resistance and durability.All stitching is extremely professional and all seams are well secured. Seams are stitched in accordance with necessity  that is, most seams are single stitched, but there is double stitching where necessary.  I found no loose stitching, or even threads that extended past their seams (at the ends, where a lot of less stringently stitched products might let threads hang at their ends  a minor inconvenience, meaning little except as a sign of professionalism).One of the reasons this is no longer termed a fanny pack, by the way, is that the bag is highly versatile and can be carried in different mannerssuch as over the shoulder (which a lot of men, especially, prefer..also, we hate the term "fanny pack"). As such, this bag includes a strap with clips at both ends for a fast changeover.As for construction, up front is a small pouch that is covered by a velcroed lid, and this pouch can carry things around the size of a cigarette pack or deck of cards, a cell phone, etc. Behind it the spacious main compartment is zippered, and its dimensions are approximately 10 wide, 5 deep, and 5 tall. It would easily carry paperback books, larger cellphones, wallets, passport, foodwhat have you. Outside, on each end can be found side nets which allow for, again, a variety of small items to be placed within: smaller cellphones, pens, cigarettes, small cameras, keys, etc. The side nets are closeable by a nice rope that has a clasp that allows it to be tightened or loosened to exactly the dimensions you wish. ..therefore, a plastic bottle of water could fit within because once the nets rope is tightened, there would be no problem that the neck of the bottle would extend higher than the pouch. And, finally, behind the main pouch there is a thick padding that makes the pack extremely comfortable to carry around the waist.There are ample clips and clasps that come into play around the bag that allow for the products belt and other items to be attached to or tightened to your own specifications.Additionally, there is no shortage of, for a lack of better terminology, loops  though that term does not really do it justice. These consist of fabric sewn in such a manner that items can be slid through and securely carried: the strap, for instance, when not in use, or a small collapsible hat, or anything that could be rolled and slipped within.The bag comes in camouflage, black and tan, and the warranty information was not clearly stated at the time of this review (which Ive noticed is true of their other bags). I will tell you that I dont see much going wrong with this bag, but if you are worried about such things you can contact the manufacturer.NOTE: I received a free sample bag with no other stipulation than I write an unbiased review, which this is.

This is listed as having six pockets, and Id swear it has more. Every time I unzip this or unfold that or look behind here or there I find another one.I know this is intended for an around-the-neck use, but I have found that its also an excellent product to use within a back packslide it into an appropriately sized portion of the pack, and it really organizes a lot of otherwise problematic material: IDs, store passes, checkbook(s), a few pens or pencilsyou name it, having something like this within your pack gets a lot of stuff out of the way.However you use it, its a great organizer. It has two long zippered pockets (one on each side, vertically placed); a clear plastic ID slot; a big pocket that runs pretty much the whole length and breadth of the pouch; then ANOTHER one right behind it, both topped by the same cover (that has a small zippered pocket itself); then right behind that is YET ANOTHER similarly sized pocket backed by a mesh.Additionally, the passport holder is made of RFID-blocking material (which protects the identity-sensitive cards from being accessed by programs which can attempt to access those codes), and at the same time that material is moisture resistant...protecting the items within from moisture like rain as well as sweat.As to its quality, the stitching is uniform and all seams and materials appear to be top-notch. This is a quality pouch with a lot of pluses.NOTE: I received a free sample bag with no other stipulation than I write an unbiased review, which this is.

Owning a small farm, I have grown to appreciate having certain things which, when needed, live up to their potential. Sure, its nice to find a plastic product every so often and benefit from its inexpensive quality, but I often find that there are those products which just DO NOT hold up when made from plastic. This is a great example.This kind of a hose connector MUST hold the hose tightly and at the same time deliver the necessary amount of water. Yet time and again those plastic connectors lose their threads  or the on/off function gives way or any number of other problems occur, and whatever you THINK you saved comes up and bites you on the butt.BRASS WORKS. It may cost a little more at the onset, but it is SO worth it.This Y connector is a quality product. Ive used it for a couple of weeks now, and I find that it holds up extremely well.And yes, the connector uses plastic parts, but they are only buffering the actual metal part beneath it: the switches have a softer plastic covering them so that the metal doesnt cut into your finger, and likewise the plastic ring around the central connector that meets up with the faucet does much the same.Im impressed with this Y connector, and recommend it strongly.NOTE: I was supplied with this product free of charge with the sole stipulation that I provide an unbiased review, which this is.

When I took my computer out of the box I was immediately impressed. Mine is the model depicted on the products page  a white tablet within a black leather case  and I like the way it looks quite a bit. The case is a stiff, protective leather and seems well made: a bright white stitching around the edges of both sides is attractive in a minimalist manner, and I have no doubt that it will hold up for a very reasonable amount of time. The tablet itself is held in place by four metal tabs that grip it firmly.As for protection, I think the case does reasonably well as a first-line of defense. I have dropped the case from my seat to the floorprobably about 15-18 inches, and the tablet held up fine. I did notice that one of the tabs slipped a bit, and I dont know if it would hold up well if one were to allow it to, say, cartwheel down a flight of stairs, but thats in my opinion probably a bit past the limit of what a computer case should be asked to do. If protection is your biggest concern, I would place this product inside a larger briefcase or bookbag, one that would encase it more securely.The tablets interface is like that of your typical Android computer, and is pretty easy to navigate. Irulu includes a small and relatively simple manual to make startup and the basics clear, but being the proud possessor of a Y chromosome I set that aside early on and muddled through it on my own. While I did make the occasional blunder, I found it easy to get the handle of the basics very quickly, despite the fact that  as my wife will be glad to tell you  I am no genius on these things.Upon startup I was a little concerned the product might display its low cost: the immediate graphics in the first thirty or so seconds are relatively blocky and dull. But, luckily, after that I was VERY impressed. Using the supplied Google-included programs really spoke volumes about how nice this tablet is. I played several  very involved YouTube videos from suppliers like the CGBrothers (a great little site to subscribe to, by the way if youre into art, popular entertainment, fantasy and sci-fi). I set playback at 780p and, waiting no more than a few seconds to let each video spool out a little (to avoid pausing during play) I was VERY happy with both the picture (which was terrific) and the sound. The sound was decent on the tablets own merits and GREAT when I used earphones. For a low cost and small-ish 7 tablet I was really delighted.I played a few games that demanded good graphics and was similarly pleased. The Ihuru tablets graphics held up well, and gameplay went on without any real hitches. I found that about anything my phone could do well, this Irulu did well, too.I was a bit disappointed with the camera: when I photographed with it I thought that the pictures came out green-tinted. It should be stressed that I did NOT spend very much time trying to fine-tune this aspect. I would guess there are settings or program software fixes that will remedy this, but I am not a genius in this area and would recommend  your looking at other reviewers to see if they fared better.I downloaded Microsoft Words basic word-processing program and installation was simple. Upon usage, however, I found my first real problems with the tablet...in particular, its keypad. Simply put, I had a problem using the small keyboard supplied alongside the tablet. I have average-sized hands with somewhat stubby fingers, and I had a lot of issues with fitting my hands on the board. Eventually I was reduced to the single-fingered hunt-and-peck method of using one or two fingers on each hand to type out what I wanted to write. I think there is a distinct possibility that small women and, most likely, children will do much better. I do not think bigger hands will do well. If your hands can fit alongside each other with no more than a 9 wingspan then I think youll do just fine.As for the seven-inch screen, sure, the size is smaller than that of a big monitor. Couple that with the small keyboard and one could draw the conclusion that this is a bit too small. Still, one might do well to consider how well so many of us cope with the restraints placed upon us by our phones. Those keyboards are minuscule, with screens maybe 40 percent of the size of this screen, and I am constantly amazed at how well young people in particular can fly along with their typing on these androids.What this tabloid does do extremely well, therefore, is provide a middle ground for people who want the portability of a something about the size of a trade paperback without having to carry around a laptop or even a netbook. It plays videos and games extremely well, and additionally I think it will provide a lot better screen for those who use road mapping devices: its a lot bigger than the interfaces provided by phones as well as the screens of the old Garmin, Magellan and other GPS screens.While the specifics of the tablet are able to be seen on the product page, it does pay mentioning here that this device has a 16 Gig storage capacity (see NOTE 1 at end), and also has a slot for a Micro SD card allowing up to another 32 Gigs of storage. It weighs in at just one 1 1/4 pounds WITH the case, and will easily fit inside almost anything bigger than an overcoats pocket.And, as Ive mentioned, it has the basic Google operating system within, but it will allow for additional programs to be installed. And there are a zillion free apps available, though your actual counts may vary It has about a seven-hour battery life, and has a front and back camera. It comes with a one-year warranty.NOTE 1: While I am using the product page I was directed to by IRULU, my tablets Storage page states that the tablet has 16 Gigs, not 8.NOTE 2: I received a free sample bag with no other stipulation than I write an unbiased review, which this is.

Wow.I have just finished one of the most involved, complex, and enterprising books Ive ever read. While it is safe to say that at various points it is a novel that concerns itself with computer tech, societal metaphor, simulated reality, kidnapping, torture, detective work, quantum physics, alternate dimensions, political statement, romance, media criticism AND pizza, I still dont think Ive come near to covering it all.At the heart of DeepFREAK, however, is a William Gibson-like future in which the influence of computers and the internet are so burrowed into our psyche that it is almost impossible to ferret out where the one ends and the other begins. While it is quite obviously about a future world, it is to the credit of author Mars Dumont (a pseudonym combining two writers identities) that there is much about this world that IS like our own. BUT (and I am stressing this) it is a world in which the authors make no bones about MAKING YOU DO THE WORK. But as taxing as it might be at times, it is really the most honest way to tell their story.For instance, were this story to be immersed in the lives of, say, professional American football players, it would not be a stretch to expect most of their thoughts, words and deeds to be steeped in the jargon of their professionblitzes, the option pass, strong- vs. weak-side, hashmarks, shotgun formation, clipping, snap countsyou get the drift.So, now, consider this short excerpt from Chapter One concerning a character on his way to a market:He noticed the ClosedCircuit TV tracking him to Paranoid blasting in his ear pods. Kool. Reality soundtrack. Invisible drones and CCTV pods transmitting millions of images a second to algorithms crunching petabytes inside LibertyCorp computers. Non-stop surveillance. Facial recognition. Gait analysis. Security is freedom. Got nothing to hide, got nothing to fear, so the adverts said. Mind your own business, and the red lights dont go off. What was deviant was classified but changed all the time anyway. Flash deviant and the nanoDrones were all over you in seconds. Yeah, paranoia was Real. Everything in that paragraph works: little things, like linking a precisely descriptive Black Sabbath song with the ever-present fear these characters wear like a second skin. Its a world in which their concern for freedom has forced them to trade freedoms no American alive before 2001 would ever have done without. Heres where their future links so seamlessly to our presenta post-Patriot Act world in which increased security is freedom, even a world where drones and other surveillance cameras pass along petabytes (millions of billions) of information through shifting algorithms as to what constitutes a correct facial expression (or manner of walking or general persona). Think MINORITY REPORT (the book, movie or TV show).But its more than that: Dumonts terminology also feels right in its lexicon of expression, a world of iCops and creditChips and holo-images; where razz (cool) kids wear lumiDress clothes that are electronically illuminated and programmable; where holo-Artistes create unique holographic 3-D experiences; when wearable direct brain-to-net chips known as neuroNets give one the ability to share feelings electronically.Think: are we really so far from a world like this? And bear in mind that even IN this world there are those who fight such technological short-cuts: at the mild end are the freeGrazers, while at the far end is an elite group of techno anarchists known as (the) Switch.The book begins with a prank conducted by a group of artistic activists called, simply, BLANK. Like todays Anonymous group, here they are disapproving of the Supreme Courts ruling allowing corporations (here, Disney Corp.) to run for the presidency. (Remind you of a recent Supreme Court ruling?)  Blanks protest was a holo-projection of giant mouse ears upon all of the heads on Mount Rushmore  a prank that has authorities stymied, and quite upset.Like I said in the opening paragraphs, DeepFREAK (the term connotes something like a bad drug trip) presents a complex world that Ive simplified for the sake of this review. Its a wise move the authors made when they chose to include a fairly detailed glossary in future editions. The book does take on an incredible amount of subject matter within its pages -- there will be those who complain, Im sure, about the authors choice toward the end to simultaneously involve a really complicated sci-fi slant that decidedly amps the tension, a slant whose scientific validation is REALLY difficult to follow closely (I eventually chose to gloss over the tricky stuff).That aside  yes, DeepFREAK is technologically ornate, but it is a novel that provides readers with a world that seems to be both very much in the future, but is at its core a lot like our own. It is a tale in which the older generation (like me) may find themselves at a distinct disadvantage when it comes to the nuances of computer jargon, but like it or not it IS an unavoidable world thats a-coming. Think of the most indelible image of todays young staring into a hand-held phone as they tap away with their thumbs. And what percentage of us really protest anymore that the main purpose of those store club or member cards is really to track our habits and even our whereabouts? How long will it be before the Google glasses become so commonplace we wonder how we lived without them? And after that the chip in our heads?When that comes, we will inevitably look at books like DeepFREAK and lament just how right they were after all.

If you look at the picture at the top of this page, it really lets you see just how small and economical this belt is. You have two pockets in this belt (theres a ONE-pocket companion belt on Amazon a lot like this one here). Both of these belts are really good, and they really only differ in the number of pockets.Both belts have really nice pleats that are tucked behind their zippered pockets that help to increase their size while neither of the pockets are big, they can store large nutrition bars, keys, money, pens and pencils, pillsI surprised myself by placing an uncovered S5 Samsung camera within one quite easily. While the objects within are protected from moisture, the company makes it clear they are not fully waterproofed. In other words, light sweat and light drizzle, even light rain, should not get through. But dont dive into a pool with it  that could leave you disappointed.As to the quality of the belt, I felt it excelled hereall fabrics were securely attached and of high quality and that was true also of the zippers and clips and seams, etc. Additionally, the product really held up well  I pulled on them and twisted them and tried this and that with them and I was very impressed by their workmanship.The belt is made for waists from 27 to 43 inches, but it is constructed of an adjustable elastic strap which extends that waist size by several inches. The company guarantees that the belt will stay in place no matter how rigorous your workout.To sum up, this is a really well made belt that provides exercisers, as well as hikers or those just on a day trip, can use to keep their items secure and, if important, hidden.  This is water-resistant and well made, and should last for years.NOTE: I received a free sample bag with no other stipulation than I write an unbiased review, which this is.

This bag is a lot like another bag being advertised by the same company, the URPOWER Fitness Running Belt Stretch Waist Fanny Packthe major difference being that the other belt has TWO expandable pouches instead of the one, longer one presented here. Your choice is simple between the two: both are excellent running belts.As one might easily conclude, the pouch in this particular running belt is approximately 8 inches long, and the interior will easily hold the items the pouch describes: ID cards, mobile phone (mines a Samsung s5 WITH a full-sized case with a cover), keys, smartphone, cash, energy bars and power bank. . In fact, (just for fun) I succeeded in packing in on separate occasions  27 full-length sharpened pencils, a pair of bicycle gloves, my 8 long DirecTV remote and, (with a little tugging on the sides) my 3.5 x 5.5 Moleskine notebook.The elastic belt is made to fit any waist size from 24" to 40", but I was able to stretch it to fit a 46 circumference. I do believe that might get a little chafe-y, but not if the person just simply wanted to wear it while walking and not jog in it.The materials are all first class, and I didnt see any problematic seams, connections, zippers or connectors. Everything looks well constructed, and I believe the belt is, as claimed, ideal for running, jogging, hiking, and workouts. The belts are advertised as sweat-proof and rain-proof (though, in their words, not fully waterproof).In terms of jogging, the belt fit well and stayed put, even with reasonable items in there. By that I mean I had no problems with items like cash, a couple of energy bars, my keys, a small cellphone or a bigger one without a case, a small notebook and a couple of pens  those kind of things.All in all, this is an excellent product and should do very well for those who are active or those who are simply taking a day trip and wish to carry items in either a hard-to-see location or simply dont have pockets. Either way, this is a quality product, and should not only do what it strives to do and also last for years.NOTE: I received a free sample bag with no other stipulation than I write an unbiased review, which this is.

This is a terrific, vibrant, enjoyable and, I'm sure, time-absorbing activity that is loads of fun. I think it's even more of a blast than its hand-drawn counterpart, as all one needs to do is touch it and Voila! the color is applied to the drawing as beautifully as if you'd taken all day to scrupulously color it in yourself by hand. I suppose there are purists who will "pooh-pooh" it and say something along the lines of, "Why, dagnab it! What's this country coming to when a machine colors in the color FOR you! Why, in MY day I..." and blah, blah, blah. To me, this took an already enjoyable task and made it better. HOORAY for Colorfy!

While yes, this is in many ways a thriller  and this novel does maintain a strong level of tension until the end  DAUNTLESS is as much a book about war as it is about the conflict between expectations and reality. This is true of not only characterization but ALSO the physics that guides practically everything that moves in this story. For instance, when Captain Geary is looking out on the activities of his massive fleet on the view screen, the time it takes to issue a command and have it realized by the ship(s) is pretty lengthy: usually from one to three minutes of book time, or as much as several times that. Granted (and heres an ironic statement) time is relative when it is being experienced by a books readers, but its so unusual and seemingly authentic that space travel and therefore warfare, too, is NOT Zip! Zap! Zoom! but instead is slowed by the vast distances that must be travelled by 1) ships, 2) weapons and 3) communication. In fact, this slowing-down effect will probably now resonate for me when I read other works, and even when I see sci-fi movies.Author Campbell explains everything without being boring: while this book never mentions our planet Earth  the good guys are Alliance soldiers, while the bad guys belong to the evil-sounding Syndicate side  it does seem entirely possible that this could be about our future.  Regardless, ships generally travel no faster than one-tenth (.1) of the speed of light in battle. They CAN travel up to a breakneck .25 (one-fourth) the speed of light, but because of relativity things begin to distort enough to make targeting, logistics and communication almost impossible. Im no theoretical physicist, but it seems to back up things Ive read.  (To show how fast this still is, traveling at one-tenth the speed of light puts you somewhere around a million miles per minute. While we typically estimate travelling to Mars will take us about six months, we could have made it in less than 40 minutes at .1 SOL if wed made the trip in 2003, when Mars was at its recent closest to us, or about 15 minutes at .25 SOL. Thats fast.)But I think what I like best about this book are the conflicting personalities of the various ship commanders, and therefore the great disputes that those captains have with their new squadron commander. Certainly one can understand conflicts having to do with a fleets new commander, even a celebrated one, as even Black Jacks reputation does not automatically create blind obedience.But its even more than that. Campbell has quite studiously created a fleet that, while futuristic, does not disobey laws of basic human nature.  The author has thought out his fleet and their motivating factors very realistically. This is a force that has been taking staggering losses over the last several decades, and therefore their fleet officers are being promoted into positions of command without properly earning them.
