They have come to realize that grand gestures reap the notice of their superiors far quicker than the less glamorous notions like strategy and patience. Rear-line officers who witness a stirring victory look for heroes to praise and promote, even if those officers displayed an on-field arrogance that caused the loss of huge troop losses.  Its not the only distortion of honor that Geary has seen rise in prominence during his 100-year absence: so has cruelty in combat, a lack of mercy, and the feeling that the collateral killing of civilians is justified in battle. After all, the Alliance personnel arguethey did it first.And thats what I find so interesting: rather than painting the war, and in particular John Geary, with a wide brush that would make all of the officers and enlisted men and women see him as a glorious hero, author Campbell chooses to dab at his characters with a much finer tool, creating a cast of characters who run the gamut of those who are blindly (or duly) obedient and those who are openly insolent.But when it comes to this the best character is definitely Black Jack himself.  Campbell has created a really interesting person who is neither all patriot or all tradition...while he can be a bit stodgy when it comes to his persistence in trying to bring back the old core conventions, he is always questioning his own actions and challenging himself to come up with ways to appeal to his own officers and men (here meaning non-officers, an armed forces term that includes women) in order to compel his people to be positively motivated.  This is a great book (and, I suppose, series) for those looking at how to motivate people to do their best.While his plan to bring back his troops, ships, and an incredibly important weapon back to his allies back home makes perfect sense to us, a substantial faction of his own men believe his actions show cowardice. He is running from his enemies, they say, frequently refusing to kill those enemies when they show themselves to be weak, as seen by his continual practice of informing a weakened and defenseless enemy that they should surrender.I also love the fact that author Campbell has created another leading character who is a politician, and she represents a small but important faction of the troops under his command. Co-president Victoria Riones presence as a non-combatant is another thorn in his side, but shes an extremely well-placed thorn in his side whose presence is both dramatic and clever, in the sense that his repeated need to explain himself helps involve and inform US, the readers, in a completely natural and fluid manner that does not drag upon the flow of the plot.But what sells this book more than anything else is the skill of the author.  This book is drenched in dramatic tension  and what is so surprising is that so much of it remains yet to be used. For instance, there is really only one actual large battle depicted in this book from start to finishONE battle within a 300-page war novel ! Yet to the authors credit the novel is continually exciting.  What author Campbell has achieved in his creation (and, Im assuming, his series) is a book that is appealing because despite its taking place in the distant future and possibly in a place far, far away  hes created a book that is innately human and eminently readable.

What a simple and clever concept: a bag that can pack itself. Its so pragmatic that I wish I thought of it on my own.If for no other reason than its convenience and simplicity, this is a really useful bag. But this is not just a cheap convenience: its a well-made and very practical bag that is only limited only by its light, simple construction and strong lightweight tear-resistant fabric. I thought it best to explain these features in the form of a PROS and CONS format that, I hope, will point out why this bag is best when used for the purpose for which it is designed.The bag I examined was the purple choice, and Amazon was offering it for approximately $14 at the time of this reviews publication.PROS:1. This is cleverly designed in its concept and execution. There is one main pocket whose two zippers allow it to be opened just a little in order to take out a single item, or unzipped fully to expose the entire interior.2. Beyond the one giant interior pocket just mentioned, there are two small zippered pockets that could hold, say, a mid-sized e-tablet, and two side pockets that can hold additional items such as a drink bottle or paperback books or food items or other similarly small, soft, or non-sharp objects.3. This is extremely lightweight: its amazingly simple to pack into its own attached bag and store away, as matched only by its simplicity when it comes to unpacking and using as a knapsack.4. Great straps; this is an ideal bag for smaller daytime hikes and bringing along a change of clothes, basic picnic food items, or other goods one would need at a get-together or simply to visit a museum with the family.5. Its an attractive bag, and looks good when its all ironed out; this can also be accomplished by filling it with things like clothes or other goods and simply stretched out6. It is made of tear-resistant nylon, and therefore will avoid tearing even if it does have a small hole. The stitching is reinforced at its seams and its straps are backed by as nylon mesh for the comfort of the wearerCONS:1. The one main pocket is so huge that it dominates what one may access as they walk. Having one main pocket limits ones choice as to single smaller items.2. There are not a lot of smaller pockets in which one can store things needed3. This is extremely lightweight, and it looks as if it shouldnt carry any heavy or sharp-edged products.4. The knapsack lacks a frame found in many larger knapsacks. It is therefore not built for long overnight woodland hikes or hiking on trails5. The nature of the bag is that once it is released from being packed in its small packet, it looks extremely wrinkled and has a messy exterior. It is so lightweight that it seems at a quick glance to be flimsy.As might be gathered when reading the pros and cons, this backpack is at its best when it is used for the purpose for which it is designed. It is not a bag one would take to the Appalachian Trail, but instead it is ideally suited for day trips where one wants to bring along changes of clothes or things to keep younger members occupied on trips to museums or long shopping trips. While it is not at its best if it is packed with extremely heavy single items it IS at its best when those items are soft items like clothes or small toys or food items or smaller thermos containers or a whole host of similar items.Therefore, this bag is a fine choice if one intends to store it away until it is needed. It is the ideal bag for day trips, and is at its best when storing a large amount of baggage. And yes, while it is probably best served by packing soft goods or goods with rounded edges, it IS a durable bag made of tear-resistant nylon and it will resist tearing even if it does indeed have a small hole. This can be seen by a close look at the fabric; that cross-hatching is what prevents the material from ripping any further than the original hole.NOTE: I received a free sample bag with no other stipulation than I write an unbiased review, which this is.

I often have an interesting conversation with my brother whenever we discuss a sci fi movie or book that involves time travel. His usual complaint: They didnt get Time Travel right, hell argue, to which I always reply that no one gets Time Travel right because IT DOESNT EXIST. His point, though, is one I do agree with, and that is that frequently all it takes is logic to see some problems with plots involving Time Travel.For instance, why do the Terminator-enabling Robots of the Future ALWAYS come back during the period between when the future John Conner, Commander of the Humans, is either about to be conceived through when John Conner is in the young adolescent phase? That decade and a half seems to be a bad period for the robots, right? So: PICK ANOTHER TIME. Go back earlier!! Kill HER mother!Be that as it may, were talking about MR. WAS now, and it's a cleverly written YA novel by Pete Hautman (that happens to use time travel). I believe it to be a fine book that young readers will take to. It contains many of the elements that will appeal to their particular bracket: an alcoholic parent, spousal abuse, a love triangle, identity confusion, war, murder, and an interesting and changing narrative that takes the shape of a series of books obtained by the author.  Oh, and that ever-appealing element of time travel. Well get to that in a moment.Books that play with narrative technique (I AM THE CHEESE, DRACULA, CARRIE, THE BOOK THIEF, FLOWERS WITH ALGERNON, THE ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN, to name but a few) are often interesting and appealing not only because of their unique nature, but because they come right out and opaquely present the reader with an essential question present in all books: can I trust this narrator? All books  or movies, poetry, or even art  contain such a challenge to the reader, but it is in books parading this narrative element that especially appeal to the young, since they confront it themselves right from the start. They come right out and say: Here I am, and here are the facts as I saw them. Believe me or not; its all up to you.It is an appealing YA technique, and my list at the top of the previous paragraph barely touches the tip of the successful YA iceberg. In one of the most famous cases, J.D. Salinger's THE CATCHER IN THE RYE starts off almost admonishing the reader that If you really want to hear about it the narrator could tell you all that David Copperfield kind of crap. So, yes, MR. WAS is a book that from the very start has an appealing tone for the young, wherein P.H., (or Pete Hautman) lets us know that his father rescued an aluminum suitcase bobbing in the surf, and within were four notebooks that have sat in an attic for almost four decades before Mr. H found them and gave them a read. He was so moved by reading them, he tells us, that he has transcribed them to type and, having done so, lets us know that he believes that the events described in Jacks notebooks actually occurred.Having adroitly lent his tale a credible attitude, the author sets out to tell his tale. And here follow the four notebooks. Number One is the longest, and at 110 pages it is best that this is, to me, the most readable and involving portion of the story, the portion in which the central characters are introduced, as well as a very interesting little element known simply as The Door. Since the doors link to time travel is addressed on the back cover, I wouldnt really call it a spoiler to address it, but I will go light on what occurs when he makes several visits through it. Suffice it to say that while at first it was a curiosity, even an escape from the pressures of his life, it later becomes a device where he believes he can use it to amend or even erase some tragic wrongs done in his life.And this is an important element in such tales. We shouldnt use time travel to help us get a better score on a spelling quiz. No: it is a thing that should only used to address Great Wrongs. While most of us have come to expect that old trope to play out  the one that tells us You Cant Change the Past  the question is: will author Hautman  going to obey that particular maxim HERE, in this story? And if such a thing CAN happen, at what price?And, unfortunately, thats where I felt the story bogged a bit. When our central character, Jack, is experiencing life, the story rings true, and tells what is for me the most interesting part of the tale. But when Book Two occurs, wherein Jack meets the shady Mr. Boggs (and his wife, among others), who explains certain elements of time travel to young Jack, that I feel the narrative begins to let us down a bit. While I enjoyed the playful notion that The Door was simply a device, and not a particularly well made one (and leaves us to believe that there must be Other Doors out there), I felt let down by the cheat of the following technique (and I quote):[Mr. Boggs] finally said, Dont worry about it son. You always go back to where you came from, its just that you cant know for sure where youve been(illegible)--you understand?While yes, this is a technique that can certainly be said to safely and truly belong to the authors Bag of Tricks  that is, that since the tale is being transcribed from notebooks found within a suitcase bobbing in the surf, it is perfectly reasonable to expect that parts might be smeared or otherwise illegible, Yet at the same time using it to avoid something crucially explanatory just feels like deception to me: a cheap ruse. It lets the author get away without having to do the hard work, the difficult stuff.And this brings me to the real crux of the Time Travel element. While each Book had its place, and each one described a different facet of the story, I felt a little let down by 1) the immense amount of time that Jack decided to put in to bring about his change, and 2) feeling really let down by the outcome of such a change. I will not reveal plot elements, but suffice it to say that this for me was an immense disappointment. Certainly, it is possible to say I should have seen it coming, but when one goes on a five-decade long trip, one hopes there is more to account for it than this. I almost felt that the book simply ran out of gas by the end.Yet I want to at the same time acknowledge that there is a plot twist later, almost at the very end that (judging by their complimentary reviews) at least one young reader found to be as exhilarating and unexpected as that of THE SIXTH SENSE. I bring this up because I don't want my singular disappointment to be an indictment of EVERYONE's reading of the book. Many, many people loved what they read, including the outcome. (So there, me...)In that light, I believe that there will be many young adults who read this novel who will not only enjoy the narrative device that frames this entire work (the four books within the suitcase), but there will be many who will enjoy the mental gymnastics presented by The Door and its consequences. I think MR WAS will really give many a young reader a workout that will prove enjoyable and rewarding. My young daughters often tell me that I see negatives where they see positives, or vice versa, and such may well be the case here. There are many young peoples testimonies to this novel that it was a book they not only enjoyed but felt it touched them and taught them something at the same time.It is because this book has many strengthsamong them cleverness, interesting characters, a gravity of plot and events that one does not often see in the old YA works that peppered the landscape before this field became completely re-energized in the last couple of decades by such terrific works as J.K. Rowlings Harry Potter series,  Phillip Pullmans HIS DARK MATERIALS, Suzanne Collins THE HUNGER GAMES, Stephanie Meyers' TWILIGHT trilogy, as well as so many other good works that have learned that the best YA fiction does not earn its stripes by being dumbed down, but by challenging young minds with the unexpected, the compelling, and sometimes even the heavier elements like death, cruelty, abuse and other similarly "adult" topics.So, all in all, I felt this was a good book that will challenge readers. While I felt that the time travel element took the some of the starch out of an otherwise crisp shirt, this was still a good work that will prove enjoyable to many young readers.

For as many times as I write reviews for glass screen protectors for your phones and tablets, Im probably going to say many of the same things: they are beautiful, long lasting and very protective of your screen. I love mine.First, a disclaimer: a glass screen protector does a great job of protecting your screen from scratches, nicks, marks and incidental, even occasional hard hits  depending on the type of hit, the strength of the hit, and the type of object you hit. Screen protectors are not going to protect your phone screen if you drop it on the corner of an anvil, or it is hit by a hammer head, or if you drop it out a car window when youre going sixty. But if youre reasonably protective and you limit dangerous conditions to an incidental hit here or there, the glass screen protector will break before your phone screen does. The best protection for an entire phone combines a screen protector with a wrap-around protector for the body.But as for screen protectors, go glass. Theres a simple reason: when you take reasonable care of your screen protector  that is, keeping it clean and not wiping it off on your OshKoshes after a day of roadwork, the GLASS protectors look beautiful; even stunningly so  depending of your care of them. I keep little packets of Zeiss Pre-Moistened Lens Cleaning Wipes nearby (they cost only about six cents per wipe) for my phone, tablet, and my glasses and the result is worth it.The thing about glass screen protectors is how hard they are and how sharp the image comes through. I cant tell you how often I look at my screen and say, Wow! to myself because of how remarkable the bright, striking image looks. Im not making this up: take care of your screen, keep it under glass and keep that glass clean (and not simply by rubbing it on your pants or with your shirt-tail) and youll see what I mean.And the process of installing glass is much easier than it is with plastic protectors. The plastic ones ALWAYS leave bubbles, no matter how I try. I have followed directions precisely and they STILL leave little bubbles that are next to impossible to remove.But with glass it is extremely simple, and with only a modicum of care and attention to detail your screen will look perfect. Just follow the directions: do what they say, and it should all go well.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

This is one of my dreams come true: a small, easy-to-carry messenger bag that has so many pockets it seems like an electricians tool bag mated with a pool table.I lost count somewhere after I hit a dozen, and I know there are more than that. And what I like best about them is that they all make sense, are located wisely, are mostly covered by zippers or pull strings or stretch fabric or well-placed flaps, making them safe to store items that might normally be easy to lose in other bags. But here the items can be set in their specific placesand one can feel secure that they will stay where they are put.This bag is just perfect for a person like me: I like to write, to keep lists, to doodle, to read, and therefore Im a person who likes to have several pens with me, maybe a couple of pencils, a Kindle or a paperback, a couple of Moleskine-like notebooks; and then of course theres my money, some credit and store cards, my phone, some charging cordsand Im just getting started. I hate when these myriad items have to be dumped into a common bag, where sorting through them is like looking for a coin in a box of fishing tackle.NoI like things to be organized in a set pattern, where I can look for such-and-such a thing even when the lights are out. Having to dump my things into a bag with a couple of sections is no more help to a person like me than if someone else packed it for me. I am not kidding when I say I have gone through a series of bags looking for the right one, and I now know I have found the right bag.The G4Free Multi-functional Tactical Messenger Bag us just what the doctor ordered. The separate pockets are well-sized, offering several medium sized pockets with smaller compartments within, allowing one to organize items into series: for instance, in one medium pocket I can put a wallet, a money clip, a credit card holder, a checkbook, etc  with some of those items in the main pocket, and some of the smaller, lesser-used (or more protected) items are held in the slots within.Another beautiful thing about this bag is thateven with all of these compartmentsit is SO compact.  It manages to encompass all the stuff I carry into a bag that is, when it is pretty well packed with that stuff, about 10 inches wide, about 10 inches tall, and about 6 inches deep. Again, thats FULL. Thats about the size of a large shoe box, which makes it a really easy bag to pick up and carryor fit behind your legs in a crowded car, or stow away in a plane. And, while there are four color choices, I picked black: not only does it look great, but the color is almost invisible through a car window against the floorboardsit removes itself from the temptation of onlookers that way.Its a really terrific bag, like I said. For me, a real keeper.

This is an excellent little organizer for a specific kind of person...and I fit into that category.Some time ago my worsening spinal condition caused me to reevaluate my way of doing things, and one of those things was my George Costanza-like fat wallet that was causing me to sit uncomfortably. A really thick wallet chock full of credit cards and receipts and paper money and what have you is a nightmare on a spine AS WELL AS organization, and a solution had to be found.Well, I've reorganized into several really thin little and very thin containers for my paper and plastic. The beauty of the system is that I can split the cards and money up into three locations on me and because of that it seems like I really am carrying almost nothing....no big billfold to worry about. Or you could simply enjoy this kind of an organizer in a pair of shorts, or a shirt pocket.For instance, a certain portion of my plastic (like my driver's license and my credit cards) go into a little RFID-blocking metal box (like one shown here). I often place my bills in a money clip, but then I have a small dilemma: what do I do with the rest of my cards and info...the grocery and other store cards, my library card--in all, my other five or six cards. Where do I put them?Well, I love this new organizer. It gives me the ability to gather up all those "extras" that sit around in a wallet and firmly encases them in a secure, single location. And what's better is it has that neat little center "pocket" that can be used in so many ways. Because this pocket's sealed at the bottom it makes for a really secure spot in which to place bills, important notes, a key or two, even things like coins and so on. The leather is nice and give the organizer a nice feel and look.The organizer seems to be well made: it is stitched well along the edges without any loose threads or other indicators of sloppiness. The stitching goes almost right to the very end of the leather, too, giving you the most inward area they can. And at its thinnest point (when empty) it measures only 2mm thick. To give you an idea how thin this measurement is, it's only HALF the height of the numbers running across most credit cards. THAT's thin, and though the holder when loaded is nowhere near THAT thin, it's why it's no bother to carry it in your front pocket.And a nice feature of its design is that the organizer GAINS strength when cards are added to it. The variety I have has three horizontal slots on each side. (They make two; one has a plastic window for displaying an ID.) Since you can tuck 2 in each slot, my variety can hold 12 cards total. I try to keep it down to one card in each slot to avoid Costanz-ising.All in all, an excellent little card-money-room key holder; I'm using mine daily.

I had a great time with these boards  since the only way to really test them was to put them through their culinary paces, I asked my wife and daughter if they would mind coming up with tasks for using them. (And I even came up with one!) Needless to say, I had a great weekend.We found the boards to be really nice to use in the kitchen bamboo is by its very nature deceptively light, making them slim and really nice to use.  If you pick up one of these boards, try to imagine it being made of cherry, or maple, or any of those other typically dark woods. Heck, even oak  think of how heavy any of those boards would be in place of this thin, light board.However, despite their seemingly delicate nature, theyre extremely strong and durable.  Again, their slim appearance might fool people who think these are not as stong as their thicker counterparts. It simply comes down to the fact that since theyre made of a really strong wood they dont have to be thick to stand up to the rigors of chopping and whatnot. Additionally, they are extremely easy to clean.And the same goes for storing them: because of their slimness they take almost no space in the cupboardthat is, if you want to store them inside a cabinet. Take a good look at them: theyre extremely attractive, and their featherweight nature AND good looks (and handles!) make them many homemakers choice of display-worthy products.Their handles make them easy to store and even display, and why not? Bamboo is a light colored, attractive wood, and is extremely sanitary. Ecologically,  bamboo is an extremely renewable resource: its considered a plant, not a tree, and one of its best traits for industry is that it grows to its fully marketable height of 15 to 40 feet in about 3 to 7 years dependant on its speciescompare that to any tree.I know Im going beyond the simple testing of a product, but I like bamboo, and believe it makes great sense as a resource.Ill give you one detraction: my wife and daughter BOTH mentioned that they would have liked to have a groove on the chopping boards in order to channel away the juices that one often encounters when cutting up moist products  like, say, tomatoes, watermelon, or a sizzling steak. A channel would help direct it away from the rest of the counter, especially the portion that would lead the juices OFF the counter onto the one doing the slicing and, in particular, their clothes (and the floor).Despite this one minor fault, we found this to be a great product...one we would buy with no hesitation.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

Did you ever look at a product that is so simple and solid in its delivery of a certain commodity to the general public that makes so much sense that you slap yourself in the middle of your forehead with the butt of your hand and yell, "WHY DIDN'T I THINK OF THAT?"Well, guess what? This is that product for me. My daughter has her own veterinary clinic and my wife is the office manager there, and they are constantly day in/day out keeping records for clients (there are still a lot of things that computers can't do yet.). This kind of work keeps them very busy, and they need quick ways to write down facts or notes or thoughts, many of which are permanent, and many that will soon be erased.So, wouldn't it be nice if there were some way to write down visit information and then erase it? Gee, I wonder how one might accomplish that?Well, credit HD Chalks for figuring out this crazy-good and simple solution. You write down the information, knowing that it will probably have to do with one person or animal or visit only (though it could be longer). The blackboard is a perfect white-on-black message system, and it's erasable yet can last for a long time if one does not erase it.We did not experience the problem some reviewers had when it came to peeling the labels off the backing paper -- I assume I got the problem right. I know some people mentioned they were having trouble with repeated peelings of the labels off of things like bottles, but we do not use the labels in this manner this way and therefore cannot comment on them. As to how we used them:We labelled the plastic file holder one often sees outside a patient's room...the one the doctor reaches into before actually stepping foot into the patient room. For this, the chalk was perfect: we wrote down the patients' name(s) on it and any other pertinent short info, and then erased it when a new patient used it.On folders, we write  info for THIS VISIT ONLY: things like names and addresses were not best served by using chalk, as you might guess. Where chalk was perfect had to do with this particular visit, and here the chalk was perfect. We also have some plastic bins which change in purpose every so often, so these labels were great. Also, there were some other things which really need to be updated, and those again are perfect. We did NOT take the labels off at any point...once they were peeled from the backing paper and applied where they had to be placed, they stayed there.Anyway, these were PERFECT! We loved them, and writing on them was a lot of fun. The unique quality of the "chalkboard" format did not wear thin on those who used them, and it is fun to write and erase on the folders and other labels. but the system did not prosper simply because of that...no, it made sense, and is simply a really smart system.So...FIVE STARS. I almost took off a point because I didn't think of this first, but I was persuaded that such an idea may not have been very "fair." So, five stars it is.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is

One of the things I really liked about this drawer organizer is its versatility...if it doesn't fit a drawer space, hang it on a wall. If you want to make it smaller, that's fine. Larger, that's fine, too. Want more organizing slots? Put in the extra dividers. Get tire of that? Take them out. You can make a lot of adjustments with this product.First off, this is a really substantial draw organizerto start off, consider its dimensions:Smallest size: 12.9 x 17 x 1.7Largest size: 19.3 x 17 x 1.7All in all, this is pretty accommodating; my kitchen drawers are about 20 x 22, so theyll certainly work at any size I want. I like the freedom that gives me.Next, bamboo is an excellent choice of wood to use when it came to the creation of this shelf. Its a good solid wood that is still significantly lighter than a lot of woods that are comparable in strength. If one holds up the organizer/shelf in his or her hands it is really pretty easy to imagine the heaviness of other woods that could have been used: oak, say, or maple or cherry, etc. They would have been a lot heavier.Im really pleased with the upsurge in using bamboo lately: its getting to be a relatively common wood one can find in the southern U.S. from eastern Texas to Virginia, and its growing in popularity for projects such as these. (Its considered a plant, not a tree, and one of its best traits for industry is that it grows to its fully marketable height of 15 to 40 feet in about 3 to 7 yearscompare that to any tree.) Its nice to see it being used in business ventures like this.Anyway, I also really like the idea of the unit dividersthe company includes four dividers for the more common narrower slots, and one divider for the two remaining bigger slots. They are sized exactly alike (the four, that is) and all have been sanded and well-prepped. The same with the slots where they goI see NO poorly sanded slots, or chips, or splinters, etc.I really like that the drawers are extendable along a rather substantial track along the two short sides of the unit. This really makes it much more possible to safely consider it as a  shelf unit, as the drawers are less likely to simply drop off or go haywire. I know whereof I speak, in that I have a plastic set that does not use this same system, and I would no more use it on the wall as a shelf than I would one with rubber bands. The Home-Complete system is considerably more solid in its design and execution.I also like the diversification allowable with these: as drawer units they are usable in silverware; utensils; in the bathroom they can organize womens cosmetics and brushes, etc.; or in a workplace it can divide smaller tools or items like nails, nuts and bolts; in electronics: in arts and crafts; or in the bedroom, where they could organize jewelry, or other items; they could gather and divide collections (coins, stamps, or other collectibles); or various miscellaneous items like coupons; hobbies; or what have you.As shelf units the sky is the limitscrewed to the wall they could be used in the kitchen, in bedrooms, in the garage, a workroom, a rec room (say, cassette tapes or games, dice, etc.); or simply for  decorative purposessay, posing small figurines or any sort of collectibles, or even sentimental items. When I received mine my wife immediately relegated it to my use, giving it hardly a glance she intimated it would not be attractive enough for her.  Yet after I placed on the wall of my workroom to post not only bottled items like nails and screws and nuts and bolts, etc, and when she paid a relatively rare trip to my workroom she uttered a little sigh, declaring she had not been given a substantial enough look at it. She would certainly have liked to use it for items in our bedroom. (I have a feeling Ill be ordering more organizers in the very near future.)Two things I wish the people making this set of drawers had done:1. Make the two sliding drawer arms be able to accommodate an adjustable drawer dividerthis would have not only given us the ability to divide the drawers (17 is a LONG drawer on each side), but it would have also stabilized the extended drawer. Sure, when it lies in a horizontal drawer its pretty stable by itself, but this isnt the only way the drawer is meant to be used: should it be vertical as, say, a spice rack, it would be nice to have a way to break up these longer shelves, which of course theyd be called that in this position.2. Im sure this idea would involve something pretty substantial, building-wise, but wouldnt it be nice if one were able to double the extension of the one drawer instead of using both drawers? That would truly allow for some larger items to be placed within it if it were a drawer OR a shelf. Its just a thought  not a negative. I truly think it would involve some real upper-level thinking, and probably would be nowhere as easy to actually accomplish as it is to suggest it. Its just a thought.Incidentally, I read a couple of 1-  to 2-star reviews (at the time of my posting there were only four each) that addressed a kind of chintzy, cheap quality to their drawers poor sanding here and there, nail pops, splinters, etc. I honestly do not see where they got their drawer units; that is, how theirs could be so cheap, whereas mine (and apparently so many others) got theirs at such high quality. I dont doubt what they say, not am I saying anything like theyre being too harsh. I absolutely believe themits just intriguing; mine is a very nice, well-made, pleasant product. Im thoroughly puzzled.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

I really like this wallet case by Mengo. Ive had only two lesser problems to address with it, and I would like to make the point (as have many other Amazon reviewers) that had Amazon a ten-point system, instead of 5, as this would be a great case for a nine out of ten. I think that this is an excellent wallet overall, and Im going to keep on using this LONG after Im done testing it. I think that says a lot about its worth.Positives:1. Though it might not be the wallets most important point, the Mengo is really a nice-looking wallet. Its sleek snakeskin (black, in this case) is certainly striking, and I am continually struck by its appearance every time I pick it up. I feel good when I look at it and, by extension, I feel good when its seen by others. And its important to state here that most of its life is spent on a farm, where mud, dust, and pooh reign supreme. If the Mengo wallet case can look good here, it will look good in most situations. Other than a small tear (whose effect Ive minimized by simply coloring the torn spot with black ink) I feel the snakeskin looks really snazzy.2. The Mengo does a great job protecting the phone. It encompasses it and holds it (maybe even a bit too tightly  see Negatives, Point 2, below) and I have confidence in my phone being protected should it fall from my handseven a fall of several feet to the ground. While I love screen protectors, I always make the point that all they do is protect the front. The sides and front edges (and therefore, the screen as well) are vulnerable from certain angles if no further protection is offered. Wallets, such as this model, does offer those protections. I dont know that it would survive EXTREME falls, but for this price, thats asking a bit much of it.3. The Mengo case also allows good access to almost all of its functional areas (with the exception of the power switch, as described in #2,below): camera, headphone jack, micro USB, speakers, etc.4.  This is an extremely light wallet as well. Its so light, in fact, that there have been several times I was convinced I had forgotten to pack it in my bag, or forgot it was in my pocket. As I often carry several other things at the same time, its slight weight is a really great positive point, especially when I have just detailed how strong and protective it is. Having both is ideal.5. The interior wallet slots are nice, but I dont try to use this very muchIve found that  the hard plastic cards that I place within them tend to scratch whatever screen protector I have (and they make a great case for why screen protectors are important).  I do particularly like the transparent slot, however, and its a great place for my drivers license. Im never without my phone, and therefore I always have my ID with me. And, situated as it is, this ID never scratches my phone. Id really like it if they used the upper part for another window, as I could put another card (such as my medical insurance card) in there. Realize too that you have the long slot under the whole ID area for bills, though it will not fit dollars without bending them in some waythats also a little bit inconvenient, but overall nice.6. I like the clasp that binds the wallet closedits called Magna-Clasp Technology and I guess that simply means it has a small magnet inside its outward-most tip. I wonder, however, if it was wise having a magnet so close to a place where other people place credit cards and other plastic with magnetic info strips. I wonder if this might be dangerous.Negatives:1. As I mentioned above, the wallet has torn a bit in the area behind the phone, but it is visible only when the phone is being formed into a horizontal stand-up position.  Plus, I easily remedied the physical problem. Yet it could be a problem if it continuesIll update this posting if it does.2. The phone does such a great job of encompassing the phone that it makes it pretty difficult to use the power switch (located just above the Magna-Clasp Technology flap). It is in fact very difficult to hit the switch effectively  say, in order to turn off the power when Im no longer using it and need to reserve power. When I do touch it the plastic rim can make it really difficult to actually PUSH the switch.  Between the act of trying to locate it and then actually getting the switch to work, the process (which used to take a second or so) can often now take me about 5 to 15 (or even more) frustrating seconds if Im not careful. One problem that can result from that is that it can really waste power if I assume it to be off when it is not. Or it can create an embarrassing situation in a movie theater. But my solution is simply to be aware, and look.To close, my feeling about whether I marked it down to a 4 out of 5 came down to this: do the problems Ive addressed interfere in a regular or really important way? As Ive said, I didnt think that the tear was a big problem, but the power switch issue can be a regular one if Im not careful. It does interfere with my daily use of the phone, though in a (mostly) minor way, a problem that I can circumvent by simply looking. I thought that was not worth taking it down a point.  So much was good about this wallet that I thought it was worth overlooking the couple of problems I encountered.Like I said, however, were Amazon ever to go to a ten-point system, I would definitely have made this a 9taking off a point out of 5 just didnt seem fair.NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

This is about as easy a doorbell installation as you could hope for. If you can use a screwdriver and put in batteries, then you can handle this installation.All you need is a slot beside your door where your old doorbell button went, or simply a nice spot youd like to put one. Since there are no wires, all you need is a smooth spot to place itit takes just 4. Inside the house, the door chimes come with their own little stand and therefore it can be placed anywhereanywhere, that is, within 300 feet of the site of the button outside the door.  If your house is larger than that well, suffer.You get 16 choices for chimes, as well. Theyre all part of a very easy-to-understand and comprehensive set of directions. Like, say, your choices of cellphone ringtones, there will be some youll like, some youll love, some youll think are almosts, and some youll have a good laugh at. They offer a good range of volume, and  youll even get the option of using the doorbell tone only, using the tone AND a flashing light, or using ONLY the flashing light. I think most people will be pleased with the selection offered, but my only recommendation here would be that  as we are now in the days of computer genius, it would have been nice to have come up with a way for some additional ones to be addedin the manner, say, that cellphones can add ringtones. (Its a thought, perhaps, for the boys and girls in Product Development to tinker with in the future...)All in all, Famili has created a very easy-to-use doorbell system that has a great range and is well thought out from the installation phase to its final operation. If youre looking for a replacement door chime  that requires NO wires to set up, one that has as a variety of chimes as well as a range of volume AND distance from the ringer itself  well, then, this is a door chime for you.NOTE: I NOTE: I was given a free sample of this product with no stipulation other than I provide an honest review...which this is.

This is an device that provides an extraordinary amount of help when it comes to working with products that A) require illumination, and B) require both of your hands and/or concentration. So much falls under these conditions that youll eventually wonder how you ever got by without them.I border on being a physical wreck, so I dont jog or anything, but I walk at night from my barn. I use tools, too, and I read at night, and I have to find things Ive dropped... in these activities, too, this headlamp is a huge help. In fact, I figure it will help out when I (or anyone else) work on a car, tend a pets night wounds, read a map, tend to ANYTHING when if my power goes out, and temporarily blind ones daughters (all right  that last one isnt recommended, but a father can find some habits to be hard to drop.)Face it: there are all sorts of reasons the headlamp is a tool that is as beneficial as the magnetic nail holder. And as for this one, there are several features that I found to be really helpful.THE BAND: Made of a stretchable elastic, the band doesnt really need an exact fitits very easy to adjust and the material is pretty slippery smooth. The importance of that is that the fabric did not seem prone to grab hair or get caught in things a more textured fabric might.THE LIGHT(S): The two white lights are beyond bright (ask my daughters). Pressed once, the white lights alternate between the two side bulbs and the single center bulb. Pressed three times in quick succession, the white lights strobeon/off/on/off and so on. Press it once a sustained second or so, and you have a red light. Once you get used to the light and its functions youll find that each of the beams has a low, medium, and high intensity, but heres a neat little thing I found:One bulb trick I discovered can be accessed when any one of the steady lamp beams is on, be it red or white. Holding the button down on a continual basis, the beam will seem unaffected at first until a second or so goes by and then it begins to fade. As long as you maintain pressure, the beam will fade until it is out completelyyet taking your finger off before it fades completely traps that beam at how low its intensity was when you let go. (Tapping the button again will turn the light off and return the light to its normal functions.)Additionally, this light puts its metaphorical money where its metaphorical mouth is: it boasts not only 100 % water resistance, but it comes with a lifetime warranty. THATs a sturdy light that guarantees its durability.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This is an extremely ambitious work for a young writer, and both of those statements contain important implications.As to the first half of that opening clause, ALGORITHM is not content simply to go to the furthest reaches of the world to tell his tale  no, it goes to the very edge of the galaxy, to the very heart of who we are, to the very reason we existindeed, to our very Maker. Its a pretty stunning achievement.What should be given prominence is that there is an interesting authenticity within this book. The author  in his real other life as a scientist  shares a prestigious award for discovering a new anti-cancer drug... a great achievement on its own. But even if that werent enough to convince us that he probably knows his way around the lab, there is enough hard science in this book to make such concepts as DNA research have an authentic ring AND still manage to be understandable, something thats not as easy as it sounds.One extremely interesting bit of science at the heart of this novel  that an object made of gold was discovered in a chunk of charcoal and must therefore be at least a hundred thousand years old and far older than we have ever believed civilization to be  is not even conjecture. No: this discovery actually happened in the late 1800s! There is more in the way of actual history in this book as well, notably a mine disaster in 1959 Pennsylvania, that provides the story with fascinating authenticity.But there is much here that comes out of the authors imagination, and though descriptions of the mine and its grounds seemed authentic, what he did with creating suspense in the many and varied action scenes was handled well. The novel is built on continuous the notion of providing action, action, and more action, and reads quickly. I had no problem poring through it and returning to it once other circumstances permitted. The author is able to create a plausible story at the same time he provides cliffhanger after cliffhanger.What I found most interesting about ALGORITHM is that author Doweyko really could have stopped halfway through this novel and still had a great book. In fact, there is so much in this story that seems to conclude, in a sense, halfway through the novel that as we neared the middle I found myself wondering, Theres no way hes going to take this to THAT stage now, is he? After all, the novels already had scientific shockers and a kidnapping and shootings and an evil business tycoon and explosions and a seeming re-animation of a dead man and  oh, yes  an alien visitortheres no way hes really going to travel to the stars for an even bigger conclusion? Hasnt he accomplished more than enough already?Well, the answer is that you may as well buckle your safety harness; the rides not over.  And in the second part of this novel things get REALLY interesting, but Ill leave thatto say much about the second half of a book is really dangerous when it comes to spoilers  though I will do a little of it toward the end of my review. Dont worry: I WILL warn you beforehand.Since the novel is his first, it bears stating here that I also thought the mechanics here were by and large very good. There were a few mechanical faults  spelling error here, a comma or apostrophe there  but for the most part they were few and far between and never detracted from the story.There is occasional prosaic writing as well, like this line: It was almost as if the melancholy sounds were calling out to them from another time, drawing them nearer like sirens to rocky shoals. Heres another concerning the tiredness felt by the two main characters: Morpheus soon embraced the duo in his comforting arms. I wondered, however, if having writing this eloquent occur here and there within a story, every twenty or so pages, might not seem a little out of placeI leave it for better minds than mine.On to some other problems, which I want to emphasize are more minor in nature. One that did bother me concerned the practice of sudden switching of narrative which I admit is quite popular in fiction nowadays: its where the story is following one track, and then suddenly the author switches us and makes us follow another. If handled well, such a technique builds suspense; and if the author can make the reader excited about both (or more) storylines, well, that reader becomes truly hooked.Here, though, such switches are sometimes handled in a too abrupt, even bizarre fashion. For instance, theres a moment when the main track of the action is following an interesting dialogue between Adam and Linda, our two main scientists who are possibly making a game-changing diagnosis in the understanding of DNA. Suddenly, the narrative jumps  in the concluding paragraph of the chapter  to this:The cylinder turned and a large engine at one end fired in a programmed series of short bursts to begin a controlled process of deceleration. The G-forces needed to be carefully regulated. Excessive forces would not damage the cocooned occupants, but could pose issues to the few awake and on duty.While such a NOTION is correct, this single paragraph in the midst of an otherwise smooth narrative is too jarring a departure and simply doesnt work. Granted, while hints of a new alien narrative angle should be exciting, this is too suddenly thrown in and discarded, like a misplaced sequence of film frames tacked in by a forgetful film editor.While there were some really minor things that irked me, like how the author kept hinting about the gradual awakening of attraction between Adam and Linda that too often relied on their eyes meeting precipitously  over and over again. But one moment that really bothered me was the really, well, just STRANGE, instance occurring at a point when Adam is off trying to discover more of the spacecrafts hidden secrets. The author gives us this comparison: It was like he was back in grammar school, trying to avoid getting caught in the schools attic where he had been searching out bottles containing dead babies. He never did find any, but remained convinced they had to be there somewhere. I dont know about you, but to me thats a pretty horrendous and contrived flashback, imagined or otherwise, to simply throw in for what I believe to be largely comic effect. Yes, a metaphorical point might be made about the ultimate direction the narrative will take late in the book, but I still think this is just too unnatural and shocking to be thrown in and then just dropped.Still, there are so many positives about this book that outweigh these relatively minor slipups. The book is continuously imaginative and even daring at times. As mentioned earlier I felt it was to Doweykos credit he did not take the easy road and conclude his novel before it really did travel to the very bounds of our galaxy. I only wished at the end  as a reviewer more than a reader  that the author had gone for the spike once hed scored his touchdown.That is (AND THIS COULD BE A SPOILER, SO BE AWARE!), I wish hed really made something more out of the Maker concept. personally thought he missed something when he made no real concrete play on the allusion (see note below). After all, his central character is named Adam. Some more work on this concept, the cleverer the better, would have really set the work apart. I am not attempting to force the authors hand in any way, nor am I telling him a direction he should have gone with it. If he wants to be heretical, fine; if he wants to be reverent, thats fine, too. I just think that he had set his table and had dinner hot and waiting on the tableI only wish that we could have taken a bite.NOTE: I spoke to the author about this, and he said that he HAD considered this as a concept -- and considered that this particular trope overdone. I can't really argue with that, and I'm glad to take my include this notation for the readers' (and his) benefit.

I was taken aback when I first de-boxed the Dechunxian Bottle-Cup, which is just as much a Bottle-Cup as it a Container-Jar and a little bit Thermos (which is a brand name AND a popular noun). Its got a striking appearance, and though I usually reserve this adjective for puppies or daughters: this is downright CUTE. I think its safe to say that if you take this bottle-cup-container-jar to work, youre going to get positive feedback.As to its features, I like the wide open mouthit makes drinking from it a very easy and pleasing experiencethis is no soda or water bottle with a tiny aperture. And, while it doesnt have interior threads for a screw-top enclosure, I think its safe to say that if you firmly situate the top down inside the mouth, that lid is going to stay closed  even if you store it on its side. There is a nicely ribbed plastic sleeve round the lid that really grabs and holds it in place.And speaking of that insulating cloth sleeve, I like that it fits snugly around the container without being at all difficult to slide the bottle-cup-container-jar withintheres no struggle at all. And it wont come off easily IF you slide the plastic clip on the top string nice and tight: it provides a great fit thats just as easily tightened as loosened.This brings up another aspect: though it comes with a very pleasant insulating sleeve, I would not necessarily think of it as something that would hold heatyoure not going to throw in a cup of hot soup and expect it to stay warm til you chow down at noon. However, it is easily microwaveable and then that insulating sleeve comes in really handy: its going to make it easy to hold a somewhat hot or cold liquid with relative comfort. As to storing a cold liquid, Id use sensible caution about packing ice cubes within it: this is glass, after all. That Dechunxian offers a three-month warranty speaks to that prudence.On the positive side, glass is SUCH a pleasant thing to drink from. I think most people will agree that glass is a LOT more satisfying container than plastic. It provides a much better taste experience and doesnt carry the smell many say plastic has.As to its size, 400 ml is about 7/8 of a pint. Its not huge; it wont provide you a gargantuan drink at the end of a workout, but it is a very good size for, say, a glass of tea or even NON-liquid treats, like nuts or granola or many other items.Which leaves us with one final point: what word will ultimately define this, um, bottle-cup-container-jar? I think boccujar is a little unwieldy, while other words like vessel or pot or jug dont quite cut it. How about ewer? (Its certainly no more unwieldy than Dechunxian.)I leave it to you to decide.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

If you are trying to use your laptop (or desktop) computer to make a multi-media presentation or play back video, this device adds an extra VGA port to your computer in a simple and efficient manner.Unfortunately I am no computer genius. This adaptor sat on my desk for quite a while before I had any real idea of what to do with it. Finally, knowing I had yet to do this review, I finally found a more savvy friend (though no computer genius) and he helped me. Here I must confess I didnt understand a lot of what he told me  in great part due to the fact that it seemed he was speaking a different language.I must admit I am at a complete loss when it comes to discussing such things as data flow and video cards and bandwidth. I feel like I am incapable of understanding anything in this realm.I know that he plugged the USB connector to my laptop and then installed the driver by using the disc provided. I also know that it didnt work the first time, and he made adjustmentsthough not extensive ones. And I know that after the initial installation-- as well as after the second adjustment -- he had to restart the computer (which the directions tell you to do), and let the computer run through its new adaptation. The second time around it was connected.Once the device was connected I thought that the images on the screen had good clarity and fine color display. I did not have any of the image problems some of the respondents mentioned such as jumping pixels, but there was a little bit of what one or two writers called lag time  in other words, a little pause right after giving the command. As this is primarily used for adding additional monitors to ones device, this should not be a huge disappointment.On top of his triumphant feelings concerning connection, my friend said that he thought that this was a good price for an adapter such as this. When I informed him that the product information displayed on the product page says it will handle up to six monitors, he believed it could be true, though it would require six adapters to do so. (I will leave it to wiser souls than mine to determine just how to do that.)It seems worth noting, finally, that LinkS provides a one-year warranty.Ultimately, I'm giving this a five star review because -- though I am not a great judge of technical issues -- it seems that this does what it sets out to do.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This is a really nice water bottle, as long as you realize its purpose is NOT to keep drinks cold. (By the way, though, it does that decently well.)I saw a "How It's Made" on bottles like this...It starts from a single pellet, flattened, and then extruded and pressed into a tubular form. One piece...no seams. It's pretty amazing.So what you don't get are any messy problems one typically gets with other kinds of bottles. No glass inside or out, no seams, no bending, melting, or fracturing the container. No leeching of chemicals into the liquid, no parts to keep track of other than the top, no taste from the plastic or any other compound surrounding the drink liquid.Just two parts: an impeccably clean stainless steel container and a plastic top.So, while it doesn't work like a true Thermos, it does a great job of working like a very good liquid container should: it keeps liquids safe and apart from any exposure to the elements; it is easy to handle and slim and could even be called "sleek." It is extremely clean and able to take a pretty substantial impact and remain not only undamaged but is also able to keep the liquid inside untainted.The container's shape is extremely beneficial to the task: it's easy to place within things like knapsacks and other carrying cases...right down to (larger) briefcases. It is very slim, and can be carried within the palm easily. The handle, if you will, is the top, which when screwed in securely becomes tote-able through its oval plastic loop. It would be easy to attach to a bicycle frame, as it is very aerodynamic. It is in effect a negligible thing when it comes to taking up space.And, perhaps most importantly, being of clean, stainless steel -- without solder or glue or any other material but the steel itself -- it does NOT impart any taste whatsoever to the liquid within. It is as clean a drink of water as you'll get: certainly as clean and clear as the water one places within it. If I may be permitted, there is something so "right" about steel as stainless steel as a container for water: it tastes pure and clear when imbibed, and thoroughly unblemished by the container that held it, which I feel is not true about certain plastics. It is like glass as a container, though there are of course no end of risks when water is transported within glass.Overall, this is a terrific container: hardy, strong, and clean. It almost will NOT break, and will not mar the quality of that which is within it.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This is a nice case that does a very good job at its initial and stated task: protecting the phone it encases. There is more to it, however, both positive (and a couple of negative points, too).First: as written, it does a good job of protecting the Galaxy S5 from collisions or strikes around the edges or back, as well as a fall upon the ground that does not strike within the screen. For instance, it would do a great job of protecting a phone that fell off a table and tumbled to the ground (or out of a pocket or even out of a moving car's window). It accomplishes this commendable feat though a combination of a hard exterior and a soft inner rubber liner. The former TAKES the hit, and the latter DISTRIBUTES the hit throughout the larger area. Together they effectively render almost all side, rear, or full-on, direct hits insufficient to do harm.In such a manner, the Mengo Stealth Armor Shockproof case does a great job of protecting its contents. It also looks nice, and adds to the appearance of the phone.As stated, the phone also comes with a stand, or "tripod," if you will. When one pulls out the little bar in the back it does indeed permit the phone to stand by itself -- though I found it more effective in the horizontal position. It tends to wobble when it's standing more vertically...at least in my experience.I found that when my Galaxy S5 was in this case and, say, in my pocket, or in my carrying pack, I felt assured that my phone was safe. I did not worry about bumping into something or placing my pack somewhere where its placement might otherwise threaten my phone's "health." Wearing the Mengo protective case, the phone was safe. It's a comforting feeling.Yet it has a couple of faults.First, while it can take a straight-on hit from all sorts of directions, it does NOT protect its screen from any kind of a strike that misses the edges and directly to its interior face. If such a hit occurs, and it's substantial -- like, say, hitting a rock or the corner of a chair or table or any of a variety of small edges. A good hit by something with an edge and contains some force to it could really hurt the glass face of the phone. But around its edges, or back, it's terrific.The other fault is that the rubber casing -- in particular, the on/off button and the volume button on either upper side --  is restrictive, and makes the pressing of those buttons difficult at best, and almost impossible at its worst. There were times I had to press, press again, and re-press that button again, hard before it would allow that button to work. While it is good that the rubber encasement is substantial in all other cases, allowing it to cover these buttons really hurts their ease of use and functionality. I might think it best to actually cut this portion OUT of the case if one finds this to be as difficult as I did.Other than those two factors, I found this to be a splendid protective case. There are a variety of collisions that could harm the phone that this case renders null ... and it looks good, too.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

Rebecca McCrays THE JOURNEY OF THE MARKED is a clever and fun YA story that occasionally stumbles over itself due to a complex list of characters and a jumpy narrative form. Regardless, it still manages to be appealing and even compelling at times.In fact, THE JOURNEY OF THE MARKED involves us because for the very same reason that sometimes makes it confusing: this is a very large story not only due to the size of the cast, but also because of their unique and diverse characteristics. The world of Zolei, we find, is a planet that seems to attract unusual groups of people. As the narrator informs us, Zolei is a refuge for persecuted species. Though the Miyran race inhabited the land first, the Tyrnotts have come along and forcibly grasped power from them, barely hiding their brutal nature. To garner help, the leader of the Miyrans, Lady Anyamae, has mysteriously placed striking marks behind the left ear of select citizens on their 16th birthdays, identifying them as future warriors for the cause.  Unfortunately, doing so also made them targets of the Tyrnotts roving military thugs, the Graelithshuge beasts who seem to be made for hunting and hurting others.And these are only a few of the races that inhabit Zolei  there are over a dozen more, each populated by unique characters. Some walk, some fly, and some even change from one form to another. Some get along with one another, and others become murderous when nearby certain others. And its getting worse: while those who inhabit its forests and cities have co-existed up until now, it is not a cohesive civilization, and the clock is tickingwhen a youth dies violently, her funeral attracts thousands of sympathizers, and the formerly peaceable peoples of the land are fed up with the status quo.To further complicate the narrative, the storylines zig-zag between chapters  that is, one set of characters and circumstances occurs in every, say, third chapter, and then two other storylines do the same. So it's easy to be confused when reading the story  it can be a  pretty puzzling potpourri of people, places, and plot.So: what to do? Well, I came up with an answer, and here goes:Go to Amazon and bring up the PAPERBACK version of JOURNEY OF THE MARKED.  Look for the little Search Inside This Book bar and type the phrase Glossary of Species. From here on in its simple: just leave that page up and refer to it as you read the book. Its going to take you a few chapters to get it all sorted out, but this will help enormously. Whenever you have a question, just pup over to that section and work it out.Once the characters begin to distinguish themselves in your mind, the going gets much easier. And thats when THE JOURNEY OF THE MARKED gets interesting. While we understand what motivates Tip, a Liput, to find whether his older brother Sri survived beyond the hour or so his oldest brother took to die; one can only wonder what it is that drives the very physical and competent Arlian teen named Kenrya to push others away. And we can certainly sympathize with the plight of Human boy named Eros, grown to young manhood without a father, and still wonders whether he will ever actually discover his own.And those are only a few of the stories.TJotM is a great tale for young adults, and while once again I think some may be put off by the large cast and complex narrative, I think they will be happy to put forth the effort. After all, every bit of the story is accessible; McCrays writing style is easy to follow and her vocabulary and her sentence/paragraph construction are extremely reader friendly. All in all, there is more than enough here to make a go of a long series, one that readers would be eager to follow.

I am in love...This glass protector for my Samsung Galaxy S5 is a beautiful thing: it was extremely easy to install and it looks WONDERFUL! I cannot tell you how pure it looks other than to say it appears there's nothing there at all...with this exception: NOTHING now mars the images on my Samsung Galaxy screen.When it was time for me to pick out a new phone I picked the S5 because the bare screen has a beautiful visual display that is wide, tall, and, unfortunately...RIPE for CRACKING.It's my greatest fear. I'm an older guy and I do all the nutty things older guys do: I carry the phone in my pocket along with things like change and nail clippers, I am always taking it out while I work on little projects that often place it around all sorts of tools, and to top it all off I have shaky hands. You can see why I worry.I did get a protective case for it, and a plastic screen protector - the little wallet shielded it front and back, but even that had its problems: the billfold's slots created little scratches on the soft plastic screen protector. So, while the screen was literally covered and protected, it always looked crummy. Additionally, the plastic protector allowed fingerprints and other impurities to further "dirty up" the screen.When I received the Bluboon protector for testing I worried about putting it on: like most people I usually had problems placing the plastic kind of protectors with any degree of proficiency: try as I might there were always bubbles in the plastic. But NOT the Bluboon: no worries at all. No dimples or bubbles or any other difficulties. Think: it's a little, tiny, pane of glass! Just peel off the backing, align it, and lay it down on the glass. Press on it to make sure it's on there, and you're done.Now, it's worth saying that, as this IS glass, if there is going to be any damage done here it will suffer like the phone's original glass screen would have were it not protected. So protect it: the best thing is to put it in a case of some kind. But you can at least rest assured that no key ring or nail clipper or seat belt or pen, etc., is going to scratch your screen. Glass is strong - until it shatters, of course. But at least it's your screen protector that will take the brunt of it in all but big hits.But until it all this screen protector is really beautiful. Minor cleaning is all that's needed...I use lint-free cloths or the little Zeiss Pre-Moistened wipes I use to keep my eyeglasses clean. With that tiny amount of care, I still really can't believe how good my screen looks.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.
This is the best book I have ever read by an author who can lick himself.

The Bluboon is a really good and faithful speaker when it comes to reproducing sound in typically wet or outdoor areas: your shower, outside in the rain, or in a workroom where you typically find things to be a little rougher on products that lie nearby. This is the great strength of the Bluboon, in fact: its an extremely hardy individual speaker.As to its overall specifics (what a great oxymoron!)The unit paired up well (and very easily) with both my S5 Samsung android phone as well as my Kindle HD Fire tabletthe process took almost no time and succeeded on the first try. It was accomplished within maybe two minutes.In terms of its fidelity, it did a pretty good job of reproducing the crisp acoustic guitar work and dead on harmonies of in 20 Years by the Civil Wars; the complexities of horn and voice of #41 by the Dave Matthews Band; the light, airy harmonies of Feelin Groovy by Simon and Garfunkel; the drop-dead joy of Roundabout by Yes the Bluboon handled all of it capably and did so while free of electronic noise and static.Like I said, its not going to do the job you might find in an expensive automobile sound system, but thinking it should isnt fair. This is a good product that will reproduce sound particularly well IN your shower areaafter all, dont YOU usually sound better in there, too? So, no, youre not going to find the same sound here as you might sitting in a sound chamber blasting a pair of Blaupunkts at you, but you SHOULD expect a fairly good representation of sound without worrying about doing harm to your sound system.As to its waterproofing: though I dont know that Ill ever get over feeling crazy when I splash water at electronic products, but this one passed that test as well. To that end, the Bluboon not only has a vigorously hardy appearance, but it played on every time it either accidentally fell or was purposely dropped: as you might be able to tell from its photo, its covered by a rubber tire exterior that really does provide it a hardy durability.Its full-sized suction cup in back is more than capable of hanging on not only DURING your shower but in the duration of time between them as well. And it will stay in place while you play with its features (e.g.: F-F, Reverse, Pause, etc.) as long as you take reasonable care when you do so. The speakers functions are reasonably easy to use, though if youre a person who doesnt wear your glasses in the shower you might find that the uniformly black and pebbly exterior is hard to read  therefore, its up to your memorizing which buttons you need to touch, say, if someone calls; or if you want to hear something over again. And while you CAN increase the volume from this device, Ive found its infinitely easier to do it on the unit OUTSIDE of the shower.This was about the only weakness I found in the Bluboon: it would be a great benefit if the function buttons were brightly enumerated by symbols, or at least raised lettering, as I had trouble determining how to adjust its features without my glasses on  which is primarily how most of us will be encountering this device in the pool or bathroom. As there is about a second long "lag" between pushing a button and having the device carry out the instruction, it does make the process of altering what ever it is you're altering -- be it volume or the track number or answering the phone -- a little worrisome.That said, though, I found the Bluboon to be a more than capable speaker unit. It reproduced sound well and across a wide range of musical and non-musical genres (if I can call answering the phone a "genre"). While I did find some of its features to be a little difficult to manage in the shower, it more than pleased me when it came to handling my playlist or answering the phone while being splashed and even dropped in the bathroom.NOTE: I was supplied this product free of charge with no other conditions other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.

Is there anybody out there who finds this "look" for a flash drive offensive? I'm all for owning guns, but I find this to be a precedent that I would not like to see popularized. Guns are a kind of item I do not want to see popularized in this manner-- like putting their lookalikes in items that children can easily own without having the maturity to understand them.

This was an extremely easy to use and easy to set up, and I don't even have an iPhone!While I did try this case ON an iPhone 6, the primary testing was done with my Samsung Galaxy s5, which was a piece of cake to set up through my Bluetooth settings. It took about a minute for the whole setup, and from that point onward it worked extremely well -- and to repeat, I was using it with a non-iPhone product.I was equally impressed with its range. I didn't JUST walk a couple of dozen feet away, but I went around a corner as well, and in between the remote and my NON iPhone were a couple of electronic devices like a cordless phone station and a working microwave, and I still had no problem.I will tell you that there is a very small lapse of time between the pressing of the button and the clicking of the camera, but it was no more than around a second. Knowing that, you can take it into account when shooting a photo.I found it pretty easy to pull out and put into the case, though being plastic there can be a tendency to be a little bit off track when trying to align the product with its housing. Placing the case ON the iPhone made the product more stable -- which of course would be the way one uses such a product, UNLIKE the way I "normally" used and tested this product, but even when I put the case ON an iPhone 6 it still occasionally "wanted" to go off the plastic alignment groove. But again, knowing this made me just a little more conscious of putting it on correctly, and it worked fine.Incidentally, I received the pink case (as shown) and, while I would not order pink usually, I still was secure enough in my manhood that I can say I found it to be an attractive plastic case, nicely made, and reasonably sturdy. While the pink color is vivid, It does not go overboard, and the case is actually quite streamlined and VERY light...it will not add a thing to the total weight of your phone.[FYI: I would NOT buy this as a protective case (which is NOT how it is being marketed, so I didn't judge it this way -- this point is purely informational). For instance, this doesn't protect the screen at all when and if it falls. But, again, it does not claim it will.]All in all, I really liked this product. While I am NOT a selfie kind of person (I think the fewer shots of me, the better), this does have excellent applications in other ways. For instance, I am a chronic pain sufferer who is over 60, and though I am quite remarkably studly in all other ways, my hands do shake. Therefore, being able to place the camera down and then click the shutter without touching it REALLY helps steady the shot, and I think many would appreciate this advantage. I found this to be the best reason to use this button, to tell the truth.Altogether, I found this to be an excellent product with some definite advantages, and it did everything it claimed it would. Overall, I remain quite impressed.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

First...you should note that each of the windows that offers you different colored case is A:SO offering you a different configuration of that product. AND: in some of those cases, the cable ties are NOT OFFERED. (See the RED one, for example) More on this later in my second-to-last paragraph.Secondly: I ordered and received the blue case, and couldn't be more happy with it. The product is well made, the elastic organizers are well situated and sewn in, the zippers inside and out are in good working order, and I only found two excess threads in the whole kit (which I nail-clipped right out)...no problem.The kit works well, and provides for nice organization of -- in my case -- a collection of similarly sized short cords. Should you want to place longer connectors in your kit, get a different model. Some are created just for that.I am very pleased with the case, and it does just what I hoped: allow me to place a series of connectors in my case for various reasons: cables with USB connectors, or pin connectors, or any number of other ones. I'm able to store different other connector tips in the mesh portion, and that portion zips.The kit also comes with Velco ties that are additionally helpful when it comes to organizing and separating the ties. (See the note below.)NOTE: my kit was missing those ties -- they WERE offered with my kit -- so I considered knocking the kit down a star or two because of that, as I was not sure how lucky or difficult I might find it to go through the process of contacting someone to report the problem, especially because I had not noticed the missing tie until a couple of days later, by which point I had thrown away some of the packing slip/invoice that came with the kit, and this is a "third-party" offering sold by Amazon. I tried to figure out how to go through contacting BUBM (or Xqueen, the seller who supports BUBM), but that seemed to be very difficult to do (maybe I didn't understand the process). So, I just went through Amazon and they were TERRIFIC, offering me a MORE than substantial credit for those missing ties. I couldn't have been happier with Amazon's Customer Service, who did a great job.Anyway, I am very happy with this kit.
