The first thing I noticed about this belt after taking it out of the package is it's quality: good stitching, nice fabric: made of cloth, Velcro and (primarily) neoprene, it looks substantially well crafted and should last a long time.This is designed to fill three purposes once for the wearer:1. to help you sweat off weight around your waist;2. to look slimmer around the waist;3. to help support the lower back.This product accomplishes all three of those goals -- and more. In short:The wrap is comfortable, and can be worn by men and women. As it is made of Velcro and is easy to adjust, the wearer might have to find somewhere private to accomplish this.If one wears it for any length of time, it will make the wearer sweat. It is not an obvious thing: no lines of sweat formed on my clothes, and in fact some of the sweat was absorbed by the belt itself. But at no time was my sweating obnoxious or problematic...in that sense the belt was a success for me. But understand this is not a belt that makes sweating the Number One Priority...there are other belts out there that will make you sweat more, but remember those belts will be hard to wear in public, while the Ohuhu should be okay -- you don't have to worry about it "popping" open. (But I'd wear it a few times to "practice" before I took it to work or somewhere else important.)For the next goal -- that of trimming the wearer's waistline -- this belt has the capacity to accomplish that just fine. As one might expect, the wearer can tighten his or her waist as much as (s)he wants (noting, of course, that the belt itself does add a little to your waistline). I wore the belt and looked in the mirror, AND asked my wife, and we both agreed it did a decent job of trimming. The belt's width is really nice when it comes to the trimming factor: it's a little over 7 inches wide, and that covered a good portion of the area between my belt and my ribs.FYI: I think I'm in the mid-range of needing to trim -- I'm 5 foot 10 and have a 36" waist. I'm not thin, and I certainly could use a good trimming. But I caution those who have a good deal of paunch below and above the area of the belt...as one might expect, it would look unnatural.As for back support, I think it did a good job for a belt like this...as once more I do not think is its a primary purpose. I think, like before, that this feature does a good job of wrapping the wearer's midsection in a pretty strong fabric, but this does not have any firm leather or plastic to prevent the wearer from hurting him (or her) self. I think the belt's presence, however, makes the wearer aware of his/her back, and the device does restrict the wearer's movements to a good extent. In that sense, I think this does protect the wearer.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This is a sharp-looking bathroom scale. Chrome edged on both sides, its glass base is accented in black along the sides and top, and its readout panel is dark enough that the numbers seem to jump out of the base once the scale is stepped upon.  They're a good size, and are easily readable. Not only are they white upon black, but they are almost an inch and a quarter in height.When one steps upon the scale, at first the numbers bounce above and below your weight until you settle and the final numbers read out the figures...like a local weather forecaster who tells you about what you may not want to hear. (My measurements were calculated in pounds, but they are also available in kilograms for those who wish to adopt the metric system...the transformation is simple.)Additionally, the base is big enough for my size 11s...I did not have any trouble getting on the scale, or with balance, or with the way it distributed my weight. The process was always easy and quite comfortable.That's not a surprise to me: Smart Weigh is a company whose products I have tested several times, and I have always been impressed with the accuracy of their scales. The same goes here. I have been able to test one scale against the other, have received calibration weights to double check those figures, and have even in this case been able to measure my weight on the scale, and then shortly after upon my doctor's scale.Dead on.And most importantly to me, my wife liked the way the scale looked, and thoroughly approved its adoption as our main scale...the old one's going to the yard sale.One additional note: this comes with batteries included: all you have to do is install them.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

"I'm not Holly. I'm not Lula Mae, either. I don't know who I am! I'm like cat here, a couple of no-name slobs." Holly Golightly (Breakfast at Tiffany's)This wonderful likeness screams Audrey Hepburn, and it's a rather stylish one, indeed:  the headpiece, the necklace, the whiskers...All right, there is some artistic license at work here, but I must tell you that I am sold on this pillow. When I was offered a chance to review it I agreed quickly as a kind of camp-y fun: I so often really try to do a good job with these reviews, and I do as much as I can to be serious about the task at hand. But this? It jst looked like a little bit of fun, and then I'd give the pillow to a relative, friend, or yard sale.But upon opening the mail I found myself to be immediately impressed: this is actually a very pretty and well made pillowcase. Yes, it's a cat with the likeness of Audrey Hepburn -- but what a nice likeness it is! The purple really springs out at you, the eyes are plaintive, the expression to die for, and the pillow's construction is actually VERY well carried out.As a result, my wife and I have placed it in the living room, front and center on the living room couch. We have no problem with displaying such a well-made product prominently. And in truth the case (you get the case only, and have to fill it with a pillow of your own) is very hearty: it's a sturdy canvas cloth exterior without being rough or uninviting, and though the pillow I stored within was abysmally near its own death, it gained a second life due to Audrey's kind adoption.The colors are vivid and well detailed: there is no bleeding off of the image across lines or any other defect. I'm very impressed. It's decently sized too: about a foot and a half square.And lest you think all the images are campy or silly, there is a variety being offered online, and you ought to check it out: there are many images I found myself interested in.So all in all I must say I accepted the pillow for its silly, fun image, but I immediately became a convert; this company (Flatworld) puts out a good product.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is...

This is exactly what it appears to be: a well-made organizer that lies flat against the door and allows the user to place within it 12 pairs of shoes. (I don't think there are shoes thin enough that would allow two to be placed within one slot).The organizer comes with the equipment that will easily allow its user to hang it over the door, and the device simply hangs there -- which,of course, is exactly what it's supposed to do. It's made of a sturdy yet breathable material, and it seems well made: the stitching is quite capably done, and the whole apparatus has the feel of something that should last a good while.You know, there is nothing that demands it be used for shoes, either. It does make so much sense, though, that it cover a nice closet door and therefore make use of a space in your closet as yet unused. But it is possible, I suppose, to put all sorts of things in them: hobby and craft equipment; knick-knacky kind of stuff you weren't sure what to make of; belts and other accessories; and so on. But the breathability of the material lends itself to letting your shoes air themselves out (as long, I guess, as you leave your closet door open). Your choice.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

I'm not a professional photographer, though I was a reporter and photographer for a small daily newspaper in the 1970s -- well before the operation of a camera became digital. but the basics are still the basics, and I can speak to these here.This is a terrific product, and I think it's safe to say it is everything the Ohuhu people say it is. It's easily carried, simple to put together and a great reflector of diffuse light in. For those who aren't familiar, "diffuse" refers to spreading the light evenly -- in effect, "softening" that light rather than projecting direct, harsh spotlight. This particularly affects two areas: 1) skin tone (as strong light tends to make a pale subject) and 2) shadows, as those tend to lighten and even disappear, including creases on a person's face, for instance, as it's really the shadows that define a crease.Though it's a bit small, this is a great reflector of light and an easy little kit to put together. It just takes a minute to assemble (though a little longer to put it back in its casing, as it's a little tricky). And, for most of your simple shots, where you are shooting head-and-shoulder "mug shots" of your subject, this provides enough reflection to do its job well.Let's say, for instance, you're outside, but the situation calls for your subject to have the back of his or her head toward the sun....hence, the face is in shadow. Assemble the kit in about a minute, and your subject is now in a softer, more pleasant light.I think this is an easy kit to throw in the car if you're heading off on a trip, even if it were to be rarely used. It's about the size of a big stack of pancakes, but light as a feather.  There's another model of this Ohuhu product  -- the Ohuhu 5 in 1 Collapsible Studio Lighting Reflector -- that is on a much bigger scale (almost 4 feet in diameter!), and this one is a lot more involved when it comes to its use, but the 9" product we're talking about here is extremely simple.All in all, I would definitely include this in my camera bag if I were a person who was serious about my photography as a job or hobby.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This is a great scale in many ways, and as Ill mention in the succeeding paragraphs I have only a couple of reasons I notched it down one point  and you may find that youll want to add that point back in when it comes to you and your family.There are several features that make this such an attractive scale. As you can see, its mostly clear, and its visible asset is that its design is so cleana curved white plastic bar on top, and two lean stainless steel bars on the side connecting the four circular pads. I just like that its so minimalistic. (I would rather they had not marked up the white bar with the kilogram/pound conversion writing, but this is NOT a big issue, and done is done.)While I like the scale a lot, the only real negative that I encountered is that it does not have a very big platformits a little difficult to climb up on it if you have big feet. There are many people out there with spine problems, like me, and there are therefore many who have a compromised sense of balance. Consequently, its difficult to get on something thats small like this, and I have had more than one occasion where the scale has wobbled under me because I had placed my foot too close to one edge.And if you notice, the upper end of this scale is given at almost 400 pounds. I dont think its a bit unkind to say that persons approaching that weight would likely have a big problem with the small space allottedand the balance issues as well.Other than that, it is a great scale. Given my balance issues, one of the things I like about it the Ohuhu scale is that the weighing process gives you enough time to situate yourself before it locks in. I like that, and so I believe will people balancing busy lives or older people who a beginning to find themselves to be a little unsteady.Whats MOST important, and really should be the only thing that matters, is that it seems to be very accurate as well. It matched up pound-for-pound with another scale I have, and also with my doctors: I weighed myself immediately before leaving for my visit, and their scale was only two ounces off ours. Id call that a winner.As I said, the only fault I found with it is that its platforms a little small, and that was the central reason I gave it four stars. If youre a smaller person, or are very sure on your feet, add that point back in and this becomes a near perfect scale.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

My middling-starred review is really a reflection of the normal high quality of Smart Weigh's usual products. It's not that this product is of really poor quality; it's not. But it's just that it's rather plain and the packaging is rather weak: I've had the box come open twice, and I've almost lost some of the paper-thin mg weights.In short, my reasons for giving this a middling grade fall into the casing and compartments. First, the plastic lid covers the compartments where I know the little mg weights should go, but I am frightened to put them under it because the lid is made of such a light plastic that, with no latch or clip or Velcro to make sure it stays in place, I am sure I would lose the TINY mg weights. Have you ever ripped paper out of a spiral notebook? You know the little nits of paper that comprise the ripped edge? Well, they're about as big as these milligram weights. (In fact, they might even be an OVER-exaggeration in some cases.) So I think the mini zip-lock plastic bag the seven or so of them come in is the best place for them.There is at least a decently strong latch on the outside of the kit, though I doubt it would withstand a drop from, say, waist high. But the outside latch IS the better latch of them all, and it's nice that it's the one keeping them all in.I can tell that there are a suitable representation of weights from the product description, and I believe that this is a good number of them to enable better calibration. In that respect, this kit seems just fine, and every bit as strong as many others.Anyway, good kit; not so hot display and storage.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

I like this new iPad cover and it has several very positive traits, but there are one or two negatives as well.First of all, the positives: I feel this case offers really adequate protection against light to medium threats. What that means is I feel it would survive a fall from, say, waist level (or a little higher), just fine. Mind you, I have not been daring enough with my iPad to subject it to such a test, protected or not, but it did get knocked off the couch once while mounted in the cover and there wasnt the slightest issue with it. I do not know if it would take a heavy shotfor instance, if someone were to sit on it, say, on an uneven surface, Im not sure it would necessarily survive that. But thats pretty unusual. For most regular everyday problems  having it fall from your knapsack, or tumbling off a desk, and so on  I think it would survive just fine. And those are the normal problems one would face, I feel.And then I really like the cover. Not only does it look really cute -- I particularly love the colors I had (from the top down, my cover is green, dark green, and orange) but I think the case is nice and thin and easy to carry.And its overall thin and easy to handle, carry, pack, and so on. The cover adds virtually NO weight to the iPadits so light its almost negligible. Theres almost no feeling of bulkiness.So here are the couple of problemsFirst, and most important, this fit our iPad2 a little TOO snugglynot only is it extremely tight when I try to put it into the case, but every time I have to remove it I think its going to break off the tab holding it in.  I DO feel the case is protective, but its just a bit too tight and unyielding; I really worry that it will soon create some kind of breakageThis really mattered because there is no way to plug in my iPad at night in order to charge it. I HAD TO remove it from the case in order to charge it. If this werent such a struggle it would be a negligible problem, but this was difficult and kind of bothersome.Also, but this is really MINOR: the additional pockets dont really allow much ability to do more than a couple of post it notes or a bus card or two. They were so tight they were almost useless.All in all, I thought it was a decent case for protection and carrying: in those respects this was sweet. But the access problems were kind of important, especially because I had no way to charge it without removing it from the case. Certainly, you want a case to really GRAB the item its protecting, but not releasing it was a difficulty. Again, Im not sure that I wouldnt break a tab before long.I was supplied this product free of charge with no condition other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.

This "kit" consists of three rectangular bags that accept a great deal of luggage on their own, yet neatly fit into their own carrying pouches when not being used. It's a great systemized approach to packing and organization -- with a couple of notes that bear paying attention to as you're considering this great little system.First of all, think of what life is like for the traveler. There are lots of items that form the core of certain classifications of clothes, and that's what lies at the heart of their Ohuhu system - underwear and socks and belts, etc in the smallest bag, t-shirts and shorts, etc in the middle bag, and pants and larger shirts, and perhaps shoes in the biggest bag. To my way of thinking, these are all bags that will have to fit INSIDE of other bags --- they don't have handles, and one of the outside panels is made of a strong mesh - not the stuff you want to have exposed to the outside world. I have found it wise to pack these bags tight with luggage in order to maximize the bags' ability to keep order within your luggage...otherwise there can be shifting within them. Not a huge problem, but if your key concern is organization, then this would be the route I would take.However you'll pack them, they can remain the foundation of certain kinds of clothes or other items you might not need at all times...kind of the equivalent of drawers in a dresser. Think of them as items you might place in that drawer, or stick somewhere out of the way...but always want to know where they are.The outside of each bag gives a quick visual cue to the kind of items that might be in one bag vs. another -- underwear and socks, for instance - there is no telling what system you might want to come up with: maybe a certain case may hold items concerning health: band aids, suntan oil, etc. Maybe you just want to know where books that might be related to a particular point in your vacation touring, or items to keep your kids busy. Regardless, the possibilities are up to you.One thing I liked about the bags is that they fold up nicely into little attached cases made of the same material as the bags. If you follow the directions in the sixth picture on the product page it will help you accomplish this goal. It's a great way to keep them in small containers if they're not being used at the time: this is a great feature that will allow you to carry all three of the bags in some corners of your suitcase that won't take up any more combined space than, say, a couple of books. They also include a little white bag for just that purpose. (If you click on one of the pictures on the product page you'll not only get a close-up of the picture, but also an eighth photo that will show you the white container.)As for workmanship, all the bags I received seem to be in good condition: no loose strings, misaligned zippers, stitching problems, etc. (I did not see any indication of a warranty.)I was supplied this product free of charge with no condition other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.

I grew up near NY City and there are certain rules you followed whenever you made the trip in, especially when you're alone:ALWAYS look as if you know where you're going. Even if you're a little lost, march someplace safe (like an eatery, or a grocery) and then get your bearings.NEVER take out a map in plain sight. If you must do it, find a place (like a discreet hallway or a bathroom) and take it out there.NEVER make eye contact with someone who looks "unusual" in this environment, edgy or confrontational.NEVER display any money. Make any transactions discretely, and do so as if you know what you're doing. And, more so...ALWAYS know what kind of change you're expecting.There are many more, especially in this new era, like NEVER hand someone your credit card, etc. (even in restaurants), but you get the drift. And the most important of all...When and if you get robbed, forget every other rule and give them WHATEVER THEY WANT...no argument.Anyway, the Landing Gear Money Belt is a great tool to avoid confrontation: it hides away (you can wear it on the outside of your clothes, but I prefer inside) and in that regard is very light and comfortable to wear. And it holds quite a lot. (If you keep a little cash in your pocket, and you prepare ahead of time to have your credit card or checkbook in your hand by the time you check out, there is really no reason for anyone to see you have this on.)The construction of the belt is superb, with double stitching everywhere and easy-to-grab zippers. The backing of the belt is a nice fiber mesh that feels comfortable against your skin  and the stretch belt is also well constructed, sewn into the fabric (and double-stitched) and is very comfortable around your back. And, while it is made of a stretchable elastic, it also allows for easy adjustments..I felt the bag looks stylish, though I would not personally like for the the belt to be seen by anyone. (It is a preferable thing for it to look nice, however.) Additionally, the fabric is quite visibly RipStop nylon (which can be seen by the little nylon squares in the stitching). This is an excellent fabric for durability -- as the name implies, it makes it a VERY difficult to rip.The uppermost pouch is approximately 11" wide x 4 1/2," but within there are ALSO two slots, or pockets, within it that are about 6" bx 3" and 3" x 3"...though the pouch's outer stitching would prevent something of that size being put in it. But, say, change would fit nicely.Also on the front, but lower, there is a 7 1/2" x 3 1/2" pouch as well. There are no inner pockets here. All in all, it is highly conceivable you could hide all your important credit cards, a checkbook or two, a decent-sized wallet (if you're a SEINFELD fan, I would not attempt to carry a George Castanza wallet...I think that might be pushing it.)Again, I was very impressed with Landing Gear's workmanship on this travel belt. I bent it and contorted it, and I felt that the bag seemed to hold up fine under worse than ideal wearing conditions. And again, there is an elastic loose-knit backing that lies against your skin, which allows for breath-ability on a hot day. (There is a slot on the upper left of this knit backing, so something could be slipped back here, too -- while there is a full 10" x 5" of area within this pouch, there is only a 2 3/4" opening, so you could not slide anything larger than that into the pouch unless it bent or was rolled up, etc.)As for the elastic band that goes around your back, if fits me fine, and I have a 36" waist. The band allows for someone several inches smaller, as well as someone several inches bigger, to wear it comfortably. I would caution that the elastic band is only 1" wide, so it would be wise to get it to the most comfortable fit, as you wouldn't want the band to become uncomfortable over the course of time, especially on a hot day,Landing Gear claims that the synthetic fabric blocks RFID (Radio Frequency Identification) protection -- that is, this fabric blocks using special electromagnetic frequencies to try to discern the identification on any card you hold that has a magnetic strip on it. This seems to be a very important quality of protection. Additionally, the company warranties the product for one year -- a period of time that would, I believe, allow you to spot any defects in workmanship.I was supplied this product free of charge with no condition other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.

A big term in sci-fi and fantasy is "World Building," and it's a quality CITY OF STAIRS has in spades. From the quoted texts that lead in each chapter, through the spot-on characters that populate it, reinforced by the fully imagined culture that surrounds every scene -on these pages the city of Bulikov springs to life.  For centuries Bulikov had been a place almost beyond imagination, a city literally ruled over by the gods - but that was before the murderous coup did the impossible and struck them down, killing them off. And in doing so their assassins had hoped to exterminate all of the dieties' enchantments as well , even though they numbered in the thousands, even tens of thousands. From the creation of great buildings to the tiniest of daily activities, the astonishing ways of the divinities that had grown to make everyday life a glorious thing were now lost, and for many decades the city lay in ruins. It was a defeat enforced as much by the death of their gods as it was by those who usurped their powers: the bureaucrats of the nation of Saypur. These conquerors had no interest in seeing the city of Bulikov prosper - instead, they even passed laws of every sort to make sure that Bulikov's very history was forgotten, making it a crime to even speak the names of the deities or recall their old ways - in the many decades of their administration they had made illegal almost everything to do with their old belief system. As such, the native Saypuri culture languished, and its people felt the iron fist of repression.The novel begins a murder of a Saypuri Cultural Administrator, and in his place comes his unlucky replacement: Shara Thivani, a woman whose position is a front that allows her to investigate the death of her former mentor. Though she is a slight woman who cuts anything but an daunting persona, she is experienced enough to know how to get things done. Yet the strong-willed Shara is soon puzzled by the roadblocks being thrown in her way as she begins her investigation. Though she is initially stymied, has a few aces up her sleeve, and one of them is an imposing one-eyed man who stands almost seven feet tall - a man named Sigrud, whose face is marked by scars and whose manners are those of someone who answers to no one save Shara.What unfolds upon these pages is more than a who-done-it: it is a tale that winds its ways around these cultures through a skilled hand that permits us to see the large and the small with equally deft strokes of his pen...and through him we are introduced to a city-state that lies in shambles, a place whose inhabitants struggle to simply make it through another day while its administrators from Bulikov live lives of privilege and power.It is to Bennett's credit that we see a tapestry of life here: those who have, and those who make do. And, while the character of Sigrud is of course initially someone who captures our interest, I quickly became invested in Shara, a woman who makes her way through her demanding job by exercising the great strength of her mind. She is a woman who knows this culture inside and out, a woman of great sophistication, yet what I liked about her most where her contradictory quirks: though she is barely ninety pounds she consumes vast amounts of tea; and in the midst of cataclysmic events her greatest profanities are phrases like "My goodness!" and "Oh, good gracious!" She is a woman who is a strong patriot, yet has not touched her country's soil for 16 years. And while she holds her native country dear, she is not afraid to go against the strictures of its highest officials, especial one great aunt who holds her neck in a not-so-figurative noose.Lest you believe this to be a world in which the writing is only about politics, society and culture, rest assured that this is a story that still packs a visceral punch. There are monsters here, both of a figurative and literal sense. CITY OF STAIRS is a tale of intrigue that does not mind getting its boots dirty, a tale of a crumbling metropolis whose very walls hide demons and horrors that hint that its deities may not truly be dead. And though the incomparable Shara is determined to discover its secrets, she soon concludes that if her own compatriots are determined to stand in her way, she might be best served by working with her enemies.I think credit should go to Bennett also for the sheer interest level his book maintains from beginning to end. Additionally, Bennett is to be praised for maintaining a high quality of writing, as his book never sinks to easy solutions or cheap tricks to solve his lofty concepts. For instance, I initially worried that the story was going to be driven by whatever silly tasks they were going to give the monstrous Sigrud, yet while Bennett does not spare us some great scenes with the man, he did not rule the roost when it comes to action scenes.If there are any faults with this novel, I'd say they were not huge: I felt the pacing at the start was a bit slow, and at the end there is a relationship that is left very unresolved. But really, these are small complaints in a sea of praises. I'm glad I read CITY OF STAIRS, and if indeed there are to be sequel(s) as hinted, I would look forward to reading it/them. Based on what I have read here, I think I shall also read more of Bennett's other works as well.A NOTE FOR READERS WHO LIKED THIS BOOK: There are two books I think which are quite close in their striking abilities to tell a tale well, to create a fictional cast of characters with a life-giving touch, to build a story of considerable heft and weight, and to "world build" so well that you will find yourself looking for travel brochures. The first is well known:  The Golem and the Jinni (P.S.), by Helene Wecker. The second is one you will most likely never have known existed: Cornerstone, by Peter Diamantopoulos. Both, though, tell strong tales that have as much to do with story as they do with creating a vibrant and breathing world in which their characters can live and prosper. Ultimately, too, these are both strong, character-driven tales that will leave you wishing there were equally substantial sequels you could take off the shelf that minute and read.

0:28 MinsThis is a very easy-to-use device that many will find indispensable. It is particularly indispensable to those who A) Don't like to fold shirts; B) Find they have a lot to do at one time; C) Care enough about things like shirts and such simple items that they don't want to simply throw them into a drawer or a suitcase willy-nilly the moment they pop out of the dryer; and D) Have limited time to do them.With this simple device one only needs to be able to lay out a t-shirt front side down, and the rest is simple: right side over the middle, left side over the middle, bottom up. Done.There are several of these kinds of devices ("As Seen on TV!") out there, and I think they're relatively interchangeable. But this particular device does have clips on the right, left, and bottom pieces that allow the user to lengthen or shorten the device (for small, medium or large shirts), and that's nice.It is definitely a device one gets better at as one goes along...but as this is best used when there is a large number of t-shirts facing him/her, the person gets better at it relatively quickly.I've included in my video an alternate manner of folding shirts that doesn't require any equipment, and it's just about as fast a method of doing it. All one needs to do is lay it out neatly -- this time facing UP -- and follow the instructions I give you in the short video. The ONLY drawback is a minor one: as it varies the method of folding very slightly, the result differs a little bit. This method of folding requires a little more careful handling of the t-shirt after completion so that the "final" sleeve does not come loose. But, again, it's free.I was supplied this product free of charge with no condition other than my writing a fair and honest review -- which this is.

A Bit of Relevant Personal History: When I was about ten (half a century ago!) I was playing with my younger brother and I zigged when he zagged, and his dive for my legs met nothing but table...and he opened up a two inch gash right at the eyebrow level. There was blood everywhere...if you've ever been unlucky enough to be there when someone cuts his or her eyebrow you'll know just how much blood a cut like that can foster.Back to Now: To help prevent another horrible accident like this, these Ohuhu cushions for edges and corners are REALLY thick...about the thickness of a man's thumb. It's a substantial cushioning guard against those naked, sharp edges of coffee tables and stair rails and wall corners and whatever else there is around a house that could really hurt young kids. After seeing and touching these cushions, I am convinced that they are substantial enough to prevent injury should anyone, child or otherwise, accidentally bump into one. They are substantial foam cushions...Ohuhu touts that these are high density and extra soft, and from handling them I can only agree: they are very generous cushions and should amply protect any corner you fear might hurt a child who comes in contact with it.And, should you look at the photos provided, you'll see the padding fits nicely against the cornering cushions, and these are easy to cut into whatever lengths you'll need. The brown coloring is a relatively neutral color, and it will minimize its placement against any wood furniture, walls, etc.While there are 15 feet of cushions, they provide 30 feet of double-sided 3M tape - when you handle these big cushioning edges you'll realize that BOTH interior edges need to be affixed firmly for maximum safety.  Unless one makes some kind of heinous error, there should be ample tape for all the corners and edges they supply.Here are my only concerns:1. Though the kit says instructions are included, I did not receive any instructions.2. I found the 3M double-sided tape to be difficult to work with - that is, to peel. My fumble-y "man fingers" did not do a good job of working with these strips...I not only had trouble with getting the first backing strip off, but the second portion was nigh upon impossible. (I do want to stress, nonetheless, that 3M tape is a very good product. It's just small and thin.It's obvviously a concern one should weigh when thinking of setting up this form of safety measure.3. I have a concern that should the double-sided tape spend any substantial time on varnished surfaces, or paint, or any other similarly damage-able surface, I worry that the tape might tear off or scar whatever surface it was taped to. I wonder if it might have been safer to simply use small Velcro tabs every foot or so, thus causing less potential area for scarring. Looking through 3M's products, I found no information that these strips were easily removable once they were used, so my assumption is that they might take some of the product off when removed.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

I was not expecting to like this film so much.While the Spiderman movies have always been watchable and even sometimes involving, I'd felt that they had lately gotten a little too angst-y for my tastes, too involved in expressing teenage issues and romance over the more enjoyable action angles. Let's face it: I wasn't paying $25 per ticket (and food) in order to see how Parker's love life was doing.But I found this movie to be almost immediately entertaining and the action scenes were snappy and drove the story quite well. There were little glitches at times, but overall I found this to be a rich and exciting movie.Like I said, I wasn't so sure at the start. I immediately cringed when I determined what passed for dialogue here...the movie aimed for what I call the "Shia LaBeouf" style of patter that dearly wants to feel it's being honest and realistic, bur really all it does is have the characters talk over each other's lines and mutter endlessly...it devalues dialogue to the point of my not caring at all. Here, though, Jamie Foxx's early depiction of Max Dillon was so purposely shy that he became a doormat for almost everyone, and his inability to articulate or project his dialogue displayed that very point.But what made this film so enjoyable for me was its terrific visual style; this movie, more than any of its predecessors , revels in its titular characters' unique method of locomotion, and it is a remarkable thing to watch in this movie. This time around director Marc Webb (The Amazing Spider-Man, (500) Days Of Summer) used cinematographer Daniel Mindel (the two latest Star Trek movies) and the change is for the better...this film is A LOT more visually stunning than the last. Replete with crystalline, lucid photography and powerful moments of "trapped" motion, the scenes of Spidey looping his way through Manhattan have such crackling visual power and kinetic energy that it's almost impossible to do anything else but be dazzled by it. I really felt like I was swooping along with Spiderman, and it consistently makes for a gloriously fun ride.In addition, there are other clever, unusual pluses in the film: for one thing, there is a playfulness within that strikes at unusual times. For example, Peter Parker (Andrew Garfield) wants so badly to talk to Gwen Stacey (Emma Stone) that he often makes ridiculous mistakes: for instance, there's one throwaway moment when he is so eager to speak to Gwen that he uses his web to swoop down to speak to her still wearing his civvies. At another point he comes in close quarters with a cop blaring away on a megaphone, and after the man in blue speaks right into Spiderman's face our hero in turn shouts out his own next few lines, temporarily deaf.And while I'm really not a fan of Jamie Foxx, I thought he did all right here. For me, Jamie Foxx movies often suffer because the actor tries too hard to eat up the scenes - like, say, Vin Diesel or Tom Cruise. He often has that "Golly, aren't I terrific?" quality -- but here I thought his role was very submerged. In fact, as I mentioned earlier his character was so mousy he almost disappeared.A little sidebar, here, in fact: I've often felt our villains tell a lot about the concerns of society: Rodan and Godzilla speak to a nation frightened by nuclear power, for instance, or global terrorism within the DIE HARD franchise, or increased depersonalization in films like The Matrix. Here, Foxx's Dillon becomes Electro after a dispute with his bosses at work. In essence, one could argue he is bears a strong resemblance to those ripped from our own headlines. Certainly, we don't feel sympathy for those in our own society who fight with their managers, then go home, gather their weapons, and return to their workplace in order to shoot it out with anyone who stands in their way. Yet our comic book sympathy increases ESPECIALLY if that very same person has that same initial confrontation -- and then falls into a very conveniently placed vat of electric eels.  Particularly because, in the latter case, you've got yourself a Super Villain.The movie makes some odd choices...I think if we haven't overworked the Nazi mad doctor (even in comic strips) we've come awfully close, and Dr. Alex Kafka (?) and his over-sized black rubber gloves, though true to the comic, may be that one time too many.But I think the award for The Most Misused Hollywood Star may be won here, as Paul Giamatti is all but invisible in this film. Granted, they're setting him us up for the NEXT film, but when will that come along? 2018? Here, I doubt most people even knew he was in the movie.But here's a personal Cry Out to ALL MOVIES EVERYWHERE: could we stop, for all time, the trope that has our hero stop the bad guy, then turn our back on him before they are sure the criminal is down and completely out? It happens at the start of this movie, during a fight aboard a private jet in which our hero's parents are duking it out with a Bad Man who has sabotaged their plane. They overcome him, but then OF COURSE, our hero turns his back on the bad guy, who OF COURSE, comes back to life.. When, oh when, will Hollywood stop using this gimmick?

This us a great pair of gloves.First of all, they fit great (more on that in a minute), they are plush, and the thick fabric really keeps the hot objects you're holding away from your skin. In this manner you can hold the item longer, which is essential if you're a wood stove owner like me. With wood stoves, one has to occasionally reach in and physically grab a piece of wood and move it, and if the glove you're using cannot insulate you from the object you're touching, you're in big trouble.In addition, these gloves come with silicone grips (the lines colored blue), which not only give you a better grip on anything you pick up, but also has the trait of holding the item even further away from your skin. Again, this is extremely important, as anyone who handles these items will tell you. These grips will come in very handy to anyone handling hot pan handles or movingAs an added feature the gloves have good wrist coverage, which should be an obvious plus.In fact, this pair of gloves is rated as heat resistant up to 662 degrees Fahrenheit...I don't want to minimize the seriousness and importance of getting burned, but doesn't that sound awfully specific? (It makes one wonder what that particular testing session was like: "It's okay...okay...okay...Ouch! Ouch! Ouch!)But on a more serious note, back to the fit: while they do not have a "true" thumb placement like a real pair of gloves, this is mitigated by the fact that they are made of a "giving" cloth fabric, which allows the thumb to shift over to a more "true" position. In case you wonder why this is important, try handling a several hundred degree piece of wood with a hand whose thumb is essentially misplaced-- where the thumb is in fact working against you -- and you'll quickly understand why having a thumb that is easy to use is so important. Plasticky or rubberized gloves will have this problem...using them is tricky and can require a lot of caution. But not these...they fit well.But there is a hidden plus to all this: you essentially have four gloves. Where this is important is: let's say you have a left-hand glove whose middle digit has torn or finally succumbed to a burn or some other similar problem...just wear that glove on your RIGHT hand from now on, and you can put that hole on the BACK of that hand's middle finger. It's a truly nice way to extend the wear or life of a pair of gloves.Realize too, there are more uses for these gloves than just around wood stoves: they can be used around grills, around normal stoves, around campfires, around fireplaces, and even changing light bulbs or handling frozen objects. In addition, the company recommends keeping them clean, as dirt or grime can reduce their effectiveness.They are one size fits all, and while they look huge at first glance one must realize that one of their assets is that they are many layered in order to increase their insulation. I always wear large-sized gloves, and these fit my hands just fine, with room to spare.NOTE: I was sent this product in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

This towel is billed at 60 x 30 inches, and it easily measures that -- my towel measured about 61.5" by 30.5". And it is soft, but realize it is thin. I think it's about the thickness of a soft shirt. The fabric is ultra smooth and comfortable to the touch. Its edges (hems?) are firmly and pleasantly stitched, so to all appearances it has a durable construction that will last a good long time.Given these dimensions -- especially its soft but thin quality -- I think one of its main pluses is that it can quite easily be folded into the size of about a trade paperback book, about 8 by 5 inches and an inch thick (It comes with a nice little bag that easily accepts it if you fold it with a minimum of care). Therefore, it would be easy to pack into a carry-on bag on an airplane, freeing you from having to use one of the blankets airlines hand out -- I never trust them for cleanliness or being germ free, whereas this would be. The manufacturer says that it has an antibacterial coating that prevents mold. Additionally, it could be used on car trips or simply sitting on your couch watching TV -- it cannot replace, say, a terrycloth robe or blanket, but it certainly is very soft and pleasant to cover oneself on the couch.Another positive quality it has is that it can absorb quite a bit of moisture. I used it to dry myself off as I came out of the shower, and it did a fine job -- the moisture almost seems to instantly disappear. I'm in my sixties, so if you have a full mane of hair you may require more than my paltry 'do, but as I said it did a fine job of drying me off. But it almost takes no time at all to dry...if you can hang it up on a hook (it comes with a nice little strap) for 15 minutes or so it feels almost completely dry. (The company says it will soak up three times its weight, and I have no reason to doubt that claim.)Therefore, I can certainly also recommend it as a towel for the gym. Not only does it do a fine mob of toweling me off after a shower, its quality of almost instantly feeling dry again is something that makes it ideal for a gym bag, or a towel to take along on a bicycle trip, or hiking, or a picnic lunch, or game bleachers, or a concert or almost anywhere one requires a lightweight cloth for sitting upon, drying off, placing on the ground as a barrier against sitting on dirt, or to soften a hard bench or bleacher seating. Like I said, it's not thick, but it certainly enough to provide comfort, cleanliness, or soaking up a mess.NOTE: I was sent this towel in exchange for an honest review ... which this is.

I have Corgis, and in so saying I have revealed that I am at the daily whim of a small pack of four-legged dictators. Add to that a thoroughly swayed wife: a woman of great mental and personal prowess in ALL other areas save one regarding an inordinately cute dog that looks like a baby bear in pajamas EVERY FREAKIN' DAY OF ITS LIFE.Regardless, this review is about Natural Balance, and its effectiveness as to my dogs. One of our dogs, Abbey, had been breaking out with skin issues some time back, and we made a great deal of effort to solve it. After countless steroid injections and shampoo trials, etc, we decided to take a food trial with a novel protein as its source: RABBIT. And it worked.Abbey's skin issues have ceased. We have been CONVINCED by our prolonged and repeated time periods of its use that Dick Van Patten's Natural Balance dog food is the answer to our dog's sensitive digestive issues.We didn't come by NB on a whim; we tried A LOT of other dog foods first -- as anyone knows who is considering buying this product (or ones with equal claims), NB (and those others) are expensive.  However, I will also put it to you that so are food-oriented and/or medical skin treatments. My wife and I weighed the two and felt this made the wisest choice.The key, we found, was the neutral qualities offered by deer and rabbit -- but trying to find brands that offered them in a dry food of sufficient quality was next to impossible. We liked the quality of Royal Canin, but a more than six-pounds SMALLER 17.7 lb. bag of RC hypoallergenic potato and rabbit or potato and venison dry food comes at costs approaching $100 at the time of this posting. That comes in at over $5 a POUND (compared to NB's coming at less than HALF that: about $2.17 a pound).NB's food is well-rounded and consistent and has a great list of high quality ingredients.-- you go through the first three ingredients (potatoes, rabbit and potato protein) before one runs into one with a chemical compound (and that's just the preservative in the canola oil), and then it's beet pulp, natural flavor, flax seed, salt, salmon oil and various vitamins and minerals.My wife and I liked that NB created a mix that's "rich in protein and low in fat," as well as concentrating on foods that emphasize carbs, potassium and other highly digestible energy sources. And just as much, our dogs LOVE the taste. Not that Corgis refuse much food (I seriously wonder if they couldn't digest a car tire), but it is a consistent winner at our house and most importantly, WITHOUT any skin issues.

A General Theory of Oblivion is a unique little book, constructed as a series of vignettes that circle around a central story of a woman nicknamed Ludo who walled herself into one apartment of a building in Luanda, Angola, and lived isolated and alone for many years.  That central core of the novel is based on a true story, but the web of secondary characters is equally fascinating.  There are people from each side of the country's revolutionary divide; in fact, the set of characters got a bit confusing (who is doing or has done what to whom?), and their paths occasionally intersected in ways I found unreasonably coincidental.  Still, I admired the author's vision and writing skill (his words translated from Portuguese), and the book surprised and intrigued me with its unusual tale.

I like the guitar solo on "Hombre Sin Nombre" (excellent!!), and a couple of the other songs are OK, but the use of autotune is a major negative for me.  Leave that to the Spears and Cyri of the world, please!

I have an iPhone 6, and I tested this Belkin Lightning charger & sync cable and compared it to the regular, non-"lightning" cables I already had.  In my totally unscientific tests, the Belkin Lightning cable averages about half a minute  to a minute for each percent in charging.  For example, it would charge 20 percent in about 20 minutes' time or less.  My other cables charge at an average of about 2.5 to 3 minutes per percent.  The Belkin is faster, though I question whether the term "lightning" really applies.  As far as syncing goes, the Belkin seems to sync at about the same speed as the other cables, probably a bit faster.I do have a use for the short (6 in) cable, but if I had this to do over again, I would go for a longer cable.  (But that's my fault, not the cable's.)

This is one of the most delicious milk chocolate bars I have ever tasted, smooth & rich.  This is Swiss chocolate; they and the Belgians are tops in chocolate making, according to my taste buds.  I also shared this with some fellow chocolate lovers, and they strongly endorsed L'corc too.

David Mitchell's new novel Slade House is bit different than his others, but then nearly everything he has written has been "different" in some way or other.  This one is indirectly connected to The Bone Clocks, his much longer book from a year ago, but Slade House works just fine as a stand-alone piece.  It's also the closest Mitchell has come to writing in the horror genre, or it could fit into the similar category of "dark fantasy."  The novel is an intriguing tale of various individuals who find their way to an old English house that's tucked away down a dark alley and can only be accessed at certain times and by certain people.  There may be an Evil Presence at Slade House that they will have to contend with.  The book is divided into five sections, happening in 1979, '88, '97,  '06, and the present day.  Each year's tale is told from the POV of a different visitor to Slade House.  Their fates are interconnected, but as I'm trying to avoid spoilers, I'll say no more about that.I was thoroughly engrossed in Slade House's gradually unfolding mystery, rooting against the bad guys and hoping somehow good would triumph in the end.  The story is well told, with a bounty of fascinating, spooky, and imaginative ideas related to the central plot concepts and themes.  I recommend it!

Super Genius Addition is a fun card game that helps to teach addition, ideally to 1st & 2nd graders, but it can be played just to pass the time.  (Improving addition skills can sneak in while we're having fun.)  It has four different games-within-the-game, mostly involving the quickest recognition of matches between two cards, correctly identifying which sum matches which addition of two numbers.  The cards are designed so there's ALWAYS a match between two cards, it's just a matter of finding it.

(CD review) Despite the foray into "rock" her band Helen represents, listeners familiar with Liz Harris' work as Grouper shouldn't be too surprised by this new music.  True, the Helen sound does have more of a basis in guitar-bass-drums, usually electric guitar, and is more "song" oriented, but the tracks on the Helen album share one major element with Grouper: a love of blurred, insubstantial, and impressionistic musical effects. In particular, Ms Harris' vocals on Helen are often even less decipherable than on the Grouper recordings.  Here we also have fuzzy guitars, somewhat shoegaze-ish, and the tunes generally have a melodic structure along the lines of garage rock.  But that's all buried within a sea of gauze.  The music could have been recorded with several layers of cotton covering the mics, or sometimes it's like it was recorded by mics placed down the hall from where the musicians were playing. I'm OK with all the abstraction (as I was with it in Grouper), but it is more of an interesting curiosity than anything I'll want to return to.  Then there's a minor frustration I have with the packaging, which contains only scribbled, mostly illegible handwriting.  If you want to learn who else plays in the band or the song names, you'll have to go online, a likely intentional irony in our transition from physical product to purely digital media.

I am not any kind of medical or pharmaceutical expert.  I have taken CoQ10 for a number of years because of its reported cardiovascular benefits.  This Viva Labs version of CoQ10 boasts "Superior Bioavailability" through "added BioPerine."  I don't know what any of that means or if it's valid.  All I can tell you is that while I've been taking this Viva Labs CoQ, my heart health has remained strong, and that I have not noticed any negative side effects as a result of taking the supplement.

The ever-cool Laurel Halo lays down a series of enervating and inventive electronic instrumental trax on the *In Situ* EP.  Often they are quite rhythmic, as on the steadily pounding "Drift."  There are also a couple of pieces that sound more like sound experiments (ex., the short, popcorn-y "Nimrud"), a pensive semi-drone ("Leaves"), and various other atmospheres and grooves along the way.

Reading "In Camera," the brilliant novella that opens William Gass' new story collection, I had such high hopes for the book.  The next novella, "Charity," promptly smashed those hopes to bits.  "In Camera" starts *Eyes* out in stimulating fashion, portraying an eccentric proprietor of an obscure photograph shop and his Quasimodo-esque assistant/ward.  The tale is filled with intriguing ideas, marvelous descriptions, and apt details.  On the other hand, "Charity" drew the same reaction from me that trying to read *Ulysses* did: perplexity, frustration, anger, and (finally) rejection.  The Gass novella is one continuous without a paragraph break--for dozens of pages.  It abruptly, jarringly shifts time and perspective during the narrative.The remaining stories include ones written from the POVs of a folding chair and a piano, respectively, neither of which was too awful, plus one clear winner ("The Man Who Spoke With His Hands"), leading to a concluding work, "The Toy Chest" that explores odd spellings, punctuations, and formatting.Lately it's seemed like every other story collection I've picked up is from an "experimental" author of fiction.  I've loved some (George Saunders) and disliked others (Charles Yu).  *Eyes* is somewhere in between, but at its worst, it is relatively horrible.

I'm just amazed that nobody has written a customer review of the new Low yet!  (At least as of this writing, they haven't.)  As a set, the songs on *Ones and Sixes* might not be quite as awesome as those on, say, *Things We Lost in the Fire*, but *1s & 6s* is a highly listenable album from top to bottom.  The preview tracks, "No Comprende" and "Lies" are each outstanding, and "Congregation" is also a powerful, unforgettable Low song.

The 2016 version of the SAT is a major change from previous versions, including the overall scoring system and the appearance of no-calculator math questions.  The new Kaplan guide will be one of the better ways to prep for the new test, containing a complete practice test plus access to two more online.  It follows the successful approach of explaining not just the correct answers, but also why the wrong answers are incorrect. However, many test question explanations don't cover the wrong answers too -- not quite up to The Princeton Review's gold standard.  (The PR guide also has more practice tests.)  Still, I'm a tutor who will happily use these practice tests when working with my SAT-preppy students.  Also, the test-taking strategies presented in this 2016 Kaplan guide are sound.

(3 & 1/2 stars)The Girl With The Deep Blue Eyes begins with a familiar noir plot -- hard-bitten former cop now working as a PI is assigned to check on a beautiful spouse of an abusive rich man -- and then things take a predictable course between the PI, Doak, and the wife, Lisa.  It doesn't take too long before the story starts to get twisty & kinky.  Eventually there are several surprises, not least of which was the ending, which was not what I expected at ALL.  The novel falls a bit short on character development -- I never got much of a picture in my mind of Lisa, for instance -- but, the plot was interesting enough to keep my reading, albeit at a pace less than "page-turner" speed.  Oh, and about the kinky side...Lawrence Block's regular readers will not be shocked to hear that Girl w/ Blue Eyes gets pretty explicit.  By now, most noir & pulp fans should know what they're getting into (no pun intended) when they pick up a L. Block book

Reading Mal Peet's fantasy parody novel *The Mudstone Trilogy* reminded me at times of reading National Lampoon's legendary Tolkien parody called *Bored of the Rings*.  That book came out in 1969, and it was grade-A humor, but it also did not hold together as a story on its own.  Its sole value was as a parody, but of course that was the point of the book.  With the late Mr. Peet's Murdstone Trilogy, he was apparently trying to make it work in both areas, but he didn't really succeed in either.I like various conceits on the parody side, especially when the agent, Minerva, lays out the "formula" for plotting out a fantasy trilogy.  The generic elements she describes are pretty apt, and funny!  On the "story" side, the writer Murdstone is a pretty unsympathetic lead character, and his actions often don't fit any sensible pattern of behavior.  Some secondary characters, such as the two librarian sisters, are amusingly drawn, but others, like the villain Morl, are just flat sketches.  This novel also has a title problem, as it has the word "Trilogy" in its title, something that could confuse potential readers looking for three books.  (The title is fully explained within the novel, but I'm not sure many will make that far.)

Matt Bell's new novel *Scapper* is an extraordinary book, but it's also relatively baffling as a coherent story.  The main character, Kelly, is a man who "scraps" for a living in the ruins of Detroit.  His life is changed when he finds and rescues a kidnapped boy while he's tearing through an abandoned house in "the zone."  However, Kelly doesn't change in the ways a predictable story-telling arc would dictate.  He remains a troubled man with a traumatic episode in his past, something involving a woman and her boy (a different boy than the rescued one).There are MANY unconventional elements to *Scrapper*, primarily the vague and not always comprehensible events that take place in the plot.  There are switches in perspective that left me behind for awhile until I caught up.  There are two SIDE tales, "Guantanamo" and "Pripyat," which appear to have little or no relevance to the rest of the novel.  Then there's the author's writing style, which includes delivering a load of sentences with poetic or literary impact (perhaps), but which often make no real sense.  A blurb quote for this book says, "Matt Bell does not write sentences--he writes spells."  In my case, at least, I'm sure I would have gotten more out of *Scrapper* and enjoyed it more had Mr. Bell stuck to sentences and avoided the spells.  And for the plot, despite several other compelling points, how about providing something as basic as WHAT exactly happened to Kelly in his deep dark past?  That wouldn't have required too much, just a flashback that filled in the details.  However, I guess the author chose not to do that because it would have been too straightforward and not consistent with the blurry, dreamlike quality he was going for.

On *A Twist of Rit*, Lee Ritenour revisits past material in all-new versions of songs from throughout his career (and I mean from the beginning!), playing them with an impressive all-star lineup of backing jazz cats: Ernie Watts, Dave Grusin, Bob Sheppard, Dave Weckl, and many more!  The results are sometimes awesome ("Fatback"), elsewhere a bit annoying (the new take on "Countdown"), but Mr. Ritenour's guitar work is ALWAYS magical on these remakes.  In the end, that makes listening to this new "twist" on old songs a very rewarding and enjoyable jazz trip down memory lane.

These comfortable & durable kitchen towels are cotton, made in India (unavoidable, I guess?), and feature handy corner bands for easier hanging up.  Their cotton fiber manufacture requires occasional ironing, but that's true of all such cotton napkins or whatever.  (That's how I'm using them - as napkins.  Their 20" x 30" size is a little too small for drying dishes.)

This collection serves as my reacquaintance with science fiction Grand Master Clifford Simak, whose novel Way Station was a favorite from my youth.  In the Intro, series editor David Wixon explains that a total of fourteen volumes of Simak fiction are planned after this first one, which is both thrilling and a bit intimidating.  I'll have to read them all.  What strikes me most about this volume is how timeless this master's writing is!  There are some chronologically dated references that are unavoidable (ex., a million dollars doesn't sound as impressive in 2015 as it did 50 years ago), but so many other elements of the author's writing and ideas are just as fascinating and engrossing now as they were when they were published.  The previously unavailable story in this volume is a quality piece of fiction, only seeing the light of day now as the book it was originally written for (the legendary Dangerous Visions 3) remains unpublished.  Now please excuse me as I go reread Way Station.

The key element I'm judging with a dog toy is whether it is DURABLE.  Of course it should be fun too.  I've nicknamed one of my two pooches "The Toy Destroyer" (the Lab).  With her, I MUST adhere to the recommendation that comes with every dog toy now: (in this case--) "Supervision is recommended when your pet plays with toys."  I take it away after supervised play.Well, she has chomped down on this Nerf football quite a bit, and it has held up nicely.  The outer shell is made of a hard-yet-flexible material that has proven its toughness.  The squeaker inside makes a lot of FUN noise, so don't let your dog have this when you're looking for some peace and quiet.  The size of the football, seven inches, makes it suitable only for medium to large dogs.

The last several Booker winners or short-listed books I've read have been simply awful.  I suppose it's a matter of taste, but I'm not faulting mine too much, since I HAVE enjoyed winners of Pulitzers, Nobels, National Book Awards, etc.  Anyhow, both of the novels by John Banville in this handsome Everyman's edition were just ultra-tedious to read.The Book of Evidence is all evidence and no book, taking the form of a murderer's confession in court, but it really happens in the narrator's mind.  The story is confusing and frustrating, as the details of the crime are long withheld from the reader, and the incidents described in the "confession" are randomly strung together.  (Yes, I know we're in the mind of madman, but it was all too disjointed for me.)As for the 2nd book, The Sea, I like what one reader on a book site said: "While I can appreciate the aesthetic and literary qualities of The Sea, the bottom line is that it bored me."  Yes.
Here's a melodic alt-folk number with a nice lead vocal by Andrew Davie.  He sounds a bit like Gary Lightbody of Snow Patrol.

This song has a shoegaze sort of vibe, with fuzzy-noisy electric guitars and a sinewy dual-octave vocal. (There is an upper voice singing the melody, and a lower one an octave below.)  It's OK, but nothing to get too excited about.

My 6-year-old Lab and 9-year-old Shepherd mix love these duck treats.  I am reporting back after gradually giving them a whole bag a couple at a time over several days, and I can say that they've had no ill health effects.  In fact, their annual checkup at the vet's fell during that time, and the doc said both doggies are in very good shape.  I was a little concerned that the bag only says these treats are PACKED in the US, but does not tell where they are made.  I contacted the company and asked the question.  The answer was they are MADE in the US, but I do wonder why that's not on the package.

In my customer rating for this book, I had to give Dianne Cook extra credit for creativity.  In this collection of stories, we find ideas that are so "out there" as to be bizarre or even ridiculous, but she takes her imaginative scenarios and carries them out to whatever extremes she envisions.  They all fit, in one way or another, into the title theme of "Man V. Nature," and often Nature drives Man to take actions universally condemned by civilized society.  In other words, frequently various forms of extreme and/or ordinarily abhorrent behavior are described in these short stories, something which will likely offend some readers--but it makes for a book that is NEVER boring!

(3 & 1/2 stars)The individual pouches (or tubes) of this instant coffee can be mixed with hot water to make a nice cup-a-joe. Apparently the product name comes from its design as a business product, a way for companies (or "partners") who buy this "blend" to make it easy for their customers to make themselves a quick hot beverage.  For an instant coffee, Partners Blend is fairly rich and high quality in the area of flavor.  However, it has a relatively significant flaw--the packets are very hard to open manually, requiring scissors or another sharp utensil to cut them open.  That's not a good thing when you're trying to make things more convenient for customers.

My main problem with this book is that the plot is too slow to unfold.  With its gradually revealed mysteries, the story is reminiscent of the TV series Lost and The Prisoner, but only in bad ways.  I have one other major issue with More Than This, however, and that is that it's inappropriately described as a book for Young Adults, even marketed for schools.  The book contains sexual scenes, a fair amount of four-letter words, and other elements that make it clearly unsuitable for a school reading program.  I'm not against those things in books for adults--I often read them myself without any concern.  However, if children are going to read this kind of stuff, it should be with full knowledge of the book's contents, and with the permission of a parent or guardian.

This rug is well named--I am happy just walking on it in my bare feet!  The shag weave is very soft...it's what I imagine walking on a cloud might feel like (without the part about immediately falling to the Earth).  Upon reading the care and cleaning instructions, I did note that professional cleaning is recommended for the rug, so hopefully it won't need cleaning any time soon.

Never having slept on a memory foam pillow, I was interested to try this Valuepedic Memory Foam Pillow.  I gave it ten nights of sleep, and found it no more comfy than my regular, non-memory-foam pillow.  The design put my head at a somewhat awkward angle above the bed, which may be why I awoke on the last couple of mornings with a mild neck ache.

Author Thomas Pierce falls loosely into the "zany short story writer" category, in that many of his stories revolve around bizarre concepts such as a TV show that creates living clones of ancient extinct animals ("Shirley Temple Three") and a woman who lives out an entire, detailed parallel life in the world of a continuing dream ("The Real Alan Gass").  The unique element of Pierce's stories is that he takes these alternate realities and makes everything else about them seem relatively ordinary, including the characters (people with problems), settings, and plot points.  While I generally appreciated the writing, it was a bit difficult for me to settle on a final star-rating for Hall of Small Mammals.  I wanted to give Pierce extra credit for his creativity and skill, but was less than satisfied by the story endings, many of which were annoyingly enigmatic or arbitrary.  (Yes, I know, authors should be allowed to do that, plus the short story form often makes "neatly wrapped up" endings impractical, but I would still have liked better constructed endings than most of these stories had.) So, four stars.

I had the pleasure of reading some superior story collections in 2013, including those by Karen Russell and George Saunders, but nothing has struck me so far this year--until now.  Justin Taylor's fourteen stories in Flings are sometimes shocking, frustrating, and/or explicit, but they are always engrossing.  Taylor handles a couple's breakup in a most unusual manner in "After Ellen," one of my favorite Flings.  Another is "Poets," with its two unique title characters who are unlike anyone I know but simultaneously fascinate and repel me.  Each of the stories in this book is compelling, though.  You can't go wrong with any of them.

Full Measure, T. Jefferson Parker's new novel, takes the reader in unexpected directions as it develops.  The main characters are brothers Patrick and Ted Norris, each struggling with major personal issues.  Patrick is a returning war veteran haunted by ghosts of fallen comrades; Ted is physically limited and has a personality conflict with his demanding farming father.  A blurb quote for this book (from Stephen Harrigan) compares this writing to John Steinbeck's, and the comparison is apt.  Besides having the West Coast setting in common, Parker portrays events similar to Steinbeck's interpersonal dramas of hard-luck people scratching and clawing to get by. But the plot is more than character studies -- the Norris family is in tough straits, and we're not sure how (or if) they will make it through.

Ransom Island, the third Miles Arceneaux story, is again set in the Texas Gulf Coast area, although this book takes place in the 1950s.  It's fun to connect these '50s characters, including a different set of Sweetwater brothers, to characters in the chronologically-later first and second books.  The plot involves a mob bid to take over Shady's, the brothers' relatively isolated and "local" entertainment operation (food, fishing, music, and libations), plus there are preparations being made for a major musical figure's planned concert at the club.  I enjoyed the good-guys-vs-bad element of this tale, which also includes a not-always-serious yet period-appropriate look at the racial tensions of the time.  In fact, the handling of that touchy subject (race) is a good illustration of the Arceneaux approach to historical accuracy -- a good ear for how things were discussed and handled at the time, but with a vein of humor always nearby, ready to be mined.  The novel moves along briskly, is frequently grin-inducing (I'm not an LOL'er), and the CCQ (colorful character quotient) is the highest yet for a Miles book.  If you dug the first two books, you will love this one.

I like the idea that the cane plants from which these reeds are made were watched over by company reps from growth through harvest and production.  These reeds produce a rich, warm sound, but it's a matter of individual preference whether this particular reed is the right one for the individual clarinetist.  All I can say is that they're a quality product.

This colorful apron is made of high quality cotton fabric that washes very well. I can never remember the meaning of the European washing symbols, so I just washed it in warm water and dried it on the usual medium heat setting. It turns out I should have dried it on a low setting, but I didnt notice any shrinkage.The adjustable neck strap and long waist ties allow it to fit just about anyone.  It can be worn by guys as well as gals.  (My girlfriend and I have each worn the apron quite comfortably -- and stylishly, I might add.)Theres a nice big pocket on the front, but Im never sure what you should put in an apron pocket.

Barbara Cofer Stoefen is the mother of an addict who felt that her story could be helpful to others who were facing a similar situation.  Her teenaged daughter Annie became addicted to crystal meth at the end of high school and as Annie became a legal adult, the situation changed dramatically as far as treatment options and the law were concerned.  I read this story with interest--while I have no firsthand experience with a family member going through addiction (thankfully), I have followed the subject of meth addiction.Ms Cofer Stoefen relates events in a very realistic way, laying bare all of the confusion, anger, frustration, anxiety, and other emotions she went through during this time in her and Annie's lives.  While there are recommendations and resources offered at the end of the book, A Very Fine House is not written as an advice book.  It is just a mom talking about what happened to her family, figuring things out as she went along.  It is also a book about faith in God, and the heart of the book details the author's initial struggle with "how could God let this happen to us?" followed by her attempts to find a solution that would draw on her spiritual support and love for her daughter.I typically avoid "religious books," but I found this to be a refreshingly honest and non-preachy account, pretty well-written and engrossing throughout.

After giving these Duck Stix to my 8-year-old German Shepherd mix, I can report that he loves them, there appear to be no negative side effects, and that he appears to move about more easily and comfortably.  He only has very early signs of arthritis, such as slight wincing when I pet his hip areas, but I'm still glad to give him some relief.  My other dog, a 6-year-old Yellow Lab, seems to love these treats too, and I don't think it does any harm to give them to her every now & then.

American author Katie Crouch's novel called Abroad chronicles the descent of a young British woman into a decadent and dangerous lifestyle while participating in an exclusive foreign-student college program in a small Italian city.  She falls in with "the wrong crowd," a trio of high-living classmates, and her fate is essentially sealed in that moment.  While the story has a gripping and irresistible forward momentum, I found the characters' behavior consistently annoying throughout the book.  This gets into the classic debate about whether a novelist has still written a good story if the characters are all unsympathetic or even repulsive to the reader.  Certainly that is possible, except in this case I had another problem with Abroad, that the plot kind of stagnated for me -- too much meaningless partying and "living it up," to the point of repetitiveness.  Only a couple of scenes stood out, when the four "friends" manage to intrude on an exclusive "secret society" party they were not invited to, as well as their "weekend at the castello."  The former passage was vaguely reminiscent of a pivotal scene from the film Eyes Wide Shut.  Not enough of that kind of stuff, though, plus I thought the ending was too unoriginal.

Mysterious author John Twelve Hawks, creator of the Traveler series, has constructed a very clever new antihero in his new thriller Spark.  After recovering from a traumatic brain energy, Jacob Underwood lost all capacity for emotion, a Transformation that makes him a perfect assassin, a trade he has become quite successful at.  His "Spark" -- his inner being (or soul?) -- is disconnected from his body, or "Shell."  This story is about what happens when unexpected events begin to shift the assassin's perceptions of himself and the world he lives in.  Could his profession, or even his very existence, be at stake?  Mr. Twelve Hawks builds a riveting page-turner around this situation and his assassin character.

I will give this Grip credit for protecting the back of my iPhone 5 and its top & side buttons.  I also really appreciated the design (appearance) of the Grip and how well it works (button function).  However, ultimately I decided that more complete protection of the phone was of greater importance to me, and I went back to my 360 protective cover.  (This Belkin Grip does NOT cover the jacks or the front screen.)

(4 stars for the studio collection, 1 star for the live disc)The ENCYCLOPEDIA OF ARTO set has one excellent CD, a cross section of material from across Arto Lindsay's career.  The song selection is satisfying, with a mix of English and Portuguese (Brazilian) tunes, and the sound quality is splendid.  It's not exactly "Arto Lindsay's Greatest Hits," but it serves as a fine overview of what the man is all about, at least in the studio.To let us hear what Lindsay is like in concert, we get a set performed in May 2012 at Pete's Candy Store in Brooklyn, seemingly in front of about 20 people (judging from the applause).  My reaction to hearing this raw, awful noise was "Note to self: do NOT go see Arto Lindsay perform live."  Instead of playing his electric guitar as a musical instrument, he instead uses it to reproduce all kinds of "speaker malfunction" sounds -- shrieks, distortions, pulsations, squawks, etc.  In between, around, and over those cringe-inducing aural assaults, Mr. Lindsay "sings" lyrics, although often he is just mumbling or "yipping."  Several of the live songs are ones that are on the studio CD in this album; there can be no greater contrast musically than comparing the studio and live versions of those songs.

The title of Ken Silverstein's new nonfiction book is The Secret World of Oil, but the chapters vary in how well they address aspects of the oil industry that are "secret."  One area where he mostly succeeds is in his stories of the "fixers," important but little-known figures who serve as go-betweens for petroleum exploration companies interested in making deals with oil-producing countries (and the dictators who run them).
