It is ultra-compact, taking up almost no room...it is just like a little brass "end cap" on the tip of the hose.You can adjust the intensity of the spray from a wide mist to a narrow blast, simply by twisting the endclockwise or counter-clockwise.Also, this is a solid brass, thick, dense, heavy little thing for its size... excellent build quality...it feels like it will last for many years.  There are real steel ball-bearings on the twisting tip.This is not plastic junk... this is all metal.I am very impressed with its design, function, form, and overall appearance.

Most lamp dimmers have a lightweight cheap feel, and a dial-wheel dimmer that also feels flimsy and cheap.Not this one.  This Lutron dimmer has a heavy feel, and a smooth sliding linear dimmer switch that feels like quality workmanship.I have more than one of these in my home, and I definitely recommend these as the very best manual dimmer devices on the market.

These little hoses are not cheap... but this is an excellent example of "you get what you pay for", as they say.I went through a number of those "expanding" mini-hoses that shrink-up when not in use, and expand when in-use (as often seen on late-night TV commercials).  I tried more than one brand of that variety.  They all break within a few months... they start to leak.  That design... though seemingly cool... is far from being perfected, so I gave up on it.I decided to try this Water Right brand hose, and it is obviously of much higher quality.  This is a high-end small garden hose.  I've only used it for a few weeks, but it is of particularly impressive build quality, and it is much lighter and smaller than a full-size heavy garden hose.  I am impressed.

I installed TWO (2) of these in my very small (4 feet x 12 feet) personal storage unit, which islocated adjacent to my assigned parking space in my condominium building's garage.It is a bare concrete floor, with bare concrete block walls.  I store extra floor tilesand extra wood flooring and a ladder and some window screens in this unit.... no foodor perishable items are stored there.This tiny room is only about one-quarter filled with storage items, so there is plenty ofempty space, and these two units are able to operate 24-hours, unblocked and unhinderedby any obstructions.Upon installing them, I noticed about 5 spiders of the "Daddy Long-Legs" variety in the unit.I left them to operate round-the-clock for over 2 weeks.Upon re-checking the storage unit, both of the 2 ultrasonic pest repellers were found to bestill functioning, with their blinking red lights (no noticeable noise being emitted from them).I also counted 5 spiders of the "Daddy Long Legs" variety still in that tiny storage unit.Most of the spiders were in webs on the center of the wall, directly in front of the twoultrasonic pest repellers... just 4 feet from them!So this product had done absolutely nothing.  Zero effect.  No reduction in the spider population.If two (2) of them, operating in a tiny, storage closet area have no effect... then I feel confident insaying that this item appears to be totally ineffective in its ability to repel spiders.

Normally, I prefer a ballpoint pen that lays down a nice thick line of a full 1.0 mm, or even 1.4 mm,for a bold and clear appearance.There are, however, instances in which I need to write with a very fine, very precise, very thin line of ink.For example:  when I am making appointment notes on my personal calendar, I need to be able to write asignificant amount of text in a small area.  For such applications... this pen is the ideal writing instrument.The ink dries instantly... no smudging / smearing, and the ink does not bleed out of the tip causing blotches.It lays down a micro-fine 0.3 mm line that is crisp, clean, and does not skip or blank-out when writing.You cannot buy 0.3 mm pens at your local office supply store... I have checked.  These are special-order pens,imported from Japan, and they have some Japanese writing on their barrel as well, indicating that they areapparently marketed primarily in Japan... and few are imported to the USA for sale.Yes... they are costly, but this is a surgically-precise, high-quality, ultra-fine writing instrument that isideally suited for applications where a maximum amount of text needs to fit clearly and neatly into aminimum amount of space.I understand why these pens have caps, and are not retractable.  It is because the cap makes anairtight-seal to keep the ink from drying-out... while retractable pens, though convenient, cannot do this.My only criticism of this pen's design would be that the cap does not have a clip on it, as nearly allink pens do.  Instead it strangely has what appears to be a tiny lanyard hole, for hanging thepen around your neck with a string.  I don't know who would do such a thing. Maybe that is aJapanese cultural thing.As a side note... I ordered one of these pens, and I was so pleased, that a couple weeks later, I ordered one more.To my surprise, they (accidentally?) sent me a whole box of ten (10) of these pens, for my intended order ofjust one more pen.

This little thing is the best computer camera lens cover on the market.It is a tiny, tiny piece of black plastic... but precision-made to slide flawlessly.Your computer can be hacked and people can watch you through your built-in computer web-camera without you knowing, and without the camera function even appearing to be "on".  They can also listen to you through your computer's speakers.There is not much you can do about audio eavesdropping from determined hackers... but this device absolutely insures video privacy on your desktop or laptop computer.

This is more of a "Statement of The Obvious"... than it is a "Review".1.) If you own this very high quality razor, and the time has come to replace the blades and foil... you must do it... there is no choice.2.) This is a very high-quality replacement blade and foil set ... and it restores razor functionality to like-new conditions.3.) This item is OUTRAGEOUSLY over-priced to a point of offensive absurdity.  It should cost... at the most ... one-third of its price.But... "what you you gonna do?" ... right?  They know they've got you.  You have to buy this every year or two.  Oh well.I gave it 4 stars, because the quality is 5 stars... but the price-value is 1 star.

We just love these Bodum glasses.  We have a few different sizes in our kitchen cabinet.  The double-wall insulated construction helps to keep hot beverages hot and sold beverages cold a bit longer than typical glasses.  Also, this design helps to prevent "sweating" due to condensation, which can leaves rings on surfaces if you do not use a coaster.  These glasses basically eliminate the need for a coaster.  Excellent design, beautiful look... the perfect beverage glasses.

Typical fabric "oven mits" have some serious limitations: - They burn and discolor easily - They are hard to wash - They offer no protection against boiling water - They limit dexterity because all fingers are pushed into one single segmentIn contrast, these no-frabric, all-silicone, grippy, five-finger oven gloves have many advantages: - They do not burn easily - They are super easy to wash - They protect your hands from a dip into boiling water - They offer superior dexterity and control, because you can use all fingers independently to grip thingsAdditionally, I like these because they are not as "over-sized" as many similar products.My wife has very small hands, and these gloves are not too big for her.I have average-size hands, and these gloves are just slightly snug, but not too tight.Unless you have very large hands (in which case these gloves would not fit you)... this is a good"compromise size" that is small enough for most women's hands, and snug but still large enough for most men's hands.The only reason I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 stars, is because these gloves will not protect yourhands from dipping-and-holding your hand in boiling water for several seconds continuously...it will get uncomfortably hot if you try to use these gloves to reach down into boiling waterfor several seconds to move things around within the boiling pot.  These gloves should only be usedfor a very brief in-and-out adjustment of something in boiling water... no more than 2 seconds...and you will be fine.  (That's a lot better than fabric oven mits, which cannot be submerged intoboiling water at all).This product's limitations are few, and its advantages are numerous.  I recommend it as an excellentchoice for general kitchen use.

This is a beautiful collection of 12 colorful stamps featuring each of the 12 Apostles.It was issued by the Marshall Islands in 2011 to commemorate the 400th Anniversary of the 1611 King James Bible.I got one sheet for myself, and one sheet for my business partner... this is certainly suitable for framing.Our company also publishes the only full-size replica of the 1611 King James Bible, in a 400th Anniversary Edition,and this can be seen on our website at GREATSITE.COMI've never been a stamp collector... but when I saw this stunning special edition sheet... so colorful and artistically detailed,I had to purchase a couple of them.

It is very difficult for me to find a cologne that I like.  Most men's colognes are eithervery musky (they smell like a dead animal's hide ... which is what musk is derived from),or they have a very sharp note reminiscent of a laboratory /chemical smell.This one is different.  It is sweeter... but not so much that it would be confused witha lady's perfume.  It is pleasant, not pungent.I used to only wear "Quasar" by Jesus del Pozo... and that is a fine cologne withsimilar characteristics, which you may also wish to try.  However, when I discoveredthis Victorinox scent, "Swiss Unlimited"... I new I had found my new cologne.To paraphrase the Dos Equis "Most Interesting Man in The World", I will say:"I don't always wear cologne, but when I do, I wear Swiss Unlimited"

I purchase from Amazon, this expensive  salt & paper grinder set made by Cole & Mason.They brag that they have been making the finest grinders for over a century in England... and I fell for it.When they arrived, the packaging revealed that Cole & Mason now proudly outsource all theirmanufacturing to China.  Within just a few months, the grinder mechanism detached from the top,and no amount of super-glue could fix it.It's very sad to see a proud and ancient English company like Cole & Mason sell-out to China,and ruin their reputation by producing pretty, but low-grade, Chinese garbage at premium prices.I went back and instead purchased the OXO Lua Salt & Pepper grinder set (about $55),which looks extremely similar to this Cole & Mason set... though it holds twice as muchsalt & pepper in its transparent center column... and the OXO Lua set is of far better quality.

Thanks to the D*A*S*H* and Quinoa Cookbooks, I have taken a renewed interest in cooking.  I am now learning the finer points of baking and enjoying it.  Nothing like fresh sunflower seed bread.  This particular pin rolls nicely, sort of like the steamroller of the kitchen.  I like the blended wood tones and the fact that this is made of recycled wood.  That is a good use of resources.  To make a good thing even better, this is dishwasher safe.  For any level of skill, if you  need a good pin, this one is for you.

In addition to the gym, these are a Godsend.  I love them.  I feel the right amount of tension and resistance on the band I use (you decide by trial and error which band or bands work best for you) and you will find yourself not only toning and firming up, but having fun in doing so!  These are high caliber bands and will serve you well for a good long time to come.  The bands are light and portable and make for easy transport.  I highly recommend this for your home gym

This is a lovely box set containing an Anne Klein watch and two bracelets.  The black clock face adds a touch of chic sophistication to the watch itself.  The band will accommodate most wrist sizes as it has an extender link.  The lens is very durable as it is mineral crystal.  It lends a touch of class to whatever one is wearing.

I've been taking CoQ10 for years and was delighted when this became available to me from Amazon.  CoQ10 is an antioxidant and is believed to protect and strengthen cells.  I take CoQ10 in conjunction with Glucosamine with Chondroitin and find that it is a Godsend for joints.  If you do a lot of exercising and if you have joint issues, then this is for you.Other health properties include being an antioxidant and is also cardio friendly.  A bonus plus is that I feel a surge of energy after taking CoQ10.  The sports doctors recommend it in my area and so does a local group of orthopedists.  A local cardiologist said in an interview that CoQ10 is beneficial to the entire circulatory system.  CoQ10 is a Godsend in pill form.  I highly recommend.

Nivea is a long established and well trusted name in excellent skin care products.  I love this set and gave it as a gift to myself.  The body wash is very gentle on the skin and does not have a strong fragrance.As other U.S. reviewers have noted, this is a hydrating agent that is ideal for dry skin.  I highly recommend this set.  It will make a good gift for anyone, yourself included.

For anybody who needs an anti-inflammatory agent, then you want to take this supplement.  Glucosamine and Chondroitin are well known and recognized anti-inflammatory agents and many users report relief at best and an absence of pain at worst.  I find these are excellent for exercise related pains as well.  Others say that these are a step above pain pills that merely manage pain.  I find these pills to be a Godsend in a bottle.  I do recommend a healthy regimen and exercise in conjunction with taking these pills.  You might also want to add anti-inflammatory foods to your diet as well.  With this bottle you get plenty of bang for your buck as you get 180 pills.

For anybody who needs an anti-inflammatory agent, then you want to take this supplement.  Glucosamine and Chondroitin are well known and recognized anti-inflammatory agents and many users report relief at best and an absence of pain at worst.  I find these are excellent for exercise related pains as well.  Others say that these are a step above pain pills that merely manage pain.  I find these pills to be a Godsend in a bottle.  I do recommend a healthy regimen and exercise in conjunction with taking these pills.  You might also want to add anti-inflammatory foods to your diet as well.

It's good for all ages including your inner child.  I never cared for Gatorade, so this is a pleasant alternative.  It has electrolytes and prevents thirst.  Even so, be sure to drink water throughout the day.  Drink this in conjunction with water and not instead of water.  I highly recommend.

Since I am new to this particular product, I followed the given instructions that came in the package.The colors are a little darker than I would like, but on the plus side the applications are easy.  You can blend the colors well with most skin tones.  While I was initially taken aback at how dark the palette appeared, I was not too sad with the overall result.  It just goes to show you that you can't judge based on color.If you like the raccoon eyed look, then you want to use the eye pencil.  It is thicker than I would like, but I believe with time and practice one can achieve a light, gentle touch and thinner lines.On the other hand, the pink blush was pale to the point of translucency.  It is not easy to see on one's skin.  Even so, more than a little dab'll do you.  With time and patience, this make up palette will be child's play in your hands and your face will be an attractive easel.

Although my dog is no longer a puppy, this is food has been enjoyed by my dog.  It gives serving amount portions so as to help determine what amount is best for the individual dog.  My dog is strong and hardy and full of spirit and energy.  Luckily it does not have a strong smell and the dog enjoys it.

"Friends - how many of us have them.Friends, ones we can depend on."  -- Whodini, 1984This book made a Sarah Dessen convert out of me!  I love the book; the characters; the dialog; the dynamics and the story line.  Sarah Dessen is a genius, plain and simple.Sydney Stanford, 17 has lived in the shadow of her hell-raising older brother Peyton III her entire life.  Once having reached near adulthood, Peyton began making very bad decisions.  He had a career in petty crimes including drugs and theft.  After a stint in rehab in February 2014, Peyton visits friends and has a few too many.  When he heads home, he hits a 15-year-old boy on a bicycle, paralyzing him.This time Peyton has to face the music.  Instead of a slap on the wrist and a finger wagged in his face, he is sentenced to prison.  The story opens in the courtroom with the Stanfords and Peyton's creeper friend Ames.  Sydney, as always feeling invisible takes a bathroom break and there sees a blond girl with a knowing look.Knowing looks turn out to be the start of a series of interconnected events.  Sydney transfers to the local public high school as Peyton's life of petty crimes have had a severe negative impact on the family budget.  She is friendly with two girls, Jenn and Meredith and they maintain their friendship, although they see less of each other due to the transfer.Sydney, newly enrolled at the public high school enters a pizza shop called Seaside.  There she meets the blond girl she saw in court.  The girl, Layla Chatham is her age and also attends the school.  Layla's older sister Rosie, 19 and brother Mac, 18 help their father run the place.  Their mother has MS and Layla's family pull together and are there for each other.Sydney is so impressed by the loving bonds that tie Layla's family together.  The girls become fast friends and Sydney also has an eye for Mac.  Her friendship with this new family deepens and Layla's lovely mother takes Sydney under her wing.  Layla proves herself to be a real friend.  Rosie, like Peyton served a stint in rehab due to drinking and had a real sense of entitlement.  Layla, who "never forgets a face" and Sydney bond over a common concern as well.Sydney and the Chathams spend more time together and Sydney even helps out on pizza deliveries.  Mac teaches her how to read people psychologically based on what they order.  A very bright family, the Chatham children are also very musical.  Mac is in a band; Rosie and Layla sing and play guitar.Sydney's circle widens to include these new friends.  Despite some set backs, things finally fall into place for her.  Sydney even learns to defend herself to her very domineering mother who views life as plans and programs, even to the point of denying Sydney free time after Sydney lets her new friends use the family basement for band practice.I didn't like the way Sydney's mother kept pushing Ames, Peyton's sleazy friend on her.  Ames would offer to stay with Sydney when the Stanfords went to visit their son in jail.  Sydney was plainly afraid of him and tried to avoid him as much as humanly possible.  It is plain that as soon as he walks in through her door and tells her that his girlfriend couldn't come at the last minute that alarm bells and red flags went off in my mind.  DANGER!  Luckily Layla comes through like the Cavalry and stays in the house with Sydney, even blocking the bedroom door to protect them from Ames.  I also love the way Layla proved to be more musically talented than Ames.  When he tried to get the girls alone to show off his musical skills, Layla demonstrated hers and showed him up big time.  Classic!Sydney's mother was remarkably clueless.  For the longest time she just didn't get how dangerous and creepy Ames really was.  When Sydney, hoping to have a punishment commuted told her that "things could go back to the way they are," meaning having extra study sessions instead of free time, her mother says that since Sydney is doing so well that "it isn't that bad."  Clueless!In time, Sydney rightfully regains her privileges and the Chathams teach her just what being a friend really means.  Fortunately, Sydney's mother after being so darn obtuse sees Ames for the creeper he really is, even to the point of danger.Reading this book is like watching a flower blossom.  Readers see the characters develop; unfold; change; evolve and the result is .... beautiful.I can't recommend this book highly enough.  I am already an avid fan of Sarah Dessen and will be reading her other books.  She is an author to watch for and take seriously.Whodini's 1984 rap "Friends" and the Beatles' 1967 classic "I Get By With a Little Help From My Friends" are the sound track of this book.

Lamb and lamb meal are the main ingredients in Solid Gold Sunday Sunrise.  Lamb in any form is a rich source of protein.  This dog food also contains other sources of protein such as eggs, peas and lentils.  Solid Gold Sunday Sunrise Holistic Dry Dog Food also contains potato which is not something every dog can eat.  Fortunately my dog has no known allergies or food sensitivities, so this food was a winner according to my dog.I like the fact that lettuce, thyme and other green foods and spices are included.  My dog tucked into this food and enjoyed it immensely.  Barring any allergies, this is a food I would recommend feeding to your dog.

I love Beatle themed games and this one is no exception.  Your goal is to make Beatle themed words, e.g. song titles.  You can play the game in its "standard" form, but it's a lot more fun if you play it in a Beatle theme.  If you play with others who are not as big as Beatle fans as you, they will learn a lot!  After all, nothing is Beatle proof!

This is an excellent product and I can vouch for it.  Jarrow's is a long established and well trusted name in health supplements and has lived up to its stellar reputation.  This supplement is no exception.For anyone who has suffered from eye fatigue and/or strain from reading or using a computer, this product is ideal.  In a fairly short time the pain and/or fatigue will diminish at worst and be absent at best.  It is also good for anybody with inflammation issues.  If you take this in conjunction with Turmeric, a well-known anti-inflammatory, you will certainly notice results.  Any product that contains Astaxanthin is good for your joints.  So is  fish/Krill Oil.

I love this product.  While I don't like the smell, that is a small price to pay considering what health benefits are contained in each pill.Turmeric is a potent anti-inflammitory that is often used to treat sore muscles and joint pains.  The pills themselves are quite potent and they do work.  If you exercise regularly and feel soreness in your muscles and joints, then you want this supplement.  For many who have joint issues and for many who have had surgery on their knees, this is the product for them.  It is recommended that you take one pill with each meal.Turmeric in any form has been touted as an excellent treatment for arthritis.  In addition, I have learned that turmeric is used for stomach and head pains as well as issues with the liver.  I learned from another U.S. reviewer that you can actually apply these pills to itching caused by rashes and bug bites.Thanks to Amazon, I have learned about Ubervita products.  I, too have found this to be extremely helpful and I highly recommend it.

I am ambivalent about this book.  It is obvious that the characters down to their names and dynamics are updated versions of King Henry VIII (1491 -1547); Arthur Tudor (1486 - 1502); Anne Boleyn (1501 - 1536); Catherine [of] Aragon (1485 - 1536);  Jane Seymour (1508 - 1537) and other well-known key players during the Tudor Period in England.Instead of a royal court in England, we have a wealthy boy's mansion.  His ambitious parents, still reeling over the death of their perfect son Arthur have now anointed and appointed Henry heir apparent to their vast largesse as well as all their hopes and dreams and general aspirations.  The party, replete with masks on a stick hollers Middle Ages at you.  A girl named Catherine [of] Aragon, as in Henry VIII's first wife is all over Henry like a case of hives.And get this - Henry's parents push Catherine on him and want him to date and eventually marry people they approve of.  Henry's brother Arthur, dead throughout this book lingers like a bad smell as he is held up as the Platinum Standard and he was also the one who instituted the Kangaroo Court in their school.  Students can try each other and have a say on expelling anyone they feel has not reflected well on their school or met some academic or social standard.Enter Anne Boleyn, as in Henry's 3rd wife.  Ms Boleyn's literary millenial counterpart rides a motorcycle; breaks school rules at the fancy elitist school they attend and is rather fearless.  Anne's stepfather is an architect who is a well respected man about town.  That having been said, there are other parallels between Anne the Rebel and her Tudor counterpart.There is the usual adolescent angst and thinly veiled references to the real Tudors and members of their court.  The chapters are presented in point of view format, alternating between Henry and Anne with each giving their account of their relationship and life in their post-Tudor, 21st century community.  The writing of these characters impressed me as making a very strong effort to emphasize that they were versions of their real life Tudor counterparts.  King Henry VIII was a dick, sorry and Henry in this story is too.  He is not as crass or as boorish an oaf as the real King Henry VIII from all accounts, but he is still somewhat of a dick at times.And get this!  Henry  has a horse with the hideous name of Bacon.  I had a bit of a giggle when I thought of "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite" by the Beatles.  The 1967 classic has this lyric:  "Henry the Horse dances the waltz!"  I had a giggle envisioning Henry's horse dancing the waltz.  After all, in 1536 the real King Henry VIII was injured in a jousting incident while on horseback and his health and mobility were compromised for the remainder of his life.  I couldn't help but wonder if that was in store for this entitled Henry.I liked Anne.  She was smart and had spirit and appeared to be fearless.  True, she made bad judgment calls, but I felt she deserved far better than what she got.The best part of this book was the use of double entendre and other forms of word play that led readers directly to the Tudor Court during the times of Henry VIII.Yes, the writing was good.  Yes, the story kept my interest.  The reason I'm giving this a 2-star rating was that I so disliked Catherine as she was an inane cliche whereas her real counterpart was, as noted by another U.S. reviewer a genuine bad actor.  I was originally expecting her to be from Spain and readers would get treated to a multicultural array of characters, but was disappointed.  The real Catherine of Aragon was from Spain.  At the very least literary Catherine could have been a brunette.I also didn't care for the heavy handed way readers were banged over the head with the Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn ill fated union.  The real King and Queen ended up on a tragic note.  Anne Boleyn was the mother of Elizabeth I and was beheaded as she was not able to produce a son for the King.There is a kangaroo court in this book and sadly, Anne does lose her head, but in a way that might surprise readers.  Enter Jane Seymour.  Watch out future Anne Cleves, Catherine Howard (who might too be beheaded in a fashion in novels of this ilk) and Catherine Parr, who just might outlive this very entitled Henry.Overall, I thought this was just okay, but there were things that bothered me about this book.

This is an excellent book to help people get their feet wet musically in musical terms.  It is clearly organized and well presented.  I really liked the tidbits, the mini-biographies of composers that is also included in the book.  It's an ideal musical "crib note" or quick Cliff's Notes.  It covers a lot of musical terms and information and is truly a Godsend.  I highly recommend this book.

I love this book.  It is a good go-to resource when encountering an arcane or otherwise unfamiliar musical term.Unfortunately, this book does not have a section with English as the lead language into a non-English counterpart.  It falls short in that if you want to write any of your own musical works in another language (French, German, Italian) you might run into some stumbling blocks.  In other words, there are no English translations.  That cost it one star.That having been said, this is still an excellent book with a lot of useful information.

As soon as I got this book, I could not tear myself away from it.  For years I have wanted to know Rosemary's story and am glad her turn at bat has been given its overdue notice.  I loved the book and found it brilliantly written and very well researched.  Larson, like Rosemary's Shriver relatives has given Rosemary's story a compassionate voice and one that will benefit the world at large.  Rosemary's life had meaning and purpose and it is in this book that readers are reminded of this as well.For decades Rosemary was eclipsed by her siblings and this was all the more glaringly apparent when her brother Jack was elected President in 1960 and Robert, then the Attorney General won the New York State Senate election in 1964 and youngest brother Ted won his senate seat in 1962.  Although her eight siblings are familiar to the public at large, Rosemary has until very recent times been relegated to the background or as Larson said relegated to the periphery of the Kennedy family dynamics.Readers get to "know" Rosemary on  her  own merits as well as within the context of her family.  Her parents' lives are chronicled in the first two chapters and Rose Kennedy's autobiography Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy:  Times to Remember is referenced later in the book.  It is in Larson's book that Rose had a ghostwriter working with her and was very reserved in what she did disclose about Rosemary.  Rosemary's fate in adult life is glaringly absent from her mother's memoir.Each of the Kennedy siblings is fully described and a part of this book.  The issues and political events of the times are included as background so that readers and historians gain a better understanding of the world as the Kennedys experienced during the 20th century.  With that background, she neatly segues into Rosemary's part in the family and Rosemary's life experiences in the ever-changing world in which she lived.Rosemary was born on Friday, September 13, 1918 during the height of the flu epidemic.  Rose, whose obstetrician was not available at the time Rosemary was about to be born held off on delivering her baby per her nurse's instructions.  The nurse pushed the baby back into the birth canal to stave off her impending arrival until the doctor could arrive.  In retrospect, trying to forestall the birth could have deprived Rosemary of much needed oxygen to her brain.  By virtue of the fact that Rose was instructed to clamp her legs together to keep the baby in place and did so for over two hours also raises the question of whether this prenatal to actual delivery time treatment impaired Rosemary's development.Joe Jr., 3 and Jack, 16 months were Rosemary's only older siblings.  One can't help but wonder how the two older boys interacted with their sister who, by their mother's descriptions was slow in reaching her developmental milestones including never mastering the ability to steer a sled or cut her own meat.  Rose and Joe Sr.  had issues in their own interactions which resulted in a short separation after Rosemary was born and prior to Kathleen's ("Kick," 1920-1948) arrival.Readers learn of Rosemary's school and travel trajectory.  She repeated kindergarten, which Rose Kennedy herself included in her autobiography.  By age 11 she was sent to the Devereaux School in Pennsylvania, the first famous alumna to attend.  Decades later Nancy Spungen (1958 - 1978) attended the school from 1970 - 1974, the only other well known student to have attended this branch of Devereaux.Rosemary could read, but never mastered reading above a 3rd grade level.  She wrote painstaking and laborious letters replete with misspellings.  Her childish penmanship remained a sore point with Joe Sr. to the point where, a decade later when he was an Ambassador to England, he would have her letters forwarded to an anonymous government pouch so as to prevent others from seeing her level of literacy.Rosemary's letters were newsy and chatty and certainly not those of someone severely limited.  She complained about the regular injections she received and the "little red pills" she took.  Other authors have identified the injections as hormone blockers to stave off her impending puberty and resultant mood swings.  As for the pills, the jury is still out on that one.  Larson speculated that the pills might have been allergy pills or possibly hormonally related.Throughout the 1930s, Rosemary would attend a total of 5 different boarding schools including a Catholic Convent school in Rhode Island.  At all times her family would try to cover for her, such as her sisters applying her lipstick and makeup for her and helping her get through meals without saying much and revealing her glaring naivete.  During Rosemary's young adulthood when her father was Ambassador to England, her brothers would dance with her, filling her dance card and discreetly encouraging their young friends to fill her dance card so as to encourage Rosemary to feel a part of things.  Rosemary had an abundance of enriching life experiences.  She traveled extensively; she and Rose and Kick were presented in Court before King George VI (Beatle George Harrison was named after him) and Queen Elizabeth.  Despite tripping upon presentation, Rosemary made a fine impression in Court.  Joe Kennedy, to his credit declared that only the wives and daughters of American diplomats could be presented in court.  This was the bird he flipped to those who had discriminated against him as a young man because he was Irish, Catholic and of humble economic origins.Rosemary apparently was happy in England.  By 1940 she was sent back to the United States where Rose led her to believe she would be "a junior counsellor [sic]," as Rosemary herself would say.  The camp was located in an idyllic part of western Massachusetts and run by the Sullivan Sisters.  The camp was for girls aged 7-16.  Rosemary, 22 was past camper age and was eager to go and try her wings.  Rose undoubtedly led her daughter to believe that she really would be a "junior counsellor [sic]" as Rosemary would write to family members.  During her time in England, Rosemary was given an ancillary role in a Montessori classroom run by nuns, one of whom had been trained by Maria Montessori herself and so saw herself in a leadership role.Sadly, Rosemary's time at the camp was short lived.  The Sullivan Sisters were furious with Rose because they didn't feel she leveled with them about the extent of Rosemary's limited social and cognitive skills.  Rosemary was described by others during this period as socially and emotionally on a par with 8-year-olds.  Rosemary's hygiene was another serious matter - instead of disposing her used monthly napkins discreetly, she stashed them in her footlocker.  The Sullivan Sisters knew Rosemary needed more help and supervision than they could give her.  Rosemary also would sneak out of their cabin at night, a matter of such grave concern that Caroline Sullivan would bar the door with her cot so that Rosemary could not wander outside at night.Rosemary's behavior, according to many sources became more erratic and unpredictable.  Some early sources claim she attacked her maternal grandfather in a fit of pique the summer of 1941.  While Larson does not make this claim, she uses reliable sources to describe Rosemary's understandable frustration at not being able to keep up to speed with her peers and siblings.  The explusion from the camp further hurt Rosemary's self confidence as her departure was expedited with Rosemary leaving behind many personal belongings.  The Sullivan Sisters described Rosemary's behavior as having an "adverse affect" on the younger campers.  They were irate when they received an unsigned check from Rose which they returned and waited several months to receive with a signature.  They also did not feel that Rose had much regard for Rosemary.It was during this time, 1940-1941 when the idea of lobotomizing Rosemary was first explored.  Joe Kennedy had his daughter Kick research the procedure and she returned with a grim pronouncement - lobotomies were generally not being recommended.  One doctor at a prominent hospital point blank refused to allow any psychiatric patients on his watch undergo this psychosurgical procedure due to the unknowns and adverse outcomes.  Many patients died from psychosurgery.His rationale for considering this dangerous option was that Rosemary, who had a tendency to sneak out at night might fall into bad company with men who did not mean her well.  He also felt that her behavior and glaring cognitive challenges reflected poorly on the family and he feared public embarrassment.  Somehow they were able to cover for Rosemary during his ambassadorship.  Once having returned home, it was a different story with Rosemary's rages becoming out of control.  Her sister Eunice bonded with her from the beginning and Eunice was often the one who could quell Rosemary's rages and smooth over uncomfortable scenes.Sadly, Rosemary was lobotomized in November of 1941.  Rose's knowledge of this procedure during this time remains sketchy and called into question.  It is known that Joe was determined to take this step as Rosemary was becoming uncontrollable.  Eunice as well as other authors described Rosemary has having incipient seizures.  At what point the seizures began is still under question.The lobotomy took away the gains Rosemary had made and left her completely dependent.  For seven years following the surgery, Rosemary was ensconced in Craig House, a private psychiatric facility for the rich in New York State.  Upon departure, she was transferred to St. Coletta's in Wisconsin, a place Joe Kennedy researched prior to having her transferred.  He provided for her, making sure she had a swimming pool courtesy of her trust fund,  a car for her caretakers to take her places as well as a private cottage called "Kennedy Cottage."  Rosemary remained at St. Coletta's until her death in 2005.Rosemary, as Larson says in this book made a difference.  She was cared for by kind nuns at St. Coletta's and did make periodic visits home over the years.  Eunice and her family as well as John and Caroline Kennedy would visit her and swim with her.  In 1961 President Kennedy disclosed that he had a sister with cognitive delays and pressed for legislation to make provisions for people with special needs.  Eunice Shriver started a camp for children with special needs at her home.  Her son Mark would later say he thought EVERYBODY had school busses full of kids coming to their homes to play every weekend.  By 1968 Camp Shriver had segued into Special Olympics.  Tim Shriver whose stellar book By Timothy Shriver Fully Alive: Discovering What Matters Most [Hardcover] describes Special Olympics and the Shriver family's spearheading this benevolent organization.  Good on the Shrivers!Eunice herself would say in 2007, just two years before her death that " ...love gave me that confidence and adversity gave me purpose."  The bond between those sisters remained intact; years after the surgery "Eunice" was one of the words Rosemary said.  The nuns who cared for her discovered her verbal ability was mostly intact once she was withdrawn from whichever medications she was taking in the early 1970s.The inclusion of previously unseen photographs and letters written by Rosemary herself made an excellent book even more so and a poignant one as well.  Each photograph made me wonder what Rosemary would have accomplished had she not been subjected to neurosurgery.Comparisons between health care and ethical standards over the decades are presented.  Prior to sending Rosemary to private schools with special 1x1 aides to meet her needs, most families floundered and had no known resources.  A large portion of the book in the latter chapters focuses on how the Kennedy family and Shriver family have spearheaded and brought an awareness of the needs for people with all special needs.  The Shrivers are especially recognized for their benevolent and philanthropic efforts and the changes their efforts have made to improve conditions in the lives of many with special needs and their families.For years I have wanted to learn Rosemary's story and how she saw herself.  This book answers many questions and will be a book I will never, repeat never forget.  Rosemary was fortunate in that she had a wealthy family who could provide for her needs to the point of luxurious accommodation, but at great cost to Rosemary herself.  I have prayed for her over the years and was glad that she was in the care of kind nuns who really loved her and had her interests at heart.Rosemary had a good work ethic as did all of her siblings.  She worked hard to secure the gains she made pre-and post surgery.  She worked to regain her mobility after the surgery.  She worked hard with the nuns hired to teach her.  This book deserves a place of  honor.Rosemary, this is for you.

There is no magic bullet.  Again, the best cure/remedy for weight issues is a healthy regimen combined with exercise.  You and your doctor can discuss what supplements will best  meet your needs.I first heard of Carcinia Cambogia from Dr. Oz in 2012.  I've taken it in times past and been pleased with the outcome.  The supplement does claim to help with cholesterol related issues and keep appetite in check.  It is not for weight loss, per se, but more for weight management by suppressing the appetite.As stated, I've had good experiences with it.

Diane Chanmberlain books are always shinies for me.  Whenever one of her books becomes available, my corvine instincts kick into high gear and I avidly swoop down on the book in question.  I loved this book and although it does, as other U.S. reviewers noted, bear a resemblance to "The Silent Sister," another book about a woman with secrets on the run it is still an excellent book.In this book, we are introduced to Molly and her husband in 2014.  Molly, nearly 39 desperately wants to adopt a baby.  She loves her husband yet keeps a secret from him that could have devastating repercussions.  Molly told her husband that her mother died from breast cancer years before they met.  In an amazing demonstration of faith, he buys her story.  Since they are both attorneys living in the Digital Age, one would think he could do a little arm chair sleuthing or pursue legal angles to checking out her story.  Ironically, Molly practices family law.The pre-adoption investigations are very tension filled and hair raising.  Readers will hang onto every word and scenario, wanting to know how this will all play out.  Molly's story is interspersed with flashbacks to the summer of 1990 when she was then 14.  Readers are introduced to Molly's dad and to the dynamics involved.  1990 was a touchstone year for Molly and Diane Chamberlain made appropriate references to the pop culture of that era and the types of interests a girl Molly's age would have had then.The characters are plausible and sympathetic and again, Diane Chamberlain's books are always worth the wait.

I like this Slumberjack sleeping bag and it arrived just in time for a camping trip.  As others on the U.S. boards noted, you do need a pad under the sleeping bag to stay warm.  It is ideal for summer camping.  The padding is soft and will retain heat.However, as another U.S. reviewer noted, if you are planning to camp in the cold country or during the cold season you will want the 0 degree bag instead.  Always use a pad under this so as to protect yourself from the cold ground.  You might also want to add some extra layers of covers over the bag if you use it during the cold season or in a cold place.The sleeping bag itself is very light and portable and has its own sack.  Campers can use the head with the drawstring like a hoodie for added protection as a good portion of body heat escapes from the head.

This product comes in powder form which makes it easy to take.  It has a really nice fruit flavor that makes this spoonful of medicine go down in the most delightful way.I never liked pills and have trouble swallowing them, so anything that comes in liquid or powder form is a Godsend to me.  This product is quite good at targeting headache and other aches and pains.  While I don't tend to get headaches, I do get sore from exercising and this has given me relief.  I think this is a good product for any ache and pain.

On the plus side, this camera is extremely light and portable.  It also has wi-fi connections that are easy to use.  The only drawback is that you have to use two buttons to record.  You first hit the power button and wait until it emits a tone.  Once you hear that tone, then you hit the record button.  As others have noted, if this had one button to accomplish those functions, that would be even better still.  Even so, this is a good camera and you can count on quality recordings.

Another stellar gem by Dr. Thompson!  This is a book that no parent, educator, physician or family member of somebody with autism should be without.  Dr. Thompson, himself the grandfather of a child with autism has made it his life's practice to educate the public about autism and to describe various intervention methods.  He goes into clear and well written detail about the distinguishing features among treatment options.  Dr. Travis Thompson, Dr. Bernard Rimland and Dr. Tony Attwood are considered saints and leading professionals in the autism community.Let's raise our glasses to Dr. Thompson!

There is no creature as beautiful or as majestic as a peregrine falcon.  This bird is the fastest bird in creation and can fly almost 70 miles per hour.  The bird can also do an aerial swoop at 200 miles per hour and has keen vision that allows it to see for several miles above ground.Falcons live above ground in cliffs and under bridges on the beams.  Urban falcons have been spotted in cities and their aeries have been found on the roofs of tall buildings.  The birds' migratory habits and nest building skills are covered in this book.These aerial hunters only hunt from the sky.  The bird has extremely sharp talons that have the ability to slice and sever small prey.  Its hooked or curved beak mark it as a hawk and it is the speediest raptor.  Readers are treated to pictures of falcons swooping down on their prey (they usually give a falconine screech/scream as they descend upon some hapless smaller animal or bird) and eating their kill.Falcons are a protected species.  DDT and other poisons have sadly depopulated and deprived many areas of this much needed bird.  Fortunately, the falcons are repopluating and are extremely intelligent birds.  They can be trained to help in airports and other places in need of security.  These watchbirds learn very quickly and many falcons have been featured in wildlife shows and demos.  The falcon like most raptors tends to be "monogamous" and mates for life with a single partner.I love the photographs and the rich supply of information this book has.  I can't recommend it highly enough.

There is no creature as magnificent or as beautiful as a peregrine falcon.  The majestic bird has been the model of strength, agility and aerial grace.  Cars and teams have been named for this magnificent bird.The boy in the story thinks that bird is special as well.  As he lets his thoughts meander, he finds himself wondering about being a falcon.  If he was this incredible bird, what sensations would he experience?  How keen his eyes and mind would be and the territory he would cover.  As readers follow the boy on his imaginary aerial trip, they are transported on the wings of a falcon to those faraway places.The illustrations are masterpieces.  Readers of all ages will love this book and will be lifted on the wings of a falcon to literary heights previously unknown.

This is an excellent made for TV movie about the inception of the Beatles from the viewpoint of John Lennon.  In John's life, he's loved them all.  John is the hub on which the movie turns.  Viewers gain insight into the influences that created and molded the then future Chief Beatle.Filming this movie in Liverpool made it all the more authentic.  Liverpool, a gritty seaport in the north of England is the birth place of the Beatles and has long since become synonymous with the fab quartet.  Viewers take a Magical Mystery Tour with John, who was raised by his maternal Aunt Mimi.  John's natural mother,  Julia lived in the area and had sporadic contact with John while John's father ("that Alf Lennon" as the Stanley Sisters called him) was out of the picture for a good portion of John's life.Julia, the youngest of the Stanley Sisters was also musical and it is from Julia as well as John's paternal grandfather, another man named John Lennon who would bequeath musical talent to the Chief Beatle.  Julia taught John banjo when he was a child and John also got his first "mouth organ" (harmonica) as a boy.  He demonstrated musical prowess from a very early age.Fans will see places immortalized in Beatle classics such as Penny Lane and its famous Roundabout; Strawberry Fields; Quarrybank High and the art college where John met his first wife Cynthia.The pre-Fabs get good coverage.  The period of 1960 - 1962 when the Beatles made the scene in Hamburg is included as well as former bandmate Stuart Sutcliffe (1941 - 1962) who would remain in Germany; marry the pre-Fabs' friend Astrid Kircherr and tragically die in Germany in 1962.Pete Best, the poorly matched drummer for the group was sacked in 1962 and this is well addressed in the movie.  One can't help but feel sorry for Pete as he plainly was not a good fit or a good match for the group.  Beatles' manager Brian Epstein is given his place in the sun and the highlight of the movie was February 7, 1964 (Beatles' Day!) when the Beatles came to America!Fans will likely find the actors don't always resemble their true-life counterparts and for some this can be somewhat disconcerting.  That having been said, the cast in this  movie overcame that obstacle by delivering rock solid performances and convincing deliveries.As for the actors playing the roles of the other Beatles, only Daniel McGowan presents Paul McCartney in a convincing way.  He rightfully portrays his Beatle counterpart as brilliant and infused with unstoppable talent.  George, on the other hand was a background figure and he was not convincing in the movie.  Sadly, the actor who played George more or less gave a stilted performance which was disappointing.  He also looked not a darn thing like George.  Ringo is given a fairly plausible presentation in this movie.Even so, remember this is a made for TV movie.  It is really quite good all things considered.

"God bless you.  You've got a lucky face.  The end."  -- John Lennon, 1964This delightful documentary takes readers on an early bird Magical Mystery Tour (oops - that's not until 1967) with the Beatles on their meteoric rise to fame!  No doubt much of the material will be familiar to inveterate, rabid Beatlemaniacs, but even so it will always be a treat to watch.Fans will have a bit of a giggle seeing the Beatles spoof on the Bard in period piece costumes.  John was a riot in drag with that hideous stiff wig and George, in pajamas and a stocking cap "sitting high on top of his wavy haired head" was especially adorable.  (For fans who have read biographies of the Beatles, George's funny cap will remind them of how Louise Harrison said in an interview that when George was a teen he let his long wavy hair grow and he would leave with his school cap sitting high on top of his head and some outfit he had customized to his specific taste.)  Yes, the boys were adorable and lots of fun.  Fans will certainly sing along with the fab 4!

This is an excellent game with a Beatles' theme.If you are an inveterate, life-time, hard-core Beatles' fan, you might find it hard to get people to play this with you as they will understandably think you have an unfair advantage. Hard-core fans will most likely know most if not all of the answers in the Beatle version of Trivial Pursuit. For those who know arcane bits of information such as what was on the flip side of each single and their release dates and what was painted on George Harrison's bungalow and where and when George Harrison wrote his very first song, quote the Beatles' movies in full and the dates the Beatles played in Boston and Denver, then you'll probably think this game is child's play!  Even so, I doubt you'll be disappointed as a) you get to talk about the Beatles and b) you can see non-fans and less enthusiastic fans beam as they acquire Beatle information. You get a Ticket to Ride Beatlemania and you will enjoy the ride! This game rocks!I just love this game and wish I could get others to be willing to play it with me. Fans, regardless of their level of expertise will learn a lot from this game and very hard-core fans will pick up the error in "which book did John pull off the bookcase in "Help!'"? Hint: The answer is a book John wrote, but the answer given in the game is not the correct book John authored.We added a rule while playing this game. Every time a movie trivia question comes up, the person who has to answer the question also has to sing the title song from the movie. If you want to have a fun, laid-back party, invite your Beatle fan (or in my case, Beatle tolerant) friends over, pop in an early Beatles' CD and learn about the Beatles!I give it a hearty yeah, yeah, yeah!

P is for Peeling will take you around half an hour to read, this one revolves around a guy who thinks he's pretty much the greatest yet to be published writer in the world, and expects when he takes his book to a meet the publishers and agents convention that they will be fighting each other to sign him up.  He looks down his nose at horror, romance, self published authors and well everyone else really.  He knows this is the day that will change his life but he's got this really bad cough and is starting to itch in embarrassing places.  Still nothing will stop his destiny.The book is interesting in that Iain Rob Wright has obviously put some of himself or his career experiences into the other writers that are looked down upon by the main character.  A young attractive female has written a book that's plot is Animal Kingdom for example.  P is for Peeling isn't my favourite of all the short stories I've read by Iain Rob Wright, but it is definitely one all fans of the author's work should check out.

Godzilla is a nice entry to the Funko Figures world, he's a bit taller than your standard Funko Pop Vinyl, if you've already got Stay Puft he's the same height as him without the hat.  Like Stay Puft he is not to the same high rise scale bigger as the one in the movie compared to the human Funko Vinyls and he couldn't really step on them. If you keep your Funko Figures in their boxes, the box is the same height as The Marshmallow Man.  The box is great packaging that I really wish other figure manufacturers would learn from. You can open the box, slide out the blister and remove the figure without damaging the box at all. There isn't even any tape or anything to cut. Then you can put the figure back inside if you decide to display it that way. The back of the box has a movie still of Godzilla chomping on a train, as does the side image with the cartoon drawing of the the reptile. You can view the figure from the front and one side of the box through the clear window. The boxes stack well on top of each other too, that's why it's great you can change your mind at how you want to display these Funkos.The only downside to the packaging is that you've got no idea if someone has opened it before you buy. As more and more people are becoming aware of the paint blemish factor, you seem to see more and more people opening these Funkos up in stores. If you're unaware it's a pretty rare occurrence to obtain a blemish free Funko figure, there's always a stray bit of paint somewhere on the figure, often on the back so even if you pick up a box in a store and the figure looks paint free, you won't know. Hence the reason customers are opening them up, or asking the online seller to do so and take photos for them to look at before purchasing. My Godzilla has small bits of white paint on it, it's not that big a deal for Godzilla as I imagine he gets bits of cement on him as he smashes through Tokyo city buildings.You can't pose his arms or move his legs, tail or anything, like the smaller Funkos he's set in the one stance.  What lets this figure down though is that you can't rotate his head at all, even though you can see where the head joins on, there is a back spike stopping his head from moving. If they weren't going to allow head movement, why not have made the whole reptile the same mold so then you wouldn't see the visible lines.  He is a fair bit darker a grey than the prototype image displayed on this page, and his red gums are more prominent.  He kind of looks like he's wearing lipstick.I think the prototype looks better but the final version still looks pretty good. I especially like his white claws on his feet and hands.  He stands no problem at all as he has pretty huge feet.

1992 released movie about a teen who gets pregnant while behind bars in juvie, and who is bullied and tricked to give up her baby.  She is told when he reaches 18, if he wants to he can track her down.  He doesn't so she decides to try and find him only to find out that he died at the age of three.  When she visits his grave with her other kids they run into an old man who criticises the demonization by people at the time of the foster mother who he is a relative of.  She investigates his death and doesn't believe the official reports that he died of non murder causes and hassles the police, talks the media and does whatever it takes to get justice for her son.I saw this one TV and when it started assumed this was a really old movie when Beverly D'Angelo appears on the screen as a teen prisoner.  I thought well this is obviously an earlier than the Vacation movies made film so was surprised when the film moved onto nineteen years or something into the future and D'Angelo is still playing the same now older character.  So for a low budget likely made for TV movie, they did a good job with the makeup, costume department and whatever to make her believable as a teen.  They also did a great job with the casting of the villain, the foster mother Lois Jurgens who is played by Dana Ivey.  I must admit I've never heard of her but she does a brilliant job as the evil woman, they should have cast her in the Carrie movie.  You despise her and that's means she's done a great job.I was also surprised to find out after the movie finished when I looked it up that this movie was based on a true story.  The movie doesn't do one of those sum everything up in a few text blurbs of what happened to the characters afterwards like most based on true crime events do.  If you read about the real Jurgens, you'll see that actually left quite a bit out about her.  Pure evil wouldn't describe her accurately.Obviously the movie deals with child abuse so may be a bit much for some people to watch but it's mostly the psychological that we the viewer see, with the sound of hitting in the background or the child crying.  The child actor does a very good job too.

The Flood might be a title that immediately gives you the impression this might be a take on the Noah story, but there's not really a flood in the book. A lot of the east coast of North and South America was flooded by a huge tidal wave but Tsunami or Ship would have given a more accurate picture title. We don't really ever experience that flooded world anyway. If you feared a preachy book based on the title, rest assured this is not one of those, there is a minor amount of pages religious character who starts a cult and a few characters pray, but you'd expect the latter in any huge disaster tale, just due to the variety of people that make up our society, so omitting that completely wouldn't be that realistic.  Basically Flood is the tale of a group of New Yorkers who are evacuated from probable death with the approaching wave by being herded onto a cruise ship which has been directed to be part of the rescue that heads out to sea to go over the wave while it is a small bump and await directions on where to dock to disburse the refugees before returning on it's cruise with the original passengers.  At first the trip seems great, the captain in generous with the passengers', food and the cruise ship seems like a comfortable way to bypass the danger compared to the hulls of the freighters and other ships the other fleeing New Yorkers were herded onto.  However the ship is seen as a target by opportunists who have been wishing an event like this would occur.  The aftermath of their actions will test  the selfishness verse community survival aspects of everyone left alive on the ship.  Can they function as a society or like any apocalyptic world story, do you have more to fear from the survivors, than the disaster event itself?There are a lot of characters in this book but up until the end it never really became slightly confusing as to who was who.  I liked the novel, it kind of reminded me of the writing style of authors like Iain Rob Wright. The Kindle version has a bonus short story at the end that isn't related to Flood's storyline, that is told through both a guy who wakes up and realises he's tied up in the boot (trunk) of a car, and the guy driving the car.  I really liked the short story Locked in the Trunk of a Car.  I'd read other books by this author both set in the same Tsunami aftermath world  or about something else.

This documentary is called Nightmare but it's more about people lying in their bed (sometimes asleep, sometimes not) who feel pins and needles in their limbs, can't move them, then are visited by shadow looking figures, sometimes one is wearing a hat, the one wearing the hat is bad.  I couldn't help but think when each of the, I think it is six people recount their bed tales, which is then played out and relived for the viewer on the screen by some pretty bad actors, that perhaps these people were drugged and abused, rather than it being some sort of nightmare or supernatural event.One guy can remember something that  happened when he was one and a half years old, so basically they let anyone with a story to tell contribute to this at the expense of screening them and omitting stuff that obviously isn't likely to have happened.  It's not just black shadow men, there's a blue man and a cat with red eyes too.Overall the appearance of the documentary is like those cheaply made true crime shows in the 90's. Not very well researched and bad acting can still be very watchable and entertaining if done properly, but this is no 1000 Ways to Die.  This was extremely boring and really could have simply been called When the Aliens Came and Visited Me in My Bedroom, and that's what you would have assumed it was about if it wasn't titled Nightmares.  I started playing games on my Kindle while this played, you know a film is boring when you are tempted to start doing that.

Hollywood has always had older actors, especially female actors playing younger aged teens so it's no surprise that they didn't find an actress  around 40 to play Jackie, a career woman about to reach that milestone and instead went with Heather Locklear.  Why they didn't just call the film Flirty With Fifty is anyone's guess.  Jackie's friend can't use her ticket to Hawaii so persuades the I don't have time to take a break from my work mother to spend her birthday in Hawaii where she can also forget about the fact her ex has the kids and a girlfriend in her twenties.  Jackie is saved from a sleazy dude at the pool by a surfing instructor (Robert Buckley) who pretends she's late for a lesson.  Of course she pretty much decides to have a lesson and later do some cougaring.  The two couldn't have more different outlooks on life, he's invented some sort of biodegrade surf wax but doesn't want to leave his laid back lifestyle to make the product a success and she can't resist answering her phone at any time of night or day for a needy client.  Neither really wants to change where they live or their outlook on life.The movie doesn't really reach any great writing heights, there's no twists in the plot or anything that happens by the end that you didn't expect would.  The ex husband is a bit of a jerk and hypocrite as you'd expect in this sort of movie.  The younger guy probably a bit too faultless to be believable, likewise her two kids who are little too happy and supportive all the time to pass as real kids, especially with the father behaving like he does.  There's plenty of swimsuit shots of both lead actors, a few hotel and other places bedroom scenes and pretty much everything else you'd expect with this sort of movie.  It's forgettable but has enough for most similar age to the father or mother character audiences that they might fantasize about being in that type of relationship themselves.

The Bank Job is based on the true story of the Lloyds Baker Street bank robbery, with the conspiracy theories of the time thrown in such as the British Intelligence involvement and photos.  The urban legend stuff of course makes this a much more interesting storyline than it would have been as the simple dig a tunnel while being overheard by the ham radio enthusiast basic vault robbery tale.  It's quite a fun movie, you do wonder why a bank without it's alarms being operational wouldn't roster a couple of its security guards to be in the bank when it's closed.  Plus the openness of discussing what they're doing over the walkie talkies seemed to be a particularly strong level of stupidity but we know that, that actually happened.  It does throw in a bit of Statham action hand to hand combat hero norm at the end which stands out as being over the top compared to the more realistic vibe of the film former to this.Overall it's an enjoyable watch, if you like a good caper film, or films based on true crime then you won't go wrong giving this one a go.

This isn't a bad movie, both the mob thugs as well as the car dealer and his brothers, do some pretty stupid things, not really thinking through their actions which gets them to the dying shot on the snow scene that starts the movie.  However it's still a good thriller if you don't mind reading a good movie.  The basic plot revolves around a worker in a car dealership who is acting more and more paranoid, he owes money to the mob and they decide to kill him for reasons never really explained.  They then tell the car dealership owner that he owes them the money, he decides to enlist his dimwitted brothers who have been bludging off his wealth their own lives to rough up the guy demanding the money.  They decide to take it to another level but the mob guy produces a gun and they are forced to play a different hand.  That hand is never a good one to play against those who are used to getting their way through violence.

Eveleigh (Isla Fisher), moves to a vineyard with her husband David (Anson Mount, Hell on Wheels), she's pregnant and they're hoping for new start after a car accident that killed another child.  She however has stopped taking her meds which had previously helped with dealing with the aftermath of the accident, and is starting to experience visions, objects flying around the room, noises such as the door banging, wine bottles exploding, and sees a guy in a hoodie.  All these things disappear as soon as she summons David. She is also convinced the guy next door is a meth cook. David is getting increasingly frustrated by her paranoia and embarrassing  escalating behaviour.  He wants her doctor (Jim Parsons, Big Bang Theory), to put her back on her meds for her own safety.  Her friend from pregnant yoga (Gillian Jacobs, Community), tells her not to give in to her husband's wants, it's her body etc.  As the terror gets worse for Eveleigh she wants David to abandon the new place, of course he doesn't want to.  Will they survive?This is your standard plot for the most part for this type of set up. Isla Fisher is the main actor in this one, the film revolves around her and she does a pretty good job. The other actors, including Anson Mount, don't have that many scenes.  If you're buying this because you're a fan of one of them, you may be disappointed that they simply don't have that much screen time.  If however you just want a good movie, this isn't a bad one, and the ending is a nice surprise that makes the film even more enjoyable so I won't give that away for you.  With so many actors who are the main character from TV shows in the minor roles the movie became more of a he's from this show, she's from that show game.  It was also obvious that those actors made this when actively shooting their TV shows, or close enough to it as they all still had the same haircuts and looked the way they do on those shows.  So you're kind of waiting for David to mention he's got to go build the railroad, Sadie to mention she's got to do something at Greendale and the doctor to mention to Eveleigh that she is sitting in his spot. Even Eva Longoria seems like she is just visiting and has to get back to her house on Desperate Housewives, although obviously that show has been over for a while.

It's an okay girl does something stupid that ruins another man's life who tries to make it right film, (that something stupid was killing his family as she was looking at another planet leaning out the open window of her car while driving).  Obviously jail and time has changed her from the person she was before the killing and this is an okay version of that often told story.  But what I think most people are buying this for is the fact there is another Earth and watching the unique stuff the plot could provide with that.  But other than some Australian tycoon offering a seat on his rocket to visit the new planet, and a moon landing type significant TV moment where a woman makes contact with someone on that planet, that's about it as far as that interesting topic angle goes.  That to me is ultimately, pretty disappointing.

Trust No One is a lot different to Paul Cleave's other books, but other than the Cleaner, I'd say it is the book with the most fun thrown in, in with people getting killed and stuff that is.  I've read a few similar scenario books where the narrator doesn't know if they are the murderer, even a series by Mike Befeler's which starts with Retirement Homes Are Murder has a man waking up with no recent memories each day but who the police believe is a murderer. Those books though are a lot lighter though than Trust No One. Cleave's entry into this world is a good one.  In his the main character used to be a successful author  but was diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease at age 49.  Now Jerry wakes in a nursing home bedroom, sometimes thinking he's on a book signing tour and he's in an unknown motel, sometimes thinking he is a murderer and that the events on the pages of his novels were his real life.  As you start to turn the pages of his current life as well as read flashback's to his earlier diagnosis days through the pages of his Madness Journal he wrote to his future self which interrupt the story, both you and Jerry began to realise it is perfectly plausible that he is somehow sneaking out of the nursing home and killing innocent women, then forgetting about it.The flashbacks and forth to the current Jerry's mind for the most part read pretty smoothly, except when we're going from the Madness Journal to a current diary.  But you can still follow it all times.  I did find the overall what was going on to be a bit more predictable than you would ideally like with this type of novel but it was still a great journey getting to the final pages.  The scariest part of the book isn't actually the serial killer aspect but the insight into the life of someone recording their mind's slip from their everyday person, they and everyone else recognise as them, to the days when the disease has taken almost over, and the paranoia and inability to remember as well as distinguish between false and true memories takes over.  It's scary because there's no way of knowing if it will happen to you, and if it does no way to stop it, at least for now.

I had seen these in stores for a few months now but always thought they were overpriced for what they were, so when this became an add on item and only cost a couple of bucks, I decided to throw it in the cart with other figures I was buying.  This is worth a couple of dollars but not any more than that.  First of all, for a product with such a high retail price, it comes in a cheap to produce blister on cardboard type of packaging.  This means you've got to make a decision, do you display it in the packaging, or destroy the packaging and display it (or play with it).  You can't change your mind later.  Compare this to cheaper Funko Vinyl Figures which the figure itself is around the same size and come in a box you can open, take the figure out, then put it back later, and you can't tell at all.  The blister card also takes up a lot of room as it is quite oversized compared to the figure so if you do keep it in the blister to display, you're limited to where you can put it due to how tall it is. Also means if you're buying it online the seller needs a bigger box that will cost more and weigh more. The blister card also is pretty average looking, it doesn't really enhance the display by keeping it in there.  It is also isn't the easiest to get the figure out, you've got to cut plastic ties, which are clear and get lost, which wouldn't be good if you had an infant that likes eating stuff it finds on the floor, as they are hard to find.The figure itself looks fairly good from the front.  It heavy but fragile.  It wouldn't survive much rough play.  It comes with a bat on a long plastic strip which you inset into a hole at the back of its coat that comes out the front around where the minon's appendix would be. When you pull the bat out the arms and eyeball move, as do the teeth and some wheels underneath.  If you ever owned a car with the same sort of insert and pull plastic thing or even ones you revved up by pulling them back and back and then letting go, this is the same concept.  It makes that same loud sound too.  The minion however doesn't move very well.  It doesn't roll at all on carpet and on a hard smooth surface about it rolls about ten centimetres before falling over.  You can also move the arms and eyeball simply by rolling the wheels with your hand.  So really it's more of a display piece.From behind it doesn't look that great you can see all the screws holding it together.  It's plastic but hollow (except for the motor) so would likely smash if knocked off a shelf or desk onto the hard floor.  The motor inside isn't obviously that secure as it rattles when you move or shake the minion. For me this is simply a cheaply made figure that I'm not really likely to ever use as a toy simply because it doesn't really work as one.  As a figure you've got to compare it to other brand minions, including even the same character as Dracula's minion.  I think they are better value and more durable.  If this comes up here again for a couple of dollars or you can get it somewhere else really cheap give it a go, otherwise there's better minions figures out there.

It is a teen rom com but don't be put off by that.  The two main characters are very likable and interesting, you do know where the story with the film's title and the fact rom coms all follow the same storyline will go, but the conversations between the two characters, as well as with their friends are interesting and enjoyable to watch.  If you were a teen watching this you might think it to be a bit unbelievable that a good looking girl like Britt Robertson's character with plenty of options would date a total jerk like her older boyfriend, but unfortunately those of us who are a bit older will tell you we've witnessed and baffled by that occurring in real life time and time again.Her parents probably weren't too realistic either that or were just incredibly stupid, plus you can't imagine they wouldn't here her talking to him on the roof or on the grass, or when she'd just closed the front door.  I mean I can hear conversations out front of my house.  Both lead actors Robertson and O'Brien do a great job though, as do the minor characters which include Victoria Justice from Victorious.  Even the guy who played Ronny did a good job, I mean you didn't like his character, that's how you were supposed to feel.

The American DVD cover certainly gives the impression this is a more Hollywood gore type zombie film than the Australian version (country where film was made) does, which simply has a woman alone in a field.  Plague is set in a post virus outbreak world, where infected types roam around the place, although we the reviewer don't see many of them throughout most of the film.  They are different to your Hollywood norm zombies as well, in the fact that they can move fast, and can in fact run down humans.  They also don't mindlessly just wait around at a building when humans are inside, they'll just bang on the door for a while and then run off somewhere else.  I'm not to sure that run away part makes sense when there isn't a lot of prey around for them, surely they would wait but perhaps the dead don't have the best memory or attention span or whatever, we don't really learn much about them since this is a survivors' tale.I agree with other reviewers who state there isn't much original with this tale.  If you've seen an old Nicole Kidman film called Dead Calm, this is pretty much a remake of that, just instead of being on a yacht in the middle of the ocean and encountering another person, this film is set on an isolated farm's shed. It is a survival film.  Plague isn't helped by the fact the male of the couple isn't very likable at all, you don't really understand why she waited for him in the first place.  Plus being how pathetic he is survival skill wise, you wonder how she would have believed (as well as how he did) survive a mass zombie attack and hike to the shed, where the group they were a part of made a pact they would meet up within two days of an attack if they survived.  In a what would you do type movie, you certainly wouldn't do what this guy does, especially when your wife was in danger.Plague does have quite a good ending, a lot better than it looked like it would be, but overall I think it will be a bit slow, a bit too unoriginal, a bit too low budget and having too few zombies for most people's desires who are after a good zombie film.  The blurb on the Australian DVD cover claiming it to be Australia's version of The Walking Dead is very misleading.

G is for Genome was a really good story. Granted a little predictable but it was still a well written fun journey there.
