Some reviews here have complained that the adapter supplied to reduce the 20mm hole to 5/8" did not fit well.  I found it to be a snug fit (the way you would want it to be, to stay put), and it went on without any filing.  With the blade on the original cardboard container, I placed the adapter ring over the hole, then tapped it into place using a small hammer.  With the adapter in place, it fits perfectly on the 5/8" shaft of my Delta Contractor Saw, and there is no wobbling.I bought this blade for one purpose: to cut thin sheets of aluminum (less than 1/8" thick) into precise rectangles.  With a good fence (I have an Incra TS-LS3) and a properly aligned saw, it was very easy to get cuts to within 1/1000 of an inch, straight, and clean.  The blade cuts cleanly and effortlessly, without applying any force that could destabilize the operation.  A light touch-up with a very fine file is good for removing the few tiny burrs to achieve perfection.My table saw can support 10" blades, and you may wonder why I got a blade with such a small diameter, when this aluminum-cutting blade is available in larger diameters.  My reasoning is that smaller blades have significantly reduced speed of contact with the aluminum, by comparing the circumference of a 10" blade to this one.  Cutting metal is best done with a slower saw.  Since I cannot change the speed of the motor, a smaller blade has the same effect as reducing the speed to about 54%.  It has to be raised to near the top of its range, but I do not expect to need to cut aluminum thicker than this blade can manage.  If you have any comments about why this might not be a good idea, please let me know, but it seems right to me.It is important to wear ear and eye protection when using this blade, although for what I am doing it is no louder than cutting wood with a wood blade.

It's all a matter of taste, but there was nothing about this album at all that I liked, let alone think was better than the original.  YMMV.  You might really like it, but one listen was enough for me.
They give you three sheets.  Even following directions, I got air bubbles the first time I tried.  A few months later I decided to try again and got it bubble-free.  It seems to work well.

I have only heard this album before as a pre-recorded open-reel, 7 1/2 IPS tape, and a vinyl record.  That recording is good, but I can hear SO much more in the quiet parts with this CD.It's been awhile since I had heard it.  The excellent remaster also means I could study the guitar work more closely.The alternate versions on the second CD are interesting, but not the reason for getting this release.

This collet adapter works very well for my purposes.  I have mainly used it for a Rockler 1/8" straight bit, which is only available in a 1/4" collet size.  My router only allows 1/2" bits without an adapter like this.
Easy to wire when using a punchdown tool.  Fit a Tripp-brand plate just fine.  The included cable hold-down is a useful inclusion.  Does what it should do.
This inexpensive item is a MUST HAVE for the PanaVise Junior.  The only real complaint is that it should be included with that vise.  It makes the vise MUCH easier to use.
Reliable, low-energy 16-port switch.  It replaced an 8-port switch of the same make when I needed to add some more ports.  The 8-port switch worked flawlessly for at least two years.

Because this came in a paint can, I assumed that it would be a liquid.  In near-winter weather, it is kind of the consistence of Vaseline, but a thicker.  The instructions say to start by stirring it.  That would have been impossible had I not put it in the oven at 160F for an hour with the convection on (while the wife was out :)  ).It says it can be applied by brush, cloth, or hand.  Depending on what you are putting it on, I could see any of these being best.  I am making a drawer unit with wooden drawer guides, and I think using a rag is best for that.It does seem to make a difference.  I'll update this review when I see how it does after being on awhile, and in different temperatures.

The phone is very good, though the headphone jack is not amplified, and does not work well with unamplified headsets.  Amplified headsets typically plug into the jack for the telephone receiver.  This renders the 1/8" headset jack useless.I bought my phone from a dealer who listed the condition as "refurbished".  When I have bought refurbished items from Amazon directly, it has always meant a unit in a box with all of the original materials, unless otherwise noted.  In this case, the phone was clean, but came without a manual and without the RJ11 connecting cord.  Keep that in mind if you are buying this phone as refurbished from a dealer on Amazon.
I have heard that some name brand plates only work well with the same brand of sockets.  In this case, it seems very standard, and worked just fine with "Cable Matters" RJ45 jacks.

I bought this to bolt to the underside of my shop-built router table, which is the outfeed table for my table saw.  I can confirm that the size of this box is large enough to be compatible with my INCRA PRL-V2 Router Lift, which has a plate size of 9 x 11, and some adjustment screws near the edges.  The inside top of the dust collector box is just a bit larger than the plate size, so there is no problem with adjustment screws, and no need for the optional adapter.  It is likely that if your router plate is this size or smaller that this dust box will be compatible, depending on how your router plate is installed and adjusted.  Mine is a simple dadoe to create a lip into which the router plate just fits.I had done a LOT of routing of slots, and it produced inches of sawdust on my floor, not to mention a lot going into my lungs.  I had more to do, so I decided to buy this box.  I had been putting off building one of my own - a very reasonable alternative - but I was anxious to get the big project done, so I bought a quick solution.  In terms of collecting dust, it does everything I need: depending on the operation, very little dust goes anywhere but into the dust collector.The dust box installs easily if you can remove your router table top and flip it upside down.  Even easier if your router top is thicker than 3/4" (mine uses two sheets of 3/4 MDF glued together, laminated with countertop laminate).  It did not take long.  The most difficult and time-consuming part was disassembling my table then reinstalling it, not attaching the DC box.My main disappointment with this unit is the placement of the 4" dust port: straight down.  It's fine if you have one permanently set up with a clamp, but in my small shop, I have to move the hose around.  The ideal would have been a panel at a 45 degree angle, pointing towards the floor on the back side.Second, a very common way of using a router involves dust collection at the fence, typically with a 2.5" hose.  If this DC box had a 2.5" port on the back, with a cap to seal it when not in use, it would be very easy to run a hose from the DC box to the fence port.Last, a gate to allow a variable amount of air to "leak" in to avoid putting too big a strain on the dust collector would be appropriate.  I see that feature on other DC boxes.Aside from these wishlist items, it's a good unit, just not worth "I love it" five stars.

I have had one of these for a couple of years and have been very happy with it.  At some point I dropped it and cracked the display, but it still works fine.  Keeping it in the provided box when not in use probably would have prevented that problem.I recently bought a less expensive one from General Tool and Instrument (on sale about $15) from a woodworking store, and now I appreciate the Wixey all the more.  Two reasons I like the Wixey more:1. Most digital calipers with fractional capability use a 3-mode display: one for inches in decimal format, one for mm in decimal, and one for fractions.  The Wixey is the only one I have seen that has a two-mode display, by combining the decimal and fractional inch display on the same screen.  This is very handy.  The fractional part only appears when it is close to a 1/64" increment - with perhaps .004 (1/250) wiggle room.  I often want to know what the nearest 1/64 or 1/32 measurement is, and having it pop up when it is close allows me to move it up or down a little to find it.2. The Wixey is all metal.  The General Tool and Instruments caliper I bought has an all-plastic body.I also have an analog (vernier) caliper.  While it does not give measurements to 1/1000, it does do 1/64, and being able to see the position between 64th ticks is quite helpful for some applications.

The picture shows maximum current as 0.35 Amperes.  The AD-5 from Casio is rated at 0.85 Amperes (850 mA).  This power supply is not up to the task; overdrawing current could cause it to fail or even burn.

Some of the top reviews for this tool report that it takes off 3/32 or 1/16" and makes a mess of the door edge.  These reviews are dated from 2008-9, and I wonder if perhaps the Dremel folks took the message to heart and improved this tool, maybe by simply shipping it with a smaller-diameter bit.  I bought mine around early 2013.In a room I have just repainted, one door was sticky at the top.  I got up on a stool and looked closely, and found that for the outermost (vertical) board of the door, it had just a bit of a hump compared to the horizontal piece it was attached to.  I figured sanding would take forever, so it was an opportunity to try out a Dremel accessory that I had not used.Following instructions for a change, it went on fairly easily and seemed secure.  I needed an extension cord, of course.  But with that and the stool, I started trimming.  I did not measure, but it took off very little material with each pass.  Judging by the quality of the debris, I would not be surprised if it was less than 1/32" per pass, and maybe even the claimed 1/64".  Holding the tool according to the instructions, and moving the tool steadily, I got a fairly flat surface with one pass, no gouging or ridges, as would be the case if it was cutting more deeply.  It was easy to control, again something I would expect from a shallow cut more than a deep one.  I needed to take a few passes to make the door open and close easily, so I repeated, trying it from the opposite side to keep it as even as possible.The tool made short work of a task that would have been difficult to do with any other tool I have - and I have a reasonably well-equipped shop for a weekend warrior.  Certainly, $20, or the extra cost of getting a kit that includes it, seemed worth the cost.The only complaint I might have, and it is minor, is that the perpendicular piece that is supposed to hold it square with the work is a bit short to do that.  If it was an inch or two longer, I could perhaps hold that in place with one hand, while using the other hand to hold the plastic piece on top against the work surface.  Alternatively, they could supply a removable piece to extend it, or at least drill a couple of holes to allow you to fashion your own out of a scrap of wood or metal.I would not call it a precision tool, nor at this price point would I expect it to be.  I bought the Dremel as a quick way to trim, sand, clean, or polish, especially for small items, and it suits those purposes well.Four stars means "I Like It".  I reserve five stars for products that exceed my expectations.  This one fully met my expectations, and I would recommend it for purposes similar to mine.

If you are planning a trip to Myanmar, you are probably wondering which travel guide to use.  This review is a comparison of the Insight Guides Myanmar (Burma), IGMB, April 2013, to Lonely Planet Myanmar (Burma), LPMB, Dec 2011.  Each has its strengths and weaknesses; they are designed for different purposes, and that needs to be taken into account when you choose.  For more information on Lonely Planet Myanmar (Burma) 2011, see my review for that book.OVERALL COMPARISONOverall, LPMB has more text details, and IGMB has lots of color pictures.  If and when LP publishes a Discover Myanmar (Burma) guide, it will be more comparable to IGMB.  For my purposes, both guides are useful and somewhat complementary in purpose.IGMB has between 25% to 100% of most pages dedicated to mostly pictures and some maps.  This has two obvious implications:1. IGMB has less text than LPMB.  LPMB does have a few pictures and more maps, but most of the pages are filled with paragraph text, text boxes, and tables.2. IGMB has a lot more pictures, in color on glossy paper, compared to LPMB.  It has maps of the larger regions, which means fewer details for use in town.Arguably, LPMB, with its greater quantity of text, and listings, would seem to be the better choice for a book to bring with you, especially if your trip is longer, or if you are going to make your plans as you go along.  IGMB has more descriptive information on the sights and history than LPMB.But all those pictures in IGMB may be very useful for travelers planning a trip, especially in deciding which country to visit, or which areas within the country to visit.  For visually-minded folks, sometimes pictures are a faster way to get a feel for where you want to visit than lots of text.  And for shorter trips, especially those with fixed itineraries, the textual information may be adequate.When I visited Myanmar in early December 2011, I had access only to the previous edition of LPMB.  I would like to have had IGMB to help me decide where to visit within Myanmar.  Having said that, I don't regret where I went, and I'm not sure that I would have chosen differently if I had seen IGMB.DETAILED COMPARISONIGMB, published April 2013, has 344 pages, is 9.2 x 6", is fairly heavy, thanks to the coated glossy paper.  The pictures look better on glossy paper than LP's unglossy paper.LPMB, published December 2011, has 408 pages.  It is 7 3/4" x 5", and is fairly light, thanks to thin, unglossy paper.  LP's thin paper allows them to publish a guide that is lighter and more compact to carry with more pages, and it works fine for text.For comparison sake, let's take a case study.  Suppose you want to stay in Nyaung U to visit the Bagan area.IGMB has about 4 pages of text (total, in various parts of the book) that lists 4 places to stay.  2 restaurants are listed, and others on the road into town are listed.  Attractions focus on temples.  There are pictures in the Nyaung U section, but the only map is of the overall Bagan area, and the Nyaung U part is not very detailed.  Hotels, restaurants, and travel are listed in a separate section from the sights; this is due to the way Insight Guides are organized.LPMB has 5 pages of text that list 12 places to stay and 7 restaurants.  In town attractions include a gallery and a golf club; shopping lists a local market.  A table summarizes the various ways to get from Yangon to Nyuang U and relative costs, including: flying, train, bus, boat, car, and somewhat detailed text on each of these is included.  There is a small map of part of Nyaung U, but the only pictures are in the rather brief photos section.  In the Bagan temple section, there is another page about temples in Nyaung U, so a total of 6.But an effect of LP listings for hotels and restaurants is that these places get full of LP travelers quickly.  They become less available.  It's strange to be in an exotic location and have the place I'm eating be full of people carrying LP.  And they get more westernized by the needs of the new travelers, which can have pluses and minuses.  There are a LOT of places in Nyaung U alone, and many more in the surrounding area.  No guide can list them all.  One approach to getting one is to book with an agent while in Yangyon.  There's no guarantee of quality, though in my experience agents do reasonably well, and LP-listed places is also no guarantee of quality.ORGANIZATIONIGMB has a two-page table of contents at the beginning of the book, and a four-page index at the end.  Both are reasonably complete and well organized, covering the right topics.LPMB has had a facelift for its recent editions, and the organization is worse IMO than editions of 2010 and before; new LP guides are harder to use than the classic ones.  They have eliminated a table of contents at the beginning of the book in favor of very short tables of contents for some sections.  There is a seven page index, and you're really going to need it to find what you're looking for, since there is no table of contents.BOTTOM LINEAs a single travel guide, IGMB will be enough for those booking a tour that includes transportation within Myanmar, and perhaps for shorter visits.  With its pictures, it is a great resource for deciding where to go.  LPMB is better for DIY travelers who need all the details, for longer trips, or for trips where the plan is made on the fly.Using both - IGMB to decide where to go while at home, LPMB to bring with you - would be ideal.

I use a Microsoft Surface Pro to give powerpoint presentations, and needed a way to connect the Mini Display Port to the VGA that most projectors support.  This adapter does work with Macs with Mini Display Port, but it also works for the Surface Pro.I plugged it all together, and it just worked without any hitches.Four stars means "I Like It", because it does what I expected and works very well.  I reserve five stars for products that exceed my expectations.

This is a lively song with some funny lyrics, when they are intelligible or sensible at all.  Read wikipedia for some background, but in short, it is claimed that the writer heard "Lucy in the Sky (with Diamonds)" and thought it was "Lucy in Disguise".  When he found out his error, he decided the world needed a song like that, and added (with Glasses).It's the kind of song that could liven up a dance tape, especially for those who remember it.

This is a very small book.  Measuring about 4.5x6 inches, with 142 pages, it really doesn't have room to thoroughly discuss the ideas it presents.  The ideas and illustrations are decent, as far as they go, but if you have a table saw and want to use it well, you need a book with better explanations.As an example, the section on table saw alignment is much too short.  While every table saw owner can and should learn to align their saw, this won't really help.  Your manual is a good start, but a book on table saws ought to tell you a lot more.  This format just doesn't allow it.The same is true for every subject discussed here; too little information.There are countless resources that offer much more details, more jigs, more techniques - books, DVDs, woodworking magazines.  There's no reason to put inadequate books like this on your shelf when there are better treatments available.

I bought the now-discontinued Miter 2000 gauge several years ago.  It serves similar purposes, but has two distinct disadvantages:1) The angle range is 0-45, instead of -60-0-+60 (the most important reason for switching)2) To use it in the other miter gauge, you have to do a multi-step procedure that takes a few minutesI decided to "upgrade" to this unit to overcome these limitations.  But there are still two caveats:1) To use it in the other miter gauge, you have to loosen two screws, slide the fence, retighten.  It takes less time, but requires that change2) The miter bar is a good deal shorter than the one on the Miter 2000, which means the width of the material to be cut is less.I can tell you that this unit DOES support most (but not all) Incra fences, including the one I got with the Miter 2000, and that's a huge win.Both models have the famous Incra accuracy, and are ruggedly built (the 2000 is more rugged, the MiterV120 is rugged enough).  Both make it VERY easy to get any specific angle you want at 1-degree intervals (and a special stop for 22 1/2 degrees).  When used with the fence, the MiterV120 is an excellent upgrade from your basic miter gauge that came with your saw.  Although the MiterV120 allows you to choose many specific angles, I use it the most set for 90 degree cuts relative to the blade.  Once it is calibrated, I can be sure of always getting exactly square cuts.Kreg has a competing model (KMS7101) which you should look at, but it has far fewer positive stops.  On the plus side, moving the fence (such as for changing which miter slot to use) is easier thanks to knobs to loosen and tighten the fence fastening (Incra's requires a tool), and the miter bar is a full 24" long, much longer than for the MiterV120, allowing for cutting wider stock.I use the MiterV120 very frequently, basically for any cross-cut that is not so large as to require a cross-cut sled.UPDATE 1/9/2015: I noticed that somehow the seemingly beefy steel teeth used for setting the angle got damaged somehow at the most important 0 mark.  The result is that it is tricky to get it into the 0 and stay there; it slipped easily into about 1/2 degree.  I noticed this when some cuts were not quite the right angle. I improved it by repairing the teeth with a file, but a replacement would be better.Changed to 3 stars ("It's OK") because it should be built to last forever.  But note: I am a fan of Incra tools and own several; I'm just disappointed with this one.

There are a lot of table saw books out there.  This is not the best of them, though it's not bad for the areas that it covers.  The main problem I have with it is that it includes some exotic operations (such as cutting coves into thick wood or pattern cutting) while not covering some essentials.Is it a beginner's book?  Yes, but it's incomplete at that.  Is it an advanced techniques book?  Yes, it includes exotic and advanced techniques that you may never use, and is by no means the last word on advanced table saw use, either.  They should really have chosen one direction or the other, or better yet, do two different books to cover both directions well.There isn't a lot here that I have not seen in other books, or the many shop magazines.  It fails to cover essential topics.  It isn't as well organized as it could be (safety covered in two separate sections, safety combined with dust control, TWO articles on kickback instead of one).Here is the organization of the book:1. Tablesaws and blades - a survey of commercially-available saws and blades2. Techniques - ripping, crosscutting, joint-quality edges, safe procedures, tearout, coves, and pattern cutting3. Joinery - box joings, dovetails, tenons4. Dust control and Safety - containing dust in a contractor saw, shop-made table saw guards, causes and prevention of kickback, and kickback again5. Cross-cutting jigs6. Shop-made accessoriesThe sections consist of articles by many different authors - many of them well-known.  This brings in the expertise of many but limits the cohesiveness of the book.If I was the editor, I would have ditched the exotic techniques in favor of including a detailed procedure for aligning a table saw.  Sooner or later, you're going to need to learn to do that; it isn't trivial; it has several steps; it requires special measuring guides; it becomes necessary eventually just from using your saw.  And it is essential both for getting good cuts as well as for safety reasons.  In general, there are advanced topics included here at the expense of essential topics.I laughed when I saw the part about cutting a 4x8 sheet of plywood.  One guy feeding it in the front.  Only at the end does he suggest a partner for helping with the outfeed.  To my way of thinking, cutting a sheet of plywood on a table saw is only suitable for very large, professional table saws like the 7 HP monster at our specialty plywood store, at least if it is 1/2" or 3/4" thick (or more).  A much better approach is to ask for the it to be cut into two pieces at the store (with a bit of excess for you to trim to exact measurements on your own saw), or to use a hand circular saw with a guide.The one part I really liked was their approach for dust-proofing a contractor saw.  I tried to do that, but my approach meant that the blade could not be tilted with the back cover in place, so I have to take it off every time I want to tilt.  I plan to try again using the ideas presented here.BOTTOM LINE: Three Stars - "It's OK".  Somewhat useful, but insufficient to be your only table saw reference, whether you are beginner or intermediate.

This book presents several useful ideas for a workshop in a form that will allow a beginning woodworker to build them - complete cut lists, step-by-step instructions with photos, and things to watch out for.It's good as far as it goes, but for my purposes as an intermediate woodworker who wants to build a workbench, it is a bit too elementary.  Only one approach is discussed for any of the constructions; there is no discussion of alternatives.  For tool drawers, he uses an over-sized bottom designed to fit into slots.  The problem is, when you load those drawers with tools, they will be hard to open, which is why most other designs use heavy-duty drawer sliders.The contents:IntroductionTools and MaterialsSawhorsesWorkbenchTablesaw WorkstationRouter TableStorageAll of these projects have been presented before, and with better designs.  Consider Fine Woodworking's Best Workbenches, which chooses a narrower range of items to build, but gives you more options for designing them, albeit without the cut-lists and step-by-step instructions that could be very useful to some beginners.  If I built any of these, I would be bummed when I later found a vastly superior design which made me want to build it again.  That's the drawback of showing only one approach for each topic, instead of giving you a broad range of options.  His elementary instructions on attaching a vise are fine as far as they go, but Best Workbenches covers the subject in four pages in a manner that will give much better results.My approach for designing a new workbench was to go to the library and find all the books that discuss workbenches, and look them all over for ideas.  Then I went into the DVDs with back issues of Wood Magazine, Woodsmith, and ShopNotes to find more ideas.  I noted approaches that seemed useful for my needs, then eventually refined these down to a list of notes about exactly how I would build my workbench.  But if you design your own, you'll have to come up with your own cut lists and figure out what steps there are to assembly.One important thing I learned, which I didn't think about because I mainly work with plywood, is that in fastening a workbench top to the base, you do NOT want to put screws in the corners if you are using solid wood or butcherblock.  As he points out, this is just asking for the top to crack as it shrinks and grows with seasonal weather changes (especially humidity).  The problem is, he wasn't very specific about exactly where to put the screws to fasten the top to the base in a manner that avoids cracking the top yet keeps the top firmly on the base; all he says is to put four screws through the top end stretchers into the benchtop.So yes, if I was a beginning woodworker, this book might be useful, although when I was a beginner I did not have the range of tools he has, or the skills to use them in the manner he instructs.  But as an intermediate woodworker, instead of jumping to the first design, we need to consider several different design methods in order to find the one that suits our individual style best, because workshops are definitely not one size fits all.BOTTOM LINE:  For me, it's three stars - "It's OK".  For a beginner, it could be four or five stars.

A workbench is the heart of any shop, whether for woodworking or other handy or hobby work.  It is a very personal thing; there is no one universal type that makes sense for all kinds of people.I think for beginners, the best thing is to make a simple one quickly and inexpensively.  But eventually, you may get to the point where it's time to build the bench of your dreams - YOUR dreams, not somebody else's.  That time came for me, and I decided to get as many books as possible and study the designs, along with designs in woodworking magazines.This book shows the classical designs of the past few centuries, and it has several variations on these themes.  Thinking outside of the box, it shows work centers that don't look like conventional workbenches.This is not a beginner's project-oriented book.  You won't find complete plans with cut lists and assembly instructions.  There is enough detail to build anything in it, but without specific dimensions etc, you are necessarily building a custom design for each idea.I took out several books on workbenches from the library, and researched back issues of Woodsmith, ShopNotes, and Wood Magazine.  Of the many resources I studied for ideas and solutions, this one is the most comprehensive for someone designing their own like me, and I like it better than the books written by the most famous names - some of whom also contributed articles to this book.The book is organized in five parts:1. Choosing a workbench - general styles of custom-build and ready-made workbenches2. Workbenches that work - a study of eight workbenches with anatomical details sufficient to build them3. Holding workpieces - vises, hold-downs, clamps, and other devices for holding the work to the bench while you work it4. Improving a workbench - tips for flattening the top, accessories that can be added to an existing bench5. Specialized Workbenches - work centers for other purposes than the general-purpose benchThe most valuable part of this book for me was very detailed instructions for mounting a front vise to the bench.  Sure, I've done it before without instructions, but there are great ideas here that I did not come up with, but will definitely use for my new bench.I was thinking about a drawer cabinet for tool storage below the bench top.  For reasons of the steel frame I am starting from, I decided I would have to build two separate boxes rather than one big one.  In this book I found a project for a drawer cabinet that also took this approach, for different reasons.  While I will still design my own, there are useful ideas to be found in reading an article from an expert who has already done it.I like the benchtop bench - a good solution for having adjustable benchtop height, in that the auxiliary bench can bring the work higher for some kinds of work.  But a really useful tip that I had not seen elsewhere is the use of two veneer-press screws for the vise.  I have decided to use this approach for my MAIN bench, for the end vise; it is much less expensive than buying a nice wide end vise, and since I'm unsure I will use it a lot, it's a good way of having an end vise available for occasional use.  There is another variation that uses pipe clamp heads that would also work, except that the vise faces cannot move is far, resulting in more dog holes.Aside from these two articles, I got lots of ideas and guidance for designing my workbench from the book as a whole.  The book is full of photographs and drawings, although it does NOT include dimensions of the sort you find in detailed woodworking plans - and I don't need those anyway.Having studied the book (and several others like it), I have picked up ideas for features that I will use, and am confident that the bench I am building will last for years.BOTTOM LINE: Five Stars "I Love It" - because it is the best (for my purposes) of MANY books I have looked at.  YMMV.  If you are a beginner, this may be too advanced, though there is a design a beginner-intermediate could build if they are able to produce their own cut lists etc.  If you are looking specifically at a traditional bench, there are other books that examine those in more detail.  This is in between - a very practical guide to today's workbench ideas for someone inclined to design their own.

I bought this triangle to help with laying out cut lines for woodworking.  I bought the smallest and largest sizes to accommodate varying sizes of wood, and I find them very handy for their purpose.  I got "smoke" rather than clear, which is easier to find in a busy shop, but you can still see through it.  The small one is a bit darker in color than the large one.I don't have a precision tool to measure accuracy of the 45 degree angles, but the accuracy looks quite good.  The right angle is as close as I can feel when placed against a precision aluminum alignment tool.This drawing triangle is very useful for drafting and for use in layout in the shop.I might have prefered that it was a bright color instead of grey, simply so that it can be spotted more quickly.BOTTOM LINE: Four stars means "I Like It".  I reserve five stars that exceed expectations in some way.  This tool does its job well and I have no complaints about it, but there are many others similar in quality and price, and this one is as good, but not better.

The main value of a screen protector is keeping the screen clean and free of finger smears.  No screen protector will protect the glass from being broken if dropped or crushed, and glass is unlikely to scratch, short of using a diamond or sharp metal on it.KINDS OF SCREEN PROTECTORSThe most common kind of screen protector is glossy, though slightly less glossy than the screen. From the perspective of optical quality, the best is naked (no screen protector), then the glossy kind, then this one (an "HD" anti-glare type), and last a conventional anti-glare type.THIS HD ANTI-GLARE PROTECTORI expect to use my Surface Pro for drawing, and having it lie flat is the easiest way to draw, but that also means it is subject to glare and reflections from any ceiling lights. This screen protector is anti-glare, accomplished by etching tiny lines into the plastic.  It calls itself "HD" (for high definition), and the fine pitch of the lines is what makes it stand out from other anti-glare screens.  HD keeps the image sharper than conventional anti-glare screen protectors.  I bought a conventional anti-glare screen protector for my Nexus 7 tablet, and even though the screen is lower resolution on a pixels-per-inch basis, the image is a bit less sharp from the lower resolution of screen scribes.I am very nearsighted, so when I look at the Surface Pro with this HD screen protector in place closely without glasses,, I can see tiny specks of color which are caused by diffracting the emitted light.  However, people with normal vision or using glasses probably won't notice these.DRAWING AND WRITINGA screen protector also adds a little friction that you can feel when using your finger on the screen, or when writing or drawing on the screen with the stylus.  The naked glass surface has very little drag.  A conventional screen protector is smoother than an anti-glare type, so it has more drag than naked glass but less than an anti-glare protector.  I consider this drag DESIRABLE, because it gives you more control, and the anti-glare drag is similar to pen/pencil on paper.  I anticipated that the anti-glare surface would be a bit less slippery, and it does indeed add a bit of useful drag for drawing and writing.COST - IS IT WORTH IT?This screen protector is more expensive than other anti-glare protectors, and there is only one provided, not two.  But the HD scribes are worth it, and I think the plastic is somewhat thicker.  There is a black border that matches the frame of the Surface Pro perfectly, and there are holes cut to allow the camera and other front panel sensors to work properly.  Most screen protectors come with a little plastic card that is used for working the bubbles out to the edge where they disappear.  THIS screen protector does not include one of those, but perhaps because it was thicker, it was easy to put it on with NO bubbles.INSTALLATION TIPS1) clean the screen thoroughly with a glass cleaner and a soft, lint-free cloth.  Allow to dry.2) when applying the screen protector, start with a narrow edge, and put the edge of the plastic right at the scribe of the glass screen3) don't press it down at first.  Gradually lay it down, checking that the edges align correctly, and in particular that the camera and other centers are at the center of the holes.  If they are not, pull it back off and start again until you get it right.  When you have the holes aligned correctly, you can smooth the remaining protector down - carefully, to avoid bubbles.BOTTOM LINEFour stars: "I Like It".  It is more expensive than conventional anti-glare screen protectors, but there is a difference is in image quality, and you are far less likely to get bubbles. I'm glad I spent the extra money.

PROS:economical spare/replacement power supply that works with Surface Pro (and probably RT)supports 100-240vac for worldwide use (with plug adapter)CONS:no USB charging port like MS power supplyno LED on power adapter to indicate that it is working when connected, like the MS power supply3-wire plug instead of 2-wire like MS power supply (NOTE: some units may have 2-wire, as shown in Amazon photo)First, this is NOT a MS branded power supply; it is an inexpensive knock-off with nearly identical specs.  The Surface Pro requires 12 volts at 3.6 Amperes, and this unit claims to support that.The MS branded power supply also has 5 volts at 1 Ampere for a USB charge port on the power supply,  This unit does not have a USB charge port.  Assuming you don't need the USB charge port, this isn't a problem.  You CAN charge on the Surface Pro anyway, though at somewhat lower current (USB3 says 0.75 Amp max to be in spec), and with only one USB port on the Surface Pro, you may need it for other purposes.The proprietary connector on the cable is the same as the one found on the original power supply; it fits well, maybe slightly more snug and therefore less likely to fall out, but also requires just a small push to make connection.  It should have an LED to show it is plugged in like the MS unit has, but there is no LED on this unit.Like the original power adapter, this one runs on 100 to 240 volts AC, so it should work anywhere in the world with a plug adapter or alternate cord.  I wish it was designed for a two-wire plug; I'm not sure what the advantage of a ground wire is for a properly insulated power supply.  NOTE: the Amazon photo shows the unit with a two-wire AC cord; mine is three-wire.It is a good spare power supply, and inexpensive enough to have one in the various places you use your Surface Pro.  I like the MS one more for traveling, so this one is used a lot as the primary power supply at my home desk.  I will update this review if I have any problems in the future.Be aware that there are probably different units with different specs and possibly different reliability, because most likely it is being produced by more than one Chinese manufacturer, yet they may all be sold as the same unit on Amazon.  Thus, your experience may vary from the reviews you find here - some say reliable, at least one says melted down.  If you buy one, test it by using it a lot during the Amazon return window.I will update this review if anything happens to change my opinion, but I think this is a good buy.

PROSAdequate protection for dropping your Surface deviceFits well with clear access to all ports, vents, speakers, mike, camerasElastic loop for stylusStand has choice of three viewing anglesElastic hand loop for holding firmly with one handCONSThe hand loop holder is mainly useful for portrait orientation, not landscapeNEUTRALNo storage accessories other than stylusThis is the early days for Surface Pro accessories, and we don't have many choices.  After reviewing what was on Amazon, I decided on this one.I wanted a case that allowed the device to be protected while in use.  Zipper bags that require you to remove the device are no good to me, because there is no protection if it is dropped.  Part of this case stays on the device at all times (though it can easily be removed thanks to a velcro fastener).  The other part snaps on and off, and must be removed to use the hand loop, but stays in place when the case is used to stand up the device for viewing.Another important thing to me is variable viewing angles when the case is used as a stand.  The built-in viewing support for the Surface Pro has only one angle, and it is the wrong angle for viewing when the device is on a desk (too steep / close to vertical to fully see the screen).  This case has three useful viewing angles, which is far more flexible.As for protection, this case is not padded with foamy stuff, but the surrounding material is thick enough to protect it.  The worst damage comes when a device is dropped onto a corner or edge, and this case has ridges in these places that prevent the device from coming into contact with a hard surface.  I think this is adequate protection.  Bigger, thicker, rubber cases are made for other devices that probably offer more protection, but at the time of writing they were not available for Surface Pro on Amazon.There IS an elastic loop for storing the stylus; it's located on the long edge opposite the spine.  I did not notice it at first, and my original review complained that there was no loop, so I have updated the review.There is no storage for any other accessories - power supply, earbuds, cables, disks, etc -  but chances are you're going to put the device in its case into some kind of briefcase or backpack that will have space for the accessories.  I would not want an increase of size or weight to accommodate these accessories.There are magnets built into the cover that cause it to stay closed when you fold it shut, but the magnets are not strong, and it opens easily.  The magnets have no other effect than holding it closed - for example, on a Google/Asus Nexus 7, covers with magnets can cause the Nexus 7 to turn off the screen when the case is closed, and nothing like that happens here, probably because MS did not put a magnetic sensor in the Surface Pro.  That's fine with me, because the Nexus 7 gets its screen turned off even when a magnetic over is folded backwards.The cover allows the use in four ways:1. Take the device out and use it "naked"2. Unsnap the folding cover and hold it with the case's hand loop3. Fold the cover all the way back and use the device flat4. Use the case to prop up the device at one of three fixed anglesI got the indigo color, expecting it to be the color of dark blue jeans.  In fact, it is darker than that, like a dark navy blue.  I wasn't crazy about the color selection; I prefer bright colors that stand out when I am looking in a black bag, or looking around the room to make sure I haven't forgotten anything.Other reviewers complained about the workmanship and stitching.  The workmanship and stitching on the one I received were very good overall.  While it's not real leather, I think it's better with durable imitation leather, because real leather can get wet, stained, or otherwise damaged.Overall, this case appears well made and likely to last.  I think it's the best currently available that meet my requirements.BOTTOM LINE: Four stars - "I Like It".  It meets my basic requirements, but there is room for improvement, especially for storing the stylus.  Nothing unique in its features to make it a five star unit.

Whether you use traditional or electric tools, woodworkers live and die by clever ideas for all kinds of work.  While titled "Setting Up Your Workshop", this book also includes many great ideas for jigs to solve various problems.  Of course, you can pick up a lot of these ideas by working with other woodworkers, or reading the magazines.  The tips here are different from the books published by magazines, which tend to be rehashes of things previously published in magazines (but can still be useful).The book assumes that the reader needs only ideas, and not complete project-oriented discussion, parts lists, dimensions, etc, so it is not a totally beginner-oriented book.  It does not teach the techniques used for building the jigs, which could be helpful for a beginner, but the ideas are simple and most woodworkers will have no trouble figuring out how to build (and modify!) the jigs.  They do offer suggestions while you are building to help you get the details right.Here is the chapter listing:Introduction - 3 short essays from experienced woodworkers about what they do and what that means for their shop1. Shop Layout - 17 pages planning the placement of major tools, benches, etc for various shop sizes, and locations like garage, attic, basement.  Lighting, power, heating, ventilation, floor2. Workbench - 14 pages covering essential construction of a traditional bench, plus 10 pages on a variety of accessories (dogs, hooks, carving holders, sawing accessories, shooting boards)3. Shop Accessories - 17 pages on dust collection, air-powered tools, and mentions of useful secondary tools like shop vac, grinders, compressors, etc4. Storage - 20 pages on storing tools, wood, clamps; a fold-down workbench and tool cabinet5. Work Surfaces - 37 pages on work tables, sawhorse and variations, clamping jigs, feed stands, shop-built extensions for routers (e.g. tables), band saw (circle cutting, extension table), drill press table, outfeed for table saw6. Safety - 16 pages on jigs to make work safer, things to wear to protect yourself, first aid, instead of admonishments to use your saw blade guard and be carefulIndex - longer and more detailed that most, but there are lots of ideas in this book to indexMost readers will find familiar ideas explained well, but also new ideas.  The ideas are text and drawn pictures organized well, and fairly comprehensive for general purpose shops.It's interesting that there is no author listed for this book.BOTTOM LINE: Four stars, "I Like It".  Many great ideas to learn from, yet not as exhaustive as it could be.

This formerly rare album, released as this 2xLP on vinyl for Record Store Day 2012, is now also available to all fans as a CD (but not, oddly, on MP3, at least not when I wrote this review).Devo was touring their "New Traditionalists" album in 1981, and they played seven tracks from that album, along with 9 tracks from "Freedom of Choice" and their earlier albums.  The full track list:1. Opening Theme2. Going Under3. Through Being Cool4. Jerkin' Back 'N' Forth5. Soft Things6. Pity You7. Girl U Want8. Planet Earth9. Whip It10. Race of Doom11. Super Thing12. Uncontrollable Urge13. Mongoloid14. Jocko Homo15. Smart Patrol / Mr. DNA16. Gut Feeling17. Gates of SteelThe CD release has two tracks that are not on the LP release (Beautiful World, and Workin' In a Coal Mine).  They are from a show earlier in Nov 1981 that I saw in Boston's Orpheum Theatre.  Also, the CD has broken out the "Set Change Countdown" that opens "Super Thing" as a separate track, though both are on the LP.From Jerry Casale: "This was cut from a cassette recording of DEVO's show in Seattle, WA show in Nov. '81. DEVO archivist Michael Pilmer (aka Devo-Obsesso), found the tape in a shoebox full of cassettes in Bob2's home fifteen years ago, which he immediately transferred it to DAT. Afterward it promptly disappeared in the flotsam of Devo history. Here resurrected it stands as a testament to Prince's claim "Devo, you guys are crazy!""When he says it is a cassette recording, I suspect that it came from the sound board, not just an audience recording.  The sound recording is good for a cassette recording that was digitized; I'd like to hear the drums a bit more on the high end.The performance is also very good, and they get even more lively as the show progresses. Most of the new songs are quite similar to the album arrangements in most cases, yet it does not sound at all like they just flipped a switch and sang along.  For songs on previous albums, they have evolved a bit from their studio versions.  The guitar work, in particular, is a bit varied compared to the studio versions, notably in "Girl U Want", and the vocals are a bit different.  "Race of Doom" is a bit crazier, especially on the drums.  Some songs sound a tad faster than the studio versions.  The audience sounds are a bit higher in the mix than I would prefer, but mostly they do not intrude.BOTTOMS LINE: Four stars - "I Like It".
