This one is a book of 13 projects for a wide variety of home-built work platforms, including a few actual workbenches.The projects are:1. Carver's vise - buy a metal screw and make a vise out of wood2. Collapsable workbench - designed to be separable into four parts to minimize storage and make moving it easy3. Fold-down workbench - a stationary workbench designed to close up into a minimal space when not in use4. Grinding bench - a small bench for a power grinder with wheels5. Crafts bench - for sewing and other light crafts6. Low bench tool tote - combines sawhorse, stool, and tool carrying7. Metalworking bench - a small bench made with metal parts and wooden top8. Miter saw bench - optimized for using a power miter saw9. Sawhorses - foldable for compact storage10. Assembly bench - for sanding and assembly, with drawers and a cabinet11. Shaving horse - you can sit on it while stripping bark from branches12. Traditional English saw horse - fixed, not foldable, sturdy13. Traditional workbench - a workbench he designed inspired by traditional woodworking benchesThe target audience would be a beginner-intermediate woodworker, who has the skills and tools to accurately cut wood in a variety of shapes and sizes, but wants to have very specific designs for specific purposes.  If any of these are exactly what you want, and the size you want, the very complete instructions, parts lists, and photos would make it easy to build them.The problem I have with this book is that it does not achieve the goals of the title ("Build your own CUSTOM Workbench") or the back cover ("Build a workbench that meets your woodworking needs!").  Woodworkers each have their own idea for what they need, but on the other hand, there are a handful of classic designs that show up in some form over and over again - including #13 in this book.Most of us end up building a bench that supports the tasks we need to do and in the size we need, but if your goal is to get ideas for building a CUSTOM bench, other books do that much better.  A key requirement is the height of the work surface, which will vary depending on the person who will use it, but there is NO discussion in this book on that design element.Of the 13 projects, there are only 3 designs for what I would call a woodworker's workbench designed to handle a variety of construction tasks.  I don't have the kind of space to have a lot of purpose-built benches around, so I need one that can be used for a wide variety of tasks, and I have studied several books on DESIGNING workbenches.  To have a CUSTOM bench, it will be necessary to create a design, or modify an existing design, but it won't be a cookbook project-based approach like in this book.The Traditional Workbench (#13) was what I was looking for, but his design is not elegant, and not as functional as this kind of bench can be.  It features a front vise (but no cover for inner jaw) and a single-screw end vise, but no discussion of other kinds of vises (tail vise, leg vise, wagon vise, two-screw end vise), and not enough detail on mounting a vise.  What he refers to as a "tail vise" is called an "end vise" in most books and magazines I have researched.  There is no discussion of types of bench tops, or the alternative of buying a pre-fab top.  Where I think it is useful to have a top that is a bit longer and wider than the base for clamping purposes, this design has the top about the same size - a mistake I made when I built my current bench.  Overall, the biggest problem is that he gives only one example of a workbench, and omits any discussion of design alternatives that are appropriate if you are building a CUSTOM workbench.The assembly bench project has lots of problems.  It is a big boxey thing with no wheels or even anything to grab ahold of if you want to move it.  No "toe kick" space on the bottom as is standard for counter cabinets so you can stand up close to your work.  I think it is much too tall for an assembly bench: it appears to be about waist high, whereas assembling larger objects is easier if you have a low table.  There is a lot of cabinet and drawer space below the work surface, but it is far more than I would need for the tools used for sanding and assembly.The best woodworking books use projects to introduce techniques skills with a variety of uses; this one does not teach much new about woodworking.  The one tip I saw was for cutting large panels.The index is minimal; most of it is just the table of contents listed in a different order in a half a page.  There IS an entry for his tip on cutting large panels.BOTTOM LINEI am an intermediate-level woodworker, and I got nothing useful or new out of this book.  There are other books that explore variations on woodworking benches and accessories that are just more inspired.  On the other hand, for someone who needs exactly one of these things and has not developed design skills, this book could be handy, but the title does not correctly describe the content of the book.

I heard "te quiero a ti" on jango's channel.  Modern sounding, with modern instruments, but there's an interesting twist: the beat is very slightly different.  It's difficult to convey in words, but if you consider the cumbia beat to be LONG-SHORT-SHORT-LONG with accents on the two LONGs, then what's different is that the second LONG comes in a little later than standard cumbia, giving a kind of "lope" to the rhythm.Perhaps this sounds subtle, but the Cumbia rhythm is mostly very standard, and of all the cumbia I have listened to (LOTS), this one stands out because it has changed the beat.  You might even say this is not quite cumbia.Now for the music in the album.  I really like the song, "te quiero a ti".  The problem is, there is not very much variety in this album.  The same loping cumbia beat is used on every song, and the overall sound is very similar from song to song.  That's the reason I have given the album three stars - not enough variety - but check out the samples to hear how this album changes cumbia, just a bit.

Konkan curries, such as Goa Fish Curry, use Kokum to impart a natural sweet and sour flavor.  Kokum is also supposed to impart a nice red color, especially when using coconut milk.This brand, purchased at a local Indian grocery, was fresh, but did not provide the expected color and flavor.

Normally I would give a four-star review to a cable that simply does the expected job.  In this case, the cable seems robustly built, tough, stronger than most cables I use at home, and very likely to last a long time.  Because it is better than the usual, yet is priced at home cable prices, it gets five stars.My intended purpose will require it to withstand disconnection and reconnection - not as much as a professional environment, but enough to put some stress on it.  If there is no update to this review, you can assume that so far it is holding up perfectly.  If I have any problems, I will update the review.

PROS:Wide range of fine adjustmentsRecharger / wall adapter works 100-240VAC, suitable for foreign travelWorks fine for a tough beardCONS:Does some jobs better than othersCombs are wider than the trimming head, so detail work is a bit harderIf you want to get rid of a beard or mustache altogether, or if you just want to get one under control, this device will do fine.  As a bonus, it also has an ear and nose trimmer that works reasonably well.  It claims to be a hair clipper, but it is no substitute for clippers designed solely for a haircut.I tested mine by letting my rather tough and thick beard grow out for a couple of weeks, then experimented on it.  This review presents what I learned from trying it out.BEARD AND MUSTACHE TRIMMINGThere are two combs you could use for this, but unless you want beard hairs longer than 1/2", you'll probably use the smaller one.  The larger one covers the same range, except it goes up to 3/4", and it is a little larger in diameter; I'll probably never use it.  Both combs slide on fairly easy once you figure out exactly how it is meant to go on by looking closely at the slots around the length gauge as put it together.  The gauge gives a reasonably effective measure, except it has numbers starting at 1, and it isn't clear how long the 1 setting is supposed to be, the minimum is said to be 3/64".  My last use was on 4, and it was shorter than I would prefer, but hey, it'll grow back.The instructions advise you to comb through the hair to be trimmed against the grain, and that's good advice.  I would further advise you to start at a setting you know will be too long, then try again a couple of notches down, and so on until you know what you want.  Eventually you'll know what you need and just set it and use it, but at first you'll want to experiment to find out what works best.I wanted my neck clean-shaven, and it had been more than a week since I shaved it.  I used the trimmer without a comb to cut it down to size and had no problems with it snagging or cutting skin, but be careful if you do this, because there is not much guard left for the moving blade.My beard is tough, and yet this trimmer had no trouble getting through it.  There is also a "Turbo" button that makes the motor run faster (and presumably run the battery down faster); I found I did not need to use it.MINI-SHAVERThe trimmer head turns a quarter turn to be removed, and the other cutters go on the same in reverse. I tried the mini-shaver to define lines around my beard, and between my nose and my mustache, for cleaning up.  It worked fine for this, but did not result in as clean a shave as my three-head Norelco shaver, not even close.  I also tried it on my neck, where my beard is toughest, and it worked poorly for shaving that clean.Don't assume that this device will replace a good shaver, if you have much of a beard that you want to shave cleanly.EAR AND NOSE TRIMMERThe device worked well for trimming hair in these places.  The instructions advise you not to insert it in your nose more than about a quarter of an inch.  This is especially important for the ear canal, because the device is rather loud when used there.  The trimmer also works well for trimming those odd hairs that show up on the edge of ears of middle-aged men; you can move it around your ears without worry of snagging skin, and it will catch most of them.There are small, battery-operated ear and nose trimmers that are much quieter (due to a rotary motor) and work a little better.BODY HAIR?The instructions say this device is for face and neck.  Naturally, it can be used for any hair anywhere, but it is not ideal as a personal trimmer.  The tips of the combs can catch on your skin, as they are a bit sharp.  A file might help take the edge off.  Also, don't use too short a setting, as the metal teeth that move back and forth are not adequately protected from snagging actual skin.  With common sense, it does work, but they probably did not call it a personal trimmer for legal reasons.USAGE NOTESTravelers will appreciate having a charger / adapter that works on 220V; not all trimmers support dual voltage (actually, all voltages from 100-240VAC).The click-stops for the trimmer combs allow the adjustment to stay put, because they fit snugly, unlike trimmers I have used in the past.The Turbo button makes the motor run perhaps 50% faster.  I didn't need that, but maybe it helps in some situations, such as using the mini-shaver.I'm not sure what "100% water RESISTANT" even means, because water resistant means that it is not 100% waterproof.  In any case, it looks safe to disassemble it and rinse it off in running warm water, but I would not immerse the entire unit or use it in the shower.BOTTOM LINEFour stars means "I Like It."  It has all the features I need as a beard and mustache trimmer.  It will be helpful for cleaning up after using a conventional hair clipper for haircuts.  The nose and ear attachment works well enough.  There is nothing to complain about here, but it also does not excel: it simply does most jobs it was designed for reasonably well.  It won't replace having a shaver and AC-powered hair clippers for those jobs.

A comedy about a Seder Supper?  Seems unlikely to be all that funny, but this one surprised me.  Not just for Jewish people, but anyone who has a clue about what a Seder Supper is may enjoy it.  Some of the humor refers to Jewish culture, but some is clever family funny stuff.Essentially, we have a family of wildly different "types" trying to have the traditional family ceremony/supper for Passover, and a lot of unexpected stuff comes up or goes down.  As the guests arrive, we see that the family is so full of extreme types as to be unrealistic, but that is part of what makes it funny.  It also has some of the most outrageously SURREAL footage (really!) I have seen in a long time.

These songs are bad remakes, not the original artists. They sound nothing like the original.  The album lists the names of the original artists, and it isn't them performing.1. Listen to "I'm a Man", supposedly by Spencer Davis Group: the singer is clearly NOT Steve Winwood (who sang the original version), and the backup band sounds like an 80s New Wave group with synth instead of organ.2. "Winchester Cathedral" is a different singer; he's not even using a megaphone as in the original.3. Herman (of Herman's Hermits) also has a distinctive voice, and this isn't him singing "Mrs. Brown You've Got A Lovely Daughter" or "I'm Henry The VIII I Am"; sounds like an 80s band.

How do you write a book about all that NYC has to offer?  It's a daunting task, and the authors here chose to pare it down to size by describing most (not all) of Manhattan, only, which represents 7.6% of the area of the city proper (calculated from numbers on Wikipedia) for all but 8 pages of the book.  Granted, the back cover says "Experience the best of New York City", and for many people, that means Manhattan.  And ok, it does actually have 4 pages each on Queens and Brooklyn.  For me, having been to Manhattan a few times, I am more interested in exploring other boroughs, and off-the-beaten path places that won't be found in a book like this.This book is called "Discover New York City," and the "Discover" series should be seen as a new breed of LP books, very different in purpose and design from traditional LP guides.  This isn't a bad thing.  Sometimes it helps to have lots of nice color photos to help decide where you want to go, and this book would be especially helpful for early research.  However, it is not going to have the depth of information found in the traditional LP guides.It also does not replace the original guide series, which is still published and updated, and you may indeed want to bring the New York City Guide with you for more details.  As a comparison point, the Lonely Planet New York City Guide has 448 pages, far fewer photos, and less white space, compared to this "Discover" guide with 312 pages and lots of photos.  What this means is that the City Guide has more information in text form, but the Discover guide shows you what things look like.  Fortunately, you have a choice of either or both.New Yorkers could argue for days about what should be listed but is not, but I would argue that what is listed I this book is a lot of the best known attractions that bring tourists to the city.The book includes a pull-out map.BOTTOM LINE: 4 stars, "I like it."  For someone who has never been there and wants to pick out highlights to optimize their time, the presentation of NYC in this book will speed up that task compared to a traditional travel guide, but it is not intended as a replacement for the latter.

I moved to the Boston area 33 years ago, and have spent a lot of weekends and vacation time exploring New England on most forms of transportation, including driving.  I have to agree with the choices of places to visit outlined in this book,but I also have to quibble with some of what they say.WHAT THE BOOK IS, WHO IT'S FORWhile published by Lonely Planet, this is considerably different from LP guides.  There is a nearly exclusive focus on places to visit that are accessible by car.  However, you may still wish to consult with conventional LP guides for information on lodging, eating, transportation, and the many excellent places worth visiting that are NOT in this book.I would recommend the book both for people coming to New England as tourists, as well as New Englanders who are so used to being here that you have forgotten what a nice place it is to be for weekends and vacation.  Even a business person who is driving around the area could benefit by knowing where really pleasant drives are for days when you have time to go a little out of your way to enjoy them.WHAT'S COVEREDNew England consists of Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine.  Each of these states have some of the best parts of New England to visit, making it hard to choose.  Fortunately, distances are not as great as they are in larger states.The book identifies 8 of the 32 driving tours as "Classic", which are defined as those top iconic sites, top activities, and unique New England experiences.  I can't argue with their choices among the 32 tours described in the book, but there are "Classic" tours, especially in metro Boston, that are not discussed (see "What's NOT Covered").NOTE: the photo of the cover shows what might have been a pre-edit version of the cover, incorrectly stating there are "37 Amazing Road Trips".  The copy I received says 32, so perhaps five were cut.The overview section also identifies top places to visit by various interests you may have: seafood, outdoor activities, beer and wine, art and architecture, history, and wildlife.New England is unique in having wonderful beach and seashore options, mountain drives, and all manner of culture within a relatively small area of USA.  There is a tangible New England feel that you can experience here, owing largely to the comparatively long history and age of the cities and towns you'll find here (of course, the age does not compare to many places on other continents).  And this book does manage to capture most of the top reasons to visit.While the book does cover some lodging and dining options, but not to the extent that a "real" travel guide would.  You don't necessarily need to get a full travel guide for more options, as there are many online resources to help you find places and read reviews (TripAdvisor, Yelp) or even book reservations.  Don't forget to consult Wikipedia for in-depth coverage on your candidate visits.WHAT'S NOT COVEREDThe back cover advises you to "Discover the freedom of the open road".  Well, it isn't always all that open.  Because New England is a popular place to visit and live, and because of the age of the roads (especially within cities and towns), there is traffic to be dealt with.  During high season, you will certainly not feel all alone in your exploration.In particular, Metro Boston is essentially skipped - it gets a two-page mention with few highlights called out, though there is a very nice plug for the LP Boston City Guide which, to be fair, is probably worth having for a serious visit.  The reason for downplaying Boston is obvious: it is best explored on foot, via mass transit, or in taxis, and NOT driving a car.  Without a GPS, it is nearly impossible for a visitor to navigate.  Within some areas, especially downtown Boston and other city centers, it can be difficult or very expensive to park.When it comes to some of the interest groups the book identifies - in particular, seafood, beer and wine, art and architecture, and history, Boston has the very best.  For history, you can't beat a day walking the Freedom Trail, which includes Paul Revere's House (it's genuine) and the USS Constitution.  For seafood, there's nothing like Legal Seafoods (on the high end) or the classic No Name Restaurant on Boston's Fish Pier (on the budget end).  For beer, in Boston you can visit a Sam Adams Brewery.  For art,  Boston has Museum of Fine Art, the Gardiner Museum, and even the Museum of Bad Art.  For architecture, Copley Square and Harvard Square are only two of the major places to see.Cambridge's Harvard Yard does get a brief mention in the "Ivy League" tour (which, oddly, is grouped with New Hampshire), though half of their words are spent describing the relatively unimportant statue of John Harvard, which they refer to cynically as the "focal point" and as the "statue of three lies," one of which they say is that the statue is not of him.  While that is true, Wikipedia says that the reason is that because he had a brief life that ended in 1638, the 1884 sculptor did not know what Harvard looked like, and had to improvise using another model.  Wikipedia does a better job explaining the truth around this legend.Page 18 has a nice picture of Harvard's distinctive Memorial Hall.  Unfortunately, they don't tell you the name of the building in case you'd like to visit it, and it's also not in Harvard Yard, which is where the tour advises you to go; rather, it is just north of it, across the street.Being a big city, Metro Boston also caters to many other interests you won't find by driving around New England - live music, nightlife of all kinds (including LGBT), ethnic cuisines, and any number of special interests and hobbies.There are many non-car activities listed I this book, but not covering Boston can be forgiven because it really is not a place you want to drive around.  Still, if you have never seen New England's most famous city, it would be worth budgeting part of your visit, for example before you pick up a rented car, or a few days before you leave.WHAT'S NOT QUITE RIGHTFall foliage is seen in countless photos of New England countryside.  However, there is no specific advice on how to experience it, and it is not even listed in the index (except in reference to a parade), although there is a Fall Foliage tour as one of the 32 covered in the book.The problem is that the peak foliage is brief, and some years it is great, other years you could come and wonder what all the fuss is about.  Although some trees start to turn in August even in Boston, "real" foliage season would be mid to late September in the north, until first week or so of November in the south.  There is lots of advice that may help if you search for "how to predict fall foliage in New England" (without quotes).The book says that high season runs from May through August.  To my way of thinking, it runs from mid-June or July 1 to Labor Day, and again in the region-specific foliage season.General weather predictions for New England are always suspect, but the book is not accurate in my opinion.  It says July and August are hot and humid.  In fact, in an average year, there will be a total of 14 days where you might really wish you had an air conditioner at night, but these "dog days" can also happen in June, and certainly we do not get them for all of July and August.  Most of the time temperatures will be less than 90F and temporary humidity around rainy spells.  They don't mention that we get a fair amount of rain - not every day, and not always all day - in May, early June, and September, but that rain can and does happen unpredictably year-round.They also don't mention the rare but not impossible snow in late April or early May, or even before Halloween.  In describing winter driving as "perilous", that applies only during and immediately after the occasional winter storms, which vary a lot in frequency and intensity from year to year.  Winter can be a wonderful time to visit natural areas, especially seashores.  Late February and March can be sunny and beautiful (though sometimes chilly) between periods of snow and rain.Page 225 (in the New Hampshire section!) states that Cambridge's Harvard Square exudes energy, creativity, and nonconformity.  They tell you to go for the bookstores and used record stores.  Unfortunately, this describes Harvard Square as it once was, but those days are over, thanks to new owners of the real estate and higher rent.  They used to say that Cambridge had as many book stores as Somerville had pizza parlous, and that was once true, but sadly, most book stores have closed in the wake of online book shops.  There still are some used record stores, mainly around, not in, Harvard Square.  The spirit of energy, creativity, and nonconformity is now found (to a lesser extent than the glory days of Harvard Square) in Davis Square, two stops north on the Red Line in Somerville.Finally, Lonely Planet is famous for its sometimes unrealistic advice on environmentalism.  This book, encouraging you to explore by car, flies in the face of the usual LP dogma as they advise you to "rev up your engine" (which is neither useful nor good for the environment).WHAT'S JUST GOOD ENOUGHThe maps are good enough to give you a rough idea of where to go, but there is no substitute for a good map site (like google maps) and a GPS, which is essential for driving in New England.  The rhetoric is written like marketing in a tour brochure, just a bit too much snake oil and not enough fact, but it suffices for the level of information found here.Tip: if you have a day with extra time, use a GPS and try selecting your destination and using an option for "shortest distance" rather than "shortest time".  I did this traveling from the heart of the Adirondacks (NY) to my home in Metro Boston, and it took me on the most amazing tour of southern Vermont.  Also, have a look at roadsideamerica dot com for some offbeat but interesting attractions along the way (I have no affiliation except as a user).The many places worth visiting really are the highlights of New England, but I have to admit that I am very pleased that they omit many of my very favorite places, which are not far from what they describe but require a bit more research or exploration to find.BOTTOM LINE: Four stars, "I Like It."  It is a useful book.  The many quibbles I have quoted herein are natural for a region that has more opinions than people living or visiting it, and do not detract in a major way from the value of the book.  The content fits the title reasonably well, even if the car is not always your best friend, especially in Boston.

I was pleasantly surprised by this album, which represents a reunion of the "real" Gong.  They put a lot of effort into the songwriting and recording, and the results hark back nicely to You and other classics, while having an updated sound.  Clearly Daevid Allen has ideas in his head that could not be realized with the technology of those days, or even maybe today's, but this album comes closer.  There is a wider range of styles of music than the Radio Gnome albums.At 75 minutes, this is what we used to call a "double album" (because it would take two vinyl discs to contain that much music).  Ironically, with that much music, they could have trimmed a bit and made a stronger album overall, but I guess I'm glad they gave it all to us.Aside from Allen, it's great to hear many of the original members.  It was obvious that some of the guitar work was from Steve Hillage, whose skill has advanced considerably from when I last heard his guitar work, though he was great back in the earlier albums.  He has worked as producer, too, and is probably responsible for the polished sound.Shakti Yoni (Gilli Smyth) is back and featured on a couple of interesting experimental tracks.  I laughed when she punned on modern technology with the line about looking on your hard drive and finding a PHP (an obvious reference to the "Radio Gnome Trilogy" from the 80s).  She sounds older, which one would expect, but I was shocked to read on Wikipedia that she is 79 years old! And still doing psychedelic and witching vocals!  You go, girl!Four stars means "I Like It".  Some tracks are very good, others just ok, but overall, it's a great update that recalls the earlier style yet gives it a new sound.  Maybe 4.5 stars.  I may revise my rating after a few more listens.

PROSUSB plug integral to unit; no need for a separate cableAccurate measurements of steps taken during a walkReasonably long lasting user-replaceable CR2032 battery (lasts about 6 months)Can display data from past 7 days, and store up to 22 daysFor PC & Mac desktop/laptop computersCONSWeb-resident management software site was down; without it, there is no data management or analysisI have been using the Omron HJ-720IT pedometer for a few years. I have replaced one that was lost, another that went through the washer and was never the same after.This new HJ-323U pedometer from Omron is different in some useful ways, but does not offer much in the way of new capabilities. There are two aspects of the better Omron pedometers: the hardware component - which you carry when you are walking - and the software product, which stores and analyzes the results.HARDWAREThe HJ-720IT was oval in shape, and a bit thicker. The new HJ-323U pedometer is rectangular, sort of like a large thumb drive or pack of gum. A cap comes off of one end to reveal a standard USB A plug connector that fits most laptops. There are three other buttons and a display.The device works in a standalone fashion to record the number of steps you take in one day. This count is always accurate. It also has some internal calculations that approximate the distance you walked, and the calories you burned. These two are based on two setttings: the length of the stride in your walk, and your body weight.The calculations are only approximations. People do not walk in consistent strides, so the total distance won't be exact. It will be most exact for exercise walking where you seek to set a certain pace and stride. The other calculation, number of calories burned, is probably based on walking on flat land; the device has no way of knowing that you might be climbing a hill, for example, which could substantially boost the number of calories you are burning.The device is intended to measure steps, only. If you ride a bike with the device in your pocket, you will get some measure that does not mean much in terms of steps, distance, or calories.It does make a distinction between "aerobic walking" and all steps taken in a walk. "Aerobic" means that you went non-stop for at least 10 minutes, at least 60 steps per minute. That may not be enough to make it really aerobic, but it's not too far off.Essentially, from a hardware-only perspective, this is not very different from the earlier HJ-720IT. Having a built-in USB plug, instead of requiring a USB A to USB B mini cable, is convenient.It would have been nice if the device included a rechargeable battery that would recharge when plugged into a USB, but it still uses the same button-style battery.SOFTWAREThe HJ-720IT includes software for Windows at least, not sure about Mac. The HJ-323U takes a different approach: it uses Web-based software to take your statistics from the device and manages and analyzes them on the Web. The Windows software of the predecessor was clunky at best, occasionally getting itself into a state where it could not load from the device without resetting the file, losing all your history.Personally, I don't see any value at all to having Web-resident software, and I do see some disadvantages. In particular, you obviously have to be on the Web, and the Web software needs to be up and running. At any point in the future, Omron could decide that they are done supporting this device. At least with the Windows software of the HJ-720IT, you can use it forever as long as you find a computer that can run it, and the required batteries.As I write this review, the omronfitness.com Web site, which has the application, has been down. It has been a few hours. Although I have used the pedometer to gather a week of data, I can't comment yet on the software. I will update this review after it is up and I have used it.I guess they are trying to take advantage of the social networking fad. I would not bore my Facebook friends with daily walking records. I suppose that you might find benefit in having a walking group to share mutual support, and this would help with that. It is likely that having the software Web-based would mean that they could support more platforms, such as Mac , tablets, and phones, with one programming effort, saving them money.The specs say "Accessible on PC & Mac desktop/laptop computers; viewable on tablets & smart phones". I interpret this to mean that you can upload data only on the PC and Mac, but you can view uploaded data on a tablet or smart phone.UPDATE 3/10/2013: the Web site that has the required drivers and does the upload and display was down for at least three days, pointing out an obvious problem with relying on the Web. I prefer to have local software for use whenever I want it.Once it was up, I uploaded, and it showed me a simple graph based on data recorded over time. I prefer the stacked bar chart provided with the local software provided with HJ-720IT. However, that unit did not support the Mac, so if you use a Mac, this one is probably better for you. Seeing the software working did not impress me enough to make me raise my review from 3 stars.BOTTOM LINEThree stars (It's ok), may change based on how good the Web resident software. I would prefer that it worked with software installed on my PC. If you have the earlier HJ-720IT(C) model, I see no compelling reason to buy this newer one, so far. If you have neither and use Windows, I would recommend the HJ-720IT(C) model. If you use Mac, this one supports that platform.

NOTE: this particular listing is overpriced. Look elsewhere to find the identical unit available for under $40.PROSUSB plug integral to unit; no need for a separate cableAccurate measurements of steps taken during a walkReasonably long lasting user-replaceable CR2032 battery (lasts about 6 months)Can display data from past 7 days, and store up to 22 daysFor PC & Mac desktop/laptop computersCONSWeb-resident management software site was down; without it, there is no data management or analysisI have been using the Omron HJ-720IT pedometer for a few years. These two are based on two setttings: the length of the stride in your walk, and your body weight.The calculations are only approximations. People do not walk in consistent strides, so the total distance won't be exact. It will be most exact for exercise walking where you seek to set a certain pace and stride. The other calculation, number of calories burned, is probably based on walking on flat land; the device has no way of knowing that you might be climbing a hill, for example, which could substantially boost the number of calories you are burning.The device is intended to measure steps, only. If you ride a bike with the device in your pocket, you will get some measure that does not mean much in terms of steps, distance, or calories.It does make a distinction between "aerobic walking" and all steps taken in a walk. "Aerobic" means that you went non-stop for at least 10 minutes, at least 60 steps per minute. That may not be enough to make it really aerobic, but it's not too far off.Essentially, from a hardware-only perspective, this is not very different from the earlier HJ-720IT. Having a built-in USB plug, instead of requiring a USB A to USB B mini cable, is convenient.It would have been nice if the device included a rechargeable battery that would recharge when plugged into a USB, but it still uses the same button-style battery.SOFTWAREThe HJ-720IT includes software for Windows at least, not sure about Mac. The HJ-323U takes a different approach: it uses Web-based software to take your statistics from the device and manages and analyzes them on the Web. The Windows software of the predecessor was clunky at best, occasionally getting itself into a state where it could not load from the device without resetting the file, losing all your history.Personally, I don't see any value at all to having Web-resident software, and I do see some disadvantages. In particular, you obviously have to be on the Web, and the Web software needs to be up and running. At any point in the future, Omron could decide that they are done supporting this device. At least with the Windows software of the HJ-720IT, you can use it forever as long as you find a computer that can run it, and the required batteries.As I write this review, the omronfitness.com Web site, which has the application, has been down. It has been a few hours. Although I have used the pedometer to gather a week of data, I can't comment yet on the software. I will update this review after it is up and I have used it.I guess they are trying to take advantage of the social networking fad. I would not bore my Facebook friends with daily walking records. I suppose that you might find benefit in having a walking group to share mutual support, and this would help with that. It is likely that having the software Web-based would mean that they could support more platforms, such as Mac , tablets, and phones, with one programming effort, saving them money.The specs say "Accessible on PC & Mac desktop/laptop computers; viewable on tablets & smart phones". I interpret this to mean that you can upload data only on the PC and Mac, but you can view uploaded data on a tablet or smart phone.UPDATE 3/10/2013: the Web site that has the required drivers and does the upload and display was down for at least three days, pointing out an obvious problem with relying on the Web. I prefer to have local software for use whenever I want it.Once it was up, I uploaded, and it showed me a simple graph based on data recorded over time. I prefer the stacked bar chart provided with the local software provided with HJ-720IT. However, that unit did not support the Mac, so if you use a Mac, this one is probably better for you. Seeing the software working did not impress me enough to make me raise my review from 3 stars.BOTTOM LINEThree stars (It's ok), may change based on how good the Web resident software. I would prefer that it worked with software installed on my PC. If you have the earlier HJ-720IT(C) model, I see no compelling reason to buy this newer one, so far. If you have neither and use Windows, I would recommend the HJ-720IT(C) model. If you use Mac, this one supports that platform.

PROSUSB plug integral to unit; no need for a separate cableAccurate measurements of steps taken during a walkReasonably long lasting user-replaceable CR2032 battery (lasts about 6 months)Can display data from past 7 days, and store up to 22 daysFor PC & Mac desktop/laptop computersCONSWeb-resident management software site was down; without it, there is no data management or analysisI have been using the Omron HJ-720IT pedometer for a few years. I have replaced one that was lost, another that went through the washer and was never the same after.This new HJ-323U pedometer from Omron is different in some useful ways, but does not offer much in the way of new capabilities. There are two aspects of the better Omron pedometers: the hardware component - which you carry when you are walking - and the software product, which stores and analyzes the results.HARDWAREThe HJ-720IT was oval in shape, and a bit thicker. The new HJ-323U pedometer is rectangular, sort of like a large thumb drive or pack of gum. A cap comes off of one end to reveal a standard USB A plug connector that fits most laptops. There are three other buttons and a display.The device works in a standalone fashion to record the number of steps you take in one day. This count is always accurate. It also has some internal calculations that approximate the distance you walked, and the calories you burned. These two are based on two setttings: the length of the stride in your walk, and your body weight.The calculations are only approximations. People do not walk in consistent strides, so the total distance won't be exact. It will be most exact for exercise walking where you seek to set a certain pace and stride. The other calculation, number of calories burned, is probably based on walking on flat land; the device has no way of knowing that you might be climbing a hill, for example, which could substantially boost the number of calories you are burning.The device is intended to measure steps, only. If you ride a bike with the device in your pocket, you will get some measure that does not mean much in terms of steps, distance, or calories.It does make a distinction between "aerobic walking" and all steps taken in a walk. "Aerobic" means that you went non-stop for at least 10 minutes, at least 60 steps per minute. That may not be enough to make it really aerobic, but it's not too far off.Essentially, from a hardware-only perspective, this is not very different from the earlier HJ-720IT. The Windows software of the predecessor was clunky at best, occasionally getting itself into a state where it could not load from the device without resetting the file, losing all your history.Personally, I don't see any value at all to having Web-resident software, and I do see some disadvantages. In particular, you obviously have to be on the Web, and the Web software needs to be up and running. At any point in the future, Omron could decide that they are done supporting this device. At least with the Windows software of the HJ-720IT, you can use it forever as long as you find a computer that can run it, and the required batteries.As I write this review, the omronfitness.com Web site, which has the application, has been down. It has been a few hours. Although I have used the pedometer to gather a week of data, I can't comment yet on the software. I will update this review after it is up and I have used it.I guess they are trying to take advantage of the social networking fad. I would not bore my Facebook friends with daily walking records. I suppose that you might find benefit in having a walking group to share mutual support, and this would help with that. It is likely that having the software Web-based would mean that they could support more platforms, such as Mac , tablets, and phones, with one programming effort, saving them money.The specs say "Accessible on PC & Mac desktop/laptop computers; viewable on tablets & smart phones". I interpret this to mean that you can upload data only on the PC and Mac, but you can view uploaded data on a tablet or smart phone.UPDATE 3/10/2013: the Web site that has the required drivers and does the upload and display was down for at least three days, pointing out an obvious problem with relying on the Web. I prefer to have local software for use whenever I want it.Once it was up, I uploaded, and it showed me a simple graph based on data recorded over time. I prefer the stacked bar chart provided with the local software provided with HJ-720IT. However, that unit did not support the Mac, so if you use a Mac, this one is probably better for you. Seeing the software working did not impress me enough to make me raise my review from 3 stars.BOTTOM LINEThree stars (It's ok), may change based on how good the Web resident software. I would prefer that it worked with software installed on my PC. If you have the earlier HJ-720IT(C) model, I see no compelling reason to buy this newer one, so far. If you have neither and use Windows, I would recommend the HJ-720IT(C) model. If you use Mac, this one supports that platform.

My 20 year old is loving this as his everyday watch (his dress watch is his grandfather's Lucien Picard gold watch). It looks perfect on his wrist: he is 6'2 and an average weight for his height and age. He especially likes it that he can wear in at the beach and in the water.Would make an ideal graduation gift or new job congratulations gift from a parent or grandparent.

You get what you pay for. I was really concerned when I got a look at the pill that it would make me nauseous but not at all.  No negative aftereffects and easy to swallow on an empty or a full stomach. I did take it with 4 ounces of water to reduce a chance of stomach upset.

Readers who appreciate literary non-fiction and fiction will equally enjoy this collection. If you have also read the author's memoir Let Me Finish  published 9 years ago you come away with a deeper appreciation for the author and the man.You can always read the title piece originally published in The New Yorker dated 2014/02/17 and still available on line - once you do you will have no question whether to buy the book.

I like the presentation. It opens with an government run nuclear reactor accident and the backstories that led up to the event are revealed to the reader. Most interesting and riveting to me was the very common story of a young marriage falling apart when the couple is taken out of the environment where they fell in love and are thrown a burden of adult responsibilities: jobs, children, money -  and how even a solid relationship will splinter when people continue to mature in their 20's.A well done debut.The basis for the novel is fascinating: January 3, 1961 a Power Plant in Idaho was destroyed after a control rod was removed incorrectly. Killed were Army Specialists, John Byrnes, age 25 and Richard McKinley, age 22, and Navy Electricians Mate Richard Legg, age 25. Byrnes (the reactor operator) had lifted the rod and caused the excursion, Legg (the shift supervisor) was standing on top of the reactor vessel and was impaled and pinned to the ceiling, and McKinley, the trainee who stood nearby, was later found alive by rescuers. The men died from physical trauma however, the radiation gave them no chance of survival.  There is no record of what the technicians were attempting to do in the moments leading up to the explosion, the 2 year  investigation posited several theories:(1) sabotage/suicide by one of the operators(2) operator error

The author lost this adult reader with "a world filled with human-size rats" lol - the 10 year old in the family thought they were pretty cool. I was concerned that the large cast of characters would be a stumbling block for a younger reader but she said no.New York City residents 13-year-old Max and her 10-year-old brother, Carter, join their father on a business trip to Germany, specifically to the village made famous by the tale THE PIED PIPER of Hamelin. Carter is thrilled, Max is not.A clever rendering and continuation of the 700 year old cautionary tale brought vividly to to life for Max and Carter.
could not be happier - easy to use, easy to clean and perfect rice every time.
twice the size I thought it would be
although wrapped in bubble wrap the lack of a sturdy box led to it's demise DOA.

I greW up in northern New Jersey and never heard of Lily Dale, NY. The author grew up near Lily Dale, N.Y. and she captured it vividly. Incorporated in 1879 as Cassadaga Lake Free Association, "a camp and meeting place for Spiritualists and Freethinkers". The name was changed to Lily Dale Assembly in 1906. The village is founded to "further the science, philosophy, & religion of Spiritualism". dvd No One Dies in Lily Dale No One Dies in Lily Dale  Lily Dale: The Town That Talks to the Dead (Plus)Bella Jordan and her son Max intend to deliver a kitty to one of the residents and move on. Unfortunately the resident is now dead, murdered. This sets of Bella's need to solve the murder before she and Max can move on. The wit and the author's way with bringing characters to life was oerfect for me.FYI - this title should not be mistaken for the Young Adult Lily Dale series written by the author in 2009:AWAKENING She may be able to see the future, but she needs to know what happened to her past. Calla thought that her boyfriend breaking up with her in a text message was the worst thing that could ever happen to her. But just two weeks later, her mother died in a freak accident, and life as she knew it was completely over. With her father heading to California for a new job, they decide that Calla should spend a few weeks with the grandmother she barely knows while he gets them set up on the west coast.To Callas shock, her mothers hometown of Lily Dale is almost entirely populated by spiritualists who can communicate with the deadand her grandmother is one of them. Suddenly, the fact that her mother never talked about her past takes on more mysterious overtones. The longer she stays in town, the stranger things become, as Calla starts to experience unusual and unsettling events that lead her to wonder whether she has inherited her grandmothers unique gift. Is it this gift that is making her suspect that her mothers death was more than an accident, or is it just an overactive imagination? Staying in Lily Dale is the only way to uncover the truth. But will Calla be able to deal with what she learns about her mother's past and her own future?BELIEVING: sequel to Awakening. After her tumultuous summer in Lily Dale, Calla has decided to stay, knowing there is still much more to learn about her mother's untimely death. As school begins at Lily Dale High, Calla finallys tarts to feel at home in her new town. Despite her excitement over the affections of Blue Slayton and her growing feelings for Jacy Bly, Calla can't ignore the urgency of her latest visions. Someone is desperately trying to contact her again-this time because the killer, whose victim she helped locate, has kidnapped another girl and may be after Calla next. Unless she learns to trust the warnings she's receiving from the spirit world, Calla could be in serious danger.CONNECTING:  Will a shocking secret change Calla's life forever? Although Lily Dale is a world apart from her old life in sunny Florida, Calla has finally accepted her ability to communicate with the Other Side. But the person Calla is most desperate to connect with is the one spirit whose energy she can't seem to feel anywhere: her mother. It seems like a lifetime has passed since her mother's death, and she's still no closer to finding out the truth. But as she and Jacy grow closer, his visions show Calla in serious danger. Together they must try to make sense of the signs they've been receiving from the Spirit world-and quickly. As long as her mother's killer is still on the loose, Calla will never be safe.Making her way back to Lily Dale with even more twists and turns, bestselling author Wendy Corsi Staub will have readers on edge in the third book of her thrilling paranormal series.DISCOVERING: Calla finally knows the "who" behind her mother's death but she still doesn't understand the "why." Could it involve the half sibling her mother kept secret for decades? Unwilling to share her recent discovery with anyone, including her father who just moved to town, Calla must call on the spirit world once again for help in finding her missing sibling and the final clues behind her mother's death. Will Calla's journey bring the closure she seeks?

SPF 15. I have been using this (4 ounces) for 30 days and no negative reactions (no rash or itch, etc). After 21 years living on the central Florida Gulf coast my 50 year old skin loves this stuff, even when this 50 year old brain has no idea what the active ingredients AVOBENZONE 3% OCTISALATE 5% OCTOCRYLENE 5%  are.FYI this product is so new that I couldn't find it on the Garnier website to leave a review.

It was a real easy setup (I did it although I am sure he would have liked to - lol). He has it in his college dorm room and doesn't take up alot of space. The quality of output is what he is looking for. He has 2 marketing courses this year and for the last 30 days the Canon wireless has met all his needs.I'll be curious to see when he will need need replacement ink. Canon was my first color ink printer back in 2003, I had bought it at the recommendation of the technician who created my in home office (and it was still going strong in 2013 when donated to our local school).
I wanted to enjoy this novel so much and I knew from the book blurb that it was the kind of book I enjoy, and I would have if, the two leads didn't leave me cold.

Makes all the other paper towels seem like they are tissue paper. After trying these I can't imagine ordering anything else ever again. Super thick and absorbent. I only needed 2 after washing my hands instead of 5 or 6 with our previous paper towels.Keeper!

If you are itching for Jack Reacher to reach a whole new level of violence than this will be for you. The author has a knack for dialogue and is a huge best seller in his home of New Zealand . His publishers asked him to set his new novel in the US. He eagerly and successfully took on the challenge. I have been to New Mexico 3 times in the last 7 years, and he captured it vividly for my reading. This is a non-stop-excitement thriller that No Country For Old Men would be proud of.Marshall Grade  is ex-NYPD living in Santa Fe New Mexico in the Federal Witness Protection program after an epic failure. The safe house the government has him in he sublets to an ex-con (and right there I am thinking Felix's days are numbered). To fill the hours he uses his skills (theft, narcotics, intimidation) looking for MIA Alice Ray. Wayne Banister aka Dallas Man, is offered a contract to take out his employer, mob boss "The Patriarch". He also goes after Marshall Grade. Leon is a drug trafficker who no longer has the $3 million he should have and like any sociopath will perpetuate any horror to get it back. And the list goes on.To paraphrase my favorite TV crime show of 20+ years: In the criminal system, there are  wo separate yet equally violent groups: the justice department who take on the criminals and the criminals who produce stomach turning horror. These are their stories.

As a child, grandchild and great child of New Englanders I had no idea how special Vermont is - lol.  Located in mountains of northern Vermont bordering Canada is an area Vermonters refer to as 'Gods Kingdom' aka the Northeast Kingdom of Vermont, encompassing Essex, Orleans, and Caledonia counties.A lovely review in the Washington Post lead me to the book.The novel reveals it's story in episodic chapters, very charming, yet realistic and I clearly need to make Vermont a stop one day. I really can't compare it to any any other novelist, perhaps if English novelist RF Delderfield wrote in this style his stories come closest.I have read any others of the author's work but I will be:Disappearances (1977)Where the Rivers Flow North (1978)Marie Blythe (1983)A Stranger in the Kingdom (1989)Northern Borders (1994)North Country (nonfiction) (1997)The Fall of the Year (1999)The True Account (2003)Waiting for Teddy Williams (2004)On Kingdom Mountain (2007)Walking to Gatlinburg (2010)The Great Northern Express (2012)God's Kingdom (2015)

The title had me at hello and it took me 9 days to read this 691 page novel - I usually start and finish a book a day but this was the first novel I read by Carolyn Chute,http://www.amazon.com/Beans-Egypt-Maine-Carolyn-Chute/dp/0899193625/ref=tmm_pap_title_1?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=,  I and I fund it so rich in everything, so original that I would read and then want to reread to make sure I grasped it enough to move on. My being a child of New Englanders was very little help, living in a rural part of the mid-Atlantic did help either. The author and her spouse live as much off the grid as they can and it is her perspective that I was so eager to learn about, almost in an anthropological way. I am truly surprised to see so few reviews of this title.

The slave trade and post-Revolutionary North Carolina. Asa is the master of his plantation, his daughter, Helen,  married a pirate, John, then died birthing their daughter Tabitha. Tabitha dies of yellow fever 10 years later.Bleak.Flashback to happiers time we see John and Helen in love. At the same time Asas slave, Moll, who became Helen's "companion" when they were age 10, is is forced into marriage.And it gets bleaker.

as viewed by Wally Baker. In the midst of WW2 Wally and her mother, Stella (a doctor) live with Stella's parents (Gigi & Waldo) in their 5 story home in Brooklyn Heights. Living on another floor is Loretta, who works for the family, and her son Ham. Stella's husband and Wally's father is away at war. I would tell you more about the rest of the players and some of the back story but it was so enjoyable for me learning it all that it would take away the pleasure. This is an all too human depiction of what war does to those left behind and how callous and heartless people can be. Stella had my heart when she felt her options had run out.

I ordered this novel of the lawless turn of the century coastal lumber town in the Pacific Northwest after reading so many rave reviews. I am currently living in the same area and I was ripe to enjoy this novel. It had all the elements but the book was a real struggle to finish. Where the NYT noted the book's patient attention to even the lowest of characters, I found it a struggle to keep track of them all. Where Kirkus reviews a dense, deep and illuminating narrative, I found it a slog to get through. And I just wasn't interested in any of the characters - I don't need to like them but I should be interested. All the fabulous reviewers can't be wrong so I will hang on to try it again.

I was floundering in grasping the story for the first 100 pages and by the time things started to gel I had lost interest. Stretching from 1913 Ellis Island to the 1950s and beginning with the Russian emigre arrival to the USA and landing a job in Bridgeport Connecticut at the Remington gun manufacturing company. It is a epic and glorious love story that is neither glorious or epic.

A profile of the lead driver, Billy Fiske (an American who 8 years later was a pilot in the RAF in WW2),  the Olympics in Lake Placid, New York, and the bob sledding team and the event itself. This is probably a book best suited for history lovers who enjoy a book full of details and side stories (that would be me).

I love it. If I am headed for a meeting and want to bring my laptop this is perfect.  Enough room for the laptop, mouse, paper, pen and charger if the meeting is an all day affair. Perfect for travel when you don't want to just throw your laptop in your luggage, it offers good protection.  I also liked the feel of the materiel.

Fyi, Abingdon Press is an imprint of The United Methodist Publishing House, in operation since 1789. For more than 200 years, Abingdon Press has continued a tradition in religious publishing for crossing denominational boundaries with thought-provoking and enjoyable books. In the early 1920s, Abingdon began publishing a wide array of high-caliber academic, professional, inspirational, and life-affirming religious literature to enrich church communities across the globe. Now beginning its ninth decade, Abingdon Press has a commitment to providing the best, most effective religious publications available.The upshot being that christians probably won't find anything to object to in reading this title.The story was intriging set in 1964 and flash forwarded 50 years later. The only negative for me was more than I could handle the dialogue didn't work.  I would say try reading the sample and if you enjoy it then give it a try.

for fans of the Die Hard movies - not so much. I loved the day to day look of life as a PI and life on cargo vessel while those look for non-stop action and gripping mystery with twists and turns along the way won't find it overloaded.
I've been in banking for 34 years and the insurance industry going back 2 generations.  I was made for this novel but the characters never caught on with me.

"Evelyn has waited eighteen years for a chance to investigate" I should have guessed from this tag line that I wasn't going to be satisfied with an investigator that can wait 18 years to solve a crime.

Rowan Mundy returns to the town she grew up in with her husband & 3 college age children, and takes a teaching position in the elementary school.I can't say enough good things about this murder mystery without giving away the things I liked about it, The 100 year old unsolved Seeping Beauty murders whose identities were never solved, the 300 year scandal of the town founders that resulted in their death sentence. Suffice to say this is a taught thriller that I enjoyed immensely.

only issue is why can't they be made in the USA - we certainly have enough mills and workers. I have been using them for 4 weeks now they go through the washer and hold up. I put the white ones in with some bleach and keep them super white. They are not plush, not by a long shot, but I don't find plush works for dish 'rags'.

the 14 year old in the family did not care for the ending - he said it didn't fit with the first 140 pages. I read it first and felt that everyone got gypped -it was like a slap of realism on top of a tragedy that had potential to be terrific.Publisher's Weekly and Kirkus reviewers loved it.

31 year old Claire,  is the Felony Division Chief for the state of Florida but she isn't getting the support of police or the other lawyers in the State Attorneys office. This novel was right up my alley, and having lived in Florida the last 25 years was a bonus. there is a huge surprise half way into the novel that some readers will love while many readers of mysteries and police procedurals just will not like. I loved Claire, Rebecca, Marc, Nonie, Gertie - I have read it 3 times now and know I will read it again.I found it compulsively readable.

Why did I order this title? the opening sentence of the blurb sucked me in and I had to know the answer "When Walter Stahl was five-years-old, his mother drove away in the family's blue Volvo and never came back". Also, I had not read a graphic novel since 3rd grade and the cover captured me (even if the guy on the cover looks like something from the 1970 manual 'The Joy of Sex').Walter's Vietnamese mother with a Liberace obsession takes off one day, Walter and his father uproot the,selves and settle in Las Vegas hoping to one day locate her there. At the same time we follow his mother on her journey, including flashbacks to her childhood, and learn what led to the family being fractured.A surpising amount of death and deception for such a quirky cover and premise. And a twist that I found disappointing.

Epic, unflinchingly  and hard hitting, in the last chapters of the book the future as envisioned by the author seems all too reasonable because she captures the last 30 years so realistically. There is a  lot to like and love in this novel of a family beset with tragedy and hope but don't expect a beautiful golden story - it's been a couple decades of terrorism, war and financial ruin for this country and so it goes for this family.For those readers, like me, who did not read the two earlier titles yet, I found these summaries helpful:SOME LUCK (2014)  a powerful, engrossing new novel stretching from 1919 to 1951 the life and times of a remarkable family over three transformative decades in America. On their farm in Denby, Iowa, Rosanna and Walter Langdon abide by time-honored values that they pass on to their five wildly different children: from Frank, the handsome, willful first born, and Joe, whose love of animals and the land sustains him, to Claire, who earns a special place in her fathers heart.  Each chapter in Some Luck covers a single year, beginning in 1920, as American soldiers like Walter return home from World War I, and going up through the early 1950s, with the country on the cusp of enormous social and economic change. As the Langdons branch out from Iowa to both coasts of America, the personal and the historical merge seamlessly: one moment electricity is just beginning to power the farm, and the next a son is volunteering to fight the Nazis; later still, a girl youd seen growing up now has a little girl of her own, and you discover that your laughter and your admiration for all these lives are mixing with tears.  Some Luck delivers on everything we look for in a work of fiction. Taking us through cycles of births and deaths, passions and betrayals, among characters we come to know inside and out, it is a tour de force.EARLY WARNING (April 2015) opens in 1953 (and stretches to 1986) with the Langdon family at a crossroads. Their stalwart patriarch, Walter, who with his wife, Rosanna, sustained their farm for three decades, has suddenly died, leaving their five children, now adults, looking to the future. Only one will remain in Iowa to work the land, while the others scatter to Washington, D.C., California, and everywhere in between. As the country moves out of postWorld War II optimism through the darker landscape of the Cold War and the social and sexual revolutions of the 1960s and 70s, and then into the unprecedented wealth, for some, of the early 1980s, the Langdon children each follow a different path in a rapidly changing world. And they now have children of their own: twin boys who are best friends and vicious rivals; a girl whose rebellious spirit takes her to the notorious Peoples Temple in San Francisco; and a golden boy who drops out of college to fight in Vietnamleaving behind a secret legacy that will send shock waves through the Langdon family into the next generation. Capturing a transformative period through richly drawn characters we come to know and care deeply for,

How could I resist a Lawrence Block title with a throw back to the 1950's lurid pulp fiction cover? And a main charater with the name Doak Miller? The clincher was the author interview I found on line at 'Hollywood Soapbox' dated September 25, 2015 "INTERVIEW: Lawrence Block returns with Girl With the Deep Blue Eyes book".

Having read the author's previous books  Outrageous Acts and Everyday Rebellions: Second Edition (Owlet Book) (published the year I graduated college);  1991's Revolution From Within; 1994's Moving Beyond Words; and the 1995 literary biography by Dr. Carolyn Heilbrun The Education of a Woman: The Life of Gloria Steinem, this a personal account of the childhood, youth, a 1971 Harvard Law School equality speech that the attendees did not appear to endorse, all the way up to the iconic 1977 National Womens Conference. that shaped this feminist icon. To understand the power and magnitude of this woman and the movement she championed, in my own personal context: my mother graduated from an accredited private college in 1960, she had a better paycheck out of college than my university degreed (and equally young father) but the checking account was in his name until 1968 (and only because he landed in the hospital unable to write a check or get cash to his wife to put food on the table or pay utilities or the mortgage), and he made every financial decision in their 40+ year marriage.  Women truly were 2nd class citizens until my generation were handed equal rights (for the most part) on a platter. This insightful memoir will tell that story in the prose of a journalist that was in parts entertaining and moving.

The flagrantly gay Francis Bacon takes off for Post WW2 Tangier with his older, and rich, lover David. What follows is a hot mess of intrigue completely enjoyable to me for not knowing the first thing about the real Francis Bacon and what a hot mess he was to himself and those in his circle.THE FIRES OF LONDON (2012) A killer takes refuge in the blacked-out streets of wartime London, upending the world of one of Britains greatest painters in this chilling and captivating reimagining of the life of Francis Bacon.  Francis Bacon walks the streets of World War II London, employed as a warden for the ARP to keep watch for activities that might tip off the Axis powers. Before the war, Bacon had travelled to Berlin and Paris picking up snatches of culture from a succession of middle-aged men charmed by his young face. Known for his flamboyant personal life and expensive taste, Bacon has returned home to live with his former nannywhos also his biggest collectorin a cramped bohemian apartment.  But one night, death intrudes on his after-hours paradise. When a young man is found dead in the park, his head smashed in, Bacon and the rest of Londons demimonde realize that they have much more to fear than the faraway scream of war.THE PRISONER OF THE RIVIERA (2013): Peace has come to England and the blackout is over, but the gloom has yet to lift from London. One night, leaving a gambling club where he has run up a considerable tab, the young painter Francis Bacon, accompanied by his lover, sees a man gunned down in the street. They do what they can to stanch the flow of blood, but the Frenchman dies in the hospital. Soon afterward, Bacon receives a strange offer from the club owner: He will erase Bacons debts if the painter delivers a package to the dead mans widow, Madame Renard, on the Riviera. What gambler could resist a trip to Monte Carlo?  After handing over the parcel, Bacon learns that Madame Renard is deadand the striking young woman who accepted the delivery is an impostor. The Riviera may be lovely, but in 1945, its sun-drenched beaches can be just as dark as the back alleys of London.

Collins (1824-1889) was popular British novelist writing in the same era as Charles Dickens (n 1851, he met Dickens, and the two became close friends "We saw each other every day, and were as fond of each other as men could be."). His first novel, Antoninia, took place in ancient Rome while his greatest success,  The Women in White, made him a hugely popular author while his title, he Moonstone, is perhaps the first detective novel published in the English language.His personal was as interesting as his novels. He never married but lived in separate homes with two women, raising a family with one under an assumed name. Suffering from gout for most of his adult life he eventually became addicted to the pain killer of the , laudanum aka opium.The bio was just the right length without getting boring.

While I didn't really care for the author's earlier novel, The Aviator's Wife, I loved The Swans of Fifth Avenue. The prose and dialogue brought the era to life in such a way that history was compellingly real and immediate. This is a not to be missed title that was so compulsively readable I blissfully put my honey-do list on hold for the whole weekend.Keeper!

I read a terrific review at Publisher's Weekly so I was eager to start this novel. I have to wonder if I was reading the same book.  I thought the dialogue and the prose were both clunky. The beginning was, to me, overly implausible with laborious plotting. I can see where the author tried to bring the characters to life, but it shouldn't so obvious to the reader, it's a good effort and needs stronger editing. The best thing about it was the Minnesota setting. I am looking forward to reading his highly acclaimed debut novel THE LIFE WE BURY, a mystery thriller that garner all sorts of accolades.

Plus a Paris city-guide and a Nice city-guide.  Don't buy it for the pictures (too small and washed out) or the map (again, too small to be of any use).4 days a round trip from Arles to the coast.5 days through the Luberon and Vaucluse7 days from Monaco to St. Remy de Provence.7 days from Nimes to Vaison La Romaineplus the usual travel guide stuff:* tips from locals* places to eat and sleep* seasonal events

He truly deserved what he got, sadly he took 267 men with him, including his younger brothers, Thomas and Boston Custer. From the 2010 Pulitzer Prize in Biography author (for the life of Cornelius Vanderbilt). Nothing revisionist or redeeming here just the fully fleshed out expose of the man,  the times that created him and doomed him. This is a keeper.Decades ago I was so disappointed to learn that Civil War hero Custer (1839-1876) was not the dashing officer portrayed by Errol Flying back in 1940. My fascination remained and this biography is wonderfully compulsively readable. First off, I had no idea he died so young (36 years old). I loved the first half of the book which covers his Civil War career and touches on the politics of the time (I would have enjoyed more information of his youth and family background from the 600 page book). He was in so many epic battles:First Battle of Bull RunBattle of AntietamBattle of ChancellorsvilleBattle of GettysburgBattle of the WildernessBattle of Yellow TavernBattle of Trevilian StationSiege of PetersburgAppomattox CampaignThe book resonated with me to such a degree I am looking forward to reading .Connell, Evan S. (1984). Son Of The Morning Star.  It was interesting to learn that after Custer's widow died at age 91 on  April 4, 1933,  Frederick F. Van de Waters "Glory Hunter: A Life of General Custer" began the brought the Custer we have come to know to the 20th century.

The unit I received has brown accents and the top of the handle is missing which is why it was probably only $3.00 on sale.  I've decided to just replace the handle with an extra one from a broom I'm not using.  Its just so annoying to buy things and find out they are defective and/or missing parts.  Not worth it to return it.  The mop head is large enough for a large area which is the only reason I'm keeping it.  Its much larger than a regular swiffer and the pad is more durable too.

This picnic cooler was a LOT larger than I expected, which is a good thing.  It looks like a small cube on the product page, so to my surprise, it fits more items than I thought.  I plan to use this for byob and table setting for potlucks.  I also added a set of retractable hotdog and marshmallow sticks for campfires/grills.There is enough room inside to add one of those 7" cheese boards with the tools (stored inside).  I have one I purchased here on amazon at this link. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0034A8HKI?keywords=brie%20cheese%20board&qid=1447702399&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1As some other reviewers have indicated, the access door on the top is marvelous.  No need in unzipping the entire top to access your wine bottle or whatever you need to grab on that side.In my opinion, this is a very good investment, because you will use it sooner or later, and its versatile.  Not like those old fashion picnic baskets that most people seldom use these days.  At least this one can be used for many occasions, even if you don't need to use the entire place setting but just the wine glasses, and some cheese and crackers.  These would make great gifts too!

These pants are quite low in the back, so make sure you plan to wear a long tailed shirt for when you bend over.  These run smaller, but the at least the inseam was okay.  I'm 5'4 and they fit perfect.  But, the fit around the hips and waist is just weird.  I'm only keeping them because the price was extremely low compared to any other retailer.  The fabric is soft, but a lint collector so be careful what shirt/top you pair with these.  Overall, I'm giving this a 3 star rating because there's just too many annoying things about these pants for an average sized female, but if you're really young, and slender these might fit better around the waist.

These BSI/NCAA offical flags are heavy duty and thick and are "real" 2 sided flags.  2 flags sewn together not a screen print.  The colors are vibrant and are the actual authentic team colors and design logos.  I will be putting mine up right after Thanksgiving.....can't wait!  Go Bucks and Go Blue! :D

This will get you some admirers.  I saw so many people looking at this while the wind blew it back and forth.  Buy it you will love it!  Make sure you hang it just like the photo or the legs will get stuck on the pole on the opposite side.  I didn't pay attention when I first hung it out and then I figured it out.  Its perfect!

This was my 2nd wine bottle tote purchase and this particular version isn't the best.  So, I now only use this to transport wine from the store to home because I'm afraid the velcro will loosen and the bottle might fall out.  Also, this tote will not stand up with the bottle(s) inside....depending on how you sit it on the floor or table.  Not very stable.  If you need a tote to transport only, its okay, but to use while you're at a function and may have an open bottle that has been recorked or cap screwed on.... I would not suggest at all.  There are others made by "Picnic at Ascot" that work a LOT better.

Yes!  I'm glad I purchased this.  I have a wine bottle carrier which this fits in perfectly :)  So, I've taken it to potlucks and BYOB events and I can pull out this tray, put a ball of cheese on it, open a small bag of crackers, open my wine bottle and BAM I have a good set up that has impressed my table buddies.  I think the best part is the fact that the tool set is enclosed so you don't have to worry about getting stabbed or cut searching for a knive or fork.  Also, after you use them you can slip them back in to the storage area and wash eveything when you return home.  They clean up really quick and easy.  The best thing this will last for years so its an investment and you can use it at home too even though its small it fits easily on any table....and instead of using it with wine/crackers you can use it for breakfast to hold butter and a block of philadelphia cream cheese.  Highly recommend.  I'm very satisfied with my purchase.

I haven't had any issues with these melting (as has been reported by other reviewers), in hot coffee at least not from my keurig coffee maker. These are the best size.  Not to long and not too short.  Fits all my cups and glasses.  No issues at all.  Glad I purchased them since they were cheaper than even sams club!  Saves me from using spoons and washing extra utinsels.

I own another model made by "Travelon" and its a lot better for sure.  I didn't pay a lot for this TETHYS version so I'm not out of a lot of money.  This one is just cheaply made and a little more difficult to open and close.  Its a waterproof bag that you would use to store items in for an extended period of time and knowing you won't access them in a hurry.  I figure I'll be using this as an additional one to have for traveling. One can hold my cell phone and misc stuff and this one can hold my camera in the event I'm in a situation where I need all of these items protected in a major pour down/storm.....or when using in a shared bathroom/hostel room etc where you need to take your personal belongings to prevent theft.  I haven't checked its durability or waterproofing condition for underwater, but it will protect items from splashes for sure.  And the difference between this and a ziploc baggie would be that this has 2 ways to carry it.....belt or lanyard.

I purchased 3 of these coolers in the lime green color.  First off, I'm glad I purchased the bright color as it really helped in marking my campsite last weekend when I took it along for a car camping trip.  Since the top is pretty hefty I laid a variety of items on top from time to time and the unit didn't try to collapse on me or anything.  I had it full of snacks and must have items.  I didn't use it with ice as it would have melted in the 3 days I was camping, but it held all my food (beef jerky, chips, crackers etc)....for one person and lots was leftover.I like how it folded up and everything fits back inside the lid.  I keep one at home, one in my truck and one with my camping gear.  I'm glad I purchased it and I really like the strap for easy carrying.Note:  I purchased all 3 of mine for a really good price under amazon warehouse deals.  Not sure I would pay full price, but I like this cooler very very much!

I own two of these.  I purchased mine from "emergency essentials" because it was cheaper. I buy a lot on amazon, but when their prices are more its not worth it.  And it looks like now, you don't even get the handle included.  I know I never used either handle, as I use mine with one of those long handles you can unscrew from a mop head.
