I've had mine for several years now and still use the original one weekly.  I initially purchased it for using while I was out boondock camping, and even though I'm at home now I still use it.  I use 3 buckets (usually)......add clothes to water and soap and let them soak about 30 minutes while I'm cleaning or watching TV.  and then start washing them and rinse them in the other bucket. I do all of this inside the bathtub while I'm standing on the outside.  I use a small bucket with a pouring spout right under the tub faucet to fill it up with water and transfer to the other buckets.  I can do all my clothes at my leisure and i purchased a very useful "european type clothes dryer" http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003XRNWG6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage that I use in my tub or outside. works great.  I have the 2nd breathing mobile washer for backup.....just in case.  This is something everybody should have if you use it now or not.  Its just a matter of time just about anyone would have a use for this......believe me :)

Yes, its October 2015 and this is the first time I've ever watched any series of the "Back to the Future" movies.  I'm not a movie type of person, unless its maybe a documentary, but all the hype that was broacast on TV about this movie and all the predictions, I had to watch it and actually I like it!  I'm working on the 2nd video tonight.  My attention span is very short, so making it through the first one was a milestone for me.  Anyway, its well worth watching and I enjoyed the excitement throughout which kept my attention.

Not much starch to rinse off this pasta.  And it doesn't fall apart easily even if its overcooked.  Hope they contine to sell these so I can order more when I run out of these.  Such a bargain to order them in 20 count box/case.  And they taste good in pasta salads.

I purchased the Jalapeno flavored ones and I don't even like HOT potato chips, but I wanted to try them for such a good price.  Anyway, to my amazement they are not that hot as long as you keep eating them.  Once you stop your mouth feels the burn, but you really can't tell while eating them at all.  And the flavor is really good.  They are not just hot chips with no flavor that's why I went through all six (6) bags in one day :(  And I just ordered some more for next months subcribe/save.  They are good, believe me....addicting good!

I own the green peat moss version too. Love both of these!  Buy a size larger and it will fit perfectly. Nice soft material, stylish and comfortable. It's long enough to cover your bottom side for when the rain drips off in the rear. I'm very happy with this purchase.

Please note that this is a "bottle" carrier and not a wine carrier (for regular size tall wine bottles).  They do not fit in an upright position, but one will fit if you let it lay to the right or left a little.  Even if you do insert a tall wine bottle it will zip, but you will struggle doing so.  This carrier is on the short side, so if you're purchasing it for smaller wine bottles, tall beer cans, or tall beer or cocktail bottles then this will do just fine.  I own a few types of these carriers and actually I like this one the best with the handle that swings, but its just too short so like I had mentioned I just don't carry 2 bottles and it will fit okay with a wine glass, some cheese/crackers etc to the side.  They do make these with two holes on the lid for the winde bottles to protrude out, but I just don't really like those depending on where you're taking this carrier, it will be obvious what is inside.  The corkscrew opener can be placed in the small exterior pocket too, to conceal it from view if needed.  And this model does stand up on its own without much of anything inside.Above all it feels sturdy and protective of anything you place inside.
2-side heavy cloth......readable from both sides.  Colors are very vivid.  Can't wait until February!

Nice THICK material and two-sided, so words are plainly read on either side.  Colors and graphics better than the product image.  I'm using mine with the enclosed window hanger, but I can also place it on my garden flag frame too.

As of right now, I own 2 of these and also one of the "lite" version.  If you're not pressed for getting a smaller size, just buy THIS one (the regular Trail Seat).  And watch the price and buy it when the price is lower ($10-13) and even watch for used ones.  Regardless, these are must have for anybody that sits in regular cushioned chairs, wooden chairs, benches, on the ground and wherever else.I keep one in my vehicle in case I ever need it, and the smaller "lite" version in my backpack, but one of these stays inside my home laying on top of a cushioned dining room chair (where I use my computer).  The cushion on the chair is only so comfortable and after awhile my bottom starts to hurt, but using one of these on top of that cushion REALLY REALLY helps.  Wish I tried these a long long time ago.Also, I think the major key in using these is to blow them all the way up with air, close the nozzle, and sit on it, and THEN release the air while you're sitting on it until it gets to the most comfortable level.  And in my opinion, less air equals more comfort with these cushions.  If you're not into the newest and best colors, just buy the cheapest one when its on sale and be done with it.  You will not regret it.

So far, I've purchased the 180 count boxes in Irish Creme and Italian Sweet Creme and the Italian Sweet Creme is the best in my opinion.  At least for everyday use.  I think the Irish Creme flavored one is best for special occasions every so often so you won't get tired of the flavor.  The Italian Creme version is like your everyday cream and sugar. 2 pouches will do the trick for most people and no added sugar necessary.  I drink my coffee black most times, but when I want a change or a treat I add these creamers.  I keep them in the fridge and take out about 15 at a time for my coffee station and of course I keep some in my vehicle and some cooler bags for when I stop by somebody's home.None of my boxes had any damage inside or out and the expiration dates are about 9 months from now.  I will order more when necessary.  But, these are definitely a bargain, and taste and smell a little like cool whip :)

These are great, however, I only rate them at 4 starts do to the hydrogenated oils.  I've tried these room temperature, refrigerated and frozen.  Frozen is the way to go!  Just pop them in the freezer overnight and the next day take one out and wait about 3-5 minutes and start eating :)  They take longer to eat that way and the flavor is a lot better too.  They taste more like "sherbet" when frozen and at least that way you won't go through the full 4 pack so easily.  But, in my opinion, they are VERY good!*note:  these do not contain milk, however other snack pack versions do.http://www.snackpack.com/

I own the regular keen whisper, but these leather versions run about 1/2 size smaller so make sure you order up!  I was hesitant in ordering a half size up as I only wear a 9 1/2 in hiking boots and figured no way are these sandals going to run small, but I guess I was wrong and everybody else in the other reviews were right.  So, I ordered up and they fit just marvelous.  I have no issues with my heel hanging out or anything else.  They fit just right.  I actually went on an hour walk within 2 hours of receiving these shoes.  When I first put them on they were a little stiff, but after my walk they felt like a glove.  As far as the weight, in my opinion they are almost the same as the fabric version.  I really couldn't tell a major difference.  I held one of each in each hand and could barely tell any difference at all.  I can tell you what I noticed right off the bat, and that's the fact these look less like a tennis or running shoe like the other whispers do.  So, these are great to wear when you want to sort of look a little more dressier without the reflective pull tabs and the keen logos.  The keen logo is very subdued, and not noticeable at all.  Please note that the laces in this version do not stretch like the regular whisper sandals, but you can pull them snuggly to fit.  I find these more appropriate for traveling when you don't want logos, reflective and bright orange markers illuminating from your footwear and providing you a choice of attire to wear without feeling you need to wear sportswear to match your footwear.  Nice casual pants would go with these (black or the brown versions).  I purchased the brown when the price dropped to about $39.99 and once the black ones drop, I'll be purchasing those too.  These don't feel any different than the fabric ones in my opinion, however the footbed seems to be a little wider, maybe a tad bit, but the feel is very comfortable.  Give them a short workout or do some bending back and forth to break them in initially......doesn't take much.  Just order at least 1/2 size up and they will fit just fine!

I already own the regular picnic time folding chair and purchased my first one back in 2006.  They are like tanks and last forever (almost), depending on how much you abuse them.  I can say the frame will last forever, as I never had any part of the frame bend, loosen or become distorted in anyway.This new "Fusion" chair is the KING of the outdoor folding chairs period.  This one has a spot for everything you want to keep outdoors at a hands reach.  No need for any additional side tables....nothing at all.I purchased a small umbrella to attach to my chair and skipped the LARGE beach umbrella thats too cumbersome to carry along with the chair.  The umbrella I purchased is at the link below and when I'm not using it, it easily stores in inside the attached "criss-crossed" bungee cords.  It slides right through the bungee cords and tightly secured, so when you're carrying the backpack on your back the umbrella can come along and you don't even know its there.  Also, when you're not using it, you can store it there and it doesen't get in the way at all.  And the best thing the colors match!  This is a must have accessory for this chair.http://www.amazon.com/Sport-Brella-Versa-Brella-Position-Universal-Firebrick/dp/B00HA2ZKFQ/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1444161321&sr=8-1&keywords=sports+brella+versaI keep a kindle on the top storage shelf under the table and store my purse inside the cooler.  I know its for ice/drinks but so far I haven't had the need to use the cooler yet or the other pockets, except the one for drinks. I know one thing, there is more than enough places in and on this chair to stash just about anything you would need while at an event, outside your home, or camping.  I can't think of anything its missing.  It has it all.  I do like the cell phone pocket a lot.  It fits my smartphone, but not sure if it will fit a "samsung note" or phaplet type phone.I do like the rear zippered storage area in the backrest, where you can place the carrying strap and other items.  The hang tag indicates that this chair was manufactured in 2014, so its fairly new.  I'm extremely satisfied with this chair and can't wait to get some more use out of it next month on an upcoming camping trip :)

So far, 5 stars.  I own the large sportsbrella too, and the only thing I would suggest is not to use these or any other umbrella in winds exceeding 10-12 mph and you shouldn't have any issues, unless you have the inside of the umbrella directly facing into the wind then it will ultimately revert.  But, for a normal breezy day this umbreall and the large sportsbrella works fine as long as you have all the joints locked into place to prevent any unnecessary movement.But, this umbrella is awesome and the right size for camping chairs!  I purchased the red one and was suprise that its NOT bright red as I thought it might be.  Its a burnt red color that doesn't stand out like neon colors.I'm using mine for the chair below.  Looks really good and attaches to the side of the backrest very tightly and secured.http://www.amazon.com/Picnic-Time-Fusion-Folding-Chair/dp/B0078K6X60/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1444160574&sr=8-1&keywords=picnic+time+fusion+red+chairIf you don't use these on a very windy day they should last you a long time.  More or less, use these like you would use a "patio umbrella" when the wind picks up just collapse them.  5 stars from me though.  If/when I have any issues I will definitely come back and update this review as I usually do with many of my reviews.

If you own a Columbia Bahama fishing shirt, then these pants are the identical color and material and match perfectly.  The pants seem to run a little small around the thighs.  I'm 5'4" and purchased the regular length.  Wearing hiking boots these the length of these pants fit just right without dragging the ground or anything.  However with sandals they do hit the ground.  I only plan to wear these with boots that have thick soles like hiking shoes, so no issues with the length.  I love the nylon fabric for helping the wicking effect.  The fabric also reduces SPF, repels water and stains and very lightweight for packing.  As some other reviewers mentioned, the included belt is very handy since its sort of built in (but can be removed if wanted).  The cargo pockets on each leg is VERY nice to have for a variety of reasons and they cand hold a lot.  I've since ordered a 2nd pair for backup, considering the price was only $14.00. These pants are perfect for hiking if you order them larger, but that kind of goes for any hiking pant which you really need a good range of motion and comfort and not so much for appearance. The zipper is YKK which is a good thing. Oh, and the color "Fossil" is tan and not beige as some of the images reflect.  I rated these pants with 4 stars due to the fact the fit around the thighs are a bit off, but I still like them and will definitely wear them for sure.

I read all the reviews before purchasing including reviews on other websites.  Just about all buyers believe this jacket runs small, so I ordered X-Large and it fits!  I wear size large in most shirts/jackets, but this one you definitely have to order a size up unless you're in-between sizes. This jacket will trim you down and make your girlish shape even more shapely, which is a major plus to me.  This jacket will dress up a pair a jeans and t-shirt and make you look more polished.I purchased the olive green color because it blends in with landscaping most places and doesn't stand out.  I really really like this color.  You don't have to worry about the sleeves fitting either, because they cinch at the wrist with velcro.  The hood cinches too and when the jacket is completely zipped up, hood and sleeves cinched you will be seriously covered and protected.The zipper has an upper and lower zip which for instance, if you're all button up and hooded up you can unzip from the bottom to access pockets or even go to the potty at a moments notice without removing your jacket.I do like the hidden interior pocket.  Its big enough to hold a man's size wallet not the checkbook size.  Anything in there should not get wet at all.  This pocket will work very well while traveling also to stash some extra cash, or a place to keep cash to avoid accessing your purse throughout the day.I'm glad I accidently ran across this rain jacket, as I had planned to purchase a different one initially.  The only CON I see in this jacket is the "columbia" name and logo embossed on the left sleeve.  But, just about everything they make has their brand name or logo displayed somewhere :)  Regardless, I love this jacket!

If you own any of those tall or short glasses with those long plastic straws, this is what you NEED.  This has to be the best brush/device to clean my straws and cups/glasses.  This brush will even clean the grooves of the lids and the inner part of the cups/glasses.  Now, I feel like my straws are REALLY clean.  When I received this yesterday, I took out all my straws and re-cleaned them, and I felt kind of sick to see there was residue in my straws that were never cleaned out until I used this straw.  They are completely clean now, including all the grooves in my lids/cups/glasses.  Buy this!  I promise you will wish you had it the day you first purchased your sports bottles, alladin cups/glasses.  Awesome product!

This is a real double sided garden flag, where it can be read from both sides.  Excellent!  Sometimes the description might say double sided but only the images are double sided not the text portion.  I plan to put this out the entire week after new years.  Nice colorful flag.

I have purchased the grape and the pineapple flavored koolaid and this pineapple flavor is awesome.  I plan to use it as a flavoring in orange juice or other drinks, including alcoholic drinks.  It taste just like pineapple juice and will really enhance any fruit juice/drink. I'm glad I took a chance and tried this.  I'm keeping some in my purse, backpack and in my vehicle with packets of stevia.  Also, the price of these packets go up and down so purchase it when the price is lower and more reasonable.UPDATE:  After mixing this koolaid with juice and also drinking it as directed, it tastes VERY VERY good with juice, but the more I drink it as directed you can taste the artificial flavorings, but its still good compared to other koolaid flavors I've used.  I will keep this on hand as an additive to other drinks, and for just making koolaid with I want a flavored drink.  I don't drink sodas and other carbonated drinks so this is a like a treat for me.  I drink tea/coffee and water most of the times.  When i run out of this flavor I will buy some more for sure.

These are addicting.  Period.  These are definitely not good for you in anyway, shape or form, but they taste good "to me" :D  The blondie version ones.  Since it was a small box, I don't feel guilty eating them all over a 2 day period.  Since there's not many in each pack, I ended up eating more than one pack in a sitting.  But, I guess it can help those who are trying to partake in only 100 calories per snack.

I know this has less calories which is probably a good thing, but it just didn't mix like "regular" mayo does and the flavor was somewhat off.  I'm back to using regular mayo and just not using as much.  I rather enjoy the flavor of my food and eat less of it than to have less calories and compromise the flavor.  I know some folks really need to use low fat/low calorie foods, but I guess I rather just cut back and use the real thing.

Order these panties by referring to the size chart "waist sizes".  My waist size was equivalent to the size 9 which is also listed as 2XL and they fit.  I wear clothing in size 12-14 and the size 9 or 2 XL fit perfect and wasn't tight but snug.I actually didn't have a good first impression of these panties.  No waistband and the weird looking rubber strips around the inner legs left me dumbfounded, but once I tried them on and had them on all day and walked for a full one-hour, I was sold.  It was hot and muggy out and my undies weren't sweaty and they didn't rise up and wicked pretty good.  I do like how thin and silky they feel.  Since they don't have a waist band they are super small to roll up and pack away for traveling or backpacking.  They are the lightest undergarments I've ever purchased.  I ordered 2 different sets while they were marked down.  These are the type of underwear to take on an extended trip where you might need to wash clothing in a hotel or B&B because they will dry fast for sure.  I'm pleased with my purchase and glad I took a chance on the size chart.UPDATE:  It has been one month since my purchase, and I really love these undies.  I love them so much I ordered 6 more (2 sets) today while they were back on lightning deals. Maybe during black friday they will go back on sale and I'll buy 2 more sets since now I'm not even using ANY of my other undies and probably never will again.

I own the "Chevron" version, and the regular short packable version without the hood and they all have their pros and cons.  But, in a nutshell, I like the regular short version the best for overall comfort, sleek style and lighweightness.This hooded version is great for everyday use when its COLD outside and a hood is definitely needed or for when you're going hiking, camping or backpacking.....this hooded version would be the best.  This version looks more casual and would go with jeans or leggings better.  The Chevron is more dressier and would look nice no matter what you have on.This hooded version AND the other two I mentioned are all filled with 90% Duck Down and 10% Waterfowl Down.  The exterior fabic is 100% Nylon and the interior fabic is 100% Polyester EXCEPT on the "Regular Short Packable Jackets" they have 100% Nylon Interiors which is why they are a lot more lightweight than this hooded version and the Chevron version.If you're looking for an all purpose hooded jacket that will keep you warm in the low 30s then this jacket is worth purchasing.  Also, this version and the short unhooded version have logos stamped on the left sleeve at the top that is not shown in any photos.  Its a little larger than the size of a quarter.

Purchased this for when I go backpacking.  I haven't used it a full night but I did try it out while sleeping on my sofa. It felt comfortable and compressed down very good to fit in my pack.  I own an inflatable pillow and one filled with foam beads and I didn't like either one especially the inflatable one.  But, this Thermarest compressible pillow will work for me!  Just the right size too.

I've used these for a month now and YES they work.  They've been out in the Arizona sun during monsoon season, rain and lots of wind and my garden flag hasn't once tried to fly away.  The rubber stopper still looks new and is still rigid.  I only need to use one at a time so, these should last for years and years.

I own several versions and colors of Calvin Klein Short Packable jackets, and this is my favorite.  First off, the "sandstone" color just makes you look dressy even if you're not :) And the gold tone hardware isn't overpowering as I thought it might be, so it doesn't look cheap or cheesy.  The hidden zippered pockets on this version is VERY nice and adds to the sleek look.  I own the "packable short hooded jacket version" and its more poofy and heavier than this one, not because of the hood but because the lining and exterior of this one is "nylon" and the hooded version has a "polyester" lining which adds to the weight.  I also own the version like this called "chevron" with the gold tone hardware.  Its a dressier version, but I still like this one better because this one is really lightweight. And again, the chevron version has a polyester lining.So, for this version, the exterior is 100% Nylon, Interior lining 100% Nylon, filled with 90% Duck Down and 10% Waterfowl down.  And the tags say Calvin Klein Premium Down, as I understand some Calvin Klein down jackets have less than 90% duck down so these would be a better buy.  I also understand that there are some really high premium down jackets made of 100% goose down, and in most cases cost a lot more than these do for sure.  Regardless, I really like this jacket and it fit me true to size and has a nice shape and curve.  I have short arms and the sleeves are not too long at all.  I also have the saphire blue color in this design and its a royal blue with silver hardware.  Another thing that I didn't notice in any of the photos was the fact on the left side sleeve at the top is a  round circle logo with the name "calvin klein" printed on it.  You can plainly see the logo on the blue and black colored ones for sure (i have several colors).  But, the sandstone one you can hardly see it because the color is a golden brown and it blends in with the color of the jacket.I purchased all my jackets when they were on sale and I would suggest buying a couple when the go on sale, like one for dressy occassions and one for a basic day out and about.  They are very nice indeed, and pack up wonderfully for traveling or backpacking.  I own a total of 4 and wouldn't hesitate to purchase a 5th one (probably a red one) at a later date.  One more thing, these jackets in my opinion are good for low 30s and above temps without any layering. Other than that layering would be a must.

I watched this video because I have an interest in visiting Quebec in the near future and wanted to see some videos of some of the cities there and special places to visit.  But, I was even more happier watching this video for the history that was revealed.  I thought it was very interesting and makes me want to see it even more.

I love the pattern and fabric very much.  It looks very good on, however, it would be somewhat better if it stretched a little more or maybe be a little larger.  My head circumference is about 22 inches (the area where a regular baseball hat would fit),  and this beanie fits snug. even so, I still like it and plan to wear it.  I wish I had purchased the matching scarf too when it was marked down.

Impressed with how long the handle is, how stiff the blue bristles are, and how soft the white bristles are.  OXO must have know I needed this and made it exactly for me!  I use this in large 33 oz glass bottles and with the harder bristles at the bottom of the brush ensures that the bottom of the bottle actually gets clean.  Buy this one for sure!

This is my second purchase of this spork.  I try to purchase them when the price drops, but they're still worth their original price too.  I keep these in my purse and backpack.  Its nice to have available in your vehicle or anywhere you may have some food, but no eating utinsel.  I routinely buy yogurt in the grocery store and eat it in my vehicle for a snack or in-between shopping runs.  This spork works wonders for that reason.
Worth the price for sure, and they hold your eyeglasses OR sunglasses in place very wel.  I keep a few in my purse and luggage for just in case.  One equals none.

Taste was fine, just like I recall from the good-ole-days, but after eating just one bowl I started to crave a bowl throughout the day, so I'm going back to good old fashion kelloggs cornflakes so I won't end up gaining weight :)  Initially, I thought there may have been some wheat starch added like they do in cheerios which I think makes those addicting.  But these don't have that wheat starch added, but these are still addicting and good to me and you can still hear the snap, crackle and POP!

I've watched several movies, youtube videos, online clips of a variety of people traveling the Camino de Santiago and I think this one is more realistic of how thing are on the trail and what to expect if you plan on going.  It shows the good and bad, and how people express their day to day life being on this journey.  5 stars for being authentic!

This is my favorite flying insect killer.  I've been using this for many years and it works!  Sometimes it might be hard to squat a mosquito, but this stuff will take them out.  All you have to do is spray in the air in the general area where they are hiding or situated.  If you spray in an occupied space, I would suggest putting a mask on until the mist settles.  But, I can say 100% this stuff works for me.

I purchased this flag to display during January/February 2016 while its still cold but the holidays have gone by.  The colors are vibrant and the image looks so nice and I'm not even a bird lover :)  But they are so cute!
Just about all Toland Garden Flags get 5 stars from me.  I purchased this one for this upcoming Thanksgiving/Autumn.  I love the colors and they look just like the photos.  nice!

I purchase these once a year and keep them in my bug-out-bag in my vehicle. I rotate them by eating a few of them here and there and re-purchasing them.  They do have some nutritional value too and a few packs will help sustain you in the event you're stranded in a vehicle waiting on a tow truck for example.  Or a convienent snack to eat while on a road trip, or to take camping.  Regardless, they are VERY good and my number one back-up snack!

Perfect size.  If you own a truck get this one.  The JUMBO size.  I have an Ford F350 and it covers my entire windshield and able to cover even a larger windshield.  I'm so happy I found this one.  I couldn't find this size anywhere and the one I've been using would fall out of the windshield.  Also, this one has cloth binding covering the edges, which the other one I was using didn't, so the edges start to peel and you'll have bits and pieces of foil all over your floor mats.  I'm a happy camper now :D

This bra fit as expected, so no issues with the fit.  However, its just a bit too heavy and padded for me. I own the Barely There Invisible Bra #4104 and I have to say I should have just ordered that one again. Its the best bra I own.  The thing with this new bra is when you move like bend over your breast start to flop inside it and I had it adjusted right.  The only reason I'm keeping it is because it was on a sale for $13.00 and I needed a nude/tan or in my case the steel color version to wear under white tops. This color does work vey good in not showing under white fabric. But, I wouldn't purchase this bra again.

As the other reviewer indicated, these zip lunch bags are for dry foods like sandwiches, pizzas, large cookies and snacks. I purchased mine at Target on clearance along with some other branded zip lunch bags. I came here to post my review because actually I like these reuseable bags better than some of the others.  Especially the padding on these bags, and it helps retain the heat/cold better than other reusable zip bags I've tried like the lunchskins. I think the zipper is easy to use on these than using the velcro closured bags, but any type of reusable bag is BETTER than using hefty or ziploc bags any day.

Thank goodness for this handy APP.  I think it works faster than going to their website.  I don't buy a lot of pizzas but by using this app its easy to order now and pick it up later or even delivery.

One of the other reviewers indicated that some of the additives (like wheat starch) probably makes this cereal more likeable to your tummy and I think they are right.  For some reason, I went through a full box in a few days. It was addicting and I think I'm sticking to Kelloggs Cornflakes which I never have that feeling of I want more and more and more.  These Cheerios taste fine but there is definitely something different about them than the olden days when I used to eat them.  It must be the additives.  I try to limit my starches and carbs per day, and I really screwed up when I purchased this for sure.  I give it a 4 but they could have gotten a 5 if they didn't have the additives!

This is so cute!  My gingerbread man :D  Now I have 3 garden flags for the Christmas season.  This is so bright and cute in person.  Can't wait until Decemeber to hang it ouside!  It reminds me of when I use to make cookies around the holidays and put out gingerbread houses.

Personally, I didn't think I would like these. They were on sale so I decided if I didn't like them I wouldn't be out of much money. But, they were GREAT!  Taste just like capuccino from a coffee house.  Not too sweet, enough milk and enough coffee. I will purchase again for sure!  awesome.
Looks just like the photo. Bright green and vibrant and can be displayed during the St Patrick's Day.  Nice!

Since I own a lot of the the Toland Home Garden flags (smaller version), they are somewhat brighter than this particular flag.  Actually, the only reason I'm leaving a review on this larger flag is because I made a mistake and purchased the wrong size :(  I didn't want to pay to return this one so I just decided to keep it and maybe sell it or give it away one day.  The portrait looks okay, just not as vibrant as some of their other flags.  However, the theme reflects an Autumn scene around Thanksgiving so the muted colors would blend in with the surrounding landscape that time of the year.

I wear size 9 in all shoes except ankle top hiking shoes where I have to wear extra thick and cushioned socks.  Other than that I wear size 9.  So, in saying that I ordered size 9 in these rain boots too and with no socks they have lots of extra wiggle room and with thin socks they have extra wiggle room, and with semi-cushioned socks (cushion in toes/heel area) in these boots they fit absolutely wonderful.  I have full- cushion socks that I wear in my hiking boots, but those are are too thick for these boots and make a really tight fit.  So, if you truly wear a size 9 and wear thin or slightly cushioned socks then these rain boots should fit fine.  I personally don't like loose rain boots flopping all over the place, and its a sure set way to end up stumbling over your feet and falling.  With a slight snugness will offer you some stability and assurance in your footing as you walk.Now on to the style and color pattern.  I purchased the Black/White floral design and at first I didn't think these would be appealing but they were on sale and plus had a coupon discount and the only one that was about $19.00 so I took a chance and purchased this design/color.  After receiving them and trying them on with my jeans, I'm VERY happy I chose this color.  First reason, is that blue jeans really blend in with the color and make it look as though the "black" color is really navy blue, and since most times when its raining or wet outside, there are probably grey skies which blend in with with the "grey" in the boots which are NOT white by the way. It also blends in with the grey sidewalks and driveways, so these black/white boots are the best color option in my opinion if you don't want to stand out and just blend in.I'm 5'4" and these fit right below the knee and I can wear my jeans inside or outside.  I figure if you're wearing them on the outside and water gets a little more deeper you can easily just pull your jeans up, so wearing jeans on the inside or outside to me isn't a big deal both ways are dooable.Lastly, the style on these boots are awesome and don't look like a lot of those clunky garden boots. I'm glad I waited for the price of these to go down!  I will keep these in my truck and when I need to use them I will have them handy.

Lets say this........I ordered 3 of these hats in green, black and tan.  I no longer wear any of my other hats.  Can't believe how cool these kept my head all spring and summer this year.  Night and Day from wearing regular baseball hats.  Should have found these years ago.  The sweatband works great and the top of my head never sweats like it did before.  I use to have to remove my hat and wipe off the sweat, now I mainly just get sweat on my face while being active.  I'll never go back to those regular cotton hats!

I purchased this jacket to wear during cool evenings and even if I need it during a camping trip at night.  I haven't had the chance to wear it yet, as I purchased it after the winter ended.  However, the fit, style and feel is just wonderful.  And its easy to pack it in the drawstring pouch. The tag indicates the exterior is 100% Nylon filled with 90% down and 10% water fowl. The interior lining is polyester.
I ordered these for myself and as gifts sometimes.  If you have no self-control, you could go through one of these packages in a 2-3 days :D  I love the BBQ lays and the Green Onion is the best!

I read the reviews and some folks think the ears look more red than pink.  The one I received looks just like the image on this product page. Its not light pink but a darker pink, and not red. I think its a cute garden flag and the price was reduced which is when I purchase most of my garden flags. I like to have one for each season, holiday etc.  I like all the Toland Home garden flags. they are very vibrant and festive.

Cheap conditioner that DOES NOT strip your color.  I primarily use this conditioner between hair treatments and/or colorings. And I noticed if I use other types that are not designed for color treated hair they strip the color. And for years I never realized that some shampoos and conditioners actually stripped the coloring like they do until I tried the color safe type.  So, this is what I plan to use indefinitely.

I was at REI a few weeks ago looking at packable backpacks and they have one similar to this one (REI brand), same liter size, same color, but it has no outer pockets at all but just the sleeves for water bottles.  That was a deal breaker for me.  The Outlander pack has so many separate pockets that its way more functional all around. In my opinion this is a backpack that everyone should own and keep handy for those just in case situations. I'm very happy with this purchase.

Love the lavender smell and the way it cleans my dishes and sink. The first time tried this I was provided one as a gift and fell in love with this dish soap so now thats pretty much all i use. Definitely worth the price and makes your kitchen smell good!

I own several different versions of these energizer headlamps and this one is so-so. There are only 3 modes, but at least the lumens are decent. I actually like the industrial version which has a blinking mode too.  This one does not have a blinking mode and I'm dissapointed that it doesn't have it.  I guess I overlooked it thinking most models have that blinking mode now. But, the main light is very bright.

These small containers really help to preserve the stockpile. Having a large refrigerated jar of this stuff can't be as fresh as using this smaller jars.  Also, I clean out these small jars and use them to store cut up onions, tomatoes etc for salads.  I loved these so much I ordered a second case while they were still at a low price.

I compared these with the Bic Lighters I purchased from a retail store, and these are identical.  So, these are definitely a bargain and they work!  Update:  I just ordered 10 more and will add some to my bug-out bags and backpacks. You just never know when you might need to light a candle or make a fire or cinge the ends of rope.

I own the Columbia boneheads, bahamas, easy ridge, and other columbia shirts and this one is similar to the bonehead version without the fishing rod holder or loops or other insignia. The fit is as expected, so if you wear a large then a large will fit. These do wrinkle and are made of cotton. For hiking, backpacking or camping etc having several of these are a must so when one is dirty you have additiional ones as backup. Also, these can be used as a lightweight jacket and layer a tanktop underneath. Also, the white color is semi-see-thru.

I have several of these shirts in long sleeve and short and love them. They are a thin cotton material and really airy.  They're good for everyday use when you're not trying to dress up but be comfortable in whatever you're doing. The pink color is not bold, but a muted type color which is very nice and doesn't scream summer. The sizes are accurate. I wear a large in all shirts and no exception with these bonehead shirts. And since these are made of cotton they do wrinkle, which don't bother me at all.UPDATE:  I was so excited about the pinkish color one and the first time I wore it I received several compliments while out shopping.  That's the good.  But, the UGLY is the fact on both sleeves around the seams of the arms back and front there are white splotches where it looks like the color was completely removed.  I noticed it after coming home from being out all day.  It was new when I wore it and it hadn't even been washed yet.  After washing it the white spots are still there.  I was only shopping, not hiking or doing any strenuous work. I think its weird as some of the spots or on the top of the sleeve, not a place perspiration would normally be a problem (if thats what the problem is). I'm afraid this pink shirt I purchased will ultimately completely fade and I'll have to throw it out.  I'm so dissapointed :(  I'm changing my rating from 5 stars to 4 stars.  I would even reduce it more, but I purchased several of these shirts and none of the others have faded at all.  I own the white, beige, orange, blue and the pink one. I'm contacting Columbia to see if they've received any complaints about the specific pink color one.  Maybe its the dye they used?  Other than this issues, I believe these shirts are outstanding. So, be aware if you purchase the pink one.

These shirts are a slight bit larger than I expected and mainly because of the draping style (as shown in the product image). I guess I was expecting them to be a little more fitted.  However, they do look really NICE and the fabric feels nice too.  These shirts would be perfect for traveling which is why I purchased the (black and purple).  Another thing, the sleeves are exceptionally long, and to correct that problem the cuff buttons need to be relocated which is what I plan to do. I initially planned on returning the two shirts I purchased and get a medium but I don't think that would change how long the sleeves are so I'll just fix the button location.  I'm 5'4" 160, 38c for reference. The shirt slightly drapes but doesn't look big and its very comfortable for extended movement.  If you're under medium to short height the shirt tail will cover the upper part of your bottom side, more than what the product image shows in this photo.  The model in the product page must be tall with a long arms and a long torso, as the shirt looks shorter on her, which is not the case for a medium to short person wearing this shirt. Oh, and I really like the hidden pocket that zips on the side seam. A nice little place to stash a small amount of cash while out site-seeing so you don't have to constantly open your purse for small purchases in high pickpocketing areas in europe or any country/region with high condensed tourist areas. The pocket will hold a driver's license, credit card, bus/tram pass, or a single key, but I would personally only put a little cash in there for convenience.

The critic Mark Schorer often talked about "technique as discovery". By that, he meant that the techniques an artist uses can better or worsen the revelation of the story being told. With a subtitle like "Mastering Storytelling Techniques", one might think that Barry Braverman would tell us how to use technique to better tell stories with video. Unfortunately, he does not. Instead, Braverman's book is a collection of tips on operating a camera, philosophical and critical impressions of equipment and sarcastic remarks.I've come to expect that a book on technique will develop itself in a logical way with each concept building on the prior until a foundation is laid, and then adding additional concepts. Instead, the author seems to have gathered random ideas, classified them into chapters and then not organized them further. Along the way, he uses many acronyms without explaining what they mean, or ideas that only an experienced user will understand, and never explains them.I am not the most experienced videographer but I hoped to get something from this book. I kept at it, hoping that by the time I reached the last chapter it would all make sense. It didn't.The format of the book reflects its lack of organization. Each chapter has a number of subheadings separated from what went before by a rule and the headings were often terrible puns as when the small paragraph on fill lights is captioned "Having Your Fill". Moreover, the continuity of reading is disrupted by the hundreds of illustrations sprinkled randomly across the pages, often making it difficult to follow the text. They are often less than two or three inches wide and hard to make out. Moreover many do nothing to demonstrate the point of the accompanying text, while others are visual puns that I didn't find funny or useful, and still others include text over the image, as if previously used in a Power Point presentation, that are not appropriate for an illustration in a printed book.I'm sure Braverman knows his business. Perhaps very experienced videographers will understand some of the highly technical matters he discusses, although if they are that experienced, I can't see that they need this book. The less experienced videographer should not spend time wading through this disorganized book

Every year I attend a big photography exposition. Last year there was just one drone exhibitor. This year there were more than a half dozen. Drone photography seems to be here.Eric Cheng is a drone apostle, having spread the word of the uses and advantages of drone photography, including as a representative of the largest ready-to-fly drone manufacturer, DJI. His book covers all aspects of drone photography, although for a few demonstrations, there are references to on-line videos. The book includes chapters on equipment, learning to fly, aerial stills photography, aerial videography, real world stories (which is a portfolio of still drone photographs), and flight, policy and travel (which discusses the status of rules applicable to drone flight as well as how to travel with a drone). This is the most comprehensive book on drone photography Ive seen.Before going on, I have to confess that I had been opposed to the use of the word drone to describe these aircraft, preferring unmanned aerial vehicle because of the negative connotations associated with the word.  Now, given the rapidly growing positive uses of these platforms, even though there is also an undercurrent of fear and distrust in the public, drone seems unavoidable.The book uses DJIs Phantom 3 Professional for many examples. This is not an unreasonable choice, given how DJIs drone dominates the market. The book also deals only with ready-to-fly drones and not the hobbyists assembled drones.The chapter on learning to fly is really just a familiarization, given the number of drone options available. In my case after experimenting with an inexpensive toy drone, I had to resort to the manufacturers publications and videos as well as many on-line resources before I felt competent.(Perhaps not so competent; in speeches Cheng warns that drones are vulnerable. The toy drone that I lost in a tall pine tree and the two Phantoms that drowned might challenge that competence.)With regard to both still photography and videography, Cheng emphasizes that it is useful to think of a drone as a three dimensional device to put ones camera into a position to capture images. He discusses the limitations and capabilities of drones, but to fully utilize a drone, one will have to go beyond the discussion in this book. For example, although the author discusses the HDR capability of the Phantom 3, one ought to understand both how to shoot and process HDR photographs.Chengs discussion of the regulatory environment is important to drone pilots, to insure they are not breaking the law or public expectations. He acknowledges that this is a rapidly changing situation and urges monitoring this environment.A while ago I reviewed this books companion Learn-by-Video and complained that it did very little educating. This book is far superior. You will still have to look at other sources to learn to fly a drone and use tools like Intelligent Orientation Control but this book will provide a good foundation for newcomers and contain a tip or two for more experienced pilots.

Its very natural for serious artists to think about following art as a career. And even folks who dont care if they make a cent from their art want their work to be seen or heard.The author is a former gallery owner who explains how to go about following a career in the visual arts. There are chapters on everything from setting goals, to finding galleries to pricing your work. There is also a chapter of comments by some forty folks in the art world who answered the authors question Whats one thing you know now that you wish youd learned sooner?If youve never thought about what is involved in an art career, this book will give you a broad overview of whats involved, but provides no real depth. For example the acme for many artists is a gallery show. Sloans advice is to follow the submission instructions on the gallerys web site or elsewhere. Unfortunately theres no discussion of how to prepare a submission. Many galleries want an initial submission of photographs. The author could have discussed what kinds of photographs, how to have them made and so forth, but Sloan doesnt touch this level of detail. Moreover, my own experience is that a live presentation is often more successful than a mailed-in portfolio of images, and that its useful for your friends who already have a gallerists ear to suggest an interview.Sloan seems to be leery of written contracts with galleries, but written contracts insure that the parties know whats expected of them. At the very least there should be extensive discussions and perhaps e-mails that describe each partys responsibilities.Sloan says its important for artists to have a budget and keep track of finances. Thats good advice. She mentions that she kept track of her finances on an Excel spreadsheet. Most people would mention using Quicken or similar financial software.I know its important to tell artists to follow their dreams but I really wish Sloan had hammered home that the artist has to keep his or her self alive and that before making a decision to pursue a career in art one should ask how one will eat. Whether its a trust fund, a day job, a supportive mate, or an unusually successful career, many would-be artists go a long way down the road before confronting the question. Maybe this is self-evident but its still important advice.If youve never thought about a career in art, this little book will serve as a nice introduction, but if you are still thinking of following a career in art after reading it, youve got a lot more reading to do.

Ho, hum, I thought, another book on portraits. Then, after I finished the first chapter, I began to wonder what there was left to teach. By the time I reached the last page, I was surprised to find a lot of useful information that I had never encountered, at least in this form, before. SHA-BANG!Hurley is a photographer of head-shots that actors submit while searching for work. (Other folks, like executives use Hurley too, but thespians seem to be his main customers.) At the beginning of the book he explains how he sets up his lighting to get his signature style. I felt like he was teaching the reader how to make pictures that looked like they were taken by Peter Hurley. But, where most portrait books ended, Hurley was just starting, PEOPLE!He followed up by an explanation of his posing techniques, like establishing a strong jaw line and having the subjects squinch. (The squinch is a technique of having the subject raise lower eyelids just a bit, which the author says makes them look confident, but I felt made them look doubting.) The last part of the book explained how the author made people feel comfortable in front of the camera and distracted them, essentially by acting silly. PEOPLE, I had never seen such a detailed explanation of getting people to look good in front of the camera. Of course, other photographers may not feel as comfortable as Hurley in being silly to relax subjects, but having seen Hurleys techniques, more restrained photographers may develop their own techniques for relaxing people and, SHA-BANG!At first I was put off by Hurleys presentation style, sounding like a TV pitchman selling soap or knives. Then I began to see it as Hurleys tool for holding the readers attention while he drilled his method into our head, and then, SHA-BANG, I began to appreciate it.I wouldnt call this a book for advanced portraitists, but you certainly will have to understand how to use your camera. Hurley will then tell you how to work your subject, PEOPLE.

Most photographers probably take photographs of buildings at one time or another but they do not think of themselves as architectural photographers. Yet most photographers would benefit from a little more knowledge of photographing structures. There are a few photographers who spend more time with structures than the average and this book is aimed at them.After an introduction, which includes a brief history of architectural photography, Schulz examines the equipment to use, including cameras, lenses and accessories; shooting techniques with considerations like perspective, converging verticals and lens focal length; and image processing. The book is profusely illustrated with photographs, which can be quite useful if the reader can learn from the images of others, because Schulz never really tells us what makes a good architectural photograph. There are also several pages of comments by another architectural photographer, Marcus Brecht, although much of it repeats what Schulz tells us.Schulz points out that there may be inherent conflicts between architects and photographers because the architect wants to capture what his art has done, while the photographer may want to make the image into his own art without consideration of the inherent art of the subject. The author specifies that it is important for the photographer to remember which goal is the purpose of his photograph.In discussing things like the importance of converging verticals and perspective, the author offers useful suggestions for dealing with problems the photographer may encounter. It is clear he believes that the best lens one can use for architectural photography is a tilt-shift lens, but the reader won't learn the details of using such a lens in this book. Although he mentions the Schelmflug principal, he doesn't explain it, perhaps because he believes controlling the plane is focus is not so useful in architectural photography.There is a brief section on indoor architectural photography, but there was little discussion of lighting such images.I was unhappy with the section on post processing. I did not expect a complete guide to using Photoshop, but rather an explanation of those unusual Photoshop tools that have particular applicability. While he mentioned such tools, his explanations were cursory. Given that he used a couple of specific images to follow in Photoshop, it would have been useful to provide downloadable images, and tutorials that are more extensive. I was also surprised that in his discussion of HDR there was no mention of the tools included in Lightroom. I know this facility only appeared in version 6, which was only recently released, but other authors managed to get advance versions of the software and include it in their books.Although I was less than satisfied with this book, I have to recommend it because there are so few other good books available about architectural photography.

Guy Tal bids fair to becoming the Marcus Aurelius of the landscape photography world. This book consists of a number of essays which apparently first appeared on his blog, in which he explores the meaning of photography, art, life and all of that.The book is divided into four parts: Art, Craft, Experiences and Meditations, although ideas often  overlap between essays. Several themes run through. Photographs that merely represent beauty are not art (nor are the photographers artists) unless the photographer brings something of himself into the art that carries it beyond representation. The best preparation to bring oneself into images is by experiencing the world and other art. The mental outlook that makes a better photographer will also lead to a better life. In the latter part of the book, the author tells how much he loves the wilderness and the small town he lives in. In the last part of the book he emphasizes how small and insignificant humans are compared to the universe.Each essay begins with a quotation from a famous person, usually philosophical in nature, and then consists of several pages relating to the subject matter of the quote. The book is also illustrated with Tal's photographs, although only spread horizontally on a single page in the midst of an essay. Even though the photographs are often striking, this is certainly not a portfolio.It would be easy to think of the author as a bit pretentious, especially given how formal his language feels. Yet, when he discusses the difference between representation and art, he hits the nail squarely on the head. In fact, I was so influenced by the earlier essays in the book that I found myself asking whether I was an artist or representer, and vowing to take a different approach to my photography.On the other hand his paeans to being a solitary individual in the wilderness began to make him sound like an anchorite and his talk of how we all live on the edge of the abyss, while meant to be positive, can be a downer. And yet, even with all of these negative features, the essays are a pleasure to read. They seem to have been carefully honed so that there were no loop holes. Even though they seemed a bit preachy, a good sermon can still be pleasing, at the very least, as literature. The essays are thought provoking and it may be best to read just one at a time and then allow a bit of time for reflection.Many photography books tell us about technique. Fewer are about the mind set of photographers. Very few challenge our perception of photography as an art. For the photographer willing to accept this challenge, this can lead to both better photography and better living.

Sometimes an artist deliberately sets out to create art within a specific set of constraints. Certainly this is true of Tilo Gockel who determined to shot elaborate flash images with just one light, and apparently with the least expensive lights he could find. This book tells of his experience.The book begins with a very general description of the flash techniques and equipment the author uses and then goes on to a series of what he calls workshops that are descriptions of particular type images he photographed. These shots are divided into photographs of people, objects and food and drinks. There is also a miscellaneous section that covers things like stroboscopic effects and melding two flashes into one for stronger light.Although I can understand that some photographers might want to economize by using the inexpensive lights Gockel uses, it seems to me that, if one can afford the more expensive dedicated systems available today, with features like through-the-lens metered output and remote control of other units, the flexibility that one loses in using these cheaper units is scarcely worth the savings. On the other hand, most of the techniques that the author applies will also work with more adaptable units. (Much of the flash equipment was made in China and is apparently available to Gockel in Germany but not readily available in the United States, at least under the brand names that Gockel uses.)The workshops are usually four to six pages, first telling you what you will learn, then describing the location, equipment and lighting, followed by a discussion of post-processing and then tips and tricks. Each workshop is profusely illustrated, although I found the screen saves of the Adobe menus to be a little small.All of the techniques seem workable, including the more exotic ones that illuminate the pretty models that dominate the people section. I wondered why one would want to limit one's self to a single flash for food photography when the elaborate setups would only be justified for commercial purposes. Still, I have foodie friends who regularly photograph their meals when dining out, if only with their I-Phones.I'm ambivalent about this book. I did pick up a few good ideas for flash photography, although I was surprised by a misleading statement about what I consider a basic. (Depth of field is not decreased by using a longer-focal length lens for a particular subject size..) Most of the techniques in the workshop are probably not readily absorbable by a novice flash photographerI would recommend this book for a more experienced flash user who wanted to expand his or her skills. I can't recommend it to a beginning flash user.

It's not often that the author of a technical photography book competes with himself. But that's what Scott Kelby may appear to be doing, since he's already written a Lightroom book for another publisher.This book is a tip book that lists questions one might have while working in Lightroom, like, how do I change the background color of a photobook? The book is organized into broad chapters like "How to Use the Brushes" and "How to Create Special Effects" (although some Lightroom users might not consider creating an HDR image a special effect). In case you are not sure which chapter to look in there is a good index. The book is fairly thorough and covers most (but not all) of the problems a user might encounter.I usually don't like tip books, but this one appears better than most, since a good number of the problems one might encounter are listed. One could almost learn to use Lightroom using this book, but I've found that tutorial books, like Kelby's other Lightroom book, with practical exercises on downloaded files are better as a pedagogical matter. Instead this seems to me the kind of book you keep near the computer for those times when you forget how to do something. (Of course, if your tutorial book has a good index, that should do the job as well).I also found that some of the author's explanations were a little skimpy. For example he suggested that if one didn't want to manually search the list of keywords to find the one you are looking for, one could use the Library filter bar. I find it much easier to use the Keyword List Panel entry bar.I was a bit shocked at Kelby's disdain for the Slideshow function of Lightroom. Of course, if one wants to do a full-court press on a slideshow, one can use one of the many dedicated pieces of software. But I've found that even for polished slideshows the Slideshow function is good enough, integrates nicely with the rest of Lightroom, and doesn't require laying out more bucks. Inclusion in Lightroom is a real bargain, even if it doesn't do all the big boys do.I'm cribbing from something Kelby once said when I say this is a good Lightroom second book, when you've already learned how to use Lightroom.

Lightroom is one of the most popular pieces of software available for people who want to process their digital images. It has an easy-to-use interface. If you learn to use Lightroom from a book like Scott Kelby's "The Adobe Photoshop Lightroom CC Book for Digital Photographers (Voices That Matter)" you can improve the quality of your images in a short time.  But if you really want to squeeze the most out of the software then you need a book like "The Digital Negative".The Digital Negative deals with just the image processing functions of Lightroom and Camera Raw, the plug-in that comes with Photoshop, which shares a processing engine with Lightroom, although the interface is different. Schewe also covers some of the uses of Photoshop for photograph processing that are beyond the capabilities of Lightroom and Adobe Camera Raw.After an introduction to Lightroom and Camera Raw processing, the author goes down the list of processing functions of the programs, covering the functions of each panel, usually in far more detail then one finds in an introductory book. (including the newest function, dehaze). Then he explains how he processes a variety of images, with his explanations of why he moved the sliders and buttons the way he did. Schewe then explains how he move images into Photoshop for the processing that can't be done in Lightroom and Camera Raw. The author finishes up with a discussion of his own workflows and even suggestions for speeding up the software functioning.This is not a book for beginners. In fact, to get the most out of this book one ought to have some familiarity with the software discussed. The author's method is to present an image that requires processing and then to discuss what adjustments need to be made to enhance the image. Since he doesn't walk the reader through the image step by step, like Kelby, it is essential that one have familiarity with the panels and the results one can expect from moving a slider. But if one is familiar with the software, one can learn just how to use it to get more artful images. Schewe's language is as simple and understandable as one can expect for this more advanced topic.The book doesn't provide downloadable images to use in tutorials, nor given the author's approach, is that necessary. Buried deep within the book (a sidebar on P.163), there is the address of a companion website where one can download a few of the images and examine the final images to see the settings Schewe actually used, but I didn't find this to be particularly helpful. Moreover it's just as well the author doesn't rely upon the reader being concerned with specific numerical settings because the screen shots of the panels required examination with a magnifying glass to see clearly.I almost wish that Camera Raw had not been discussed, because of the dangers of confusing it with Lightroom, but Schewe does a good job of distinguishing them. He does show that there are some things that you can do with an image moved into Photoshop with Camera Raw that you can't do with Lightroom.The Photoshop section deals with just a few tools to improve an image beyond Lightroom and Camera Raw. Some are pretty familiar, but the suggestions for selective sharpening may require several readings to comprehend.Notwithstanding the blurb on the back cover, this is not a book for beginners. On the other hand, once you have a handle on Lightroom, Camera Raw, and for the fifth chapter, Photoshop, this book should help you to improve the quality of your images.By the way, the great Ansel Adams wrote an influential book called "The Negative".

There are a number of good books about wildlife photography that deal with photographic techniques, like focusing, exposure and composition. Fewer deal with what I call field craft, that is, taking care of one's self in the wilderness at least as well as your equipment and then finding and getting close enough to the wildlife to capture the image.Joseph Classen deals almost exclusively with field craft in this book. After an introduction showing the relationship between photography and hunting, he talks about researching the target animal and the importance of safety. There is a discussion of field gear including self-defense (!), bags, cooking and the like, and then specialty gear like clothing, scent, blinds and calls and decoys. He urges the photographer to practice before the big shoot, and discusses scouting the shooting location. Classen considers the two techniques of stalking and waiting for animals. Next are a few thoughts on the actual shoot, and its follow-up, both on site and at home, where, curiously given his avoidance of photographic technique, he discusses editing the images.Unfortunately, the book seems aimed at photographers who are going to be introduced into an extremely wild habitat where survival will be an important element. Places like the more well-traveled national parks are not disdained, but looked on only as places to practice wildlife photography. On top of that, most of the recommendations are generic. For example, the author tells us to research a target animal on the web, but offers no specific hints of places to look, or even the type of Google searches that help. For approaching animals, other than the suggestion that one use heel-toe walking to avoid sounding human, there is little advice other than to be prepared to walk or crawl into position. It would have been useful for the author to provide some specific examples of how he deals with particular animals.As to animal images they are all of the mega-fauna that hang out in Classen's area of Alaska and are rather pedestrian. I'm not certain that the author's advice would even be useful in say, Uganda. Some of the images are laughable, like a photograph of a person reading a book to support the point that the reader should research his target species. I certainly didn't need two small images of helicopters accompanying the text that tells me that rescue in the wilderness may be difficult.Even though I've photographed plenty of wildlife, I hoped to learn a few tips that went beyond common sense and what I could figure out on my own. I didn't.

China Mieville is one of the cleverest and smartest writers of speculative fiction. From "Perdido Street Station" to "The City & the City" he often uses his tales to illuminate cultural and economic situations. ( I still think of "Iron Council" as being an exposition of the difficulties of anarchy). Moreover, he is not afraid to experiment with both form and language."Three Moments of an Explosion" is a collection of short stories that are so varied that I have to conclude that most of them were written to experiment with style. On the one hand he plays with language, like Joyce in "Finnegan's Wake", and on the other he tells a straight tale with a twist in the end reminiscent of the Hitchcock television show. He shifts point of view from participants, to observers to third parties from story to story. For many of the stories, it's difficult to give examples without revealing spoilers because the strangeness of the stories begins right with the exposition.Many of the forms did not work for me as stories. There are a number of "trailers" for movies that don't exist yet, or at most exist only in Mieville's mind, that show a concern for setting a tone, or perhaps for mocking the trailers for real movies. It was interesting to see this form of exposition of an idea, even if I didn't get the idea. There were also a few stories that seemed to be quite straight forward in the telling that left me asking after I finished, "What happened here?"This book will be of greatest interest to the author's fans, because it will illustrate how much he experiments with developing his ideas and will increase their appreciation of his past and future work. Non-fans will certainly find a few stories that they will enjoy, but may be perplexed by as many more.

I previously reviewed the second edition of this book, and gave a favorable review. This edition adds a new speedlight and several newer cameras to the lineup of items in the Nikon Creative Lighting System (CLS). (CLS is the Nikon system that allows for the controlling of multiple flashes from a single point.) Rather than create a new review of this excellent book, I'm going to copy heavily from my old review, with a few additional points.The book deals with each of the Nikon speedlights and cameras capable of being used with the system, including discontinued models. After a brief background review and quick start guide, the author delves into the nature of flash, and then offers separate chapters on the SB-500, 600, 700, 800, 900 and 910 speedlights. There is also a chapter on the SU-800 commander, the SB R-200 flashes and Nikon's ring-light kit. Each of these chapters explains each and every button, switch, and menu on these units in sufficient detail to use them properly, including Hagen's recommendations on settings. The images of the equipment and screens are ample to show what must be done. The author recognizes the complexity of the equipment and offers a linear plan for using the equipment to accomplish the lighting task. He also explains the cameras that fit into the system and how to set them. Examples are provided, with the general details of how CLS was used, and finally there are recommendations for ancillary equipment like umbrellas and stands and even batteries.One of the best things about the book is that it concentrates on the automated processes of the speedlights (although it does cover manual set-up as well.) Given the ease and accuracy of the automated systems developed by the Nikon engineers, it makes sense to rely upon these systems as much as possible rather than return to the dark ages of guide number calculation. On the other hand, Hagen provides information on manual flash, including guide numbers.The task Hagen deals with is immense since each of the pieces of equipment is quite complex in its own right. Readers only need read the instructions for the pieces of equipment they own since matters applicable to all are covered in separate chapters. Hagen's writing is quite clear, and leaves no unanswered questions about the operation of particular pieces of equipment. On the other hand this really is a technical manual about the equipment. The examples of actual application of the equipment are useful but can only give a taste of what is possible. To get the most out of the equipment requires further reading on possible set-ups, like the excellent series of books by Joe McNally. However, no book is better than this one at explaining the technical side of CLS.I note that some of the images of the screens on the back of the speedlights are a little dark. I realize that this is true of the actual screens, but in the interests of ease of reading, it would have been nice if the images had been brightened a little.I noted a few small typos, like the omission of the D800 from a long list of CLS capable cameras, but the camera was covered in the actual discussion so I don't consider the typos critical.A question owners of the 2nd edition might ask is, should I update to the third edition. If you've added a flash that was not covered in the 2d edition my answer is yes. If, on the other hand, you had a CLS capable camera covered by the 2d edition and have upgraded the camera, you probably are familiar enough with the system so that you don't need this book. On the other hand, if you have Nikon CLS equipment and don't have any edition, you should probably buy this book.In the interest of full disclosure, the book is sponsored by Nikonians, an on-line independent bulletin board (and much more) for Nikon camera users. I have been a member of the organization for many years and serve as the moderator of its books and magazine forum.

I've taken an interest in using the video capabilities of my DSLR camera. My grandson has indicated an interest in "getting into video", whatever that means. That made an introductory book on Video Production interesting to me."Video Production 101" looks like the introductory book for a course in video that its authors meant it to be. The chapter headings give no hint as to what each chapter contains, and sometimes it's difficult to guess from reading the section headings. What the book does is provide a broad brush view of every aspect of video, from creating a story to capturing an image. Most of this is very general so that if you are interested in learning how to edit clips you will learn that it can be done using software but not how to do it. If you came to this book wondering how to use a camera to capture an image, you won't learn here. You will learn the difference between a close-up and a long shot and you will learn that there are controls on the camera that let you adjust focus and aperture, but not how to apply that knowledge.At first, one might think that is not very practical. But if you approach video from a particular skill, like say writing, you will understand how that skill fits into the larger world of video and that should help you to be a better writer for video. If you know nothing about video but are interested in getting a general  background, this book will do the job.It is clear that the book is aimed at people hoping to make a career out of video. It is an introductory textbook, after all. However, many parts of the book will be of interest even to folks who think of themselves as just watchers. For example, a section called "The Poetry of Content Creation" discusses the characters in a story and the structure of stories. This information may hone your critical skills as a watcher. The explanation of the job titles of people who are involved in video production will at the least help you understand the categories for which Oscars and Emmys are handed out.Occasionally the authors dipped into technical information that was far more specific than most of the book, as when they explained how to handle conversations in a sound track to cover up room sound. I found the information, which I had never encountered before, useful for my own editing, although it might be too much for, say, a writer.The writing is easy to understand and interesting, perhaps because it is keyed to a general audience.This isn't a book that will teach you a lot of specific video skills. However, if you are getting into video production, it will provide you with the kind of overview you will need to do a good job.

The idea of street photography seems easy. You get an impromptu photograph of someone on the street. That shouldn't require much thought, it might seem, until one has tried to do it, and returns with a sad collection of uninteresting images. There seems to be a real need for photographers interested in doing this kind of work to get some help as the publisher presumed when he asked the author to create this book.The author offers chapters that talk about things like cameras and technique, look at the work of a few practitioners, suggest places where one can take street photographs, and discuss the styles of street photography. Lewis finishes up with his ideas on what makes a great street photograph. But most of this boils down to: have a small, unobtrusive camera; learn to work fast, at a moment's notice; and have a deep reserve of chutzpa to take pictures of complete strangers with or without their knowledge. A large supply of luck is also desirable. And yet with all of that, anyone who has tried (but not persevered) at street photography can tell you that you won't get many good pictures.That's because street photography has to have content and knowing how to find it, recognize it  and capture it probably can't be found in a book. Looking for something strange or wonderful is probably good, but some of the great street photographers have looked at the ordinary and in looking,  made it extraordinary. In fact the most useful tool for a street photographer may be an inquiring mind. As folks say about tennis, or anything else that requires great skill, you've got to do it 10,000 times and you still may not master it. So far I haven't found much street photography skill between the covers of a book, although spending as much time as possible with masters like Henri Cartier-Bresson, or Elliot Erwitt, or Garry Winogrand can certainly help. I would have had greater confidence in Lewis' advice if his own photographs had approached closer to those greats.That's not to say that this book can't help you become a street photographer. It does tell you the basics of the set-up of street photography, and if you haven't been able to figure that out from looking at street photographs, or you need a little encouragement, the book can be useful. Just don't expect to read this book and take great (or even good) street photos. After you've shot 10,000 you can decide if the book helps.

One of the most difficult things for new digital photographers to realize is that it is hard to get the picture on one's monitor to look like the output of one's printer. That's because there is enough variation in one brand and model of a monitor and various printers and kinds of paper that a color management process for output is essential.As a part of the color management process a person needs to adjust the color controls of the monitor to a standard.
