Zotos from Sally's is a decent spray but the color is far too orangey and it took quite a bit of blending with my fingers to get it to work well enough to hide my silvery highlights.  I also tried Hairmarker, which has a sponge applicator and seemed to dry out almost immediately.  I could never get enough product on the applicator and the dark blond shade was very ashy.  I also tried Color Wow, which is just a fancy eyeshadow that doesn't offer much coverage at all unless you apply it on top of wet hairspray and even then, it wears off really quickly. Rita Hazan is perfect though.  The color is a dark neutral blond that will blend will all shades of dark blond hair.  However, the spray comes out really cold so it's a bit uncomfortable for a few seconds.  But this situation passes quickly and it covers my silvery strands as well as the darker virgin tresses really well.  The best part is that it lasts a really long time, even through sleeping, so I often don't need to spray it the next day.  Yes, it's a small container but it's so concentrated that just a few spritzes down my part and on my temples is all I need to disguise my gray regrowth. I wouldn't be surprised if this small can lasted 6 months! However, you must shake the can really well prior to applying it, otherwise you won't get a good saturation of color. It's the perfect solution and enables me to stall retouching my roots for another couple of weeks.  I didn't have much luck with the other root concealing products I tried, but this one is different and so much better than the others.  I absolutely hate it when my gray hair begins to peek out after just two weeks.  I try to color my roots every four weeks, but it's so hard to wait if you don't have some sort of cover up.  Rita Hazan Root Concealer has solved the problem for me.  For $25 I've found the perfect solution for my fast growing hair.  If you buy it at Sephora or Ulta, you can always return it if you don't like it.  However, I think you'll be thrilled with the color and the coverage and will especially like the fact that it lasts until you shampoo it out (which is easy by the way, even with a sulfate free shampoo).  There's simply no negative things I can say about this product.  It has out performed the other brands I tried by a long shot.  I am no longer plagued by unsightly gray roots and no one would ever know I'm not a natural blond, lol!  I put off trying this brand because it was so much more expensive than the others I tried (with the exception of Color Wow which is even pricier) but now I know what all the fuss was about.  It's absolutely amazing and no one need know I have any gray hair at all now, lol!  I highly recommend this product.

My gray hair starts to peek out two weeks after I color it so I was looking for a product that would hide the silvery highlights until it's time for another touch up. I tried another root concealing spray, Zotos from Sally's, but I wasn't very impressed with it because the dark blond shade was very orangey and my hair is more neutral.  However, I did use it and simply tried to blend the product in with my fingers.  However, in harsh lighting the off color was very noticeable so I stopped using it. The solid powder concealers, such as Color Wow, are nothing more than expensive fancy eyeshadow and they don't really last very long unless you spray hairspray on your part first and while it's wet, apply the powder with a large fluffy brush.  I found this method time consuming for not much coverage and would much prefer a spray concealer that isn't so much work.  I also tried the root concealers that have a mascara wand applicator but found that there wasn't much product in the tube and that it dried out quickly.  Hairmarker didn't work any better and the sponge applicator never seems to have enough product on it, no matter how many times I dipped it and the dark blond shade was very ashy.  So when I purchased this Rita Hazan product I wasn't expecting to like it but made sure that I bought it at Sephora where I could return it if it didn't work out.  The first time I tried it I knew I had found the perfect root concealer.  It's the perfect neutral dark blond, which will blend with many shades, and it definitely covered the gray and helped the darker virgin hair blend in as well.  However, when it first goes on, the spray is very cold and it can be a bit uncomfortable.  But this situation dissipates quickly and once the powder dries, it hides my gray completely.  Be sure and shake the can up really well before you spray, otherwise you won't get nice saturated color.  The color also lasts all day and longer, as long as you don't brush it out.  This is the perfect product to use for those awkward weeks between touch ups when ugly roots start to show.  Although this container seems small, especially for the price, it lasts quite a long time because the spray is so concentrated that just a few spritzes is all it takes to cover my entire part and another spray or two for my temples. I don't even need to use the product every day because the powder clings really well to my hair even while I sleep so a daily spritz is not always necessary.  And this product also washes out very easily, even with sulfate free shampoo.  I like everything about RH Root Concealer and am so glad I finally found the perfect shade and formula.  It's superior in every way to other root concealers I've tried and is definitely worth the price.  I wouldn't be surprised if this spray can lasted me 6 months!  And I call that a true bargain!

I bought this product at Sally's because I needed something to hide my silvery roots in between root touch ups.  My gray begins to show after two weeks and I'm just not inclined to color that often so I decided to try this root cover up to see whether I could actually last another couple of weeks.  I only use it in my part and a small area near my temples.  The color is rather warm (a bit orangey) compared to my neutral dark blond but as long as I work it into my roots well with my fingers it blends pretty well.  It definitely hides the silver and masks the darker virgin hair too.  It will work between touch ups and that's why I bought it in the first place.  It goes on like dry shampoo but isn't as powdery and the color lasts until I wash it out.  It keeps me from having to worry about the gray showing through, which is the whole point.  I think it was worth the $7 and although the can is small, it will last a long time because I only need a few spritzes to do my part and temples.  Be careful not to over spray it though because too much product won't blend as easily. All in all, I'll keep this product on my shelf and will definitely use it up.  I'm not sure I'll repurchase it though because, like I said, the color is somewhat off.  I can always use eyeshadow  to do the same thing, just fyi.  I recommend this product if your hair is a warm dark blond.  Otherwise, keep looking for the perfect color.  Spray cover ups definitely work, it's just a matter of finding the perfect shade.

This spray is not what I thought it was.  I wanted a spray, more like a hairspray, that I could spray at the roots of my finished style that would provide some lift and volume.  This spray doesn't dry quickly and needs the addition of a blowdryer to make it work.  It goes on very wet and is therefore disruptive of my curls (which I spent 15 minutes doing).  I don't know why it's so hard to find a root volumzing spray that works like a hairspray and that dries quickly.  I bought two Jonathan Product Root Lifter sprays at TJ Maxx for $6 apiece and absolutely loved them.  The nozzle was directional and could be aimed right and root for lift and volume.  I guess this spray was discontinued because I can't find anymore anywhere.  I've been searching for something similar and as of now, all my efforts have been a total waste of time and $$.  This spray isn't what I was looking for and therefore will be going back to the store.  I suppose that if you're willing to blowdry and want volume, this might be the perfect product for you.  I did use it once that way but didn't notice any thickening effects or any volume. For me, this product was a complete miss.  I will say that it smells nice, very fruity and light, but the fragrance dissipates quickly.  I'm not impressed with it at all.  If you're looking for something more like a thickening hairspray, I suggest you try Bumble and Bumble Thickening Hairspray which really does add thickness and volume but dries quickly.  This TIGI spray wasn't sticky or stiff, so it has that going for it.  All in all, my search continues and hopefully, there's a decent root volumizing product out there that dries quickly and will add some lift at the crown.  But so far, this effort has been fruitless.

I'm a firm believer that great style is something you just can't teach.  It evolves from adolescence onward and is modeled on the way we see the women in our lives dress.  Yes, you can take tips from others and from magazines, etc.  but an innate sense of style is something we're born into.  This book does have some pointers for those people who want to update their look but it isn't a style bible and lacks something crucial that escapes the telling.  Ines may have great personal style and certainly it has gained ground as she rose in the modeling world, but true style is something you just can't teach.  I grew up watching my mother and grandmother dress, who both had impeccable style and grace and certainly much of their style rubbed off on me.  I occasionally imbibe a tip here and there but have basically always followed my own path, regardless of trends.  Parisian style involves mixing the unexpected in new and interesting ways.  The only way to do this is to try different combinations until you find a mix you like and that makes you happy.  If you're not comfortable in your own skin, this method will be very trying.  You'll know you hit on the right combination when the compliments begin to flow.  Frankly, I'm not sure why I bought this book.  It didn't tell me anything that I didn't already know and the presentation lacks a sparkling something that would have made the content more interesting.  Still, it's an OK book, but not one that gets a high recommendation from me.

I've finally figured out how to use this spray to the best advantage.  When I purchased it, I was looking for a spray to use on my roots that would give my finished style some volume.  However, this spray is a styling product not a finishing one so it didn't suit my purpose at all.  However, I recently read an article in a fashion magazine that suggested that layering two products is the best way to get nice loose beachy waves and have them hold all day.  I use Living Proof No Frizz Weightless Styling Spray and absolutely love it.  It's truly weightless and I can't feel it in my hair at all and yet it has great hold.  So I sprayed LP on as usual and then added some of Superstar on top.  I then let my hair air dry overnight and used a curling iron in the morning as usual.  I have a layered lob (i.e. long bob) and my main objective was to get volume on the top but using this spray not only gave me great hold, it also definitely made my hair look thicker (and who wouldn't want that?).  This spray definitely requires heat to work and although I'm allergic to the hair dryer (a complete klutz with the round brush, lol!), the heat from the curling iron definitely activated it and it made me look like I have a ton more hair.  While it didn't really add the volume at the roots that I'd hoped for (I'm still looking for a root spray), it made enough of a difference for me to keep using it.  This spray would also work really well for fine hair.  When my hair was finally dry, it was a little stiff until I brushed it through, but this is a minor complaint.  Once I curled it, it had a nice amount of body.  And this spray actually smells pretty nice.  I'm going to keep experimenting with the amount (I used just a small amount the first time) but I certainly noticed a nice difference and the effects lasted all day and into the next.  I did purchase this spray on Amazon, where the price was about $7 less than Ulta's.  It seems the magazine article was right: layering products really does help and gives me the illusion of much more hair.  This spray didn't interfere with the effectiveness of the curling iron either.  I now have a style that looks exactly like the picture I showed my stylist!!  Yay!!  I definitely recommend it if you want thicker looking locks. I'm sure it would work equally well if you blowdry.  Guess I'll be keeping it after all, lol!

I bought the 3 ounce size of Olaplex No. 3 from my stylist to use at home.  I had No. 1 and No 2 in the salon when I have my color services (highlights with bleach) and my hair felt and looked great, no damage at all.  I wanted to use No. 3 at home to continue the good work.  I used No. 3 on unwashed hair (per the instructions) even though it had considerable product in it and left it in overnight.  The next day I washed and conditioned and let my hair air dry.  Once dry, my hair looked incredibly healthy and shiny and felt just like virgin hair.  Although my hair wasn't severely damaged beforehand, it was quite dry because in addition to regular coloring (permanent color and a demi toner in addition to the salon highlights) I also heat style frequently.  But Olaplex did its awesome work and my hair looks and feels like virgin hair.  No one would know I'm not a natural blond, lol!  I haven't had virgin hair for many decades but this stuff did a great job of restoring my hair to total health.  Olaplex is a bond multiplier, not a protein treatment, and strengthens the desulfide bonds present in healthy hair and depleted in damaged hair.  No 1 has the greatest concentration of the active ingredient (which was originally developed to prevent rejection in organ transplant patients) with No 2 catching those bonds that didn't take with No 1.  No 3 was created as a result of client demand and has the least of the active ingredient.  If your hair is really damaged, you should get all three in the traveling stylist's kit.  However, if your hair is in fair condition, like mine, No 3 will work great.  Just follow the directions because it's not used like a conditioner and the longer you leave it on, the more bonds are created.  You can do a protein treatment in addition to Olaplex because they do different things and both are crucial if you're trying to restore very damaged hair.  A great protein treatment is Apoghee Two Step from Sally's.  There's none better imo and you should follow the directions exactly.  However, I find that when I use Apoghee I need extra hydration so I use a moisturizing mask for 45 minutes with heat in addition to the second moisturizing step.  Olaplex, protein and moisture will work to create a head of very healthy looking hair.  If you use bleach, you should ask your stylist for Olaplex because it makes a huge difference and is worth the extra cost.  I've had balayage with bleach in addition to babylights and both times my stylist used Olaplex and there was absolutely zero damage to my tresses.  But after using No 3, my hair is silky and soft and super shiny.  I will use it at least once a month from now on.  If you can't get Olaplex No 3 from your stylist, you can reliably purchase it on eBay from runwaybeautytrends, which sells the authentic product.  I know several people who purchased from this seller and all of them have reported receiving the real thing.  I have no idea about the sellers on Amazon but check the reviews because fakes are plentiful and the Olaplex bottle is easy to dupe.  If it makes no difference in the condition of your hair, you'll know you got a counterfeit product.  Ebay is the better option.  All in all, I'm loving this stuff right now.  Nothing I've used in the past has made as big an impact as doing a protein, moisture and Olaplex No 3 treatment in succession.  My hair is absolutely gorgeous now!!  I definitely recommend this product.

This isn't a spray like hairspray (which is what I wanted), it's a spray mousse.  I wanted something I could spray on the roots that would give my finished style some lasting lift and volume but this spray isn't what I was looking for at all.  It does give some height, which is good, but it's not something can  I use on my finished style after curling.  I will continue my quest for something more like a quick dry hairspray.  I just purchased the TIGI Bedhead Thickening Spray, which will hopefully work the way I want it to.  I love several TIGI products including the Catwalk Strong Mousse and my DIL loves the Lightweight Mousse.  But this spray mousse isn't the right product for my needs so I returned it to Ulta.  The Thickening Spray should do what this product doesn't and will likely give me some lift at the crown and will dry quickly and give me lasting hold.  It's been a long time since I used a thickening spray and years ago, I hated them because they made my hair a tangled, gnarly mess.  Technology has improved and it's likely that this won't happen again.  But if you're looking for a volumizing mousse, you can't go wrong with this Root Boost Spray.  Blowdry your hair upside down for the most lift.  I'm still giving it three stars despite the fact that it isn't the right product for my needs because it does give lift, it's just not the right product to use on a finished style.

I didn't buy this shampoo and conditioner from Amazon, but from Ulta, so I know they're authentic.  However, they don't work as well as I'd hoped.  My hair is dry from loads of coloring and from regular heat styling so I was looking for something that would quench my parched strands.  But this is not the remedy it was supposed to be.  Yes, it's a luxury product and supposed to be excellent but it doesn't work well for me at all.  I've used more than half of the bottles and my hair is in no better condition than it was at the beginning.  I have to say that it's no worse off, but still, I expected better.  For the price of $64 for this duo, it was surely better than something I could get at the drugstore.  But apparently not.  I have since found the perfect shampoo and conditioner for my dry hair.  Agadir Argan Oil Moisturizing shampoo and conditioner restored my hair in just two uses.  It looks healthy and shiny and it just keeps getting better every time I use them.  I also use the Agadir Argan Oil Treatment, which is a silicone/oil blend that not only zaps frizz but also provides thermal protection due to the silicone.  These three products have given my hair a new lease on life.  The shampoo is sulfate free, so it's color safe and it lathers well, which is unusual for a sulfate free formula.  The conditioner is thick and rich and has a lot of "slip" so detangling is easy.  I use about a nickel size dollop of the serum for my below shoulder length hair and it smells really nice and gives me tons of shine, while completely eliminating frizz.  If it works for me in Florida, it will work anywhere, lol!  Alterna is just okay, nothing special and certainly isn't worth the high price tag.  I don't know what all the fuss is about.  Agadir works much better and you can buy the shampoo, conditioner and treatment for about what one bottle of Alterna costs at Ulta.  I'd be a fool to keep using something that just doesn't work.  The question now is what to do with the half bottles of Alterna Caviar?  I definitely don't recommend this shampoo/conditioner for anyone with dry hair.  If you're looking for serious hydration, try Agadir, which works even better than Moroccan Oil imo.  My next step is to try the Agadir mask, which I think will be awesomely wonderful if it's anything like the three Agadir products I've used thus far.  My hair has never looked or behaved better.  Even my stylist has commented on it and that's something that I didn't expect.  Alterna does smell great, I can say that.  But that's about the only good thing I can say has come out of my experience using these products.  My hair needs serious moisture and Alterna just didn't deliver.  I have no clue why there are so many good reviews for these products.  I don't think my situation is anything special. Surely there are a lot of people out there with dry hair and these products are supposed to be moisturizing aren't they?  They aren't exactly an epic fail just a do nothing duo that people with dry hair would be better off passing up.  If you want to cure dry hair in one fell swoop, try Agadir.  Before you waste precious pennies on Alterna, try a less expensive and better alternative.  Agadir will make a believer out of you too, I promise.

This lip liner works pretty well to keep lipstick from migrating into the fine lines around my lips. However, it's pretty soft and squishy rather than firm so I don't think the pencil will last very long.  Something happened to my order and it was lost for a while and in the meantime I purchased Urban Decay's Ozone liner (the large one) which is also a clear pencil designed to keep lipstick from running.  It's a firmer pencil than Mary Kay and it seems to work quite well.  I keep both the Mary Kay and the UD in my purse and use them interchangeably.  A clear pencil definitely keeps lipstick in it's place especially those really moisturizing formulas that are somewhat liquidy.  I'm not sure I'll repurchase the MK pencil but it was a bargain compared to UD but likely won't last as long, so there you go.  A conundrum.  I do like the larger size of the UD pencil because it covers my lips with just a swipe or two.  However, it works best when allowed to set for a few minutes.  The MK pencil doesn't do this and letting it set seems to make no difference in its performance.  I like it well enough and for the price it's decent.  I just don't think I would buy it again.

This spay works really well and the 1 ounce size is $14 at Sephora, so you might want to think twice before ordering from this Amazon seller.  It works great on my somewhat oily skin and helps my makeup stay fresh throughout the day.  It works much better than any other setting spray I've tried.  I originally purchased the small travel size just to test it out but as soon as I used it up, I purchased the full size because now I can't live without it.  All I need to do is blot my face with blotting paper about 6 hours in and after that, my makeup stays perfect and fresh.  This spray does take quite a few minutes to actually dry so don't touch your face during that time.  But once dry, it seems to control excess oil while leaving a nice somewhat dewy finish that looks youthful not a cracked or dry finish like some oil control products.  I'm still surprised that I can check my makeup after quite a few hours and it still looks like I just put it on.  I first tested this spray out on my son's wedding day, which happened to fall on a day with an unbearable October heat wave.  My makeup looked great despite the heat and other than a blot or two, looked freshly applied for the entire afternoon and night.  It definitely passed my test and if it can hold up in the Florida heat and humidity, it can work anywhere.  I now use this spray on a daily basis and I think it makes a huge difference.  This spray is absolutely amazing and I recommend it for anyone who wants to have her makeup look perfect for many hours.  Just a spritz or two is all it takes. I should also mention that my skin is very sensitive and I didn't experience any breakouts or rashes after using this spray.  The only reason I'm giving it four stars is because I wish it had some sunscreen in it.  But hey, it's great as it is and if you're having problems with your makeup not lasting, this is the best spray to fix the problem.

This is the only mascara that keeps the curl in my lashes.  I use an eyelash curler that I warm up with a hair dryer so I get a nice bend to my lashes.  Regular mascara doesn't keep the curl and although I like the fact that I can apply several coats, my lashes are stick straight in an hour, which is unacceptable.  I've tried other waterproof mascaras (Loreal Intenza, Lash Sensational) but for whatever reason, they don't keep the curl as well as this Rocket waterproof mascara.  With Rocket, I get tons of nice volume, even with one coat (it's impossible to do multiple coats with a waterproof formula because it dries too quickly).  I've tried using several coats of  regular mascara and then finishing with a coat of Rocket waterproof, but my lashes don't stayed curled as well as they do with just one really good coat of Rocket waterproof.  And this formula is definitely waterproof and is going nowhere once it's dry.  The brush does get every single lash pretty well and I've gotten no clumps to speak of.  It coats my lashes with very dark color and thickens well, almost making my lashes look like falsies.  As I've gotten older my once thick lashes have thinned out somewhat but they're still long and this mascara is the best mascara I've tried in a long time and I don't get mascara marks on my brow bone.  I recently purchased Diorshow regular mascara but wasn't impressed and it definitely didn't hold the curl, even when topped with a waterproof formula.  Right now I'm using the Dior eyelash primer, which does adds some thickness because it has very tiny fibers that add considerable volume.  I then top it off with a coat of Rocket waterproof and I'm good to go and my lashes stay curled pretty well throughout the day.  I only wish I was able to apply multiple coats, but alas, that's true with any waterproof formula.  I've also tried other high end mascaras (regular formulas) only to be disappointed. I've learned my lesson (a very expensive one unfortunately) and will be using Rocket waterproof from now on. It's easily removed with a cleansing oil or even olive or grapeseed oil but stays put until you take it off.  I've had no issues with losing lashes while using it as long as I remove it at the end of the day.  I definitely recommend this mascara, especially if you're having trouble getting the curl to stay all day.  This is the best formula for that purpose.

This "rose" blush has a peachy undertone so it's not a true rose.  It has substantial gold shimmer, which may be too much for daytime wear.  It does go on very smoothly and is highly pigmented, especially for a drugstore formula.  I suggest using just a touch of this blush, going very easy until you are well acquainted with how it performs.  A fluffy brush is the best application method, imo.  It does give a luminous finish so if you're not into shimmery products and prefer matte finishes, then this isn't the blush product for you.  It does wear well throughout the day, which is surprising for so economical a product.  I do blend it in with loose powder on top, so that may help with its staying power. This blush is a great dupe for Nars Orgasm, which is a pinky peach with gold shimmer.  Unfortunately, I already own Orgasm so this blush is something I don't need and probably won't use it unless I finish up Orgasm and decide not to purchase another one (unlikely).  I don't think this Milani blush wears quite as well as Nars, which lasts all day without a touch up.  I wanted an actual rosy color but the addition of so much gold makes this blush more orange than rose (pink + gold= peach).  Still, it's a great product for the money and I might use it a few more times but go back to CVS and purchase a Milani color that's actually rose.  I recommend this blush for anyone on a budget and for anyone who wants the look of Orgasm without the high price tag.

This isn't really a concealer at all.  It doesn't hide my dark circles and actually makes them look rather gray.  I can't understand the cult status of this product at all.  It perhaps works better as a highlighter but it certainly isn't for concealing.  The texture is pretty thin and liquidy although it is easy to blend.  But for my purposes it was a complete fail.  Although it doesn't really crease once set with loose powder, it doesn't hide anything.  I bought two shades of this for $45 apiece and I was hoping that for that price I would get a true gem.  But alas, this was not to be.  I've had both tubes for quite some time and I refuse to throw them out because I paid so much for them.  I might try using them as highlighters on the center of my forehead and down the bridge of my nose.  At least that way I'd be able to use them and might get my money's worth.  Both colors are really too light, although my complexion is light.  The lightest shade, #1, would be more suitable for super pale skin tones.  I wish like heck I hadn't wasted so much money on these products.  If I can't find some way to use them, then I might as well have flushed my cash down the toilet.  This is just another example of a high end product that many people have been brainwashed into buying because of the stellar magazine reviews.  You have to remember that beauty editors receive products gratis in exchange for good reviews.  I suspect that if these same editors had to actually fork out the dollars to purchase these products, the reviews would be more truthful and many cult status products wouldn't be so highly touted.  All in all, if you want to use this product as a concealer, reconsider.  It's too thin to hide anything, including dark circles, and the colors leave a lot to be desired.  I definitely don't recommend this product and I'm hard pressed to find a use for the two I purchased.  Look at all the reviews before making up your mind.  I'm positive you'll find some that are in line with mine.  On Amazon, this product has an average of four stars, which means there are plenty of reviews that are three stars or less.  I wouldn't give an Indian nickel for this stuff.  I'm so upset I wasted nearly $100 on two of these "concealers"/ "highlighters".  Next time, I'll be more careful about spending my money for cult status products and if I decide to take the plunge, I'll buy them from a store that allows returns.  I ordered these online but in the future, I'll take the time to drive to a store where they carry what I'm looking for.  I'd rather waste some gas and have a nice shopping day than have two products that I can't use.  I definitely don't recommend this product.

This is a bit of a heavy fragrence, but I found it to be quite pleasing. It is in a cute red jar and would make a great stocking stuffed for the holidays. Just go light with it and spray on the wrists or even on the inside of the shirt or it will be way too overpowering.

This is a beautiful table but it arrived with a scratch and a stripped bolt on the leg. Thankfully the scratch could be hidden and the stripped bolt was repaired by my husband. The table was also flattened a little bit on the side of the rim and the plastic on one of the feet was ripped off. We had to request a replacement leg and really should have just sent this back but needed it for a family gathering. It is very thin metal, but it is very pretty.
These are rather hard on your rump, but beautiful and easy to assemble. They match the set perfectly and are well priced.
I absolutely love these little turtles. They could use a bit better hanging hardware but no biggie. My 7 year old son is so happy with them!

Light and refreshing cola. We are not big soda drinkers due to the syrups and lack of nutritional value. As a matter of fact, it has been about 3 years since I have tasted soda other than a can- maybe two - of ginger ale. This is nice for a treat. The presentation is very nice. The twist cap requires a bit of effort but is not a big deal. The citrus is barely there, which is fine by me. My husband says 4.5 stars and I agree.

This ornament makes a perfect stocking stuffed for friends and family. It is well made and pretty. One thing to consider is the ribbon as the hanging mechanism. I think decorative wire would have been more practical as ribbon will twist and turn the picture around. Not a big deal though and easily fixed if you are creative.

My son had the older version of this before we moved so when I got the changlce for the new one I jumped. This is so soft and cute. The low volume is a actually bearable and he has a bunch of pressable buttons. Great for a bedtime pal!

This is yummy! It is light, refreshing and low calorie. It is perfect if you need to spice up your water a bit. My husband is very picky and his first question was "How many bottles did they send?". We will be buying this in the future. Thanks,

I received this mattress and it replaced a 12 inch memory foam by Lucid for my 10 year old son. This is very thin and not very comfortable, even for a small child. This would be best for a guest bed or sofa sleeper. It is well made, just not good for nightly use in my opinion. I found my son sleeping on the floor this morning - that says it all.

These came well packed and are large and festive wine glasses. They fit OK in my Orleans style wine rack for storage and will look lovely on the holiday table. Just need to find some charms to put around them that match the theme.

This is my third Harley for kids. They are really big and powerful when you let them go the full speed. They have some nice acceleration as well. Turning isn't as good as the quads, but it isn't horrible either. Keep it dry if possible and charge it inside. The battery is under the seat. Overall these are a blast and affordable.

I have used this for a week as well as a competitor's product - Vichy. They are both in the same price range. This was a little less smooth than the Vichy, but it did leave my face feeling smooth after it dried.

This is a lovely set by Lenox. I received it with a small dinner plate to review. I love the pattern. The plate is very cute, however a little too shallow for deviled eggs. You will have to be careful transporting eggs on the platter. This was sturdy and very well packed. It is not too flashy but definitely not dull and boring. It is just right, in my humble opinion.

We absolutely LOVE this table!! Two of my kiddos helped put it together in about 15 minutes flat. The hardest thing was wrestling it out of the second box and finding the hardware. It is a little short for my 7,10 and 12 year olds to use, but I think it is very sturdy. It has a nice finish and does not wobble. Paper is included as well, and was easy to thread through the other side.
Some of my favorite memories growing up are the Christmas tree Lenox plate we used to set out for Santa. I have a few of these plates and they are a nice decorative tradition for the holidays.

This is a pretty planner. Perfect for a teenager's schedule or for a professional needing a decent planner. I keep mine as a backup to my cell phone calendar. I also gave one to my 12 year old daughter to keep track of her school.

I have tried saving money by purchasing a few knock off versions of this. Both bands have gone in the trash. This fits my husband's bicep well and is sturdy. The phone gets a little sweaty, so I would suggest occasionally taking it out to wipe down.

I am at that age where the wrinkles are starting to sneak up on me. I use coconut oil for my skin and hair, which really helps. Lately I have been ill, and the effects really have taken a toll on my face and skin tone. I have used Vichy for a week now, and it has really filled in the small lines around my lower eyelids. It is also nice smelling and not sticky or goopy like many other products. So far I am happy. I am not sure that I would be able to afford this at this price point, but if I keep seeing these results maybe I will treat myself once in awhile.

My friend has just gotten this version of the Upwords game. I had pitched mine years ago after losing most of the letters, then words with friends came along etc. This is a great game to spend face to face time together, especially if you have young spellers in your family. Not quite the same sturdiness as my old board, but not as bad as some other classic games have devolved into as far as quality.

These are great for pregnant moms not wanting to choke down horse pills for their daily vites. I think that the smarty pants gummies were tastier, and came in a bigger bottle, but am giving these a 4 because they are lower in sugar, which pregnant moms should probably consume less of.

This is absolutely lovely! It is closer to black than bronze. It was easy to hang and is very light. I have it on a small wall to give some pop to the room. I could not possibly be happier with this product.

I got these because they looked cute, are larger, and are reasonably priced. I happen to like the jewels in the circles, I think it adds a bit of pick-me-up to the attractiveness of the scrolls. I have these with a squared medallion centerpiece. If you hang them with picture hooks and put it though the middle of the piece where the scrolls are it is not nearly as noticeable. Overall these are cute and useful.

I just got a pool basketball hoop. This is perfect for rebounding shots and keeping the fun going. Young kids may be tempted to pull on this, which would be something I would discourage as it may break over time.
This has about 22 lines per day. I use it to keep track of my student's progress throughout the year. It has a nice cover, is sturdy and is well bound. Overall I couldn't be happier!

I have heard the saying "friends don't let friends buy soundbars" and for the most part I do agree. Much of what I have seen offered in big box marts is really just awful, cheap garbage and a waste of money. This item is really a cut above the rest. Now if I can't convince you to toss this money towards building a nice system with Sony's freestanding speakers (which I happen to have myself)  then at least go big and get a good sound bar. This one will knock your socks off and takes up less space than 2 floor speakers, a sub, centers, bookcase speakers plus receiver.This is a heavy item, but the bar itself is light and large. By far the sub is the beastie of the package and you may want someone to help unpack and mount this. Overall, maybe a touch high on the price point, but the quality is there to justify it imho. Inspect the box well before signing. Mine looked fine, then I looked on the other side and there was a gouge out of the cardboard with foam coming apart. Sony aced the packing of this, too. The speakers were nice and snug and safe.

We are gluten-free due to my 10 year old son who is autistic. If he gets ahold of gluten he has behaviors, pain, horrible diarrhea etc. We have given up goidies for the most part to respect his feelings, and gladly so. I got these as a part of Amazon's Vine program to try out. The muffins were good, but a bit dry. Next batch we will try adding more oil to see if that helps, but they weren't bad by any stretch.

Bose has been a marvel for excellent sound in a small footprint. This SoundTouch system connects to WiFi and has its own applications. A big letdown is that while Pandora, IHeartRadio, iTunes and Spotify are supported, Amazon Prime music services are not. Big bummer for this Amazon customer. I don't feel like cluttering up my phone with downloaded songs to stream to the player either. This deserves a star off at a minimum, in my opinion.Pros: small footprint, great soundCons: cheap remote, narrow range of supported sites.

This is a really nice product. The cremes are chewy and don't get stuck in your teeth. Beware that these are not good to ship in hot weather. It was 85 when they arrived and they were showing signs of melting . Otherwise, a great value.

I love hot cocoa. My favorite is with marshmallows. The nestle mix is very good. It is very smooth, chocolaty and there are enough marshmallows. I am definitely not thrilled about the removal of calcium as mentioned by another reviewer, but that can be overcome by adding a bit of milk back.I doubt trying these will make me switch from Swiss Miss, but perhaps..

I haven't purchased vegetable oil in my home in over 15 years and am always open to new cooking oils to complement the olive and coconut oils I utilize. This takes a bit of getting used to. I used it to fry some eggplant and it was a bit more bitter than I am accustomed to. I do know that flax is great for hair, so I am planning to use this stuff for off label uses as well. So far I am pleased, but do with the bottle was a bit nicer. The cap was a little loose.

My nails aren't even despite taking collagen and various supplememts. This set is easy to use and removed the vertical lines on my toenails. I had been hiding this with nail polish not having other options. So far so good!

This is a glass scale with wifi to the Nuyu site. I am not too impressed with the site so far, would he happier if this gave a few options like sending wirelessly to jawbone or at least my fitness pal. It is accurate. It does look a little tacky imho. I also have a tankta and a homedics which have been working great but sadly are not wireless either. I am taking a star for appearance.

This thing is a tank. Wow..I was able to review little cousin to this beastie, then was offered to review this product as well. I had been so against HP and their approach to ink (both price and waste) and was so happy to see Epson and Cannon take baby steps towards righting this issue for the consumer. Epson just barged ahead in this endeavor with the WorkForce series. I love the refillable tanks. I have a job working from home (and attend college with my husband half time and teach three kids online full time) and I print. I print a LOT. This printer looks like it might actually stand up to the demands of my household. I might actually be OK on ink for awhile - I hope!If you are the occasional or novelty printer you may want to look at a few other products in this series. This beastie is best suited for somebody who has a no-kidding need for a printer that is the center of their day. Even if you don't flinch at the price tag believe me you will flinch when you have to find a place to put this puppy. 2 people are needed to get it out of the box and hoisted up to its home. It needs a solid table or a large printer stand. It is heavy, wide, tall and did I mention heavy?? Overall, this thing is a machine you will appreciate if you need a printer that works with you all day long.

This leapfrog is a worthy item to consider for kids up to about 12 years old. We have 2 kindle fire tablets, a windows tablet and 2 computers to educate and entertain our three kids aged 7-11. This is bound to attract some negative attention, the apps are expensive, it doesn't have the "feel" of a tablet etc. The big advantage here is the content is filtered and educational. I know when they are on this they haven't slipped away to play candy crush or world of goo or words with friends. Not that I don't find some educational value in those apps, just sometimes I want them working towards something a bit more difficult. We used to have other leap products, this by far is the best.
This is a cute and sturdy glove for little girls. The ball included is nice and not too heavy. My 11 year old daughter's hand still fits perfectly. No complaints at all

I have had a plethora of printers through the Vine program. They have totally changed my opinion of my old mainstay, HP. My current printer is an Epson with the three cartridges. Hey, it is a step up from HP's ink and prices. The print quality certainly doesn't suffer so I am a happy girl. Now Epson tells me that I can save big money on ink. I LOVE the refill idea. 2 years of ink, and I priced this ink and it is really cheap. I work from home. I print a LOT of papers. I need a printer that is a beast. I also need a fax, since I am not allowed to fax with computer applications.I can't comment on refilling the ink obviously. I can tell you that this thing is large. It is a beastie. But if you are looking for a printer in this price range, chances are you aren't kidding around anyway. Best of luck on your purchase.

I live in sunny Florida, but there are some things I cannot grow outside due to the heat or humidity. I have recently sprouted some rambutan from seed, and unlike most plants, we are actually too cold in the winter. So I have a handful of seedlings that need to come inside my garage this winter and hopefully for many years to come. Luckily, I have one light fixture to work with and being offered this bulb was a good stroke of luck. Positives are that it is long lasting, negatives are the field that is illuminated is a bit small. I also have aerogardens for extra light, and think they are a possible substitution for this bulb, depending on what you want to grow.
This is a portable charger with a solar panel. To charge this backup device using solar is 18 hours. It is best to keep it charged and only use solar when needed. Otherwise very good, no complaints.

Small box of blocks and you need to apply decals to them for the alphabet. I was hoping maybe they were pre-printed. I like a lot of the megablocks sets, but this is overpriced and not the quality or quantity I'd hoped for.

This is a medium sized box of blocks. The container they come in was really smelly, not as rigid as I would have liked, and not worth while to keep. The blocks on the other hand are just fine and were a big hit with my 6 year old and his older sister. I would suggest getting a small sterlite tote to toss these into and toss the smelly storage container.
These are beautiful for decor. They are dark earthy tones and well stitched. They go well with my quartz countertops and stainless appliances.

I have several magnet building block sets for my 6 year old son and his sister as well as a lot of Legos. This is our first try with K'Nex. I thought this set was a lot of fun. We have the Nerf blasters as well, but it is a lot more fun to build your own. Highly recommend to spur curiosity in little boys and girls and it provides hours of fun!

This is a nice, thick and well stitched shower curtain. It is a little heavy, so if you are using a tension rod be sure to have that baby as tight as it will go. This is a simple, yet attractive curtain and I will update if anything changes.

We live in Florida, the lightning capital of whatever. I just bought a home, and had my dad install this. He spent 40 years of his life as a commercial electrician. The install was fine and I would HIGHLY recommend taking the advise on having a pro do this. So far we have been doing OK. We usually get some really close strikes and I have a lot of equipment hooked up so it is so important to me to keep my stuff at least somewhat safe.
Loved the idea of putting this on wet skin, however it takes forever for it to dry. Kids love it, it smells good too.

Seventh Generation has been a product line on my list lately for their corporate social responsibility policy and overall good products. I have been using Finish products in my dishwasher because our water down here is horrible. I have used this for a few runs now and it does not leave behind a residue. So far we are very happy with this product. We also use their dish soap.

I received this item from vine to review. I typically love Jergens, and I like the way their lotions smell. It is neat to be able to apply this to wet skin, however it takes a long time for this stuff to dry. It smells nice, and it spreads evenly. It did make my forehead break out in pimples, which is very unusual for me.

This has a nice smell and removes dirt easily. I have two sons, and they come in from the yard unbelievably dirty. This I use all over feet, hair and their hands to scrub them up. The pump dispenser is a bit of a pain.
No germination in South Florida after three weeks. Total waste of money. The rambutan and lychee I had started from seeds are already 6 inches high, and were planted the same day, same growth medium.

I have used artscape several times. It is easy to manage. One small downfall is sometimes it can be difficult to cut. Other than that, i also have the wisteria pattern up in a batbroom and it is very nice.

Carrots, Radishes, Cucumbers, lend me your earsI come to bury calories, not to praise them.The evil that fat does lives after ThanksgivingThe good is oft interred with veggie sticksSsamjang is a spicier, less-fattening, and more versatile condiment than Ranch dressing. Ssamjang -- Ssam is Korean for "wrap," and jang means "paste" -- is a thick, fermented sauce used as a vegetable dip or a topping for wraps. The sauce from a cultured soybean base called doenjang (fermented soy bean paste), chilli paste, fresh garlic, onions, scallions, and sesame oil.This Korean staple can be used as a vegetable dip, a condiment for Korean BBQ lettuce wraps, which include grilled meat and pickled vegetables like kimchi (pickled Napa cabbage), or combined with mayonnaise to create a bold and salty sandwich spread.The lettuce wraps are simple and delicious. Just wash green leafy vegetables like lettuce and place one flat in your hand. Add a slice of slow-roasted pork belly, bulgogi or whatever cooked meat you like. Add a dab of ssamjang, wrap and enjoy.Ingredients: Soybean paste 56% (Water, Soybean, Wheat flour, Salt, Wheat, Malt), Maltose syrup, Wheat flour, Water, Sugar, Cooking rice wine, Salt, Onion, Wheat, Red pepper powder, Shiitake mushroom extract, Garlic extract, Sesame seed, Soybean powder, Garlic, Red pepper paste, Glucose, Koji (Contains Barley).Allergen warning: Soya, Gluten, Wheat, Barley, Sesame.Storage: Keep in dry and cool place. Once opened, keep refrigerated.Shelf life: 12 months.Rating: Five stars

3:09 MinsKai, my eldest son, is different. And he knows it, too. He would do well in Horsemouth, New Hampshire at Kaboom Academy, a new and alternative school for middle-grade kids.Innovation. Experiments. Inventions.Friendship. Tolerance. Teamwork.And lots of silly humor (and silly illustrations).Despite the occasional eye-rolling joke, Middle-School Cool was a light, entertaining summer read for Kai. The book falls outside the ordinary, for better or worse, on the shelves for his age group.Kai didn't feel overwhelmed with the book's alternative school vs. public school message or the other social messages contained within.Rating: Four stars

The major complaint with Watch Dogs is that the parts which are enjoyable have been done better in other games -- and made more sense in other games. Watch Dogs can't quite figure out what it wants to be and finds itself unable to fully commit to anything. Strung together by a story line that never quite sets its hooks, the experience is like eating a seven-course dinner where each dish is individually good but the whole doesn't work together.Despite the complaints, the game is fun. Walking down the street and seeing intimate information about people provides a voyeuristic charm. Figuring out the best way to utilize the character's many hacking abilities is interesting. The skill trees feel a little bit forced but do provide a good structure for choosing where you want to improve and the kind of game you want to play (e.g. sneaker, shooter, or other).GraphicsThe game is very good visually; there's enough detail in the background -- cars, people, etc, to keep the player immersed -- but it lacks the beauty of games like Grand Theft Auto 5 or Skyrim.At the game's best, when you're hacking or trying a bonus game, the visuals can be exciting (for example, driving through demons while the city burns in the background). However, for most of the game, the visual are standard fare. (Keep in mind, I'm playing this on the Xbox 360 and not the Xbox One.)SoundCars, screams, gunshots, talking; they are all there and they are all good. The soundtrack was uninspiring for a game that can't seem to decide whether it wants to outdo Grand Theft Auto or Saints Row. On other games I've played, I'd find myself singing along with a song. Watch Dogs did not offer the same level of pleasure.ControlsThe controls are basic for most things. Want to shoot, drive, run, walk, reload, or whatever?  There's a button for that. What really sets this game apart (no surprise) is the hacking, which Watch Dogs does well, whether blowing up a charge or changing lights at the right time. Hacking adds something that makes the controller feel a little more fresh in your hands.Game playThe hacking is fun and the repetitive parts of the game are made less annoying by being fairly quick. Hacking adds a dimension to this game that makes you think in a way different from other games. Perhaps the closest thing I can liken it to is a mundane version of Shadow Run, where hacking replaces magic.Rating: Three stars.

For a couple, this 50 oz. press offers a generous supply of morning coffee.The Francois et Mimi Large Stainless Steel Double Wall French Coffee Press is functional. The double-walled design keeps coffee warm longer than a glass model without making the press too hot to touch.The Francois et Mimi Large Stainless Steel Double Wall French Coffee Press is attractive. The retro-looking design -- square with a shiny stainless steel skin -- offers appealing lines without sacrificing functionality. (The mirror finish attracts fingerprints.)Functionality * Are you an enthusiastic plunger? Take note, the plunger action is smooth on the Francois et Mimi Large Stainless Steel Double Wall French Coffee Press. When plunged, the press doesn't spray coffee all over or bubble up and shoot over its sides. * The finer screen filters of this press doesn't leave the sludge that be found on poorly designed presses. * The stainless steel construction relieves any worry about the press breaking from a fall. The press is heavy and, when full, feels about like carrying a gallon jug of milk. * The press is dishwasher safe.Rating: Five starsSlow coffee drinks beware! The Francois et Mimi Large Stainless Steel Double Wall French Coffee Press is not an insulated thermos. Press it. Drink it. Make another.If you want to transfer your coffee to a thermos (and I do), I recommend the Thermos Nissan 34-Ounce Stainless-Steel Vacuum Insulated Briefcase Bottle.If you want slightly smaller coffee press (34 oz.), I recommend the Bodum Columbia 8-Cup Stainless-Steel Thermal Press Pot.

3:09 MinsKai, my eldest son, is different. And he knows it, too. He would do well in Horsemouth, New Hampshire at Kaboom Academy, a new and alternative school for middle-grade kids.Innovation. Experiments. Inventions.Friendship. Tolerance. Teamwork.And lots of silly humor (and silly illustrations).Despite the occasional eye-rolling joke, Middle-School Cool was a light, entertaining summer read for Kai. The book falls outside the ordinary, for better or worse, on the shelves for his age group.Kai didn't feel overwhelmed with the book's alternative school vs. public school message or the other social messages contained within.Rating: Four stars

I purchased a subscription back in 2008 because my young sons (ages 6 and 4 at the time) loved to check the mailbox and get mail.I purchased a couple magazine subscriptions for my sons the previous Christmas to supplement their library books and school materials.The magazine says it is intended for children aged 3 to 7 years but don't be shy subscribing to this sooner rather than later. The magazine is mostly animal pictures and very colorful ones at that.I personally like the Family Fun Guide which has given us a couple good ideas to stave off a rainy weekend. There's also links to their web site which is full of family activity tips.Your Big Backyard is a nice change of pace from our sons' book collection of Dr. Suess, DK Readers and Berenstain Bears.Rating: Four stars

4:29 MinsMy 10-year old son Kou tilted his head with apprehension as I announced, "A new book arrived for your review today. The Odd Squad."His face furrowed when I told him the book was about school, Emily Dickinson Middle School to be exact. Kou scrunched down tighter, fading under summer dreams."How many pages?" he asked."A couple hundred I'm pretty sure. Look, the book has illustrations. It looks like a comic book."He took the book from my hand and marched down the hall to his room, where he read nightly before going to bed.By the end of the weekend, Kou emerged with the book gripped as tightly as a game-winning ball. He was smiling."This was funny," Kou said. "I'd read the next one if we can get it."The second book in the Odd Squad series finds middle-schoolers Nick, Molly, and Karl encountering a new student Simone and a new school-wide "Zero Tolerance" policy on bullying.Kou was convinced the group was in fifth grade (actually, they are in seventh) but, given the silly illustrations and goofy humor, the age difference isn't that apparent.Rating: Four stars

Moen's single-handle, high arc design is a huge improvement over the standard bathroom faucet, especially those chrome-plasticy models that sell for less than $50.The brushed chrome finish and sleek design are eye-catching but it is the smooth, one-handle lever that is this model's best feature. The placement of the stopper lever, behind the body of the unit, adds to the clean design. The handle is easy to use, not too tight and not too loose. The tension is gentle yet firm enough for all ages to operate.Plus, the Moen 6190 offers water savings, without sacrificing pressure "feel." A tool is included that allows the owner to easily remove the aerator for cleaning, as needed.Measure twice to ensure this high arc design is compatible with your bathroom. The faucet complies with Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) specifications but a low-hanging cupboard or medicine cabinet might conflict with the faucet. (I'd rather move the medicine cabinet than keep an old faucet.)Installation is a single-hole mount, although the 6" x 2" cover plate can fit over existing two-hole or three-hole sinks. Our installation experience was very easy -- thank you, Jetta! -- and took less than an hour.Please take a look at the photo I posted after installation.Rating: Five stars

The book's size and layout work against the reader. Rotating the book back and forth to view landscape and portrait illustrations is not ideal when reading with a child on your lap.The suggested audience (kindergarten to third grade) simply isn't realistic. As you would expect from a picture book, the illustrations are designed to entertain kindergarten-age children not third-grade students. Some of the acrylic illustrations are vivid and eye-catching while others with dark color mixes distract from the narrative.Speaking of the narrative, the rhyming verse and vocabulary are inconsistent. For example:"Stir-fries and soupare no life for me.I want to grow upand find out what I'll be."Not many 4-year-olds are acquainted with stir fry (my sons, Kai and Kou, being an exception), much less the concept of "no life for me."  And, yet, Arlo Rolled read by an 8-year-old elicits eye rolling instead of deep thoughts.In summary, this book feels like a group of talented people tried too hard. The result is an awkward picture book that failed to excite parents and children.Rating: Two stars

With Eklund Essential Omega Norwegian Fish Oil, I don't experience the fishy aftertaste, belching or heartburn that I experienced from other brands.I appreciate that these softgels are easier to swallow than either Kirkland Signature Omega-3 Fish Oil or the NOW Foods Omega-3 Mini Softgels. The natural lemon flavor of Eklund Essential Omega isn't unpleasant; there's no hint of fish flavor.Each Eklund Essential Omega softgel has 800 mg. of Omega 3 fatty acids, 430 mg. of EPA and 290 mg. of DHA. A suggested use on the bottle is for three softgels daily, taken with meals.Eklund touts its industry-leading purity and freshness. Each batch is individually tested for over 254 contaminants including 220 Pesticides, 6 Heavy Metals, and 7 PCB's.That higher quality does come at a cost. Elklund Essential Omega is more than twice the price per softgel of either Kirkland Signature or NOW Foods brands. However, it is worth noting that Eklund guarantees its Essential Omega, offering a full refund if the customer is not completely satisfied.Rating: Five stars (Five stars for quality; four stars for price)BTW: WebMD provides valuable health information that is timely and credible. Here's the benefits the website lists for Omega-3 Fatty Acids:* Blood fat (triglycerides). Fish oil supplements can lower elevated triglyceride levels. Having high levels of this blood fat puts you at risk for heart disease. DHA alone has also been shown to lower triglycerides.* Rheumatoid arthritis. Fish oil supplements (EPA+DHA) can curb stiffness and joint pain. Omega-3 supplements also seem to boost the effectiveness of anti-inflammatory drugs.* Depression. Some researchers have found that cultures that eat foods with high levels of omega-3s have lower levels of depression. Fish oil also seems to boost the effects of antidepressants and may help the depressive symptoms of bipolar disorder.* Baby development. DHA appears to be important for visual and neurological development in infants.* Asthma. A diet high in omega-3s lowers inflammation, a key component in asthma. But more studies are needed to show if fish oil supplements improve lung function or cut the amount of medication a person needs to control the condition.* ADHD. Some studies show that fish oil can reduce the symptoms of ADHD in some children and improve their mental skills, like thinking, remembering, and learning. But more research is needed in this area, and omega-3 supplements should not be used as a primary treatment.* Alzheimer's disease and dementia. Some research suggests that omega-3s may help protect against Alzheimer's disease and dementia, and have a positive effect on gradual memory loss linked to aging. But that's not certain yet.

We have two sons who are currently studying in the fourth- and fifth grades. They are sponges, absolutely ripe for music, math, language and science, especially when it is delivered in as entertaining a form as Mark Miodownik's Stuff Matters: Exploring the Marvelous Materials That Shape Our Man-Made World.I picked up the book for myself, having just finished a couple rather dour non-fiction books on politics and race relations. Miodownik's enthusiasm for his subject and his cheery writing style captured my attention from the first chapter.His book is a fascinating read delivered in a conversational style that makes it easy to share with my 11-year old and 10-year old sons. That's a rare treat in this medium, whereas we often share science documentaries on the Discovery Channel or PBS. I'm looking forward to having my sons share the book next with their grandfather next.The book has a charming ability that makes it difficult to look at these materials - glass, concrete, steel and plastic - the same way again.Rating: Five starsOn a related note, I've recently reviewed two illustrated books from DK Publishing that are for the young adult audience. I recommend both History Year by Year and Firearms: An Illustrated History and would love to see a similar treatment applied to Stuff Matters: Exploring the Marvelous Materials That Shape Our Man-Made World.Both of the DK Publishing books are filled with full-color photos and graphics; and large enough to cover a kid's lap. "Firearms: An Illustrated History" is 12 x 10.3 x 1.2 inches and "History Year by Year" is 10.9 x 8.8 x 1 inches.Miodownik's essay on metal, specifically stainless steel, would make a fantastic illustration.

I'm a happy owner of the Amazon Kindle Fire HDX Standing Polyurethane Origami Case. In fact, I own two cases for each Kindle Fire HDX. Still, I was willing to try out another case, especially when it retails for half the price of the Origami.Two things jumped out for me when I first saw the Tek-nical Case by Incipio: there's an elastic band to hold the Kindle Fire HDX in place and there are no magnets, which on the Origami allows me to automatically turn off my Kindle Fire HDX when I close it.It isn't realistic to expect either the Tek-nical Case or the Origami Case to save the Kindle Fire HDX from a 10-foot drop onto concrete. In our household, the cases are used to protect the screen from spills and scratches. So, the Tek-nical Case lack of functions really puts it behind the Origami Case.CONS:* The Tek-nical Case is only stable for landscape hands-free viewing. In portrait mode, the case slides and wobbles.* There are no magnets, so the Kindle Fire HDX won't automatically turn off when the case is closed.* The elastic band has a cheap feel and doesn't inspire confidence.You get what you pay for. If price is your first consideration, the Tek-nical Case will probably fit your needs. If functionality is more important to you, I recommend the Amazon Kindle Fire HDX Standing Polyurethane Origami Case.Rating: Three stars

Dear Mr. Castle,We can't thank you enough for upgrading to the OXO Good Grips Complete Grate and Slicer Set. The OXO safety features are important to us, especially the non-slip feet, the secure container handles and the food holder.The slicers and graters fit neatly into the container, which eliminates the risk of reaching into a kitchen drawer and withdrawing a bloody finger. You remember that time you jammed an antique cheese grater into the drawer and it popped out like a spring? Whew! We were lucky to avoid a trip to the emergency room.In addition to the safety features, we like the design and bright colors of this four-piece set. The compact design saves kitchen space, too.We're feeling much better about your grating and slicing plans.Sincerely,Your Fingers (and Thumbs, too!)BTW: We own and recommend the following OXO products, too.* OXO Good Grips Smooth Edge Can Opener* OXO Stainless Steel Strainer, Double Rod* OXO Good Grips Angled Measuring Cup* OXO Good Grips Salad Spinner

The Samson Expedition XP308i 300-Watt Portable PA is a great value that offers an outstanding combination of portability, convenience and versatility for indoor and outdoor venues.We put the PA system to the test at a co-worker's 70th birthday party. It was an indoor-outdoor event at his home, so the system was set up on the covered back deck. He used the iPod dock to play recorded music. The system's performance was outstanding.I can't say enough about the portability. Snapped together, the compact PA system - dual 2-way speakers, an on-board mixer and 300-watt power amplifier - weighs a manageable 30 pounds, making it a breeze to transport. Everything connects into one case with rubber handles: one speaker stores the mixer in the back and the other speaker stores the cables.Equally important is the fact that setup only took a few minutes. Even though the manual is a bit light, the party host was able to hook it up the PA system even though his audio experience is limited. Experienced operators will appreciate the portability and value in this Samson package, features that won't be lost on novices as well.Several other reviewers mentioned the cooling fan noise. It is noticeable in a quiet room, for example if used for a church performance. However, on the back deck at the birthday party, there was enough background noise to cancel out the cooling fan.The built-in iPod dock was the only frustrating feature because the connector doesn't fit all iPod models without an adapter. That problem has more to do with Apple and its aging line of iPods than Samson, so I'm not going to drop a star from my rating.In summary, the Samson Expedition XP308i 300-Watt Portable PA is an outstanding value at this price range that is convenient, versatile and performs well for both outdoor events and small-to-medium-sized indoor venues.CONS:If you own an older iPod model, you might need an adapter to use the mixer's built-in dock.No Sub Out; a minor quibble.Rating: Five stars

Proof that there is still much to mine from America's fascination with chefs and professional kitchens, author Simon Wroe delivers a dark, funny and sometimes grotesque meal that is loaded with hard-to-shake images, profanity and a kitchen environment that could easily be mistook for a torture chamber in just under 300 pages.Readers hoping for Julia Child recipes woven into the narrative will be shocked by the brutal and illegal operations and dealings that occur in the Swan, an upscale London restaurant where our nameless narrator, a novice chef, toils away with a band of misfits who alternately curse and delight in this grubby space.Wroe, a former chef, draws from a rich, personal environment for his debut novel. He manages to infuse the book with energy and colorful language that equally entertain. Anyone with even a hint of professional kitchen experience will wince, laugh and nod along as Wroe reveals the brutal, sweaty business of restaurants.In summary, Chop, Chop makes a perfect summer read: fast, funny and entertaining.Rating: Five stars

My second experience with Arriba! Salsa resulted in a perfect combination of fire-roasted flavor and layered heat. The combo pack is two jars of Medium Chipotle Salsa and two jars of Medium Green Salsa.I gave a three-star review for Arriba! Fire Roasted Mexican Hot Red Salsa last month, a free sample provided through Amazon's Vine program. Here's what I wrote about that variety:"I opened a jar and tried it over three different meals: a lunch of chicken nachos; a dinner of bean burritos; and a dinner of fish tacos. In each and every case, the salsa overpowered the dish. My sons, ages 11 and 9, also tried the salsa. (They have their own condiment bottles of sriracha.) They came to the same conclusion: the hot red salsa was too strong."The Medium Chipotle Salsa (the smoky flavor of chipotle peppers) marries well with nachos and burritos while the Medium Green Salsa (fire-roasted green tomatoes and tomatillos) was best on scrambled eggs with a pinch of melted mozzarella. Unlike the hot salsa, my sons had no trouble enjoying these medium salsas. My wife noted the fire-roasted flavor, which included burnt bits of peppers. She recently added a spoonful to her Mexican rice recipe.Again, I am impressed by the easily-pronounceable list of ingredients in Arriba! Fire Roasted Salsas.Medium Chipotle Salsa: Tomato, Jalapeno, Chipotle Pepper (Chipotle Pepper, Tomato, Salt, Sesame Oil, Paprika, Vinegar and Spices), Cilantro, Onion, Garlic, Carrots, Vinegar, Salt, and Sesame Oil.Medium Green Salsa: Tomatoes, tomatillas, serrano peppers, cilantro, onions, garlic, carrots, vinegar, salt, sesame oil, and spicesThe price is roughly $5 per jar, which is reasonable considering the quality. I would drop a star from my rating if the price climbs much higher.Rating: Five starsADDENDUM: Riba Foods produces the Arriba! brand of fire-roasted salsa as well as pepper sauces, bar-b-que sauces and the Texas Pepper Works brand of bread and butter-type pickles, peppers, and mustard. I recommend the Texas Pepper Works brand as well.

Touted as "the first comprehensive critique of the War on Terror's new front -- the specter of domestic terrorists, Arun Kundnani's "The Muslims are Coming!" failed to engage me. In fact, the book more often felt like an overwrought term paper with barely a paragraph between citations.Part of my disappointment with this book is that it doesn't compare well against another book I was reading at the same time. The other book, Dog Whistle Politics: How Coded Racial Appeals Have Reinvented Racism and Wrecked the Middle Class by Ian Haney Lpez, offered a tighter narrative but no less depressing a topic.There were several factoids in this book that provided new information for me. For example, I was stunned to read that "the Somali population in the Twin Cities is the largest in North America." I would have liked to read more about why this location was chosen but the author delved no further than to write, "Minnesota has a history of refugee settlement..."Credit the publisher, Verso, for tagging the book with a play on the classic film, The Russians Are Coming, the Russians Are Coming. Unfortunately, the book's tone does not reflect the title.Rating: Three stars

Any doubt that dog whistles - code words that turn Americans against each other - is a relevant topic in 2014 is illustrated by Nevada rancher Cliven Bundy and Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling.Author Ian Haney Lpez was interviewed on Bill Moyers' PBS show last February. He described the motivation behind the political tactic, the "dark magic" used to seduce middle-class voters."It comes out of a desire to win votes," Haney Lpez told Moyers. "And in that sense... It's racism as a strategy. It's cold, it's calculating, it's considered, it's the decision to achieve one's own ends, here winning votes, by stirring racial animosity."It would be hard to say from which political perspective (party) this book touches most. For a Republican, it is a reminder that the party's appeal to white Americans includes a racist element. For a Democrat, the book serves as a scorecard for the party's failure to illuminate and defeat dog whistle strategies.The book is even-handed and well researched, but not entertaining like All's Fair: Love, War, and Running for President. I imagine the book elicits outrage in many readers but, for me, it was a dour read. Several times, I wanted to stop reading because the subject matter is so depressing. I associate this to watching Schindler's List, an experience you should take once but not one made for repeat viewings/readings.Rating: Five stars

Hungry really doesn't describe it. My sons are voracious, ravenous...insatiable. They come home from school and scour for snacks. They do their homework before leaving for swim practice. They return eager for dinner. Sometimes, they grab another snack before and after the meal.And, oh my, the weekends are like a plague of locusts.I picked up the first bag of Chef Piggy Tail Microwave Pork Puffies Pork Rinds with Amazon's Add-on program, which ships products with qualifying orders over $25. We followed the instructions, microwaving the entire batch in two minutes in our Panasonic NN-SD997S Genius "Prestige" 1250-Watt Sensor Microwave with Inverter Technology.The mouthwatering pork aroma didn't disappoint. We chose not to season the first batch. No matter, my sons cleared the plate in less than ten minutes on a Saturday afternoon, following a swim meet.I paid $4.25 for Chef Piggy Tail Microwave Pork Puffies Pork Rinds, which is the price still available through Amazon's Subscribe & Save program. The 2-ounce package produces four cups of pork rinds. That's about twice the price of an average family-sized bag of potato chips and more expensive than these other pork rind brands:* Greasy: Lowrey's Bacon Curls, microwave Pork Rinds* Dry: Baken-Ets Fried Pork Skins* Flavorless, but cheap: Utz Pork RindsCompared with Lowrey's, Baken-Ets and Utz brands, Chef Piggy Tail is the best. It is a tasty treat and keeps my 'snackers' happy. My only complaint is that I can't purchase a multiple pack at a discount on Amazon.Rating: Four stars

Buying this book with an Encyclopedia Britannica-sized expectation will set you on a course for disappointment. DK Publishing excels at merging history and factoids with colorful photos and graphics. This isn't a 30-volume collection of everything under the sun.For my sons (ages 11 and 10), Firearms: An Illustrated History is yet another treasure trove of entertaining learning that nicely complements History Year by Year, another exceptional reference book for young readers published in association with the Smithsonian Institution.My review for "History Year by Year" began as follows: "Forgive me for a moment if I can't help giggling. I can't help but think of the Seinfeld episode, `The Bookstore,' where Jerry and George are at Brentano's and George borrows a large book to accompany him into the bathroom."The point then and now is that my sons carry these books with them everywhere. It is beside their cereal bowls at breakfast, in their beds for nighttime reading and smuggled into the bathroom for casual browsing.Both books are more than 300 pages and large enough to cover a kid's lap. "Firearms: An Illustrated History" is 12 x 10.3 x 1.2 inches and "History Year by Year" is 10.9 x 8.8 x 1 inches.I interviewed my oldest son, Kai, because, so far, he's outmaneuvered his younger brother and me to spend the most time with the book.So, how would you rate the book?"I'd give it four and a half stars."Why not five?"In the disguised firearms section (page 300), the picture doesn't show the barrel for the knife gun," Kai said, flipping the pages. "And, in the special purpose firearms section (page 222), you can't really tell from which side the single-shot cigarette pistol fires." More page flipping."Also, I wanted to see more sides of the Dolne Apache pistol (page 220)."Well, you know I'll round up, so four and a half stars becomes five."That's OK. I really like the book. I just like some more photos of these special firearms."With that he gave me a goodnight hug before tucking the book under his arm and heading off to bed.I recommend checking a few pages for yourself using Amazon's 'Look Inside' feature on this product page. See for yourself how colorful and interesting this book is for young readers. This book would make an excellent birthday or Christmas gift.Rating: Five stars.

The B-Daman Crossfire Break Bomber Battlefield Set is an eye-catching toy, especially with the Thunder Dracyan and Lightning Dravise figures. However, the game's style points are squandered with plastic flimsiness and a lack of replay value.Probably the fastest thing you'll discover about the B-Daman Crossfire Break Bomber Battlefield Set is how quickly it will bore your children. My sons (11-year old and 10-year old) played the game twice, each winning a game, before they asked me if they could stop and go play with something else."It felt like Pokemon and not as strategic as Magic the Gathering," said Kai, my 11-year old. "It isn't as fun as it looks. The game says it is for ages six and up but it really is too simple for kids older than 8."PROBLEMS* The trigger is touchy. B-Da marbles stick in the magazine.* Once the B-Daman figures is loaded with B-Da marbles, the figure is top heavy and easily falls over.* When marbles strike each other, especially the heavier marbles, they tend to fly outside the Break Bomber Battlefield.* The B-Daman figures are not durable. I cautioned my sons to play with them gently but it is easy to see why so many people report the game breaks.Rating: One star.BTW: If the Japanese B-Daman toys seem familiar, that's because the toy industry has become quite adept at squeezing huge profits out of combining animated TV shows and collectible toy sets. For example:* Mighty Beanz* Pog* HeroClix* Bonkazonks* Ninjago* Bakugan* Redakai* Beyblade* and who could forget Pokmon?

On a lazy Saturday morning, the whispering from the kitchen grew louder."No. You put your finger in it.""No. You do it."My wife and I sat in the living room, wondering if we should get up, wondering if we should be more nervous when the kitchen went quiet.A couple minutes passed. Then, our sons carried in four bowls of hot McCann's Steel Cut Irish Oatmeal topped with sliced bananas, courtesy of the HomeFlav Monkey Loves Banana Slicer.Conversation progressed as we enjoyed breakfast. Our sons slowly detailed their kitchen experiment: the slicer was sharp enough to cut through hot dogs, cheese sticks and, finally, celery. Actually, the celery didn't cut cleanly, the fibers dangling like loose strings.Then, one brother dared the other to put his finger in the slicer. Dare. Double Dare. Double Dog Dare.
