Still, with no takers, they turned their attention to bananas.And those came out perfectly. The slices are thin enough to top either a bowl of oatmeal or a plate of waffles.Most bananas in our household end up in smoothies, so we don't use the slicer except on the weekends when we enjoy a slower family breakfast.I asked my wife what she liked most about the HomeFlav Monkey Loves Banana Slicer."I like that I don't have to clean a cutting board," she said. "I can drop the slices right into the food."The slicer is durable enough to be used in a busier operation, like a child care facility, where it can get enough use to justify its place in the kitchen utensil drawer.The slicer is easy to clean but do so with care. Those blades are sharp.Rating: Five stars.

"I'm making pizza. Pizza! Pizza! Who wants some pizza?"That happy announcement is a clear indication that one of my wife's preschool students is playing with YazyCraft's wavy dough-cutting wheel -- the pizza tool -- the favored hand tool of the entire kit.My wife's classroom is filled with four- and five-year old students who are developing their motor skills. For nearly two months, she's tested the YazyCraft Rainbow Dough Tools Kit with at least 20 children each day.The only tool in the kit to fail this durability test was the straight dough-cutting wheel. The wheel came off too easily and too often, so my wife finally put it away.Her students use the other five tools with Play-Doh and PlayFoam. They use the hand roller to make cookies with PlayFoam; the rolling pins to make pies and cookies with the Play-Doh; and the spatula to engage in spirited sword fighting, which is why the spatula is sometimes put away, too.I asked my wife to compare the YazyCraft Rainbow Dough Tools Kit with the toys you can find in a dollar store."The YazyCraft kit is more durable and the dollar store quality isn't even close," she said. "The handles are thicker, which makes it easier for my students to grip."Overall, my wife said the kit is a good value. She wishes YazyCraft would address the straight dough-cutting wheel or replace it with another wavy dough-cutting wheel that is in higher demand in her classroom."Pizza! Pizza! Who wants some pizzas?"Rating: Five stars

I'm a proponent of Amazon Certified Frustration-Free Packaging but there are times -- and this is most definitely one -- when less packaging ruins the product.I received one 5.1 ounce bag of Lindt Lindor Caramel Milk Chocolate Truffles from the Amazon Vine program for my review. At the same time, I purchased an entire box of the same truffles. The two orders arrived in separate packages. The bag arrived inside a bubble wrap envelope. The box arrived in a cardboard box, surrounded by air pouches.The box arrived in perfect condition. The bag arrived crushed, with milk chocolate and caramel oozing out of the wrappers.I do not recommend buying bags of these truffles from Amazon until it stops using bubble wrap envelopes, which provide no protection for these delicate milk chocolate shells.Now, as for the taste...My wife said she prefers the Lindt Lindor Caramel Milk Chocolate Truffles to the Ghirardelli Chocolate Squares, Milk Chocolate with Caramel Filling, which has a liquid center.She emphasized the truffles taste best when balanced with a hot cup of tea or coffee."They are sweet and creamy," she said. "It is very easy to pop one in your mouth and, then, another."We also purchased a box of Lindt Lindor Milk Chocolate Truffles. I asked my wife to select the variety she likes best. She said it was a tie. The flavors she likes least are the dark, white and hazelnut truffles."These are really creamy," she said, holding up another caramel truffle.Duly noted: creamy. She's happy with my purchase. She has two boxes of sweet treats to complement her afternoon coffee and after dinner tea.Rating: Five stars.BTW: Lindt Lindor truffles are Kosher certified and made in the USA.

I wish I had bought these pro-grade spatulas many years ago. The frustration of cooking with (and trying to clean) cheaper spatulas was evident the first time I used di Oro's silicone spatula set.The set includes a large (11.2" / 28.5cm) silicone spatula, a large (11.2" / 28.5cm) silicone spoon and a small (8.8" / 22.3cm) silicone spatula, which is perfect for reaching into jars.I purchased the set because I wanted a seamless, one-piece design. I was tired of fighting to clean out all of the food that gets trapped between the handle and spatula head. I was also tired of having handles bend and break.The di Oro spatula set comes with "S-Core Internal Stainless Steel Handle Support Technology" that greatly increases the tools' stability, strength, and leverage. The set also features a textured finish that prevents slipping.On top of all of that, di Oro offers a lifetime guarantee against defects in materials or workmanship. Simply, this is the last set of spatulas you will ever need to buy.I paid $24.71 for my three-piece spatula set. I can expect to spend $6-$10 for a cheap spatula at a discount store.Once I used the di Oro spatulas, I was reminded again of Aldo Gucci's words, "The bitterness of poor quality is remembered long after the sweetness of low price has faded from memory."Once you use di Oro's seamless, silicone spatulas you will never go back to the cheaper models.Rating: Five stars

What's the difference between fudge and chocolate? I pose the question because, as I shared Tobermory Single Malt Scotch Whisky Fudge with friends, several asked if this was really fudge or caramel.It is all a bit confusing, especially when a search on the internet produces pages of recipes for "Chocolate Caramel Fudge" (!) and "Chocolate Fudge Cupcakes with Salted Caramel Frosting."I dug a bit further and found this:* Caramel is sugar, and can be combined with milk or cream.* Toffee is sugar, and can be combined with sugar and butter* Fudge is sugar, milk and butter, and can be combined with chocolate.* Chocolate is a bean.So, caramel, toffee and fudge are all sugar. The difference is sugar concentration and temperature, specifically:* Fudge: Soft-Ball Stage (234 F-240 F /112 C-115 C); Sugar concentration: 85%; Soft ball: A small amount of syrup dropped into chilled water forms a soft, flexible ball, but flattens like a pancake after a few moments in your hand.* Caramel: Firm-Ball Stage (242 F-248 F /116 C-120 C); Sugar concentration: 87%; Firm ball: Forms a firm ball that will not flatten when removed from water, but remains malleable and will flatten when squeezed.* Toffee -- Hard-Ball Stage (250 F-268 F /121 C-131 C); Sugar concentration: 92%; Hard ball: At this stage, the syrup will form thick, "ropy" threads as it drips from the spoon.That all seems a bit much for sharing a piece of candy with friends but the experience illustrated cultural nuances (i.e. expectations) of what fudge should taste like. For some Americans, fudge is synonymous with chocolate.Tobermory Single Malt Scotch Whisky Fudge is not a chocolate experience. The fudge is sweet, creamy and smoky with a pleasing aroma of single malt scotch. The texture is soft but slightly grainy (sugary) and will literally melt in your mouth.I shared the fudge with co-workers, ranging in age from 30 to 70, and with my family, including my two sons (ages 10 and 9). The flavor didn't suit my sons. I found that the older the person, the more they enjoyed this particular flavor. Still, younger people liked it, although they described the taste as caramel instead of fudge.Every scotch and whisky drinker asked me where they could buy more.In summary, while this is not a chocolate fudge experience, it is a mouth-watering treat all the more delicious when shared. I purchased two more cans and gave them away as gifts. Both recipients reported they loved Tobermory Single Malt Scotch Whisky Fudge.Rating: Five stars.

After learning about the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle, I switched to a standing desk. I found an old, four-drawer desk once used for the production of a weekly newspaper. It is now a converted (three drawer), stand-up writing desk with a shiny, smooth lacquered finish. I love the desk and I'm adjusting to the switch of working from a standing position.One drawback of an old desk is that the drawers are a bit sticky. I was told to use an old fashioned remedy, paraffin wax, to treat the drawers and wood runners for smooth operation.I went to a big box home improvement store but they had nothing in stock to treat old wooden drawers. I then went to a local hardware store but all they had in stock was Lundmark Wax Pure Bee's Wax, which came in a 0.7-ounce package for $4.49. Unsure if it would be enough for the job, I also purchased a 1-pound package of Gulf Wax on Amazon for $7.75. (Lesson: The time and gasoline spent driving around to shop could have been better spent had I gone to Amazon first.)I found a piece of advice about how often to apply the wax: [["once a day for a week, once a week for a month, once a month for a year, then once a year for life." That's mainly for finishing with wax, not lubricating, but it still applies to some degree. You want to reapply frequently for a while because the wax will work itself into the pores of the wood (and get scraped off the surface). After a while, you don't need to do it so often, but you should always do it every year. It only takes a few minutes once you get used to it.]]I waxed all three drawers and the wood runners. I barely scratched the first of four bars in the package. At this rate, I figure I can get at least a year of use from my 1-pound box of Gulf Wax.Rating: Five stars.I found a great article online. "How to Apply Paraffin to Sticky Drawers" by Laura Reynolds of Demand Media offers these tips:1. Spread a few sheets of paper on a surface. Pull the drawer completely out of its case, and lay it on the papers. Check the edge of the drawer and the slides in the case to ensure that no splinters have formed along the drawer edges or wood trim that forms the slides. Lightly sand any rough edges -- even tiny splinters catch and grow larger as the drawer is forced open or closed.2. Warm a brick of canning paraffin at least to room temperature (70 degrees Fahrenheit). A warm brick will work into the pores of the wood more easily.3. Cut the brick in half or quarters if the drawer box is small, and wrap a piece of waxed paper around the end you will hold. The waxed paper provides a layer to protect against rough edges and splinters.4. Rub the end of the paraffin block along both edges at least six times on each. Do not exert pressure, just move the block along the edges; this way, the paraffin wax becomes embedded in the wood.5. Wax the drawer and its slides periodically -- perhaps every two or three months -- to keep drawer edges and runner surfaces lubricated and splinter-free.

After learning about the dangers of a sedentary lifestyle, I switched to a standing desk. I found an old, four-drawer desk once used for the production of a weekly newspaper. It is now a converted stand-up writing desk with a shiny, smooth lacquered finish. I love the desk and I'm adjusting to the switch of working from a standing position.One problem arose. My laptop keyboard and mouse wouldn't stay in place. As I typed, the keyboard would rattle and slide down the desk.A co-worker suggested I try Duck Brand Non-Adhesive Shelf Liner. It works better than I expected. My Logitech Optical TrackMan Mouse and Microsoft Natural Ergonomic Keyboard 4000 now stay in place. My keyboard is 11 inches wide, so the 12-inch wide material is a perfect fit. The liner is sticky, so much so that I have to hold the material down to lift the mouse from it. The liner left no residue on my desk.I used 30 inches of the material for a base beneath my ergonomic keyboard and mouse. I plan to change the liner as often as needed, since it will collect more dirt and dust than if it were stored in a drawer. That means I can replace my modified keyboard/mouse pad seven more times.  Getting eight pads for $8.99 is a good value.Rating: Five stars.UPDATE: I received a question from another Amazon customer regarding my mouse. The Logitech Cordless Optical Trackman features a large, finger-controlled trackball. A regular mouse would not work on the shelf liner but it is fantastic for trackballs.

I don't shy away from hot and spicy foods. However, I eat them for the taste, not the effect. I didn't blink when offered a chance to sample Arriba! Fire Roasted Mexican Hot Red Salsa.I opened a jar and tried it over three different meals: a lunch of chicken nachos; a dinner of bean burritos; and a dinner of fish tacos. In each and every case, the salsa overpowered the dish. My sons, ages 11 and 9, also tried the salsa. (They have their own condiment bottles of sriracha.) They came to the same conclusion: the hot red salsa was too strong.Despite our experience, we are interested in trying Arriba! Fire Roasted Southwestern Medium Garlic & Cilantro Salsa next. We noted the ingredient list on the jar was simple and easy to pronounce: Tomatoes, jalapeno peppers, cilantro, onions, garlic, vinegar, carrots, salt, paprika extract, sesame oil and spices.I'm giving the salsa a three-star rating to reflect the quality ingredients and the open-roasted process, I just wasn't able to find a match that the salsa paired with instead of overpowered the meal.Rating: Three stars.

I love food. I find the ingredients, preparations, styles and tastes fascinating. I can't help but drool a little when I thumb through the hundreds of marinade recipes.What I like about Marinades: The Quick-Fix Way to Turn Everyday Food Into Exceptional Fare is that the book is as comfortable in my lap for browsing as it is in my kitchen as a guide or on my coffee table as art. I tip my spatula to Harvard Common Press for taking author Lucy Vaserfirer's ingredients -- 19 chapters of cultural and ingredient-driven marinades -- and turning it into a full course experience.Whether you bend a corner, use sticky notes or whip out a highlighter, you'll find yourself adding recipes to your to-do list because there are so many that look delicious and are easier to prepare. Mind you, I enjoy a challenge but I tend to back away from dense recipes that read like a weekend survival training.Summer is coming. Grilling season. My goodness, this book is going to get a lot of use.Rating: Five starsJUNE 2014 UPDATE: As expected, this book is getting regular use. The gin marinade was a tasty surprise. The book works like a springboard. We're scouring the refrigerator and cabinets for the ingredients to "turn everyday food into exceptional fare." If you are grilling this summer, you really should pick up a copy of this book.AUGUST 2014 UPDATE: Now, our sons are getting into marinades. They pick out one they'd like to try and gather the ingredients, including picking fruit off the vine.

I suppose having a pre-K teacher and two sons (ages 11 and 9) makes our household a perfect laboratory for reviewing pencil sharpeners. I once joked that our family uses so many pencils that we plant seedlings to ease our guilt.This is our third or, maybe fourth, pencil sharpener review for Amazon.What makes the Acme Westcott iPoint USB Pencil Sharpener unique is that it can be powered either by batteries (4 AA) or USB cable.What makes the Acme Westcott iPoint USB Pencil Sharpener frustrating is that it lacks the motor and blades -- the heft -- for anything but casual use. I opened a package of pencils and sharpened each one. The sharpener handled the first four with a steady but slow grind. Sharpening the rest was a catchy, chuck-and-pluck effort.I tried to think of a situation where I needed a portable sharpener, powered by either batteries or a USB cable. Maybe, it is designed for business travelers. Sure, but I'd carry a pack of pre-sharpened pencils in my briefcase. Maybe, it is designed for an office worker who doesn't have a nearby outlet. Sure, but that's all the more reason to occasionally get up from the desk and stretch your legs.Honestly, I don't want pencil shavings and dust anywhere near my keyboard and computer.I recommend two other pencil sharpeners, both of which can handle six different pencil sizes and provide shaving receptacles. 5 stars: X-ACTO SharpX Principal Electric Pencil Sharpener -- a 550cc blade motor in a 1.5-pound sharpener (8.8 x 6.1 x 8.8 inches; and 4 stars: Stanley Bostitch QuietSharp6 -- one pound (10.6 x 6.1 x 9 inches). For classroom use, I rated the SharpX Principal one star higher than the QuietSharp6.There's a rush to design USB connections to a lot of products. Some work (I've got a nifty USB powered fan) and some don't (the coffee warmer never got hot enough). The Acme Westcott iPoint USB Pencil Sharpener falls into the latter category. I would much rather plug a pencil sharpener into an electric outlet than use AA batteries and a USB cable.Rating: One star

Admittedly, we fell into a Keurig rut. After a frenetic start of buying sampler packs, we dialed in our favorite 3-4 varieties available through the Subscribe & Save program. We eschewed the variety packs and holiday samplers that too often are sugar-coated substitutes for people who, apparently, prefer candy bars to coffee.Prior to tasting the Brooklyn Bean Roastery Variety Pack, we regularly bought San Francisco Bay Coffee Fog Chaser, Timothy's World Coffee Parisian Nights and Martinson Donut Shop Blend. We tend to favor darker roasts but, on occasion, prefer the lightness of breakfast/donut shop blends.The Brooklyn Bean Roastery Variety Pack is a delicious addition to our Keurig collection. We prepared these coffees using Keurig's small mug (7.25 oz) setting. We enjoyed the French Roast, Columbian and `Fugheddaboutit' blends the most, although there wasn't a `bad' blend in the entire box.My wife especially enjoyed the flavored blends Maple Sleigh and Hazlenut.The cost is $18.70 with Amazon's Subscribe & Save program, which works out to a very reasonable 47 cents per cup. We plan to buy the Brooklyn Bean Roastery Variety Pack for a couple more months, until we've landed on the 2-3 blends we like best. Although, I wouldn't be surprised if my wife occasionally requests the Variety Pack again to enjoy more flavors.For a first-time Keurig owner or for an office environment (many palates to please!), I highly recommend the Brooklyn Bean Roastery Variety Pack.Rating: Five stars

Cut flowers die. But this Starbucks gift card is eligible for Amazon Prime free delivery, so there are no hidden charges. I get another small bonus using my Amazon credit card, which provides cash back on my Amazon purchases. I also benefit from living in Oregon, where there is no sales tax.Oregon has bolstered its gift card protection laws in favor of consumers. Go to the Oregon Department of Justice's consumer protection website for more information about those protections.There are even more benefits available if you register the card on the Starbucks website. You can earn free drinks and food and receive special offers and discounts.My wife would rather I bring home a Pumpkin Spice Latte instead of a dozen roses. This gift card makes it easy.Rating: Five stars

Ah, the orange cap! The Original (Shoyu) Dressing is our second-most favorite after the Angelo Pietro Sesame & Miso Dressing. Shoyu is our go-to dressing when one of our friends blesses us with fresh fish.Angelo Pietro dressings are versatile as a marinade for seafood, pork, poultry, and beef as well as a dip blended with mayonnaise and as a dressing for vegetable dishes and pasta.Bottles retail for $6-7 and can occasionally be found on sale, two for $8-10. All of this means that the Amazon price with the Subscribe & Save option, currently $5.89 is reasonable. Now, a 9.3-ounce bottle of dressing might not sound like a good value at the price but this dressing is dabbed on rather than poured on foods. The thin cap restricts the dressing to a slow dribble.How good is it? Well, my sons (ages 11 and 9), sneak pieces of French bread into the bottom of their salad bowl, which empties much faster when Angelo Pietro dressings are applied instead of ranch or Italian dressings.PROS* All Natural, No MSG, No Cholesterol, No Preservatives* Made in the USA (California)* Awarded First Place, Best Dressing, 2012 Scovie Awards!INGREDIENTS: Soybean oil, expeller pressed canola oil, onion puree, soy sauce, brown sugar, rice vinegar, salt, distilled vinegar, black olives, tangle extract, sweet red peppers, yeast extract, garlic, fish sauce powder, white pepper, onion extract, mustard flour, xanthan gum, roasted garlic, shitake mushroom, dried bonito powder. Allergen information: contains fish, soy, wheat.Rating: Four starsHere's the story behind the dressing from angelopietro[dot]com:The Start from One Restaurant.The story behind Angelo Pietro reads a bit like the Japanese version of our own American dream.A man with a big passion for Italian cuisine, Pietro Founder Kunihiko Murata followed his heart and opened a small Italian pasta restaurant in 1980 in his hometown of Fukuoka, in south-western Japan. He quickly learned that Japanese food lovers shared his passion for the flavors of Italy. One restaurant became two, then four, and within a few years, Murata was running a successful chain of over 60 Angelo Pietro restaurants throughout Japan.The hugely popular Angelo Pietro salad dressings began as a humble sideline to the pasta business. "We cook our pastas to order and that takes about 10 minutes," said Mr. Murata.  "To keep our patrons happy, we created the idea of an Italian vinaigrette with Japanese flavors to accompany a small salad and vegetables as a start.  Customers loved it, but most importantly, children loved it." As the story goes, parents noticed that children would eat their salads and vegetables - but only with Pietro's special dressing.After repeated requests from parents for dressing to take home to families, Mr. Murata began filling his empty wine bottles with salad dressing. He soon realized that he had a hit on his hands, something that would eventually become an even bigger success than his original restaurant concept.From these modest beginnings, Pietro Dressings have now become the best-selling soy dressings in Japan with more than 17 million bottles of dressing produced and sold each year. "And I give full credit to the children of Japan, who served as our inspiration, said Murata. I sincerely hope that American families have the same experience!"

You can kid yourself into thinking that a homemade sesame miso dressing is just as good as Angelo Pietro Sesame & Miso Dressing but anyone whose enjoyed the real thing will know better.Angelo Pietro dressings are versatile as a marinade for seafood, pork, poultry, and beef as well as a dip blended with mayonnaise and as a dressing for vegetable dishes and pasta.Bottles retail for $6-7 and can occasionally be found on sale, two for $8-10. All of this means that the Amazon price with the Subscribe & Save option, currently $5.89 is reasonable. Now, a 9.3-ounce bottle of dressing might not sound like a good value at the price but this dressing is dabbed on rather than poured on foods. The thin cap restricts the dressing to a slow dribble.How good is it? Well, my sons (ages 11 and 9), sneak pieces of French bread into the bottom of their salad bowl to soak up the last few drops. The salad bowls empty much faster when Angelo Pietro Sesame & Miso Dressing is added instead of ranch or Italian dressings.* All Natural, No MSG, No Cholesterol, No Preservatives* Made in the USA (California)INGREDIENTS: Expeller Pressed Canola Oil, Water, Brown Sugar, Sesame Oil, Rice Vinegar, Sesame Seeds, Onions, Salt, Distilled Vinegar, Soybeans, Contains 2% or Less of the Following: Rice, Wheat, Cottonseed Oil, Red Pepper, Fava Beans, Yeast Extract, Garlic, Citric Acid, Sardines, Maltodextrin, Tangle Extract, Maltose Syrup, Sugar, Spices, Xanthan Gum, Shiitake Mushroom Powder, Bonito Powder. Allergen Info: Contains Fish, Soy, WheatRating: Five starsEXTRAHere's the story behind the dressing from angelopietro[dot]com:The Start from One Restaurant.The story behind Angelo Pietro reads a bit like the Japanese version of our own American dream.A man with a big passion for Italian cuisine, Pietro Founder Kunihiko Murata followed his heart and opened a small Italian pasta restaurant in 1980 in his hometown of Fukuoka, in south-western Japan. He quickly learned that Japanese food lovers shared his passion for the flavors of Italy. One restaurant became two, then four, and within a few years, Murata was running a successful chain of over 60 Angelo Pietro restaurants throughout Japan.The hugely popular Angelo Pietro salad dressings began as a humble sideline to the pasta business. "We cook our pastas to order and that takes about 10 minutes," said Mr. Murata.  "To keep our patrons happy, we created the idea of an Italian vinaigrette with Japanese flavors to accompany a small salad and vegetables as a start.  Customers loved it, but most importantly, children loved it." As the story goes, parents noticed that children would eat their salads and vegetables - but only with Pietro's special dressing.After repeated requests from parents for dressing to take home to families, Mr. Murata began filling his empty wine bottles with salad dressing. He soon realized that he had a hit on his hands, something that would eventually become an even bigger success than his original restaurant concept.From these modest beginnings, Pietro Dressings have now become the best-selling soy dressings in Japan with more than 17 million bottles of dressing produced and sold each year. "And I give full credit to the children of Japan, who served as our inspiration, said Murata. I sincerely hope that American families have the same experience!"

Amazon Vine sent me a Swurve to review but, unfortunately, they sent me a 7" model (I own the Kindle Fire 8.9"). I turned the Swurve over to a friend who owns the 7" Kindle Fire and asked her to help me review the case.What did think of the Marware Swurve Kid Proof Case overall?"When I first saw it I didn't think I'd like it because it doesn't have a cover."Is there anything you do like about it?"The case is very ergonomic. There is easy access to the power and volume buttons."Anything else?"It looked cheap but it is growing on me. I like the color. It feels like you could drop it and it would be OK, but I didn't drop it to try it out."Would you recommend it to someone else?"I probably wouldn't. I like to throw my Kindle in my bag, so I need a case that has a cover. Most of the time I leave it at home, so the Swurve works OK there."So, the MarBlue Swurve foam case is more durable than you probably expect. It is lighter and easier to hold than other Kindle cases. Still, it needs a screen protector and a less cheap-looking appearance.I still prefer my Amazon Kindle Fire HDX Standing Polyurethane Origami Case.Rating: Three stars

This is a hard book to review because fans of Elmore Leonard are likely to pick up regardless what I write. Author Charles Rzepka gets the delicious assignment of digging through Leonard's books and picking gems out of a well-stocked treasury. I'm not quite sure how the Leonard himself would have approved of the academic treatment (Rzepka can be a tad verbose at times), but I can't ignore the professor's enthusiasm for his subject.For readers unfamiliar with Elmore Leonard, I recommend instead a three-book set available on Kindle, Pronto, Riding the Rap, Fire in the Hole, which features Deputy Marshall Raylan Givens of Justified fame.My only complaint is that The Johns Hopkins University Press chose to publish the hardcover edition is a small, hard-to-read typeface. This is a shame. The book includes a small collection of black and white photos but the overall design is, well, academic. The publisher missed the marketing mark, so to speak. Ugh. Anyway, I recommend the Kindle edition for a better reading experience (the ability to increase the font size).Rating: Four stars

While I'm new to Peter Clines' Ex-series, I'm familiar with zombies, having watched the first three seasons of The Walking Dead, and I'm familiar with superheroes, having watched The Avengers, Thor and The Amazing Spider-Man.Now, I must confess this isn't my most traveled genre. It has been years since I read Neuromancer by William Gibson and A Scanner Darkly by Philip K. Dick. And while Ex-Purgatory doesn't rise to the same level as either of those hugely influential SF stories, it is a well-paced book with enough cultural references to keep me entertained (Seinfeld appears on page 161).George Bailey (The Mighty Dragon or St George) is an interesting antihero. His dreams of a zombie apocalypse are - no surprise here - more than just dreams. You'll see similarities to the Terminator storyline as the "superheroes" save humanity from zombies. Several reviewers believe this book is ready made for the big screen. I can't argue that, but I wish it was made more for originality in a genre overcrowded with zombie apocalypses.Rating: Three stars

A good balance of price and performance, I recommend the Corsair Vengeance 2100 for PC gaming and listening to streaming video. While the headset doesn't have the cross platform capability of the SteelSeries H Wireless Headset with Dolby 7.1 Surround Sound, it comes at less than half the price.You need a USB port and Windows 7, Windows 8, Windows Vista, or Windows XP, and an Internet connection for the software download.For the price, the headset is comfortable and delivers an ergonomic design that makes it easy to adjust volume. It comes with a braided cord and a fabric cover on the ear cups.In summary, my only complaint is the lack of cross platform capability. This headset is well priced for watching videos and listening to music; just in case PC gaming is not your interest.Rating: Four stars

1:40 MinsMy fourth-grade son, Kou, grabbed this book up quick and disappeared into his bedroom. Even though Pinkbeard's Revenge (The Adventures of Jo Schmo) is the fourth book in the series, my son had no trouble enjoying the witty tale.I'm reluctant to give this a five-star rating as it is the book reading equivalent of chewing gum. The story pops but the flavor wears out quickly. The book aims to be silly and fun and accomplishes that well.My sense is that Kou liked this book but not nearly as much as another recent book, Desmond Pucket Makes Monster Magic.Still, Kou enjoyed the story and buzzed through the 126-page book. Please check out his video review. The publisher set the age range as 6-9 years (grades 1-4), which is a pretty big range. The vocabulary wasn't too challenging, so parents of first-graders shouldn't worry.Kou's rating: Five stars

2:30 MinsThis re-imagined Robin Hood tale slowly grew on my 11-year old son, Kai. It took him a couple days to get through the first couple chapters but the rest was faster paced. He and his younger brother had recently watched and thoroughly enjoyed the Merlin series from the BBC.The titular character is 13-year old Will Shackley, who escapes into Sherwood Forest, where he meets up with bandits known as the Merry Men, including a giant named John Little (Kai found that character quite funny).Aside from the slow start, Kai liked the book and offered a 4.5-star rating in his video review. I'll amend the four-star rating after his younger brother reads the book next.Rating: Four stars

2:19 MinsMy son, Kou, is very generous with his book reviews. As you'll see in his video review, Kou offered a six-star review of The Sultan's Tigers even though I'm quite sure he knows a five-star rating is the ceiling.Kou enjoyed watching The Adventures Of Tintin, which features the salty Captain Haddock as the young boy's adventure mate. In The Sultan's Tigers, that role is filled by Uncle Harvey. The two adventure tales also share an older, rougher approach to children's fiction. If The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn offends your sensibilities, stear clear of Tom Trelawney and Tintin.I ask my sons Kai (age 11) and Kou (age 9) to help me with book reviews. My start here on Amazon began with the picture books that I would read to them at bedtime. Over the years, the picture books evolved into chapter books and my nighttime reading became their own. Not every book they read is a pleasant experience. I push and cajole them to read different genre, to expand their horizons. Occasionally, though, I provide them with sheer entertainment.The Sultan's Tigers was great fun for Kou.Rating: Five stars

I like this case because it allows me to carry the Kindle in my backpack, along with books and other electronic devices, and not have to worry about scratching up the screen.Granted, it took a bit of origami-folding practice to get the hang of hands-free landscape or portrait viewing. My wife like to set it up in the kitchen while she's making dinner and either watch streaming videos or listen to music from our Amazon cloud.From reading the one-star and two-star reviews for the Amazon Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" Standing Polyurethane Origami Case, I'm come to the conclusion that many people have unreasonable expectations. This is a tablet case, not a 100-and-1 multi-tool. But, if that is your expectation, here are the negatives.CONS* No airbags or parachute protection* Doesn't respond to thought control* Can't do income taxes* Won't make breakfast in bedThe other most common complaint is the weight, which comes from a combination of durable polyurethane, a microfiber interior and an integrated magnetic closure. I don't have an issue with the weight, which I perceive as durability.The case stays shut and keeps my screen clean. If that wasn't enough, there are two more excellent design features: (1) opening and closing the case wakes up the Kindle or puts it in sleep mode and (2) sliding the Kindle up in the case in landscape mode will trigger the rear camera for quick pictures.In summary, the Amazon Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" Standing Polyurethane Origami Case is durable, versatile and well designed to provide added benefits beyond keeping the screen scratch-free and the overall Kindle protected from spills and minor drops.Rating: Five stars

The SteelSeries H Wireless Headset and our new Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" are keeping our family together. Before Christmas, there was a long discussion about purchasing another TV for our household.Our sons, now ages 11 and 9, like to watch programming that my wife and I are less than enthusiastic about sitting through. (Really, Shark Week again?!)The SteelSeries H Wireless Headset with Dolby 7.1 Surround Sound works with our Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" Tablet, our Toshiba LX835-D3310 23.0-Inch All-in-One Desktop and our Xbox 360.My wife was so impressed with the packaging that she kept the box for storing the headset. She said it took less than 20 minutes to unpack, read the instructions and set up the headset. The headset came with two rechargeable batteries, one charged inside the headset that could be used right away. The Li-Ion battery pack charges quickly."The headset is very comfortable," my wife told me. "I can wear it for a long time. The cushy earpieces don't hurt my ears."She uses the SteelSeries H Wireless Headset to watch streaming video from Amazon and Netflix. My sons use the headset on their Xbox 360. Everyone reports that the sound quality is every bit as rich as you'd expect from Dolby virtual 7.1 surround sound technology.The styling is equally impressive with a matte black finish combined with a glossy finish on the cups. As my wife attests, the memory foam padding makes movie-length time periods comfortable.The combination of comfort, cross platform capability and superb styling make this our go-to entertainment headset.Rating: Five stars

Bright, bold and blue! It took only one weekend for my youngest son to tell me that wireless controllers aren't all they are cracked up to be. He happily switched over to the Afterglow Wired Controller and hasn't looked back.Funny thing about wireless controllers, players don't often stray beyond the comfortable distance covered by a cord - nearly 10 feet.My 9-year old son says the controller size and plastic texture feels comfortable. He was happy to upgrade as his wireless controller was showing significant signs of wear.Overall, I'm happy with the price and the fact that a corded controller eliminates the need and hassle for batteries, rechargeable or otherwise. My only regret is that the Afterglow Wired Controller wasn't available when we first purchased the Xbox 360.Rating: Five stars

My wife said, "Lipton has good tea, but I'd rather drink their black tea and make my own Chai Tea."Why?"It was really sweet and very strong for me."We're talking about Lipton K-Cup, Delight Chai Tea. Our Keurig has two settings, a 6-ounce cup and a 4-ounce cup."The 6-ounce setting was too strong, so I combined them to make a 10-ounce serving. It was still too strong for me and very sweet. I added some milk, which improved the taste."My wife prefers chai tea with cardamom and fresh ginger. She has purchased Oregon Chai Original Chai Tea Latte Powdered Mix in the past.So, for now, my wife will stick with Lipton's straight teas and pass on the Chai Tea K-Cups."I wouldn't buy it again because it was really hard to tweak it. It is pre-sweetened, overly sweet, with a heavy dose of clove. Too much."Rating: Two starsUPDATE: I've tried a few more preparations and still haven't found a way to cut the sweetness without diluting the spices. I like Lipton K-Cup, Delight Chai Tea best over crushed ice. I drink it quick though, before all the ice melts.

Fourth Down and Inches by Carla Killough McClafferty mines a hot topic - concussions - in the football world, cobbling a slight history, family pictures and heavy heart strings to fill less than 100 pages in an awkward, picture book format.I emphasize "cobbled" because the cover photo - of the NFL Washington Redskins - comes from iStockphoto, nearly a quarter of her source notes cite the New York Times, and only former New England Patriots fullback Kevin Turner is mentioned in the acknowledgments as an interview subject.The NFL isn't even cited in the index.The book starts with the Harvard football team in 1905 and lily-pads eighty years of the game's development to land again with brief mentions of Joe Theismann compound fracture and Ronnie Lott's amputated left pinkie. The narrative fluctuates between medical research on traumatic brain injury and anecdotal stories of high school players.The book's design is too slick for the seriousness of the subject. Adorned with a grass field border on the bottom of each page and a damaged, blurry typeface for chapter headings, the design is a garish hybrid of children's picture book and coffee table decoration. The brain trauma illustrations, and there are many, are flat and do little to complement the narrative. Worse yet are the gratuitous family photos of high school football players who suffered concussions and died. The pictures are too large, oddly cropped and give the book the feel of an obituary.I can't recommend this book, despite the subject matter. Held up next to League of Denial: The NFL, Concussions and the Battle for Truth, McClafferty's book pales in comparison. Her book lacks NFL sources and details that are at the forefront of the concussion issue, and is padded with photos, poetry and generalities like "Football not only unites teams, it also unites the school and the community."Rating: Two stars

I read the account of Garrett Webster's testimony to a Senate Committee in 2007 about his father, Pittsburgh Steelers legend Mike Webster."He asked if anyone in the room had any idea what it was like to shock one's father with a Taser to alleviate his pain; or if they had experienced receiving a desperate phone call from his dad, saying he was about to kill himself to escape the unending torture; or if they had watched a "once-proud, strong man" like Mike Webster beg for Kentucky Fried Chicken. But it was Garrett's story about how his father missed his tenth birthday without so much as a phone call -- a man who once called him practically every night before bed -- that left everyone in the room pondering the future of pro football."I thought of my own father, a machinist by trade, ravaged by hot metal chips flying off a lathe that left his arms covered in scar tissue; the multiple back surgeries to repair damage caused by years of lifting cylinders into the chuck; his tinnitus, a permanent, high-pitched ringing that resulted from decades of industrial work during an era when no one understood or valued ear protection. His generation missed out on safety improvements and workplace protections commonplace today.A "once-proud, strong man" filled my memories and I cried.Webster died at the age of 50 in 2002. He earned four Super Bowl rings and played in nine Pro Bowls during his 17-year career. Webster was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1997, voted to the NFL's all-time team in 2000, and played in more games, 220, than any other player in Steelers history.However, it was the discovery of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) in Webster's autopsy that could overshadow his on-field achievements. CTE was a condition never previously identified in football players. Webster's autopsy provided the first hard evidence linking football to permanent brain damage and, ultimately, the largest settlement in NFL history.League of Denial: The NFL, Concussions and the Battle for Truth details how, over two decades, the National Football League and, specifically, former commissioner Paul Tagliabue, who left office in 2006, and current commissioner Roger Goodell, covered up and denied a growing body of scientific research that revealed the connection between frequent, repetitive hits and brain damage.This book was released on Oct. 8, 2012, the same day the Frontline special, "League of Denial: The NFL's Concussion Crisis" premiered on PBS. The book excerpts appeared in Sports Illustrated and ESPN Magazine.How damaging is `League of Denial' to the NFL? Commissioner Roger Goodell launched spin control via his 10 million email address database a day after the excerpts from the book ran on ESPN.com and in Sports Illustrated. Goodell touted the NFL's increased safety efforts, including launching a new program called "Heads Up Football," which is designed to ensure that coaches are trained and certified in proper tackling techniques as well as concussion and hydration education.The Fainaru brothers wrote:"The NFL's strategy seemed not unlike that of another powerful industry, the tobacco industry, which had responded to its own existential threat by underwriting questionable science through the creation of its own scientific research council and trying to silence anyone who contradicted it. There are many differences, but one is that football's health crisis featured not millions of anonymous victims but very public figures whose grotesque demises seemed almost impossible to reconcile with their personas. One eight-year NFL veteran would kill himself by drinking antifreeze. Another prominent player would crash his Ford pickup into a tanker truck while leading police on a high-speed chase. Two players, Dave Duerson and Junior Seau, would fire handguns into their chests; Seau used a .357 Magnum that his family didn't know he owned to shoot himself in a guest room of his beach house filled with the memorabilia of a legendary 20-year career. As the crisis grew, the brains of those famous players became valuable scientific commodities. A macabre race ensued among researchers to harvest and study them -- even while the bodies were still warm. Minutes after Seau's body was carted out of his house, his oldest son, Tyler, began getting calls seeking his father's brain.Nearly 6,000 retired players and families would ultimately sue the league and Riddell for negligence and fraud. Their argument was that the NFL had "propagated its own industry-funded and falsified research" to conceal the link between football and brain damage.One week before the start of the 2013 season, the NFL settled the case -- agreeing to pay the players $765 million, plus an expected $200 million in legal fees. The NFL did not admit wrongdoing, but the settlement hardly resolved the question at the core of the league's concussion crisis: How dangerous is football to one's brain? Unlike smoking, there was no scientific consensus about the risks of playing football.The NFL settlement - at three quarters of a billion dollars - is still roughly half what ESPN spends annually just for the rights to broadcast `Monday Night Football.' That might explain why ESPN recently cut ties with the Frontline investigation after 15 months of collaboration.One neurosurgeon connected to the NFL said children were more likely to sustain a brain injury riding a bike or falling down. Another neurosurgeon, also connected to the league, called for abolishing tackle football entirely for children younger than 14."The mention of children brought the book home for me. I'm a father of two sons, ages 11 and 9. Would I allow my sons to play football? Aware of the long-term effects of concussions, would you?Rating: Five stars

Having the benefit of multiple perspectives - a preschool teacher (my wife) and two students (my sons, ages 11 and 9) - I felt confident that my five-star review of the 10 Minutes a Day: Math Grade 2 workbook was not unduly influenced by my desire to have my children excel in math.My sons are in the fourth and fifth grades, several years beyond the math level for which this workbook is designed. However, their ability to compare their second-grade math work to this workbook (published by DK Children), was insightful. They are far enough removed from the work to appreciate its presentation while being close enough to offer details that would escape adults. Here are three bullet points that capture their perspective:* Presentation matters: The workbook design is clean, airy and complemented with a balance of color illustrations. Each page is cut out to provide access to a bright orange 10-minute timer.* Instructions: My sons both commented on how the instructions for each math lesson are easy to read and easy to understand. The publisher uses a colored bar atop each page to highlight the instructions, which are never more than 20 words in length.* Timer: It is funny how such a novelty can motivate a young learner. Set a child down and instruct them to do math homework and the results vary. Set a child down with a stopwatch and see them rise to the challenge. Even though the work was relatively easy for my sons, they wanted to test themselves against the clock.In summary, as a parent who wants my children to excel, this workbook is a good investment. At less than $10 each, the workbooks are an affordable addition to classroom exercises.Rating: Five stars

Breakfast in my home has not been the same since my family has taken to making smoothies. They juice fresh carrots, spinach, celery, apples; blend in frozen blueberries, mango and cherries; and add wheat germ, flaxseeds, nut butters and yogurt.So, it should come as no surprise that the KRUPS Infinity Slow Juice Extractor sits on our kitchen counter like a stainless-steel Buddha, treasured and revered by the breakfast crowd. To be fair, the Krupps juicer isn't much larger than other juicing models (perhaps, a tad taller). Although, the stainless-steel finish is attractive enough to justify leaving it out on your counter if you have the space to spare.As for the juicer's performance, it does what it claims and it does it well. Clean up is still about five minutes, standard for counter-top juicers, to disassemble, wash and brush out the last bits of pulp from the basket. The Krupps juicer comes with two stainless steel baskets, a fine and coarser grid to accommodate everything from juice to sauces and smoothies.TIPS:* Read the manual. Additional instructions are on the company's website. This juicer uses an auger to compress the ingredients instead of chopping them up with blades.* Practice assembling and disassembling the juicer a couple times before you embark on your first adventure.* Cut your ingredients into smaller pieces. The feeder holes are smaller than what you'll find on other juicer models. Also, the auger handles some foods (e.g. spinach) differently than blade models. The results are better but you need to make some adjustments in your prep work.Finally, The parts are dishwasher safe, a feature that my wife greatly appreciated. The juicer comes with a two-year warranty, a feature that I greatly appreciated.Rating: Five stars

Seasoned business travelers are often proficient techies who, no doubt, would argue that there are other batteries on the market that can offer similar benefits for less cost. No argument from me on that point. However, if you aren't a one-suitcase, three-flights-a-week business traveler who and still need a reliable, easy-to-use universal battery, then the Duracell Powermat GoPower Overnighter is smart buy.We tested the GoPower Overnighter with a tablet and smartphones and were pleased with the charging results for both.When used with a Duracell Powermat, the wireless charging evoked the famous phrase, "Set It And Forget It!" from Ronco's Famous Rotisserie Oven infomercials. That reference has merit since both products appeal to a customer base that doesn't want to fuss and fidget with an instruction manual and a zippered pouch of multiple charging cables.The GoPower Overnighter is the Christmas gift you give your parents, or grandparents, who use a smartphone and a tablet, and who often travel to visit the family.In summary, is the GoPower Overnighter more expensive than other batteries on the market? Yes. Is the GoPower Overnighter the simplest, most portable battery that provides a charge rate comparable to being plugged into an outlet? YES!Rating: Five stars

I prefer dark, bold coffee. No cream; no sugar; and certainly no infused flavors or shots of syrup. However, during the holiday season, I tend to stray from routine.My nose caught the sweet fragrance of caramel crme as my wife tested Martinson Joe's Caramel Crme K-Cup coffee (we received a small box to test through the Amazon Vine program).She likes lighter, sweeter coffee. Given the choice of a dozen roses or a Venti Pumpkin Spice Latte from Starbucks, she would gladly drink another, thank you very much.While Martinson Joe's Caramel Crme K-Cup coffee doesn't rise to the decadent level of that concoction, it should be noted in fairness that a single K-Cup costs ten times less than the Starbucks beverage.I can't recommend this coffee to drinkers who generally eschew flavored blends. You know who you are and, no, this blend probably won't change your mind. However, if you are like me and find yourself straying from routine during the holidays, Martinson Joe's Caramel Crme K-Cup coffee is a pleasant treat.Rating: Four stars

Author Jeff Tapia's footnoted construction stands out among children's books for this age group. Tapia is swimming against the stream here. Most popular fiction for this age group is so saturated in illustrations as to push books into comic-book territory.The story in a nutshell: twins Jimmy and Stella restore the titular creation to save the town of Wymore. The book's humor is buried inside thick layers of diner slang and colloquial phrases and copious explanatory footnotes that occasionally break the fourth wall of entertainment.Tapia's footnotes reminded me of the challenge and struggle my sons had earlier this year with Margarita Engle's Mountain Dog, a book written in free verse. My advice to parents is to welcome more challenging reading experiences like this and encourage your children expand their reading experience beyond the angst-ridden middle school series -- the fast food of the children's publishing universe -- populating the book shelves.It wasn't long into reading Hippomobile! my son, Kai, was making comparisons to Ian Fleming's Chitty Chitty Bang Bang and Daniel Pinkwater's Adventures of a Cat-Whiskered Girl, two other imaginative adventures designed for ages 9-12 (grades 4-7).In summary, the book is a silly adventure that occasionally needs more action, more humor and more adherence to a forward-moving plot. I highly recommend you read the Amazon review written by "Just Trying to Help." That reviewer provides a short version and a long version, the latter of which is a must read before buying this book.Rating: Four stars.

2:44 MinsI ask my sons Kai (age 11) and Kou (age 9) to help me with book reviews. My start here on Amazon began with the picture books I would read to them at bedtime. Over the years, the picture books evolved into chapter books and my nighttime reading became their own.Not every book they read is a pleasant experience. I push and cajole them to read different genre, to expand their horizons. Occasionally, though, I provide them with sheer entertainment. Books like Stick Dog by Tom Watson and The Strange Case of Origami Yoda by Tom Angleberger. These are fast and funny reads with a cotton candy quality that provides a nice break from the more serious (read: grim) classic stories for young adults.Please watch Kou's book review. His enthusiasm for Mark Tatulli's book Desmond Pucket is undeniable. Kou gives the book a five-star rating.Even more telling is that his older brother is chomping at the bit to read it next.Rating: Five starsJUNE 2014 UPDATE: Kou told me that Desmond Pucket was one of the hardest books to reserve at his school library because of its popularity. He said his friends plan to buy a copy and take it on their summer vacations.

Carrots, Radishes, Cucumbers, lend me your earsI come to bury calories, not to praise them.The evil that fat does lives after ThanksgivingThe good is oft interred with veggie sticksSsamjang is a spicier, less-fattening, and more versatile condiment than Ranch dressing. Ssamjang -- Ssam is Korean for "wrap," and jang means "paste" -- is a thick, fermented sauce used as a vegetable dip or a topping for wraps. The sauce from a cultured soybean base called doenjang (fermented soy bean paste), chilli paste, fresh garlic, onions, scallions, and sesame oil.This Korean staple can be used as a vegetable dip, a condiment for Korean BBQ lettuce wraps, which include grilled meat and pickled vegetables like kimchi (pickled Napa cabbage), or combined with mayonnaise to create a bold and salty sandwich spread.The lettuce wraps are simple and delicious. Just wash green leafy vegetables like lettuce and place one flat in your hand. Add a slice of slow-roasted pork belly, bulgogi or whatever cooked meat you like. Add a dab of ssamjang, wrap and enjoy.Ingredients: Soybean paste 56% (Water, Soybean, Wheat flour, Salt, Wheat, Malt), Maltose syrup, Wheat flour, Water, Sugar, Cooking rice wine, Salt, Onion, Wheat, Red pepper powder, Shiitake mushroom extract, Garlic extract, Sesame seed, Soybean powder, Garlic, Red pepper paste, Glucose, Koji (Contains Barley).Allergen warning: Soya, Gluten, Wheat, Barley, Sesame.Storage: Keep in dry and cool place. Once opened, keep refrigerated.Shelf life: 12 months.Rating: Five stars

Duck Brand duct tape is the universal fix-it for campers and hikers. Sticky on the inside with a heavy-duty adhesive and slick and waterproof on the outside, Duck Brand duct tape reduces the friction that causes blisters.Type "hiking blister" on YouTube and you'll find step-by-step instructional videos that illustrate how to prep your feet with duct tape to prevent blisters as well as how to protect your feet after a blister forms. Blisters can quickly ruin a hike, so it is important to wrap strips of this silver-colored duct tape around your trekking poles or water bottle. For longer trips, I recommend taking a whole roll.As a repair kit, Duck Brand duct tape is second to none in the outdoors. Patch holes in your tent, reinforce a torn backpack strap, or hold together a pair of shoes long enough to get back home. I've read about hikers using it for rope, zipper pulls, belts and camp sandals, too.I use Duck Brand duct tape on my own feet and I take it along on my hikes and camping trips. I can't imagine going hiking or camping without it.Rating: Five stars

"Crap." "Ass." Fingerprints of middle-school humor smear the story but the book doesn't quite fall off the cliff into South Park territory. Broken families are en vogue in young adult literature and Travis' story (he's the protagonist and narrator) follows in line. His mother remarried, Travis spends a summer with his grandmother (his dead father's mother) in rural Minnesota.The quirkiness of the characters and the surroundings immediately conjured up the 1996 film, Fargo. While that's not a film for my 9-year old son, who I asked to read this book along with me, it is a good point of reference for parents who have watched the Coen brothers' comedy of errors.Author Lisa Bullard wants to turn heads (literally and figuratively). She opens the book:"There were so many dead bodies stuffed into Gram's freezer chest that it was kind of like wandering through a cryonics lab. You know, one of those place where they turn rich old guys into Popsicles? Gram had been hearing odd noise from her cellar for a while now, and she was convinced it was this dying freezer she kept there. So my punishment for the day was to clean it out and stuff everything into these jack-o'-lantern leaf bags that Gram had been saving since who knows how many Halloweens ago."My 9-year old son doesn't know who Ted Williams was, much less that his frozen head in kept in Florida, awaiting a scientific breakthrough that will put The Splendid Splinter back in the ballpark.In trying to step beyond her past work in picture books, it felt as though Bullard wasn't entirely comfortable settling into children's books. Trying to be a mystery, a coming-of-age story, a wry comedy, the book ended up without a clear identity; the mishmash overwrought at times.In summary, I didn't care for the snarky tone or the Nickelodeon sense of humor. Here's three examples:* "It stinks like `Snakes on a Plane' stank."* "Holy crap, dodo -- I don't think we're in California anymore."* "Since all the people in the room had their eyes closed, I thought it was the perfect time for me to send up a little prayer of my own, asking the Big Guy Upstairs to levitate me out of there or maybe turn me invisible while nobody was looking."Rating: Three stars

"Here's blood in the kitchen, there's blood in the hall:Here's blood in the parlor, where the lady did fall.False Lamkin shall be hung on the gallows so high,While his bones shall be burned in the fire close by."Dark notes abound in Catherine Jinks' fantasy novel, the first in a trilogy set in Victorian London. What does the title mean? Bogle = monster. Catch = kill. However, a title of "How to Kill a Monster" isn't' as catchy.Designed for Harry Potter fans searching for a new fantasy fix, author Catherine Jinks presents Bogle-killing master Alfred Bunce and his 10-year old apprentice, Birdie McAdam. Birdie isn't so much a "Go-Devil Man" like Bunce as she is monster bait: her singing voice attracts monsters from dark places.Perhaps intentionally, Birdie reminds us of Pippi Longstocking by Astrid Lindgren and Harriet the Spy by Louise Fitzhugh. Of the three, How to Catch a Bogle is the darkest tale, so prepare accordingly. The monsters are only part of the East London menace. Birdie chooses Bogle hunting over the paupers' school, the workhouse, or living on the street, begging and stealing to survive.In addition to the Dickensian pot of social miseries, the prodigious Cockney accent and the interspersed English folk ballads together make this book a bit more of a challenge than most 9-year old readers tackle. Parents are advised to stay close, answer questions and allay concerns as they arise.Rating: Five stars

THE STORY OF WOMEN AND POWER is a BBC television three-part documentary written and presented by historian Amanda Vickery (THE STORY OF WOMEN AND ART), who teaches early modern history at Queen Mary University of London; shes an award-winning author who also reviews for The Guardian and BBC Radio. In this history, she considers the centuries-long struggle of women for their political and sexual equality.  Suffragists, as I prefer to call these brave women who struggled with society, their families, their husbands, rather than the more common, cutesy term suffragettes, endured many challenges in their fight for women's political influence. For many centuries, women were owned as chattel by their fathers/brothers/husbands, had no right to their own lands, money, children.  In this sweeping, often shocking series, Vickery tells the untold story of British women's battles in the centuries-old war of women vs. men.This illuminating documentary features the stories of some of the most notable women in British history. Vickery profiles key figures including Mary Wollstonecraft, the mother of feminism; Hannah More, who found ways for women to enter public life; suffragist  leader Emmeline Pankhurst; Queen Victoria, who had progressive views on womens rights. She discusses the tragedy of a suffragist who apparently committed suicide on the race course at the Epsom Derby, longtime social highlight of the year. She enlightens us on Margaret Thatcher, who , decades ago, served as the first female Prime Minister in the U.K. The historian shows us a museum piece, a frightening torture device for women deemed scolds by their husbands, which would restrict their ability to speak. She visits the Houses of Parliament, Queen Victoria's holiday home, and a livestock market where men once sold their wives at auction. (She tells us that ,over the years,  there are at least 300 documented cases of men selling their wives). And she converses frankly with other experts, among them current Member of Parliament Stella Creasy and the son of Nancy Astor, the first female member of parliament (MP).Vickery guides us through history, from an early march for women's rights in 1649 to a notorious incident in 1738, when the Duchess of Queensberry crashed the House of Lords, to the militant activities of the Edwardian suffragists, the modern-day campaigns that remind us the fight is not yet over. The DVD release coincides with the upcoming release of the new film SUFFRAGETTE that stars three-time Oscar winner Meryl Streep as Emmeline Pankhurst, Cary Mulligan and Helena Bonham Carter. The presenter does limit herself to Great Britain, which I found a pity: Id have preferred information on parallel developments on the continent of Europe, and here in the United States.  Nevertheless,  the narrative is richly told; footage found, travel to places of unusual interest made across the country.  And the documentary has resonance beyond the British Isles. It also has subtitles, thank goodness, as Vickery moves and speaks swiftly. The boxed set , which I received as a review copy, consists of one single DVD, containing three episodes running approximately 180 mins. A lively, accurate, engaged history lesson that might open some eyes.

MISS FISHERS MURDER MYSTERIES, Series Three. In this Australian television series, Essie Davis (THE SLAP, THE BABADOOK), stars as the title character, as she returns as Miss Phryne Fisher, a lady detective from Melbourne with a stylish  wardrobe, a sense of fun, a gold revolver and a flair for solving crimes. The entertainment, based on the novels of Kerry Greenwood, is set in the late 1920s: Australia is slowly recovering from  World War I. In what might perhaps best be described as an historic, light-hearted romantic comedy mystery series, Miss Fisher continues her unconventional antics, solving crimes with the help of her ensemble of household cohorts and the suave dedicated Detective Jack Robinson, (Nathan Page, THE SECRET LIFE OF US), with whom she shares a playful partnership.  Although she often outraces him to the crime scene. In the current costume series, which is being shown in the United States on select PBS stations in syndication, we watch as, despite Jacks efforts to keep matters on a professional level, their partnership grows  more personal. Phryne and Jacks developing relationship is matched by the on-again, off-again romance of Phrynes assistant, Dot Williams (Ashleigh Cummings, TOMORROW, WHEN THE WAR BEGAN), and Jacks constable, Hugh Collins (Hugo Johnstone-Burt, SAN ANDREAS). Also present to enjoy the fun is Phrynes Aunt Prudence (Aunt P), played by the highly-esteemed  veteran of stage and screen, award-winning actress Miriam Margolyes, who has achieved success on both sides of the Atlantic. (She won the 1993  BAFTA Best Supporting Actress award  for THE AGE OF INNOCENCE(1993);also won Best Supporting Actress at the 1989 LA Critics Circle Awards for her role in LITTLE DORRIT (1987).But Miss Fishers  estranged father, Lord Henry George Fisher, Henry, Baron of Richmond, arrives  unannounced after selling up the family estate in England. As Phrynes father does his best to ingratiate himself with her household: Dot, Bert, Cec and Mr. Butler, his roguish charm is lost on his own daughter. Phryne recalls a secret encounter that she witnessed during the War, between her father and the cousin from whom the Fishers inherited their title; she begins to suspect that her ancestor is still alive and could be out to exact his revenge.  Also, Phryne's Aunt Prudence takes on more than she bargained for when she opens her home to psychiatrist and natural healer, Hayden Samuels. And when Phryne hosts a tennis tournament to raise money for female tennis players, the practice partner of a rising tennis star is fatally bitten by a funnel-web spider, sparking a murder investigation that reveals one of Phryne's hidden fears.In 1920s Melbourne, Phryne (apparently pronounced Frinee) Fisher is a rather liberated, modern woman operating  in a male-dominated world. (It is also a world in which aborigines and ethnics are apparently invisibleor caricatured.) And just to get it off my chest, as the daughter of a baron, Phryne should be addressed as the Honourable Miss Fisher, or Lady Phryne, but apparently they dont do that in Australia, and whos counting.  At any rate, the Melbourne scenery is splendid in high-definition, the historic costumeswhich are outstanding, flappers galore,  interiors and modes of transport appear to be accurate for the period. The acting is uniformly fine. The plots are sharply written, smart and fresh; the dialog is witty as this female cross between the Saint and James Bond goes about her business. The episodes are:1.Death Defying Feats. Dot, Cec and Bert are having a night out, see the magic show The Mighty MacKenzie and the Cavalcade of Mysteries. First, the guillotine trick: the machine is tested on a cabbage head first, works fine.  Then it decapitates Miss Pearl, the magicians assistant and fiance.2.Murder and the Maiden.  Night time; outside the chain link fence surrounding the RAAF Victorian Command HQ, a desperate woman runs, crying for help. A figure catches up with her; gloved hands strangle her as we watch, horrified.3.Murder and the Mozzarella. A tenor sings La Donna e Mobile in the background; an elderly woman is attacked in an Italian restaurant kitchen.  Nonna Luisa, iron-fisted matriarch of the restaurant family, expires.4.Blood & Money. Paddy, a street kid, hires Phryne to find his missing brother Ned.  We discover two more members of their gang murdered; see that Phryne is really troubled by the loss of young lives.5 .Death & Hysteria.  Phyrnes Aunt Prudence feels indebted to Dr. Samuels, a psychiatrist who had helped her son, Arthur, before he died, and is also now trying to help her deal with her grief after the death. Samuels loses his office space; grateful Aunt P lets him temporarily set up his sanatorium for wealthy women, and their problems, in her mansion. The women have all been diagnosed with hysteria, a Freudian diagnosis  meaning they were sexually unsatisfied. This is an interesting episode, addressing the problems with womens sexuality that the medical establishment had trouble recognizing, much less attempting to ameliorate: an early medical vibrator is important to the plot.6 .Death at the Grand. On the rooftop of a hotel that has seen better days, a man begs for his life; his knife-wielding stalker snarls, Wheres the money? Failing to get the answer he wants, the assailant pushes the pleading man off the roof. Inspector Robinson calls Phryne to the crime scene. Not to consult with. But because the dead man was holding a satchel labeled: Property of Miss Phryne Fisher. Phyrnes father is involved.7.Game, Set & Murder.  Stanley Burrows, one of Phyrnes oldest friends, has married Constance, a tennis pro. Phyrne sponsors a fund-raising tournament; top players have arrived in Melbourne to participate. Theyre at Aunt Ps place, practicing on her tennis court. Theres a terrible accident. Player Bell Rosewell, Constances frequent partner, is bitten by a spider, one known to bite repeatedly to make it more dangerous, that lives only in moist dark vegetation, that  isnt native to Melbourne. Thats stuck in her shoe.8. Death Do Us Part. The backstory of Henry George Fisher, Baron of Richmond, is finally revealed. At a cost, including the death of Mr. Quentin Tode, recent winner of the Wren Institute of Science annual prize, found dead in his observatory, his eyes and hands glowing bright blue.The box series consists of a three disc set; eight episodes running approximately 448 minutes. Bonuses include: behind the scenes footage (35 mins.); character clips (7 mins.); Mr. Butlers Drink of the Week, (8 mins.).  And a behind-the-scenes photo gallery. Be aware, there is some violence, nudity and sexual situations, though they are not heavy.  Thank goodness, there are subtitles, for those of us not too familiar with Australian lingo.  I received this as a review copy.  Davis, whom we will soon see in next seasons GAME OF THRONES, makes a swashbuckling leading lady, who does always find her manor woman.  Shes entertaining as can be.  So is the series.

Scarlet Women: The Scandalous Lives of Courtesans, Concubines, and Royal Mistresses, by Ian Graham.  The existence of courtesans, concubines and royal mistresses is a reflection of the fact that historically, throughout the world, marriages of royalty, nobility and even the wealthy were made for dynastic, family reasons, not love or even lust.  Powerful, rich men might well find themselves with wives who were unattractive, slow-witted, poorly educated, poorly dressed.  SCARLET WOMEN tells the stories of the most notorious courtesans, concubines and royal mistresses. Its contents range from the ancient world to the present day, from Europe and America to the Far East.Courtesans, you see, were an elite group of talented, professional mistresses, outstanding in beauty, wit, education, fashion sense, the most successful of whom became wealthy and famous in their own right.  They led charmed lives, enjoyed freedom and political power unknown  to most women of their time and place, but were ostracized by what once was known as polite society.  This book ranges from the hetaerae of ancient Greece to the cortigiani onesti of 16th century Venice, the oiran of Edo-period Japan to the demimondaines of 19th century France.  Concubines were secondary, subsidiary wives in societies where they were allowed; mistresses, of course, had but one lover.The extraordinary women featured in the book include:-Cora Pearl, who served herself naked on a platter at her legendary parties;-Harriette Wilson, who blackmailed her clients;-Clara Ward, an American woman who married a Belgian prince and then ran away with a gypsy violinist;-Klondike Kate, queen of the Yukon during the Klondike gold rush;-Veronica Franco, the leading sixteenth century Venetian courtesan;-Mesdames de Pompadour and du Barry, two of Louis XVs many mistresses;-Nell Gwyn, the saucy orange-seller who captivated British King Charles II;-Marie Walewska, Napoleon Bonapartes reluctant Polish mistress;-Cixi, a concubine who rose from obscurity to rule China;-La Belle Otero, last of the great European courtesans,a volcanic Spanish beauty. Her patrons included Kaiser Wilhelm II, the Prince of Wales (later King Edward VII) and Grand Duke Nicholas of Russia. She accumulated an enormous fortune, but gambled it all away, died in obscure poverty;-Marie Duplessis inspired characters by both Dumas and Verdi;-Ninon de LEnclos, offered 50,000 crowns for one night by the wily, powerful royal advisor Cardinal Richelieu; money left in her will paid for the education of Voltaire, great 18th century French thinker.Ian Graham is a British author of popular science, technology and history books. He studied physics and journalism at university, worked as a magazine journalist before switching to authorship; he was a joint winner of the 2012 Royal Society Young People's Book Prize, was shortlisted for the 2014 Educational Writers' Award.  This book is written at the young adult level, but never mind, it is light, bright and breezy, a quick read.  Its emphasis does appear to be on the famous royal mistresses and courtesans of France.  The big question to my mind: wherever on earth are the pictures of these women, such as are available?  Dont tell me they were beautiful, show me!

AT-A-GLANCE QuickNotes Weekly / Monthly Appointment Book / Planner, 12 Months, January Start, 8.25 x 10.88, Black (7695005). This appointment book, which covers 12 months, from January to December, allows both week and weekend days to be broken down into quarter-hourly appointments.  From 8:00 a.m. to 8:45 p.m.which allows for clear scheduling and planning. The two page per week layout is column-style with  full-length vertical column for each day including a single column for QuickNotes, highlighted yellow. One page monthly calendars feature ruled daily blocks and lie adjacent to a full QuickNotes page. Two past and six future month reference calendars are also shown,  federal holidays highlighted in red. It comes with a storage pocket;  premium paper resists ink bleed and contains 30% post-consumer waste. It is wirebound; black simulated leather cover. 8.25 in. x 10.88 in. page size.Well, its not yet 2016, ya know, and Ive not yet begun using this marvel of a diary, but the Vine rules say I must review it now.  So, it sure looks good, and as if theyve thought of everything and then some.  Approve of recycling effort. Dont really need to break my life down into quarter hour appointments  aside from the odd doctors appointmentretired, ya know.  But its a feature that might come in handy and does no harm.  And, as I am a crazed maker of lists and agendas, the highlighted QuickNotes pages and columns should sure come in handy.  Like the size and weight, not too big or heavy. Dont see any down side.

Solid Gold Furrever Young Holistic Dry Cat Food, Turkey, Brown Rice & Cranberry, Less Active Adult Cats, All Sizes, 4lb Bag. This food is intended for less active, mature, adult cats according to its makers.  It will hopefully support his/her activities with a well-balanced, nutrient-rich formula that combines turkey meat, a lean protein, vitamin and mineral rich whole grains and antioxidant inclusions with vitamin e and c plus cranberries.  Combined with the manufacturers Gold Source core nutrition, a proprietary blend of powerful nutrients.  This Gold Source core nutrition consists of egg - nature's perfect protein with essential amino acids to support your pet's muscle growth and metabolism; Omega fatty acid blend - an optimum balance of omega -3 and -6 fatty acids to promote immune system function, plus skin and coat health. Taurine and l-carnitine - taurine to support heart health and l-carnitine to help burn fat and maintain muscle mass. Ocean fish meal - a balanced protein to help support muscle growth. Probiotics and natural prebiotic fiber - to support your pet's digestion. Vitamins c and e - nature's antioxidants to help support your pet's immune system and long term health. And: super food inclusions - nutrient-packed ingredients like carrots, pumpkin, cranberries, blueberries, broccoli, almond oil, kelp and lentils.Yeah, yeah. Plus, Divo, now 7+ years and slowing down,  liked it immediately.  I didnt have to mix it in with kibble he was already on, which cats usually require before switching to new food.  Put it in his dish, he sniffed it, dived in, licked his chops. He likes it, I like it.

Thrse Raquin tells the dark story of a young woman (in the title role, Oscar-nominated Kate Nelligan, THE CIDER HOUSE RULES, THE PRINCE OF TIDES), bored with her restricted, mundane life and trapped in a marriage with her perennially ill, feebleminded and apparently impotent first cousin, Camille (Kenneth Cranham, MALEFICENT). The BBC three part television serial originally debuted in 1981; in the United States, it was shown on Masterpiece Theatre. A historical costume drama, it is based on the classic 1867 scandalous novel and play by famous French author mile Zola: it was shot on gritty Parisian streets and in the idyllic countryside. In it, Camille brings home their childhood friend, Laurent (Brian Cox, THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, BRAVEHEART). (The three young people had shared an achingly free childhood on the river).Once remet, the romantic chemistry between Thrse and Laurent is instantaneous: they begin an affair. The strong  ensemble cast garnered wide acclaim for their performances, with Nelligan hailed as electrifying and Cox as superb (Daily Express, UK), in this BAFTA Award-winning miniseries also starring Alan Rickman (SENSE AND SENSIBILITY, DIE HARD, Harry Potter films) and Mona Washbourne (MY FAIR LADY).  This classic, star-studded tale, made in the days when the BBC really knew how to make historic costume dramas, has been released to coincide with a new Broadway adaptation of the play starring  Keira Knightley and Judith Light.The Canadian-born Nelligan had been tipped to be a major star, which never happened, but shes superb here, carrying the production with extraordinary power and sensuality.  And her performance does shoot sparks in a production that cannot be called cheerful. (Personally, I am surprised that no grand opera was ever made based on this material; it has all the ingredients.) Direction was by the noted Simon Langton. Photography is evocative, though, perhaps too evocative for some, as the streets of Paris, the city of light, have never looked more drab and gray. The riverside scenes, however, are simply dreamy. Of course, costuming, interiors and dialog are appropriate to the age: this is a BBC production, after all. Unfortunately, the age of the original material means that it could not always be updated perfectly for this release. I received this as a review copy. The box set contains one DVD on which are all three episodes, totaling approximately 166 minutes. With subtitles, thank goodness.This dark, rather slow-moving tale of forbidden love will not be everyones cup of tea  and how the French do drink tea in this production.  Nevertheless, it has grandeur, and is powerful, with some hot-blooded sex scenes. I loved it.

Iron House, (2012), by  North Carolina author and former criminal defense attorney John Hart. This thriller follows on the heels of the New York Times bestselling crime novels THE KING OF LIES, DOWN RIVER, and THE LAST CHILD. Hart is the only author in history to win the best novel Edgar Award for consecutive novels; he has also won the Barry Award and England's Steel Dagger Award for best thriller of the year.
