His books, to date, all of which I have reviewed and loved, have been set in North Carolina: generally the mountainous west of the state.As his earlier works, IRON HOUSE is centered on families, stressed and in danger, several of them in this complex, multilevel work.  At its heart are Julian and Michael, who are apparently orphans, marooned at the Iron Mountain Home for Boys, where there was nothing but time. Enough for them to learn that life is not easy. Julian, physically and mentally weak,  survives only because his bigger older brother, Michael, is both feared and fiercely protective. When Julian brutally kills an older bully,  Michael takes the rap to protect his brother,  flees the orphanage in a snow storm. For two decades, he does well on the streets of New York, eventually making a bountiful living as a mob enforcer for Otto Kaitlin. But this life begins to unravel when he meets Elana, who knows nothing of his past. Michael now wants a fresh start, the chance to build a family of his own. But organized crime does not allow for retirement. As a hunted man, everyone he loves at risk, Michael carries Elena back to North Carolina, to the side of the brother he'd lost so long ago.Harts books have been translated into twenty-nine languages and can be found in over fifty countries. He has worked as a banker, stockbroker, and apprentice helicopter mechanic. Now a husband and father of two, he spends his time in North Carolina and Virginia. I saw him speak as a younger man, several years ago, at a mystery festival sponsored by the local Wilmington, N.C. library.  He was, of course, intelligent, well-spoken, with a fair amount of wit.  As in his earlier works, the author does a fine job of giving us the geography, flora, fauna, roads and transportation, social peculiarities of  North Carolina and neighboring states.  And New York too.  His narrative and descriptive are crisp, his dialog cuts.  The suspenseful plot sucks you in from the first page, and, despite the writers literate broodings on the nature of family, doesnt let up to the last.  There are touches of Southern Gothic-- greatly exaggerated characters -- to be sure, again as in his previous novelsin a pair of very nasty mothers.  This book is certainly more violent than his earlier works, with a much higher body count  in fact, a very high  and bloody body count.  I dont mind that, but, if you do, beware.  Its entirely possible that this book is more commercially-oriented than its predecessors.  Who cares.  Not me.  I love it, as I did his earlier works.

Viva Labs High Absorption CoQ10 with BioPerine, 100 mg, 150 count,from Viva Labs.  This health aid, according to its manufacturers, promotes powerful cellular defense that supports the bodys production of energy in each cell.  It is especially critical  in maintaining  healthy cardiovascular and circulatory systems. The product features BioPerine,  a patented black pepper extract shown to improve the absorption of CoQ10 by at least 30%. Each softgel contains 5mg of this powerful compound, significantly enhancing its bioavailability. The formula also contains fruit extract, extra-virgin olive oil, gelatin, vegetable glycerin, beeswax and purified water.  It has been  USP Pharmaceutical graded, is 100% naturally fermented.  CoQ10 has been clinically shown to promote heart health by supplying energy, strengthening heart muscle and improving oxygen delivery. It also helps maintain healthy cholesterol and blood sugar levels - CoQ10 is required for a variety of metabolic pathways including promoting "good" HDL cholesterol and monitoring blood glucose. The health aid also has a natural power enhancer, a powerful cofactor known for its ability to improve endurance, helping to increase overall performance among individuals. It can help fortify cognitive and immune functions. In addition, CoQ10 helps to defend cells against the effects of harmful oxidation, shown to support healthy aging, and assist in exercise recovery. (Oxidation also hinders physical activity.)  Each small, easy to swallow softgel contains 100mg of CoQ10 with 150 softgels in each bottle.Most importantly to me, this health product is also widely recommended to users of statins, which most heart patients are: and many of us are considered heart patients these days.  Have been told that the use of statins produces cramps. I have long been bothered with cramps, sometimes extremely painful, in my legs and feet upon awakening in the morning.  This product was recommended to me to ameliorate that, and it has, slowly.  The cramps gradually got milder.  This morning there were none.  A very good thing.

LOUISES WAR, (2011), by award-winning North Carolina author Sarah Shaber, is first in her popular historical  mystery series: it stars, and is narrated by, Louise Pearlie, a young widow working for the Office of Strategic Services in Washington, DC, during World War II.  It follows on the heels of the writers well-known Simon Shaw series.It's 1942.  Louise Pearlie, a young widow, has left her familys fish camp in coastal Wilmington, North Carolina; come to Washington DC to work as a clerk for the legendary Wild Bill Donovans Office of Strategic Services, precursor to the CIA.  She is employed in the Research and Analysis Branch, discovers a document concerning the husband of her dear college friend Rachel Bloch-a young French Jewish woman Louise is desperately worried about; realizes she may be able to help Rachel escape from Vichy France just ahead of the Gestapo with its plans to send all French Jews to concentration camps. Rachels husband, Gerald Bloch, is a hydrography expert on the coastline of French North Africa; he has knowledge critical for the soon-to-come Allied invasion of that continent.  Accordingly, the man has requested asylum for his Jewish wife and child while he joins the Resistance to fight the Nazis.  Louise  takes the Bloch file to her supervisor. Who is found dead in his ransacked office-- the file missing.Louise resolves to find the file, get it to Gen. Donovan, have him initiate plans to bring Rachel to the States. But it's difficult for Louise to know whom to trust. She fends off several would-be suitors who may be Vichy supporters. One of them takes her to a party  at a posh mansion, home of famous Washington based hostess/heiress Evalyn McLain, where the file clerk chats with Clark Gable. Louise frets over FBI agents staking out her boarding house, breaks into the French embassy for more information on Gerald Bloch. She's confused about her fellow boarder, the Czech Joe Prager, who may or may not actually be a professor of Slavic languages.Is this crime drama chick lit?  Without a doubt, set in the classical world of white-glove wearing women and their concerns, with no onscreen blood, violence, sex, profanity. I have not been previously familiar with the authors work, although I believe I may once have seen her speak at a meeting of my local Wilmington, N.C.-based, mystery book club.  But reviewers familiar with the writers Simon Shaw series say that, while the Louise books are still best described as light-in-tone cozies, they are less so than Shaber's Simon Shaw series. LOUISES WAR  has been followed by LOUISE'S GAMBLE, LOUISE'S DILEMMA, LOUISES BLUNDER and LOUISES CHANCE.  The authors Professor Simon Shaw murder mysteries are now available as eBooks. She's also the author of a stand-alone horror novel, BLOOD TEST, and editor of TAR HEEL DEAD, a collection of short stories by North Carolina mystery writers. Anyone familiar with my work as a reviewer will know that chick-lit cozies are not my cuppa; I prefer darker work, and dont mind sex, violence and profanity at all. Still, this book does illustrate just how narrow minded 1940s society was, with women expected to wear hats and stockings, accept lesser, lesser-paying jobs, get coffee for their bosses; homosexuals to hide their preferences, people of color to accept job discrimination. And, as a 10-year resident of Wilmington, N.C. I enjoyed the authors portrait of the earlier city, and its popular, plentiful  smelly--fish camps.  It gets an extra star for that.

CHASING SHADOWS.  This British television series by ITV is akin to detective dramas with currently fashionable flawed detectives, brilliant at their work but socially inept heroes like Bones, Monk and Sherlock. In this current day, London-set police procedural, DS Sean Stone (Reece Shearsmith, THE WIDOWER, THE LEAGUE OF GENTLEMEN) possesses an uncanny knack for seeing patterns where others dont, getting inside the minds of serial killers. His ability makes him a brilliant detective, but hes hindered by a personality disorder that rubs colleagues the wrong way. Following a workplace blunder-- Stone embarrasses his chief at the Metropolitan police force, (the Met), at a news  conference. A conference meant to celebrate the MetsStones  successful solving of a case.  The detective  is demoted from the homicide division to the Missing Persons Bureau, seconded for life, where hes forced to team up with his polar opposite: warm, empathetic analyst Ruth Hattersley (Alex Kingston, ER, DOCTOR WHO,UPSTAIRS DOWNSTAIRS).  This four-part British mystery series, which I received as a review copy, also stars Noel Clarke (STAR TREK INTO DARKNESS, DOCTOR WHO) as DI Carl Prior, Stones police counterpart.  It comes as a two disc set containing four episodes, running approximately 183 minutes. With subtitles, thank goodness, for those of us not up-to-date with London slang.The intense, socially awkward Stone and Hattersley, mismatched partners, clash from the start. Nevertheless, Stone dives headfirst into the bureaus massive database  as many as 300,000 people go missing in the United Kingdom every year -- to spot signs of serial killers behind some cases. Did the lonely teenage girl who posted on a suicide message board kill herself? Why did a lawyer and devoted family man disappear? To find the missing,  and protect societys most vulnerable from the evil that may stalk them, Stone will have to reckon with his own personality flaws before they destroy his career; harness Hattersleys talents. Also starring Don Warrington as the chief, the very same role he plays in MURDER IN PARADISE; Alfie Field (THE WOMAN IN BLACK).  Guest starring the mega talented Susan Lynch, a North Ireland-born actress who seems to have worked without stop since her debut in THE COMMITMENTS, going on to such as CRACKER, WAKING NED DEVINE, ELIZABETH:THE GOLDEN AGE. This dark, sophisticated crime drama features smart scripts, strong performances.  And has no onscreen sex, profanity, or violence. The episodes are:1. Only Connect, Part 1. After publicly criticizing police procedure upon the eventual capture of a serial killer, DS Sean Stone, who seems never to take off his raincoat, is sent to the Missing Persons Bureau. There he begins to track Leanne, possible multiple murderer  the usage Stone prefers -- of vulnerable teenagers.2. Only Connect, Pt. 2. In trying to track Leanne, Sean and Prior arrive at an eerie disused shopping mall, to find Ruth, whod gone to meet Leanne, with a bad head wound. Prior's concerned  about Ruth's injury; Sean's more concerned about whether she got a clear look at Leanne.3. Off Radar, Pt. 1. Sean, sorting through the deluge of missing persons cases coming into the office, singles out one that doesn't seem to fit the normal categories. And if there's one thing Sean finds more interesting than someone who fits a pattern, it's someone who doesnt.4. Off Radar, Pt. 2.  A convicted multiple murderer who is being kept in a secure mental hospital dies: police brass want to bury the whole affair and move on. But Sean's not so sure.  This episode ends on a cliffhanger; in this house we  sure hope  therell be a second series.CHASING SHADOWS is well-written, with tight scripts, good dialogue, appropriate chat in the cop shops. Uniformly good acting.  Its well photographed.  And it gives us the highs and lows of its world: striking views of London, an immensely impressive imperial city, also views of abandoned factories, malls: its gritty to the taste.  And witty. The entertainment is quietly funny, warm in its presentation of people who are concerned about each other. While still keeping the viewer glued to the edge of his/her seat.  Another binge-watcher in this house, we gobbled up its four episodes

The Wild West with Ray Mears.  In this BBC television presentation, wilderness skills expert and TV presenter Ray Mears takes viewers across North America on a journey back in time to the Wild West.  He follows in the footsteps of the intrepid would-be settlers, who set out to conquer the west-- and discovered a frontier that wouldnt easily surrender .This two-disc boxed set, which I received as a review copy, gives us eight episodes that run approximately 204 minutes, with subtitles, though the sound throughout is pretty clear. Also, a 16 page viewers guide with map of settlers routes west, articles on stagecoach services, how the west was wild, pioneering womens right to vote, little-known facts about cowboys, and Geronimos art of war.  Also, profiles of interesting women of the west. The series is currently syndicated to public television stations through APT.Long before superhighways spanned North America, (right here in Wilmington, North Carolina, home to the Great Smoky chain of the Appalachians, U.S. 40, after more or less running into the Atlantic Ocean, then begins officially.  With a sign that says  if it hasnt been stolen againBarstow, California, 3225 miles.) But, back then, of course, westbound settlers lumbered across a dangerous continent by covered wagon or on foot. In this documentary, survivalist Mears retraces the steps of the 19th-century travelers and discovers how the trip's rugged terrain and deadly hazards affected and tested the pioneers.  He takes viewers across the seemingly impassable mountain ranges, sprawling grasslands, and arid deserts that confronted those, from North America, Europe and the British Isles, and Asia, who made the journey.Along the way, from the densely forested Appalachians  he gives us a good interval showing the beauty of this old mountain range, and interviews Cherokee tribal elder Davy Arch--to the windswept peaks of the Sierra Nevada, Mears ventures into parts of America that remain untamed to this day.  He shows us settlers sod houses on the prairie; the route taken by the infamous Donner Party, which was forced to descend into cannibalism while being trapped  in the Rockies for a very long winter that didnt end until April.  And the Navajo Indians, agricultural dwellers of the Great Plains, and their close relationship with its Buffalo; also the Blackfoot tribe. The impact of railroads on the settlement of the west. A fascinating few minutes on how a local, riding a sure-footed formerly wild Maverick horse on Utahs Angel Trail, part of the outlaws escape route, is able to carefully navigate loose rock and dust down into a crater that would have sent a chasing posse home pronto.  Also, Tombstone, one of the most famous Western towns, with its daily recreated fight at OK corral.  And he discusses the warrior Apache tribe, particularly its famous leader Geronimo, and his methods of war. Finally, he pans for gold in California.The episodes are: The First Settlers, Furs and the Mountain Men, the Wagon Trains, Homesteaders and Cowboys, Plains Indians and Buffalo, Gold and the Boomtowns, Bandits and Lawlessness, The Desert Indians. I found this series fresh, interesting and informative: it should appeal to fans of history, or those who are interested in nature survival.  It can clearly be helpful in schools; or more than that, where any group of children  or adultsis regularly gathered for learning/entertainment purposes. Highly recommended.

TULIP FEVER is a finely imagined, thoroughly researched international bestseller by the London-based Deborah Moggach, a well-known British TV writer and prolific novelist who also authored THE BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL, upon which the recent hit film of the same name is based. This novel, which was optioned by Steven Spielberg, is set in an absorbing time and place: 1630s Amsterdam, Holland.  As were such recent books as Susan Vreeland's GIRL IN HYACINTH BLUE and Tracy Chevalier's GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING.  Of course, early 17th century Amsterdam has been forever immortalized by the serene, precise domestic realism of the canvases of Vermeer and Rembrandt.  But this historical fiction is a thought-provoking story not just of the societys contemporary art; also of beauty, lust, greed, deception and retribution -- set in a hard-working, otherwise responsible, refined society ablaze with tulip fever.In this romantic drama, we  meet wealthy elderly merchant Cornelis Sandvoort,  his young , dutiful, lovely  and bored wife, Sophia, whom he hopes will bring him the joy that not even his considerable fortune can buy: a child, praises be a son, to grant them immortality.  As so far the burgher and Sophia have failed to produce an heir, in a bid for a different sort of immortality, the businessman commissions a portrait of himself and his wife by the talented young Rembrandt-influenced, real-life artist Jan van Loos. However, as surely as Van Loos begins to capture Sophia's physical likeness on canvas, a slow passion begins to burn between the beautiful young woman and the talented artist.  The portrait is fleshed out,  the household's inhabitants enter a wrenching period of change, as ambitions, desires, and dreams breed deception, the lies multiply. Meanwhile, in the society at large, frenzied by tulip fever, immense sums  are being spent on the latest hybrids: a single Semper Augustus bulb sells  for "six fine horses, three oxheads of wine, a dozen sheep, two dozen silver goblets and a seascape by Esaias van de Velde."The author enriches her tight, taut novel with period detail. The Amsterdam of the period is brought almost physically alive.  Characters are each given their hours in the rare sun of the city.  Chapters are brief, each told from various characters points of view, Sophias in the first person.  The chapter headings from contemporary 17th century Dutch sources are on point and often charming, as they quote contemporary views of morals.  Her language is clear and witty: her dry humor underlies even the most tumultuous scenes of the novel. And the plot is exciting, as the  two pairs of lovers, Sophia and Jan, and the merchants servant Maria and her lover Willem, run through a series of improbable adventures while they struggle to make their way in the citys overheated air.I have not been previously familiar with this authors output, though I was marginally aware that she authored the, I expect richly charming novel upon which BEST EXOTIC MARIGOLD HOTEL is based.  However, I absolutely loved this book, and will be looking for more of Moggachs work.

Nature's Haven Full-Size premium warmer, by Scentsy.  This scent warmer uses a wickless candle system as a low watt 25-watt bulb slowly melts its specially formulated wax.  So it gives you your choice of more than 80 Scentsy fragrances, in any room of your home, without flame, smoke, or soot: thus, a safe clean way to enjoy ambient fragrance.There is a very wide selection of available warmer styles.  Different modalities of the product are also available, including Nightlight Warmers, travel sizes and a campus collection There is also a wide selection of fragrances, including guava honey, banana berry, black raspberry vanilla, and blueberry cheesecake. The item comes packaged as a full size warmer: base and warmer dish, with a 25 watt bulb; is meant for use with Scentsy waxes only.  To use the item, just screw in the light bulb, plug in the warmer, place one or more sections of your bar or brick into the warming dish, and enjoy.  To change fragrances, completely melt the wax in the dish; then pour the melted wax into its original packaging to reform.  While it is still warm, clean dish with paper towel.  Let wax solidify, then store used bar in cool place for later use, or discard.  You should, of course, always unplug unit when not in use.Its too hot outside for mother nature to be welcoming today, but this item is currently dispersing a warm, welcome black raspberry vanilla scent in my kitchen. I needed it.

Death of an Artist: A Mystery, by Kate Wilhelm.  This standalone crime novel is by award-winning author Kate Wilhelm, author of more than 30 novels including WHEN LATE THE SWEET BIRDS SANG; best known for her Barbara Holloway legal thrillers, most recently HEAVEN IS HIGH.  In this thriller, the Eugene, Oregon-based writer, gives us a small Oregon  coastal town, a seasonal resort, near Portland,  that is the scene of a case of art fraud, and murder.Silver Bay, Oregon with nearly a thousand year-round residents, is home to three generations of women: grandmother Marnie, long-widowed owner of a small gift shop; granddaughter Van, who is about to graduate medical school and begin her Chicago internship; and middle-generation mother  to Van, Stef, mercurial, difficult,  a brilliant artist who runs through men, refuses to sell her work. When Stef discovers that Dale Oliver-- latest husband/paramour in a long line--is trying to sell her work behind her back, she puts a stop to it and threatens to do the same to him. Shortly thereafter, Stef dies in an apparent accident in her studio; Dale shows up with a signed contract granting him the right to sell her work. Except that Stef had deliberately misspelled both her first and last names: shed evidently thought  shed  fix his wagon.  Marnie and Van are convinced that Dale murdered Stef in order to steal her artwork, decide to do whatever  they can to see that Dale doesn't get away with it,  including seeking  the help of the new stranger in town, Tony Mauricio,  former New York City cop, who is seemingly  the only person who can prove the death was murder.Well, having spent several years living in a small, seasonal coastal resort, I have a soft spot for them, but this one isnt well-drawn.  Neither is Portland, or the general area. Neither are the characters, who are cut from cardboard, predictable.  Neither, unfortunately, is the plot, which is linear, predictable: we always know the murderer and his motive, and soon enough, his method is given us, though Wilhelm seems to think we need further explanation of it. However, I've been reading this with my Carolina Beach mystery book club, and  it is a quick, easy entertainment, might do well as a beach read.

Quickie Flip-Lock Dust Pan & Lobby Broom. Youve surely seen something similar to this in many places, including beauty salons and barber shops. This ingenious large capacity, flip-lock system saves the user from a lot of bending, whether cleaning up big messes or small. And it allows broom and dust pan to snap together for easy and convenient storage. The angle-cut broom with its "split-tip" broom fibers and long handled oversize dust pan with floor-molding lip are designed to get into corners and allow quick pick up of small and large debris . The 30 inch broom handle is made of coated steel, has a comfort grip, and hangs with ease.  The item is safe for use on all types of floors. The durable dust pan handle comes complete with swivel hang-up feature. The Stand and Store  item, of course, also stands for easiest storage. Full 10-year warranty for normal household use  from date of original purchase (Receipt required).Life around here seems to require plenty of bending, what with the garden, dishwasher, washer and dryer, spilled cat food, and the weekly blast of catnip. We were looking to cut down on the bending where possible, and so recently acquired this item. It works fine.  For most sweeping needs, we no longer need to bend. A lot of convenience at a reasonable price.

LA's Totally Awesome All Purpose Concentrated Cleaner, 32 ounces, by La's Totally Awesome.  This 32-oz. bottle of little-known professional grade cleaner can clean everything washable: wood, laminate, stainless, marble, granite, plastic, porcelain, glass and more.  And it can be used in bathrooms, kitchens, playrooms and garages.  It removes blood stains, grease, wine, liquor, gum, oil, glue, coffee, pet stains, some inks, fresh paint, varnish, hair dye, food stains, grape juice, berry juice, etc.;  It is also useful  in carpet cleaning machines, cleans tile and grout too. It should be used in well-ventilated areas.This product was recommended to me by cleaning professionals.  It contains no acid, no ammonia, no bleach, no phosphorous, is safe for septic tanks, and is nonflammable.  Best of all, its just spray and wipe off. And it really puts a lot of cleaning power to work for the user. I find it really deep cleans in a jiffy.

DII 100% Polyester, Machine Washable, Tonal Bordered Fabric Tablecloth, 60 x 104", Gray, Seats 8 to 10 People. Polyester is a good fabric for this usage because it hardly shrinks, is machine washable, and stains tend to come out easily. The cloth comes out of the washer/dryer with few wrinkles, requires little to no ironing, can be simply folded and look freshand who wants to iron household items these days.  The imported table cloth is, in addition, treated for stain resistance.  It features a 1 fold-over hem for a polished look; its seamless heavy construction means that it will sit firmly and drape well on the table.The cloth has an elegant, pleasant linen-y look and feel, is a pretty gray, with a very nice looking tonal border, and of course, gray is a hot color in home dcor these days.  This solid color cloth should look good on its own or layered under lace. Matching 100% polyester, gray tonal bordered fabric napkins are available. I have recently found DII, through its offerings here, and at home furnishing stores such as Bed Bath and Beyond, to be a maker of quality, well-thought out, useful home goods. I like this tablecloth.  Do you remember that old Italian song that goes something like Lazy Mary, get out of bed, we need the sheet for the table.  No need for that these days!

BABE LASH EYELASH LASH CONDITIONER SERUM FOR LONGER LASHES - 4ml by BABE LASH. This ophthalmologist-tested, hypoallergenic formula promises its users effortless, beautiful naturally longer and fuller lashes in as little as four weeks; with full results in 12 weeks. The 4mL Serum, which is made in the U.S.A., should be a 6 month supply. The manufacturers state that their formula is exclusive, containing among other ingredients, hyaluronate acidcurrently a very hot cosmetics ingredient; grape seed extract, ginseng root extract, yeast extract, chamomile extract, and bearberry.  And that it will enhance eyelashes from the inside out, so that there should be no need to apply layers of heavy cosmetics.  The product can be used by contact-lens wearers. Of course, users cannot expect the results given by LaTisse, the expensive, prescription-only eyelash serum.The manufacturers instructions are: Use once daily, preferably at night. Skin should be clean and dry before application. Apply Babe Eyelash Serum to the skin right above your upper lash line. Use a single brush stroke for each eye. Avoid rubbing your eyes until the serum has dried. When you are satisfied with the results, continue using Babe Eyelash Serum two to three times a week to maintain long lashes.As a younger woman, I had a 25-year long nervous habit of pulling out my eyelashes; my lids were usually bare.  Ive had some regrowth since then, but my eyelashes are still sparse.  So when this product was recommended to me by my beauty salon, and I saw that the cosmetologists working there had great looking lashes, I had to try it. Almost immediately I  felt what lashes I had were thicker and stronger.  I now have been using the product for four weeks or more, and see some regrowth, but, so far, the  regrowth lashes are  weak  and pale; results  do not compare to the regrowth produced by Latrisse, unfortunately.

Benefit Cosmetics They're Real! Mascara (BLACK) 8.5g, from Aviance. The manufacturers of this mascara promise a jet-black mascara that lengthens, curls, volumizes, lifts and separates lashes.  They say that, when using it, 90% of users saw base-to-tip curl; 94% saw visible lift and dramatic length and volume; 100% saw long-wearing results. They add that their specially designed brush features staggered bristles that will grab close to the root of the lash, and the custom-domed tip uses precision bristles to lift, define, and curl even the tiniest lashes.  They add that it is a glossy long-wearing formula that won't smudge, clump, or dry out.Their suggested use: position wand horizontally and wiggle from side to side, base to tip of the lash to achieve maximum volume, length and lift.  Hold wand vertically and stroke upward to curl and separate.  Layer generously as desired.As a younger woman, I had a 25-year long nervous habit of pulling out my eyelashes; my lids were usually bare.  Ive had some regrowth since then, but my eyelashes are still sparse.  So when this product was recommended to me by my beauty salon, and I saw that the cosmetologists working there had great looking lashes, I had to try it.  I do think it makes more of what eyelashes I have than other mascaras I have tried, but I wish it came in shades other than jet black.

Blonde Faith (Easy Rawlins Book 11), is by Walter Mosley, prolific veteran New York Times and international bestselling author of crime fiction and science fiction, who is best known for this Easy Rawlins Los Angeles-set series, in which this is the eleventh. Mosleys debut crime novel in this thriller series, the set in LA, in the immediate post-World War II years, DEVIL IN A BLUE DRESS, introduced us to Easy, an angry black World War II veteran, scuffling to make a living.  The book was a critically widely praised, surprise best seller which was filmed under the same title, DEVIL IN A BLUE DRESS, starring Denzel Washington.  But the clock has ticked on since then; in real time, this book was published 17 years after Mosleys debut; in fictional time, we are now in 1967.  A middle-aged Easy Rawlins, who narrates, comes home from work one day to find Easter, daughter of his friend Christmas Black, left on his doorstep. Easy knows that this could only mean that former marine Black is in trouble, and in the wind. Then Easy finds that his lifelong friend Raymond Alexander (Mouse), who has also disappeared, is wanted for the murder of a father of 12.  And Easy has his own problems: Bonnie Shay, love of his life, is about to marry another man, an African prince. As Easy searches for these two very dangerous friends; two MPs who dont feel quite right insist on  hiring him to find Black for the U.S. Army. Easy's investigation brings him to Faith Laneer, a beautiful blonde with a questionable past.Mosley is one of America's most  acclaimed, popular writers; his books have won numerous awards and have been translated into more than twenty languages.  In addition to the celebrated Easy Rawlins  series, he is author of  the Fearless Jones series, and two collections of stories featuring Socrates Fortlow,  for which he received the Anisfield-Wolf Award. The native Angeleno now lives in New York City, Brooklyn, to be precise. The writers father, like his character Easy, was an LA school janitor; his mother was a Jewish World War II Holocaust survivor.  Although racially mixed marriages were legal in Los Angeles at the time, his parents were, for a while, unable to find anyone to marry them.  The Irish novelist Edna OBrien commented, as she taught him in a New York City College writing course that with his mixed black/Jewish background, Mosley was well-placed to have an outsiders view of America.  And nobodys books have commented more  sharply and descriptively on black life in America after World War II.  Further, Mosley is able, as always, to capture  his hometown in its climate, social mores, byways and highways, with absolute brilliance.  He is also well able, as ever, to keep his books moving with the times. His dialog is fine, as ever, even the black dialect. The plot is convoluted as ever, perhaps this time, somewhat melodramatic; there are, as ever, almost too many characters.Unfortunately, BLONDE FAITH  shows the Easy series age in many ways: it is filled with melancholy and regret, has the feeling that it may be the last of the Easy books, and for several years, it was.  Now, I have loved the authors work dearly, read every novel in turn up until CINNAMON KISS , the one before this,  and this one.  I am just getting back to these two now; and can see why Mosley and I stopped back then.  I have reviewed in these pages Mosleys Easy novels DEVIL IN A BLUE DRESS, LITTLE GREEN and ROSE GOLD, and his free-standing ALL I DID WAS SHOOT MY MAN.  Mosley is always worth reading, but this series began with a bang with DEVIL IN A BLUE DRESS and petered out with a whimper with CINNAMON and BLONDE. Until  the author was ready to come back to Easy with LITTLE GREEN  and ROSE GOLD.  Best to begin at the beginning with BLUE DRESS, see how it goes.

I have several pairs of Jambu shoes and sandals and they all have the best arch support imaginable. I was so shocked to put these on and find an utter and complete lack of arch support. As a matter of fact it feels like negative arch support - like the sole is hammock shaped or something. I would never even take a casual walk in these of more than a couple of blocks. Even for walking the dog it is not enough support.

I don't like ugly shoes, but I simply cannot wear uncomfortable shoes now that I am getting closer to the "when I am an old woman I shall wear purple" days. This puts me on a constant search for shoes and boots that manage to combine the two. These shoes are at the top of my list right now. I own several pairs of Fly London shoes. I have found that in general, it pays to go down a size in this brand. That being said, this shoe is the most comfortable of the lot, and perhaps more comfortable than any other pair I own, including some Jambu and Dansko shoes that I treasure for style and comfort. They are a bit odd looking. I have them in black and even though they go with everything, I am longing to buy them in a softer color because the style looks sort of stark in the black. Laced up, they hug your feet perfectly. The wedge heel gives nice height and shape to your leg, but without the pain of a pump. I paid more for these shoes than I  normally want to pay, but I am satisfied that I got my money's worth! I will continue to lust after other colors and add to my collection of Fly London shoes!

Well, the chairs seem nice so far. Sadly, the cushions were ruined almost immediately. The minute whirlybirds fell on them and got damp from dew there were huge stains on them. That was sad for me. I will look for some nice all-weather cushions to go with these chairs.
This is a very comfortable shoe. I can be on my feet for a long time in these shoes, no problem.
This is the best round brush for my medium thick, wavy long brown hair. It pulls the hair just tight enough and doesn't cause huge static problems like some.

My 10 and 14 karat gold rings were making my fingers turn black. I read online that this is a sign of an iron deficiency. Since I had other symptoms like tiredness, I decided to give this a try. My fingers stopped turning black where the gold rubbed within about 10 days of starting with the Megafood blood builder. Plus I feel better. No scientific data here, just human observation. Still, it is pretty compelling.

I bought this based on the mainly positive reviews, and I was sorely disappointed. The bricks themselves look super fake-y, but that was not my main problem with them. Even though they looked so totally plastic and fake, I still took them out to my garden beds, figuring I would use them for one season and replace them next year. However, the stake that is affixed to each hollow, plastic fake brick is less than 2" long and about the size and diameter of a plastic toothpick you get at a cheap steakhouse. I pushed it into the ground and sat and stared at it for about one minute, before boxing everything back up and sending it back. There is no way those things were going to stay in the ground! I am glad others had better luck with them, but I am going to go get some real bricks.

I was surprised at how well made this dress is. The seams are well done and it is fully lined. The contrasting lime green lining shows at the collars and hem and adds an interesting detail. This is a perfect dress for work for summertime, as it is lightweight, but gives good coverage for blasting air conditioners when you are inside. For spring or fall just add a camisol layer or tights. The one thing you might want toknow is that the shirt-tail hem comes up a bit high at the sides. Revealed a bit more leg than I wanted to, especially if I put my arms up for any reason. Don't wear your Spanx unless you want everyone to know your secret! I am 5'4"and I got the 4. Wish I had gotten the 6.

I ordered this necklace for a charm pendant. The packaging is very nice and the color of the gold is pretty. The problem for me is that the chain is unbelievably thin. Don't look at the photograph because it is taken at about 200% zoom. I use thicker dental floss and I would probably hang a charm off of that before I hung it off this necklace. It just looks like it would break with any kind of pressure.
These are comfortable and give me a little lift. The wedge heel adds some height. Buckle detail is very well done. I am happy with this shoe.

I did not even make it to the water. Captain Philip was still on LAND when I became so nauseated and headachy that I could not continue. The shaky camera techniques that start from the first second of the movie were enough to ruin it for me. I hope and pray that this era of "gritty realism" ends soon and directors come to the realization that the shaky cam should be used in small doses for effect - - NOT A TWO HOUR MOVIE!!!!!
My favorite bronzer is Chocolate Soliel by Too Faced. This is by far the best brush for applying it. Light and fluffy and great for a light, overall dusting of color.

These jeans were described as high rise, and the photo certainly makes them look that way. I am well past my low rise days but I love the fabric of these jeans so I gave these a shot. The ones I got didn't seem like high rise and they certainly didn't match the photo here in terms of rise. My muffin top spillith over. Going back.

I am in love with the 4 way stretch denim these jeans are made of. It is a dark, substantial denim that feels as comfy and soft as leggings. The cut is not quite as kind to my figure as I had hoped from the reviews. I bought these and the boot cut, and I am keeping these because the boot cut ones were way too low for me. The legs are so long, so all you 6' ladies out there are in luck! I am 5'4" and these will have to have more than 6" hemmed off.

I have clogs from Dansko, Ariat, and Jambu. These are my favorites. They hug my foot just right. My danskos are comfy but I get tired of the clomping sounds when you walk on concrete or hard wood, and also the part across my arch goes numb sometimes with my danskos. The stretchy fabric across the arch holds onto my foot in this gentle, secure way. I love the way these feel.

I was hoping for a nicer top due to the positive reviews and the price I paid for this top. In my opinion, a top of this quality (thin material, kind of see through, finishes merely average) can be obtained at a store like Forever 21 for a fraction of what I paid for it. I like the white British three-quarter sleeve tee from Three Dots, but it is also pricey. If I had to choose between the two, I would pick the Three Dots shirt.

I have paid the big bucks for a couple of Canada Goose parkas for my teenage daughters, and even though the pricetag made me hyperventilate, they have loved those coats so much and worn them non-stop in the cold winter months, and for me, justified the price tag. I have been looking for a pair of down mittens and even though these are men's I bought them in small for myself (average hand size woman). Yes they are too big. But the real disappointment is how thin and flimsy they are. Maybe that is good for a man whose hands don't get so frozen as mine do. But the price seems outrageous for such an insubstantial mitten.

I got this dress in stripes for a really good deal. Like a really really good deal. I tried it on and burst into laughter. I couldn't decide if I looked more like I had on a surgical gown or prison garb. I paid so little for it, it is almost ridiculous to send it back, but it would be even more ridiculous to keep it. I have other Kavu stuff I love, but the cut and fabric of this dress were unflattering in the extreme.

I was excited to receive these because of the good reviews, but was disappointed. Yes, they are salty, but that is the only discernible flavor. I will eat them, but they do not have the kind of flavor I was dreaming of.

I got this for my 17 year old daughter for a school event that required white. It is a spring event but it has been very cold in Michigan and the weather will be a big question mark. Most of the white dresses I looked at were sleeveless or eyelet. Not appropriate if it is 40 degrees out that day. The material is very nice - thick without being heavy. The 3/4 sleeves are perfect. If it is warm that day she will be fine and if it is cold she won't freeze. Plus it is very flattering. She is petite (5'2" around 100#) and the 0 fit her like a glove. Length was perfect. The mesh panels add interest but are not too revealing. We spent more on this dress than I would have liked but to find a dress that worked for both mother and daughter, and could accommodate a wide range of weather factors was worth every penny.

Very happy with this dress. The material is very comfortable like workout clothes. The top part is clingy and the bottom is swingy, and that works for me. LOVE the 3/4 sleeves. That length works for me in Michigan for about 10 months of the year. Can dress this look up with statement jewelry or scarves, add a jacket, sweater or vest to change up the look. I will get lots of wear from this dress. 5'4" and 125# and the medium was a good fit. I also removed the attached belt. I wore it with a cute thick belt today.

The material for this dress is very nice. Soft and substantial. The cut is kind of empire waist and I thought it was relatively flattering on me. The only thing I would change is the ruching on the shoulders. It makes for a lot of material on top of your shoulders for a tank style cut. Doesn't detract from the sleek, simple look too much, though and I love the material and will get lots of wear out of this dress.

Well the icy season is going to last for a long while here in Michigan, and this product has been key in keeping our walkway from the side door to the cars safe. I like the way it is packaged for sprinkling. I bought a bigger supply of some similar stuff, but I am going to save the jug to refill because it is easy for anyone in our family to apply.

I am not a fan of cut flowers, but I love having flowers inside my home in all seasons. I am a big fan of the plants from Trader Joe's floral section. They are so reasonably priced and some of them, like the mini orchids, last forever. It has become my favorite gift for friends when they need a lift. I have been keeping a supply of these little pots on hand and whenever I need a quick gift for someone, I head to trader joes and pick out a nice flowering plant. I quickly throw it in one of these pots and with a bow or a mini card on a bamboo skewer it is instant gift. Everyone loves it.

I bought this in blue. As it is still super snowy and cold in Michigan, I was expecting to have to wait a month or so to wear it, but when it came I tried it on with tights and boots and it looked great! The pattern is very pretty, and gives the skirt a textured knit look, even though it is really cotton material the weight of a soft, heavy t-shirt. Anyway, I tried it on with a black turtleneck, tights and boots and it looked great! So I can start wearing it right away, and change to sandals and bare legs in a few months and wear it any time! Love it and just bought another in black and white.

I did not check the reviews here carefully enough before purchasing this product. It was only after I made my purchase that I noticed that nearly all of them were written right around the same time, by reviewers who have not reviewed any other products. I wish I had looked more closely before purchasing.

I finally settled on these boots after buying and returning so many pairs of black boots that I thought Amazon might discontinue their free returns policy. There were other boots that were very close, but one little problem or another made me continue my quest for the perfect pair. I have an average size calf, and some boots were too tight in the calf (enzo angiolini deanja), others too loose and caused the pirate look (Keen Akita) others had such rugged soles I felt bad keeping them on indoors (corso como womens gage), others fit in the calves but bagged and irritated me in the ankle (steve madden jaden). These are leather in the front but the entire back is made out of a ribbed stretchy material so they can fit a good variety of legs to perfection. Some people might not like having the material in the back, but I found it made the boots comfortable, and at the same time gave the shape of my leg definition, which is nice since I have athletic calves but a smaller ankle. The buckle detail is pretty, and not as clunky and over the top as some of the boot hardware these days. It has been quite a snowy and cold winter in Michigan this year and I have been so happy to have a great pair of boots I can pull on every single day and look dressed up, but also go from indoors to outdoors without fear. I found these amazing fleece tights and leggings here on amazon and I have given up on pants because they are so much warmer and more comfortable than pants! I just pull on the tights, my boots and a wool skirt and sweater and I am so happy all day. Still can't wait for spring but man, these boots were a godsend this winter!

The tips seem very basic, like get a lot of boxes and put your stuff in them and then write what's inside them on a 3x5 card and tape it to the outside. That's practically a chapter. Lots of christian sayings to motivate you to get rid of stuff. And seriously, more power to you if that helps you. Whatever it takes. Generally I feel better if I get even a tip or two from a book like this but I can't say there was anything too new or exciting in this book for me.

I got these noodles to make my own version of low carb mac and cheese lottie and doof style (don't ask, just google it. now.). The recipe came out as delicious as if I had used regular pasta. The noodles are not tough or chewy like some lower carb pastas. When you have something as yummy as this mac and cheese around, it is pretty hard to do portion control and yet it did not seem to rock the boat too bad in terms of my weight loss program. I do not track blood sugars, so I cannot comment on that. I served this to several people who were not doing low carb and they gobbled it up without question. Nice to have a few dishes in my repertoire when I need to break (anything but) bread with my non LC friends! I have a sensitive stomach at times when it comes to low carb products, but the dreamfields line does not give me any trouble. I like the angel hair spaghetti and the lasagne as well.

Got these for my 16 year old daughter along with a few other pairs of digital print leggings from various sellers on amazon. The King Tut leggings were her absolute favorite. She thought the material was the nicest and she loved the funky print.

Based on another review I ordered a large in the ivory, even though I normally wear a small. I think this sweater is designed to look like you are bursting out of it like the girl in the photo. The large is snug on me (5'4", #130) and there is significant button gaping at the bust (sexy?) and waist (definitely NOT sexy). There are also problems with the stitching along the seams of the button row. The sweater is ivory but there are bits of grey thread peeking out intermittently along the front seams. Given these problems, the price was so reasonable I am going to just keep it for an extra sweater to keep in my office to ward off the chill. I may be able to rinse it and block it to fit better. Bottom line: extremely fitted - order up or face extreme button gap!

These boots satisfied every requirement of mine (look good with dresses, fit under slacks, not too high, no hardware or buckles at the top, side zip, stretch to the leg. They are beautiful and I was very excited when I opened the box. However, the top part of the shaft fit perfectly on my calves, but the ankle had baggy material. It didn't actually look that bad, but I like to wear boots with no socks or hosiery and the material rubbed and chafed around the ankle. I think it has to do with the shape of my legs (athletic calves, smaller ankles) and returned them with sadness, as they are such pretty boots.

I tried Miracle Noodles when I first started trying to reduce carbs in my diet, about 7 years ago. My experience was not good at all. The fishy odor and rubbery texture of the noodles could not be overcome and after several attempts, I threw out a large quantity of packages. Since then I have been wary, but I kept seeing posts and suggestions from other low carbers and decided to give these one last try. I made two changes in preparation methods and now I can say these are most certainly edible for me, which is great. I googled "dry fry miracle noodles" and found lots of suggestions. One I read said to rinse the noodles well, drain well, snip them up into smaller pieces with scissors, then dump them into a nonstick pan and gently tossing for about 8 minutes. This sounded like a long time to me, but the noodles didn't seem to crisp up or burn in the process. I turned the heat way down then added salt, then a giant whop of pesto, tossed in some walnut pieces and shaved parmesan and let it sit for another minute. Slid it onto a plate and it looked beautiful, did not smell of fish, and filled me up completely. The dry frying seemed to eliminate some of the intolerable odor for me, and snipping them up reduced the chance that a noodle would get semi-swallowed and stuck with one end down my throat and the other in my mouth. That sensation about killed me when I tried them way back when. The texture is still a bit rubbery, but I found them very satisfying. Glad I tried again.
This riser worked for my widescreen all-in-one computer. The keyboard is too long to fit under it, and the legs cannot be moved wider.
These are so elegant. The t-strap and mesh create a very beautiful evening look. This is a shoe for a special event!

I only use this a few times a year, and that is why I decided against getting a more expensive one. I have a black and decker mini chopper that has it's own share of design flaws, but does not fill me with dread like this one does when I get it down from the high shelf of the garage. The lid sticks every time, and as other reviewers have noted, it is really frustrating to have a bowl full of pureed whatever and be wrestling this thing like a wild boar. Today I was doing cranberry sauce and I stopped to type up this review as I eyed the bowl full of BRIGHT RED pureed cranberries, that I once again cannot access. I see that some people have no issue with this and happy day for them. For me it is an issue every time.

I had a terrible time with the billing on this card. I kept missing payments. I tried so hard to get a routine with paying it but the system was not good for the way I do my bills. So I paid it off and removed the store card from all my preferred payments. Well it kept sneaking back in through subscribe and save items, and before I knew it I had missed another payment. I tried to go through each item when it might be hidden and take it off. Finally I got frustrated and cancelled the card. Between the missed payments and the dun I got for closing the card, I lost many important points on my credit score. This card may work out fine for you but I regret ever going near it.

I like to wear my boots without socks or hosiery and these insoles are a dream come true for my feet. They support the arches and give me a soft landing spot at the same time. They transformed a pair of rain boots into pure heaven.
Nice and roomy. Helps me find space in my small bathroom and keep the counters clear. I put it inside the cabinet door below the sink so I can get things quickly.

This is a very sleek top. I am not sure I will have the nerve to wear it alone because it is rather clingy. That's too bad because the pattern is very pretty. The neck was a little tight on me, but it is ok, I just stretch it after I put it on. At least the neck is low profile and not bulky, which makes me happy.
Nice set, really exactly as they look.  My wife likes this style of print, so I thought it would fit in our kitchen. Very much does. Usable and decorative all at once.

Every task needs the right tool for the job. A hiking backpack is made to fill up, be as light as possible, have some accessible pockets but mostly be about getting to a certain place and then unloading.  For hunting or other task oriented adventures, a different type of pack is needed, one that offers maximum accessibility and convenience, with a wide range of carrying options.This bag fulfills the latter role perfectly. It's not light, but it is comfortable and carries well. The best thing is that this has a crazy amount of storage options almost all of which are immediately accessible.  No need to dig into a large compartment, pulling out everything to find one thing.  With good organization, this bag is an immense time saver, allowing for everything in its place, when you need it as easy as possible.  It's designed for hunting but its use excels beyond that task. Great for photography or anything that requires a fair amount of accessories.  I even can see bringing this when hiking along with my young kids, with easy accessed compartments providing quick response to mood swings or needs.Perfect for what it's made for and very useful for all sorts of additional reasons, this really is going to get a lot of use.  I'll update if I find any concerns about long term quality.

I'll admit, I've been a bit reluctant to the whole Princess obsession.  Our 3 year old daughter has a lot of other interests, and loves playing outside, so I had thought maybe we could avoid it. She loves Doc McStuffins and Sheriff Callie and Mickey Mouse Clubhouse, which I think are much more fun and much better role models.  We even went to Disneyland this past March without her really obsessing over the princess stuff (which helped make the visit much more fun for the whole family).  But, she has cousins, and watching Disney jr brings the commercials. She's not obsessed yet, but definitely likes princess items, and increasingly so.  She's starting to get into Frozen, and, well, I am a sucker for that look of delight on her face.There's a lot of accessories out there, an endless amount, but for your money and space, this is the one to go with.  It's not cheap and it's certainly not small, but its really the perfect accessory to get an imagination going.  It comes effects (lights and a transforming stairs) all sorts of accessories, and otherwise really captures the grandeur of the movie (which I liked).  All in all, a wonderfully designed product that captures the scene as well as a toy can.  More importantly, my daughter utterly and completely loves it.I do wish it came with some characters, but that's a minor complaint.

I'm a novice with flying these, so I'm reviewing from that perspective.First of all, I had a very negative impression when I first opened it and tried to get it out of the box.  It's secured with very small and tight zip ties, which are connecting this vehicle by its very thin plastic cage to the very thin plastic mount.  I accidentally sliced one of the support bars in taking it out.  With this, I was flummoxed by not having a stand inside the box.  Then I realized the very cheap and thin packaging plastic it's on in the box is the "stand".  For a toy like this, pay a bit more for some higher quality and more secure plastic if you're going to call it a stand!  I had no idea they were passing this off as the stand, so I cut through it in order to better get as those horrible twist ties.Once out of the box, however, it gets better.  The controller (looks like an X-Box controller) needs batteries, but it comes with a tiny screwdriver (I'd prefer to have a stand instead of a screwdriver) to open it up.  Getting the battery in the vehicle isn't very intuitive, and the instructions are a fair bit out of order, telling you how to control it first, with you having to dig farther in to find it tells a bit about setup.That bother out of the way, this becomes fun.  The instructions to fly are helpful, and after a few sessions (charge, fly, recharge) I started getting the hang of the controls.  Really sensitive and yet the plastic cage makes for a protected adventure.  Starting to have a lot of fun with this.  If you go into it knowing what I know now, I think that would lighten the initial frustrations. Really, if they had just included a better stand and secured it in a better way in the packaging, I would have been much more thrilled with it from the get go.

A year or so ago, I got a PowerAll PBJS12000R Rosso Red/Black Portable Power Bank and Car Jump Starter which I've loved.  It has provided a few emergency car starts and been a handy charger on other occasions. A few problems. It's a bit pricey (though well worth it), a bit large (though shockingly small for what it does), and gave me a bit of hassle in the airport. I got pulled aside by TSA as they looked through my bag. They let me pass through with this, but it is enough of an extra hassle that I've left it behind.What I love about this NOCO XGrid is that it is a perfect size and shape for bringing along.  I have often found myself in a situation where I'm moving from place to place and realize my phone or other USB charged tool is dying. I usually have my laptop with me, but that requires it to be open and on to charge, making for inconvenient moments of awkward laptop placement that doesn't give me near enough power because I don't have the time.  This is truly a travel charger, a camping charger, for hiking or for work or, I'd heartily suggest, for school. Easily kept in a backpack or bag, it's always handy so there's never an excuse of running out of juice.  Charge this at night if you use it. If not, the lithium ion holds its charge for a long while.  That this is rugged means its the tool that will come along on any outing, and the tool you have is better than the best tool you don't have. The flashlight is always much more handy than I expect. Having it handy means I don't fumble around in the dark, I have this nearby and use it even to find pens or usb dongles or whatever in the depths of my soft briefcase.I wish it came with a wall charger adapter, only has a USB, but adapters are pretty cheap these days.

Two reasons I wanted this and why I like it.  We're streaming media ever since we cut out our cable bill.  This provides a quick and steady access to our various media stored in computers and a home server.  It's a bit overkill for just streaming directly from online, as the online download speeds won't get anywhere close to what this can offer.  But, it's great for stored files, and it also keeps the wireless signal from getting bogged down with too much demand. I also have a home office where I regularly transfer very large files and folders from and to various computers (home pc, personal laptop, work laptop) using dropbox and OneDrive. Using this allows for very fast transfers, which is great when I remember at the last minute.Installation couldn't be easier.  I've found no problems at all using these at various speeds and now am more than happy to recommend this 500Mbps.  There are versions that have the plug pass through (allowing you to plug something in the adapter), but those tend to be larger boxes that tend to block a fair bit of the other outlet above, so it doesn't really help.Extremely pleased with TP-Link yet again as they've really given some flexibility to our home network that saves a fair amount of bother everyday

In my new quest to pursue a healthier lifestyle, I've started changing my diet to include fresher foods, avoiding sugar and processed products.  My problem has been that I'm not always at home.  I got this for use at my office.  I can keep ingredients in the small kitchen there, and make up a selection of smoothies or quick additions for basic food I bring from home.  It works great, perfect for the setting. Crushes ice like a champ, as well as my ice shaving machine, doing much more much quickly.  I can blend a quick smoothie using the ice, fruit, nutrition powder, etc, very quickly, with easy clean up.  I'm generous so others are using it as well.  Not as powerful as some blenders, but the ease of use, flexibility, with still more than enough power for my needs makes this a great help for me sticking to my goals.

I work from home and teach at a couple different campuses. I regularly use 3 different computers (personal laptop, work laptop, home pc) depending on my location, need, and other factors.  I have a number of different projects going on at once and different work locations that often requires the need of multimedia files. I've gotten used to optimizing my flash drive for the files I think I'll need most, but keep finding myself wishing I was back at home for that one file I didn't think about or didn't know I'd need.This is a full sized hard drive with plenty of room to spare for my needs, a fast USB 3.0 connection so I can store, use, and save files on the disk with no slow down.  What I love is that it is no thicker than the USB plug, is well-constructed, very quiet, and fits nicely into a slot inside my soft-briefcase.  At the same time, it's not so small I have to dig around for it.  Really, it's the perfect size for me in every respect, and that means I use it regularly, putting it through its paces enough to value its dependability.This is getting used daily for me, more so once the school year starts.  I'll update if I have any performance or dependability problems, but for now I really like it.

We've been sold on memory foam toppers for a number of years.  Comfortable sleep for a fraction of the price. But with a bed spring, mattress, and a topper, the bed is pretty tall.  As we reorganize our various rooms, it was a good time to reassess our bed situation. The mattress with the topper goes into the guest room (where are frequent family visitors will appreciate the larger size than the full bed), and we go lower profile with this mattress and a Classic Brands Europa Deluxe Wood Slat Platform Mattress Foundation Bed Frame.Love the packaging of mattresses these days.  Heavy box but much more manageable to get into the house and right room than before.In terms of comfort, I'm impressed.  I am a very warm sleeper, and so the latex offers more temperature comfort than the memory foam (and we had a nice topper).  I like that it doesn't slip around or feel unstable on the edges, which is important since our young kids sometimes like to crawl into our bed and that means I'm relegated to the edges.Very pleased overall.

I got the 5' x 3' version. Small goal, but very secure. Great for target practice or small field or small teams with no dedicated goalie.  Use this with my kids and with friends, with great success and no bothering at all with the goal once it's set up.

My 3 year old daughter loves being outside and notices everything. She goes on weekly adventures outdoors with her grandpa and often with me or her mom in addition.  She's curious and attentive, but easily distracted and not very careful.  I wanted to help her develop her curiosity more but didn't want to invest too much at this point.These binoculars are a very useful addition to her outing paraphernalia.  They provide a decent zoom, without too much bother. If they break or are left outside I'm not too worried. A great introduction to helping her see farther, and get used to using nice tools (that I'll help her learn how to, but not yet trust her to, take care of).  I like they look like standard binoculars and are instantly recognizable as such by my daughter who has seen more higher quality binoculars. So far no complaints about comfort. The quality of lens is what you'd expect for the price.

It's always nice to receive something that fits expectations and has no unfortunate surprises.  These earrings were a little small than I expected, but that was totally fine. Not garish, a worthwhile accessory without breaking the bank.  If you like the way these look, you'll like these when they arrive.  Not all jewelry is like that, so for me that's the key element to note.

We're living in an old rental house.  Which means, among other things, there's a lot of minor irritations that I'm not going to invest in fixing since we'll be moving before too long. This lock lube takes care of a few irritations, in a way that seems to last longer than WD-40. Easy application with the included straw. The bottle isn't that big, but you don't need very much. Noticed an immediate difference.

In academic studies, it's common to have texts that are primarily literature reviews. They usually are not not best reads nor offer the most application. However, they're essential for delving into a topic, theme, or study of any kind.  In looking at these, one has validity only inasmuch as they can show they know the broad field and what people have written about it.  Now, for every text on a topic to do this would be unwieldy and re-inventing the wheel. So, some scholars do the yeoman's work of writing a literature review so that such studies can be cited, discussed, broadened, analyzed.  The groundwork is done, so other scholars or interested parties can use the material for different purposes.Reagle here has done this for that most diffuse sort of literature: internet comments.  Diffuse but not unimportant, as a great deal of worth both in content and style can be gleaned.  Indeed, I've found that comments really give a very interesting perspective on the broad range and general pattern of human response.  I've become very interested in comments, not because I expect my mind to be changed (though this happens) but because I learn so much about people in general. We have social boundaries in most of life, but there are a few contexts where the boundaries are not formed, leaving us to expose our true personalities. Online comments are a lot like driving in that way, you can tell a lot about a person, or people, by how they drive, and what comments are left.So, while on what may seem an ephemeral topic, Reagle offers a great resource.  He gives a good overview, showing he has does rigorous and long term study, offering good frameworks and analysis. Then in each chapter he focuses on different kinds of comments/commenters: the informed, the manipulated, those seeking improvement, the alienated, the shaped, and the bemused. Often you can find all of these in the same comment thread!  For those experienced with the online world, this won't be ground breaking, but it does offer a cohesive and fairly comprehensive perspective that can be then properly cited and referred to.A great resource for my own research and writing on social media and anthropology

Very straightforward.  Durable and very user friendly, comes with two lines that are easily attached.  Firm padding, but not too firm. They're not very long, so not for a big boat, but that's not my situation.  I liked the shape, better than the round ones I've used before.  Gives a lot of flexibility for use besides as fenders, and on a boat where space can be tight, that's very nice to have something that can be used as fenders, or a seat, or padding.Given what I've read, these rectangle shapes aren't good for long term use, more surface area on the boat means they rub as the boat moves. The round one roll. Short term, that's not an issue. So more for boats that you put in the water and then use docks for various reasons than boats that are kept at docks.I have the white, but I would likely get another of the darker colors in the future, mostly because of dirt or stains or such that happen.I can't attest to long term durability yet, and that's an important issue, so if I have any problems I'll post an update here.  As of now, these are a great buy. Quite usable without too much cost.

This is an ideal bag for traveling on planes for short trips or if you're wanting to pack light.  It's surprisingly roomy, with a big compartment and a lot of different pockets for various items, keeping organization under control.Ideal for flying without having to check bags, the main bag can go above your heads, while the small detachable can be used at your seat. Likewise, with tourist travel, leave the bigger bag in your hotel, take the smaller one for day trips.  As a lover of water, the two roomy water bottle holders will be sufficient for decent sized bottles, like my 40oz Klean Kanteens.It's not a hiking backpack, it's a travel backpack, and it's really an amazing design. Only time and use will determine the long term durability, but it seems pretty solid.  All the straps stow away, with there even being a zippable cover for the shoulder strap, a handy addition should you want to check this bag, or are using it/carrying it in a way that the straps are annoyances.For us, this is an ideal bag to bring when we fly or, I say with a bit of hope, a great bag for traveling around in Europe or such destinations, where you want to have enough resources, but don't want to be weighed down or bothered by heavy luggage.  You really can pack well for a week with this (if you're efficient) and that makes this really versatile.

I'm not a survivalist guy, but I spent a fair amount of time outside, camping/hiking.  Meaning, I'm likely close to the target audience of this product, especially lately, where I've not been out of cell phone range for a year or so.  Add to this preface, my experience hiking in Joshua Tree. Overconfidence from prior visits, reliance on a GPS that stopped working, led to a long hike towards an oasis that, at some point, veered the wrong way.  We realized well too late we were going the wrong way and heading farther into the rocky expanse.  Some hikers coming the other direction confirmed this.  Time to turn back.  So far in, that twilight arrived. It was getting dark. Joshua Tree with no moon dark.  There was a point that we realized that if we didn't get to a recognizable trail, we'd have to stay out all night and wait for morning. I rustled around in my small bag and found what I had been hoping against all hope was there, my headlamp that I brought along for the campsite.  The batteries were low, but worked well enough. We got back, an 8 hour day of scrambling, sliding, tearing clothes.  Exhausted and exhilarated (at least I was).Ever since then, I've been very good about having emergency tools even on short hikes. A person never knows what will happen or when.  That's what I thought of when I received this. This is a "what if" tool. It's not a primary survival tool, nor something you'd want to rely on for regular use. It's very light, compact, and can stay in a very small bag, there when you need it. The tool you have is better than the best tool, and this is something that can stay ready for use.I didn't experience any of the problems noted by other reviews.  The multi-tool came fully functioning, and while some elements were stiff at first, everything is pretty easily accessible.  I live in California, so concerns about cold aren't really a factor. The compass is pretty cheap, but can help orient general direction to find landmarks.  The paracord is less useful, as I can't imagine retying it so compactly and so will likely never untie it. You'll need your own clip or carabiner to attach the tool itself to anything.  It's not the highest quality, to be sure, as the plastic seems of minimal quality, even as the knife, saw, sharpener are higher quality.For what this is, as a pal for survival, something to leave in the car or your small hiking bag, this works fine. Having tried it out, I have no doubt it would have been a help had we needed to spend the night in the desert.  So, I wish I had it then, and based on that, am glad I have it now.

With a three year old and an almost 11 month old, we've had our share of diapers over the last few years. Got a diaper genie before our first was born, and have been using it ever since. No complaints, other than the cost of the liners. Diaper genies are a bit like printers. You may think it's low cost at first, but they get you on the supplies. Even with a different brand of liner, it only saves a few dollars. It adds up. And it really only serves the one role, so when the last is potty trained, the Diaper Genie is going away.But, again, no problems. I didn't know there could be a better way. I think, for us, this Bubula is that better way. First off, ours worked right out the box. No problems or hassles or dents. Push down the big button on the side, the "trap door" opens and the diaper drops in, to be sealed back up again. Took a lot of pressure at first, but it loosens up a bit. My 3 year old can only open it the slightest bit, so I'm not worried about her getting a hand caught or dropping all manner of other items in there.The white steel looks nice and is fairly durable, though it's not very thick so vulnerable to dents if knocked over or into really hard.Some minor complaints. I would have liked to have some more information about it. In the box is just the can, with the pictorial instructions on the lid, and on a small card. It's not that complex, so not a big deal, but it seemed pretty spare in that box. The latch is my other complaint. It advertises a "lock" but I don't see how that works. The latch is easy opened and not terribly secure. No worse than the Diaper Genie, to be sure, but not at all "locked".What I love is the fact it takes regular garbage bags. Get the scented kind and it's even better. No more extra hassle of running out or getting the special brand. Holds a lot. Another great thing is this has a longer usage. Once we're done with diaper, it can serve as a nice trash can, or as we're planning, for recycled cans/bottles.More expensive at first, but really does save money in the long run, and can keep being used. A worthwhile investment.

I have a variety of sleeping bags, collected from various sources, used in camping in various contexts.  My bags are mostly nicer, made for warmth in cold places, while packing small and light.  My trouble, that I run into a lot, is that I got my bags at various stages of camping goals, venturing into winter camping, or in the mountains, or hiking through national parks, both islands and forests.  Here in Southern California, these latter are more often warm than cold, and so while my bags are great for those times I go to more distant climes, I find my bags are often less suitable for the places I'm at.  Now with a young family, we're doing a lot of car camping on road trips.  Another thing, I tend to sleep really warm. That's been a quandary. I bought warm bags for times they are most needed, and make do with them when it's not so cold out.That's why I was excited about this bag.  And I love it.  It doesn't pack down very small, though a compression sack would help a fair bit. Nor is it that light. It's not something you'd throw in a backpack for a wilderness trip.  It is, however, my new favorite bag for casual campground camping and road trips.  It becomes what you need it to be, converting to being flexible for a wide variety of needs, from near freezing to summer nights.It opens fully, so can become a blanket if need be. The hood zips off, making for a nice little pillow. There is a middle layer, which is a great idea. You can sleep on top of or under the middle layer, offering comfort or warmth, or take it out altogether.  The bag has a storage sack as well as a wrap at the end that rolls around it and can be tightened (this isn't shown in the picture). The sides are exposed, but it's pretty secure and has a carrying handle. The bag itself has straps for carrying by hand or over your shoulder.If I could design a perfect bag for me to bring along on road trips or campgrounds, this is pretty close to everything I would want. My more expensive bags are going to get a lot less use now, keeping them only for more adventurous outings.Definitely recommend.  Size/weight are bit high, but for the cost that's to be expected. What you get is definitely well worth the money in terms of flexibility and design.

This is the book I needed at this moment.  I'm in the early stages of discussing a new venture with a good friend of mine. It's a great idea, untapped market, etc. and so on. He has experience starting and running companies. I don't.  It's trendy to say one has an entrepreneurial gift, but I don't.Some of that has to do with personality. Which is fine, I offer other elements to the table. A lot of it has to do with experience.  Being in the world of business and start-ups and contexts of development offers their own lessons.  That's not where I've been, but I'm moving towards needing facility in those places. I don't look for mastery, just familiarity and ideas of what I should expect, how to process steps and stages, and, basically, feel like I'm keeping up with my venture partner.This book offers a great starting place, a conversational journey through the process. It's not an MBA in a book, it's not a step-by-step guide. But I don't want or need those.  I want to understand the themes and thinking and pitfalls of the process we're entering into.Dan Shapiro has experience with startups and is an engaging writer, mixing narrative with concept in a very readable and engaging way. Definitely the book for me at this point so I recommend it to others.

I have good Bible computer software. I also have a seminary degree and a PhD in Theology.I like having a print concordance around even still for several reasons. One, I like print still. I am on or near a computer all day, and this book lets me step away from that. My brain works differently when I'm turning pages and reading real texts, making connections.Two, I like something that is more immediately useful to others. I think in our day and age, anyone can have a quality knowledge of how to best engage the text.  This book allows me to sit down and walk them through a quick process of intro word studies, using a tool that they can buy (rather than the 100s or more that the higher quality software costs).  The NIV provides a common resource focus.Third, as to this concordance itself, it packs in a great deal of content in one volume.  It's well presented and organized, easy to take up and get to using.  Or, browsing.  I like bookstores for the same reason.  I learn through browsing.
