The design is a simpler one than my older staplers and it does not affect performance and seems to make the stapler less prone to jamming. It does have an initial load factor that requires a good deal more hand strength than my other staplers. The net result is greater penetration with the staples. I would not however recommend the Bostitch staples as their blunt ends are not as effective as other brands that have pointed tips at the ends of the staple.

Bought this to replace this coffee maker's predecessor as we love the slow brew setting. First one lasted 5-1/2 years which is good for something like this. Not only does the "aroma" setting make for tastier coffee, which we notice as we drink coffee black, it also allows for less coffee to be used. A coffee measure that is for ground coffee works well for unground beans at a 1 measure for 1 "cup" of coffee. Without the aroma setting I would be using at least 25% more coffee to get the same level of richness.Bitter coffee is the result of the water being too hot and removing alkaloids from the coffee beans and with the aroma setting this is avoided completely.As mentioned the newer model has a carafe with thinner and more fragile glass so care needs to be taken even when the carafe is cold.

I was surprised to find that there is only 10mg of tocotrienols in each capsule or 1/35 of what is provided in other brands' formulations. This is not a good choice for people who want to take vitamin E for its anti-oxidant qualities

Best single book on cholesterol, heart disease, and statins I have read. It does the best job of covering the biological mechanics involved and does so in a way that a lay person can understand but without being dumbed down. The information provided references studies so anyone who want more detail can easily research further.One aspect that Graveline covers in detail is the FDA's Medwatch database which though poorly organized and categorized can be researched with time and diligence to find thousands of cases of reported physical damage from the use of statins. It is not only that statins provide only a 1.1% gain in absolute numbers for preventing heart attacks but that statins also lead to increases in cancers and diabetes and other factors that lead to disability or death.Information such as Merck having filed a patent for a combination statin and CO Q10 product which shows that this drug company was away of the downsides of statins, is something I have not seen mentioned in any of the books or articles on the subject that I have read. It speaks volumes to the corruption of the health care industry in this country and also to the unique perspective provided by Dr. Graveline.If you only care to read one book on statins or are looking for something to give someone you know is on statins and about whom you care, this is the one to get or give.

The size is perfect and it holds the SD cards in individual pockets securely. The downside is that the Velcro closure makes a great deal of noise when opening the case to get a card out. This limits where it may be practical to use.

The nut drivers were actually shipped in a nice reusable round plastic container. The DeWalt nut drivers have a marginal magnet for use with construction screws like the ones from Simpson. My old brand had a stronger magnet and so fewer dropped screws than with the DeWalt version.

True 60-Watt iron that is more than adequate for heavy gauge electrical connections. Nothing fancy but gets the job done for a reasonable price. Tip is wide enough for a twisted wire bundle and fine for this sort of task. Not for delicate or precision work.

I charged the battery and the first use the light lasted for a little over 3 hours. I recharged the battery and the second time at 2/3 output the battery lasted less than 2 hours. Recharged the battery a third time and the light lasted for 10 minutes.There is no way to know the state of the charge as the red LED indicator lamp immediately changes to green when the charger is plugged into the light and never changes, even when left for 24 hours.

My mistake in thinking that niacinamide equals vitamin B-3. As it turns out B-3 is composed of niacinamide and niacin. Both are precursors to NAD and NADP and so can provide health benefits.I wanted "B-3" to treat cholesterol and bought this niacinamide not realizing that it is worthless for this purpose. Only the nicotinic acid form of B-3 is effective for treating a cholesterol profile."Although the two are identical in their vitamin activity, nicotinamide does not have the same pharmacological effects (lipid modifying effects) as niacin. Nicotinamide does not reduce cholesterol or cause flushing"Same applies to IHN which does not produce flushing but is also not bioavailable and "theres no evidence that it reaches the therapeutic levels needed to alter lipids' according to a recent study in the Journal of Clinical Lipidology.

This light works very well within its limitations. The light beam is very broad at more than 120 degrees and bright enough on the high and often on a lower setting (output is adjustable). It is not truly a work light with its short battery life of 3 hours. If you can get the task done in 3 hours it is OK. If you need something that will provide light for more than 3 hours then you need to get either an 110v AC powered work light or one with user replaceable batteries.Intsun Portable Cordless 24 leds 30W 2400LM 3 modes CREE XM-L Rechargeable LED RGB Flood Spot Light Outdoor Camping Lamp Floodlight, powered by 3PCS 18650 3.7V Rechargeable Lithium Battery, battery included. (24 LED)It is smaller than my halogen work lights and it puts out less than 1% as much heat which helps in confined spaces. A halogen worklight easily becomes a space heater. No worries about getting burned as with the halogen worklights.A battery charge lasts up to 4 hours on a dim setting. It can be powered off the 12v DC brick that could be plugged into 110AC but that makes the light unwieldy and there is no mechanical strain relief so this is not really a solution.There are some aspects that could stand to be improved. For one the On-Off switch is on the bottom of the housing as is the place to press to adjust the light level. Better if they were on the back or top of the housing.Second is that star washers were used where the knobs are screwed into the housing for the handle and bottom support. They do nothing to prevent the handle from flopping around. I have replaced the metal star washers with fiber washers and that helped keep the handle and LED housing in position.Third is the charge indicator is worthless. When the charge is down to nothing the light goes out and if the brick is plugged in to recharge the battery then the LED shows as Red initially and then switches to Green. Whether the charge level of the batteries is zero or 100% the small LED indicator lamp shows Green so there is no way to know what the charge level is or even if it is at 100%.I would recommend this light as a backup light or for use when the 3-4 hour battery life is not a problem. At two-thirds brightness the battery charge lasts for less than 3 hours. For extended work I would recommend one of the LED work lights where the batteries can be removed for charging and a fresh set put in their place.

Excellent camera with upgrade autofocus performance over the D800e. Large files produced but this can be reduced by using 1.2x crop more or shooting in 12-bit instead of 14-bit capture. Pro build quality and a step up from the D750/D610/D7200 cameras.Only area that needs to be improved is its use of one CF card slot and one SD card slot so two types of memory cards are required.Be careful about buying this as there are businesses selling the D810 that are not authorized by Nikon and in the USA if you later need servicing or repairs Nikon will refuse to provide it for the camera. There are places where you can download a PDF file for current authorized dealers, which does not include Amazon or Abe's of Maine (which is selling Import or Grey market cameras and pretending falsely that they are returns).

It shows as compatible with GM vehicles when it is not. Should be 22mm and closest non-metric size would be 7/8 that would be oversize but might work. Nice concept but better to buy a retractable ratchet wrench or breaker bar and whatever socket size is actually needed for your car or truck.
Tastes like cardboard with chocolate bits. When it arrived it also had a code life of less than 60 days remaining.

The breaking strength according to the Mile Marker website for this thickness of their synthetic rope is 15,000 lbs. or a lot more than is indicated on the product listing here.This is not designed to be used like a snatch strap which makes it a lot safer. Problem with a snatch strap is that if it breaks loose from either vehicle the strap and whatever is on the end of it becomes a potentially lethal projectile. It has taken out many a windshield and not long ago killed a good Samaritan pulling a vehicle that was stuck in the sand at Pismo Beach.It you have two vehicles it is much safer for both of them to use their combined traction with a tow rope to extricate the stuck vehicle. It also puts a lot less stress on the attachment points on the two vehicles so there is less chance of damage to either vehicle.

I have only used it on salmon and halibut that were then grilled but the results were terrific with the flavor of the fish enhanced but not masked as with many marinades. Faster as well as I rubbed on the ingredients and put the fish immediately on the grill.

The feeder I received does not have lids or covers for the top of the suet holders which makes them a hazard for small birds. For some reason Amazon cannot be trusted to insure that the product pictures match the actual item being sold.

We were surprised at how much of an improvement this phone set was over our old one. Lots of improvements including easier to read display for incoming calls, calls are announced with the person's name if they are in the directory, directory that holds20x as many phone numbers, auto turn off and turn on by hour of the day with its Silent Mode, junk call filtering, ability to label phones with a name (office, garage, etc) instead of a number.Many other features including the ability to integrate it with a cell phone. We do not have cell phone service where we live in California (along with 14,000 other people) so we cannot comment on how well it works.If we had to replace these and had to spend twice as much it would be worth it.

I had bought the Garmin 760LM with the B-20 camera as a kit and this makes it practical to leave the base and sender for the camera in the truck and have this one ready for use in another vehicle.Expensive for what it is but I was glad to get a solution that worked without having to buy a new GPS

I cannot yet comment on how well these socks will wear but they do have a reinforced toe pocket so I am optimistic in this regard. They are thinner than what I want in a hiking sock but good for walking shoes or for snug boots where a thinner sock is desired. For use as a boot sock I would not recommend them.There may be a problem with quality control. The first pair I put on snagged one of my toes. Turning the sock inside out there were a half dozen threads that made for a 3 inch loop that I had to cut off with scissors. Time will tell if this causes the sock to unravel.

The feeder I received is not like the one shown in the picture. The picture shows that the suet block holders have a top cover and the feeder I received does not have the covers. Without the covers there will be small birds getting trapped and dying inside the suet holders.

Excellent compass. There is also a MC2GM version that is metric and a better choice for use overseas where the maps will be in metric dimensions. A bit of a pain having to have two compasses but that is the price to be paid for living in one of the most backward regions of the world.
These are very comfortable socks and have good cushioning. Too early to comment on how well they wear over time but in the past Fox River socks have provided above average longevity.

High price for a piece of plastic to stick over a speedlight. Output is broadcast to the sides and back so 75% of the flash output is wasted. This results in fewer flashes per set of batteries and longer recycle times for a lose lose result. I tried this at a wedding and after 5 minutes tossed it into the recycle bin.Far better to put your money into Neil van Niekerk's excellent book "On-Camera Flash Techniques for Digital Wedding and Portrait Photography" and learn how to use your flash properly. Most flash units have a popup plastic reflector or one can use an index card and a rubber band to the same effect as the Gary Fong plastic globe.

40% refined sugar makes these far from healthy and on par with something from Kellogs. A bit of a con to use agave sugar which is no different than a high fructose corn sugar for the body. So difficult to find a low sugar low sodium low refined sugar snack bar.Guess I will go back to making my own.

It is a small and slender nozzle that has its pluses. One is the low cost, another is the ease of rotating the nozzle even with full water pressure to open or adjust or close off the water stream completely. It also adjusts to produce a good spray pattern for watering individual plants.Its shortcoming is that when the nozzle is adjusted to produce a solid stream of water the slender nozzle reduces the stream to half that of any other nozzle I have used. If you want to use the jet setting to rinse an area or to get maximum distance without having to drag the hose to some spot then this is not the nozzle to get.

Images were not bad but few were ones of the level I would want to show them to someone. I did not do an actual count but it felt like 99% of the images were taken during inclement weather. It is one thing for photographers to direct their efforts during the golden hours but with these images I felt like the UK did not have golden hours at all. Most of the time the sky was included in the shot and the editors selected only images where there was a dramatic (i.e. cloudy) sky. This process no doubt eliminated a lot of images from the selection which is most unfortunate.

I bought this book to get ideas of places and times to photograph the Great Sand Dunes NP and the surrounding area. This book is one of very few that surpassed my expectations. Highly recommend this book for anyone visiting the area.

As you know, this is a huge box of huge (full-sheet) labels. You can use them full-sized, of course, or cut them down into smaller labels of shapes and sizes that suit your purpose.Pros:1. Full-sheet labels maximize versatility2. 250 sheets in this huge box3. Avery makes it easy, by providing templates for printing labels and other goodies. For example, for these big sheets, they also have several halloween themes, for cutting out pieces to be used to decorate pumpkins.Cons:1. These labels are not thick enough to fully mask writing that's beneath them. OTOH, if they were thick enough for that, they wouldn't go through your printer, so this is probably the better option.These are great for a variety of uses, albeit a really big box of them, and thus, expensive.

I have worked with a number of Epson printers in recent years and am a fan of the brand. This unit was no exception.Epson printers come well packed and with user-friendly unpacking -- there is light blue tape in various places that might wiggle during shipment, each with a tab to make it easy to remove. Plug in, install the ink cartridges, and give it a few minutes to run its setup drill. While this is happening, I went to the Epson site to get the drivers (as a Mac user, I'm often on a machine w/o a CD drive, and it's easy enough to go to the Epson site). I grabbed and installed the scanner driver and then read on the Epson site the info that the printer driver is now delivered through the Apple App Store (free), which is a good improvement. (I didn't need it since I have other Epson printers, and my driver is current). I set up wifi, did the suggested firmware update, and was good to print.As with any small in one, you will have a continued expense with the ink cartridges. Epson have chips in them to try to prevent you from refilling and things like that. Every once in awhile the electronics of the cartridge fails, but you can make a claim with them. It's all kind of annoying, and yet somehow I remain a fan of the printers because they just work and print so nicely. This one is no exception.Pros:1. High-quality double-sided printing2. Copier and scanner, too3. The new EPSON drivers allow printing from mobile devices4. Well packaged for shipping5. Easy setupCons:1. Cost of ink adds up over timeNote: I worked with an XP-610 and have an XP-810 at home right now. I prefer the 8XX series because of the document feeder at the top and I like the larger touchscreen LCD. I don't use the fax that's available on the 8XX series, but I like those other things. Contrariwise, this is a smaller unit, and sometimes that's a very nice thing.Again, I have consistently been pleased with the Epson printers I've worked with, and this is another happy experience.

Since there are few reviews right now for this TV, let me point out that there are more for the Polaroid 50GSR3000 on Amazon. Looking at the Polaroid site, the difference between the FA model (this one) and the non-FA model, the FA model is 60Hz and the non-FA model is 120Hz. They don't have both versions showing up on the Polaroid site right now, but for the 55" versions, the FA model has an 8ms response time, while the non-FA model has a 5ms response time. (You can google response time and get folks' opinions about that for different uses -- e.g., gamers don't much care for it.)I thought this was going to be too much TV in our little house, but yay, it fits fine, and wow, does it ever look great. My other TV is a Toshiba 46L5200U 46-Inch 1080p 120Hz LED TV (also from Amazon, almost three years ago), and the Polaroid is so much crisper in the images.I agree with the reviewer who said that instructions are lacking; even just putting the base together was a minor pain. For some stuff, you might find it useful to go to polaroidhdtv dot com to find the user's guide, and will also give you more specs than are here. I will put instructions for assembling the base and more specs from the Polaroid web site in comments below, to keep this from getting too long.I found the TV way too dark immediately out of the box, but after tweaking the brightness and contrast, I'm very very happy with the picture. I also think the sound is fantastic. My Toshiba is hooked up to surround sound, and I haven't done that with the new Polaroid yet, and the sound is surprisingly great for no external speakers. (I see in the reviews for the 50GSR3000 that some folks complained about the sound being wimpy. I dunno.)Pros:1. Great picture, and great sound. Maybe I have just this one pro, but that's what you want out of your TV, right?2. Energy Star rating -- estimated yearly energy cost is $12.Cons:1. Weak instructions.2. 60 Hz. Consider the 50GSR3000 instead... or one of the other screen sizes.3. I agree with the previous reviewer that the scanning for channels is a big drag, but yeah, TVs do that.Other:1. If you go chase down the online manual, you'll see that the inputs are towards the middle of the TV, and not easily accessible from the edges. There are pros and cons to either approach, depending on how your TV is set up, how you want it to look, and how you're going to use it.Again, I'm really delighted with this TV.

I love this bag, but it's just a little bit too small. It will just barely fit 8.5 x 11-inch papers, which means that they're hard to get in and out. But it'll work. A standard-sized pocket folder, which is just a bit longer (11.5 inches?) can also squeeze in, but again, tricky, and you couldn't put a bunch of them in. (A manilla folder should work as well as regular paper.) I do think I can use it for carrying standard-sized paper things around, and will probably do that. It is a happy-making thing.Pros:1. Totoro!2. Pockets! Two outside glasses pockets (probably too small to get most beverages into) a back zipper pocket, the front flap pocket (the whole inner flap area is one big pocket), two open pockets under the flap, an interior zipper pocket on one side and small open pockets on the other interior side.3. The interior has a Totoro print.4. There is a zipper across the main interior pocket.5. Everything seems reasonably well constructed.6. The front buckles also snap on at the two rivets, so you don't actually need to fiddle with the buckles. Just unsnap and snap. This also allows for some adjustment if your bag is overfull and you can get another couple of inches out of it.Cons:1. Cotton canvas like this has a limited life span, so we will all be sad as our bags disintegrate.2. I just wish it were a little larger.All things considered, it's a very happy thing.

Amazon tells me that I got this April 7, 2012I picked this tray for two reasons: because I like the bamboo and because I have a LOT of flatware, and it's capacious. I am not disappointed by those two things. I am disappointed because it's not made very well. I am regluing it today, or trying to, which leads me to visit Amazon and write a review.Pros:1. I do like the bamboo, quite a bit. It makes me happy2. I have a space-crunched kitchen, and this fits well in the top drawer3. I think I have service for 16 (two 8-person sets), plus some extra pieces like iced tea spoon, and this holds it all. Maybe I have service for 20, even, come to think of it.Cons:1. Everything is a little bit warped. I'm pretty sure it was when I got it, but it certainly is now. This make the regluing effort a bit questionable.2. What led me to reglue is that table knives started sliding underneath, out of their official bin. (This did, of course, over time, lead to increased wedging. FWIW, I have for years now just slid the knives back out and popped the dividers back into place, but the knives want what the knives want, and they do it again. Today, I had enough silverware in the dishwasher that I decided it was a good day to try to reglue.3. The back piece appears to be a veneer, so who knows what I'm gluing to, anyway.4. Whether over the course of time or initially shoddy construction, the dividers will not meet flush with the base. I was initially trying to glue and clamp and gave that up. I did try that for a few hours, and then decided to treat it more like caulking with my Elmer's: I am trying to make a barrier that will prevent the knives from slipping underneath again and continually wedging things up.Four stars because I still love the wood of this, the depth, and that it fits so well in my drawer. As I was hoping, it's a good use of the space that I have, and it's classy, even with all its flaws.FWIW, I have gotten over the need to have one specific item in each compartment. In the longest bin on the left, I have serving spoons, pushed towards the top, and iced tea spoons, pushed towards the bottom. In the next compartment, I have the knives, which was probably the worst choice for them, giving the wedging behavior, and I might rearrange when I refill the drawer. Next, I have forks, the real dinner forks. On the far right, I have the regular spoons at the top of the bin and the teaspoons at the bottom of the bin. I have almost no use for desert forks, so I put those across the top, in the smaller bin that goes sideways. And I can't easily reach the very top bin, so very seldom used things go there. I gather my intermingling of different types of silverware is a disappointment to some readers, but it really works well for me. Again, I am space crunched, and this is the optimal solution. I will probably swap the knives and the spoons when I refill the drawer, since this will give the knives less opportunity to escape. I think.

Overall, I really like these for working in an open environment, when my colleagues might say something to me, as opposed to when I'm legit in putting my head down and trying to entirely shut out the noise from others.Pros:1. Ability to hear what's going on around you while you are listening to your own music or computer sounds or whatever.2. I think the sound quality is fine for what these are. I do have to move them around a bit to get them to the point where I feel that way about them, not just put them on.Cons:1. I have a huge head (23 or 24" hat size), and these are uncomfortably tight for me. They need the pressure to do their thing of course, but need to either come in sizes or be adjustable.2. They don't always work well with eyeglasses. They work fine with my metal frames, which don't have a lot of bulk near my ears. But they bump up against my plastic frames, which have broader earpieces. (They bump the glasses frame a the "corners" of the headphones, where it's turning down to get to my ear.)Overall, I think these are great to have. But for the comfort reasons, I can't wear them all day or anything.

It's a shame that as I write this there is very little information about this product available on the web. I can't find the Amazon listing for it, and even the littleBits web page doesn't really refer to it yet. I will to to update later when I have a better sense of what you'd already know and what I can add.Me: I am a STEM educator (Science Technology Engineering and Math). I teach students older than these kits are designed for, but have volunteered with younger groups, and raised a technically-oriented child. I've worked with the MIT miniboard and handyboard, which were precursors to the Lego mindstorms kits now available.LittleBits is an amazing, amazing product. Modular electronics that enable kids to be creative and explore without anyone having to fret too much about breaking things or doing dangerous things. From the moment of seeing the box, you want to engage, and everything is colorful and happy and accessible. There are step-by-step instructions for a number of projects to get you going, but then, similar to a Lego Mindstorms set, tons of room to create and invent on your own.Resources:1. The littleBits website has lots of resources: littlebits dot cc -- this will help you understand what stepping into littleBits entails. (Amazing!)2. It's not yet available, but there will be resources specific to this kit available at littlebits dot cc slash ggkit3. Once you've decided you're on the littleBits path, you'll want to decide which is the best kit for you. There is a comparison chart at littlebits dot cc slash shop slash compare-kits -- again, as I write this, this kit is not yet mentioned there.In this kit:1. There are 15 "bits" -- the core electronic pieces that snap together to make things. I will list them below2. There are instructions to make 10+ projects (plus, because there are variations and there are/will be more available online)3. There's a bag full of extra things you need -- Lego-like boards for holding things together, wheels, batteries, glue dots, velcro, ...)4. There's a bag with cardstock (paper) pieces needed for some projects (and/or templates), and stickers for decorating things, including printable labels.5. There's an instruction book.LittleBits divides the primary components into four categories: Power, Input, Wire (connections), and Output. These are color-coded to blue, pink, orange, and green, respectively. I was wondering how this compared to the "Deluxe Kit" when I picked it, so I'll use that as a point of comparison for the provided core componentsThe 15 littleBits included in this kit are:POWER  2 power bits  (1 in deluxe kit)INPUT  2 slide dimmers (1 in deluxe kit)  1 light sensor (none in deluxe kit)WIRE 1 wire (4 in deluxe kit)  1 wireless transmitter (none in deluxe kit)  1 wireless receiver (none in deluxe kit)  1 split (none in deluxe kit)OUTPUT 1 buzzer (1 in deluxe kit)  2 dc motors (1 in deluxe kit)  1 servo and hub (1 in deluxe kit? it's called a "servo" there, so maybe a different part)  1 fan (0 in deluxe kit)If I've kept track of everything correctly, the additional parts that the deluxe kit has that this one does are INPUT: 1 button, 1 pulse, 1 sound trigger, 1 timeout; WIRE: 1 fork (maybe the same as my "split"?), 1 inverter, 1 latch; OUTPUT: 1 light wire, 1 rgb led. The Deluxe Kit includes 18 "bits" in total, while again, this Gizmos and Gadgets Kit includes 15 in total.I'm currently of the impression that while there's some overlap, there's a number of obvious differences, too, and that somewhere down the road, these two kits might be wonderful complements to each other. I don't have the Deluxe Kit, so I'm not sure, but the one in my hands feels like an amazing introduction to this whole path and an excellent starting point.Pros:1. Amazing, amazing educational toy that makes doing these technical things accessible, appealing, and exciting for young learners.2. 10 guided projects and huge room to explore/design/create other projects oneself3. An active online community encourages sharing of ideas, questions, and accomplishments4. You can download Avery templates for printing on the labels -- nice!5. I really love that there is nothing that hints at gender hereCons:1. My only gripe is the way they did the project book, which has staples on the left edge (not with folded longer sheets and staples down the middle, but a stack of single sheets with three staples along the edge). This is not going to wear well. My suggestion is to immediately fold 1/4" up or back along that edge to try to make it "know where to open to" and have a bit of a longer life span. Otherwise, the pages are going to start ripping soon.Other:1. The card-stock things, of course, are going to get spent and used up. I think having them as examples is important to the creative process and then your kids will need to come up with alternative means of accomplishing the same thing. I don't currently see a better solution (so I'm not calling this a "con"); maybe they will provide refill packs.I'm laughing to myself right now because we've been working on clearing old stuff out of the house and it turns out I have my son's old electronics kit in a pile right across the room from me. Although he is a very technical person (he's now an engineering major in college), I could never get him to play around with me and the electronics kit. There was a barrier to understanding what was possible and what was cool about it, and a steep learning curve until you "got it". Littlebits erases the step up to the accessibility of electronics. I am entirely in awe.

I'm a fan of Epson printers and have worked with several. The others are "home office" type all-in-ones, and this is the first one that I wouldn't use at home and will use at work. But it has all the great features I'm used to, plus a number of great things I wasn't even expecting.My previous work printer was an HP 4700 (or something close to it). That was a workhorse printer, and as near as I can tell, this Epson WorkForce is it's match -- plus, the Epson has a number of modern features that mean that it's a much better printer to work with.As others have described, this is a big heavy thing, and the only real question to my mind is whether you have enough space for it. The side wings that enable the long-lived ink supply mean that this really takes up a lot of room. As with my other Epsons, this comes enormously well packed, with blue tape tabs holding things securely for shipping, but easily eye catching and easily removable once its in your hands. The instructions were straightforward for putting in the ink cartridges and other minor setup things, and you will need to install printer drivers on your computers, and then you're good to go.Pros:1. Great print, copy, and scan quality (I don't use a fax, so I can't comment on that).2. Multiple connectivity options, including network (ethernet), wifi, wifi direct, USB, and Google Cloud3. Reasonably well designed interface on color touch screen for setting options4. Ink that lasts for a remarkably long time.5. I kind of expect double-sided printing at this point, and yes, this has it.6. I have gotten spoiled by Epson's wireless scanning (to my device) in the past, and this will continue to spoil me.Cons:1. The only drawback I can see to this printer is its large footprint. Again, it's a regular large-size work printer, but then has the earmuffs for the plentiful ink. (I see that there's another version of this with a different ink system if the size of the printer is an issue.)Basically, I love everything about this printer, and am delighted to have it.

There are so many things to love about this product.Pros:1. Human-grade food for your pooch. I feel so good about that.2. Also, responsible ingredients, including the wild-caught pollock3. My dog couldn't wait to eat it from the moment I opened the box4. Low-impact packaging. The notion of "add water" dog food is entirely new to me. I have bought some dog food from amazon in the past and I always feel so bad about how much packaging and labor is involved in getting it to me. This is a lot less of those things for moist food in the end, even.Cons:1. This can't sit around, like dry food does. My dog ate it immediately, but that's not her usual behavior. Usually, she nibbles over a stretch of time.2. Inside the box are two plastic bags (4lb. version); you need to cut these open and then find a way to reseal them till you've used things up. I just used a binder clip.3. I have also tried the grain-free turkey version, and this one -- not surprisingly -- stinks of fish.Other:1. I don't usually give my dog wet food, so that part is strange to me. Also, the having to wait part.2. My dog will "eat anything", but she also lets her displeasure be known when it's not something she was hoping for. Again, as soon as I opened the bag, I had her interest. She doesn't usually do this at meal time, and doesn't attack the food when I give it to her like most dogs do. She was very attentive as I was making this, and ate it immediately. (Since people are mentioning their breeds... she is a shelter dog, so I don't know, but certainly part lab and maybe part chow. )I am very happy to have discovered the Honest Kitchen dog foods, and am now feeding my pup about 50-50 this and her regular kibble.I really appreciate this product and hope I get used to the mixing part and that my dog continues to love it.

I don't even have a spiralizer and I love this book.What I have is an allergy to grains and a lot of veggies from the CSA (community-supported agriculture -- I pay for veggies every week, but don't pick what I get). I often run the squash through the grater on my Cuisinart and end up with a similar base for foods. For me, this cookbook provides a wealth of suggestions for what to do with that grated squash, which does start to get a little tiring after a while. And it's also has inspiring ideas for many other vegetables as well.As you know there are four main sections of recipes here: gluten-free, paleo, vegetarian and vegan, and raw food. Some of the recipes fit into other categories than the one they're in, so there's quite a bit to chose from for anyone on one or more of these restrictive diets.My only criticism is that there aren't enough pictures.... but the ones that are there are well done.(This cookbook is encouraging me to get a spiralizer, but in the meantime, grating is working fine for me.)

I love teal and was eyeing this bag for a long time before I decided to go for it. It is a very nice bag, and I'm glad I did.Note that it's 7"x10", not 8"x10" as currently listed on Amazon.Pros:1. Perfect deep teal color.2. Heavy, high-quality leather3. Loads of pockets to help keep things organized: back outside, front inside (just under the flap), slender inside pocket behind that, and then the main compartment has a zipper pocket on one side and an open stash pocket on the other side.4. Adjustable-length shoulder strap.Cons:1. I am tall, and to wear this messenger style, the strap is a little short... but it still works.Other:1. I couldn't tell online, but the buckle on the front is for show and conceals a magnetic clasp underneath. Similarly, the back pocket is not entirely open and has a small magnetic claspI was fortunate enough to get this bag at a considerable discount from its current price on Amazon and other sites, so I'm feeling pretty lucky about that. (Oh, I get it. I actually bought it from Amazon, but now it's only third-party sellers.)Among the things I most love about this bag is that I can expect to have it for years because it's such nice leather and so well made.

I used to regularly feed my dog Eagle Pack, but moved and never found a seller in my new town. I didnt realize till today that Amazon carries it though maybe they didnt, a few years ago.Anyway, thats my primary comparison to the Wellness CORE food.I think both companies make products that are particularly targeted toward healthy food for our pets. Most of us looking at these sorts of brands are aware that the food streams for humans in our country are sketchy, with questionable additives and questionable farming practices; its the same, of course, for our dogs.The Eagle Pack is cheaper on Amazon, but it also relies on rice and other grains. This relies instead on potatoes for starch. There are downsides to both of those choices. As you might know, all rice grown in the US contains some amount of arsenic, which is implicated in cancer and auto-immune diseases. Its a naturally occurring substance, but historically was used as a pesticide, so in some fields it has been added. Rice soaks it up like a sponge, so it ends up in our food supply. Potatoes are less of a concern on my list, but you might not know that nightshades (which includes potatoes, tomatoes, and peppers) are implicated in rheumatoid arthritis. As my girl ages, this is something I think about.I should mention as well that my dog loves this, but the truth is that she just loves food, so that doesnt mean much. And even though I put out a bowl of this and the other kibble I had on hand (Trader Joes, cause Id run out), and she picked this she will fairly consistently pick anything new over anything familiar, so I still dont know that it means anything. But she doesnt hate it, I can assert that!This is an excellent product, and Im happy to have had the opportunity to try it. Its also wonderful to see that its available via Subscribe and Save, so I can get the 15% discount and not have to lug the heavy bag back from the store. Win.

Most of us are aware of the growing crisis in our healthcare system, but might not understand the breadth of this nor how to navigate the broken system when we need healthcare. This is such a wonderful book to learn about both.I'm not usually a fan of books that are full of anecdotes, but in this book each one is used to provide a very clear example that is anchored in the experience of the author, and many are backed up with references or resources.The book unfolds through three parts (each with mutiple chapters) that give advice on how to select and work with your primary care physician, how to escalate to an expert and deal with an emergency, and how to cope with a serious illness. The end of each chapter has a nice summary of the points in that chapter to recap.)A constant message throughout is that you should be an informed consumer of your medical care, that you should keep track of your own (and family members) medical history, and that you need to advocate for yourself and inform yourself.Since we all need medical care even in the broken system, this is a book for all of us.

This is a fantastic cellphone case. It's just a little bit thicker than the black jelly case I was using before, but offers more protection against drops.Pros:1. Two-layer design offers rubbery layer inside and smooth shiny layer outside2. Buttons all work wonderfully... no problems at all3. Still easy to get on and off if you want to swap cases.Cons:1. Not as sleek as my black jelly case, which makes my phone a shiny glossy black brick (which I seem to kinda like). But of course that one is not very protective.2. Not as protective as an Otter-Box-type case. But of course you knew that.This is a really great compromise between sleek and protective... a little of both

This is far and away my favorite hair coloring. You couldn't find it for a stretch there, and I was buying it from off merchants when I could find it, and now I'm so excited to see that Amazon is selling it again.My hair is naturally what I've long called dirty dishwater strawberry blond and a friend more poetically called the color of honey. It's a reddish dark blond or maybe a light auburn, but isn't a fiery carrot top of any shade. For me, this covers (or disguises?) the gray that's creeping in and kicks up the red a bit.When I was unable to find this and trying to find "my shade" in other brands (hopeless), I was always embarrassed to be near other people just after a coloring because it all stinks so much. Not to mention what the hell am I doing to myself with those harsh chemicals. (For some brands, the included conditioner smells like fake coconut and that's a smell I particularly detest; the conditioner here is more of a neutral scent.)This won't be for everyone because it's not "permanent", but for me, I like that it gradually fades out and doesn't leave a line with the new growth. And I also like that it doesn't make my hair a monotone color... it adds color and leaves natural variation, and I think the result is very natural looking. For me, I try not to leave it on too long or it ends up a little redder than I'd like most of the time.FWIW, I have very long hair but just use one box. I do all the wrong things and color just after shampooing, so my hair is still wet from that. Plus, of course, the ends don't need much.

I love marcasite and sterling jewelry, and was excited to give these a try. I find them a little disappointing, but mostly a lot of fun. Now that I have it in my hands, the marcasites are smaller and stingier than I think they should be, and the silver is too whitePros:1. Fun baubles that look a lot like they're presented here.2. Marcasite and sterling silver, though the red part is glass.3. Not "too heavy", though definitely heavier than most other earrings I wear.4. Come in the lovely black with blue accents Amazon Collection box, so they are nice gifts.Cons:1. I think the design is a little quirky, and I don't quite get the swirly shapes on the back.2. I don't know what Amazon does with their sterling silver. It's very white, and sterling naturally has a warmer tone.3. I wish these were lever backs; I find the hooks and the plastic keepers don't look as nice to my mind. In this case, the wires look sort of cheap next to the rest of the earring, because they are relatively thin wires as compared to the relatively solid earrings.4. I am confused by the pricing on these; currently $46.25. These should be maybe $25 or $30.Other:1. The listing is off, saying 38 marcasite stones in one place and 8 marcasite stones in another. I think there are 23 stones in each earring and 46 total.2. As with the other Amazon Collection sterling items I've gotten, they are stamped on the back with "PAJ 925" and "China". Googling tells me that 925 refers to the maker; 925 of course refers to the silver, and China, of course, is the country of manufacture.I took the picture attached here both to compare with an more "classic" marcasite and to compare to the size of a quarter (and to show the little plastic earring back that comes with each earring). The older earring has had a chance to develop a patina, but I'm not sure the Amazon one ever will. It just seems like the metal is coated or treated somehow, and I wish Amazon were straightforward about what they're doing with their sterling.I think they're fun earrings, but they are a little disappointing, too.

I've now tried three different keyboard cases for my iPad Air 2, and I don't think this is my favorite. It's a solid case and has a nice flat and responsive keyboard like Macs. I am not crazy about the way that the iPad is set in from the outer edge of the case, which seems to make everything bigger than it needs to be. However, it doesn't have a full keyboard, which won't matter to almost anyone reading this, but for me, it doesn't have an escape key, and that turns out to be something that geeky me needs to use when traveling (when accessing remote unix machines). For normal people, though, this is a pretty excellent case.Pros:1. Solid keyboard, with keys that are evocative of the lovely sleek Mac keyboard keys.2. Cutouts in all the right places3. Easy enough (but not too easy) to get the iPad in and out.4. The closed case has a reasonably nice aesthetic, to my mind... my favorite of the three cases. To me, it's the best suited to the aesthetic of the iPad itself... I would really love to find a case that's Apple-like and very sleek; the iPad Air 2 itself is so lovely and any keyboard case I've seen just stomps all over that. Le sigh.5. Has nice F and J bumps to find homerow without looking.Cons:1. No escape key. When I looked at this online, I was just checking for cases that have six full rows of keys and didn't check carefully enough about particular keys. Very few users will care about this.2. Can't adjust the angle of the screen relative to the keyboard, as you can with some cases.3. This is rather awkward to fold back the keyboard and just read from the tablet. It doesn't comfortably4. I prefer a case that has velcro or something to hold the cover when you're not using the keyboard and just reading on it as a tablet.The other cases I've tried are:1. The Belkin QODE Ultimate Keyboard Case for iPad Air 2 (White)  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00QTDTT5Y  This has only four rows of keys, so I was definitely disappointed2. The Kensington KeyFolio Thin X2 Plus Backlit iPad Air 2 Bluetooth Keyboard Case (K97391US)  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ODV5YP8  The keyboard layout is similar for these two cases (including no escape key; maybe I am SOL)  The Kensington is overall a smaller case, and hard plastic, but seems to have a weak spot at the hinge between the two halves  But is really rather similar in functionality to the Kensington here.I am going to look into keyboard remapping, and contact both manufacturers, but my guess is that I don't get to have an escape key. I'll also continue to try out both keyboards, and will update this review if I learn more or my opinion changes.Update: I was just googling the escape key iPad issue and found some helpful suggestions that I will note here and try out later:1. "If you have a keyboard with the "keyboard key" the fourth from the left On the top row of keys. This functions like the escape key on other keyboards." So this might work.2. Give Ctrl and [ a try that should send the same as Esc (ASCII 27).This might mean this case works fine for me... when I'm in a position to connect to the servers, I'll try it and report back.Update 2:1. This did not work for me, as well it should not. The keyboard key is there to allow you to have the regular iPad keypad show up on the screen itself.2. Ctrl-[ did work for me3. Fn-<home> also worked for me (function key + the square button, on the upper left)I'll mention as well that I'm using the app Prompt to get to the servers, which does provide an escape button on the touch screen... but I wanted it on the keyboard.So I will keep trying out this case and might end up deciding this is my preferred case.

I've now tried three different keyboard cases for my iPad Air 2, and in most regards, this is my favorite. It's a solid case and has sleekest profile when closed. However, it doesn't have a full keyboard, which won't matter to almost anyone reading this, but for me, it doesn't have an escape key, and that turns out to be something that geeky me needs to use when traveling (when accessing remote unix machines). For normal people, though, this is a pretty excellent case.Pros:1. Solid keyboard, with keys that are evocative of the lovely sleek Mac keyboard keys.2. The most form-fitting of the three cases I've tried, which means that it adds the least bulk to the iPad.3. Cutouts in all the right places4. Easy enough (but not too easy) to get the iPad in and out.5. Reasonable enough when folding it back to just use the tablet.Cons:1. Little bumps to tell you where F and J are are barely anything, and I can't easily find them. These are essential for a touch typist.2. The outside feel of the case is disappointing. It's hard plastic, with a very nice texture, so that it's not slippery. It's actually very thoughtfully designed. But there's something about it that feels cheap to me. Others will enjoy how solid it is, so this is just my aesthetic... the lone iPad is such a lovely sleek thing and I would love to find a keyboard case that has a similar aesthetic.3. No escape key. When I looked at this online, I was just checking for cases that have six full rows of keys and didn't check carefully enough about particular keys. Very few users will care about this.4. Can't adjust the angle of the screen relative to the keyboard, as you can with some cases.5. You can predict where this is going to give out, which is the hinge between the two hard-case outer pieces. Moving this around -- folding and unfolding -- you can see that that point is taking a lot of stress and is not sturdy enough for it.6. I prefer a case that has velcro or something to hold the cover when you're not using the keyboard and just reading on it as a tablet.The other cases I've tried are:1. The Belkin QODE Ultimate Keyboard Case for iPad Air 2 (White)  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00QTDTT5Y  This has only four rows of keys, so I was definitely disappointed2. The Logitech Type+ Protective Case with Integrated Keyboard for iPad Air 2, Dark Blue (920-006913)  http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00QOOI6MK  This Logitech has a very similar keyboard layout to the Kensington here (including no escape key; maybe I am SOL)  It has a larger profile, with maybe an extra 1/4" buffer around the outside edge of the iPad  But is really rather similar in functionality to the Kensington here.  It has a textured vinyl exterior that is not as tough as the Kensington, and yet doesn't seem to have the obvious weak spot at the hinge.I am going to look into keyboard remapping, and contact both manufacturers, but my guess is that I don't get to have an escape key. I'll also continue to try out both keyboards, and will update this review if I learn more or my opinion changes.Update: I was just googling the escape key iPad issue and found some helpful suggestions that I will note here and try out later:1. "If you have a keyboard with the "keyboard key" the fourth from the left On the top row of keys. This functions like the escape key on other keyboards." So this might work.2. Give Ctrl and [ a try that should send the same as Esc (ASCII 27).This might mean this case works fine for me... when I'm in a position to connect to the servers, I'll try it and report back.Update 2:1. This did not work for me, as well it should not. The keyboard key is there to allow you to have the regular iPad keypad show up on the screen itself.2. Ctrl-[ did work for me3. Fn-<home> also worked for me (function key + the house button, on the upper left)I'll mention as well that I'm using the app Prompt to get to the servers, which does provide an escape button on the touch screen... but I wanted it on the keyboard.So I will keep trying out this case and might end up deciding this is my preferred case.Later: Yes, I am at peace with the things that were awkward before, and I am very happy with this case.

I used to always carry tiny purses, but larger phone sizes and the need for reading glasses mean that most of them are too small any more. This is a perfect size for those two essentials, plus some money, credit cards, etc.Pros:1. Accordion design -- there are three main compartments -- allow for expandability when needed (although stuffed would look weird).2. Reasonable price for what it is.3. Handy wrist strap, which is easily removable if you prefer a clutch.4. Gold chain provided, if you prefer a shoulder bag or cross-body bag. I am tall and this is plenty long for cross-body wear. Obviously at this price point, it's not a very nice chain and is sort of plastic-y5. Really nice set of pockets. There are the three main compartments. One has a side zippered pocket within it; the middle one closes with a zipper, and the third one has a single credit card slot. (The whole thing closes over the top with another zipper.)Cons:1. It's stinky, but I'm sure that will dissipate.2. The embossing makes this look cheap to me.Other:1. The listing says "genuine leather". I think it is PU leather (aka bi-cast leather). PU leather is "a leather product", but the outermost part is polyurethane. This might not be what you had in mind. I think it is as nice PU leather as I've ever seen. Not that I am a PU leather aficianado or anything.I don't like the embossed reptile design, but I love the color and the cross-body wearability, and I expect this to get a lot of use.Note: I received a free sample for an honest review, but this did not require a good review. This review is genuine.

I used to always carry tiny purses, but larger phone sizes and the need for reading glasses mean that most of them are too small any more. This is a perfect size for those two essentials, plus some money, credit cards, etc.Pros:1. Refined, sleek look2. Accordion design -- there are three main compartments -- allow for expandability when needed (although stuffed would look weird)3. Reasonable price for what it is.4.
