Not that I am a PU leather aficianado or anything.This is a nice sleek mini purse, and I'm happy to have it.Note: I received a free sample for an honest review, but this did not require a good review. This review is genuine.

I got these not because I wanted business cards (right now?), but because I wanted to use them as gift tags and the like.Avery is great about providing templates for their products, and I've always been pleased to find the templates. I found the site hard to navigate to find the business card templates I needed, but eventually figured out how to move around and sample some designs of interest.You'll need to make sure you understand your printer to do two sided printing. I was frustrated that I didn't find a template that had both sides as one document; instead I had to get paired 'page 1" and "page 2". I have a two-sided printer, so this seems a bit silly (and I guess I don't know how to use Word well enough to combine the two docs). You might want to do a test run on a regular sheet of paper to know what side is going to get printed on. For my printer (an Epson 810), a printed side one needs to be face up in the paper tray to print the next side face down.The cards don't quite separate cleanly, though you don't want them to separate too easily, of course, or they'll come apart in your printer. I imagine this is the right mix of sturdy and separable.All in all, isn't it wonderful that we can print our own cards. And these are a pretty nifty product.

I have recently found the Vega line and am impressed with their products, including this one.Previous to trying Vega products, I used greens supplements, such as GreensPlus or PaleoGreens, and I still appreciate those products for greens. The Vega products I've tried -- this and the chocolate protein and greens drink mix -- also have protein and so, they can pass for a meal, and in particular, seem to work pretty well for me for an occasional breakfast.My only big gripe is that I don't generally favor sweet drinks, and I picked the "natural" flavor, hoping they would leave out the Stevia. No such luck; it's still sweeter than I would like.Pros:1. Non-GMO, non dairy, non soy (the major source of the protein is peas), vegan2. 20g protein, 6 servings of greens, vitamins and minerals, fiber, and even probiotics3. easy to mix4. tastes fineCons:1. Too sweet for my tastes2. A wee bit gritty, but very minimal for a product like this3. Doesn't stay well suspended, and I have to keep stirring, but again, that's fine for this type of product.My cons are not necessarily yours of course, and I do think this is a wonderful product.Note for those who think this is expensive: Have a look at PaleoGreens and/or GreensPlus to get a sense of what high-quality greens supplements cost.

Unsurprisingly, this is a great little gadget. The only thing I don't like about it is that it doesn't have Amazon Prime.As you know, this fits into the same niche as Roku or Fire TV. I have a Roku and a Fire stick as points of comparison.Aside from not having Prime Movies, this is clearly the best of the bunch because of the added ability to "cast" from your laptop or phone to the TV screen. Awesome! (Because of the missing Prime, I'm still going to be using that Roku regularly.)I think it is strange that they don't include instructions in the box, but of course you can google that up. If you've owned another similar device, you won't need instructions to get started. And there is a video once you're using it that describes how to cast.

I have become the queen of over-the-door racks since moving into a house that has only one proper closet. I had five over-the-door racks in my house and one at work before getting this one to try out. (On the back of three bedroom doors, on the inside of the door of the one closet, and on the back of the kitchen door, which, following the time-honored Maine tradition, is the primary entry to the house.)The biggest problem with choosing an over-the-door rack that's going to work for you is knowing that you're buying something that will work with the thickness of your door. Standard/traditional interior doors are 1-3/8' thick, while standard/traditional exterior doors are 1-3/4" thick. For most over-the-door hooks, if you get one for a thinner door than you have, you can't get it over the door. If you get one for a wider door than you have, it doesn't work, either. (Initially surprising, but if it's not the right size, it sort of starts to fall off, and it's no longer flush across the top and you can't close the door.) This clever design will accommodate both of those widths, and of course, anything in between.(Note that at work, I have a 1-3/4" interior door, and exterior doors can be as wide as 2-1/4"... so you will still want to measure before ordering.)I don't think this would work well for doors less than 1-3/8", but it should work for doors up to 1-7/8" -- that's the spacing between the vertical plastic pieces at the top.Another thing to consider is the clearance at the top between your door and the door frame. I can't put this on the back of my front door because there's not enough clearance there, though it works fine at my kitchen door. If you have a clearance problem, you might fare better with hooks that have a metal brace across the top... That style is usually much thinner than this plastic version.Oh! it's also possible that due to the thickness of the plastic, you're not going to like the way the door closes when it hits the jamb. In other words, maybe there's enough clearance at the top, but not between the top front of the door and the inner jamb the door meets up with.This is just shy of 20.5 inches wide and it's 7.5 inches high.Another thing to consider is what you'll be hanging up. The rubber-coated hooks on these will help protect clothing.I can't think of anything else that are "gotchas" when buying these things... everything else is sort of aesthetics and obvious functionality. Do you like the way the hooks look and do you want single hooks or double hooks?I'm giving this four stars because it solves the pesky problem of variable door widths (within the stated range), but the thicker plastic on the top means that it won't work on my bathroom door, as I was hoping. (It does work fine for other doors in the house.)

For reference, my favorite bluetooth speakers are Bravens. I have tried a few of those at work (e.g., 600 and 570) and always been pleased. That's not a fair comparison to this, since it's a larger speaker. However, the HP Roar Mini still compares well.I've used this mini HP Roar for both listening to music and for participating in a conference call. and for the price and the size, it's great. There is an advantage to the smaller size, of course, that it's not going to take up much space, either on your desk or in your bag if you're travelling with it. Also, the smaller speaker has a longer battery life.Pros:1. For the current Amazon price ($44), this is a a good balance between the quality of the sound and functionality and the price.2. It's aesthetically pleasing, including especially the speaker itself, and also the back.3. You can also plug in an external device directly if you prefer.4. Relatively easy to set up and use.5. It comes with a little bag, but see the cons section.Cons:1. The instructions are very minimal, but everything works as expected. This would be more confusing to someone who hadn't used a Bluetooth speaker before, though.2. The little bag is too small. It just exactly fits around the speaker, which means a. it's hard to get the speaker in and out, b. one end of the speaker remains exposed, and c. it's hard (but possible!) to also store the charging cable in the bag. Also, the bag is a mesh. So it will help keep some things off the speaker (e.g., dust or cat hair), but not all things (e.g., grit or sand). I do kind of like that it's stretchy, though.Indifferents:1. To be clear, this is not the best sound you're going to get out of a portable speaker, but that's because it's small. I think the quality is better than one would expect at this size, thus my rating.This is a great little speaker, and would make a nice gift.

I'm giving this five stars because yes, it's the same active ingredients in the same percentages as Frontline Plus, so it is "the same thing" as claimed and available at Amazon, which is a win.I had previously thought that flea and tick meds had to be bought from the vet, so learning that these products are available at Amazon is  wonderful news to me. I tried to do some googling to learn what had changed, and found this: "EPA-registered spot-on products are in fact available as "non-restricted use" products that are commercially available through a wide variety of sellers - the EPA does not determine who can sell these non-restricted use products, and there is no "over the counter" vs. prescription classification of pesticide products. Basically, it's up to the manufacturer to determine how they want to distribute their product." (That was via AMVA dot org.) Part of the thing here is that these are not categorized as medicinal. They're categorized as pesticides.I also learned from that site that the pesticides used in "spot on" flea and tick treatments for dog are under an EPA investigation, due to reports of adverse effects in dogs. This includes the ingredients in this product (and Frontline Plus) as well as the different pesticides in Vectra 3D, which my vet had recently switched me over to. (In my reading, the adverse effects are markedly more likely for puppies and smaller dogs.)Sentry fiproguard Plus and Frontline Plus for this weight class have the following active ingredients:Fiprornil 9.80%(S)-methoprene 8.80%Vectra 3D hasDinotefuran 4.95%Pyriproxyfen 0.44%Permethrin 36.08%Vectra 3D is both a repellant and a killer, and the repellant characteristics are why it is preferred by many people. In the reading I just did, some folks use both products, on a staggered schedule (one or the other, every two weeks).My dog and I have both had Lyme disease at this point, and I am hoping not to repeat that. So, although I am concerned about the potential adverse effects of the pesticides, I am more concerned about the critters, and I think I will adopt the staggered schedule of the two different products.Anyway, for this product:Pros:1. Available online / from Amazon2. Yes, same chemicals as Frontline PlusCons:1. Horrible clamshell packaging that shouldn't be needed for an Amazon sale.

Okay, so you buy something like this because you're silly, and the color makes you happy. Guilty as charged. It's lovely glittery green, and yes, it makes me happy.But then you worry that it's all style and no substance and that doesn't seem to be the case here. It's very solid, including the jack points. And yes, it will charge your phone. My only complaint is that it smells totally weird, heavily perfume-y. I charge my phone in my kitchen and find that an especially annoying scent.Pros:1. Gorgeous.2. Sturdy.3. Charges your phone.Cons:1. Smells perfume-y or incense-y -- strongly. I've tried wiping it off with a damp rag, but no luck yet. (Ah! Windex worked better.)The sparkly color is a very happy-making thing for me, so I'm glad I got this.I will use this as my primary charging cable, and will update if something goes wrong. The main concern with something like this, of course, is that it'll look pretty but not actually work, and so far I have no complaints.p.s. This is my second one; I entered another review because the different colors are listed separately, and I noticed there were no reviews yet for this one.

I am using this rod at work, where afternoon sun is too bright for the light-duty shade that is already in the office window. (Strange to say that there's too much sun in the winter, but for me to work on the computer, it was just not good). I have very lightweight curtains up there (chambray voile from the Company Store).The stainless look is perfect for the aluminum-framed windows at work, and in general, I do like the aesthetics of this. I first tried to use a standard white tension rod, but it bowed out enough that it kept falling down. So far, so good with this one.I am concerned that even with the lightweight curtains, the rod bows a bit. Note that I'm towards the outer ends of the span this is supposed to work for, and if you've got more like a 60-inch window, it will likely work much better. Most curtain rods that cover a long span like this have a center support. I liked that this one didn't have that, but yeah, there's a reason that most long curtain rods have a center support. I might try to figure out how to rig something up.Don't be an idiot like me. I was trying to figure out how to get the curtains onto the rod, and pulled the two pieces apart at the middle. It all went back together, but that's not what's intended. Instead, the flat end pieces will screw off, a much better approach.If you care: This product is made in China.Update: six months later... this has been working great for me. No problems whatsoever. (Remember that the curtains are very lightweight, though.)

Just providing another data point here.I have been using Roku for years, and got this for the little TV in the guest room since I didn't want to spend a lot.Like the Roku, it works well in the sense that you can use the internet to stream content from places like Amazon Prime or Netflix. (I use internet services for TV and movies, and don't pay Time-Warner for TV cable service.)Things that are wrong:1. Once something is playing, mine hiccups from time to time, skipping a moment of content.2. The interface is amazingly terrible. I always think Hulu is bad, but this is even worse. Amazingly, it's especially bad with accessing Amazon content. I can't imagine what they were thinking.With the Amazon content on the Roku, I can easily navigate to my Watchlist for TVs or Movies. Here -- WTF? -- the movies and TV shows end up in the same listing.The bad user interface is a software issue, so I'm hoping that Amazon will step it up and we'll get updates and the usability of the device will increase.The hiccuping, I'm not sure; maybe it's a firmware thing that can be addressed with an update, or maybe I got a defective unit. Hard to say.

This is a great little blender, just what it should be for the price. I'm using it to make smoothies, but it's easy to see how it could tackle other small mixing jobs well.A clever thing about this design is the way that the blade fits first onto the food jar, is then inverted, and placed on the motor. While this means that you can't add things from the top as you would a normal blender, it enables walking away with your drink... or if you're using it for soups or cooking ingredients, easily schlepping things to the stove -- or to the fridge, for storage.Pros:1. Small counter footprint for small jobs.2. Clever design with the inverted jars.3. Easy to swap in standard mason jars.4. Two sets of jars included, and more available for sale if you want them.Cons:0. This is as great as I was expecting, and I don't have any.Indifferents:1. This is just a preference thing, but I find the black drink lids weird -- there's just too much plastic there in your face when you're drinking. So I just end up drinking straight out of the jar.2. Yes, it's only one speed, that's part of the price point. I think it works fine.Note:As the instructions indicate, and as is true of blenders and food processors, you need to have enough liquid in the container so that the solid ingredients can move around.I'm a fan of green smoothies, so I'm usually running vegetables through this and/or protein-powder shakes. It has been working very well for me for that sort of breakfast on the run.

This heater makes almost zero noise, but I do wish it would make a bit more, because no noisemeans low fan speed and very little heat projection.I believe the unit should have a low and high fan setting, which it does not; actually, it has no fansettings, just the low you get.I will have to back the unit up with an actual fan.Other than this major draw back, it is a good unit.
I have been putting up with a full sized heat gun for many years, and finally pulled the triggeron this smaller unit.It works great for the smaller stuff that I work on these days.
Great little unit for working on my electric guitar circuits. Better than fumbling aroundwith a gun, or a loose pencil iron.heat controls are good.They could have lost the spool cage.
Considering the money spent on this fancy down wringer, you would think it wouldremove more water from the mop than it does.It's just OK.
Best microwave popcorn out there.
cheap. does not sit flat. The sandpaper sits on a warped surface.
Beefy zips when you need to really hold something together/down.
Beefy zips when you need to really hold something together/down.
Nice small wire stripper for the price.

This is an EXTERIOR SHIELDED CABLE/WIRE, with NO CLOTH.What that means, is that you have a webbed outer jacket over a PVC inner jacket over the actual single wire you usefor hook up.It is heavy. splitting the outer shield web away from the inner PVC for tinning/attaching to wire, or terminal/lead, is a royal pain (I believe this is where the "plastic melting" comments come from).Again, this is an OUTER SHIELD wire that may come in contact with other wires, and ground them out.As far as I am concerned, the only good thing about this wire, is that it will give you almost a 100% shield; if you don't need that (and I don't know any applications that come to mind that do), you would be better served using the 22-Ga Rickenbacker Style Pre-tinned Grey Wire  from MojoTone which you buy per foot at about the same price. This is a double jacketed wire with an easy to get to shield wire between the two jackets, and has the same gauge wire in the middle. You can also get Tensility wire from Digi-Key that comes in pre-cut rolls (1 meter, 5meters, Etc.) and uses product numbers like T12**-*-ND; The asterisk's is where 22, 24, or 26 gauge, and length are defined.
Very expensive for what you get.Order bulk from MojoTone instead.
Very expensive for what you get.Order bulk from MojoTone instead.

This is as close as you can get to the old 46b, of which I have just opened the last 6 pack.Thanks to oral b's obvious departure from the old fashioned tooth brush, and putting all theirattention and efforts into the electric brush end of the business, I have finally given up in disgustwith this once on top of the heap company, and gone with the Gum 516 with better quality, and price.As other reviewers have stated, it somehow still amazes me how a viable company can just throw awaytheir business................

Got the movie for Ellen Muth, as I became a fan from watching the Dead Like Me series, and have iton DVD.Ellen is spot on the same actor in this low budget, B rated movie, which is acceptable for this part, but does makeher fall into the typecast realm. Ellen can break out of this rut, as she has shown in some of her other movies.The movie has a plot, but is very choppy, and rambles from scene to scene. It is made up of older known (I barely recognizedRobert Loggia; he is so old), and younger, not so known actors, with the exception of Ellen Muth.For some, this movie may be a stretch to get through, but as a Muth movie collector, it has a place with me.If you are not a fan of any of the actors in this movie, then you might want to give it a pass.
Great 18 ga, 7/32" (not 1/4") crown staples for the smaller guns.Best price I could find.
Great 18 ga, 7/32" (not 1/4") crown staples for the smaller guns.Best price I could find.
Great 18 ga, 7/32" (not 1/4") crown staples for the smaller guns.Best price I could find.

Good set of (not too small) droppers, even if you do have to wait a while to get themfrom China. I use mine for the animals.This dropper is very easy to clean and dry out by separating the bulb from the dropper; they comeapart easily, and go back together with no effort, with no lose of suction, or harming the bulb to droppermating groove. This is important, as these should be washed and dried out between uses to stop mold buildup.This is the best price I have found for this size product.

The hole in the stem tenon is very small, and restricts the draw.This is not good, no matter what you are smoking.I drilled out the existing stem/tenon hole using a 7/64 inch drill afterstraitening out the stem bend.Once this was done, the pipe draws as it should.The bowl is also very deep for my application, so I cut some of it off.This is a lot of modifying to get a pipe to perform as you want, butI am used to customizing items to fit my needs.

I picked up this package on sale for under $100.00, and would not pay any more for it.The big surprise here, is the brad/staple nailer (blue hawk SGY-NS8) which uses 7/32 crownstaples, not 1/4" as I have seen advertised in some circles, is very smooth, and drives to full depthwith no problem at pressures around 80 PSI for the longer nails/staples.The rest of the kit is complete, although cheap.The compressor is only two gallon, makes a lot of noise on pump up, and should be used for verylight work around the house, and not include pumping up your car or truck tire, as thiswill take forever. If you want to pump up tires, get at least a four gallon dual tank compressor like theCampbell Hausfeld HL5402, which goes for a little more than this little guy does.

I have been using these filters with my upgraded intex 1000 gal pump, for about five years in my 1500 gal. exercise iPool.While the iPool is small, after a few dust storms, and fires (I live in the desert), I was not able to get the water clear, even if I put ina new filter, so I finally had to pump out a portion of the water as I vacuumed out the bottom, Via the pump inlet to the pool.THIS IS THE ONLY METHOD THAT WORKS 100%, other than emptying the pool.I have read of other people being able to use pantyhose to filter out what the type A filter does not, but this does not make ANYsense at all, as the filter has a much finer weave than pantyhose do???? I have actually tried this method, and all I get is a largecloud of silt forming outside of the pantyhose. I have used thick white cotton athletic socks for this purpose with half way decent results, as what you get is a dirty looking sock, which is the silt.  As far as adding something like diatomaceous earth to coat the filter, this just seems like a recipe for disaster, in that your pump could be overworked due to the blockage, and stop working!These filters will last for years (not weeks or months), if cleaned out on a regular basis.  I have no experience leaving these filters forweeks without cleaning, and this my result in you having to replace them, especially if you are just to lazy to clean them out byspraying them off with a garden hose spray nozzle.

I am a hard candy nut, which I picked up from my Mom, as hard candy was all that was available when shewas a kid.The only problem with the FireBalls, is that THEY GET HOT!I find this SMALL ( 1/2 to 5/8 inch in diameter) size perfect for something that gets this hot in your mouth.Both the 3/4 and 1 inch sizes are typically too much, and I end up taking them out of my mouth for a brief respite.Your going to get 1, or 2, or 3, or 5 pounds of the candy no matter what size you order, so, I don't see the fuss overwhat size you get, other than what I have mentioned.The candy has its own special taste, and it changes throughout the experience.

Ordered 427R, which looked gold/yellow, and got skin/translucent picks???It looks like ALL Ultex picks are translucent skin, or black color, and the translucent skin picks are VERY HARD TO SEE.If I dropped the skin pick on stage, I  would NEVER be able to find it!As stated, Dunlop makes a black version of this pick, so introducing a pigment into the Ultex mix does not look like a problem.Pick is small (jazz), Very stiff, and slippery; I like it.Since this is one of  the smallest picks you can buy, it makes me wonder what Dunlop was thinking by also making it closeto impossible to see.

Ordered three, got two pick samplers.I have a very large guitar collection, so most of my guitars do not leave the studio, whichmeans I use everything from a dust gig bag, to a Fender deluxe gig bag. Hard cases have twofunctions: to gig/travel with, and to house very expensive guitars.This bag falls someplace in the middle with minimum padding, but, I feel, is probably thebest bag with padding that  you are going to get for the money.You DO GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR, so don't expect heavy padding for 19 bucks!

For a basswood body guitar, this guitar is heavy.  It is actually heavierthan my roadcore 320M, which has a mahogany body.  This makes no sense atall, accept, it makes you start to wonder if ibanez is just using whatever wood is available atthe time to make their roadcore guitars.I am not a big fan of rosewood fretboards, and this guitar backs up my trepidation of this wood, asit has an alarming tendency to shrink over time, and expose fret ends.  Again, we are assuming ibanezis using rosewood.The guitar is right on the edge of finger rash, and hopefully a couple of fret oil treatments will help.The three Core-Tone pickups and 5 way selector switch give you a large selection of sounds,and the pickups perform surprisingly well, which, in my experience of late is a positive trend ibanez is heading in.I would not pay full retail on this guitar (and did not), but as a three single pup guitar, it plays well, with no fret buzz, andis comfortable to hold.The 330T is out of production and replaced with a different color guitar (430T), but made exactly like this one.

M stands for maple on maple neck.This is an amazing guitar that is out of production; what a shame.I just picked up a factory second (flaw that you can't see), and am already in love with it.The guitar is light weight with a flawless finish.The pickups are the big surprise, as they are the best sounding STOCK pickups I haveever run across.

My first PH3-12R-03 went into operation in 2011. I had no problems with this unit until last night 07/16/15 when it started to makea shrieking sound. This was fixed with a thorough cleaning. (See Addendum for fix/cleanup.)This unit is a better heater than a cooler, but for a small room (I use it in my 190 sq.ft. bedroom) it does an OK job at a low price.I would not try to use this unit in anything over 300 sq. ft.With any portable air conditioner, you must keep the exhaust hose as short as possible, and if you can, insulate it.  You also must keep the room as air tight as possible just like your whole house conditioners,  for best results.I bought a second unit in 2012, as a back up, and tested it when it came in, and everything worked.The unit was covered up, and put away in a closet. I pulled the unit out early in 2014, and the compressor did not come on, so what I had was  fan only. I tested the run capacitor and it was OK. I got further into the unit, and found out that the Solenoid coil and 4 way valve are made by Sanhua, and the scroll compressor is made by Shanghai Highly (Hitachi), and looks like a custom unit that you can only get in China. As stated, the origin of the PH3-12R-03,  is China, so Soleus air is ONLY a reseller, and buys these wholesale from China.  This may be the reason for the terrible service, as they REALLY DON'T KNOW WHAT THEY ARE DOING, SINCE THEY DON'T MAKE THEM!  As other reviewers have stated, the help you get from Soleus air is pitiful.When you call (the only way to contact them other than mail) and if you get through, you are assigned a number, called back, and taken through a list of questions like "is the filter dirty" when you have just told them that the unit may be two years old, but is in new condition, as it has never been used, which told me that I was talking to a drone on the other end of the line.The return shipping is totally up to you, so my second (non working) unit is pretty much for parts unless I go ahead and use a piercing saddle service valve (sold by Amazon) and charge it with R410A, in hopes this brings it back to life.Between the two units,  maybe I can keep one up and running at all times.I am running a Koldfront AP12000S-1 as backup, that I picked up JUST FOR THIS REASON.The AP12000S-1 actually cools better than the PH3-12R-03.Addendum: 07/26/15I removed the panels on my working unit, and thoroughly brushed and blew out four years of grime and dust throughout the unit, but especially the coils and fins which were close to completely blocked, even though, I actually run two air register filters on the outside, in addition to the piddly slide out filters that come with the unit . The unit is actually pretty easy to clean, and this should be done at least every 2 to 3 years. Panel removal is as follows: (1) Remove 6 screws from front panel sides and tip forward.  (2) Remove 2 screws from black top cover, and then use a dead blow, or rubber mallet and tap the cover off, as it is held on via 6 plastic fingers on the underside of the cover. (3) Remove the remaining screws from the sides and back of the unit, and then take off the two sides.

I stopped buying the Club C (classic) once I found basically the same shoe (Kirkland Court Classic) in Costco for a fraction of the cost.Costco like so many other (too big for your britches) companies stopped making the $12.00-$14.00 shoes, so now I am back to theexpensive Club C's.  Reality is, that at $40.00, these shoes are close to the cheapest CLASSIC tennis shoes you can buy thesedays.I ordered a half size larger (11 instead of 10-1/2), and am glad I did, as the shoes are snug, which should go away after some use.The tread is not as aggressive as the Court Classic, but is not made up of a heal and toe section glued onto a sub sole, but a one piecesole cap that (if I remember correctly) lasts longer than the heal/toe pieces that have a tendency to come apart over time.  What the Club Cwill do, is sooner or later crack somewhere just ahead of the arch. This is probably the best CLASSIC tennis shoe you are going to find at this time.My search continues for a replacement, and will update this review if I find anything.If someone out there thinks they have a classic shoe at a better price, I would like to hear about  it.

I have always wanted a 12" compound saw, but could never justify the large amount of moneyfor something I would rarely use.The Wen 70712 fills this niche with a quality tool for the least amount of money.95% of this tool is made from aluminum and plastic which makes it very light weight.After the correct set up, the tool cuts straight, and should make any weekender or hobbyist happy.If I was a professional, I would look elsewhere for a beefier tool.The only real bummer about the whole tool, is the itty bitty dust bag you get.  I actually thought it wasa joke.  When I went to put it on, it just ripped from expanding the spring.  Also, the pull out material rodsare a little short.

Used two to replace dead batteries in a ToiletTree oral irrigator.Worked great, except I do wish Ternergy would tin their tabs, as itwas a bit of a pain to paste, and then solder, which even then took some doing.Shrink tubing was kind of useless.

The following will be a REAL review of this product, NOT "I like it" or "It works"I am cleaning (Roebic K-570), and adding to my leach field, that was installed in 1986, so the existing two leach lines have lasted 28 years.I contribute this to living in the Mohave desert, as this is unheard of in most other regions of the U.S.The Advanced Drainage Systems (ADS) Distribution box 1369AB is made from the same material as your one gallon milk jug (HDPE # 2), and is also a blow molded product, albeit, a lot thicker. The inspection/cleanout is 6" O.D. The Septic tank inlet is 5-1/4" O.D. All other side and back holes (7) are a little larger than 4" O.D.If you are not using ADS plumbing for this box, you will have to first find a product that will adhere HDPE to PVC, and that you can actually find in your area.I did tests using left over cap pieces from the 3 outlets on one side, and the back outlet (which can be easily removed with a hack saw), and pieces of 3/4" PVC irrigation line I had laying around.THE RESULTS:Clear Silicone adhesive: NOOatey Blue: NOOatey All Purpose Cement: Fair adhesion, which works fine for slip fits.Liquid Nails: YES. (I used this product as a fillet sealer on the outside (tube to box) to add flex strength,  plus auto rubber undercoating as a final sealer, as I did nut trust the Liquid nails in this environment without some  type of a sealer coating over it).If transitioning from the HDPE box to PVC septic lines (which most of us would do) I would recommend using 5" long cutoffs of your 4" tubes to adhere to the box outlets first, and then use straight, and 45 deg. couplers to get to your actual perforated leach lines.You will have to chamfer, and hog out the mating I.D. surface on your 4" cut offs a bit to fit over the slightly larger than 4" O.D. outlets on the box.I would also recommend using the Fernco P1002-44 rubber coupler to attach your septic 4" PVC outlet line, to the distribution box inlet, as the 5-1/4" O.D. is an oddball size. This also lets you slide the 4" line into the box first, and then back onto your line coming out of the septic tank which you can then glue in place.You will have to do a lot of prep work if using this box, and the reason I chose it, was because it had three outlets on one side, which is what I needed to add two more lines to my existing leach field.The box is a bit flimsy, but does have a good pan down to collect solids which is where a lot of (so-called) leach field failures happen; at the distribution box, not the leach lines. The box outlets will also flex 10 to 20 degrees, which makes line assy a bit easier.

I just rebuilt the rear end section on this scooter for a neighbor who took it out, and told methat the rear axle had broken in the first 30 minuets of use.Being a retired Electro/Mechanical Engineer with a full repair and fabrication shop, many of theneighbors bring me their broken stuff.  For instance, in the last week, I have made this gent polycarbonate (Lexan)spacers for the trucks on one of his skateboards, fixed this cheap scooter, and added 12 inches to the down tube,on his latest scooter where the handle bars were to low.This scooter has some serious engineering problems, that I call the trifecta of bad engineering design.The foot board is made of an aluminum half H section that continues back to fork around the rear wheel and holdthe axle bolt with thin wall spacer tubes, which hold the wheel in place.What went wrong on this specific scooter, was that the forks flexed to much, which made the wheel try to go sideways, whichover stressed the thin wall spacers, and then finally broke the fancy axle bolt at the bottom of the tap for the fancy allen screw.Again, the initial cause of the axle bolt failure was the foot board fork being too long, and in turn allowing flex which set up thewhole domino effect (trifecta).I am sure there are far better scooters available for this price.

Good price on 10.Replacing, due to broken plastic fluted knobs on old units.This type of knob uses a plastic knob with pressed in threaded stud.They will last until something breaks the knob, which is why getting10 is a good thing.The "Won't crack, become brittle or discolor" statement does not hold water in the desert,as ALL plastics lose their plasticizers at an accelerated rate in a hot dry climate.

Up front, I have a lot of Ibanez guitars, and love most of them.A beautiful, great feeling guitar that may require extensive set up.The one I received required Saddle, Pickup, and Truss rod adjustments,and a string set replacement, even though the strings looked to be new D'aDarroio 9'sThis may be too much set up for a novice.I have supported a youngster for over three years with guitar lessons, and equipment, and he stillcan't set up his own guitars, even though he can play very well.This guitar looks better in person, than the pictures you see.  It is a string through fixed bridge plate/saddle design.The double allen saddles (typical) are a pain to adjust; even more so than most.The nut is cut correctly, and the tuners are just barely adequate, as a couple are jerky.The pickups are nothing to write home about, and just OK.The neck is fast, and the body is sleek, and is a joy to hold, and the fret ends are what you want, with NO finger rashat all.I have actually upgraded from three to four stars on this guitar, as the longer I own it, and dial it in,the more I am appreciating it. I have picked up a second one, just to swap out pickups to the SH2/SH4 combo.

I have used Carpenters glue for at least 40+ years, and it has NEVER failed me.What does fail, is the actual wood that is adjacent to the bond.I have used the product for both interior and exterior applications with the same resultsof NEVER debonding. I owned a small sign shop for 5 years, and we did a lot of sandblasted,and routed wood exterior signs where every one of them was glue lamned, and then planed, routed,or sandblasted, and I NEVER had a failure. Over time, in some cases, the actual wood would shrink andstart pulling apart, but even this could be repaired with Carpenters glue by gluing into the split, and clamping.Of late, I have been using Carpenters glue to repair guitars (Head to Neck, split Sound Boards, Etc.) with no problemsat all.  Water based Carpenters glue by its nature lets the glue permeate into the wood for not only a great substrate tosubstrate bond, but better holding power by actually creating an anchor into the wood. All the new epoxy based glues can'tdo this; I have tried them all, as especially with guitars, everyone tries to talk you into the latest fancy glue on the market, or goway back in time and use Hide glue.I did buy a small amount of the Carpenters Max glue, just to try it out, but ordered another gallon of my favorite.

Great tool for scratching all materials, and center punching softer metals,plastic, wood, Etc. If center punching hard metal, then I would recommenda real metal center punch.

Great price for 10 fluted knobs.Had to replace three out of four that broke the plastic knob part offon my Eagle Auto lift.As far as the plastic not getting brittle in the future; it would be the first pieceof plastic I have EVER seen to not lose some of its plasticisers after a few yearsin the desert.
Better made Combo Square, than the one I had, which is a no name brand.Much easier to read the scale.Slides and locks easily.What more can I say other than a good price for a good tool.

Had to bring in a smaller bass amp for my bedroom, and switch out from my Ampeg BA112 (50 watt version), soI compared them even though this is kind of like comparing apples and oranges, but it was there, so what the hey.I was actually looking around for a smaller cab 1x12 to replace the larger BA112, but there is no such thing  The orange, and Kustomare a bit smaller than the BA112, but not enough. This is due to a bass amp (more than guitar amp) needing a larger cab for lower frequency resonance created by the speaker, so in most cases, you have to match the speaker size with the cab: Small Speaker=Small Cab,Large Speaker=large Cab.The Rumble 15 (I also have a Rumble 100, 1x15 Combo) sounds much better than I had anticipated, considering my other two bass amps are a 1x12, and a 1x15.  The BA112 is much louder, and can handle the E without breakup which the 15 cannot. With this one exception aside, the 15 has excellent sound (at about half the volume), and you will have to adjust from the larger amps by turning up the guitar, and amp volume morethan you are used to.For the price, and small footprint, this is a great choice for the bedroom (apartment, Etc.) where room, and volume is limited.For those that (unrealistically) expect a big sound out of this 8 inch speaker amp; GET REAL!

A great clamp for the price.I ordered two of these to add to the two I already had.These are the largest spring clamps I use. They are very powerful, and will do a goodjob of a gluement (my word) assembly, or hold a piece of wood on a table for cutting whenyou would have to go for the C clamps.

I have many types and sizes of spring clamps, but these are the size I use the most.  ( 6" long, and hold 2" stock)I ordered another four pack to add to some of the same size, but when they came in I noticedthey are made from thinner sheet than my existing clamps, and do not have a good flat areaon the clamp side, but just come to a point which is not as useful.An OK clamp, but you can get a much better clamp (2" heavy duty spring clamp) for less money at anothersource, from which I have just ordered 6 more.

Very beefy bar clamps; in some cases, too beefy.The Jorgensen Heavy-Duty bar clamps are somewhere between the Light to Medium (like Bessey and Pro-Gurad) clamps, anda Pony clamp.For some cabinet/wood glue up work, they may be too heavy and cumbersome for the task at hand.I would use these for larger structural glue up work, or for wood with a thickness of 1/2 inch, or more.Reality is that you use what you have available, but if  you are working with thin materials, and have a choice, go with Jorgensen, orBessey, or Pro-Gurard regular/light duty clamps and save some money and the hassle of dealing with the sheer weight of these clamp assemblies.

16, 24, and 36 grit discs can be hard to find, as most people do not use this aggressive a sanding disc.I use ALL of the grits mentioned for removing wood, metal, and bondo on projects around the shop.The discs cut better than aluminum oxide.A word to the wise on storage; put them all together face to back, and thenclamp them all together with three spring clamps, and they wont warp out on you.

16, 24, and 36 grit discs can be hard to find, as most people do not use this aggressive a sanding disc.I use ALL of the grits mentioned for removing wood, metal, and bondo on projects around the shop.Nothing unusual about discs, but a word to the wise on storage; put them all together face to back, and thenclamp them all together with three spring clamps, and they wont warp out on you.

I was looking for a 1/2 inch combo tongue and groove bit set that would cut something thicker than the standard 3/4 inchstock on the tongue side, and the Freud bit set does this, and more.I am not a professional, but needed this set up, and a Grizzly router bit spindle for my Grizzly 3HP shaper to take ona whole house shaker cabinet project.I must have been one of the lucky ones, because the packaging,  as received was some of the best I have ever seen; the twobits are housed in their own plastic case, snug as a bug...........
Much smaller than expected (Delta bag much larger), but will do in a pinch.

It took me a while to figure out I was watching the old school (1960's) flavor of Godzilla, and I think he was fightinga modern version of Mothra.Once this clicked in, I started to enjoy the movie a bit more, even though it was hard to get away from the thought thatHeisenberg had gone to Godzilla heaven, just to die all over again.An OK B rater to watch.

As stated in the title, you will probably have to make a special table for this belt sander, as it sits much to high onyour typical 32" leg length high table. (Unless you are 7.5 feet tall). The leg length you will end up with will be from 17" to 20" which is around what a chair seat is.  You will also have to Lazy Susan it if the table is against a wall, as you need to rotate the unit to get to the front, the side, and the back when the belt is down so that the belt is moving away from you, instead of coming at you. This is easily done with a round piece of ply with a center bolt going through the ply, and table, and then running four Round Head Carriage Bolts up from four holes in the Lazy Susan ply, which then attach via nuts to the unit. I bought this unit to remove LOTS of material, so the 100 grit belt that comes with the unit came off in short order for my favorite 80 grit belts. I have not (and may never) use the disc sander, so can't comment on that, other than saying I would rather not have it. The unit is LARGE, and a bit heavy, but not as heavy as a table top planner.As stated by other reviewers, the dust collection sucks, and also does not blow, but kind off puffs a little. The black plastic tube needs to be all the way in, as it is just sitting loose in the unit; this is probably the worst part of the sander.You may have to shim the work table mounts to get the table to actually sit correctly.When installing a new belt, you may get a bit of belt slap (ticking), but this will go away when the belt is on the unit for a day.This is a great unit for a hobbyist, and OK for light professional use, but understand, that this is a heavy weight unit, and not something thatcan comfortably be hauled around.When you add in shipping cost from other retailers, this is by far the best price you are going to get on this unit.

As the title says; save your money and get a Fender Mustang III V.2 (100 watt), or better yet, the Fender Mustang II V.2, or better yet, the Fender Champion 40 (40 watt).While the Orange does have an OK sounding dirty channel, where gain control volume can be turned way down, that's about where it ends.The amp is close to 45 Lbs., which is VERY HEAVY for a 1x12 solid state amp., and is wider than it has to be.The controls are located at the top/back of the unit which is hard to get to if pushed up close to a wall for practice.The Clean Channel offers NOTHING, and is as milk toast as it can get, which means the speaker is just OK.I have a lot of new amps from Mesa, Fender (most of my amps), Roland, Marshall, Line 6, Vox, Etc., Etc., and this amp kinda fallsinto a boutique-ish one jump chump category that makes it above average for overdrive applications, and close to useless for everything else.I actually get much, much better overdrive, and clean out of my Champion 40, and Mesa V-twin Pre-Amp pedal.

Loved the movie, but it left a bad (director (Besson), and so called visual effects) after taste.The first BIG downer, was when Lucy was repeatedly kicked in the stomach by a drug czars henchmen, when they knew the very expensive drugs where inside her belly; REALLY?  The next blunder was on the part of the so-called visual effects people (there were a few of them to blame), when they used the old roll the room effect that is so old and lame, that nobody uses it anymore. REALLY?I found the effects (or the lack of) the most offensive part of the movie, especially the growing black computer fingers; REALLY?Not a bad movie with a 40mil budget/88 min running time, and I am sure Scarlett and Morgan got a large share of it, as it was not well spent on the production.Compare this with the 2012 The Avengers, at 220mil/143 min running time, and you can see it was a low budget film from the start, and for that reason, they actually did a pretty good job.
Checked with Symantec (very helpful), and Product Key never used (good).Now I'm all set up for 2016Thanks GamerSwop

Worked when Cable Matters 10 pack DID NOT.I have tried MANY 1/8" Stereo to RCA adapters, and have ALWAYS been disappointed withtheir performance; or the lack there of.Sometimes you just have to shell out the bucks to get a part that will ACTUALLY work, and thisis that part.You can get it for a little over $6.00, but that is the best price I have found.As a side note, I have found, that split wire (6", or 8") adapters do usually work if you just don't havethe money for this adapter.As another side note, there seems to be some confusion about what is stereo, and what is mono.That double black ring on the male jack (NO MATTER WHAT SIZE) means STEREO.If on the other side of that jack, there are two Female plugs (or whatever), that means that the signal has been split into two mono lines, which when hooked up to two speakers gives you the definition of what STEREO is (2). If the jack only has one black ring (or none) and you split this mono signal, you will only get mono (1) out the other end, no matter how many speakers you hook up to it. It's pretty simple really, Mono (1), Stereo (2).

This is the same guy that did "A Beautiful Mind", and "Gladiator", ARE YOU KIDDING ME.This movie was one big yawn, as even Crowe could not carry the weak, and sometimes fantasy riddenstory line.Sometimes, even being thrown a boat full of money is no reason to do a bad movie.

I find AVG VERY cumbersome to load, as you ACTUALLY have to go to their web page and get REAL OFFICIAL product number, after you enter the NOT SO REAL product number on the envelope holding the disc.ARE YOU F...ing KIDDING ME!!!!!!!!!!!And then you get to go through a bunch of stupid rider applications, and make some kind of educated guess as to whether you want them junking up your computer, and then it wants to archive everything; yeah, let's junk up the computer even more than it already is, SHALL WE!  IT GOES ON AND ON.I'm sorry, but I'll take Norton Antivirus any day over this laborious bloated piece of software.

While I do sympathize with all those Fender fanatics out there, trying to pushthe Squier to the Epiphone level.The bridge pickup was DOA, and I only revived it after shooting a good amount of Deoxit D5 into the toggle switch, which is the normal first (go too) place if a pup does not work, as it is VERY unusual for a new pup to not work if hooked up right, as there are NO MOVING PARTS except for magnetic fields.Don't get me wrong, I agree that Squier is an up and coming guitar manufacturer that is makinggreat inroads into the under $300.00 guitar market, and it would have really pissed me off (if I didn't know anything about guitars, like a lot of the Squier market) and had to return this guitar, as the fit, and over all feel, is just great, even though work had to be done beyond the dead bridge pickup thing, like getting the strings down, and then adjusting the saddles to stop a couple of fret buzz areas. The guitar is also VERY HEAVY for a Basswood Squire and comes in at 8.25 Lbs.I purchased three Bullet HH's recently, because they impressed me so much, and this Jaguar is a better guitar than the bullets which seem to have fret buzz problems that require fixing.They no longer make these guitars, which is when I normally swoop in and get the close out deals.The guitar, with it's fixed bridge fits my style of playing which tends to the blues/jazz/rock.I read a review where someone was saying that there was no intonation adjustment on this guitar; so what is that screw on every saddle????

These work, while their 10 pack adapters DO NOT!I have used both types (splitter cables, and adapters) over many years, andhave had nothing but problems with the cheap adapters, while these split cableswork just  about every time.

Have only tried a couple of these batteries, but am very disappointed with them so far.Since I have never used them before, I tried them out on the simplest thing I could, two clocks,and they both lost time, no matter how many times I rotated the battery (in case of bad connections).I then installed new (regular) Duracells, and no problems.I will only use these on pen flashlights from now on, as even at a lower voltage, you can get some use outof them, but this is the last time I try to cheap out on AA's!

JUNK! DO NOT WORK.I bought this ten pack, along with a two pack of 8 inch adapters from the same supplier, and same manufacturer.The 8 inch work, these do not.My application is from a laptop to powered speakers.Amazon promptly sent me a return label and credited my account.Addendum: Ordered three Planet Waves PW-PO47C adapters, and they ALL WORK!The only problem with the Planet Wave parts, is that you get one instead of 10 for theprice, but if the ten don't work, what good are they, other than another irritation to dealwith.

Flat steel skewers with pointed tips that can be used for a number of things, fromkabobs, to holding parts in place on rotisseries.These skewers are made of thick stainless metal, and are substantial, so should holdup to anything you throw at them.

I ordered the XLI am exactly 6 foot tall, and weigh 185 pounds. The full length robe fits as shown in picture.The sleeves are full length, but do not go beyond the hands, and the robe stops at the ankles.The robe girth is expansive, so if you are of medium (correct) height to weight, you willhave to wrap/overlap the robe a little more to get a tight fit.The robe is made about as well as any terry robe I have worn over the past 60+ years.This robe is meant for cold weather; hence the full length.  Normally, I wear a 3/4 Terry robe, and in summer,a 3/4 cotton robe.As stated in my headline, what I appreciate the most about this robe, is the full collar that you can flip up to coverup all of your neck, the back of your head, and some of your ears.JUST WHAT YOU WANT ON A VERY COLD MORNING.

Amart is selling a system builder (or to the rest of the world) OEM disc that is considered illegal to sell to the public for existing computers. As the term system builder and OEM imply, these discs are to be used only on new computers.This disc is not identified for 1, or 100 users/computers, so it is with great trepidation that I started this new mystery software journey.I thought I was getting the boxed version as shown, which Amazon should take down, but, this will never happen. You can get the boxed version at an equal price if you just take some time to search it out.With this said, I have loaded the software on three of my four computers, and everything went smoothly. When trying to load it on the fourth, it DID hiccup and would not let me.There seems to be a lot of confusion about just what year of Norton Antivirus to buy;IT DOES NOT MAKE ANY DIFFERENCE. ALL YEARS WILL WORK, AS LONG AS YOU HAVE A NEW PRODUCTKEY NUMBER!

THIS EBOOK HAS THREE MAJOR PROBLEMS:First:  The music and tab notations cannot be enlarged, and are very hard to see.Second:  The included MP3 files are HTTP MP3 addresses, not MP3 files which means you have to be online to hear the music samples; this may or may not be true of the Kindle readers, I don't know.Third:  When you click on the HTTP MP3 file you also get the VERY IRRITATING "New Oxford American Dictionary" window; REALLY!When you order a printed music book, you usually get readable music and tab notation, and a music disc.A printed book would have it all over this ebook.Lynne does a great job of explaining the basics of bass guitars chord patterns/progressions with play along HTTP MP3 tracks. Using the Kindle PC App., I can actually hold the bass guitar and follow the book using my remote mouse which makes more sense than fumbling around with a reader that has to be held close to see, and screen touched to move it along.Bass is not my main instruments, which are guitar and keyboards, but bassic basslines is a good starting point.This is my first try at a Kindle file on any device.  The one I am using, is the one that does not cost me anymore money than the ACTUAL e-book (Bassic Basslines) which is by using the Amazon Kindle for PC App. on my computers at home.The Kindle for PC executable file can be copied over to each computer (or loaded from the Amazon site, or other searched sites),  and once you register each computer, your purchased e-book and a few free ones will be available to read.I believe the computer monitor has it over an i-pad, or Kindle reader because of monitor size (obvious) and speed of execution.One of the most important reasons I was staying away from the e-books, was because my eyes are not what they used to be.  This degradation of site is due to age, and (you guessed it) using computers almost my whole life. For people like me, this PC or MAC App. may be the answer, BUT UNTIL AMAZON GETS THEIR KINDLE E-BOOKS ACT TOGETHER, I WOULD STAY FAR, FAR AWAY FROM A MUSIC BOOK VERSION.THIS IS THE FIRST, AND LAST EBOOK I ORDER.

I ordered two of these;; one for me, and another for a friend.After using the unit twice for 4.5 Lb whole chickens, I am not impressed, as theyboth had burned skin. The first bird was brined for a day with salt, spices, and brown sugar.The second just had a short, light salt brine, and then spices sprinkled on the skin.This could be just the way the unit works, as I have had very little experience with rotisserie ovens.The over all design looks solid, with the exception of the heat shield that roughly slides in between the insideback of the unit, and the heating elements. This looks to be a badly executed after thought, and is the only clumsy partof the design.I will keep at it, but don't see how the burned skin is going to go away.

Far superior to the opaque light grey, or black hoses.This clear hose has outlasted every grey, or black hose I haveused over the past 4 years. Two grey, and two black have gonein the garbage in this period.

I replaced an iPool pump (that is a total piece of junk) with this pump, and just  today replaced the lastiPool hose (that is a piece of junk) with the intex clear hose that holds up for a very long time.I have not had ANY problems with this pump, and have been running it for around 12 hours, every other day.I did get an extra because of the bad reviews, but (again) have not had any problems with this pump.

I have been using the 750 for a couple of years now, and the only complaint I have is the flute alignment thatrelies on a couple of spring loaded pieces of sheet metal that are supposed to magically align to the smallest part of the drill.This is a critical part of the drill bit set up, and as far as I am concerned, Darex has dropped the ball on this function.As such, this function takes longer than it should, and if you don't get it right, the rest of the set up is for not.If everything is done correctly, you get a good grind, and a like new drill bit.

Ordered the WD blue along with a StarTech non-eSATA duplicator.My 320GB Toshiba hard drive was starting to die on me (normal via a lot of reviews) on my Acer Aspire 5750Z  (Z for cheap).The whole operation went great, with no problems, and I now have a new HD with my original operating system on it.

The 320GB Toshiba hard drive on my Acer Aspire 5750Z started to slow down to a snails pace, so got a 500GB WD blue and used the StarTech (non-eSATA) unit to clone over to the new drive.When I first started the operation, the 100% went on right away (that would never happen), so reinserted the two HD's, turned it on, and pressed the clone button for a longer period, and everything worked great, and the operating system was transferred in aboutan hour. Installed the new WD, and the computer acts brand new again, plus I have a lot more storage now.If you, and run more than one computer, I would highly recommend getting one of these units.Just an added note: If your old hard drive is good enough to be cloned, then save it as an emergency back up that you can use if you mess up the new hard drive (which I did). Just redo the same procedure, as the process will wipe the destination drive before the write process starts.Also, if duping to a larger HD, you will have to allocate the leftover "unallocated space" via your windows Disk Mgr.See:http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/how-to-use-unallocated-drive-space-in-windows.html

I have over 150 guitars in my collection, and have returned a couple of mid level Fenders that just did not do it for me.FIRST THINGS FIRST. Leave the guitar alone! If you want to replace the tuners, get the same trapezoid tuner, or go to: http://amateurluthiery.wordpress.com/2011/09/05/replacing-the-tuners-on-a-squier%C2%AE-by-fender%C2%AE-bullet-strat%C2%AE/ and make up your mind.What is important on a nut, is NOT what it is made from, but the string to string dimensions, the height (rise and fall), and the proper groove cuts. Bone IS NOT THE BIG ANSWER TO ALL YOUR GUITARS ILLS, and may just add to them, as bone is NOT consistent, and is hard and soft throughout (plastic is consistent). The pickups DO NOT NEED REPLACING, and deliver great punch, sustain, and string response.I bought this low end (I thought) fender just to see what all the hubbub was about.The rationale: If I didn't like it, I could always change out the neck and put a new loaded pickguard on it.For a little over $100.00, this thing just rocks! I just picked up two more on sale at under $100.00 each, so now have 4, plus misc. necks and bodies.The most important thing to me, is that it is made in Indonesia; why you ask, because Indonesia has been producing the best offshore guitars for the last 6 or 7 years, and in my humble opinion blows Korea out of the water on low end guitars.First off, the tuners don't blow as bad as you are led to believe; this may change after a while, but as new tuners, they are just fine.The neck is straight and unfinished which makes it fast. The medium frets are right on the edge of giving you some finger rash, so a little light sanding may be in order.The strings are cheap (Duh!)After installing the (included) extra tremolo spring (I always use 4, this way I don't have to block it), I gave the truss rod a half turn down, lowered the saddles, and corrected the pup angles (closer to high e, further from low E), and voila, other than the stock strings, and frets needing a little dressing, the guitar played just as well, or better than at least half of my mid range $400.00 to $600.00 guitars.The black hardware is great; I get so tired of looking at chrome.....................Pickups sound like they are mid range (6-8K), and come across with good punch and sustain.The shining star on this rig, is the VERY lightweight basswood body. While it may be more dent prone, I don't usually go around banging my guitars into hard objects, and if I did, at $100.00 to $120.00, who cares!!!

I have had my iPool for 4 years now.I am going on 70 but am still in very good shape, but have just goneon low dose BP medication so have cut way back on the salt and startedcardio routines which (duh!) includes an exercise pool.I was an Olympics hopeful in my teens and trained every day at theSan Diego Town and Country Club (At that time, the only one in Mission Valley) asit was the only Olympic sized pool available to me except for NAS (now Marine air station)on Kearny Mesa.Never made it due to finances; as so many American athletes succumb to, butdid swim for the Marine Corps.Full size lap pools and pump pools are insanely expensive, or take up to muchroom, and I have other things to do with the money I live on.The pool took me about 6 hours to set up at a medium pace and doing other thingsin between. (You know us old folks; we wonder off once and a while)Putting the side rail pieces in was a bit of a challenge, as you need to pay attentionto exactly what side you want the harness on, ladder on, and pump on (which by the wayiPool calls a filter).While we are on the filter subject, iPool recommends replacing the Filter which is thewhole frigging unit once a year and says you should only run it for 4 to 6 hours a day.I have had my iPool for a few months now and agree with the other reviewers aboutthe pump; IT IS A JOKE!Don't even think about using this piece of junk, as it does not move any water.Along with your iPool, go ahead and buy an Intex 637R (56637EG) filter pump from Amazonat around $40.00 which hooks right up to the iPool 1-1/4" fittings. Use the supplied strainerand water inlet nozzle and just shove them in the holes where the iPool supplied dome strainerswould go.Also, the resistance cord does not last that long (rubber tube). I replaced the set up with fine strand nylon ropes, instead of spending $30.00 plus shipping for something that will go bad after two years.The ladder has been upgraded from the standard iPool which has a problem with the inside bottom rung not being cushioned.Once your in the pool, it is a great workout, and fulfills all of my requirements which saysit should take care of just about any one out there.I agree with a comment from another reviewer that the tie points should be set at the end unlessyou are trying to literally hold up a non swimmer or small child and then you move them up.3 feet or 2-3/4 feet is more than enough to swim in, so don't get excited about water depth.The cover is cheap, but works very well, even with the ladder and harness rig in place, but if youlive in a hot climate like I do (Mohave Valley AZ) you need to leave the cover off, or make sure you have a layer of water on top of the cover so that evaporative cooling of the water can take place. If you leave the cover on without this layer of water on top of it, the small pool will get very hot and feel like a bath. To winterize, I take off the overhead tubes, and use a 10'X 12' heavy duty canvas tarp with grommets that is very well tied down (does not touch water) so that the high winds that come in winter do not rip the cover apart, as would happen with the standard plastic cover. Also, a heavy duty canvas tarp will cost you about the same as the plastic iPool cover.

I ordered one of these for my niece, who is just getting started with guitar, and was so impressed withit that I just ordered a second for me. Once I checked it out, I realized, that this was the most concisetab book I had come across.  It covers basic guitar holding, tuning, tabs.  Right and left hand techniques,with no chord redundancy. Also advanced, and putting it all together sections, and a track CD.This book is probably the first one you want to get for your beginner.

I should have done more research (see the title) on this CD.To tell you the truth, I did not recognize one song on this CD from the movie.I was actually looking for just one rhythmic tune that I wanted to play lead guitar to; no suchluck! It is probably just part of the score.The CD songs are:  1 Need to Be Next to You - Leigh Nash  2 Central Reservation (The Then Again Version) - Beth Orton  3 Here With Me - Dido  4 Divided - Tara MacLean  5 Silence - Delerium  6 I'm No Ordinary Girl - Anika Parks  7 Lose Your Way - Sophie B. Hawkins  8 My Baby And Me - Nick Garrisi  9 Rome Wasn't Built In A Day - Morcheeba  10  Hush - Angie Aparo  11  Our Affair (Remix) - Carly Simon  12  Love (Remix) - Sixpence None The Richer  13  The Only Thing That's Real - Sister Seven  14  Never Gonna Come Back Down - BTWill pass CD on to someone that wants it more than me.

Gatorade in general is a real life saver where I live, in Mohave County AZ.  It gets REAL HOT, and lately,REAL HUMID from June through Sept. Real humid to me is 60-80%, because the temperature is around120 deg F. I just recently worked outside in this muck for a couple of days, and payed for it, as I was lethargic,my muscles ached, and, well things were not as firm in the morning as they should be.I forgot to take my regular Gatorade thirst quencher, and continually hydrate during the day.This is a good product to replace electrolytes (potassium), but does not give you any lift, as that is notits specific purpose, I actually get better results from the regular thirst quencher when taken correctly.As a product to bring you up to a correct electrolyte level when the body has been starved, I would say, use it.If you hydrate yourself properly and use something like the thirst quencher (which you can get at any local store), I would recommend not spending the extra time and money on this product.

I use both the 32GB and 8GB flash drives on my two computers running windows xp, and one running 7.These flash drives come with security and text files that I never want to use, so I do a quickformat, and then a full format of the flash drives to clean them out. (I also use Lexar 2GB sticks)I don't get all excited about speed, so the drives work just fine with no problems.This is a good flash drive for minimal cost.

I also have a review of the PN15 sunburst, which is the one I normally play.I ordered the atn guitar for my collection, as it looks like this (antique natural) is going away, or is onlymade for the overseas market. I do not have this (eatn) guitar, but with no reviews, this is better than nothing.This, or the sunburst are great parlor sized guitars, and I have not found a better pricedparlor of this quality.The guitar is made very well, and sounds much better than some of my higher priced parlors, andworlds apart from a 3/4.The Musicians Gear acoustic gig bag is a good choice for this guitar.PLEASE NOTE: Both the atn and eatn are mainly sold in the UK, Canada, or Australia, so don't believe anybody(including so-called USA Ibanez reps) when someone tells you that there is no such thing as an eatn, or atn.

Amazon had the best price on the Epi Jumbo case, but the packing was non existent, as the case wasjust thrown in a box, so it ended up with one dime size ding on an edge.  I guess I am lucky it was notworse. This is the standard build Epi hard case, and I have over 20 to attest to this fact.  The case holdsa new EJ200CE I got, and it fits like a glove.  Checked gig bags, and they were actually more expensive than this hardcase.

To start off, before anyone gets their feelings hurt, I am an Ibanez guitar lover, and have over 20 of them.As delivered from Zzounds, the guitar was a complete disaster.The best part of what was delivered, was the guitar case which is a semi-hard case consistingof nylon fabric cover (like a gig bag) with molded and covered, hard foam interior sections.The fret job is the worst I have ever seen on a new guitar; the frets are clipped, with no dress at all.After tuning the guitar and taking that first strum, I wanted to throw up, as it sounded like a badly madeshoebox guitar.Next, I went through the frets which were pitted, and discovered that two of them were loose and high which caused the high e and Bto go dead from the seventh to ninth frets.Because I have over 120 guitars in my collection, I have to work on a lot of my own guitars, and posses the tools andability to do most work including fret, bridge, neck replacement, Etc. Etc., pressing the two frets down and redressing themis no big deal, other than time. I have found the best way to check for high frets (not seated properly) is to use a short metalrod,  1/2" to 3/4" Dia., and about 3" long. You want the rod to sit on 3 to 4 frets at a time. By holding down the rod hard on the frets,and then pressing on one side and another (rocking), and moving it from fret set to fret set, you will be able to discern a slight rocking when a fret  is high.So, bad frets found, pressed and dressed back into place.  Fret edges block filed at the proper angle, filed, sanded, and crowned.Oh, by the way, the fret radius is 9.5 inches.When removing the strings, the nut popped off, and one of the bridge pins broke off, so replaced all the pins, and put a little white glue on the nut and cleaned up the grooves, as they were full of plastic filings from cutting the grooves. I later replaced this deeply cut nut for one that ACTUALLY worked.Replaced the 11-52 strings with new Martin 11-52's, and will probably go with 12's after I am happy with the set up.Tightened the tuning pegs down, as they were flopping around, and treated the fretboard.The guitar sounds great now, but the frets edges will need more work (normal), as I continue to play the guitar.I must admit, that I bought two guitars the same week, and the other was a flawless Epiphone EJ-200CE with NO PROBLEMS!Up front, this did spoil me a bit.To get this guitar right, you would have dumped $200.00-$400.00 at your local guitar shop for a $165.00 guitar.Methinks this makes no sense.......................

Projector: YES.  Monitor: NOT SO MUCH.I bought the Ipevo due to a review I read saying it was a good way to enlarge text tomake reading easier; NOT! I may use it's other functions later, and I may buy a digital projectorfor it, but at this time it is pretty much useless for my current purpose.This is mainly a document reader/camera to be used with a projector, or via your computer and the software included with the package; other reviews go over these functions in depth.If used just for enlarging via monitors, it does not enlarge an 8.5 x 11 inch page enough to make it useful, unless you are using something like a 30" to 50" TV screen/monitor, which is the same thing as projecting the image.

THE EXACT GUITAR DIMENSIONS ARE: 43" Long. Upper Bout: 12-9/16" Wide.  Waist: 10-3/8 Wide.  Lower Bout: 17" Wide. Upper Bout Thickness: 4-3/16". Lower Bout Thickness: 4-3/4". Body Length (including neck heal): 21-1/2"This may be the ONLY place you are able to get this EXACT dimensions, as EVERY Web sight has a different flavor.The guitar, is flat out gorgeous!I am a guitar collector and hobby player with over 100 guitars in my collection.I have stayed away from jumbos in the past, because I am mainly an electric guitar player, and thelargest acoustic I am comfortable with is the Ibanez PN15 Parlor.I wanted a bigger sound as close to the high priced Gibson SJ200/J200 as I could get, and I think this guitardoes just that.  The guitar is made in Indonesia, which I personally like about it, rather than China made.  There is anongoing battle between which is best, but I have had better luck with Indonesia, and that is all I can speak of.The finish is flawless, with no finger rash.  The stock strings are great, with no need to change them out. The action is low, withno fret buzz, and no need for any truss adjustment. I think I lucked out with the set up on this one.I just ordered the Epi hard case from Amazon for this guitar, as their price just blew away everyone else by at least $20.00.I have not tried out the electrics on the guitar, and did not buy the guitar for this function, so look elsewhere for this.Due to my trepidation about the guitar size, I was very pleased that being a jumbo, the guitar felt playable, and reach around wascomplete, without wanting to play in front of a mirror to see where my fingers were placed. I have one guitar (made in Canada...ahemmm) that is 5" deep, and I just can't play it.This is a VERY well made guitar, with a full rich (not muddy like the Canada guitar) sound, and worth at least twice the asking price.

I am not much of a hat person (mainly because they make my hair flat), so I will not be wearing this in public often, but this makes an awesome selfie prop! I don't really like how it looks the traditional way, but to the side or turned around, it is really cute (of course, this is a matter of preference). The colors are bright and stand out against the black background and give it a cute spring look. The stitching is very well done and it's put together sturdily. The bill will bend slightly so you can shape it how you want it (and the logo on the bill is just a removable sticker). Unless you have a really small or really large head, it should fit just fine; there are 7 snaps and you can adjust it so it will fit you. It actually seems a little big on me because it comes down a little past my ears if I push it all the way down, so the fit isn't perfect, but I never wear other hats so I don't know if this is a common problem or if it's just the size/shape of my head or the hat. Overall, it's very good quality and super cute.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

I really wanted to love this necklace, but the chain ruined it for me. First of all, my chain came with no hook closure. There is no way for me to wear the necklace with this chain unless I want to tie it in a knot or something. Secondly, the chain is a lot shorter than I expected. It describes the necklace as a "long necklace," so I expected it to be like a sweater necklace length, coming down to mid-chest. It actually hangs more like a pendant - not that I can wear it with this chain anyway since there is no closure. The chain itself seems decently sturdy and didn't break when I tugged on it, but I'll be disposing of it and buying a new and longer chain.The skull itself is gorgeous, detailed, and intricate. It is not as big as they make it seem in the picture unless that person just has REALLY small hands. I am a 5"3, 19 year old girl, so my hands are pretty small as it is, and the skull is still much smaller than pictured. I will add a picture of the necklace in my hand so you can get an idea of the size. This is not a bad thing, however, at least in my opinion. It's big enough that you can see the detail without being so big that it's distracting. It'll be a great piece to wear on Halloween and Day of the Dead (it looks quite a lot like a sugar skull). The skull definitely makes a gorgeous necklace, but the chain needs a lot of improvement, so be prepared to buy your own chain with this piece.I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

I gave these as a gift to my little brother and they were a big hit. You get six boxes, three jujubes and three jujyfruits, all in a pretty black gift box. The jujyfruits are my favorite (I actually stole a box back from him they were so good). They're what you would expect from a gummy candy: chewy, fruity, and addicting. The jujubes are also fruity, but they're a lot more chewy than the jujyfruits. I wasn't really very fond of them because of how gummy they were - they stuck to my teeth pretty badly - but they were my brother's favorite. They taste good, just are very chewy. I have never heard of either of these before, but apparently they were one of my mom's favorites when she was younger, so she was very surprised to see I had some and has already ordered some for herself. This makes a great gift set!I received this product at a discount in exchange for an honest review.

I already have tons of different kinds of cellulite creams, so I gave this to a friend to test it out. She's been using it for just at two weeks now and is actually seeing results. Her problem areas are thighs and upper arms, so she's been focusing on that. The smell is pleasant and not overbearing, and it goes on smooth without leaving a greasy or sticky residue that lots of creams do. She's been using it 2-3 times a day. It is very moisturizing, and while it's not a miracle cream, she has been seeing some results (even I can tell the difference). The areas of her thighs she's been using it on are a lot smoother than before. The difference isn't quite as noticeable in her arms, but there's still some skin tightening. There is still cellulite there and we both doubt that it will go away completely, but she's very happy with how well it's working so far and asked me where I got it so she could buy some more when she runs out of this. I have several other art naturals products and I'm impressed with the quality every time.I received this product at a discount in exchange for an honest review.

This works okay, but it's a bit of a hassle to use and it's definitely NOT painless. The coil works by trapping the tiny hairs in between the coils and ripping them out, which is effective but, again, not painless. It's also a bit of a hassle to use. It's a nice tool to have, but I probably won't be using it often. The razor, however, is painless and much easier to use than the coil. It comes with a cover you can keep over the end to protect the blade and protect you from cutting anything with the blade. It's not very sharp, but it is sharp enough to trim facial hair. I have peach fuzz on my upper lip, and the only reason you can see it is because it's shiny and blonde and catches the light. I don't want to actually shave it off because I don't want it to grow back darker, so this razor is perfect for me because it trims it to where it's not noticeable but doesn't actually shave it all the way down.
