But that isn't really too surprising after reading her own published writings.While I would have liked a more extensive biography, this is a well written book and wholly suitable to its target age group. It is well worth anyone of any age learning more about this extraordinary woman.

Although long interested in Native American history and culture, until I ran across this book I had never heard of Zitkala-Sa (Red Bird). That was clearly my loss. She turns out to have been an extraordinary woman, and one worth becoming acquainted with.This collection of works has three sections. The first are her reminiscences of her time on the Yankton Reservation, and then her time in a boarding school where they tried to take the Indian out of her. In her case the results yielded a very complex figure. Being unusually intelligent, western learning and music appealed to her. But she also retained a profound resentment for the way whites had treated the Native peoples. This part is very well written, and is both compelling and informative.The next section has some of her writings in defense of Indians and demanding that the country honor the treaties it had signed with the native nations. These works are far more formal in style, and of more historical than literary interest.The final section contains translations of stories she heard from elders when she was a child. Most are about Iktomi, their culture's trickster, and contain moral lessons relating to his failures to attain what he wants by subterfuge. The stories vary in quality, but that is to be expected from such collected stories; the translations all seem well done.This is a short, inexpensive book that provides a great introduction to an extraordinary woman. Read it!I was provided a copy for review by the publisher.

Ian Tattersall has been at the forefront of the understanding of human origins for decades, as well as being a prominent writer in the field, and this is his opportunity to look back, from the twilight of his career, at the development of the field.While this book covers the history of the field it is, by the author's intent and admission, a personal view, not a not an attempt to be comprehensive or balanced. Tattersall spends a lot of his narrative on misinterpretations, closed mindedness, dead ends, quirks of personality, feuds, and the like. This helps to elucidate the rocky path paleoanthropology has followed to get us to our current, and still disputed, understanding of our ancestry. He provides a good discussion of what molecular and DNA testing have told us, and also why it has sometimes met opposition from cladists when molecules have seemed to tell a different story than bones, or at least how one person or another has evaluated bones.This is a short and easy to read book that contains a lot of information, history, and authorial insight. I highly recommend it to anyone interested the question of where we came from.

Montero's recording of the Rach 2 is good, although I found the piano recording slightly too bright, but is up against a wide range of top recordings. You can get Rachmaniov's own, amazing, recording, in admittedly very dated sound. Then there is the wonderful recording by Earl Wild. Most every great pianist has recorded it, often very well. This one's no slouch, but not the best, either.The primary interest is the selection of her own pieces, three improvisations and a work for piano and orchestra. The improvisations are pleasant, but you enjoy improvisation for its novelty, not for repeated hearing. "Ex Patria", unfortunately, isn't a compelling work. It has some nice segments, but the whole is really not that interesting.

This is a very compact charger that takes up little room when I pack for a trip, but lets me charge two devices at the same time. I liked it enough to buy a second one for home use. Being small, if you push it it will get hot. There is always some waste heat when you convert high voltage AC to low voltage DC, and the smaller the converter the hotter it will run.

I'm not sure what there is to say about Sharpies. They do mark on nearly anything. These are chisel point, so you can make a wide mark or a more controlled one. You won't have the control you'd get with a small point, but it's a good compromise for every day marking.Having several colors allows the option of color coding it you are so inclined. From an artsy standpoint I'm not sure this set offers an inspired palette, but you do have a choice ...
My plants were starting to show a little bug-nibbling, so I used this on them. Three weeks later and the nibbling continues to be under control. So it appears to work!

I saw this advertised by Amazon at a good price, and figured a second remote wasn't a bad thing to have. It's shaped a little differently than the Canon, and comes in a simple, small pouch. But it's completely functional. What's not to like?
